column2: CHICAGO, Ill., April 30.--Bridget Morgan, a kitchen girl in a hotel here, while cutting some bananas from a huge bunch last evening, was severely stung in the right thumb by a tarantula, which was concealed in the fruit.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 30.--George Cowles, a farmer of Wethersfield, last night discovered a tramp in his barn lighting a match. He ordered the tramp out, but the follow seized a pitchfork and drove Mr. Cowles from the barn,...
The workmen of Corby, Duncan Co., piano forte manufacturers, were ordered on strike last Wednesday by the Grand Lodge of United Pianomakers.
Emanuel De Freitas, the last recruit of the bridge-jumping cranks, was bailed yesterday by Patrick Huran, of 249 East Broadway, and will ornament a Bowery museum.

LONDON, Apirl 30.--The press view at the Grosvenor Gallery yesterday revealed a tidy little show, beginning very strong and tapering off in the back rooms to characteristic weakness. Holman Hunt's two promised pictures have not yet been hung and a big work by John R. Reid that was looked for is also absent.

The ferry houses of the New-York and South Brooklyn Ferry Company have been completed and were thrown open to the public yesterday. The South Brooklyn, the boat which has been built expressly for the line, took a party of guests down the Bay in honor of the occasion.

Twelve-year-old David Peck came to his home at 294 South Fifth-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, from school Friday noon, and after crying and refusing to eat any lunch bade his mother good-bye and started back for school.
There is a fortune in store for the man who will invent a substitute for the rubber shoe. The wearing thereof is one of the hardships of our long Winters and rainy Springs.

ROME, April 17.--I am not going to remark that the production of a new opora by Verdi is the musical event of the year. Anybody can say that, and in fact 84 Italian newspapers by actual count have already said it. Besides, it is not true.
Mayor Hewitt will take at least to the end of the current week before making any appointments in place of those Commissioners whose terms of office expire to-day.

MILWAUKEE, Apirl 30.--The will of Alexander Mitchell, the millionaire banker, was made public to-day. No approximation of the value of the estate is made, and the terms of the will will prevent the filing of an inventory, so that the exact wealth left...

RICHMOND, Va., April 30.--The influential leaders of both political parties and the leading society people here are vving with each other in showing attentions to Sir Edward Thornton, who is here as the Commissioner of the foreign holders of Virginia bonds.
The bids for the $584,000 registered bonds of Kings County, issued under resolution of the Board of Supervisors on April 14, were opened yesterday by County Treasurer Adams.

There has not been a great deal stirring in yachting circles during the past week, though a seasonable amount of activity has been shown among the builders in the way of fitting out boats for the season which will soon open.

The Catholic Herald, in commenting upon the position taken by the Archbishop in reference to that paper in its issue of to-day, states that he has strictly construed, and in fact strained his power in the matter, denying the right or privilege to criticise any one of his official acts. It continues:

Easter begins with a midnight service, but on the evening before samples of the principal dishes to be used on the following day are brought into the church or placed on the outside steps in order that they may share the blessing. Among these truncated pyramids of curds and colored eggs are conspicuous.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 30.--The local union of iron molders has rebelled against the authority of the national union and has determined to resume work on Monday next at the old rates and to accept the St. Louis patterns or any other that may be offered. President Fitzpatrick, of the national union, has filed to control his men in Cincinnati.

The stove manufacturers held a meeting yesterday. They are determined, they said, to show a firm front to what they consider the unjust demands of the men. They believe, however, that the trouble is practically over for the present, and that all the men will soon be at work again.

The inhabitants of the "Devil's Kitchen, as the tenement district at West Thirty-secondstreet and Tenth-avenue is called, looked down from their windows and porches and housetops yesterday afternoon when the cornerstone of the new Berachah Mission building was laid at 463 West Thirty-second-street.

It certainly seems to me, from consideration of the various matters referred to, that our modern ones are decided physically stronger and capable of greater exertion, and also that, independently of that, they are able to obtain more result from their exertions...
WATERTOWN, N.Y., April 30.--George B. Rose, a prominent citizen of Ogdensburg, committed suicide this morning by blowing his brains out with a shotgun.
PITTSBURG, Penn., April 30.--Intelligence is received here of a tragedy which occurred this morning at Roseburg, a station 10 miles west of this city on the Fort Wayne Road.

ERIE, Penn., April 30.--The victims of the Nickel Plate disaster at Silver Creek who failed to get settlements with the company for their injuries are hurrying matters now because of the sale of the road announced for the near future. J.P. Harrington, of the Erie Steam Forge Company, who was frightfully maimed, sued to-day for $60,000 damages.
Samuel F. Perry, a well dressed man, about 45 years old, who is wanted for having last Winter swindled the proprietor of the Rossmore Hotel out of a board bill, has been arrested.

The third largest school district in this city is the Ninth. It is bounded by Fourteenth and Houston streets, Sixth-avenue and the North River. There are seven schools for 10,000 children and one house is forced to accommodate about 3,000 boys and girls.

"Jim, the Penman," and "The Taming of the Shrew" both reached the end of their long runs last night. Mr. Palmer's company present Sir Charles Young's play in Boston at the Park Theatre to-morrow evening, while Mr. Daly's comedians begin their Summer tour at the Chestnut-Street Opera House, Philadelphia.

J.P. Harrington, of the Erie Steam Forge Company, who was frightfully maimed, sued to-day for $60,000 damages.
Samuel F. Perry, a well dressed man, about 45 years old, who is wanted for having last Winter swindled the proprietor of the Rossmore Hotel out of a board bill, has been arrested.
KINGSTON, N.Y., April 30.--This morning at about 6 o'clock the phenomena of a snowstorm, a fully developed rainbow, and brilliant sunshine were seen at one and the same time by people in this city.

There is every reason to believe that less Belle Bartow, a talented lady who was visiting relatives in Astoria, Long Island, committed suicide by jumping into the East River at Hell Gate yesterday morning.

LONDON, Apirl 30.--the Italian Government denies the reports received at Cairo from Massowah to the effect that a battle had been fought between a large body of Abyssinians and a force of Italians which was advancing on Keren.

HELENA, Montana, April 30.--Gov. Leslie today issued a proclamation forbidding the importation of cattle from the States of Illinois, New York, New-Jersey, Pennsylvania, Maryland, Delaware, Virginia, Texas, Vermont, and the District of Columbia, except upon a certificate from the Territorial Veterinary Surgeon that such cattle have been quarantined for 90 days and are free from disease.
The case of Mr. and Mrs. SCHMIDT, of Newark, as reported in THE TIMES a day or two ago, is singular enough to deserve attention. She was a loving wife, and insured her life for her husband's benefit.
Mud scow No. 1, of the F.P. Eastman Dredging Company, left the dock at the foot of West Fifty-ninth-street at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon in tow of the tug Arrow, for the dumping ground.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 30.--The extra day's races to-day were largely attended. The track was fair.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Apirl 30.--Eight hundred persons were in attendance at the annual sale of thoroughbred colts and fillies, the get of Enquirer, imported Great Tom, Bramble, Luke Blackburn, Vanderbilt, and Plenipo, at Belle Meade Stud Farm, six miles west of this city, today.

Some curious statistics have come to light at the last census in Germany, which was taken about a year ago. According to these there were at the end of 1885 no less than 72 male and 160 female centenarians in Germany.

About 100 of those gentlemen who supply the metropolis with sealskin sacques and the various furs so dear to the ladies, met last night at the Hoffman House for the first time since they have been collectively known as the Manufacturing Furriers' Association of New-York.

One of the most notable events in the social history of Montclair, N.J., was the marriage, on Thursday evening, of Miss Adele, daughter of Mr. Julius H. Pratt, to Mr. Charles H. Johnson, Jr. son of another prominent resident of that place doing business in this city.

The Haytians are an intensely vain people, and the thing they most pride themselves on is their army. Nothing will convince them that as a military power they are not vastly superior to any nation, either in the Old or New World.

BOSTON, April 30.--The stockholders of the Fitchburg Railroad turned out in large numbers today to vote on the agreement for consolidation with the Troy and Boston. Polls were opened about noon and will be kept open until 11:30 A.M. on Monday.

Last Sunday week, as Mrs. James A. Ward, accompanied by her little daughter and two other ladies and a dog, were taking a walk through the woods on Mr. Ward's ranch, on Dry Creek, Mendocino County, they had a little adventure that they will long remember.

At the Electric Club banquet on Thursday night's veral electric stories came out. They were all true. If they had not been electric men would not have told them, as a matter of course. One of them was about a horse--a Massachusetts horse.

At a meeting of a well known charity organization of this city recentrly several clergyman delivered addresses in which they urged that it was unwise to bestow charity on persons whose antecedents were not known.

WASHINGTON, April 30.--There has been some fault-finding criticism of the President here because he chose to write a letter to Secretary Lamar in regard to the Guilford Miller case, the burden of the complaint being that the way of announcing the policy of the Administration was extraordinary and uncalled for.

The military marriage in France is a serious affair. It is said that 15 years of peace have developed a craving after the bonheur conjugal among young officers, but the ridiculous obstacles and formalities surrounding the ceremony are a formidable barrier to any officer wishing to marry.

TRENTON, N.J., May 1.--The Court of Pardons held a brief session yesterday. The case of Disque, the Hoboken wife murderer, sentenced to be hanged next month, was laid over until the coming Wednesday. There are numerous petitions before the court praying for the commutation of sentence to imprisonment for life.

BOSTON, May 1.--In the New Era Hall tonight Mr. Edward Atkinson delivered an address before the Central Labor Lyceum, in which he compressed more solid, though unpalatable, truth than has been given to laboring men from any platform in a long time.

MACHIAS, Me., May 1.--Heavy freshets prevail here, and owners of mills and other river property are apprehensive of loss. The heaviest freshets for years are now being experienced in St. Croix. Bridges and crossings have been swept away and some dams and booms started. The sawing season is set back three weeks.

PARIS, May 1.--M. Schnaebeles has returned to his home. The Temps and many other journals deprecate the idea of the public subscribing to present him with a diamond cross. Premier Goblet has given M. Sehnaebles a long holiday.

Ridgewood Park was opened for the season yesterday with a grand May festival. The Plattdeutsche Volksfest Verein of Brooklyn attended in a body. Beer, merriment, and music flowed in about equal proportions.

BOSTON, May 1.--The spar plan of Gen. Paine's steel sloop is perfected, and the sparmakers are now getting out the sticks. The mast, a beautiful stick of Oregon pine, measures 86 feet from heel to masthead and 62 feet 3 inches from deck to hounds.
ROME, May 1.--Advices from Massowah say that Gen. Saletta, the Italian commander there, has proclaimed a land and sea blockade.
No definite information has yet been received by Mr. Douglas Taylor in regard to the cabman who drove over Mr. Taylor's son at Madisonavenue and Forty-second-street on Wednesday last.
Services were held in the chapel of the new West Harlem Methodist Episcopal Church, Seventh-avenue and One Hundred and Twentyninth-street, yesterday for the first time.

Extensive alterations have been begunin the building on Catharine-street, occupied by the NewYork Port Society. At present the renovation is in progress on the lowerfloors, which are devoted to the use of the many classes under the society's charge.

WASHINGTON, May 1.--The case Of Deputy Surveyor Wyatt, now in the hands of Secretary Fairchild for determination, comes to him from both Collector Magone and Surveyer Beattie, and the Collector and Surveyor both recommend his removal.

About a quarter of a million of people, of whom, according to a careful estimate made by the fat policeman who keeps children from falling into the hippopotamus's tank, at least 50,000 were infants in arms, visited Central Park yesterday.
Mr. Henry E. Abbey will sail for Europe on the steamer Eider, May 14. Mme. Patti will sail the same day on the Umbria.

The Very--Rev. Patrick Anthony Ludden, Vicar-General of the Albany Diocese, was yesterday consecrated Bishop of the newly created see of Syracuse in Central New-York. The ceremony occurred in the Franciscan Church at Syracuse.

For the first time in the history of the Masonic Temple the full funeral service of the Ancient and Accepted Scottish rite was held under its roof last night, when the members of the rite met to pay their last tribute to the memory of Simon W. Laureys.

CHICAGO, May 1.--The branch Post Office in West Madison-street was entered by burglars some time Saturday night and a determined effort was made to rob the safe. A drill, which was started is near the combination, broke off, and the burglars gave up that part of the job.

The peach growers of lower Delaware and lower Maryland have been somewhat anxious about their prospects for peaches this season because of two very severe frosts which fell upon them at the time when the bloom is supposed to be most susceptible to injury from that cause.
A meeting in aid of the work of the American Church Building Fund Commission was held last evening at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, on Fifth-avenue.
Miss Sarah Peckham was engaged by the Board of Education, of Glen Cove, to teach in the public school at $15 per week. Her contract was for a year.
PATERSON, N.J., May 1.--Dr. John H. Banta, who lives on Broadway, opposite Churchstreet, was shot and slightly wounded this evening by his brother-in-law, John Dunning, a lad of 18.

A new naphtha spring burst a few days ago near Baku, hurling sand and stones weighing 20 pounds high into the air. After the first violence of the eruption the oil was for several hours shot into the air to a height of 150 feet in a continuously-maintained jet. All the reservoirs were quickly filled. The overflow is now emptying itself into the Caspian.

Herr Krupp, of Essen, is at present manufacturing a gun weighing close upon 139 tons. Its length is to be 52 feet and its calibre 15.7 inches.

WASHINGTON, May 1.--Baron Tavera, the new Minister from Austria, has submitted to an interview of some length with a representative of the Post, in the course of which he touches upon the Keiley affair, the war agitation in Europe, the Bulgarian situation, and Austria's apprehension about it, and the probability of war between France and Germany.
The holders of first mortgage bonds of the Central Iowa Railway have been asked to meet at Room No. 27. Sears Building, Boston, May 10, to agree upon some plan for the protection of their interest.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., May 1.--Samuel S. Broadbent was accidently killed last evening at Dump Rock, near Nonquitt, Buzzard's Bay, by the discharge of his gun, the entire charge entering near and below the right eye and penetrating the brain.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1.--The Philadelphia Times to-morrow will say that James N. Taggart, who for several years has been Paying Teller of the Union Trust Company, at 611 and 613 Chestnut-street, has absconded, and an examination of the books of the company shows a deficit of something less than $100,000.

Brooklyn's cricket season will begin on Saturday with the first match between the Manhattan and New-York Clubs, in Prospect Park. The Manhattan Club has arranged a match with the St. George Club for May 16, in addition to the 36 matches already made.
Barrooms to the right, barrooms to the left, barrooms in front, and barrooms behind deserted and closed.
David Peck, the 12-year-old boy who has been missing from his home, 294 South Fifthstreet, Brooklyn, since last Friday noon, returned home yesterday afternoon. He was in a deplorable condition.

Fencing bouts and sabre practice were carried on with much vim yesterday afternoon at the hall of the New-York Turnverein, 66 East Fourth-street. There were over 50 fencers present, representing the New-York, Bloomingdale, Harlem, and Newark Fencing Clubs.

Michael Walter, an intemperate bricklayer, went to bed at 318 East Eighth-street at 6:30 o'clock last evening. Shortly after his wife, hearing a pistol shot, went to his room, and found him dead, with a bullet in his left breast. He was 55 years old, and was married 33 years ago. His wife and daughter had for a long time, owing to his habits, contributed largely to the maintenance of the household.
In the Summer of 1818 a man drove through the streets of Portland with a novel load that excited much wonder.

The result of the Lockwood McClintock suit against E.B. BARTLETT and Health Officer SMITH makes the latter's continuance in office a gross public scandal.

The entertainment given at the UnionSquare Theatre last night by members of the New-York press as a testimonial benefit to Mr. E.C. (Zeke) Chamberlin, the veteran doorkeeper, was a financial success of very agreeable proportions.
CHICAGO, May 1.--There were so many theatrical attractions in Chicago during the week just ended that none of the big playhouses did more than a fairly good business.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 1.--A car porter of the Buffalo, New-York and Philadelphia Railroad, while at work in the Louisiana-street yards about 10 o'clock yesterday morning, found a bomb, which is supposed to be a dynamite bomb.

The cutter Medusa, while coasting along the Long Island shore of the Sound yesterday morning, ran ashore at the mouth of the harbor, near Port Jefferson. The cutter is not damaged, but cannot modore Robert Centre, her owner, was on board when the grounded.

LONDON, May 1.--Mr. William O'Brien, editor of United Ireland, and Mr. Kilbride, one of the tenants evicted from the Lansdowne estates, sailed from Queenstown for NewYork to-day on the steamer Umbria.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 1.--A dispatch was received this morning from New-York announcing the sudden death there on Saturday evening of Bishop Binney. The bells of the various Episcopal churches were tolled, and the news quickly spread through the city.

The American Temperance Union did not gathar many people to its meeting at Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon, but those who did come made up in enthusiasm and Spring bonnets for what they lacked in numbers.
Chickering Hall held even a larger crowd last night to hear Dr. McGlynn than it held that night last Fall when he spoke in the George campaign. The people were of all classes.

MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga., May 1.--Mrs. Day, the sister of Mr. A.J. Kent, a well-to-do farmer of Baldwin County, will be lodged in the lunatic asylum here next week. The cause of her lunacy is peculiar.

The Central Labor Union held its usual meeting yesterday, and among the first business done was to appoint a committee to wait on Benjamin Wood and ask him why he allowed an editor of the German edition of the Daily News to edit the boss bakers' journal which is trying to disrupt the journeymen bakers' union.

Coney Island takes a long time to recover from the effects of a Summer's dissipation, and when a large number of people yesterday visited the popular watering place to pay their respects to the ocean, the elephant, and the Frankfort sausages, they found little waiting to receive them.

Representative of 76 German singing societies met yesterday at Arion Hall to organize and fight for a new construction of the amusement law. They voted to call themselves "The United Singers of the State of New-York."

From present indications the season of baseball which has now opened will surpass in popular interest all preceding ones. In the two leading professional associations the clubs are as evenly matched as could be reasonably hoped, and the League is especially fortunate in this respect.

BALTIMORE, May 1.--The story published in a New-York paper to the effect that Cardinal Gibbons has been summoned home to call a convention of Archbishops to consider the question of the Knights of Labor is denied here.

ALBANY, May 1.--The Assembly contains an unusually large number of gentlemen who are ambitious to some back to Albany next year as Senators. Mr. Ives is desirous of succeeding senator Plunkitt, though he would accept the nomination of Civil Justice in the goat district.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 1.--The Edmeston National Bank of Edmeston, Otsego County, will open its doors for business to-morrow morning.
PHILADELPHIA, May 1.--General Master Workman Powderly has decided, at the earnest solicitation of his physician and intimate friends, to take a rest from the active work of his position for a month.

A buggy, shorn of its right fore wheel, lying at the side of Jerome-avenue, on the west side of Macomb's Dam Bridge, at 8 O'clock last night, was all that was left of the great procession of vehicles which crossed the bridge and were driven over the avenue from noon until dark.

SPOKANE FALLS, Washington, April 30.--Two sharp shocks of earthquake were felt here at 4 o'clock this morning. The vibrations were from north to south. Many of the citizens were awakened. There was only a moment's interim between the shocks.

A sensation which has produced the utmost excitement throughout such parts of Queens County as the news has reached came to light yesterday in the announcement that District Attorney Thomas F. McGowan, of Winfield, Long Island, was a defaulter to the extent of between $19,000 and $20,000, and that he had left for parts unknown, probably Canada.

LONDON, May 1.--There was a limited demand for discount during the past week at 1 for three months and for short. Business on the Stock Exchange was inactive; the tendency was good, but there was an entire absenco of speculation and investment by the public.

The members of the New-York Athletic Club who visited their clubhouse yesterday to escape the general dryness and heat had plenty of interesting points to talk about. Incidentally they got a glimpse of a big package, well wrapped in stout brown paper and containing a lot of neat cases.

The Hon. John Jay has written a letter to Dr. Strong, Secretary of the Evangelical Alliance, in which a novel and forcible argument is made against the appropriation of public school moneys for sectarian institutions. The letter is here printed:

CHICAGO, May 2.--President Albert Keep, of the Chicago and Northwestern Railway, said to-day that his determination to retire from the Presidency of the road was final and would not be reconsidered.

CHICAGO, Ill., May 2.--The visible supply of grain on April 30 was at follows: Wheat, 47,318,000 bushels; decrease, 1,364,000 bushels; corn, 18,651,000 bushels; decrease, 566,000 bushels; oats, 3,932,000 bushels; decrease; 476,000 bushels; rye, 329,000 bushels; decrease, 27,000 bushels; barley 474,000 bushels; decrease, 93,000 bushels.

CINCINNATI, May 2.--This morning an unknown man jumped off the suspension Bridge with suicidal intent and was drowned. This afternoon Steve Brodie, who has jumped from the Brooklyn Bridge, made the jump from the suspension Bridge and was pinked up by a yawl comparatively uninjured.

Among the quaint novelties introduced this week at Ye Olde London Streets is a May pole dance by lads and lasses. The happy scene is pictured by the dancers with a good deal of fidelity to old forms, and it is made very enjoyable to the spectators.

Mr. Clinton Stuart's well made adaptation of Pailleron's "Le Monde ou l'on s'ennuie" was reproduced last night at the MadisonSquare Theatre. The occasion was one of great pleasure to a large and brilliant audience, which received every point of the play with an abundance of laughter and applause.
The Mets will play their first home championship game of the season this afternoon at Staten Island.

Mme. Janauschek's strong portrayal of Meg Merrilies was applauded by a numerous audience at the Windsor last night.

CHICAGO, May 2.--Willie, the five-year-old son of W.H. Kaitenbach, of Oak Park, while playing on the street, March 22, was bitten on the chin by a vicious cur. No attention was paid to the wound, which appeared to be a slight one, and nothing serious was apprehended.
The office of Assistant Master of the Ceremonies has become vacant by the death of Mr. Savile. It is in the gift of the Queen, and is worth about 300 a year.

"Tom" Gould, who a few days ago returned from a Canadian exile to face the charges against him of violating the excise and the assessment laws, was being looked for last night by two Deputy Sheriffs on an order of arrest for contempt of court.
The steamship Aurania, of the Cunard Line, which arrived yesterday morning from Liverpool, stopped near the Southwest Spit, while on her way up the Lower Bay.

A suit for $250,000 damages has been brought by ex-Gov. Leon Abbott for St. Alphonsus's Roman Catholic Church, of the Redemptorist Fathers, on South Fifth-avenue, against the Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company. An application will also be made for an injunction restraining the road from running past the doors of the church.

The Citizens' League of Brooklyn, which 12 months ago was organized in the interests of good municipal government, without respect to national partisan politics, held its first annual dinner at the Academy of Music, in Brooklyn, last evening.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May. 2.--There is considerable excitement at Holyoke over the refusal of the Mayor to sign the liquor licenses and the resulting cessation of liquor selling.

CHICAGO, May 2.--An explosion of molten iron in a retort occurred about midnight to-night at the North Chicago Rolling Mills, at South Chicago. Nine men were injured and it is thought that most of them will die. They are John Burns, James Garner, Patrick Dolan, James Carney Daniel Shea, Philip Mortimer, Michael McConnell, Patrick McConnell, and James Block. Some were skilled workmen, and others laborers.

The trunk lines moved forward all along the line yesterday, and last night their representatives were confident that the commission fight would soon be ended in their favor.

PRINCETON, May 2.--At the preliminary contest the following were chosen to represent Clio Hall in the Lynde prize debate next June: J.W. Queen, Jr., Francis H. White, S. Dodd, G.L. Robinson, alternate. This debate has always been one of the most interesting features of the exercises during Commencement Week, and the ability of the above speakers and of those chosen from Whig Hall promises a brilliant and spirited public contest.

What is described as a romantic-comic opera, called "Prinz Waldmeister," was produced for the first time at the Thalia Theatre last evening under the personal direction of Mr. Adolf Neuendorff, the composer of the music, and of Mr. Heinrich Italiener, the librettist.

The will of Homer Morgan was filed yesterday for probate. It is dated April 27, 1883, and was witnessed by Frank L. Clark and Robert L. Griffith.
CHICAGO, May 2.--All but one of the big shops of the Chicago Forge and Bolt Company, on Fort-third-street, were burned to-night.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 2.--Mrs. Herman Lyons was murdered on her ranch, near Napa, on Feb. 17, by a farm hand, Peter Olsen, who escaped, and for whose capture a large reward is outstanding. A report reached here Saturday that Olsen had been killed while resisting arrest near Bakersfield, Cal. An investigation made yesterday showed, however, that the wrong man had been killed, the victim being M.H. Siebert, a farmer who lately settled near Bakersfield.

Peter Smith, who is under sentence to be hanged on Friday, is, according to the reports of the prison officials, resigned to his fate. Yesterday he made confession to Father Duranquet and received the sacrament.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla, May 2.--In the Legislature to-day the vote for United States Senator was as follows; Perry, 21; Bloxham, 21; Pasco, 16; Finley, 2; Goodrich, 11.

WASHINGTON, May 2.--The President this after noon appointed William H. Barclay to be Pension Agent at Pittsburg, Penn., and the following named Postmasters: Henry Gaillard at St. Augustine, Fla., vice M.R. Cooper, resigned; Edward D. Home, Bessemer, Mich., vice F.F. Jeffers, office become Presidential.

LONDON, May 2.--In the House of Commons to-night Mr. Healy moved that the first clause of the Crimes bill be so amended as to indicate clearly to what portions of Ireland the bill would be applicable. He suggested that the words "proclaimed districts" be omitted, and that "Kerry, Londonderry, and Belfast" be inserted in their stead.

Patrick Flood, a sailor, who arrived in New York about three weeks ago on the steamer Alumbaugh, from Rio Janeiro, attempted suicide in City Hall Park about 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, May 2.--Four thousand spectators witnessed the first game between the Washingtons and New-Yorks to-day, filling all the seats and spreading along the fences.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 2.--One of the persons who have just been convicted of plotting against the Czar is a student named Oulianoff, the son of a high Russian official.

ELMIRA, May 2.--The remains of Dr. C. E. Sayles, who stabbed himself to death near his late home, Valley City, Dakota, are on their way to this city for burial. Mr. Sayles was born in this city and resided here, where he had a lucrative practice, till six years ago, when he went West to engage in stock raising.

The Brooklyn investigation committee's endeavors to find Skeele, the promoter of the unfortunate Williamsburg District Telegraph Company, have proved futile, and, when it adjourned yesterday afternoon, with every prospect of no further meetings for the purpose of taking testimony, it looked as if its forthcoming report on Brooklyn corruption would lack that person's testimony.
Most people who know anything about the doings of the theatrical world are familiar with the connubial vicissitudes of Mr. Edward Solomon's career. Mr. Solomon is distinctively a marrying man.
Policeman John O'Brien, of Capt. Gunner's command, ushered two young men into the Yorkville Court yesterday morning.

OTTAWA, May 2.--A brief discussion on the fisheries question took place in the House of Commons to-night, arising out of Mr. Ellis, a New-Brunswick member, asking for the return of all United States vessels boarded, warned, or interdicted by the Canadian fisheries protection fleet.

ALBANY, May 2.--Ex-Senator George Raines, of Rochester, has been selected by the Howe committee, having in charge the Tilden memorial services, to deliver the oration, and has accepted the invitation. The services will be held not later than the 19th inst.
SANTIAGO DE CUBA, April 23.--Private advices just to hand report business very dull in Hayti and gradually getting worse. Exchange there on the 17th inst. was up to 40 per cent.

PITTSBURG, May 2.--The main steam pipe on the towboat J.C. Fisher exploded a few minutes before 4 o'clock this morning with terrific force, shattering the vessel, killing one man instantly, and fatally injuring two more.
BALTIMORE, May 2.--Both branches of the City Council to-day passed a resolution congratulating Mr. A.S. Abell, publisher of the Sun, on the approaching semi-centennial of his continuous management.

Stanley, was a citizen of Illinois and claimed to be the Assignee of certain shareholders ...

NYACK, May 2.--In the Oyer and Terminer Court at New City to-day, the breach of promise case of Miss Maggie O'Hara, of Mount Moor, against Roger Harty, a dry goods merchant of New-York, was tried. The suit was for $10,000 damages, and the jury after being out a quarter of an hour brought in a verdict for the plaintiff for $2,500. The defendant says he will apply to-morrow for a new trial.

BALTIMORE, May 2.--The Trustees of Johns Hopkins University have been notified of the gift by Mrs. Adam T. Bruce, of New-York, of $10,000 to be used to establish a fellowship of biology. The gift is made as a memorial of her son, Adam Bruce, who died while holding the position of instructor in that science at the university.

The second of the hearings upon the appointment of Commissioners of Appraisal of the amount which the Metropolitan Transit Company shall pay to the city for the use of its streets, in which to build an elevated railroad, took place before Judge Donohue yesterday afternoon. Gen. George W. Wingate and John Clinton Gray appeared for the Transit Company, and Assistant Corporation Counsel Dean and Wickes for the city.

READING, Penn., May 2.--In court here to-day the failure and insolvency of the Malden Creek Iron Company, which operates a large rolling mill at Blanden, this county, was announced, and Hiram Kaufman was appointed Receiver to wind up the company's affairs. Assets, $95,000: liabilities, $65,000. The creditors are principally New-York and Philadelphia parties. The mill continues in operation.

RED BANK, N.J., May 2.--To-day's municipal election resulted in the defeat of the Prohibition ticket, the present Board of Commissioners pledged to grant licenses to saloons being reelected by a majority of 160 out of 374 votes polled.

The sale of the Academy of Music property by William B. Dinsmore, President of the Adams Express Company, to William P. Douglas, for $435,000, announced last week, received indubitable confirmation yesterday in the formal transfer of the title.

CALAIS, Me., May 2.--The water in the St. Croix River rose about two inches last night. The back boom at Barring broke last night releasing about 100,000 logs, carrying away the King mill, owned by G.M. Porter, also two bridges from the railroads to the mills, and what remained of the old toll bridge.

The Rev. Mr. Spruille Burford gave his usual Monday night "at home" to the parishioners of St. Timothy's Episcopal Church at his residence, 371 West Fifty-sixth-street, last evening. Mr. Burford resigned from the pastorate of St. Timothy's last Sunday, and will deliver his farewell sermon next Sunday, so many members of his congregation availed themselves of the opportunity to call and express their regrets. Mr. Burford goes to a charge in Memphis.

GLASSBOROUGH, N.J., May 2.--A levy was made this morning by Sheriff Packer on the factory of Gibbs Wesley, the missing shoe manufacturers, who are said to have eloped last week with two girls employed in their factory.

Wall-Street did a good deal of moving yesterday. A hundred Stock Exchange firms have gone into new quarters. The Equitable Building and other new buildings were generally filled. Many firms have changed partners.

Mr. J. Rogers Maxwell's new sloop Shamrock was launched yesterday afternoon at Mumm's Yard, foot of Fifty-fifth-street, Brooklyn. The new vessel is painted white above her water line and green below. A pole was erected in the place where her mast will be and flags ran fore and aft from this.

The sage Coniston has lately fulminated against cycling, in the interests of "Shanks his mare" and the adequate study of the picturesque. It is to be feared that his protest is likely to be as practically effective as Mrs. Partington's contest with the Atlantic Ocean.

The civil district courts were crowded yesterday by landlords anxious to get possession of their premises, and by tenants equally anxious to retain a little longer the premises which they had bean occupying, with or without paying their rent, for the past year.

Colombia's Trustees held their regular monthly meeting yesterday. Hamilton Fish presided, and 15 Trustees were present. Reports of the various committees were read, and President Barnard made his annual report.
WASHINGTON, May 2.--Secretary Fairchild this afternoon approved Surveyor Beattie's action in removing Deputy Surveyor John M. Wyatt.
HAVANA, May 2.--Damaso Campos, a planter, who, on April 26, was kidnapped near Vegas by bandits, has been released on the payment of a ranson of $9,000.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2.--The embezzlement and flight of James N. Taggart, who was the Receiving and Paying Teller of the Union Trust Company for four years, which was reported in THE TIMES this morning, was the talk of the town today.
Two cases of smallpox were found yesterday, one at 111 Bedford-street and another at 372 Seventh-avenue.

LANCASTER, Penn., May 2.--Edgar, a 2-yearold son of William Boyce, of Drumore Township, while playing about the house found a small box of poison, and swallowed enough of it to cause death in two hours.

Arnheim's merchant tailoring establishment, 190 to 194 Bowery, is a great store, 70 by 120 feet on each of its three floors. It is crowded with goods chosen with skill and experience for excellence in quality, design, and finish.

A thousand and one barks, yelps, and howls reverberated through Madison-square Garden last night, and indicated the kind of chorus that may be heard in and around that famous old building for four days to come.
LEXINGTON, Ky., May 2.--The sale of Leonatus yearlings to-day was but fairly attended and prices were below what was expected.
The new steamship Worcester, of the Great Western Line, now loading for Bristol, England, at Pier 18 East River, was designed specially for freight carrying.

Yesterday morning Kreitter, the mendicant who stabbed a gentleman close to St. Stephen's last November, because he refused to give him alms, was hanged. He showed great stoicism to the last and burst out laughing while the rope was put round his neck. His last request was for a pair of new boots, as he did not like to appear in shabby garb before the distinguished public that would witness his death.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 2.--About 6,000 persons witnessed the opening day of the New West Side Park. It was a beautiful day, and great sport was afforded, the favorites winning straight through.
PARIS, May 2.--M. Calvinhac, Radical, has been elected to the Chamber of Deputies from Toulouse by a majority of 2,000 over the Conservative candidate.

LANCASTER, Penn., May 2.--An east-bound freight train on the Pennsylvania Railroad was wrecked this morning at Gap Station. Ten loaded cars were badly broken and their contents damaged. Both tracks were blockaded for several hours.

Somebody advertised yesterday that Warren I. Ritch had left his place of business, 301 Broadway, on Tuesday, April 19, and had not been seen since. The employer, father, wife, and friends of Mr. Ritch are at a loss to imagine why he disappeared or where he can be.

In the brand new armory of the Twelfth Regiment, last night, the athletic young men of that organization, with other muscular youths from outside clubs, ran and jumped and pulled manfully at the section of hawser which goes with eight cleats and eight men to set a tug-ofwar up in business. There was a big attendance of spectators.

CHICAGO, May 2.--Replies are coming in slowly from the Eastern creditors of Clapp Davies in regard to the proposed settlement of 35 cents on the dollar. Of the 247 creditors of the firm over 50 have responded and declared their willingness to accept the terms.
Elijah Smith is opposed to the proposed plan of reorganizing the Central Iowa Railroad and next week there will be a meeting of security holders to protest and prepare to fight.

RICHMOND, Va., May 2.--Gov. and Mrs. Fitzhugh Lee this evening gave a reception at the Executive Mansion in honor of Sir Edward Thornton, the Commissioner of the English bondholders of Virginia's debt, and his daughter, Miss Thornton.

The conferences that for several days past have been held between the Whiting Manufacturing Company and its striking silverworkers have not ended satisfactorily, and the men complain that the company has not been acting fairly with them.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2.--A very disastrous fire broke out about 3 o'clock this morning at the immerse warehouse of Brown, Johnson Co., Fourteenth and Maple streets.

PORTLAND, Mo., May 2.--No more ocean steamers will come here this Spring. The Sardinian, of the Allan Line, and Ontario, of the Dominion Line, are still here, but they will sail this week. During the season just closed 38 steamers have arrived at this port. Their combined cargoes have loaded between 6,000 and 7,000 freight cars. Of this freight about one-third was consigned to the Western States, the rest going to Canada.

A further important advance has just been made in utilizing hydro-carbons for steam raising purposes on board ships. A legitimate objection to the adoption of liquid fuel at sea under certain circumstances has been that the use of steam for the diffusion of the oil in the boiler furnaces entails a considerable loss of fresh water from the boilers.
ST. LOUIS, May 2.--Horace J. Pullen, alias W.H. Armour, and T.T. Johnson were arrested this evening on the charge of carrying on a gigantic fraud under the guise of a legitimate business enterprise.

The second game between the Jersey City Club and the Rochesters in the International League championship series was played yesterday on the Jersey City Grounds. It resulted in the defeat of the home club by a score of 11 to 8.
The threatened strike of the tin and slate coofers was practically settled yesterday, an agreement having been signed by conference committees of the bosses and men.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 2.--The crew of the foundered schooner Louis O'Neill arrived here to-day from Conneaut, having rowed across Lake Erie in an open boat through a violent storm, to which they were exposed 60 hours. One sailor is in the City Hospital here. Capt. Walker and the remaining six sailors leave to-night for their several homes in Marine City and other ports of Michigan.

CHICAGO, May 2.--It is estimated that fully 3,500 hod carriers and laborers refused to work to-day in consequence of the decision of the contractors not to pay the wages demanded by the union.

A well known English lady has sent the Pope a valuable Easter egg. The shell is of ivory, lined with white satin, and the yolk is a golden case wherein is a large ruby set in diamonds, the whole being valued at over 2,000.

The regular monthly meeting of the Federal Club was held in its rooms at 619 Madisonavenue last evening. It was announced that invitations to speak at the dinner to be given by the club to Theodore Roosevelt at Delmonico's ...
The Hudson County Board of Freeholders, elected for two years, was sworn in at Jersey City yesterday, and will organize today.

It is easy for a shrewd scoundrel in public office to gain a reputation for generosity, and even to become popular and powerful, by a liberal use of money which he has stolen from the people. That has been shown repeatedly in this region since the days of the generous and charitable TWEED.

CHICAGO, May 3.--A severe windstorm which passed over the Northwestern portion of this city yesterday did much damage in the surburban towns. Several houses were unroofed; many outbuildings destroyed, and fences and trees generally torn up and scattered about. Several people were seriously injured, and one carpenter, who was blown from the top of a building, will die.

GREAT FALLS, N.H., May 3.--Great Falls is excited ever an innovation in the appointment of a young woman as Clerk of the police court by Judge Knapp. The excitement is somewhat intensified by the fact that the lady is a niece of the Judge. This is the first case in the State where a lady has been appointed to occupy such a position.

In acknowledging the munificence of Judge HILTON'S gift to the Metropolitan Museum, Mr. JOHN TAYLOR JOHNSTON, its President, took occasion to express his special gratification at the fresh proof given by Judge HILTON of "the public spirit of our citizens, which has done so much this Winter to make the Museum worthy of the metropolis of our country."
WINNIPEG, Manitoba, May 3.--The Hon. Gilbert McMicken, just returned from Ottawa, says he learned there from Sir John Macdonald that he (Sir John) was to be raised to the Peerage on June 21.

EL PASO, Texas, May 3.--A shock of earthquake was plainly felt here at 3:08 P.M. to-day, the vibrations lasting about two minutes.

MANCHESTER, May 3.--The Manchester Exhibition was opened to-day by the Prince of Wales, who was enthusiastically received. The weather was dull during the opening ceremonies.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 3.--The track was fast to-day and the time good. The attendance was heavy and the number of ladies larger than has been at any race course in the South for years. Franklin Haven, of Boston, is at the Windsor Hotel. J.J.C. Abbott, of Montreal, is at the St. James Hotel.

DETROIT, May 3.--The Roman Catholic community of this city was taken greatly by surprise to-day by the wholly unexpected announcement that Bishop Casper H. Borgess had resigned his high office, and that his resignation had been accepted by the Pope.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 3.--Miss Emma Weiss, aged 20 years, a highly respected lady of this city, was struck by an engine on the Pennsylvania Railroad at Mocanaana this afternoon and instantly killed.

ALBANY, May 3.--The Republican Senators astonished themselves to-day by agreeing in caucus that the nominations of Knight of Labor Buckbee and Granger Armstrong should be reported adversely by the Railroad Committee, and that they should then be rejected.

FREEHOLD, N.J., May 3.--The May term of the Monmouth courts opened here to-day, and after routine business had been transacted the granting of licenses to hotels was taken up. The hotels of Red Bank and other towns were given licenses by the court without demur, but nearly all the petitions from hotels at Long Branch were laid over until next Monday.

LONDON, May 3.--Mr. Charles Edward Lewis, Conservative member for North Antrim, in the House of Commons this afternoon called the House's attention to the breach of privilege committed by the London Times in an article charging Mr. John Dillon with having told a falsehood when he denied the paper's allegations that he was an accomplice of Sheridan, the Invincible.

MADISON, Ind., May 3.--Madison voted against higher license to-day. The Repubicans elected four and the Democrats two Councilmen, leaving the body Republican by one majority, as before. The Democarts re-elect the Treasurer, Clerk, and Water Works Trustee.

The committee which has in charge the arrangements for the Queen's jubilee celebration in New-York met last evening at the Hotel Brunswick and completed the programme.

CHICAGO, May 3.--The Directors of the Board of Trade to-day adopted a plan for a life insurance society, limited, to members of the board. The plan contemplates the formation of a company similar to those in existence among the expressmen and other benevolent organizations.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3.--The hotel lobbies present lively scenes to-night. They are crowded with delegates to the State Democratic Convention, which will be called to order at noon to-morrow.

Mme. Janauschek played Meg Merrilies last night at the Windsor, not in the least disturbed by the consciousness that an attachment from the Supreme Court was floating around somewhere directed against her diamonds and her jewels generally.

Some 200 men and four women attended a sale of "unclaimed and abandoned goods" at the Barge Office yesterday, when 500 out of 1,092 articles were sold. The balance will be disposed of to-day.
The State Board of Fire Underwriters met yesterday afternoon at 115 Broadway. The State board recently promulgated certain rules which the Buffalo board refused to recognize.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3.--The Hon. John G. Carlisle arrived here yesterday from his home in Covington. He comes to attend the State Democratic Convention, of which it is generally understood he will be Chairman. The Polish residents of New-York had a grand time last evening at Irving Hall, where they celebrated the anniversary of the free constitution of Poland obtained in 1791.

Under-Sheriff Sexton left a suit of black clothing and a set of new underclothing at the Tombs Monday night for Peter Smith, who is to be hanged to-morrow for the murder of Watchman Hannah. When Smith woke and saw the new clothing he said: "I suppose now it's all over."

LONDON, May 3.--The race meeting at Chester opened to-day. The race for the Mostyn Two-year-old Plate was won by Brydges Willyams's b.f. Saucy Lass. Lord Cholmondeley's ch. f. Polydor came in second, and R. Crest's b.c. Chilperic third. There were 10 starters. Saucy Lass won by a length.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 3.--The conference of the Executive Committee of the National Union Labor Party to-day was a very quiet affair and, as stated yesterday, did not go beyond the consideration of plans for State organization.

OXFORD, N.J., May 3.--An epidemic of measles, accompanied with pneumonia, prevails in this place. A number of cases have proved fatal. About 250 persons, including some of advanced age, are afflicted. The public schools will remain closed until the physicians report that all danger is past.

At yesterday's meeting of the National Rifle Association Gen. C.F. Robbins reported that the butts at the 500-yard range had been repaired and two new ones erected for off-hand shooting.

WASHINGTON, May 3.--Queen Kapiolani, wife of King Kalakaua of the Hawaiian Islands, arrived here to-night at 8 o'clock from Chicago on her trip to be present at Queen Victoria's jubilee. Her royal Highness and suite were conveyed from the railroad station to the Arlington Hotel ...

Holy Trinity Church is again without a Pastor, the resignation of Rev. Wilbur F. Watkins having been accepted by the Trustees on Monday night.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 3.--Though there was a good attendance at the third annual sale of the Algeria raised youngsters to-day there was no spirited bidding, for it was generally believed that the first three colts offered were bid in by their owner.
The Committee of Forty of the First Assembly District Republican organization met last night at 117 Hudson-street. They organized by the election of John H. Grimes as Chairman.

Racing at Cedarhurst will be resumed to-day, and six races are on the card, all of which have a goodly number of entries. The big events will be the running of the Rockaway Green steeplechase and the race for the Rockaway Cup, presented by Dr. D.L Haight, President of the Rockaway Hunting Club.

The Mets, fresh and smiling from a long row of defeats, played their first home championship game of the season at Staten Island yesterday. Their competitors were the Brooklyns, who stood as near the head of the list as the Mets did near the tail.

BOSTON, May 3.--The annual report of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad, which will be ready for the stockholders on Thursday next, will be an unsually interesting document, containing much valuable information relative to proposed extensions of the system.

BOSTON, May 3.--The discovery to-day that Capt. A.J. Houghton was a defaulter and absconder created something of a flurry in certain circles in which the Captain was very popular. Capt. Houghton lived in Newton, and was the commander of the Claflin Guard, Fifth Regiiment, M.V.M.
HAVANA, May 3.--The storekeeper of the warehouses known as Almacenes de Depositos has disappeared, and is said to be a defaulter to the sum of $400,000.
A serious accident occurred at 11:30 o'clock on Monday night on the horse car line running from the northern part of Jersey City Heights to the Pavonia Ferry.

MUNCIE, Ind., May 3.--The largest gas well in the world has just been discovered at Fairmount, near here. The test of Prof. Orton, State Geologist of Ohio, shows that it is flowing nearly 12,000,000 feet per day.

A portion of the Tagliapietra-Careno Opera Company arrived yesterday on the steamer Philadelphia from La Guayra. The company left on Feb. 17 for Caracas, where they had an eight weeks' engagement in Guzman Blanco's theatre.

The movement to enforce the excise law in this city, coupled with the interpretation of the act by Corporation Counsel Lacombe, which was read to all the Police Captains by Superintendent Murray yesterday, has aroused the hotel men of the metropolis to action.

Brooklyn's Academy of Music was given up to an impeachment of the Ives Pool bill last evening and several of the city's best known clergymen did the impeaching. They had a bodyguard of vice-Presidents which filled the platform, and a crowd of hearers that needed all the seats in the place.
Judge Nehrbas, of the City Court, presided at a meeting held at Terrace Garden last night of persons who claim that their business is injured by the enforcement of the excise and amusement laws.

ALBANY, May 3.--The appeal in the Broadway Railroad case of New-York City will be argued before the General Term of the Supreme Court next Tuesday, the counsel on both sides agreeing in court to-day to that date.
The Brooklyn Board of Education has drawn up a budget of expenses for the ensuing year, estimating the same at $2,031,795.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 3.--The National Opera Company is in serious trouble. Mme. Pauline L'Allemand is out on a strike and no member of the company has achieved such a distinct success in this city as she.

Col. John R. Fellows, Assistant District Attorney, who went to the Hot Springs, Ark., two months ago for his health's sake, after much hard work in connection with boodle trials, has returned to the city without being apparently much benefited physically by his trip.
WASHINGTON, May 3.--Mme. Adelina Patti was heard here last night by an audience that quite filled Albaugh's Opera House. The gathering was a brilliant one.

The wall paper pool has been abandoned and the price of that very necessary commodity promises to take a tumble of about 25 per cent. next Spring unless a new pool is organized under the auspices of the American Wall Paper Manufacturers' Association.

LAHORE, May 3.--It is reported that the troops of the Ameer of Afghanistan were recently routed near Jellalabad, that Khelat-i-Ghilzai has been captured, that Ghuzni is surrounded, and that the insurgents threaten Candahar.
PARIS, May 3.--The performance of "Lohengrin," at the Eden Theatre, this evening, was witnessed by a large audience, who warmly but quietly applauded the singers.

Halsted, Haines Co., the old dry goods firm that failed in July, 1884, was built on a solid foundation away back in 1804. The founders established an enviable reputation and amassed fortunes. One by one they died or retired, and new blood was infused into the concern.

TROY, N.Y., May 3.--The Fitchburg Railroad Company was to take possession to-day of the Troy and Boston Road. A large crowd met at the Union Station here this morning to greet the train that was to bring the Fitchburg officers to Troy.

Clement W. Alburtis, who is the lessee for a long term of the large building 57 Broadway, has brought suit against the Manhattan Railway Company, claiming $5,000 damages. He appeared before Judge Barrett yesterday in Supreme Court, Chambers, and asked for an injunction upon the company.
The offices of the New-Yorker Zeitung, at 7 Frankfort-street, were burned out Sunday, April 17. Since then the paper has been published from 13 Spruce-street.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 3.--A year ago to-morrow Milwaukee was the scene of labor riots unprecedented in her history, and five persons were killed by the militia in a successful effort to protect life and property at Bay View. Many arrests were made.

Mr. Speaker CARLISLE has been again explaining his views on the situation of revenue reform and other matters, this time in an interview with a reporter of the Louisville Courier-Journal. The Speaker is still cheerful.

WASHINGTON, May 3.--This was the first day of the Spring meeting of the National Jockey Club at Ivy City, and the attendance was very large for an opening day, over 3,000 persons being present. The track was slow and dusty. The winners were Pasha, Telie Doe, Dry Monopole, Omaha, and Ten Strike.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 3.--Shortly before 3 o'clock this morning as a switch engine in charge of Engineer Berdell and Fireman W.D. Bates was coming out of the Belle Dock roundhouse the boiler exploded. The engineer, fireman, and several other employes were badly hurt.

"The Highest Bidder" is a little play that closely resembles a dozen of the pieces that used to come from the nimble pen of Henry J. Byron. A queer idea, a little bit of sentiment, and a fair quantity of mild humor are joined together in it very agreeably.

OTTAWA, May 3.--The fishery correspondence was laid before Parliament to-night. It forms a book of nearly 300 pages, and contains over 195 dispatches. The concluding portion indicates that the negotiations are now well under way for a settlement of the vexed question on a basis regarded here as anything but unfavorable to the United States.
A new system for heating railway cars was tested on the New-England express train which left the Grand Central Station at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3.--The reception accorded to Augustin Daly and his New-York company at the Chestnut-Street Opera House last night was one the heartiness of which astonished the oldest playgoers of this city.

KEY WEST, Fla., May 3.--Judge Locke has made an interlocutory decree in the case of the cotton on board the ship Slobodna of 25 per cent. on dry cotton, 33 1/3 per cent, on partially wet cotton, 40 per cent. on all taken from six feet of water, 50 per cent. on the balance, and 45 per cent. on material. The salvage by the final decree will probably be about $53,000.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 3.--A. H. Straus, furniture dealers at 153 West Fourth-street, assigned this afternoon to Samuel Wolfstein. Assets, $40,000; liabilities, $50,000; preferences, $57,000.
ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, May 3.--The steamer John Knox, Capt. Brolly, struck the southwest point of Channel Harbor, on this coast, yesterday morning at 1 o'clock and sank in about half an hour.

There was a large attendance at the open ing games of the Brooklyn Hill Lawn Tennis Club at Ryerson-street and De Kalb-avenue, Brooklyn yesterday. Four of the most promi nent tennis players in the country appeared in the opening set and played a good game, although out of practice.

Judge Barrett, after hearing the argu ments of Mr. Hummel for "Tom" Gould and of Corporation Counsel Lacombe for the city, de cided yesterday afternoon that Judge Van Brunt's sentence of Gould to 30 days' imprison ment in Ludlow-Street Jail and the payment of $250 fine must stand.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4.--Philadelphia won the last game of the series from Boston to-day by better all-round play. Casey was very effective, only four hits and a base on balls being made off him, and he was splendidly caught by McGuire.

PORTLAND, Me., May 4.--At the auction sale of the property of the Dennison Paper Manufacturing Company at Mechanic Falls to-day, Charles R. Milliken, of this city, was the successful bidder. The price paid was $100,000, subject to mortgages of $50,000. This includes the Canton ill.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 4.--A. semi-official denial is given to the report that the negotiations of the English and Russian commissions on the Afghan boundary question have failed. The commissions will hold their first formal joint meeting to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4.--A permanent organization of the managers of variety theatres in various cities was effected to-day at a meeting in Manager Gilmore's office at the Central Theatre.

The condition of Oliver Hoyt, the well known leather dealer of 72 Gold-street, who was thrown from his wagon while driving with his wife near Greenwich on Monday, was about the same last evening as on the previous day.
LONDON, May 4.--At the Chester meeting to-day the race for the Chester Cup was won by Mr. Somers's 4-year-old b.c. Carlton.

CITY OF MEXICO, May 4.--In all the higher circles of the capital little else is heard but talk of the prospective duel in which the Spanish Minister is concerned, and the hope is expressed that the trouble may be settled without bloodshed.

WASHINGTON, May 4.--The New-Yorks won their second victory from the Washingtons by an opportune streak of hard, safe batting in the fifth and sixth innings, which gave them 7 runs, of which 6 were earned, and a lead which the home club could not wrest from them, though they made a slight rally in the ninth inning.

A meeting of hotel proprietors was held at the Grand Central Hotel last night to consider the laws restricting the sale of liquors to their guests on Sunday. They first perfected an organization by sleeting E.L. Merrifield President, A.L. Ashman Vice-President, H.H. Brockway Treasurer, and W.D. Garrison Secretary.

George Cabot Ward died yesterday at his residence in this city, in the sixty-third year of his age. Mr. Ward was one of the best known business men in this city for many years.

TRENTON, N.J., May 4.--Vice-Chancellor Vanfleet, of Newark, who resigned the position today, was at once reappointed by Chancellor McGill for a new term of seven years. He has been on the bench 12 years. His salary is $5,000 per year and $10 extra for each day's actual service on the bench.

Col. John A. McCaull turned up bright and smiling at Wallack's Tuesday morning with his lieutenant, Benjamin D. Stevens, and began his preparations for the Summer season of comic opera, which he has made a feature of the house.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 5.--Congressman Foran, replying to a letter from the Hon. John McBride, declines to allow his name to be used in connection with the Democratic nomination for Governor. He understands his election to Congress to be a contract between himself and the people of this district, and feels in honor bound to abide by its implied terms and serve his constituents, as they have designated, in the National House of Representatives.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 5.--A terrific storm of wind and rain, accompanied by vivid lightning, passed over the city this afternoon. The clouds hung down to the earth and the darkness was that of night. The storm was directly from the south and the rain came down in sheets.

BUCHAREST, May 6.--It is reported here that disorders of an alarming nature have occurred at Jassy and that a number of arrests have been made.

MIDDLETOWN, N.J., May 6.--The Rev. E. Everett Jones was ordained as Pastor of the Baptist church last night. The sermon was delivered by the Rev. J.K. Manning, of Red Bank, and the right hand of fellowship was given by the Rev W.W. Case, of Holmdel.

SOCORRO, New-Mexico, May 6.--There were two legal executions in New-Mexico to-day. Henry Anderson was hanged at this place, and Theodore Baker was executed at Springer, Colfax County, Both had been convicted of murder.

BOSTON, May 6.--Mr. Oscar B. Farnham is a persistent man. This morning, tired of life, he tried in three different ways to kill himself, but failed through his neglect to take precautions against any noise he might make being heard by others.

A dispatch from Nashville announces that the Dwyer brothers have purchased from B. W. Curtis, of the Auburn (Ind.) stables, for $15,000, the famous runner Egmont. Mr. Curtis bought him at the Belle Meade sale as a yearling in 1884 for $275.

BOSTON, May 6.--A persistent effort is being made to test the constitutionality of the Act of 1885 establishing a Board of Metropolitan Police for the city of Boston, and a bill for that purpose was filed to-day in the Supreme Judicial Court.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., May 6.--Jefferson Davis has written a review of Gen. Wolseley's "Life of Gen. Lee." Mr. Davis takes exception to many of the English General's statements, and while not findings fault with the superlative opinion of Gen. Lee's military ability expressed in the book, he shows very plainly that he considers Gen. Wolselay's criticisms of other Southern leaders unjust and unwarrantable.

CATSKILL, May 6.--Hotel men in the Catskill Mountains are greatly exicted. To-night, with the aid of firemen from this village and the large population for miles through the range, they are fighting a fierce forest fire with varying success.
PITTSBURG, Penn., May 6.--The Post will to-morrow print two pages of interviews with the Democrats of the Pennsylvania Legislature on the question of President Cleveland's renomination.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 6.--The iron industries situated along the New-York and NewJersey borders are now experiencing a noteworthy revival, while the old mines that have been worked right along are compelled to put on extra forces.

After many ineffectual attempts to obtain a quorum, the Committee on Law of the Board of Aldermen held a meeting in the City Hall, yesterday, to consider requests for franchises from new electric light companies.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 6.--George Propheter, aged 50 years, living with his family at 640 Racestreet, where he kept a manufactory of hosiery and a notion store, was found in the cellar this morning by-his wife with the top of his head blown off by a shotgun, which he had discharged with suicidal attempt. No cause could be assigned, unless it was derangement from the effect of a fall yesterday from his wagon.

NANAIMO, British Columbia, May 6-2 P.M.-- The exploring party that want down this morning broke through into the mine and discovered the dead lying in all directions. All hope is now given up of saving any of them alive. Thirty-five bodies were recovered from the mine this morning. The fire is still burning, but is under control. The mine is owned by the Vancouver Coal Company, of London, England.

BOSTON, Mass., May 6.--The Senate committee on the Beverly bribery case submitted a majority and a minority report this afternoon. The majority report, after summarizing the evidence, declares that no specific attempt to influence corruptly the vote or action of any Senator has been proved.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 6.--The Southern Baptist Convention, the largest religions body in the South, assembled in the Broadway Baptist Church at 10 o'clock this morning.

Dr. Carver, the wild Western shot, succeeded in defeating the English champion, William G. Graham, in a shooting contest at Erb's Grounds in Newark yesterday. Monaco rules, with 30 yards' rise, and 18 yards' boundary were used. Dr. Carver killed 86 of the 100 birds he shot at, and Mr. Graham 85.
OTTAWA, Ontario, May 6.--Considerable interest is being manifested in the Finance Minister's budget speech, which will be delivered next Thursday.

RICHMOND, Texas, May 6.--The private bank of T.R. Beard made an assignment to-day. The liabilities amount to $64,000. The assets are valued at $62,000. For several years the bank has been conducted by Mrs. Beard under the name of her deceased husband.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, April 30.--Owing to the undeniable fact that the Government has taken no steps to have the lower classes vaccinated, and has failed to caution them regarding the contagious nature of smallpox, the disease is rapidly spreading in this city.
LIMA, Ohio, May 6.--W.W. Williams, a dry goods merchant, assigned this morning. Assets, $32,000: liabilities unknown.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 6.--Sister Mariana Flynn was to-day appointed Superioress of St. Mary's Academy, at Emmettsburg, to succeed the late Mother Euphemia, who was the Mother Superior of the Order of Sisters of Charity in this country. Sister Angelina Davis is made Treasurer, The new Mother Superior is a native of St. Louis.

Michael Neysor, alias Vogtal, who was arrested in Chicago April 25, charged with having embezzled while Postmaster at Morbach, in Germany, 8,000 marks belonging to the German Government, was brought to this city last night by detectives from Chicago. PITTSBURG, Penn., May 6.--Telegrams from the coke region state that Laughlin Co., Stewart Iron Company, Hogsett Co., Percy Mining Company, and Everson Co. have granted the demands of the strikers and resumed operations.

WASHINGTON, May 6.--The theartening weather didn't serve to keep many from the races to-day, the last of the four days' meeting for there was a large crowd at the track, including a host of ladies.
A little boy playing with a group of children at State and Bond streets, Brooklyn, at 6:30 o'clock Thursday night was suddenly grasped by two men, thrown into a carriage and driven rapidly away.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 6.--The Captain of the schooner Drucilla arrived at Louisburg last night and reports the loss of the schooner Tiber. She was crushed in the ice at St. Peter's Bay.
A premium of 4 per cent. was yesterday bid in London for the new bonds of the Mexican National Railroad, large numbers of which were lately subscribed for in this city.

CHICAGO, May 6.--Col. W.H. Bolton, who was convicted a year ago of embezzling about $12,000 from the Government while Superintendent of Second Class Mail Matter, slowly dragged himself into Judge Blodgett's court room this morning leaning on the arm of a Deputy Marshal to receive the sentence for his crime.

MONTREAL, May 6.--Mr. J.H. Smith, representing John Swan Sons, live stock importers of Glasgow, has returned from an extended tour of the ranching country in the Northwest and British Columbia.

This will be the third day of the Cedarhurst races, and, if the weather favors, it should be productive of excellent sport.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., May 6.--A terrific storm passed over this region this morning. Four buildings at Randolph were struck by lightning and burned. Several horses and other live stock were billed by lightning. Fruit and forest trees suffered considerable damage.

The Methodist Episcopal Church at Tremont was on the point of seceding from the New-York Conference on Wednesday last, and was only prevented from doing so on the spot by the counsels of some of the cooler heads of the congregation.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 6.--The excitement attending the imprisonment of Col. J.R. McCorkle, a well known young lawyer of Buena Vista, by Judge Willis has been intensified by the affliction which befell Judge Willis to-day.
John H. Wardwell, who becanme so prominent through his connection with the contest over the Paine estate, died in Bristol, R,I., yesterday morning at the age of 70 years.

BOSTON, Mass., May 6.--The full bench of the Supreme Court has sent down a rescript in the case of Post Co. against the Toledo, Cincinnati and St. Louis Railroad Company overruling the defendants' demurrer.
The Spartan Harriers have their athletic meeting at the Madison-Square Garden this evening, the last event of that kind to be held in the structure.
ST. LOUIS, May 6.--Wednesday night a freight train on the St. Louis and Iron Mountain Railroad, bound South, was thrown from the track by a landslide near Cliff Cave Station.
Herbert Platto, a hat and cap manufacturer, reported to the police Thursday that he had been made the victim of an attempt to blow up his shop at 59 Bleecker-street.

TRENTON, N.J., May 6.--Gov. Green signed the Incidental bill to-day, having first vigorously applied the pruning knife and cut out of the act at least 30 items. The whole amount of the bill when it reached his hands was $17,186,77.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 6.--The Yale 'Varsity crew received a visit from Robert J. Cook, of Philadelphia, the "Bob Cook" stroke man yesterday. He was on a business trip in this section of the country and found time to give the crew a few points about rowing.
PARIS, May 6.--Le Paris states that France has concluded a defensive alliance with certain other powers, and that henceforth France will not be alone in the event of aggression against her.

LOCKPORT, May 6.--There is hurry manifested by the Canadian Government to have the buildings removed from the reservation preparatory to the opening of the Queen Victoria Canadian Park the latter part of June.

BOSTON, May 6.--A large seizure of wool at this port for alleged undervaluation by a Boston firm has just come to light. The amount involved is about $30,000, and it is simply another instance of the liability of the wool importing trade to get into snarls with the Treasury Department.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., May 6.--A large mastodon tooth was plowed up to-day near Perry. It weighed eight pounds. Search will be made for the remainder of the skeleton. A similar tooth was found at the same place three years ago.

SAN FRANCICO, Cal., May 6.--Drafts on NewYork--Sight, 15 cents; telegraphic, 20 cents.

The sale of the Durand-Ruel collection of French paintings was continued and ended last evening at Moore's art galleries and realized $23,847 50 for 61 pictures.

The dog show came to a successful end last evening. Over 1,500 persons examined the canine specimens during the day. some of the dogs looked tired after their long siege as objects of inspection and were fain to lie down and sleep away the last hours of the exhibition.
KINGSTON, New-Mexico, May 6.--David Burke, a well known citizen of this place, has been shot and killed by a miner named Con Ryan.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., May 6.--A terrific thunderstorm passed over this city early this morning. Morris moray, aged 17 years, was struck by lightning while in bed and instantly killed. A companion in the same bed was not injured.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 6.--The will of Eleaze T. Slater, who died at Knowlesville last week, bequeaths an annuity of $250 to the Presbyterian church of Knowlesville, $60,000 to the Niagara Presbytery, and the remainder of his estate, which will amount to nearly $200,000, to the Synodical Board of Foreign Missions.

Douglas Campbell, counsel for Grace B. Deems in her suit against her husband, Dr. Frank M. Deems, for a limited divorce, began the argument yesterday morning before Justice Daly on the petition for alimony and counsel fees.

The case of the Fifth-Avenue Bank against James B. Colgate, the Wall-street banker, seeking to hold him liable as a general partner in the firm of Humphrey Co., has been on trial for several days before Judge Freedman in the Superior Court.

CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., May 6.--About 100 Hungarians in the Mount Pleasant coke district left yesterday for their native land. A large number have purchased tickets here. They say that the strike will last five or six months, and that they can live cheaper during that time by going to their own country and returning at the end of the strike.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 6.--The male pupils of the Prichard-Street School have notified the teachers that unlees their hours of study are so arranged as to admit of their attending baseball games after Monday next they will strike.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 6.--About 1,200 people listened to the Rev. Dr. McGlynn's lecture on "The Cross of the New Crusade" in the Hyperion Theatre here to-night. The audience was at times very enthusiastic. The lecture was substantially the same as his first one in New-York on the same topic. No Catholic priests were noticed in the audience. The lecture was given under the auspices of the New-Haven Labor Club.

LIBERTY, Va., May 6.--Lindsay Anderson's body was discovered hanging from a limb of a tree near his home in this county to-day. He has been missing from his home for three weeks, but nothing could be heard of his whereabouts till his body was discovered. It was undoubtedly a case of suicide. He was highly respectable and in good circumstances.

HAVANA, April 30.--The new sugar refinery that has been built at Matanzas, on the spot where the "Grand Central China" formerly stood, is already at work.

BELVIDERE, N.J., May 7.--An aggravated form of epizooty has broken out among horses in Warren County, and is causing horsemen great uneasinees. It was first introduced here by a drove of Western horses. A number of animals have already died and the disease is spreading. Work horses are especially susceptible, and farmers find difficulty in getting horses to do the Spring work.

GALLUP, New-Mexico, May 7.--A difficulty with Navajo Indians occurred yesterday morning at Defiance Station, seven miles west of here. A dispute arose in a store in the village between E.T. Allen, a clerk, and an Indian.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 7.--The Roane Iron Company commenced operations in this city to-day with its steel mill. It is the largest Bessemer steel plant ever built in the south, the investment representing $1,000,000. It starts with a capacity of 250 tons of steel per day and employs over 800 hands. Two Bessemer steel mills are now in operation at Chattanooga, the only ones in the South.

Chattanooga fruit growers are reaping the benefits.

LYNCHBURG, Va., May 7.--The White Knights of Labor bolted the Labor Convention last night, and today held a separate convention and put a tick et in the field for municipal offices. The colored Knights have also put up a ticket. It is thought the Democrats will indorse the white ticket, which will insure its election.

Mayor Hewitt was somewhat surprised when he read in yesterday's TIMES a list of the men who would probably be appointed by him to the existing vacancies in the various city departments. He privately admittted that the list was remarkably accurate, considering the closeness with which he has guarded his choice.

An attempt is to be made to revive the interest in the American Church Building Fund Association, and with that object in view several clergymen met in St. Ann's Church, on Clinton-street, Brooklyn, last evening. The Rev. Dr. Reese F. Alsop presided, and Bishop Littlejohn, the Rev. J. W. Malcolm, and the Hon. L. Bradford Prince spoke.

CHICAGO, May 8.--The transcontinental roads, after having been in session in this city three days, adjourned last night without having been able to form a combination for the maintenance of uniform rates, which was the principal object of the meeting.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8.--Mrs. Alice Wilson, residing at 2,220 South-street, was found dead in her bedroom about 9 o'clock this evening with a bullet hole in her right temple.

WICHITA, Kan., May 8.--Officer McMahon arrested a man named Hopkins, who two years ago committed a heavy diamond robbery at Lancaster, Ohio. Hopkins has been living here for some time under an assumed name, investing quite extensively in real estate. He fell into the trap laid for him, and partly confessed his guilt.
