LONDON, May 9.--A fatal duel was fought at Pesth on Saturday by two students. The weapons were pistols. One of the combatants was shot dead, a ball passing through his liver.

BOSTON, May 8.--An epidemic of letter stealing by people outside the Postal Service seems to have broken out in Boston. Yesterday two Quincy House messenger boys were arrested and a snug sum in money and stamps pilfered from letters was found in their room.

CHICAGO, May 8.--Chilly weather still prevails evenings, and there is no perceptible falling off in the audiences at the playhouses. The last week was a fairly prosperous one for most of the managers.

OMAHA, Neb., May 8.--F. Oliver, of Beardsley, Ill., jumped from a west-bound train on the Burlington Road at Iowa Point and was drowned in the Missouri River. He was frightened by two confidence men who were working him. He ran to the platform, dragging with him his 10-year-old son. The conductor grabbed the boy in time to save him. Mr. Oliver was temporarily insane.
HAVRE, May 8.--The steamer La Champagne, which sailed yesterday morning for NewYork, and which afterward returned, having been in collision, was run into by the steamer Ville de Rio.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 8.--District Grand Lodge. No. 7, Independent Order B'nai Berith, met in annual session here this forenoon. There was a very large attendance of delegates from the States of Tennessee, Alabama, Mississippi, Arkansas, Louisiana, Florida, and Texas.

Torres, of Sonora, saying that Cajame was shot, after a short trial, according to law.

Four young men were found concealed in a New-York Central freight car which reached this city yesterday morning. They were arrested and arraigned in the Yorkville Police Court on a charge of burglary.

J. Francis Murphy was yesterday awarded the Webb prize of $300 for the best landscape painted by an American under 40 years of age, and shown at the exhibition of the Society of American Artists.

George W. Cassedy, the Master in Chancery of Jersey City, is taking testimony in the suit brought by Mrs. Mary S. Clarke against her husband, William Bayard Clarke. Mrs. Clarke's maiden name was Wolff, and, besides being the owner in her own right of an estate valued at $200,000, is connected with two of the wealthiest families in the country.

MACON, Ga., May 8.--A negro was killed in a singular way on the Georgia Railroad eight miles miles from Macon last night. He made a pillow of his coat and lay down between the cross ties and went to sleep. He was aroused by a passenger train rolling over him, and as he raised his head, a bolt on a brake beam struck him, tearing off the top of his skull.

"Billy" Welch, who was lately connected with Dockstader's Minstrels, will be taken to Harrisburg to-day for burial, it having been decided to hold no funeral services in this city. A movement is on foot for an entertainment for the benefit of his family. Dockstader's Minstrels have sent $150 from Buffalo. "Billy" Emerson has offered his services and $100 for two seats. Dixey and "Billy" Rice, Thatcher, and others will volunteer their services.
LOUISVILLE, May 8.--Every Protestant puplit in the city to-day was filled by a Baptist preacher, both night and morning. Many of the sermons were notable for profundity and eloquence.

Michael O'Connor, 16 years old, of 173 Thirdavenue, while visiting friends at 128 Varick-street last evening, went into the back yard, and was there attacked by a large dog. The injuries were cauterized and dressed by a surgeon from St. Vincent's Hospital, after which O'Connor was taken home.

FALL RIVER, Mass., May 8.--Augustus E. Soper, a passenger on the steamer Bristol, from New-York, died this morning between Newport and this city. He was second mate of a schooner which recently arrived in New-York, and occupied a stateroom in company with Capt. McKinnou, who claimed to be Captain of the same schooner.

BELVIDERE, N.J., May 8.--Nellie Hooper, the 14-year-old daughter of Prof. Hooper, of Belvidere Academy, was kidnapped by her mother at Phillipsburg Saturday afternoon and taken to Atlantic City. Prof. Hooper and his wife are not living to gether. The girl and her aunt were driven to Phillipsburg by a detective named Hall, who had ingratiated himself with the Professor. The town is considerably excited over the affair.

American railroad securities shared in the general dullness; there was a slight increase in buying for investment, which helped to keep quotations firm.

CITY OF MEXICO, May 8.--Consul F.C. More arrived from Kansas this morning. Mr. Porch will turn the office over to him and take a trip to the States preparatory to entering into business in Mexico.

Another of New-York's old churches will soon be torn down. Yesterday the last services were held in the Allen-street Presbyterian Church, near Grand-street. For many years the church has been a sort of half-way house between up and down town, and its congregation has been an ever-changing one.
The committee which is to have charge of the amateur billiard tournament at the Racquet Club met in the clubrooms yesterday to further consider the task before it.
BOSTON, May 8.--For the first time the Country Club members will have to compete with entries from New-York this season, and they are looking around for new flyers to add to their strings.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 8.--The Commissioners of the Canadian Reservation at Niagara Falls have ordered many tenants to vacate at once. The museum and Prospect House will remain as they are until the close of the present season.

ALBANY, May 8.--The Supply bill and the Arnold bill providing for a Constitutional Convention were placed in the Governor's hands on Friday. The Legislature will not adjourn for three weeks, so he will have only the usual 10 days in which to dispose of them.

Lawn tennis, which grows more popular every year, will this season have a big boom in New-York, Brooklyn, and New-Jersey. Already the players are getting out their flannels and racquets, and practice has begun on the numerous grounds which have sprung up all around.

An audience that filled every available foot of sitting and standing room in the Academy of Music last night greeted Henry George when he stepped before the footlights. Many had come in expectation of welcoming the Rev. Dr. Curran, who had been announced to preside, but in this they were disappointed.

There may be people who will doubt it, people who will perpetrate the stale old joke about carrying coals to Newcastle, but doubt or no doubt, jibe or no jibe, Boston is boring for natural gas. Something like an epidemic of natural gas has broken out all over the country.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., May 8.--The British steamer Miranda, which had been ashore at Cedar Tree Neck, arrived here last night under her own steam. She is leaking one and a half inches per minute. She is being examined by divers to-day. The brig Addie Cliffod has been chartered to carry her cargo to Boston. The entire cargo will be lightered, and the steamer will proceed to New-York for repairs.

The pilot of a vessel which passed Quarantine last evening reported that there had been a collision in Gedney's Channel during the day. An unknown bark had been run into in the fog by a large steamer and had sunk in the channel.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 8.--The union men, numbering about 200, employed in all the breweries in this city were discharged last night.

After the destruction of one of the buildings of the State Industrial School in Rochester last Winter, the Assembly by resolution called upon the State Board of Charities for an opinion as to what plan should be followed in rebuilding.
While the light of day was trying to rise out of the fog yesterday morning between 5 and 6 o'olock some 200 Irishmen gathered on the starin dock at Cortlandt-street.

Carpenters and other mechanics descended in force upon the Madison-Square Garden when this morning was but a very few minutes old, and went to work on the last of the preparations for the cattle show which is to open to-morrow morning.

There was a fight last evening at 135 Crosby-street, in which Mary Adressa, Ann Bennett, and Alice Maher took part. During the fracas the woman Bennett struck Alice Maher on the head with a small hatchet, causing a slight fracture of the left temple, and Mary Adressa also beat her with a broomstick. The injured woman was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital and her assailants were locked up.
There was a lull yesterday in the warfare which the Tremont Methodist Episcopal Church has been waging against the higher powers in the shape of the Bishop, Presiding Elder, and Conference.

Ex-Senator Stephen W. Dorsey, of NewMexico, was at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel to-day, having arrived only a few hours before from a four months' trip to Europe. Senator Dorsey spoke freely on the Presidential possibilities.

READING, Penn., May 8.--The fifth convention of Philadelphia and Reading Railroad employes was held here to-day. About 100 delegates, representing every department, were in attendance. Quite a number of grievances were presented, but their nature and the action taken on them could not be learned. A resolution was unanimously passed authorizing the boycotting of the beer manufactured by the Philadelphia Brewers' Association.

LONDON, May 8.--Mr. Gladstone gave a dinner last evening to Earl Spencer, Baron Wolverton, Mr. T.D. Sullivan, Mr. Justin McCarthy, and several Irish members of the House of Commons.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 8.--Murat Halstead, of the Commercial Gazette, will print in his paper tomorrow over his own initials a stricture on Jefferson Davis's historical inaccuracy in that gentleman's recent criticism of Gen. Wolseley on Lee at Fredericksburg.

August Littlejohn, a strolling musician, died at the Charity Hospital, in Jersey City, last night. He, with John Heidelberg and Heidelberg's son, also musicians, entered John Loftus's saloon, on Grand-street, near Bergen Junction, about midnight of Saturday.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., May 8.--This morning a number of colored people belonging to the congregation of Mount Zion Baptist Church assembled on the wharf at the head of Lizardi-street to be baptized by immersion, according to the rites of their church.

ST. LOUIS, May 8.--The Browns achieved another magnificent victory to-day, defeating Louisville for the fourth successive time. It was a hard fought battle and Ramsey was again hit hard by the champions. King pitched a splendid game, and was especially effective at critical points.

Gottlob Pfluger, a German, 49 years old, committed suicide yesterday at 441 West Thirtysixth-street by shooting himself through the heart. Pfluger was formerly a pianomaker in the employ, for 19 years, of Steck Co.

Healy, in the House of Commons this afternoon, asked what answer had been returned by the Government to the letter of Patrick Egan, Treasurer of the old Land League, offering to return to Dublin and stand trial on the charges against him, provided the venue in his case was not removed from Dublin.

The Twenty-second Regiment gave a dress parade and bugle drill last evening to which many friends had been invited and to which many came. The old armory on West Fourteenth-street was decorated with flags and streamers.

R.C. Kemble, of Weldon, Kan., called upon Post Office Inspector Dosser yesterday in the Federal Building. He said that several months ago some sawdust swindlers of NewYork wrote to him and that for a long while a correspondence had been kept up.
UTICA, N.Y., May 9.--The assignment of Charles L. Hynde, of the Utica rubber store, to Charles H. Sayre, has been filed. The preferences amount to $4,550.
The Old London Streete has added another to its attractions in the shape of an entertainment hall, which was formally opened last night with an exhibition by Hercat, the magician.

BALTIMORE, May 9.--Eighty-eight Massachusetts veterans reached here to-day after a tour of the Virginia battle fields on which they fought twenty odd years ago.

GREENCASTLE, Ind., May 9.--The Monon passenger train for Chicago, due here yesterday morning, was wrecked one mile south of this place. The engine went one-third of the way down a 35-foot embankment.
The well known farmer, philosopher, and Southern humorist, "Bill Arp," entertained a fair-sized audience with one of his amusing talks in Chickering Hall last evening.

BOSTON, May 9.--The most important customs seizure at this port for many years was made to-day, when the large Provincetown schooner Rebecca R. Nickerson was taken into custody by the United states Inspectors and Capt. Arthur W. Tatner was placed under arrest.

WASHINGTON, May 9.--Senator McPherson has joined the procession of Democrats who at one time showed a disposition to be refractory and are now rapidly marshalling for Cleveland's renomination. He does not quite like the way the Pacific Railroad investigation is being conducted ...

BOSTON, May 9.--Before an audience that filled every seat in the Boston Museum this evening Mr. Richard Mansfield, an actor of remarkable versatility, unusual perceptive powers, and a perfect command of all the minor resources of the stage, gave form and substance to a character entirely new to the drama.

Policeman Harrison White, of the Jersey City force, was called upon yesterday by Henry Reinecke, who keeps a saloon on Newark-avenue, to shoot a dog that had shown symptoms of madness.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., May 9.--The schooner C. B. Manning, 68 tons, built at Salisbury in 1866, Bank halibut fishing, went ashore yesterday at Garnet Rock, Yarmouth, Nova Scotia. The crew was saved. The vessel will be a total loss. She was insured for $2,500.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., May 9.--Henry Pearson, a master builder here, has been missing from his home since April 26, since which time nothing has been heard from him. It was thought at first that he had committed suicide, but an investigation shows that he leaves about $10,000 in unpaid bills.

Four or five collectors of American pictures have decided to sell their smaller paintings and such as they have tired of, extra pieces by artists who are already represented on their walls, and canvases which take up space that is better filled by more recent purchases.

ALBANY, May 9.--Gov. Hill went to Elmira this afternoon to preside over the anticoercion meeting in that town to-morrow night. He left two sealed envelopes with his private secretary, with instructions to convey them to the Senate this evening.

Moncure D. Conway read a paper on "The General and the Journalist in Time of War" before the Military Service Institution at Governor's Island last night. He related his experiences as a correspondent in the Franco-German war and the policy of the commanders to the reporters.

The pavers and rammers in this city struck yesterday for an advance of 50 cents per day. The contractors for the pavement in Fifth-avenue said that there was only three months' work there, and as they they had a year in which to complete it the men would tire of waiting. John B. Devlin, who is doing the paving in Seventy-third-street, acceded to the men's demands.

Cider vinegar came in for a good share of the discussion at the meeting of the New-York Retail Grocers' Union last night at 213 East Twenty-thirdstreet. There are vinegar inspecters nowadays, and the say 2,000 grocers in this city sell vinegar that will not stand the test the law requires.

The examination of the accounts of Michael H. Murphy, the defaulting Water Register of Hoboken, has been completed, and William Macy, the expert, reported to the Water Commissioners last night. The deficiency is placed at $41,291 49, extending over the 16 years Murphy held the office. These figures may possibly be increased if Murphy failed to credit all payments he gave receipts for. Nothing has been heard from the defaulter since he left.
OTTAWA, May 9.--Sir Charles Tupper this afternoon brought down the estimate of the Dominion expenditure for the next fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, May 9.--A large number of gentlemen who look extremely well fed and wear shiny silk hats throng the corridors of the hotels this evening in preparation for the ninth annual convention of the Hotel Men's Mutual Benefit Association, which convenes to-morrow.

STONEWALL, Col., May 9.--Fannie Murray, aged 15 years, left home early Saturday morning to visit her brothers, who lives some three miles distant. She had been permitted to ride a broncho horse, which was equipped with a man's saddle.

HAVRE, May 9.--The reports of the loss of life among the emigrants on the French steamer La Champagne, which was beached after being damaged by collision with the steamer Ville de Rio Janeiro on Saturday, were exaggerated.

His Roya1 Highness, Prince Leopold of Germany, accompanied by his suits, arrived in this city yesterday on route to Europe, and is now domiciled in Mrs. Langtry's old rooms at the Albemarle Hotel.
CATSKILL, N.Y., May 9.--For the second time inside of a year the Saratoga, of the Citizens' night passenger and freight line, between New-York and Troy, ran ashore.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 9.--The people of the Upper Chenango Valley are just now filled with excitement and enthusiasm over the remarkable developments of natural gas and petroleum at the new well near Morrisville.
There is still a chance that a compromise may be resorted to to settle up the differences of the railroad companies on the subject of commissions to agents.

The members of District Assembly No. 91, shoemakers, boasted yesterday that the strike at the shoe factory of Hanan Son world soon be won, because the firm had not more than one-third the number of hands that they usually employ at this season.
Police Justice J. Henry Ford suddenly became very ill on Saturday evening. He was compelled to go to his rooms in the Hoffman House and send for his family physician, Dr. Edward Bradley.

Thomas Moore, a coal shoveler, who lived with his sister, the wife of a press feeder on an afternoon newspaper, at 369 West Twelfthstreet, was found, six years ago, at Eighteenthstreet and Ninth-avenue, stabbed in 13 places and nearly dead from loss of blood.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 9.--The boss carpenters of this city have granted the journeymen a reduction of time from 10 to 9 hours per day with an increase of 25 cents in wages. All of the men left work at 5 o'clock and the bosses were obliged to submit because of the great pressure on the building trade.

At 9 o'clock this morning the New-York Dairy and Cattle Show, at the Madison-Square Garden, will be thrown open to the public and, an hour later, the exhibitors of Holstein cattle will begin to subject their blank-and-white pedigrees of breeding and butter production to the critical gaze of the judges.

An exciting scene, not on the programme, occurred last night in the new theatre attached to the Old London Street. It was the opening night of the theatre, and Hercat, the magician, made his first appearance before a New-York audience.
MADISON, Ind., May 9.--Robert McKim, the wealthy merchant, banker, and philanthropist, died this morning of Bright's disease, aged 71. He was born in Ireland, County Tyrone, May 24, 1816.

BALTIMORE, May 9.--Corbett's Station is a small village of four houses, near Mason and Dixon's line. Saturday afternoon Scott Pearce, a white man, aged 22 years, and Edward Bond, a colored youth, began a friendly boxing match in the presence of spectators. Both became angry, and Pearce suddenly drew a knife and stabbed Bond, who died shortly afterward. Pearce fled. He is still at large.

GOV. HILL has appointed three Commissioners to examine the proposed Code of Evidence and to report upon it to the next Legislature. To most persons the report of the appointment will bring the first news that any Code of Evidence was proposed; to others it will revive facts tending to carry conviction to minds open to it.

LEXINGTON, KY., May 9.--The sale of yearlings to-day was made by various parties, but principally by Milt Young, of the McGrathiana Stock Farm, and B.G. Thomas, of the Dixiana Stock Farm. The attendance was large, the weather pleasant, and bidding fair.
Post B of the New-York State Division of the Travelers' Protective Association met at the Morton House last night to appoint delegates to the State Convention, which will meet in Buffalo May 21.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 9.--The Indianapolis Club Directors to-day signed Larry Corcoran, of Nashville, as pitcher. They pay him $2,000 and paid Nashville $1,000 for his release.

A German proverb advises us in emptying bathtubs to throw out the dirty water, but to keep the baby. This simple feat the Legislature has thus far been unable to accomplish with regard to "concert saloons."

A convention of longshoremen recently held decided to demand on Monday next the old rates of wages, 30 cents for day work and 60 cents for night work, along the North River, and 40 cents and 60 cents on the East River.
CALCUTTA, May 9.--It is rumored that the Russians are collecting supplies at Chardjui, about 200 miles from the Afghan frontier, preparatory to advance on Khamiab.

TROY, N.Y., May 9.--The police of this city to-day received a telegram from Inspector Byrnes, of New-York, asking for the arrest of Ellas Rosenthal, a New-Yorker, who was wanted for grand larceny, and who was supposed to be here. A search of the hotels was made, and Rosenthal was arrested at the Mansion House.

PITTSBURG, May 9.--The Amalgamated men at A.M. Byers Co.'s rolling mill struck this morning because the firm refused to employ an extra helper at the furnaces as provided for in the scale agreement. The mill has closed down and 600 men are temporarily thrown out of employment.

CHICAGO, May 9.--East-bound shipments of dead freight from Chicago, although very light, keep up much better than was expected. The shipments of last week show a slight increase instead of a decrease, as was anticipated.

William H. Cooper, a builder and prominent resident of Hempstead, Long Island, is missing. A week ago he felt Hempstead, telling his workmen he was going to Brooklyn to purchase building material.

P.H. Williams Co., who failed some time ago, were yesterday reinstated on the Cotton Exchange, having settled their liabilities.

The New-York Dairy and Cattle Show, the first exhibition of the kind ever held in this city, was opened at Madison-Square Garden yesterday forenoon. Though the arrangements were not nearly completed, sufficient progress had been made to insure smooth running in all departments by to-day.

SCRANTON, Penn., May 10.--A judgment note for $75,000 against Franklin Howell, of this city, and in favor of Margaret Thomas, of Pittsburg, was entered here this afternoon in the office of the Prothonotary of Lackawanna County. This large sum is the price which young Howell pays as the result of his promise to marry the girl. Howell, who is about 24 years of age, has had quite a romantic experience within ...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 10.--Engineer Frederick Eager, of the Shore Line night freight, discovered the body of a man upon the track a short distance east of the Stoney Creek station, about 10:30 o'clock last night. He signaled for brakes immediately, but the train ran nearly a quarter of a mile before it was stopped.

GALVESTON, Texas, May 10.--Dispatches from Central, Northern, and Northwestern Texas report copious rainfalls in those sections during the past 48 hours, making the second general precipitation in ...

PHILADELPHIA, May 10.--Notwithstanding Patti's only night in opera at the Academy of Music, the largest and most fashionable audience of the season gathered to see Augustin Daly's production of "The Taming of the Shrew" at the Chestnut-Street Opera House last night. Many ladies were without bonnets, and gentlemen ...

The Merritt Fruit Company, Limited, at 83 and 85 Park-place, is financially embarrassed, and application has been made for the appointment of a Receiver. A judgment for $1,830 in favor of Peter Denniston Co., of Glasgow, Scotland, was entered against it yesterday.

ERIE, Penn., May 10.--Patrick McNulty, a well known oil operator, lost his life in a manner unprecedented among oil operators. He was working alone in the Kane field and expected to strike a vein of gas. When it was tapped the flow was so powerful that he was asphyxiated on the spot and was found dead at the drill.

ALBANY, May 10.--As was expected, Gov. Hill has vetoed the Arnold Constitutional Convention bill, which the Republicans have been juggling with all Winter. For political purposes they thrust the holding of the convention over into a Presidential year, which would manifestly be a very improper time.

The condition of the municipal Legislature in this city would be amazing to every citizen if long experience had not dulled our capacity of astonishment, and if several other American cities were not in the same situation.

TRENTON, N.J., May 10.--The Grand Commandery Knights Templar, of New-Jersey, held its annual conclave in the Masonic Temple to-day. Officers for the ensuing year were elected as follows: Grand Commander--Edward W. Price.

BOSTON, May 10.--Richard Mansfield's brilliant acting in Russell Sullivan's dramatic version of "Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" has caught the fancy of the town, and seats in the Boston Museum will be at the premium all the week.

NYACK, May 10.--The trial of the Rev. Dr. Bristor came up at New City this morning. All the interested parties on both sides were present and District Attorney Demarest opened the case for the prosecution.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 10.--The steamboat Helen ran on a flat in the river yesterday and is still aground. The passengers were taken off by rowboats and took the train at Seabright for this place.

CHICAGO, May 10.--The Board of Review of the National Trotting Association met at the Grand Pacific to-night. There was an executive session which lasted two hours, at which the question of Secretary Vail's incumbency came up.

WASHINGTON, May 10.--Notwithstanding the unfortunate and confusing experiences of Mr. James W. Hyatt, of Norwalk, in undertaking to represent himself at his home as already appointed United States Treasurer, ...

ALBANY, May 10.--The bill repealing the life insurance tax of 1880 and remitting a million of dollars in taxes which have accumulated against these companies failed to pass the Assembly to-day by a large majority. During the afternoon and early evening a most remarkable change of front occurred among the members.

CHICAGO, May 10.--A few days ago the Central Traffic Association roads and the trunk lines decided to accept not less than 28 per cent. as their proportion of the regular through rates on transcontinental business.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 10.--The Spring meeting of the Louisville Jockey Club begins here to-morrow at Churchill Downs, and the prospects of a fine meeting and excellent sport are very promising. The track is slow to-day, but will be in fine condition to-morrow, as the weather promises to be bright and pleasant. There will be nine starters in the event of the ...

The electric light monopolists in the Board of Aldermen had a sharp tussle yesterday with a few honest members of the board, who were led by Aldermen Conkling and Van Rensselaer. The monopolistic brigade was led by Alderman Dowling, who is the recognized schemer of the present Common Council and who is known by a sobriquet of a not very complimentary character.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 10.--Widow Margaret Ernst, 72 years of age, was murdered in the basement of her house on Spruce-street early this morning. Her dead body was found by a milkman lying on a sofa.

ELMIRA, N.Y., May 10.--Gov. Hill, accompanied by W.L. Muller, Judge of the Court of Claims, arrived in Elmira on an early morning train, and both mere driven to the residence of R.R. Soper, business manager of the Elmira Gazette, on Columbia-street.

Mrs. Bertha Wagner, of 12 Market-street, who was made sole heir by the will of Edward Hen, the tobacco and pipe merchant, to his fortune of $2,000,000, has effected a settlement with the next of kin, who were ready to contest the will, and had retained Lawrence ...

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., May 10.--Capt. John A. Henriques, United States Revenue Marine, who has been supervising the construction of a coal depot at Wood's Holl, is ordered to the command of the steam cutter Commodore Perry at Erie, Penn. Lieut. A.D. Littlefield is detached from the school ship S.P. Chase and ordered to Wood's Holl.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal, May 10.--Drafts on NewYork-Sight, 15 cents: telegraphic, 20 cents.
The annual meeting of the Mercantile Library Association was held last night at the library in Astor-place.

Physically and mentally it was a fine audience that filled the rooms of the American Art Association last evening and assisted in making the last meeting of the Nineteenth Century Club for this season one of the most notable in the organization's history. Everybody, one gentleman excepted, was in evening dress, ...

Seldom has there been such a congregation of brokers on the floors of the Stock Exchange as were on hand yesterday at the opening of business. The announcement of the result of the annual election was awaited. The "independents" were victorious; with only one exception all their candidates were elected.

BOSTON, May 10.--Railroad deals are the order of the day, and the latest move of that description is one affecting the Boston and Providence Road. There have been strange fluctuations in the stock of that road for several days, fluctuations that have been all the more surprising as this is one of the most solid of the Boston stocks.
MONTREAL, May 10.--The Gazette to-day publishes an editorial warning William O'Brien that if he insults the Governor-General he does it at his own risk.
SEABRIGHT, N.J., May 10.--John Brehm was taken to the insane asylum to-day from Freehold having been crazed by the loss of money.

WASHINGTON, May 10.--At 10:30 this morning the Hotel Men's Association was called to order at Willard's Hall by President W.D. Garrison, who delivered an Earnest and impressive a address. He compared the association with other beneficial institutions, making a clear showing in its favor.
A fire broke out at 11 o'clock yesterday morning in a laundry in the basement of a three-story cottage at Avenue A and Eighty-fourth-street known as the Montefiere Home for Chronic Invalids.

John E. Develin presided over the County Committee of the County Democracy organization for the first time this year at last night's meeting of that body. The meeting was held in Cooper Union, and there was a large attendance.

The change in the management of Wallack's Theatre, the preliminary announcement of which was made exclusively in THE TIMES three weeks ago, was definitely made yesterday afternoon, when Lester Wallack and Theodore Moss, representing the present management, and Messrs. Abbey, Schoeffel, and Grau signed the contract which brought the negotiations to a ...
NEWBURG, May 10.--Mrs. Eunice Veltman, over 70 years of age, was killed this morning at Howell's Station by an Erie train. She was the mother of nine children.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 10.--The Advertiser's Wetumpka (Ala.) special says: "News reached this city to-day that Mr. Ross Powell, of Elmore County, a highly respectable citizen, had occasion to cross a field where Mr. Fallins with his two sons were working.

LOUISVILLE, May 10.--The sale of the Woodburn yearlings to-day, the property of A.J. Alexander, completed the Kentucky series of sales. Thirtynine youngaters were sold for $28,600, an average of $735. The animals sold, their breeding and the purchasers are as follows:
Miss Clara Morris will appear in "Article 47" to-night, in "The New Magdalen" Friday, and in "Camille" at the matinee on Saturday.

The approaching celebrations of the Queen's jubilee are full of a suggestiveness which cannot fail of fruition. The suggestion which comes most forcibly home in this American metropolis is that there ought to be a proper attention to the occasion by that class of Englishmen who, though compelled ...

LONDON, May 10.--In the House of Commons to-day, in committee on the Coercion bill, Mr. Healy moved an amendment that a person committed for contempt of court be treated as a first-class misdemeanant. He argued that witnesses committed for refusing to answer questions ...
The funeral of W.K. Thorn took place yesterday forenoon in Calvary Episcopal Church, at Fourth-avenue and Twenty-first-street.
ALBANY, N.Y., May 10.--The following reports for the quarter ending March 3 have been filed with the Railroad Commission:

BOSTON, May 10.--It seems that a few Boston speculators are really about to bore on an estate in Winthrop in search of natural gas. Those reported interested in the search laugh at the scheme one and all, but the attempt will be made just the same within a week.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 10.--The Democratic State Committee met here this afternoon and agreed upon Cleveland as the place for holding the State Convention on July 20 and 21. The politicians are here in consider force and the general talk is favorable to an aggressive campaign during the Summer.

MOUNT STERLING, Ky., May 10.--Squire Silas Stofer, who took the unusual course of liberating Mr. Cornelison, who was serving a sentence for his assault on Judge Reid, has been arrested on the charge of unlawfully aiding the escape of a prisoner. This proceeding is under a provision of the general statutes, and the trial will begin to-morrow.

The Seawanhaka Yacht Club's new house will be completed before May 24, and the organization expects to formally open it on that day. The house has already been described in THE TIMES. The club is in a remarkably prosperous condition and is growing rapidly. It has taken in, since the beginning of the year, 60 members, making now nearly 300 in all. The fleet numbers 110 vessels.

BUFFALO, May 10.--The jury in the great conspiracy trial acquitted three of the five defendants to-day by instruction of the court, because the allegations in the indictment were not sufficiently established. The men released from indictment are Henry H. Rogers, Ambrose McGregor, and John D. Archbold, all of ...

The body of Samuel Brown, a copyist in the Brooklyn Register's office for the last 10 years, was sound in Prospect Park yesterday with an ugly bullet hole in the right temple. Under the body was a revolver, with which Brown had shot himself.
BRUSSELS, May 10.--The bill fixing the duty on imported cattle was passed in the Chamber of Deputies to-day with amendmemts exsmpting cattle intended for re-exportation. The vote was 69 to 54.

The committee of Irish societies appointed to receive William O'Brien, the Irish leader, after five hours' search through the fog, succeeded in getting him off the Umbria at 11 o'clock Monday night and bringing him to the city.

The feeling that is very general in financial circles that the constant accumulation of money in the Treasury of the United States threatens a disturbance to the money market is not unreasonable, but it would be easy to yield too much importance to it.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 10.--Henry W. Clarke, Principal of one of the local grammar school, has been informed that his son, Lieut. Arthur H. Clarke, attached to the marine corps on the Iroquois, at Panama, committed suicide on Saturday.

HANOVER, N.H., May 10.--The most destructive fire that Northern New-Hampshire has ever known occurred in Lebanon this morning, breaking out is Mead, Mason Co.'s furniture factory at 1 o'clock. The adjoining buildings, also occupied by Mead, Mason Co., built of wood and filled with inflammable materials, were ...
It was just a year ago yesterday that "Erminie" was first seen at the Casino, in this city, and the anniversary of that production was gayly celebrated last evening.

We have referred more than once to the subject of disinfection at this port as connected with charges of conspiracy involving the Health Officer and certain political intrigues. The question has at last been submitted to a jury, whose verdict is very significant.

Anna Scheustaher, the little daughter of karl Scheustaher, was killed at the Rivington-street station of the elevated railroad on Dec. 19, 1883. The company's physician told the child's parents that the Manhattan would pay for her burial. Whereupon ...

WASHINGTON, May 10.--The President has appointed the following-named Postmasters: Samuel T. Kilpatrick at Irvington, N.Y., vice Charles H. Browne, removed; Peter Mckellar, Pawnaw, Mich., vice Robert O. Beebe, removed; J. Guy Hammer, Hailey, Idaho, vice Henry Bews, resigned.

Henry N. Smith, the veteran Wall-street operator, has just made an ineffectual effort to induce Judge Barrett to open the judgment of $906,236 97 which Adameon R. McCanless, the Assignee of William Heath Co., obtained against him.

WHEELING, West Va., May 10.--A double murder for purposes of robbing was perpetrated at the little village of Holiday's Cove, Hancock County, 39 miles north of this city, at an early hour this morning, the victims being Mrs. V.B. Baker and her mother, Mrs. Drusia McWha.

WASHINGTON, May 10.--Acting Commissioner Stockslager, of the General Land Office, has recommended to the Secretary of the Interior that the Attorney-General be requested to file a motion in the Supreme Court for reargument of the Maxwell land grant case, in which the decree of the Circuit Court for the District of Colorado was affirmed on April 18. Mr. Stocklager says:
CHICAGO, May 10.--The following telegram was received by the Associated Press today:

PARIS, May 10.--In relation to the dispatch from Berlin stating that experiments showed that melinite decomposes if kept long, and is therefore, of no use for war purposes, the Government assert that the substance experimented with in Berlin was not melinite and base their assertion on the fact that melinite is unknown in Germany.

BOSTON, May 10.--Queen Kapiolani visited the State House to-day. Senator Morse, of Canton, was right in the middle of a sentence when the Senate doors were thrown open, revealing Sergeant-at-Arms Adams in all the glory of his tall hat, ornamented with a rosette, and carrying the official mace.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 10.--The Rev. Stewart Means, Rector of St. John's Episcopal Church, was married this morning in St. Thomas's Church to Katherine Elizabeth, daughter of the late George D. Gower.

There was a large audience, and an extremely good-humored one, including actors, at the Star Theatre yesterday afternoon, when a performance was given for the benefit of Mr. C. W. Couldock, in commemoration of his completion of 50 years of service on the stage.

Thomas Moore, who stabbed Officer Lavin, of the Sixteenth Precient, Monday night, and was shot at four times by the officer, died yesterday at the New-York Hospital. His injuries had been supposed to be slight, but one of the shots had entered his abdomen, Lavin is recovering.
The following advertisement appeared in one of yesterday's papers:

At the meeting of the Rapid Transit Commission yesterday the President, E. Ellery Anderson, who was not present, gave an opinion in a letter in regard to bridges across West-street from the ferry houses over any elevated road that might be built.

CHICAGO, May 10.--The inter-State commerce law was the direct cause of two very large failures to-day, aggregating nearly $755,000, the firms being Schnabel Co., barb wire manufacturers at Deering Station, Ill., and Sherman Marsh, barb wire manufacturers at Grand Crossing, Ill.

The compositors employed by the NewYorker Zeitung, the office in which there have been several incendiary fires of late, are indignant that pertain papers have intimated that the fires were started by some one among their number.

All the officers of the Twenty-third Regiment of Brooklyn went to 106 Montague-street last evening to bid a formal farewell to ex-Col. Charles L. Fincke, who sails for Liverpool this morning on the Adriatic.

ALBANY, May 10.--The big legal fight over the Broadway Surface Railroad in NewYork was begun in the General Term to-day before Judges Learned, Landon, Bockes and is likely to last through to-morrow. It came up on an appeal from the decision of Justice Peckham in the case of the people against John O'Brien ...

The Pacific Railway Commission wanted to examine Amos H. Calef yesterday, but it had not succeeded in serving a subpoena upon him. Sergeant-at-Arms Walsh has had that task on hand since last Thursday. He told the board yesterday that he had made nine or ten vain efforts to serve the papers.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10.--A thin, graymustached man, who looked like a gentleman inspite of his threadbare clothes and hollow eyes, sat in the Central Station dock shortly after 2 o'clock this afternoon waiting for his hearing. He gave his name as George C. Harris, of 42 Pratt-street, Baltimore.
The Brooklyn Citizen, the organ of the local Democracy, published yesterday the official majority report which the Bacon investigating committe will present to the Legislature to-day.

The case of Catharine Quinn, whose conscience would not allow her to keep money that she recovered from the city for injuries received by falling on a defective side walk, made no progress yesterday toward getting the money from the priest to whom she intrusted it.

CHICAGO, May 11.--To-night the long, stubborn fight against T.J. Vail, Secretary of the National Trotting Association, was brought to a close. The case was settled in a closely guarded session of the association's Board of Review.

LONDON, May 11.--Mr. Ernest's ch. c. Van Dieman's Land, by Robert the Devil, dam Distant Shore, won the Breeder's Plate of 300 sovereigns at the New-Market meeting to-day. Hark second, Simon Pure third. The last betting was at even money against the winner.

CHICAGO, May 11.--Detective Mahon, of Washington, D.C., will start East to-morrow, with Charles Majors, the negro diamond thief, arrested here a day or two ago. Majors has partially confessed, and this has led to the recovery of the following jewelry stolen by him:

A meritorious collection of pictures by American artists, with here and there one by a foreigner, was offered for sale at the Ortgies artigalleries, 845-7 Broadway, last night. The pictures were generally very small, and on many of them it might be said they were mercy exercises.

BUFFALO, May 11.--The ninth day of the great conspiracy trial ended this evening, with Frederick G. Saxton, a Corry (Penn.) saloon keeper, on the witness stand. Although a witness called by the defense, he proved to be a boomerang, and upon cross-examination he recoiled painfully upon the defense.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 11.--The b.c. Montrose, the son of the Duke of Montrose and Patti, won the great Kentucky Derby. It was not a great race, but it was a pretty one.

The Cedarhurst Spring meeting closed yesterday, and, though Prince Leopold and suite were not there to see the fun, there was good sport. The attendance was greater than on any day of the race, and the bookmakers were hard hit by the fortunate backers of the short...

The growers of small fruit in the counties along the Lower Hudson have had occasion of late to complain of the inroads made upon their profits by increased use of gift packages instead of return crates.

A private letter from Henry Bell, brother of James Bell, owner of the Thistle, to a friend in this city, written two days after the launch of the cutter, says that she looked exceedingly well in the water and pleased all those interested in her.
The American Wall Paper Manufacturers' Association held its-regular monthly meeting at Delmonico's yesterday. It was attended by nearly all of the thirteen active members of the pool.

DETROIT, May 11.--Judge Cooley, President of the Inter-State Commerce Commission, is spending a short time at his home in Ann Arbor, and has given to a reporter some impressions with reference to the business and railroad situation that are of interest.

The body of Richard Westerman, of Jersey City, one of the four victims of the drowning accident caused by the capsizing of a sailboat off Communipaw on April 7, was found last evening. The body was entangled in a shad fishermen's net, and was drawn to the surface, No trace has been found of Westerman's companions, who were undoubtedly drowned at the time.

Mr. William Wall, a brother of Berry Wall and an ardent sportsman, was defendant in a dog case before Justice Murray, in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday afternoon. The complainant was a young lawyer named Henry C. Beach, who has his once in Room 13,...

New securities were listed on the Stock Exchange yesterday as follows: $6,500,000 additional 6 per cent, gold trust bonds of the Richmond Terminal Company, making $8,500,000 now listed; $3,805,000 additional 4 per cent.

Mme. Patti was slightly indisposed last evening, as placards at the Metropolitan Opera. House portals announced, and there was no opera. The box office was kept open for the return of money or the exchange of Wednesday night tickets for others, good for Friday night's performance.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 11.--The people around Warsaw, in Milton County, are exercised over the strange recovery of John Hendricks from a chronic rheumatic affliction. About 10 years ago Hendricks, who was a strong and robustman, a type of manly vigor, was arrested for illicit distillation.

Mrs. Annie E. Johns yesterday asked Judge Barrett to set aside the divorce which she herself got from her husband, Henry W. Johns, five years ago. She said that her brother, Henry Bachman; her counsel, Everett P. Wheeler, and...

The Federal Club expressed its apprecia-- tion of the Hon. Theodore Roosevelt by giving him a banquet at Delmonico's last night. More than 200 men of unquestioned standing in the business and professional life of the metropolis sat down at the six tables, which literally...

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 11.--Charles Deaken, of Susquehanna, who was swindled out of $20,000 by Charles F. Anderson, the spurious Michigan "Judge," has just arrived home from London, England, after having secured the punishment of the offender and recovered $2,000 of the sum of which he was fraudulently despoiled.
Edward Littell, a resident of Lincolnavenue, Orange, N.J., attempted to commit suicide early last night.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 11.--The Chronicle publishes an interview with Charles E. Locke, of the National Opera Company. In response to the question "Has the season here been satisfactory?"

ALBANY, May 11.--After a debate of over two hours the Senate to-day ordered the Ives Pool bill to a third reading by the vote of 16 to 13. The affirmative votes were cast by Senators Coggeshall, Hoysradt, Low, McMillan, and Worth, Republicans, and Senators Cullen, Daly...

HARRISBURG, May 11.--The Democratic State Central Committee met in this city to-day. Dallas M. Sanders in the chair, and 51 members being present. After a long and animated discussion Aug. 31 was decided on as the date for the state Convention.
Henry Hart, who owns more Pacific Mail Steamship stock than any dozen others of the company's shareholders, is much in earnest about reforming the management of that big corporation.
The attendance at the New-York Dairy and Cattle Show yesterday was about three times as large as it was the previous day. The result was that there was a large-consumption of milk and koumiss.
The committee which has in charge the coming billiard tournament at the Racquet Court Club, which is to decide the amateur championship of the United States and is to...

"The Hummocks" is the name given by the natives to a long low strip of marshy land abutting on Hempstead Bay, near Long Beach. Upon this narrow strip a number of one-story shanties have been erected by oystermen.

LONDON, May 11.--The House of Commons this evening resumed consideration in committee of the Coercion bill. Mr. Peter McDonald, Nationalist, member for North Sligo, moved the adoption of an amendment to the effect that the evidence of witnesses at preliminary inquiries should not be adduced against them except in case of perjury.

CHICAGO, May 11.--Chairman Midgley announces that the Southwestern Missouri River Roads have agreed to accept the regular pro rata on California traffic at the reduced through rates recently established by the transcontinental lines until the next meeting of the latter in this city on May 16.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 11.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. W.C. Ruger and associates present, the following business was transacted: No. 1,084--People, respondent, vs. John M. Schny1er, appellant--Argued by N.C. Moak for appellant, John Lansing, District Attorney, for respondent.

PITTSBURG. Penn., May 11.--This city has a nearly parallel case to that of Nina Van Zandt. W. T. Lavelle was convicted yesterday for robbing Pan Handle freight cars. During his trial a pretty girl named Vannie Hi11, his afflanced, has sat by his side in court.
The Vedder Liquor Tax bill having been made a party measure by caucus action, the Republicans of the Assembly are making great efforts to bring it to the front for the purpose of passing it.

NEW-HAVEN, May 11.--After the Sophomore games at the Yale field this afternoon T. G. Shearman gave an exhibition in running broad jumping. He was in fine form and cleared 21 feet 2 inches, breaking the Yale record and very nearly equaling the inter-collegiate record. The games resulted as follows:

NYACK, N.Y., May 11.--The Bristor case occupied the court at New-City all day, but the end has now come. The principal feature of today's proceedings was the testimony of the Rev. Dr. Bristor, who made a general denial of all the charges against him and said he had not influenced Ida Downs to make her retractions.

BOSTON, May 11.--The full bench of the State Supreme Court sent down a decision today affecting the rights of naturalized citizens, which pronounces unconstitutional the act of the Legislature of 1885, which provides that "no person hereafter naturalized in any court shall be entitled to be registered as a voter within 30 days of such naturalization."
Viscount Gen. T. Tani, Minister of Agriculture and Commerce of Japan, arrived at the Gilsey House yesterday from Europe, where he has been making a tour of observation.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 11.--Capt. Samuel H. Buck, Postmaster of New-Orleans, has forwarded his resignation of the office to President Cleveland and has accepted the Presidency of an Alabama land improvement company.

CHICAGO, May 11.--The clique in wheat returned actively to the market to-day, after several days' rest. All day long their brokers were sellers of June and July, and buyers of September and other distant futures. In the aggregate their transactions were very heavy.

Yesterday was the busiest day which Castle Garden has known during its entire history. Thirteen steamships, the majority of which had been detained off Sandy Hook since Sunday by the fog, came in together with an aggregate of 9,802 immigrants.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 11.--The case of the forger Blackwood has now assumed a phase never before known to international law. The spectacle is presented of a State becoming a litigant in one of the lower courts of a sister State.

Mayor Hewitt yesterday received a letter from a woman living in Hoboken asking him to send her "a fine gentleman husband, who is yet quite young, well and handsome of person, and naturally of a kind disposition, and whose personal property at his own disposition is valued at about $250,000, to marry me."

The annual meeting of the American Tract Society took place yesterday at the Madison-Square Presbyterian Church. The report of the Treasurer shows a balance of $1,279,54 on hand. The business of the concern has decreased within the past year $20,000.

Miss Helen L. Webb, daughter of Gen. Alexander S. Webb, President of the College of the City of New-York, was married yesterday to John Alexandre, son of Francis Alexandre, of this city, at the residence of Gen. Webb, 15 Lexington-av. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas J. Ducey, Pastor of St. Leo's.

The electric light "combine" in the Board of Aldermen was the talk of the city yesterday. The Aldermen who had followed the lead of Dowling were kept busy explaining their votes, and many of them were evidently greatly frightened at the developments that had been made.

WHEELING, West Va., May 11.--The evidence before the Coroner's jury examining into the murders of Mrs. Van B. Baker and Mrs. McWha, at Holliday's Cove, leaves no reason to doubt that Mrs. Baker's husband murdered the two women.
OTTAWA, May 11.--No little talk has been created in official circles over the announcement that the Imperial Government has sanctioned the Newfoundland Bait bill.
The Directors of the Metropolitan Opera House have been advised by their associate, Mr. Stanton, now in Berlin, that he has re-engaged Herr Anton Seidl as conductor for next season.

CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, May 11.--The first intelligence of the shooting of the Mexican army officers on account of the Nogales incident reached the public at this capital today and caused a profound sensation. Nothing was known of the execution of the sentence at the American Legation last evening.
"A.L.S."--Either form of expression is grammatically correct. Jacob Sharp's case has gone over until to-morrow. Then, it is believed, the jury panel will be drawn and the trial set down for Monday.

LOUISVILLE, May 11.--The Republican State Convention was called to order by Judge T.Z. Morrow, of Somerset, Chairman of the State Central Committee, at 12:10 o'clock today. The room was entirely filled with delegates and a number were standing in the rear. The gallery was about a fourth full.
Nearly all the prominent shots of the Coney Island Rod and Gun Club were present yesterday to compete in the first regular club match of the season and the first on the new grounds at Woodlawn.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., May 11.--Hundreds of thousands of eyes were turned anxiously toward Mahanoy City to-day, where the miners' committee met to deliberate on the replies made by the coal companies and operators to the demands for a 10 per cent, advance in wages.

MONTREAL, May 11.--Mr. William O'Brien arrived in the city at 8 o'clock this morning and was accorded a reception that was, to say the least, very tame. The gathering at the railroad station was a small and unrepresentative one, not a single prominent citizen being present.

WASHINGTON, May 11.--The President on several occasions since the adjournment of Congress has had his attention directed to reports and statements concerning an extra session of the Fiftieth Congress.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 11.--The cruiser Triumph arrived in port this evening after a nine day's cruise. She visited a number of ports and harbors and reports that American fishermen are conducting themselves to the entire satisfaction of the customs authorities.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 11.--Drafts on NewYork, sight 15 cents; telegraphic, 20 cents.
The Governors of the Stock Exchange have referred to one of their committees the consideration of a policy for the Exchange in conformity with the Saturday half-holiday law.

On Saturday evening last Messrs. Vaux and Burchard, of the New-York Canoe Club, while running to catch a train at West New-Brighton, were assaulted by two of the ruffians who have become so common on Staten Island recently.

The Paint, Oil, and Varnish Club of this city has appointed a committee to wait on the trunk line freight classification committee to secure relief from the apparent injustice caused by the recent reclassification.
PHILADELPHIA, May 11.--At the meeting of the Board of Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, this afternoon, the following resolution was adopted:

CALAIS, Me., May 11.--Calvin Graves, who was yesterday convicted of shooting and killing Game Wardens Niles and Hill, was yerterday sentenced to imprisonment at hard labor for life. The verdict was murder in the second degree.
BALTIMORE, May 11.--Racing was continued at Pimlico to-day, with the following results:

CHICAGO, May 11.--The General Passenger Agents of the roads in the Central Traffic Association to-day agreed to make a rate of one and one-third fare on the certificate plan for any regularly organized association where 50 or more persons will be in attendance, whether an association of business men or not.
The new law that reduces the price of gas in Brooklyn to $1.60 per thousand will afford some relief to consumers in that city, but the price should have been reduced to $1.25.

A great crowd of good-humored people assembled in the Windsor Theatre last night to see Miss Clara Morris depict the horrors of unrequited love and the discomforts of insanity.

FREEHOLD, N.J., May 11.--The counsel for the Law and Order League of Eatontown has drawn up a writ of certiorari to take the granting of the license to the clubhouse at Monmouth Park by the County Court yesterday to the Supreme Court at Trenton, returnable at the June Term of the full bench.

CHICAGO, May 11.--The bricklayers' strike began in earnest to-day, and before noon 500 men who had gone to work in the morning had been ordered out. By 5 o'clock this afternoon the number had increased to 1,200, and tomorrow the strike will be made complete on every job superintended by members of the Master Masons' Association.

FREEHOLD, N.J., May 1.--The Grand Jury came into court this afternoon with 64 bills of indictment. warren Leland and Ferdinand Crammer, proprietors of the Ocean Pier Hotel at Long Branch, were indicted for keeping a disorderly house. They sold beer on Sundays last Summer.

It took the Kentucky courts nearly three years to decide that JOHN J. CORNELISON, the brute who cowhided Judge. RICHARD REID and drove that sensitive gentleman to commit suicide because he was a law-abiding citizen and would not kill his assailant, as the public sentiment of the State demanded, should be punished by the slight sentence of three years' imprisonment.

CHICAGO, May 11.--The strike of the bottom filers, which took place last week in the blast furnace of the Calumet iron and steel mills, was last evening declared off by the strikers, who will return to work at once at the old rate of wages. General satisfaction is expressed over the speedy termination of the difficulty.

DETROIT, Mich., May 11.--A prominent officer of the Michigan Central Railway to authority for the statement that the Canadian Pacific Railway people have effected an arrangement with the Michigan Central by which they will be allowed to use the Central track between St. Thomas and Detroit. The Canadian Pacific is at liberty to make whatever arrangements shall best suit it for a road west of Detroit.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 11.--Crop reports from 60 counties in Minnesota, 40 in Dakota, and 35 in Iowa show that seeding throughout the Northwest is now completed, and under circumstances more favorable than in any previous season for years.

HARRISBURG. Penn., May 11.--The High License bill passed the Senate to-day by the decisive vote of 36 to 11, a result which surprised even the most sanguine friends of the measure. When it came up Mr. Reyburn, of Philadelphia, moved to strike out all after the enacting...

Mrs. Emma Waldron is 37 years old and lives on the third floor of 481 Hicks-street, Brooklyn, where she keeps house for a man named Lovett. Her husband, a painter, works on Coney Island and comes home Saturdays.

Miss Sophia L. Mattern brought only one witness against Russell Sage yesterday, and thus allowed her case to be closed in the most gracious manner and without a dissenting word. All the lady's excited manner had departed, and she was suave, smiling, urbane, and evidently well entertained yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 11.--Tha Edwin Hartt Sewing Machine Case Manufacturing Company assigned to-day. Liabilities, $15,000. Assets small. UTICA, N.Y. May 11.--Henry C. Anderson, of Rome, N.Y., hotel keeper, made an assignment this morning to D. Francis Searle, of Clinton, with preferences of $7,000.
The dog show and the horse show have now become annual institutions in NewYork. It is natural that the success of these should have aroused emulation among the breeders of cattle.

Peter L. Worth, a young Post Office clerk at Station D, got $40 a month for distributing letters to the carriers. He gave $30 to his mother and reserved $10 for himself. Peter went to the races, bought pools, wore expensive jewelry and altogether cut quite a swell.
WASHINGTON, May 11.--An army retiring board has been ordered to meet from time to time at Fort Leavenworth for the examination of such officers as may be ordered before it.

MADISON, Ind., May 11.--At Washington, Ind., James A. Cunningham, of this city, to-day got judgment against the Vincennes and Lafayette Railroad Company for $92,500 for the burning of a starch factory at Vincennes.

John Christian was Captain of a ship about six weeks ago that was bound for a port in Africa. Somebody got out an attachment on the bark for debt, and one day he tried to move his ship from a North River wharf, as he claimed, to aless expensive wharf at Staten Island, but, as the law officers on board the ship thought, to Africa.
The National Academy of Design had its annual meeting yesterday at the Academy building, corner of Twenty-third-street and Fourthavenue.

MURPHY'S, Cal., May 11.--News has just reached here to the effect that J.B. Fruchier, an American citizen, who left here last October to visit France, was seized on his arrival there and imprisoned. He was denied counsel and was forced to serve in the French Army. He is now in the Seventh Regiment of the line.

The difference of opinion in regard to the extension of the East River Bridge beyond Nassau-street, which was found to exist between Mayor Whitney and the rest of the Trustees at the meeting on Monday, will probably lead to the permanent retirement of the eight Trustees subject to appointment by the Mayor.
ST. LOUIS, May 11.--The Wool Growers and International Sheep Shearers' Association held the second annual convention at the Cotton Exchange to-day.
The proposition of Wallace Ross to row Willlam O'Connor three miles, for $500 a side, brought a quick response. On Monday we received by wire from Toronto:

At the regular monthly meeting of the Republican Club of the City of New-York last evening the report of the Committee on Constitution and By-laws, which was issued May 2, was discussed and acted on. The Hon. Giles B. Stebbins, of Detroit,addressed the club on "The Protective Policy."

FREEHOLD, N.J., May 11.--Monmouth County's new Board of Chosen Freeholders were sworn into office to-day by Judge Alfred Walling. The board organized with Capt. John H. Heyer, of Holmdel, as Director.
For several years the Yonkers Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children has claimed the fines paid by persons prosecuted through their agency.

DETROIT, Mich., May 11.--The new smelting works of the Calumet and Hecla copper mine at Groveton, near Lake Linden, were started up this morning.

Stung by the severe but thoroughly just criticism showered upon them by press and public alike, the New-York baseball players pulled themselves together and managed to defeat the Washington nine yesterday.

The Board of Street Opening and Improvement met yesterday in the Mayor's office to consider the Elm-street widening project. President Beekman of the Board of Aldermen said that the subcommittee to whom the matter was referred was not ready to report, and the matter was laid over.

BERLIN, May 11.--It is stated that the increase in the Russian duties on imports recently put in force has had the effect of bringing the German Government to a decision to increase the German duties on cereals from 3 to 6 marks as a reprisal.

WASHINGTON, May 11.--The hotel men took the town to-day. Last night's banquet convinced them that the capital had been made over to them in fee simple, and this morning they entered into possession. At 9 o'clock a long string of carriages left Willard's and about 75 of the visitors left for the Soldiers' Home.

STONY CREEK, Conn., May 11.--The funeral of Charles I. Way, the young station agent at this place, whose body was run over a short distance east of this station by the Shore line night freight Monday night, took place this afternoon in Madison.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, April 30.--Her British Majesty's iron ram Canada, with Special Commissioner Clement Hill, of the Foreign Office. London, on board, reached this port yesterday direct from Port au Prince.

MIDDLEBOROUGH, Mass., May 11.--Serious wood fires are raging to the southward, in South Middleborough and Wareham, destroying standing wood and cranberry bogs. Much alarm is felt tonight, as dwellings and valuable timber are in danger.
WASHINGTON, May 11.--The eighteenth reunion of the Society of the Army of the Cumberland was begun this morning at 10 o'clock by a business meeting at the new Grand Army of the Republic Hall.

Herdman Co., wholesale dealers in clothing at 433 Broome-street, have failed. The firm is composed of Ferdinand Herdman and Mrs. Rosa Schwab, the latter the wife of Leon Schwab, formerly of Siedenbach, Schwab Co., who failed several...

Mayor Hewitt's new Park Commissioners attended yesterday's meeting of the Park Board, and one of them, Theodore W. Myers, was chosen Treasurer. Matthew C.D. Borden was re-elected President of the board.
PaulKlemm, a bartender at Justus Schwab's saloon, 50 First-street, was arrested on April 16 for violation of the excise law. He was tried yesterday in the Court of General Sessions, Part III.
The Red Star steamship Belgenland, from Antwerp, drifted against the steamship Hartlepools at 11 o'clock Wednesday night while coming into Quarantine.

The Society of Medical Jurisprudence and State Medicine were treated to an able and exhaustive paper by Prof. Jarvis S. Wight, M.D., upon "The Legal Responsibility of Surgeans" at their regular meeting, held at the Academy of Medicine, in West Thirty-first-street, last night.

Mrs. Ida Morrell, a respectable young woman who keeps a small candy store at 344 West Thirty-seventh-street, went to Police Headquarters yesterday and made a serious complaint against Patrolman John Kennedy, of the Twentieth Precinct.

LONDON, May 12.--Mr. Parnell arrived at Euston Station this morning, having, according to his custom, slept on the boat from Kingstown the previous night. He had telegraphed to Henry Campbell, member for Fermanagh, his private secretary, to meet him with his letters.
DETROIT, Mich., May 12.--Ex-Gov. R.A. Alger has bought Munkacsy's famous picture, "The Last Days of Mozart," paying for it $30,000, and it will be presented to the Detroit Art Museum.

"The Lady of Lyons" with the thermometer at 80! Yet there was a fairly large audience at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre who followed the action of the old play attentively, and who, if not enthusiastic, were at least cordial in the matter of applause.
NEWBURG, May 12.--Canoeists along the Hudson River are preparing to hold a regatta on May 28 and 30 near Sing Sing.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12.--James N. Taggart, the Paying Teller of the Union Trust Company, who led a double life while robbing the institution of a big pile of money, and who fled when his crookedness was discovered, has been traced to Paris.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., May 12.--At an early hour this morning the visiting members of the Sixth Army Corps were on their way to the battlefield of Spottsylvania Court House. Many went by the way of Salem Church in order to see again the old shot-riddled structure near which Gen. Sedgwick's corps and a severe battle with Lee's forces in 1863.
The National Rod and Reel Association will hold its fifth annual fly and bait casting tournament at Harlem Mers, Central Park, on May 25 and 26, beginning each morning promptly at 10 o'clock.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 12.--Several weeks ago a rumor got out that a rupture had occurred between Bishop Dudley and the Rev. George C. Betts, of Grace Church.

During the second act of "A Scrap of Paper," at Miner's Theatre, in Newark, last night, Osmond Tearle threw a lighted piece of paper in a grate filled with savings, which blazed up, the flames communicating to the scenery.

People are learning that the cattle show is not in any sense an exclusive affair, but that it appeals warmly to the sympathy and possesses points of interest for all who use dairy products--in other words, to everybody.

In the trial yesterday, in the Court of General Sessions, of Morris Marx for the murder of Mrs. Anna Jakowski by throwing vitriol in her face last December, several witnesses testified as to finding the injured woman writhing in her bed after the vitriol struck her.
The Fitchburg Road and the Boston and Albany were represented yesterday at a meeting of the General Passenger Agents of the trunk lines at Commissioner Fink's office.

PARIS, May 12.--The sale of the Crown jewels seems to have excited more interest in America than it does here, where little is felt and still less manifested among the natives. From the crowds who visited their exhibition at the Pavilon de Flore the representatives of the so-called directing classes were persistently absent.

Dressed in a black Prince Albert coat, light pantaloons, white vest, and wearing a brilliant solitaire in a white tie, the three-hundred-thousand-dollar defendant in the McBride divorce case was conspicuous in the Supreme Court room yesterday. Still more attractive was the richly dressed, fair, and plump plaintiff.
LOUISVILLE, Ga., May 12.--In the Superior Court to-day Fred Morgan (colored) was convicted of murder and sentenced to be hanged on June 17.
There has been such close connection between the firms of David Dows Co. and David Dows, Jr., Co. that generally they have been considered as one.
NEW-ORLEANS, May 12.--Capt. Ottisen, the crew, and Timothy Moroney, owner, of the steamship Gulnare, arrived by the steamship Harold from French Harbor, Ruatan, this afternoon.

We do not think Mr. THEODORE ROOSEVELT helped the cause of the Republican Party very much by his speech of Wednes-- day evening, and we should say that it must be a matter of some surprise to many of his friends and of regret to others that he should have made it.

The little town of Boonton, N.J., has had a good many sensational rows in its time, but that which ended yesterday morning in the death of one of the most popular young men of the place set all the inhabitants talking.

The New-York Athletic Club will have its annual Spring games on Saturday, June 11, at the club grounds, Mott Haven, N.Y.
LONDON, May 13.--The steamship Arabic, (Br.,) Capt. Burton, sld. from Liverpool for New-York yesterday.
The ninety-eighth annual meeting of the Tammany Society was held last evening in the Fourteenth-street wigwam for the purpose of installing the 13 Sachems elected at the April meeting of the society.

BUFFALO, May 12.--In the conspiracy case to-day Mr. Thompson McGowan, of Cleveland, Ohio, an expert in oil manufacture, went on the stand and contradicted much of the testimony given by Prof. Hitt, of the Buffalo High School, regarding petroleum gases and vapors as to their explosiveness and combustibility.

King-Harman, and why Mr. Balfour shirked...

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday appropriated $16,000 for the employment of additional searchers in the Register's office.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12.--A fire occurred this afternoon at the glass works of Burgin Sons, on Montgomery above Girard avenue, causing a damage to the works and surrounding properties which will foot up to fully $50,000.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 12.--The hop growers Of Central and Southern New-York enter upon the season of 1887 Under discouraging circumstances.

QUEBEC, May 12.--The greeting which met William O'Brien on his arrival in this city might be regarded as a triumph. Of the 50,000 or more of a population here about 12,000 are Irish, yet it, seemed on the arrival of the train at the station as though the whole city had turned out to cheer and welcome him.

BUFFALO, May 12.--The Tioga, which left here for Chicago at 6 P.M. last week Thursday, passed the breakwater on her return trip at 7 o'clock tonight, making the fastest round trip on record, seven days and one hour.

KINGSTON, N.Y., May 12.--The West Shore Railroad runs through the centre of this city. The city extends from the Hudson River a distance of two and a half miles or so inland, and it so happens that all the churches are situated at the two ends, locally known as up town and down town.

MONTREAL, May 12.--The annual report of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company was made public to-day, and shows that the agreement entered into with the Government on Nov. 10 provided for the payment to the company of the balance of the cash subsidy, and for the release of $4,000,000 of the $5,000,000 of the land grant bonds held by the Government under...
Jacob Kopelski, a tailor, living at 86 Sheriff-street, went to Police Headquarters yesterday in search of his daughter, Wladislawa 17 years old, who had been missing since Saturday last.

The Southern Society of New-York proposes to erect a memorial tablet in bronze at the very spot where Gen. Washington bade adieu to his comrades is arms when on the point of leaving New-York for Annapolis, where Congress was assembling, to which body he intended to resign his commission.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 12.--The Republican State Convention adjourned at a late hour last night after completing the ticket by nominating W.H. Childers, of Pulaski, for Superintendent of Public Instruction, and T.J. Tinsley, of Muhlenburg, for Register of the Land Office, the latter in opposition to a colored man.

CHICAGO, May 12.--The noteworthy feature of the wheat deal to-day was a further heavy covering of shorts by St. Louis. Purchases on this account to-day and yesterday were said to have aggregated 9,000,000 bushels.
DOVER, Del., May 12.--The fruit growers of Delaware and Maryland met in convention here this morning. Many commission men from the Northern and Eastern cities were present.
SENORA, Ga., May 12.--Just at dark last night L.W. Couch ran upon T.N. Burdette, who was sitring in a store doorway.
The annual meeting of the American Bible Society took place yesterday at the Bible House, on Astor-place, Judge E.L. Fancher presiding.

Mr. Henry E. Abbey, manager of Wallack's Theatre, yesterday perfected arrangements with Miss Rose Coghlan by which she is to return to that theatre next season as leading lady of the new stock company which he is organizing.
The 12 ex-constables who arrived in this city from Ireland last week attended the reception given last evening by Company H of the Sixty-ninth Regiment to Joseph E. Haynes, the Mayor of Newark.

OMAHA, Neb., May 12.--J.H.N. Patrick sold his farm of 615 acres, adjoining this city on the north, to-day for $615,000. This is the largest real estate transaction ever made in Nebraska. Messrs. J.A. Allen and F.H. Underwood, of Kansas City, are the purchasers.

A "gentleman by birth without means" wants some one, presumably a gentleman by birth with means, to "place and maintain him in the New-York Athletic Club." This want was made known yesterday by an advertisement. The "gentleman by birth without means" offers two inducements to any philanthropico-athletic...

Garfield, raised by the Society of the Army of the Cumberland in honor of one of their comrades, was this afternoon uncovered with appropriate ceremonies, and accepted for the people of the United States by President Cleveland in a brief, comprehensive...

In the Hudson County Court of General Sessions, sitting at Jersey City yesterday, four boys named Andrew Horning, Robert Montgomery, John McGuckin, and Alexander Smith were convicted of an attempt to commit an assault upon Lena Wendling, a 12-year-old girl.
The case of Garret A. Hobart, Receiver of the First National Bank of Newark, against Mary A. Dovell and Louis Dovell, Executors, was on trial yesterday before Judge Depue in the Circuit Court.

CITY OF MEXICO, May 12--via Galveston. --This city was much startled yesterday morning by a report in the Two Republics that Arvizu, Gutierrez, and Rincon had already been executed in conformity with the sentence of the courtmartial before which they were tried. The report was wholly false.

Some time ago a suit was instituted by A. M. Palmer and Marshall H. Mallory, managers of the Madison-Square Theatre, against Thatcher, Primrose, and West, the minstrels, in which damages of over $7,000 were claimed for breach of contract.

CHICAGO, May 12.--The raft of mental scientists, faith healers, and the like which have recently sprung up in Chicago are greatly disturbed over a bill now well along in the Illinois Legislature, which, if it becomes a law, will make them no end of trouble.
Trouble was expected yesterday at Calvary Cemetery between the New-York and Brooklyn undertakers and the Newtown Board of Health.
