Mayor Whitney, of Brooklyn, is going to consult Corporation Counsel Jenks in regard to his action concerning the result of the Bacon investigation. "I shall act on Mr. Jenks's advice," said the Mayor yesterday. "Whatever he says should be done I will do."

PHILADELPHIA, May 12.--Ewing is beginning to play ball again, and fearing the substitution of another man at second base, is playing a game there with which no fault can be found, as yesterday's and to-day's games show.

Corporation Counsel Lacombe not objecting. Judge Barrett yesterday afternoon ordered the release of "Tom" Gould from Ludlow-street Jail. Mr. A.H. Hummel, Gould's counsel, promised that he would pay his fine, $250, and all the costs of the contempt proceedings.
DENNING, N.Y., May 12.--Trout fishermen here and elsewhere in the vicinity of the wilds of Ulster County are up in arms, and unless a settlement is effected there promises to be bloodshed.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 12.--A syndicate headed by Nathaniel Baxter. Jr., to-day purchased the daily American, newspaper, which will to-morrow be consolidated with the daily...
BOSTON, May 12.--There was a guest at the Parker House to-day that fairly divided attention with the dusky visitors from the Sandwich Islands.
The police force were employed yesterday in leaving cards at the houses in this city reciting the provisions of sections 95 and 96 of the Sanitary Code in relation to ashes and garbage.

GLASGOW. May 12.--The new cutter yacht Thistle has returned from a spin in the Clyde. A slight northwest breeze was blowing and the cutter carried a huge mainsail, a jibheaded topsail, a No. 4 jib. and a small staysail.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 12.--Harry Gorman, who has been a sailor in the United States and British navies, was killed at 3 o'clock this morning by William Higgins in a street brawl.
ALBANY, N.Y., May 12.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. W.C. Ruger, Chief-Justice, and associates present, the following causes were argued: No. 367--Bank of Batavia, respondent, vs....

The bark James A. Borland, which arrived yesterday from Nuevitas, ran into a large whale on May 6 on the edge of the Gulf Stream. The whale disappeared, but the water was stained with blood for a long distance Astern. No injuries were sustained for the Borland.

CALAIS, Me., May 12.-Everett White was burned to death in the fire at Shaw's tannery at Grand Lake stream yesterday. His remains, burned almost beyond recognition, were found in the ruins of the storehouse. He is supposed to have been engaged in removing leather when he was overcome by the smoke. He leaves a widow and seven children.
RONDOUT, May 12.--Queer things are being seen and caught in the waters of the Hudson River these days. At Esopus Island boatmen say that two Norway seals are now disporting themselves there.

Two weeks have passed since the publication of the President's letter of instructions to Secretary LAMAR concerning GUILFORD MILLER'S homestead and the opening of 100,000,000 acres of land to settlement.
The annual Commencement of the College of Physicians and Surgeons, which is the medical department of Columbia College, took place last evening at Steinway Hall.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 12.--The body of George M. Kraft, a restaurant keeper, who had been missing since Sunday night, was found to-day on a fisherman's hook in the Tennessee River. When last seen he was drinking and had a large sum of money in his pocket. Only $4 could be found on his body when it was discovered. He leaves a family at Manlewood, Mass.

Wednesday evening Thomas P. Dougherty, a broker, met his acquaintance, Col. Fitch R. Wilder, a grain dealer, in the corridor of the Gedney House, where both are guests, when the latter suggested that Mr. Dougherty should settle a small debt of $70, due from an account part of which had been paid.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 12.--Drafts on NewYork--Sight, 15 cents; telegraphic, 20 cents.
The sale of the collection of oil paintings by American artists, which was begun Wednesday evening at Ortgies's Art Galleries, 845 and 847 Broadway, was closed last evening.
District Attorney Martine yesterday sent to Mayor Hewitt a letter thanking the latter for his efforts to secure room in the General Sessions building for Part III of the Court of General Sessions.

Ira Shafer, the belligerent hero of the Cleary trial, sat at a window of the Manhattan Club Wednesday night and ruminated. Visions of the old days of chivalry floated through his brain, and the blood coursed swiftly as he thought of the deeds of derring-do accomplished in the times, gone, alas, forever.

ST. LOUIS, May 12.--James J. Busby, a bookkeeper for the grain firm of Sheridan Ryan, of 104 South Levee, asked several days ago for a leave of absence to attend the funeral of a friend, and has not put in an appearance at his desk since.

DETROIT, May 12.--The annual meeting of the Detroit, Lansing and Northern Railroad was held in this city yesterday. The annual report showed that the total length of road owned by the company is 221 miles, besides 48 miles operated under lease.

The Rapid Transit Commissioners decided yesterday in executive session upon the routes to be pursued by the proposed extensions of the elevated railroad system along the water front on the east and west sides.

ST. LOUIS, May 12.--The fight for the control of the St. Louis and San Francisco Railroad took a new and startling turn to-day. Fraud and conspiracy are charged in yesterday's election. Mr. Walter Delmar, of Oppenheim Co., figures as the aggrieved party.
In the McMahon-Flynn subway suit yesterday before Commissioner Shields. Frank Jenkins, a Wallstreet broker, testified that he had bad a conversation with Mr. Flynn on subway affairs.

A story to the effect that the District Attorney had secured two witnesses who could and would testify as to a direct deal between Jacob Sharp and Billy Moloney in the bribery of the 1884 Aldermen was telegraphed yesterday to an evening paper from Albany. Mr. Martine read it and said briefly, "Nonsense."

RED BANK, N.J., May 12.--George A. Longstreet, local editor of the Standard, was married this afternoon to Miss Harriet Hubbard at the residence of the bride's parents on Washington-street by the Rev. George H. Neal, Pastor of the First Methodist Episcopal Church. Mr. and Mrs. Longstreet took an evening train for a wedding trip to Washington.

CHICAGO, May 12.--Under its new tariff issued since the Inter-State commerce law became effective the Michigan Central has quoted a freight rate through from Joliet to seaboard points identical with that from Chicago.
Mme. Carola Malvina will give an entertainment at the Lyceum Theatre this afternoon.

The works of the Paterson Iron Company at Peterson, N.J., were entirely destroyed by fire at a late hour last night. The loss is estimated at $150,000. At 1 o'clock this morning the fire was under control, but all travel on the Erie Railroad, the tracks of which are near the works, was obstructed.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., May 12.--The public school at Bethel, near here, has been closed on account of an epidemic of scarlet fever among the school children. The disease has also spread into adjoining school districts.
The racing stables of the Hon. W.L. Scott, of Erie, Penn., reached this city yesterday and went at once to the Prooklyn Park, where the horses will run in the meeting opening to-morrow.

Gov. Hill having signed the bill permitting Mayor Hewitt, under certain restrictions, to permit the sale of beer where vocal or instrumental music is rendered, many applications for special permits were made at the City Hall yesterday.

Charles L. Boyd, who said he lived at 264 President-street, Brooklyn, reported to the police of that city last night the mysterious disappearance of his sister, Miss Kate E. Boyd, of Oakland, Cal. Mr. Boyd is a prosperous merchant,...
SAN FRANCISCO, May 12.--For several nights the temperature has been very low, and heavy frosts reported have caused fears for the grape crop.
Ex-Mayor Smith Ely, Jr., looking even thinner than usual, called with a friend on Mayor Hewitt yesterday. The ex-Mayor whispered into the Mayor's right ear.

The chief scandal in the passage of the bill by the Assembly repealing the life insurance tax law lies in the extraordinary change of front produced within a few hours on Tuesday afternoon and the means by which it was produced.

PARIS, May 12.--The action of the Budget Committee of the Chamber of Deputies yesterday, in declining to accept the proposal of Premier Goblet to reduce the Government estimates 13,000,000f. on the ground that still...

WASHINGTON, May 12.--It is not probable that the President will immediately make use of the power given to him by Congress to declare a policy of non-intercourse with Canada in order to secure prompt concession of the commercial privileges which Mr. Bayard hopes to obtain by...

The New-York Institute for the Blind, Thirty-fourth-street and Ninth-avenue, celebrated its fifty-first anniversary last night by an entertainment and exhibition given by the blind pupils of the institute.
Five of the six cables of the Baltimore and Ohio Telegraph Company which cross the Narrows from Staten Island to Long Island were injured by the anchor of an ocean steamer last Wednesday morning.

CHICAGO, May 12.--When Secretary Schoenthaler this morning wrote the following notice upon the blackboard in the Builders and Traders' Exchange the signal was given for the inauguration of the greatest lockout ever seen in Chicago:
BOMBAY, May 12.--It is reported that the rebels against Ameer have captured Kelat-iGhilzai and now surround Ghuzni. The Russians are rapidly bridging the Amoo-Darya River.

The Pacific Railroads Commission's investigations into elementary memory were important yesterday. Mr. Giovanni Morosini told how each partner in the old firm of W.E. Connor Co. attended strictly to his own business. Mr. Ruasell Sage tried to photograph a very faint mind picture of events seven years old, and Mr. Nathaniel Niles tried to call up his personal experiences as a Government Director of the Union Pacific Railroad.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 13.--Private advices received here state that the whaling bark Europa, Capt. Hall, with a crew of 32 men, has been wrecked off the coast of Japan near Hakodate. No particulars of the disaster have been received. The Europa was owned by Aiken Swift of New-Bedford, Mass. She left this port Dec. 12 last year.

Twenty-five persons were made sick, in some cases violently so, Thursday, from drinking milk which came from Stormville, Dutchess County, N.Y. A Harlem physician reported to the health authorities that afternoon that a woman was sick at 1,990 Second-avenue, and that the symptons were of sewer gas poisoning.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 13.--Both houses of the Legislature have adjourned until next Wednesday, and have voted to take a final adjournment at noon Thursday next. The Senate to-day concurred with the House in the bill freeing all toll bridges on the Connecticut River, the expense to be assessed on the towns benefited.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 13.--The Post Office at Shrewsbury was robbed last night of stamps and money to the valve of $550. The safe was blown open and the room thoroughly ransacked. The thieves forced an entrance through a cellar window. The work was done in a room directly under a tenement that is occupied by a family.

A party of friends of Frederick Schmalz rejoiced with him at the house of Dr. L. de Plasse, 58 West Twelfth-street, Thursday night, and wished him a safe survival of the dangers attending a trip to wicked Boston.
QUEBEC, May 13.--Lord Lansdowne is now in Toronto, and the news to-day regarding what will occur when Mr. O'Brien gets there to lecture on Tuesday evening is less warlike than it was.
TAYLOR, Texas, May 13.--A few nights ago seven men went to the residence of James Trim, south of town, called him out, and gave him a whipping.
The Ives pool bill has hit Brooklyn politicians pretty hard, and they could be heard swearing yesterday whenever the subject was brought up.

Two more suicides in Central Park yesterday make the unusual number of five within a month. Shortly before 5 o'clock in the morning a policeman saw the body of a man hanging from a tree near the arch opposite Sixty-second-street.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 13.--A special from Locust Point, on the shore of Lake Erie, near here, says: "The French settlers along the lake shore, in Erie Township, Ottawa County, a few miles east of here, were surprised and amazed last night over the appearance of an unknown fish of mammoth size.
BALTIMORE, May 13.--About midnight last night four men demanded entrance to the house of James Porter, a miserly farmer, who lives near Whiteleysburg, Caroline County.

While laborers were excavating a cellar at Tenth-avenue and Seventy-fourth-street yesterday they unearthed a rather curious fossil, about 30 inches in circumference, having very much the appearance of a skull.

C.L. Boyd, whose sister Kate arrived at the Grand Central Station on Tuesday, and then disappeared completely from the sight of her friends, is a Seventh Day Adventist, and was to have sailed to-day with a party of 17 others to do missionary work in South Africa.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 13.--The Cedar Lake shops of the Minneapolis and St. Louis Railroad were destroyed by the early this morning, together with a number of freight cars. The loss on the shops is estimated at from $35,000 to $50,000, and on freight care and contents $25,000. Shortly after this a boarding house at 206 Sixteenth-avenue, South, burned, and Mrs. Matt Johnson was rescued so badly burned that she cannot live.

RED BANK, N.J., May 13.--The Women's Christian Temperance Unions of Monmouth County held their annual convention in the rink at this place to-day. There were 150 delegates present from the 18 unions in the various towns.
PORT TOWNSEND, Washington Territory, May 13.--Particulars were received here today of the burning of the four-masted ship Ocean King, of Coos Bay.
Mayor Whitney of Brooklyn, Mayor Hewitt of this city, and other officials met in the New-York City Hall yesterday and heard arguments for and against the proposed bridge ...

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 13.--The National WoolGrowers and Sheep-Shearers' Association met at the Cotton Exchange this morning, and, after listening to speeches and passing resolutions, recommended the appointment of a committee of five ...
PARIS, May 13.--There were fewer police officers and more private persons present at the sale of the French Crown jewels to-day.

ST. LOUIS, May 13.--Mr. St. John, Gaudaur's backer, received a telegram from Hanlan to-day agreeing that the great race for the American championship with Gaudaur shall be rowed at Pullman, Ill., on Decoration Day. All arrangements are now perfected, and Gaudaur will at once proceed to Pullman and finish his preparations. Fred Plaisted writes that the champion is in fine form and rowing 10 miles a day.

The law permitting the Mayor to issue permits for the giving of concerts to places that already have licenses from the Excise Board for the sale of beer aims at a proper purpose and is founded upon a sound principle.
Mayor Hewitt, under advice of Corporation Counsel Lacombe, yesterday granted permits to have music and beer in Sulzer's Harlem River Park and in Lion Park.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 13.--The cornerstone of the Leland Stanford, Jr., University, perhaps the most magnificently endowed institution of learning in the world, will be laid at Palo Alto to-morrow morning.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., May 13.--A hearing in the reference case for a partition of lands owned by Jane A. Porter, of Niagara Falls, a lunatic, represented by the Hon, Benjamin Flagler, of Suspension Bridge, as committee of person, and Mrs. Frederica P. Burnall, sister of Miss Porter, residing in London, England, was had here to-day.

MONTREAL, May 13.--The long-expected statement of the Bank of Montreal was made public to-day, and it shows an improvement on last year and is said to be nearly as good as was expected, yet the effect has been to cause disappointment, as the market is weaker this afternoon. The following is a summary of the statement:
CHICAGO, May 13.--The Supreme Council of the Catholic Knights of America concluded its biennial session to-day.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 13.--The city physician was called to the East Side flats yesterday to visit Joseph Anderson, a Norwegian. The man was found to be a victim of leprosy. He is 36 years of age, but has the appearance of being an old man.
TEXARKANA, Texas, May 13.--James Jones (colored) was hanged here at noon to-day for the murder of Cate Hicks in Bowie County last August. Two thousand persons witnessed the hanging.
The ferryboat Alaska, of the line from Williamsburg to Roosevelt-street, and the sidewheeler Morrisania, of the old Harlem line, came in collision off the foot of Market-street yesterday morning.
CHICAGO, May 13.--An evening paper prints a half column of interesting gossip concerning the wheat deal, extracts from which are given below for what they are worth:

With the close of the cattle show to-night an exhibition will end which has been in the highest degree creditable to the breeders of this section. The effort to make a fine display has been encouraged and the show has served as a public educator.

There was a well attended meeting of the Master Plumbers' Association last evening at 54 Union-square, to take action on Mayor Hewitt's letter in regard to trades unions. The committee appointed to draft an answer presented a report, which was read and approved.
NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., May 13.--A pretended army officer has been here this week playing a number of insane freaks upon traders and other citizens.

A benefit entertainment was given yesterday afternoon at Chickering Hall to the Martens Damen --Frau Martens-Emes, and Fraulein Emma Elsner. The programme was much clipped, only 12 out of 19 numbers being given.

PITTSBURG, May 13.--The Post will tomorrow publish the result of a canvass of the Democratic editors and County Chairmen of Pennsylvania supplemental to its previous canvass of the Democratic members of the State Legislature.
PHILADELPHIA, May 13.--An extensive strike was begun to-day among the hand-loom carpet weavers employed, in the shops where the manufacturere intend to enforce the recent reduction.
ALBANY, May 13.--The following is the report of the Sixth-Avenue Road, of New-York, for the quarter ending March 31:
WORCESTER, Mass., May 13.--Robert Kane, charged with disturbing the peace by crying "scab" during the strike at Heywood's boot and shoe shop, was to-day convicted in the Superior Criminal Court.

A young girl went to the Morton House at 11 o'clock Thursday night and registered as "Miss M. Cottrell, Newark." She was given a room on one of the upper floors, and nothing further was heard from her till yesterday morning, when the odor of escaping gas from her room attracted the attention of a porter and at the same time that of Mr. T.F. Ames, of Albany, who occupied an adjoining room.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13.--Detective Spittall, who chased J.N. Taggart, the defaulting Teller of the Union Trust Company through Canada, has forwarded photographs and descriptions of the fugitive to the police officials of the principal cities of Europe. Taggart, who left Halifax on an Allan Line steamer, and is now believed to be in Paris with his companion, 15-year-old Margerie Harris is safe in his refuge abroad, as he cannot be extradited on a charge of embezzlement.

The Spring meeting of the Brooklyn Jockey Club opens to-day and a programme including six races is offered for the amusement of patrons of the new and very pretty track. Superintendent Brush has everything in excellent condition and excellent sport is a certainty.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 13.--Although the Russian Government has treated Sir West Ridgeway, the Chief of the British Commission on the Afghan frontier dispute, with the utmost courtesy since the arrival of himself and colleagues here early last month, it refuses to abate any of its claims.

The Metropolitan Transit Company did not meet with much success yesterday in defending itself against the attack of Robert and Ogden Goelet, James A. Roosevelt, and their associate property holders on Broadway.
CHARLESTON, S.C., May 13.--For the past four years the negro has been a thorn in the Episcopal flesh of South Carolina. Once a year he turns up smiling at every Diocesan Convention that is held.
WASHINGTON, May 13.--Col. George Gray, of New-York, and Mr. W.K. Mendenhall, of this city, counsel for the Northern Pacific Railroad, will tomorrow have a conference with Secretary Lamar ...

MERIDIAN, Miss., May 13.--At a public reception given Mr. Jefferson Davis here yesterday morning he made a speech the memorable part of which was its closing words. After drawing a picture of the heroism of the South during the rebellion he said:

BOSTON, May 13.--The Harvard class races were rowed on the Charles River late this afternoon, with tide and weather favorable. Immense crowds witnessed the race from the river banks, from the roofs of buildings along the water front, and from tugs chartered by the friends of the respective crews.
CHICAGO, May 13.--At the very lowest estimate 20,000 men employed in the building trades will be idle to-morrow.

Mrs. U.S. Grant has been very ill for a week, but last night she was resting comfortably and the crisis had been safely passed. Mrs. Grant's health has not been good since the beginning of the Winter.
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 13.--A verdict will probably be reached in the great conspiracy trial to-morrow. The defense have practically closed their case.

ALBANY, May 13.--Quick work was made of the Ives Pool bill to-day. At 12:45 o'clock it had been re-engrossed and was in the Governor's hands. The Governor has fixed a nearing on it for the afternoon of Monday, May 23.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., May 13.--Prohibition having gone into effect here on May 1, under local option, the Law and Order Association has engaged Detective Jules Giquel for another year and promises to put more vigor into its work.

Jacob Sharp's trial will begin Monday morning at 11 o'clock. When Judge Van Brunt opened the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday morning District Attorney Martine immediately moved that Sharp's trial be set down peremptorily for Monday. Mr. Stickney had no objection to offer. Judge Van Brunt thereupon set the case down for that time.
NEWPORT, R.I., May 13.--It is stated upon excellent authority that Willie Sprague, son of ex-Gov. William Sprague, and grandson of the late Chief-Justice Chase, is to sue for divorce.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 13.--On March 28 a committee of Republican members of the Legislature requested Senator Sherman to address that body on national politics before the adjournment.
"People who must trouble about something are asking what we are going to do in July," said Prof. Rossiter W. Raymond at the crowded prayer meeting held in Plymouth Church last night.
PALATKA, May 13.--A petition was sent to-day to the Inter-State Commerce Commission, remonstrating against the suspension of the fourth clause of the Inter-State Commerce act.
According to recent advices from Pernambuco the idea of a federation of provinces, with a large measure of self-government for each, is steadily gaining adherents in that province.
PHILADELPHIA, May 13.--The Philadelphia Times to-morrow will say that Fairman Rogers and A.J. Cassatt went to New-York City this morning.
In the appeal by the Knickerbocker Fire Insurance Company from the decision in its certiorari proceedings to review the action of the Commissioners of Taxes in the imposition of ...

Among the passengers that arrived yesterday by the steamer Trave was Mme. Adolfine Ziemair, a singing soubrette from Germany, who has come here under contract with Gustav Amberg to appear in his new Summer theatre, the old Terrace Garden.
HAVANA, Cuba, May 13.--Regarding the announcement that the storekeeper of the Almacenes de Depositos (Warehouses) had absconded with a large amount of money, it has been learned ...

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 13.--Sir Charles Tupper, Minister of Finance, in his budget speech early this morning, dealt with the fishery question in a manner which has raised hopes in political circles that the Canadian Government will not make a complete back down.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 13.--Archbishop Leray received yesterday from Rome a commission by which Dr. Thomas Layton, of this city, was promoted from the rank of Knight to that of Commander of the Order of St. Gregory the Great.
The Emperor and Empress, with their personal and medical attendants, removed from Petropolis to the Aguas Claras plantation, about 60 kilometers beyond Petropolis, on the 11th inst.
A letter has sent by the Excise Commisioners yesterday to the Police Board in reference to the place known as the Chelsea Garden, at 112 West Thirty-third-street.

CHICAGO, 13.--A youth of the name of Ford, not yet 19 years old, recently caused the managers of the Palmer House some uneasiness, and subsequently tried to swindle two or three business firms out of small sums.
At 5 o'clock yesterday morning as Milkman Aaron P. Quimby was passing through Lakeside-avenue, in Orange, N.J., his horse shied.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 13.--In the case of the Rev. W.R. Goss, of the New-York Conference, who has been on trial here for some days past by a select committee of the Conference, a result was reached to-day in a verdict of acquittal of the charges of immoral conduct made against him.

WASHINGTON, May 13.--The talk about Mr. Cleveland teing better than his party, which has been heard so frequently of late, may be alluring to his opponents, and is indulged in by them so uniformly as to justify the belief that it is expected to prove useful in driving the Democrats away from him as a candidate for renomination.
The first relay of the Manhattan Athletic Club's team which is to compete in the English championship games will start for England on the Umbria this morning.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 13.--The steamer Acuba, of Philadelphia, for Sydney, has arrived at Louisburg with her propeller broken by ice. Heavy ice prevented her getting to Sydney. The ice is packed solid on Cape Breton and many vessels are on the coast.
BOSTON, May 13.--A dispatch has been received in this city stating that the ship Ocean King, the largest American ship afloat, had been burned ...

The American Cattle Trust promises to become an interesting example of a new class of commercial organizations, or conspiracies, whose power and characteristics are most forcibly shown by the history of the Trust which has established a monopoly of the petroleum business in the United States.

The Senate has persisted in its practice of ignoring the interests of the public and the wishes of the local authorities of this city and yielding to the behests of corporation lobbyists, and has passed an act to give new life to the cable railroad scheme.

Just think, ye New-Yorkers, who dote on the turf and the joys thereof, just think of this for a spectacle: Russell Sage, Wall-street king, perched behind a flying four-in-hand and dashing around Fleetwood's race course bent on breaking a record.
DOVER, N.H., May 13.--A peculiar occurrence, a death and a marriage in the same house at almost the same time took place here.
CAIRO, May 13.--In the new convention between the Porte and Great Britain it is agreed that the period of the British occupation of Egypt shall be not less than two and not more than five years.
CHICAGO, May 13.--The Chicago Civil Service Reform League has written a letter to Mayor Roche urging him to introduce the merit system in making appointments to office.

PEORIA, Ill., May 13.--It is believed here that the whisky pool will be reorganized at once. The distillers are said to have a big scheme on hand. They have not increased capacity materially since the pool suspended.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 13.--Two heavy seizures of smuggled opium, estimated at 5,000 pounds, worth $50,000, were made to-day by Custom House officers on the dock of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 13.--The special committee of the National Amateur Athletic Association, to whom was referred the appeal of Malcolm W. Ford, of the Brooklyn (N.Y.) association, from the decision of the Executive Committee, have been in session in this city two days, and to-night announced their decision to sustain the action of the Executive Committee in displacing Ford from the amateur ranks.
LINCOLN, Neb., May 13.--The Board of Railway Commissioners of Nebraska has forwarded communications to the General Managers of the Burlington and Missouri River and Union Pacific ...

PHILADELPHIA, May 13.--New-York's victory yesterday must have been well celebrated by Ewing last evening, for he played a miserable game to-day, making four errors readily and being responsible, with O'Rourke's assistance, in losing the game.
CHICAGO, May 13.--T.S. Gardner and his wife, proprietors of the Farm Journal and the Farm Album, were before United States Commissioner Hoyne this morning charged with fraudulently using the mails.
NORWALK, Conn., May 13.--The friends of the Hon. James N. Hyatt are making preparations for giving him a banquet in honor of his recent appointment to the United States Treasurership.

In Central Park, to-day, the New-York and Riverside Cricket Clubs will have a practice game, in Prospect Park the Manhattan Cricket Club's first eleven will play a match with the Almas, of Newark, ...

A mysterious disappearance which attracted considerable attention in Brooklyn 20 years ago was cleared up yesterday. In April, 1867, George H. Kirkland, 15 years old, left his mother's home, at 248 Gold-street, and was never heard of again.
Staten Island was invaded yesterday by Columbia College boys on their way to the Athletic Grounds, where their thirty-first field meeting was to be held.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 13.--For some time past a feud has existed between John Turner and Jesse Edgeman, residing near Lincoln, Lincoln County.

The life-saving stations on the New-Jersey coast from Cape May to Sandy Hook were closed on May 1. Superintendent John G.W. Havens's report shows that during the year 69 vessels received assistance and many lives were saved by the crews of the stations at the risk of their own.
ALBANY, N.Y., May 13.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. William C. Ruger, ChiefJustice, and associates present, the following business was transacted:

Since the new ferry from the Battery to Thirty-fourth-street, Brooklyn, has been in operation the Brooklyn, Bath and West End Railrord Company has wanted to lay tracks through Thirty-fourth-street from their main line on Fifth-avenue to the water front.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 13.--John B. Franchier, the citizen of California who last November went on a visit to his parents in France and was forced into the French Army, has written to an old friend here stating that after sojourning a week at his old home in Saint Martin he was seized by gendarmes, court-martialed and imprisoned ...

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 13.--Prof. E.E. Barnard, of Vanderbilt Observatory, has discovored another comet. It is situated in that part of the sky between the Centaur and the Scorpion, and is moving slowly toward the northeast.
BALTIMORE, May 13.--The Spring meeting here closed to-day, the horses leaving this evening for the Brooklyn track.
LIMA, May 13, via Galveston, Texas.--The Government and the Mole and Dock Company of Callao have made a contract ad referendum for a modus vivendi until Congress meets.
The West Shore Railroad will put additional sleeping cars on its through trains between this city and the West--beginning to-morrow.

The police Captains, under instructions from Superintendent Murray, yesterday told their men that all persons having fruit and fruit stands or bootblacking chairs which were outside of the "stoop line" were to be instructed to remove them. If than did not do so they were to be arrested.
FARMINGTON, Me., May 13.--A dispatch from Rangeley, received at noon to-day, announces that the ice has just left the big lake and that all the lakes will be clear by Sunday.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 13.--There was a slight shock of earthquake at Summerville, and a slight rumbling at Charleston last night. The vibration was not greater than would be caused by a loaded wagon passing along the street.
PHOENIX, Arizona, May 13.--Leah Diaz, the Apache Indian, charged with the murder of Lieut. Mott, United States Army, on the San Carlos Reservation, has been convicted of murder in the first degree.

Chief-Justice McAdam made the opening speech at the dinner of the Thirteen Club, at Morelli's, in West Twenty-eighth-street, last night, and Gen. Winfield, District Attorney of Hudson County, N.J., addressed the diners.
NOGALES, Arizona, May 13.--The following dispatch was received from Gov. Torres yesterday:

WILMINGTON, Del., May 13.--Peter J. Ford, of the Ford Ryan Morocco Company, and an extensive real estate owner, contractor, and builder, failed to-day. His liabilities are about $100,000, and his assets $80,000. The judgment creditors, representing about $85,000, are thought to be protected. The failure does not affect the financial standing of the morocco company.
WASHINGTON, May 13.--Capt. F.W. Elbrey, Surgeon, has been ordered to appear for examination before the Army Retiring Board in this city.
The National Academy of Design held its annual reception at the art rooms, at Twentythird-street and Fourth-avenue, last evening.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., May 10.--The season at these world-renowned springs is at its highest pitch. Seven thousand visitors, health and pleasure seekers, are registered at the hotels, which are crowded to overflowing.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 13.--Several towns and villages in the eastern part of this State are suffering from a plague of caterpillars. Trees, bushes, and shrubbery are loaded down, and fences and houses are covered with them.

The Police Commissioners, at their meeting yesterday, decided that the annual parade of the police should take place on May 31. Invitations will be sent to President Cleveland, Gov. Hill, members of the Legislature, Board of Aldermen, and heads of departments to review the parade from the Worth Monument.
Some of the results of the President's action in the Guilford Miller case can already be seen.

WASHINGTON, May 13.--Inquiry at the Department of State regarding the British vessels seized in Behring's Sea last Summer discloses the fact that no demand has ever been made by the British Government for the release of the vessels, nor has any claim for damages caused by the seizures been made upon the Government of the United States.

MONTREAL, May 13.--Four young Americans, named A.M. Strickland, F.E. Cole, Martin Prendergast, and John Donnelly, all employes of the Hochelagos cotton factory, were upset on the St. Lawrence River this afternoon and Prendergast and Donnelly were drowned. The others were rescued unconscious.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 13.--Dispatches received to-night from a dozen points in the Northern Michigan Peninsula and the Wisconsin counties adjacent are to the effect that the forest fires are increasing.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 13.--Exchange--Sigh drafts on New-York, 15; telegraphic, 20.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 13.--An attachment in a suit for $1,000,000 brought by Clinton J. Farrell, Receiver of the Bankers and Merchants' Telegraph Company was served upon the local office of the Western Union to-day.
ROME, May 13.--The Pope will, it is announced, communicate at once with Archbishop Corrigan, of New-York, regarding the case of Dr. McGlynn.

In the rooms of the New-York Chess Club on Second-avenue last evening the second teams of eight players each from the New-York and Manhattan Chess Clubs contested the second series of the match games of 1887.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 13.--A colored child who went last evening with a party of blackberry pickers on the Daigre place, 10 miles below Baton Rouge, was torn in pieces by wild animal supposed to be a panther.

LONDON, May 13.--The May Stakes of 700 sovereigns, for 2-year-olds, run at Windsor to-day, was won by J. Porter's Mon Droit, by Isonomy, dam. In Bounds, Anarch second, Princess third. The betting was twenty to one against Mon Droit.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, May 13.--Isaac Hartshorn, aged 55, a wealthy resident of the Peninsula, committed suicide to-day by taking poison while laboring under temporary aberration of mind resulting from illness.

The University of Pennsylvania nine is having great trouble to arrange games with the College League teams. Yale cannot get permission from its Faculty to come here, and cannot afford to offer Pennsylvania sufficient money to ...

WILMINGTON, N.C., May 13.--Spirits of Turpentine firm at 31 c. Resin firm; Strained, 85c.; good Strained, 90c. Tar firm at $1.17 . Crude Turpentine firm; Hard, $1.20; Yellow Dip, $2; Virgin, $2.30. Corn steady; White, 57c.; Mixed, 54c.

The fog which hangs over the management of the Pacific railroads was just about as dense as ever last night. Three witnesses had appeared before the investigation commission during the day, and one of them had answered many questions, but the flood of light had not come.
NYACK, N.Y., May 13.--An extraordinary streak of hard luck in a family at Tompkins Cove is reported here to-day. Mr. Henry Roderman is a prosperous shipbuilder at that place and well known.

LONDON, May 13.--Mr. Edward Samuel Norris, Progressive Conservative, member for the Limehouse Division of Tower Hamlets, asked the Government in the House of Commons this afternoon whether, in the event of the passage of the Coercion bill, they would consider the question of recommending to the...

An iron lighthouse for the Government, which is to be placed on Anclote Key, a narrow sand strip lying between Cedar and Tampa Keys, on the west coast of Florida, has just been completed at the Colwell Iron Works on Twentyseventh-street.

ERIE, Penn., May 13.--The citizens of Erie met this evening in the Park Opera, House to unite in a protest against the Coercion act now pending before the British Parliament. Mayor J.C. Brady presided.

Col. J.C. Reiff returned yesterday to this city from Texas, where he has been spending the past fortnight upon concerns of the St. Louis, Arkansas and Texas Railroad Company, of which he has just been elected a Director.

Mme. Patti's recent indisposition did not prevent her from being in most excellent voice last night. She was welcomed by a large audience when she tripped to the footlights of the Metropolitan Opera House as Violetta in the first act of "La Traviata."
SANDWICH, Mass., May 13.--The extensive forest fire which has prevailed on Cape Cod since Wednesday is thought to be now under control.

The Clearing House Association met yesterday and discussed the half-holiday law. Then it adopted a resolution that, there appearing to be nothing in the legal requirements of the act that conflicts with the rules of the association, "the members of this association continue ...

The trials of the suits of Alfred W. Young, Ruth Torbett, Jennie and Jessie Woods, and Jessie Watson, the discharged and unpaid chorus singers, to make the American Opera Company settle their indebtedness to them, took ...

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., May 13.--News has reached here that a desperate fight took place yesterday among the silver miners in the mountains about 16 miles from this city, in which a noted miner and proprietor, J.A. Wilson, was killed. It is supposed that the trouble grew out of disputes over some mining claims which Wilson was working. Officers have gone to the seat of war.

BOSTON, Mass., May 13.--The Supreme Court, in a decision just sent down in the cases of S. P. Train against the Boston Disinfecting Company, says that the Board of Health has the right to make that regulation that rags brought from a foreign port shall be disinfected, and that the board has the right to impose the expense thereof on plaintiff and to subject the rags to a lien therefor.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 13.--An important life insurance case, which has attracted much attention and discussion throughout the country, was decided in the United States Court to-day by Judge D. M. Key.

CHICAGO, May 13.--After an exciting passage with State's Attorney Grinnell, the defense in the boodle cases to-day consented to the swearing in of four jurors, and succeeded in having the bailiff removed who has heretofore been selecting panel men.

WASHINGTON, Ind., May 14.--The saddest tragedy that ever happened in Daviess County occurred last night. It was the accidental shooting by William H. Sanford, Sr., of his son Hamlet, aged 16 years. They were spending the night in a house on Mr. Sanford's farm near the city, and the boy, in a somnambulistic spell, got up and went out into the yard.

To draw the chain of evidence as closely as possible around Chamberlain and Taylor, the self-confessed murderers of Mrs. Ernst at NewHaven, Inspector Byrne telegraphed the Chief of Police at New-Haven yesterday morning to send to this city the handkerchiefs and the chisel found in the room where the murder was committed.

NORWALK, Conn., May 14.--A banquet to United States Treasurer James W. Hyatt was spread at the Norwalk Hotel this evening, and more than 80 citizens and invited guests were assembled in honor of the guest of the evening.

WASHINGTON, May 14.--The death of Justice William B. Woods, of the Supreme Court of the United States, at his residence, in this city, at noon today, was by no means a surprise to those who have known his condition for a year or more.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 14.--John C. Brown, of Davenport, late Justice of Sessions of Delaware County, and a noted politician, has just brought suit in the Supreme Court against William Duffus, a note broker, of Syracuse, for $30,000 for alleged defamation of character and false imprisonment.

The good citizens of Pamrapo were preparing for a little festivity last evening, to which they feel they are justly entitled. Four weeks ago old John Bnskirk, a colored oysterman who for 20 years lived with his son in a cozy little house between Bayonne and Pamrapo, returned to his house after an absence of about an hour, to find it in flames.

BOSTON, May 14.--There died in Boston to-day a man to whom belongs more justly than to any one else the honorable title of the Father of Cheap Postage in America. This was the veteran Lysander Spooner, who passed away at his home on Myrtle-street at the age of 79.

For the first week in May the Lake Erie and Western Road earned $31,313, an increase of $5,010 over the same week in 1886; East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia, $81,105, an increase of $11,863; New-York City and Northern, $9,725, a decrease of $602.

Dry Monopole yesterday ran the greatest race of his life, and in so doing not only won the rich Brooklyn Handicap, but lowered the record for one mile and a quarter to 2:07. Up to yesterday the record had been 2:07 , Binette having first run the distance in that time on the track of Washington Park, Chicago, July 12 last.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 14.--J.H. Dickhaut, who is to be graduated from the Reformed Theological Seminary next Thursday, has been instructed by the Faculty to change the subject of his address. He was to have delivered an oration on the proposal, made in the Independent, to unite the Reformed and Presbyterian Churches.

The Merrimac-Monitor Panorama at Madison-avenue and Fifty-ninth-street is as popular as ever in this the second year of its existence. The exhibition building is always comfortably filled, but is now crowded in the afternoons by people who after visiting Central Park take the opportunity, while in the vicinity of the panorama, to witness the famous battle between the ironclads.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., May 14.--The jury in the case of Isaiah Jones, an old man who fatally stabbed Stephen Adams in a saloon at Mahanoy City in April last retured a verdict this afternoon of voluntary manslaughter, with a recommendation to mercy.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 14.--A special from Lima says that the producers in the Allen, Wood, and Hancock County oil fields are organizing a union similar to the Producers' Exchange in Pennsylvania, and that they intend to get a fair price for the oil. Pipe lines to Lake Erie and the refineries are planned, each oil producer to be a stockholder in the new exchange.

The Spartan Harriers met yesterday at Peteler's South Beach Pavilion Hotel, near NewDorp, Staten Island, for their regular bi-weekly paper chase. The hares--Messrs. W.E. Knox, August Kitchelt, and John Hatton--started at 5 o'clock, followed 10 minutes later by the pack in charge of Edward Weinack, Mater and Louis Sharp, and "Jack Bell" as whippers-in.

A quaint advertisement of 1703 informs all and sundry desirous to pass from London to York that on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays they may be received into a stage coach, "which performs the whole journey in four days, if God permits."

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 14.--At the annual convention of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers, to be held next month in this city, an entirely new scale will be drawn up equivalent to an advance in wages all round of 10 per cent. The new scale will be almost the same as the one in force during the year 1883-4.
Paul Bauer, who was stricken with paralysis a few weeks ago, is better, and yesterday was able to go about his hotel at Coney Island, but he knew none of his old friends.

LONDON, May 14.--London was ablaze with excitement this afternoon, the occasion being the visit of the Queen for the purpose of opening the People's Palace at Mile End. The route selected for the royal progress extended from Paddington Station, in the western portion...

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 14.--A telegram from Gaudaur to-day states that he and Plaisted will leave Washington for Pullman next Wednesday. Mr. St. John, his backer, says that Pullman is destined to be the great rowing centre of the United States. The Mississippi Valley Amateur Rowing Association...

ALBANY, May 14.--The worshippers in the Catholic Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception were startled about 6 o'clock this evening by two pistol shots which disturbed the quiet of the great edifice. A puff of smoke by a confessional box near the altar drew their attention in that direction.
William R. George, of 24 Lincoln-place, Brooklyn, who is the Secretary and Treasurer of the Empire State Iron Company, at 121 Liberty-street, was a prisoner in the Tombs Police Court yesterday.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 14.--W.H. Murchison, of Madison County, had a stroke of paralysis in his throat 58 days ago, and has not been able to eat or drink since that time. Strange to say he is still alive and is cheerful. He converses freely with his friends and fully understands his condition. He prefers death but it does not come.
The Schlaraffia Nova Yorkia, a social club, composed of German actors and journalists and other men of kindred pursuits, had a banquet last evening at Dilky's restaurant, on Third-avenue.
The charge that sour and putrid hams are sold to an enormous extent in New-York is made in a long letter to the New-York Market Journal by L.J. Callanan, a butcher at 41 Veseystreet.

The O'Brien Reception Committee met at the Hoffman House last night to arrange a reception for Mr. O'Brien upon his return from Canada. A telegram was expected from him saying when he would return, but it did not come, and no time was fixed for the reception.
TERRE HAUTE, Ind., May 14.--This city is to have the biggest distillery in the world, having a maw that will receive 7,500 bushels of grain a day.

The Manhattan Athletic Club held an invitation meeting for its members on the club grounds at Eighty-sixth-street and Eighthavenue yesterday afternoon. Every seat on the grand stand was occupied and a band played popular selections in the intervals of the games. All the events were handicap, and two--the 440-yards' run, and the 1-mile walk--proved highly interesting.

The first great cricket match of the season was played yesterday at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, when the Manhattan Cricket Club's first eleven competed with the Alma Club, of Newark, and won a well contested match by 23 runs in a single inning game.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 14.--The Grand Jury of the Criminal Court late this evening returned six indictments against David P. Hadden, a member of the three Police and Fire Commissioners and President of the taxing district.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 14.--Three weeks ago Edward T. Wheeler, a Baltimore architect, while visiting Philadelphia was knocked down and robbed of $340 and some jewelry. Ever since that time he has been melancholy, whether from the robbery or not is not known. His business has been prospering and the loss of a few hundred dollars was not serious to him.

The river and harbor improvement work in the vicinity of the city is at present going on somewhat slowly, owing to the fact that the last session of Congress did not result in adding to the appropriation for that purpose.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 14.--Judge Sloan this morning granted a stay of proceedings until the next term of the Supreme Court in the Grottkau case. The Judge did not occupy the bench, as the matter was settled at Assistant District Attorney Turner's office, only the attorneys being present. Grottkau's bail was fixed at $2,000.

RALEIGH, N.C., May 14.--Secretary Harrell, of the North Carolina Teachers' Assembly, will leave this city to-night for Washington to invite President Cleveland to visit the assembly during the coming session at Morehead City, June 14 to 29.

CHICAGO, Ill., May 14.--The National Educational Association, which will meet in this city July 12, will open with a reception in the Exposition Building Tuesday evening, July 12, at which it is thought the entire body, consisting perhaps of 10,000 teachers, will be present.

FRANKFORT, Mich., May 14.--The propeller George D. Sanford caught fire on Lake Michigan yesterday afternoon, scorching her cabin and destroying a quantity of freight. During the accident Watson McGregor, son of the Captain, fell overboard and was drowned.

Henderson, Chairman of the Democratic Central Committee, and now Deputy Commissioner of Internal Revenues, came all the way out here to see that his town went for the party.
PARIS, May 14.--At no time in years has the city of Paris been uneasier and more perplexed than now. The recent municipal elections have not reassured the public.

The body of Henry P. Smith, one of the men who committed suicide in Central Park on Friday, was taken from the Morgue yesterday afternoon by his friends. Mr. Smith was about 30 years of age and unmarried. He had been employed during the last 15 years in Wall-street by numerous firms, but of late has been speculating for himself.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 14.--The Federal Grand Jury has been at work all the week in the investigation of the tally-sheet forgery, and it is believed that a more thorough and impartial inquiry is being made than has ever before been attempted. The records of the State or of the county will scarcely show one more determined effort to thwart justice than has been made in these celebrated cases.

BRISTOL, R.I., May 14.--The steamer Empire State, which has been lying at the wharf of the railroad company during the Winter past, was totally destroyed by fire this morning. The fire was discovered about 1 o'clock.
WASHINGTON, May 14.--President Cleveland, it is commonly remarked since the unveiling of the statue of Garfield, saved this ceremony from being a dismal and utter failure.

The protracted hearing in the McBride divorce suit before Judge Ingraham, in Part IV, of the Supreme Court, ended yesterday. The court room was crowded as it had not been before since the case was called.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 14.--During a dispute at the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad shops here this morning Thomas Beresford, signaler, was accidentally pushed upon a buzzaw by a fellow-laborer and terribly lacerated. The saw cut through his back into the chest cavity. He cannot recover.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 14.--This fashionable Summer resort is attracting much attention just now. The Summer of 1887 is near at hand and many prominent families from all sections of the land will visit the city to enjoy its invigorating breezes and to spend their money freely among the townspeople who are anxiously awaiting their arrival.

LOUISVILLE, May 14.--The races here to-day were run with the following result: Half mile, for 2-year-olds. Santaline won, Balance second, Little Virgil third. Time--0:51 . Truxillo, Cast Steel, Miss Ruth, Beggoyet, Vateo, Contraband, Pride of the Great, Tenpenny, Aberdeen, Fleika and Tommy Collins also ran. Betting--Six to one against Santaline, five to eight on Truxillo.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14.--In the Spring contests of the Athletic Association of the University of Pennsylvania today W.B. Page beat all previous American records in the running high jump by clearing 6 feet 1 inch, thus eclipsing his performance at Wilmington, Del., a week ago, when he jumped 6 feet inch. Creditable records were also made in the various other contests.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14.--John L. Brewer, the champion trap shot of New-Jersey, in reply to William Graham's offer to give $200 to any man who will defeat him in a pigeon-shooting match under English rules, announces his willingness to accept the offer and will meet Graham on any date between May 25 and May 30.

A remarkable story is told of a woman's freak which brought her a surprise she had not counted upon. The story comes from Oakland. Frankie Brown fell heir, on the death of her father some years ago, to a comfortable fortune of perhaps $50,000.

LONDON, May 14.--The race for the St. George's Plate of 500 sovereigns, for 2-year-olds, five furlongs, was won by E. Jones's b.c. Admiral Benbow, by Victor II., out of Sultana, by a head, Lord Calthorpe's Toscano second, J. Porter's Mon Droit third. The betting was four to one against Admiral Benbow, five to two against Mon Droit. There were eight starters.

CHICAGO, Ill., May 14.--This morning some workmen found the body of Isaac Moore floating in the lake. Mr. Moore, who was a member of the firm of Moore Brothers, furniture dealers, disappeared from his home on May 6. A diligent search was instituted, but without result. Mr. Moore had been in bad health for some time, and his brain was thought to have been affected. The body when found showed no marks of violence.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., 14.--At a dinner to W. Frederick Layton, who is about to sail for Europe, last evening that gentleman stated that he had made his will and among other things gave $100,000 in cash for the maintenance of the art gallery which he is now erecting to present to the city.
BALTIMORE, Md., May 14.--Cardinal Gibbons is expected to arrive in Baltimore on the 7th of June. The Catholics are already making arrangements on a large scale to receive him with unusual honors.
BUFFALO, May 14.--The great oil conspiracy case is now in the hands of the 12 good men who have sworn to pass upon the evidence without bias or favor toward either side.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 14.--Bishop Ireland reached home this morning from Europe. He was received with warm welcome and was presented with a handsome carriage and a pair of fine horses by friends, regardless of denomination.

Mary E. Carpenter was put under $700 bail in the Yorkville Court yesterday to keep the peace for a month toward Lillie E. Bentoil, of 241 East Thirtyfourth-street, who is living, Mrs. Carpenter says, with the letter's husband, John G. Carpenter. She could not give the bonds and was locked up.

HANOVER, N.H., May 14.--The managing editor and business manager of the AEgis, the college journal, having furnished an apology for the publication, and delivered up for destruction the unsold copies of that periodical in which the President was attacked, the Faculty of Dartmouth College have changed their punishment from "separation" to suspension until the annual examination in June.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., May 14.--A mass meeting of citizens to-night by a nearly unanimous vote decided to urge the Legislature to pass an amendment to the city charter giving the city permission to vote bonds to the extent of $500,000 for the purpose of bringing natural gas into the city to offer free as an inducement to manufacturers. Assemblyman Frost attended the meeting, and will introduce the bill on Monday.

The first lacrosse match of the season betwen the New-York Athletic and Princeton Lacrosse teams was played yesterday at the St. George's Ground, Staten Island. When the game began Princeton got the ball and at once pressed the New-York goal.

The residents of Fifth-avenue, between Ninth and Thirteenth streets, are in a particularly unfortunate condition, just now. The street has been torn up for repairing, the sidewalks are almost blocked by huge piles of granite paving stones, and the butcher, the baker, and the candlestick maker--to say nothing of more important purveyors--have no means of approach to the houses. In addition to this there is no immediate prospect of the situation being altered.

The Cheribon is a big French steamer that brings Italian emigrants from Naples to New York. The law says that she may carry 739 passengers. Eugene Antoni, her Captain, packed 1,158 men, women, and children into the Cheribon on Feb. 23 and brought them over the sea.

Only a few weeks have elapsed since the world of archaeology was highly interested by the news of a most important archaeological "find" in the neighborhood of the ancient Sidon. The discovery was made by Dr. Eddy, an American missionary, who resides at Saida.

About 2,000 people surrounded the basin of Henry Piepgras's shipyard, at City Island, yesterday afternoon, and declared with one voice that Mr. Oliver Iselin's new steel sloop Titania was one of the most beautiful specimens of marine architecture they had ever beheld.

TUSCOLA, Ill., May 14.--A remarkable case is that of Mrs. Hughes, widow of John Hughes, who died yesterday in Sargeant Township. A few months ago she received a stroke of paralysis, but her early recovery was looked for.

BOSTON, Mass., May 14.--The friends of Franklin J. Moses, the lawyer and ex-Judge and ex-Governor of South Carolina, have made application to Gov. Ames and the Council for a pardon. Moses, in October, 1885, was sentenced to three years in the State prison, having been convicted of forgery. It is stated that he is in poor health.
BOSTON, May 14.--The Harvard lacrosse team this afternoon defeated the Stevens Institute team of Hoboken, N.J., by a score of 6 goals to nothing.

The news that the Mayor and the Superintendent of the Bureau of Incumbrances intended making general raids upon the newspaper and bootblacks' stands throughout the city excited much apprehension on the part of the keepers or owners of these alleged street obstructions.

Judge Barrett has denied the application of Mrs. Annie E. Johns for the setting aside of the absolute divorce which she got five years ago from Henry W. Johns for infidelity. This was a most extraordinary application.

FOTT SNELLING, Minn., May 14.--Although the court-martial trial of Lieut. Wilcox, Seventh Cavalry, ended on the 5th inst, the findings have not yet been made known from department headquarters at St. Paul, and it is believed that the sentence involves a dismissal from the service, in which case the action of the President is necessary.

UTICA, N.Y., May 14.--The Grand Jury to-day handed up an indictment against Chael Roark, charging him with robbery in the first, degree in stealing from the West Shore Railroad Company's ticket office at Utica station on the night of Tuesday, March 15 last, and threatening Ticket Agent Barger...
An adventure with a shark occurred at Black Point, on Saturday, March 12. On that evening Mr. Justice Boucaut was fishing in his dingey, but without much sport, save in small sharks and dog sharks.

The last of the Mohicans' "high jinks" dinner of this season will take place at the club's rooms, 31 West Twenty-seventh-street, this evening. Mr. Edward Aronson will preside, and the Hon. Frederick G. Gedney is to be High Jinks.

CHICAGO, Ill., May 14.--Lillian Snavely Watson's jewelry, taken from her by Watson after he had decoyed the girl into marrying him, has been recovered through her attorney. Lillian's adventure with Watson and Davidson cost her about $3,000 week. Watson will be released from the Bridewell on Tuesday, where he was sent for an assault upon his pal. Davidson.

The Spring time table of the Central Railroad of New-Jersey takes effect Monday, May 23. The most important changes will be between New-York and Philadelphia by the Bound Brook route. The express train now leaving the foot of Liberty-street at 7:45 A.M. will be changed to 7:30 A.M. A new train will be put on the road leaving this city for Philadelphia at 3 P.M. The train now leaving at 4:30 P.M. will be discontinued.

BLUE SPRINGS, Neb., May 14.--A terrific cyclone swept over this town at 4:30 last evening, blowing down the schoolhouse, which is a complete wreck. School had been dismissed a few minutes before, and the only occupant of the room was W.H. Rambaugh, janitor.

The last day of the cattle show was the best of all. When the show ended last night the manager was complacent and the breeders greatly encouraged. Minor vexations of the show were forgotten in the consciousness that it had been a success in every respect.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 14.--The Granite Mountain mine millionaires have all served notice on the city that they will move to New-York within a month if the law requiring mining stock to be taxed is enforced. L.M. Rumsey, President of the company, yesterday transferred 31,000 shares of the market value of $1,900,000 to his brother-in-law in Detroit to evade taxes. The tax on this amount is about $44,000.

The commission appointed to consider the feasibility of a bridge or a tunnel over or under the East River from the foot of Grandstreet, this city, to the foot of Broadway, Brooklyn, Eastern District, concluded its report yesterday, and it will be presented to the State Legislature to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, May 14.--Capt. L.A. Beardslee has been ordered to attendance on torpedo instruction, Capt. G.C. Wiltse to command the receiving ship Franklin, Lieut. D.L. Wilson to instruction in torpedo service, Lieut. Harry M. Hosley as inspector of steel for the new cruisers, Surgeon B.F. Rogers to duty at the Marine Rendezvous, NewYork; Cadet Engineer Frank H. Conant to duty on board the Quinnebaug.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 14.--Drafts on NewYork--Sight, 15c.; telegraphic, 20c.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 14.--The insurrection among the South Carolina Episcopalians against the negro is alarming. Bishop Howe said to-day that it was the most serious breach that has taken place in the century that this doicese has been in existence.

Such success attended Miss Juliet Corson's recent lectures on gas-stove cookery, delivered at the Metropolitan Assembly Rooms, that at the request of several ladies the series was begun again at the Lexington-Avenue Opera House yesterday afternoon. Nearly 800 ladies, mostly residents of the apartment houses in the neighborhood, were present, and they showed great interest in the exposition of a gas stove's possibilities.
TUCSON, Arizona, May 14.--Three distinct shocks of earthquake were felt here between 1:30 and 2:25 P.M. yesterday, but no damage was done. Shocks were also severely felt about Tombstone.

Mead Tooker, Bernardo Palacio, Antonio Quijano, J. van D. Reed, Vicente Gutierrez Palacios, Harris Newmark, Henry Goodkind, Fischer Glove, F.G. Cunningham, Jacquin Belagver, S. Brentano, and L.F. Delisle.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14.--At 7 o'clock this morning 10 gentlemen in light-colored coaching coats, a gaily bedecked guard, the Greyhound's white body and drab wheels, and four prancing horses enlivened the pavement in front of the Brunswick, in New-York.

LONDON, May 14.--It is a poor week when you cannot find some able informant who knows just when the long advertised general European war is going to break out and can trace into futurity the precise train of events which are going to precipitate the crash.
Aromantic issue to a recent Nihilist trial is reported from Moscow. The accused was a medical student who had been detected while attempting to conceal explosives in a private house.

A strange story of human sacrifice comes from the Madras Presidency. A woman was supposed to be possessed with a devil, and in consequence to have remained barren. Her father consulted an exorcist, who said that a human sacrifice was necessary.

The ceremony of the reception and profession of novices took place yesterday in the chapel of the Dominican Sisters' Convent, 137 Second-street, near First-avenue. There were nine young candidates, dressed in satin bridal robes, with lace veils and orange wreaths.

MONTEAL, May 14.--A private dispatch received in this city this afternoon says that the Whole valley of the St. John River is inundated and an immense section of the finest part of New-Brunswick is threatened with a terrible disaster.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 14.--Delta Phi. the oldest and wealthiest of the seven secret societies represented at Rutgers College, will erect a large and handsome chapter house on Bleeckerplace, opposite the college. The building will be of pressed brick, will cost $13,000, and the cornerstone will be laid during the Commencement season, Ground is to be broken for the foundations at once.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 14.--The Rev. Bayless W. Hanna, the Minister to the Argentine Republic, is expected home shortly, and the people of Crawfords ville are preparing to give him a public reception. Hanna is one of our diplomatic jewels.

Miller Hoy, who keeps a confectionery store in Cohoes, showed signs of insanity this morning and had to be removed to his home. A physician said he was suffering from acute insanity and will recover.

The New-York branch of the Collegiate Alumnae Association had its quarterly meeting at the Hotel Brunswick yesterday afternoon. Eight colleges for women are represented in this branch of the association, and about 75 members were present yesterday.

Herbert Newcomb and George Weiman, of Boston, appeared at the Astoria Police Station yesterday and told Capt. Woods they had been robbed in a boat on the river by two young men whom they met in this city.
BALTIMORE, May 14.--Detective Gault left to-night for Buffalo to bring to this city R.M. Green, who was arrested at that place yesterday afternoon on account of a telegram sent by Marshal Frey.

WILKESBARRE., Penn., May 14.--A young and beautiful girl about 18 years of age arrived at the Luzerne House last night and registered as Miss Fairbanks, of Nanticoke.

CHICAGO, May 14.--The Builders' Exchange formally indorsed the action of the Master Masons' Association in declaring a lock-out until the bricklayers came to their senses, and in unmistakable terms declared its intention to break down the power of arbitrary trades unionism.

BURLINGTON, Vt., May 15.--Mrs. Catherine Rood, of Essex Junction, died at the residence of her son at that place to-day, aged 103 years and 7 months. She was one of the oldest persons in the State and the oldest member of the Methodist Church in Vermont, having become a member of that denomination over 70 years ago.

Miss Helen Graves, age 46 years, a lady known in educational and society circles from one end of New-Jersey to the other, met with a very painful accident at the Market-street station of the Pennsylvania Railroad in Newark early last evening.
ST. LOUIS, May 15.--A terrific electric storm passed over the city between 3 and 4 o'clock this afternoon, killing two men, injuring several others, and doing an immense amount of damage.
SMYRNA, May 15.--Several earthquake shocks have been felt here during the past week. BERNE, May 15.--The people by a plebiscite have ratified the spirit Monopoly bill by a large majority.
Manager E.G. Gilmore has decided to sue Mrs. Langtry for his services to her as her manager, and to include, as defendant, Frederick Gebhard, whom he considers to be her partner.

LAREDO, Texas, May 15.--Heavy rains fell througout the Rio Grande Valley last night, continuing for four hours. The Rio Grande began rising very rapidly about midnight, and by noon today had risen eight feet. One of the largest ferryboats on the river was sunk and the Custom House was washed away to-day.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 15.--Seven hundred ore handlers at Ashtabula, employed by different railways, struck yesterday for an increase of 20 cents a ton. The advance they demand is about 20 per cent. Business on the docks there is at a standstill.

The principal event among the kickers of the leather sphere this week will be the departure of the Alma (Newark) Club, of the American Football Association, for Canada on Thursday. It is late in the season for football, and the three matches they will play will prove rather exhausting.

Students of the fine arts hailing from America have so often given a good account of themselves in Europe that the story of their triumphs is stale. Not so with science. It is rare that an American reaches high honors on the other side of the water for work done in his adopted country.

Many strange things have been unearthed within the past few weeks at Point Rincon by railroad graders. Pockets containing Indian skeletons, shells, and bones of sea monsters have been struck by men while engaged in excavating.

The Mohican Club ate their final dinner of the Spring last evening at 31 West Twenty-seventhstreet. A big crowd of the members was present, and they had a hilarious time. It may have been a dry Sunday elsewhere, but it wasn't there. Judge F.G. Gedney was "High Jinks" and Edward Aronson President.

BOSTON, May 15.--The Episcopal Church of Methuen has got into a pretty little quarrel over the question whether high church or low church principles shall predominate. Just now the high church element has the upper hand.

The Central Labor Union, which allowed itself to be led by the Socialistic element to denounce the Musical Mutual Protective Union because the Carl Sahm Club, composed of Socialists and Anarchists, had a grudge against it, acted on sober second thought yesterday and reversed its former action.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15.--The American ship Charles H. Marshall, which cleared London on Dec. 5 for Philadelphia or New-York and passed the Isle of Wight on the 15th of the same month, has not been heard of since and she has been given up for lost, with her crew of 23 men.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 13.--The strike at the mines of the Acadia Coal Company, of NewYork, situated in Picton County, Nova Scotia, is over. The men had been out about five months. They go back at reduced pay.

Eminently successful is the popular verdict on the exhibition at the Academy of Design which closed on Saturday night. That must be the verdict of the artists also, for the sales have reached a sum over $4,000 greater than the total of purchases from the exhibition last Spring.

A well attended meeting of the Anti-Poverty Society was held last evening at the Academy of Music. Henry George, after briefly going over the objects of the society, as at its previous meetings, answered several questions which were put to him by persons in the audience.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 15.--Developments of last night and to-day expose a condition of demoralization in the management of the Indianapolis Baseball Club that was unexpected even by those nearest the directory. President Newberger has announced his determination to resign, and it is expected that he will withdraw from active connection with the club within a few days.

Two Bucks County girls, Miss Sophia Stover and Miss Belle Hinkle, on Tuesday of last week walked from New-Britain to Philadelphia and made a very good record. They were up bright and early, and started at 4:45 in the morning. They reached Edge Hill by 9 o'clock, and got to Philadelphia at 12:45. Twenty-five miles, more or less, is the distance.

Queen Kapiolani rose early yesterday morning and sat at her Fifth-avenue window, in the Victoria Hotel, for a long time, busy watching a New-York Sunday unfold itself in Madisonsquare. She breakfasted in the public dining hall of the hotel, but there were few guests in the room.

The entries for the Racquet Club amateur billiard tournament, which is to begin next Monday, are O. Oddie, Jr., of Brooklyn; J.E. Soule and L.A. Flanagan, of the Philadelphia Union League Club; Alexander Morten, of the Racquet Club, and Charles F. Jones, of this city. The committee having in charge the arrangements for the tournament have several other names under consideration, and at its meeting to-day will probably admit two or three more contestants.

C.H. Bliven, the young man who has been mixed up in the case of Miss Frankie Bell, of Brooklyn, has found the doors of many of his old friends closed against him. Even his appearance in the Academy of Music on Thursday night, when the Amateur Opera Association, of which he was Secretary, gave a benefit for the Beecher monument fund, excited some disagreeable comment.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 15.--Stagg, Yale's pitcher, has received a telegram from James O'Rourke, the baseball player, asking whether he would enter the professional ranks, and telling him that he might join the New-York Club on his own terms. Mr. Stagg has no present intention of accepting any offer. He had already refused to join the Indianapolis Club.

ITHACA, May 15.--Cornell students and Alumni are much interested in the trip which the university baseball nine are now taking to Eastern colleges, as it is the first trip of the kind the nine have made. They will play with the Amherst men at Amherst to-morrow; with the Yale men at NewHaven on Tuesday, and with the Harvard men at Cambridge on Thursday.

An ingenious young man, who took tho precaution not to patent his scheme or even to advertise it, posted himself yesterday near the New-York end of the Thirty-fourth-Street Ferry. Quite as many funerals as usual crossed to Long Island by the ferry yesterday; in fact it was a good day for funerals by this route.

Julia E. Miller, a girl 18 years old, was shot in the head at Jersey City last evening by her betrothed, Frederick C. Kull. The shooting occurred at the girl's home, 294 Grand-street. Kull had been drinking heavily for several days, and his condition was noticed when he called on his affianced.

James C. O'Shaughnessy, a fireman of Hook and Ladder Company No. 1, who died Wednesday night from the effects of injuries received at the fire at Hegeman Co.'s drug store, 203 Broadway, April 11, was buried yesterday afternoon from his residence, 11 Clark-street.

Arthur Clark, 24 years of age, and Bartlett Norton, 30 years of age, both of NewBrighton, Staten Island, attended a wake on the body of a child at New-Brighton, Saturday night. Beer drinking was the feature of the wake, which was kept up until early yesterday morning.

HANOVER, N.H., May 15.--The will of the widow of Richard Bond, of Boston, gives $23,000 to Dartmouth College.

The Gas Commission, consisting of the Mayor, the Controller, and the Commissioner of Public Works, Will meet to-day to open bids for the lighting of certain streets by electricity for the year beginning June 1.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May. 15.--The agitation against the Monday pay day proposed by employers of labor in the East has reached this city, and the power of the employers to make the change will be tested here first by the workmen of N.K. Fairbanks Co., who have 260 men on their pay rolls.

ALBANY, May 15.--That bill remitting the $1,000,000 in back taxes due the State by the life insursance companies is expected to appear in the Senate this week. Many of the Assemblymen who voted for it are already regretting their course, for the news has percolated ...

RONDOUT, N.Y., May 15.--John Eaton, of Shamokin, Northumberland County, Penn., hired out with J. Simpson, Captain and part owner of the Delaware and Hudson canalboat No. 793, at Honesdale, two weeks ago. Simpson's boat was locked through to Tidewater last Wednesday, and after the boat had passed Greenkill Eaton was fished out of the canal more or less intoxicated and bleeding profusely. He was cared for at Eddyville.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 15.--The bridge over the Avon River, near the town of Windsor, was burned last night. It was over 50 years old and notable as being the last toll bridge in the province, tolls being collected till last Spring, when the Government took control. It was a quarter of a mile long.

NEWBURG, N.Y., May 15.--Fruit growers all along the Hudson River between Cornwall and Catskill, a distance of over 60 miles, are angry with the commission men in New-York City who expect to act as middlemen between the producers and consumers this Summer.

Humphreys read a paper of much interest last week before the Statistical Society on "Class Mortality," in which he drew attention to the fact that in the Peabody Buildings in London, which now accommodate some 20,000 persons of the poorer classes, the number of infant deaths has been reduced seven per 1,000 below that of infants in London generally during the last five years.

CHICAGO, May 15.--A disreputable house on Fourth-avenue, kept by Mrs. Jennie Johnson, runs back to an alley upon which a window in the back parlor opens. At 10 o'clock this evening the parlor was entered through this window, and $1,500 worth of jewelry, belonging to Mrs. Johnson and concealed in a sofa bed in the room, was stolen.

Everest, thus convicted of the crime of conspiring to destroy the business and blow up the works of the Buffalo Lubricating Oil Company, grew a shade paler.
