This book is addressed to Germans. Dr. Gneist, who has recently died, was a very great authority upon the English Parliamentary and constitutional system. His "History of the English Constitution" is perhaps the best work on that subject.
MONTREAL, May 15.--O'Brien and Kilbride have spent to-day in Montreal, and their stay has been marked by the greatest enthusiasm.

Attired in their old-time red shirts and glazed hats, the members of the Brooklyn Volunteer Firemen's Association will turn out on Wednesday night to celebrate by a parade the purchase of old "Fourteen" engine from the Glen Cove Fire Department.

The visit of Queen Kapiolani to this city is at an end, and the municipal wheel of business and politics is again permitted to revolve uninterruptedly. Whatever may be said of the surroundings of the party in Boston, the Queen and the Princess during their entire stay conducted themselves in a dignified manner, adding grace and charm to every entertainment and reception. Everywhere they were worthily received, and everywhere they gave evidence of their appreciation.
There should be a great abundance of asparagus from New-Jersey this week, and there will be, unless the temperature should be unusually low. The quality, also, will be unusually fine.

WARSAW, N.Y., May 15.--The Harvard College quartet gave a concert here on Friday, and Miss Clara A. Hunt, of Boston, appeared as their soprano. Her dress was cut in modest decollette and without sleeves, and was an odd combination of blue and red. Her arms, however, were incased in long gloves. The most prudish people in the audience were not impressed with the idea that she showed any indelicacy.

The trial of John Greenwell for the murder of Lyman S. Weeks on the night of March 15, which begins to-day in the Sessions Court, at Brooklyn, before Judge Moore, promises to be of unusual interest, principally from the fact ...

ATHENS, Ga., May 15.--A singular woman was buried here to-day, whose life has been a romance. In her coffin was placed the original copy of "Home, Sweet Home," which had been addressed to her by John Howard Payne, who was then a suitor for her hand.

Congressman Tom Reed, of Maine, has been placed in nomination for the Presidency by Gov. Long, of Massachusetts. Mr. Reed is an able man, but he is wanted for the Republican Speaker of the House of Representatives two years hence. With Robert Lincoln or Phil Sheridan as President, the team would be a strong one.

The verdict of the Buffalo jury convicting HIRAM B. EVEREST and his son, CHARLES M. EVEREST, on an indictment charging them with conspiracy to ruin the business of the Buffalo Lubricating Oil Company will bring consternation to the Standard Oil magnates.
An interesting and memorable passage in "Endymion" records Lord Beaconsfield's estimate of the relations that ought to subsist between a Minister and his private secretary.

The two-horse car companies crossing Weststreet to Pavonia Ferry having applied for a permit from the Dock Board to lay water pipes and drains and erect "goosenecks" for watering the car horses in front of the ferry house. Engineer Greene was asked to make a report.
Mme. Baurey Saurel sends to the Salon a capital portrait of dear Barthelemy Saint-Hilaire. The remarks of that philosopher and statesman about Cleopatra were original.

The attention of a Journal reporter was to-day called to the fact that Daniel Webster, the Massachusetts statesman, at one time owned considerable land in this county. Register of Deeds Rowell having discovered a deed recorded in 1842, by which Mr. Webster conveyed certain lands owned by him in the town of Dunkirk to one John Porter.

EMPORIA, Kan., May 15.--The arguments of the attorneys in the case of Yarborough, who killed the son of Robert Laird Collier, occupied the entire day yesterday. The court room was crowded to suffocation. The jury went out at 5 o'clock, and at 9 o'clock returned with a verdict of guilty of murder in the first degree. The attorneys for the defense filed a motion for a new trial.
An Augusta lumberman tells the following story of Sam Smith, one of the best known lumbermen in the Penobscot region, 40 years ago, and who knew about all there was to be known of the Maine forest.

Mr. Black's novel with the above title impresses this wholesome lesson to young women--"Never marry a horsy man." Sabina is the daughter of Sir Anthony Zembra, a hard, cold, matter-of-fact Englishman, who likes, however, to see his name in the paper.

Gen. Buckner, the Democratic Gubernatorial candidate, is very popular in Kentucky just now. How it will be after he has enacted the role of Governor three or four years is another question. If the General should hustie around lively and make a smart canvass, he might roll up a majority of 50,000 votes, instead of 40,000 on a come-andgo-easy canvass.

The Reformed Congregation, which has hitherto worshipped in a small church on Ninthavenue, between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth streets, yesterday opened and dedicated a new edifice on Fifty-second-street, between Ninth and Tenth avenues. The new church is a hand- ...

R. Burch, who resides on Rock Creek, north of town, paid us a call last evening. He informs us that during the storm of last Friday afternoon, as he and his family were watching the clouds, a flock of wild geese passed near the house.

CHICAGO, May 15.--Negotiations are said to be going on between the Union Pacific and the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railway Companies for the purpose of establishing closer relations between the two companies than have existed heretofore.

--The time of publication of M. de Lesseps's reminiscences is now given as October next. They will appear simultaneously in Paris and London. A German edition has also been arranged for, its first appearance taking place in a Berlin newspapers as a serial.

A well dressed young woman walked into Mount Sinai Hospital about 3 o'clock Saturday morning, and asked to be taken care of. She said she was ill, but it was soon discovered that her trouble was mental. Among other vagaries she declared that she was the Queen of England.
Nearly 3,000 people saw the game at Ridgewood Park yesterday between the Cuban Giants and the Uticas. The Utica team defeated its dusky rivals by the score of 7 to 5 after a close fight.

Branches of the United Labor Party in the Eleventh and Twenty-second Assembly Districts held a mass meeting in Lyric Hall last evening. A long-haired pianist opened the proceedings with all "The Mikado" chestnuts, and a tall man, with a bright red rose in his buttonhole, explained the objects of the meeting.
It is natural that with the advance of civilization in the southern temperate zone there should come a revival of interest in antarctic exploration.

The Supreme Court, General Term, of this department handed down decisions on appeal in 139 cases on Friday. In 56 of the cases the decisions of the court below were modified or reversed--generally reversed.

There was a striking resemblance between the temperature of New-York yesterday and that of the average New-Yorker--both were cool and dry. The general lack of moisture reminded Capt. Williams of a period when the youthful ...

BALTIMORE, May 15.--The 400 brewers of Baltimore will go on strike to-morrow. The 27 firms composing the Brewers and Maltsters' Association refuse to accede to the demands, which are for an in crease in wages of about 15 per cent., for the employment of no one who does not belong to the Brew Workers' Union, for the allowance of only one apprentice for every ten men, and for various other concessions.

A man apparently about 48 years of age, dressed in a pair of dark diagonal trousers, black coat and vest, gaiter shoes, a gray flannel undershirt, white overshirt, and a black derby hat, was found dead at Tompkinsville, Staten Island, early yesterday morning. He was lying in a pool of blood at the end of the platform at the station of the Rapid Transit Railroad.

Central Park was a centre of attraction all day yesterday to thousands of work-weary people and their children. Never did the Park look more beautiful. The trees all wore their new Spring suits and the skies were as blue "as when Minerva smiled."

WILLIS, Texas, May 15.--About 3 o'clook this morning a body of armed men surrounded the calaboose, where two colored men, Andrew McGeehe and J.B. Walker, were confined on a charge of shooting young Granville Powell while he was assisting some young ladies on a passenger train Saturday evening.
PHILADELPHIA, May 15.--Dr. John Barnett, an octogenarian, who kept a little drug store at 534 South Fourth-street, was found dead in his room on the third floor over the store this afternoon.

LONDON, May 15.--Discount was extremely inactive during the past week, three months being quoted at 1 and short at . On the Stock Exchange a moderate amount of business was done and there was a general advance in prices. On Friday Consols sold at 103 , the highest price ever recorded.
The annual service for the American Tract Society was held last evening at the Church of the Holy Trinity, Madison-avenue and Forty-second-street.

WASHINGTON, May 15.--It will become apparent in the course of a few days, when the new civil service rules regulating promotion in the departmental service are applied to the War Department, that the letter writers who have been addressing the public through the local press ...

It is the misfortune of the French people that they are constantly forced to bear in their minds two subjects of the most exciting and trying character--revolution and foreign war. Since the opening of the present century, of which one-eighth remains, ...

Tammany Hall was quite as crowded yesterday as it has been on many of the occasions when politics have been the attraction by the union meeting of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen, held under the auspices of Just-inTime Lodge, No. 149.

PARIS, May 15.--The race for the Prix de Diane was run at Chantilly to-day. It was won by Michel Ephrussi's brown filly Bavarde, by Hermit, out of Basilique. Baron de Schickler's filly La Jarretiere was second and P. Aumont's b.f. Tenebreuse third. The distance was about one mile and a quarter.

WASHINGTON, May 15.--Policeman Julian Arnold, of Alexandria, Va., was shot dead, and Ernest I. Padgett, a companion, wounded in Alexandria at a few minutes before 1 o'clock this morning while attempting to arrest two men whom they overheard planning a robbery.
The Rev. Charles H. Eaton, of the Fourth Universalist Church, Fifth-avenue and Fortyfifth-street, preached last night upon the AntiPoverty Society.

CHICAGO, May 16.--Fifty-five years ago to-day Mr. Philip D. Armour first saw the light of day. That happy event seemed to have entirely escaped his memory, as he was at work in his office all day as usual.
CHICAGO, May 16.--East-bound through shipments of dead freight from this city are again decreasing. The total shipments by the eight Central Traffic Association...

LOUISVILLE, May 16.--Montana Regent won the Louisville Cup, two and a quarter miles to-day, and Mr. Morrissey, his owner, won $15,000, and is now ready to match his horse against Lucky B. or Volante for any amount that Mr. Baldwin desires. The contests resulted as follows:

BOSTON, May 16.--The third murder in the little country town of Groton, in this State, within a few years, was perpetrated to-day. As a result of a slight quarrel this afternoon Henry Winch, a cabinetmaker, was shot and instantly killed by Nathan Nutting.

BUFFALO, May 16.--THE TIMES'S correspondent to-day asked Mr. C.B. Matthews, President of the Buffalo Lubricating Oil Company and complaining witness in the great oil conspiracy case just ended, if he was not afraid the Standard Oil Company would now use greater efforts than ever to crush him.

PARIS, May 16.--Lot 29 of the crown jewels--a buckle for girdle, composed of 296 brilliants--which was sold to Mme. Gale on Saturday, has been purchased from that lady by Tiffany. The sale to-day attracted the usual crowd, and lots were disposed of. The purchasers and the prices paid were as follows:
The Executive Committee of the National Amateur Athletic Association met at Knickerbocker Cottage last evening to reconsider the case of Malcolm W. Ford, some weeks ago ruled off the amateur list.

Morris Marx, who was last week convicted of manslaughter in the first degree in having killed Mrs. Anna Jakowski by pouring vitriol over her, was to have been sentenced yesterday. His counsel, however, made an application for a new trial, basing his request on the discovery of new evidence, and Recorder Smyth, before whom it was made, reserved his decision.

The Rev. William A. Snively has resigned the pastorate of Grace Episcopal Church, Brook lyn. Ill health is the cause assigned. In his letter of resignation Dr. Snively says that for a year he has been suffering from asthma and physical prostration, consequent upon overwork, ...
SAN FRANCISCO, May 16.--The Canadian Pacific Railroad has secured for tranportation across the continent 8,000,000 pounds of sugar in addition to the 2,000,000 pounds shipped last week.
ALBANY, May 16.--The following is the report of the Manhattan Elevated Road for the quarter ending March 31:

In the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday, Jacob Sharp, a gentleman who stands accused of having bribed Ludolph A. Fullgraff, an Alderman, to vote favorably on the question of granting to the Broadway Surface Railroad a franchise, was placed on trial for his alleged crime.

In the third race at Clifton yesterday, Covington, who rode Harry Rose, had his leg broken. The horse, being crowded against the rails, stumbled and fell, throwing Covington, who struck a post and fractured one of his legs badly. The jockey was taken to Peterson for treatment.

The first match in four years between the St. George and Manhattan Cricket Clubs was played yesterday on the old grounds of the former in Hoboken. The Manhattans did not present their best teams, and the same may be said of the St. George.

Archbishop Corrigan yesterday morning made his episcopal visitation to the Church of the Sacred Heart, in West Fifty-first-street. He made an address of 35 minutes, touching on the land question and the extent of the Pope's authority.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 16.--The seat of the Hume-Andover controversy has been removed to this city. On Wednesday the Alumni of the Yale Theological School will hold its annual meeting, and the Rev. Dr. Kingsley Twining, of the New-York Independent, and the Rev. J.W. Backus will be the essayists.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 16.--The report of the loss of the clipper ship Charles H. Marshall, owned and sailed by Capt. Charles Hutchison, of this city, is regarded here as undoubtedly incorrect.

"The Pyramid" is the title of a comic opera in two acts produced at the Star Theatre last night. The libretto is the work of Charles Fuerner and Caryl Florio and the music was composed by Mr. Puerner alone.
NYACK, N.Y., May 16.--The investigation of the charges against the Rev. Adolph A. Schabehorn, of the German Presbyterian Church of Nyack, is in progress to-night.

The new Republican County Committee will meet this evening at Grand Opera House Hall, and will organize for the year. An invitation has been extended to the Chairman of each Assembly district committee to meet at 4:30 P. M. in order to map out a programme for the larger committee, which will assemble at 7:30 o'clock.

The latest portrait of Henry Ward Beecher, painted by A.J. Conant, of St. Louis, and owned by S.V. White, one of the Trustees of Plymouth Church, was placed on exhibition in the Art Association Rooms on Montague-street, Brooklyn, last evening, with the collection of...
George Gick and Patrick McGuire, roundsmen on the police force, passed the civil service examination for Sergeantcies, having been marked about 90.
JACKSON, Ga., May 16.--Mrs. McNair, the wife of the man who was assassinated in Worthville, reached this place to-day and gives a graphic description of the tragedy.
CLEVELAND, May 16.--The Metropolitan Club left the Cleveland baseball grounds to-day with a victory to their credit. It was won comparatively easy, although a home-run drive by Mann in the...
After Judge Browne of the City Court had directed verdicts last Friday for the full amounts of wages claimed by Alfred W. Young, Ruth Torbett...

NEW-ORLEANS, May 16.--Information of a peculiar tragedy has just been received from the parish of Ascension. On Ascension plantation William Leman, a colored boy 12 years of age, shot Mrs. Michela Gioja, the wife of an Italian laborer on the same place.

The Inter-State Commerce Commission has completed its Southern investigation and is expected soon to decide upon the measure of relief to which the railroads of that section are entitled from the effects of the long and short haul provision of the law.

The second trial of the ejectment suit of Mrs. Mary Maud Watson, of Hartford, Vt., against John D. Phyfe and James Campbell was begun yesterday in the Supreme Court, Circuit, Part I., before Judge Lawrence, and...

The bids for lighting various portions of the city with electric lights were opened by the Gas Commission yesterday. The following bids were received: The Bull Electric Light Company, 25 cents per light per night; the Brush Illuminating Company, 25 cents per light per night, according to the statement of the representative of the company, or $91.50 per light per year, according to the formal written bids; the United States Electric Light...

On May 7, Gussie Merritt, the 15-year-old sister of Mrs. Jennie Duryea, disappeared from the latter's home at 585 Gates-avenue, Brooklyn. Yesterday William A. Verona, a Cuban, of 79 Henry-street, was arrested, charged with her abduction.

BOSTON, Mass., May 16.--The steamer Venetian, Trant, from Liverpool, reports that on May 8, at 6 P.M., latitude 50 36' north, longitude 25 west, passed the schooner yacht Coronet bound west. All on board were well.

The actors employed during the season at Wallack's Theatre, or some of them, appeared on the stage of Daly's last evening in " The Romance of a Poor Young Man," and they will be seen there probably in the same play for a fortnight.

The Court of Sessions in Brooklyn was crowded yesterday with men, who never left their places from the time the tedious process of selecting a jury to try John Greenwall for the murder of Lyman S. Weeks on March 15 began until Judge Moore adjourned the court.
The tally-ho coach Pioneer returned from Philadelphia last evening, and the passengers were landed in front of the Hotel Brunswiek at 6:57, three minutes ahead of time.

A plan of the tract in Battery Park which the Rapid Transit Commissioners propose to take for the new roads designed to be built was submitted by the attorney of the Manhattan Elevated Railway Company at the meeting of the commission yesterday. It contained no fig- ...
Archbishop Corrigan has made the following changes and transfers among the Catholic clergy:
The vacant block of land extending from Park-avenue to Lexington-avenue and from Thirty-third to Thirty-fourth streets has at last been sold by the New-York and Harlem Railroad Company.

READING, Penn., May 16.--The announcement to-day of the arrest of Albert E. Loomis, for several years manager of Bradstreet's Mercantile Agency in this city, caused considerable comment in the business community.
The first social reunion of the Presbyterian Club took place last night at the Brunswick Hotel, and a very pleasant occasion it was.
BOSTON, May 16.--Augustin Daly's company made their first appearance to-night in the Museum in "Love in Harness." Every part of the house was full and the audience was extremely fashionable.
KINGSTON, N.Y., May 16.--For years the juniors have given the senior pupils at Vassar College, Poughkeepsie, an excursion, the point of destination being kept a secret.
WILL PERSONS WHO WITNESSED OUTrageous expulsion of a gentleman from the Fourteenth-Street Theatre on Friday evening send address to my attorney, J.W. Egan, 62 Wall-street?

The North German Lloyd steamship Fulda, which arrived yesterday afternoon from Bremen and Southampton, grounded near Owl's Head shortly after passing Quarantine. Pilot Morley, of Pilot Boat No. 1, was in charge of the Fulda when she grounded, Capt. Ringk was very much disgusted at the accident, which came through no fault of his, having completed what was otherwise a most successful voyage.
The new differentials, settled upon the Baltimore and Ohio and the New-York, Ontario and Western when the last-named road entered the trunk line agreement, will go into effect to-day.

Frederick C. Kull, who attempted to kill his sweetheart, Julia E. Miller, by shooting her in the head at her home in Jersey City on Sunday night, was formally charged by the young lady's father before Justice Wanser yesterday...

Public School Superintendent Jasper had his attention called yesterday to an alarming discovery in the girls' department of Grammar School No. 28, in Fortieth-street, between Seventh and Eighth avenues, in the Twenty-second Ward.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--Major Morse K. Taylor, Surgeon, has been retired. Leave of absence for four months has been granted Capt. Wells Willard, Commissary of Subsistence, and for two months to Second Lieut. Lewis M. Koehler, Sixth Infantry.

FALL RIVER, Mass., May 16.--The weavers of the Wampanoag Mill No. 2, who struck for more pay last week, returned to work this morning in a body. A compromise was effected by an advance of three-quarters of a cent. per cut.
LEADVILLE, Col., May 16.--The most shocking accident that has been reported from the midland tunnel for months occurred near the west portal on Saturday last.

One of those Japanese terrors, the salamanders, was roaming at large somewhere about Charles Reiche Brother's animal store, on Park-row last night. On Sunday the two warty beasts were left in a shallow tub, and yesterday morning both had escaped.

At the meeting of the Baptist Pastors yesterday Prof. E.T. Tomlinson, a youthful instructor in the preparatory school of Rutgers College, read an essay on "The Legitimate Sphere of Denominational Institutions." He expressed the opinion that the weakest spot in the Baptist system was the educational question.

Several local yachtsmen said yesterday that the Thistle's reported sailing of 15 knots an hour for two hours, standing up under all her canvas in a big breeze and crying for more sail, was a good yarn.

BISMARCK, Dakota, May 16.--George E. Reed, for two years past City Treasurer, is missing. It is believed he has gone to Canada. His accounts are said to be $9,000 short. Reed has hosts of friends, who believe that he has not gone with the purpose of defrauding the city. Mrs. Reed, however, told a friend that he would never see Reed again in this region.

The remains of Mgr. William Quinn, late Vicar-General of the New-York Catholic Archdiocese, arrived yesterday morning on the Arizona in charge of the Rev. Michael C. O'Farrell, of St. Teresa's, who was the dead priest's traveling companion on his European trip.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 16.--The Czar and Czarina started this morning for Novo-Tcherkaek, the capital of the Don Cossacks country.

CHICAGO, May 16.--Were it not for the large number of deserted unfinished structures all over this city nobody would know that most of the men employed in the building trades in Chicago have been locked out by their employers until the bricklayers come to time or their organization goes to pieces.

ALBANY, May 16.--An attempt was made in the Assembly to-night to legislate a little for the New-York hotel keepers. A bill of Mr. Langbein, of Gotham, was on its final passage in relation to orders of arrest in actions in District Courts.
Justice Murray devoted two hours yesterday afternoon to the examination of Paulus Thomas, the walking delegate charged with conspiracy by Peter Boyle.

LONDON, May 16.--The proposal of Mr. Smith that the House of Commons adjourn for the Whitsun holidays, from May 24 to June 6, leaves the House only four nights for debate on the Coercion bill before the adjournment, as all the other sittings will be occupied with the estimates.

The affairs of the Weymouth Paper Company, whose New-York office is in the Tribune Building and its mills at Weymouth, N.J., are still in an unsettled condition. Numerous judgments have been filed against Charles R. Colwell and Robert Fulton, who formerly carried on the business.

Two of the Daily Graphic's lithographers struck yesterday morning and the paper had to come out in the afternoon without its usual illustrations. The men were employed in laying the transfers on the stone.
The Young Men's Democratic Club met in Parlor E of the Hoffman House last night and showed great interest in a paper read by Richard M. Henry, entitled, "Who Should Have the Offices?"

BALTIMORE, Md., May 16.--The inauguration of the Summer operatic season at Harris's Academy of Music to-night by the McCaull Opera Comique Company drew out probably the largest audience ever assembled in the spacious...

The 12 men selected in Judge Ingraham's part of the Supreme Court last week to determine whether Robert P. McBride had been guilty of excessive drinking and of cruel and inhuman treatment toward his wife, Josephine McCarroll McBride, reported yesterday that after due consideration they found they could not agree.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--The United States Supreme Court assembled at noon to-day. The Chief-Justice announced the death of Mr. Justice Woods, whose chair was draped in black, and said that as a mark of respect to his memory the court would adjourn until Monday next, when motions would be heard and a later date fixed for the court's final adjournment.

Mayor and Mrs. Hewitt called upon Queen Kaplolani yesterday morning at her apartments in the Victoria Hotel. The Mayor extended the Queen an invitation to inspect the public institutions and see the city, and accept generally the hospitality of the Metropolis.
The members of the Board of Management which made such a success of the cattle show last week had a meeting last night at the FifthAvenue Hotel to hear final reports from the Executive Committee.

At the fiftieth annual meeting of the American and Foreign Bible Society yesterday in the committee room of the American Tract Society the Rev. Dr. W.H. Parmly was re-elected President, and all the other officers were chosen again except two.
The steamship Arizona, of the Guion Line, and Servia, of the Cunard Line, which left Queenstown about the same time, May 8, arrived at Quarantine yesterday within an hour of each other.
Philip Stolz, a well known Brooklyn German Republican, having a bakery at 270 Atlantic-avenue, sprang off a car in front of his residence last night, slipped, and fell under the car.

We accord this morning to Mr. C. C. HINE, editor of the Insurance Monitor, the privilege of stating the case of the insurance companies against the newspaper editors and correspondents who have insisted that the bill repealing the insurance tax law is improper...

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 16.--The police authorities to-night notified Col. Wagner, manager of Shakespeare Hall, that they would not permit John L. Sullivan and his combination to appear in the ball to-morrow night as advertised. Wagner then applied to the Mayor for permission to give the show, but that official informed him that he should not allow the performance to be given.

MONTREAL, May 16.--The Orangemen, atleast that section of the order which threatens war on the editor of United Ireland, have put their foot in it. This is the verdict of their own friends, while the Catholics, who have nothing to do with the matter, seem satisfied to look on and laugh.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--A great deal of anxiety is undoubtedly felt by department employes to learn just how searching the examinations for promotion under the new civil service rules are to be, but the people who are grumbling loudest will be thankful perhaps when they are informed that the rules as approved are not so severe as they might have been.
Master in Chancery Williams yesterday decided that as Dr. Josiah Hornblower was willing to provide for his wife the court could not order him to provide her a separate maintenance.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 16.--The last and fourth caisson for the Poughkeepsie Bridge is being sunk, and the construction of the bridge is far in advance of the terms of the contract. Extra men have been put to work to handle the large quantity of ironwork which has arrived and is ready to be placed.
CHICAGO, May 16.--The clique in wheat sent its brokers into the pit at the first tap of the bell to-day, and kept them there until the afternoon session closed, steady bidders for the June futures.
COLUMBIA, S.C., May 16.--Negro nurses in South Carolina have of late years developed a mania for poisoning white children intrusted to their care.

It is not wonderful that the owners of property along the ten miles or more of water front on Long Island from Fort Hamilton to Astoria should be anxious for increased facilities of communication between that shore and the eastern shore of Manhattan Island.

LONDON, Ontario, May 16.--L. Cleverdon, Reeve of Strathroy, Warden of County Middlesex and Superintendent of a Sunday school, is reported to have absconded, leaving very heavy liabilities and a quantity of forged paper behind.
From the 15 entries received for the amateur billiard tournament of the Racquet Club the committee has declined 9 and accepted 6.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16.--In room C of the Court of Common Pleas to-day the case of Charles H. Stevenson and Kate E. Stevenson, professionally known as Kate Claxton, against J.E. Kingsley Co. was called.
The capable company at the Standard Theatre appeared in Millocker's opera, "Gasparone," last evening and gave satisfaction to a numerous audience.

The New-York Club yesterday met its first Western rival and added one to its small string of victories. After the club's recent weak playing it was perhaps fortunate that it was the baby of the League the New-York team had to meet, and not one of the heavier teams.

The fire insurance experiment in NewHampshire has reached a critical stage. The enactment of the so-called valued policy law drove out of the State fifty-eight companies organized elsewhere, which had been doing business in it with due regard for the local statutes.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16.--President Roberts, Vice-President Du Barry, General Manager Pugh, and several other officers of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company left to-day to inspect the Pittsburg terminals and the company's Western lines. They expect to return on Saturday or Sunday.
T.B. Maguire and T.B. Barry, of the General Executive Board of Knights of Labor, have been going backward and forward while investigating the troubles of the Knights in this city and Brooklyn.
The New-York and Indianapolis teams play at the Polo Grounds this afternoon, and the Uticas play the Jersey City at Jersey City.
No clue has been discovered as to the identity of the man who was found dead early Sunday morning at Tompkinsville, Staten Island. The police have been looking for the missing pistol without success.
The congregation of the West Twenty-thirdStreet Presbyterian Church filled that edifice last evening to take part in the installation of their new Pastor, Dr. Robert F. Sample.
BERLIN, May 16.--Gen. Boulanger's plan for an experimental mobilization of the French Army next October is distrusted here. If France mobilizes Germany will mobilize also.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, May 16.--It became known here early this morning that late last Saturday night Swan Brothers, a well known firm of live stock dealers, consisting of Alexander and John Swan, had made an assignment of all the property of the firm and of the individual members for the benefit of their creditors, without any preferences.

Eugene Storer, a burly, red-faced man, carries a club and pistol and is enrolled in the Richmond County police force. Sunday afternoon he was stationed in the waiting room of the Staten Island Ferry, in this city.

BALTIMORE, May 16.--The Baltimore Sun, which was founded by A.S. Abell May 17, 1837, will celebrate its semi-centennial to-morrow. The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore have adopted resolutions commemorative of the event, and from...
EATONTOWN, N.J., May 16.--Robert Crummell, colored, was lodged in the jail at this place to-day pending an investigation into the death of his 10-year-old son, who it is suspected was murdered.
In regard to the story of George Parisen and his wife, Mary, published on Sunday, in which they say that they went to Anthony Comstock, ...

John Johnston, the head of the dry goods firm of J. C. Johnston, Broadway and Twentysecond-street, and one of the best known merchants of this city, died of heart disease Sunday evening at his residence, 7 West Fifty-thirdstreet.
This afternoon racing will be resumed at the Brooklyn Club's pretty track at Gravesend and Starter Sheridan will try to get the horses off in time so that the full programme may be run off.

Dominico Rocco did not appear in Justice Naeher's court in Brooklyn yesterday when the charge of abandonment made by his wife, Rosa, was called. An investigation showed that Rocco had been his own bondsman, pledging his house, ...
Miss Pixley's "professional matinee" occurs at the Union-Square Theatre to-day. No tickets have been sold, and "The Deacon's Daughter" will be given before a houseful of actors.

A hearing was had last evening at West Brighton, Staten Island, before Justice of the Peace Powers in the case of the assault upon C. Bowyer Vaux and Roswell B. Burchard, of this city, by Bernard McTammany and James Johnson, of West Brighton.
EAU CLAIRE, Wis., May 16.--James and William Murphy, respectively 13 and 15 years, have been lodged in jail here.
RICHMOND, Va., May 16.--Sir Edward Thornton and Mr. Braithwaite to-day received from London a cablegram instructing them to reject the last proposition made by the legislative committee.

The novel feat of tweaking an evangelist's nose and pulling out a handful of a minister's beard was presented to the approving gaze of the villagers at Park Ridge, N.J., on Sunday night, by James Leach, stationer, of 86 Nassaustreet, this city.

MILTON, N.Y., May 16.--Henry Whaley, clerk in the Milton Hotel, was drowned in the Hudson here last night. Whaley intended making a trip with two shad fishermen named Donaldson and Barton, and, while waiting for them to come after him, he sat down on the stringpiece of the steamboat dock and fell asleep, and later on rolled over into the waters of the Hudson. The body was recovered to-day.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 16.--Information was received here this afternoon of a tragedy enacted at Millington, Tenn., 18 miles north of this city, on the Chesapeake, Ohio and Southwestern Railway.

In the trial of the ejectment suit brought by Mrs. Mary Maud Watson against John D. Phyfe and James Campbell after some two hours of manoeuvring a jury was obtained yesteday, and ex-Judge George M. Curtis made the opening argument for the plaintiff.

LONDON, May 17.--Lord Durham's ch. c. Brooklyn, by Glendale, out of Frivolous, won the Zetland Stakes for 2-year-olds, at the York Spring meeting to-day. Belle Mahone was second and Sister Agnes third. The Great Northern handicap was won by R. Crest's br. h. Renny, 5 years old, by Castlereagh, out of Harriet Laws. Nightcap was second, Scotilla third. Six others started. Betting three to four against Renny.

WASHINGTON, May 17.--The New-York Independent Schuetzen Corps has had an extremely busy and pleasant day in Washington. At 9 o'clock this morning they escorted Mr. John B. Hasslocker, of Ehret Co., the king of the last shooting contest, out to the Washington Schuetzen Park.

TORONTO, Ontario, May 17.--The following extract from a letter to Erastus Wiman from Senator John Sherman on full reciprocity between Canada and the United States will appear in the Canadian papers to-morrow:

NYACK, N.Y., May 17.--The investigation of the charges made against the Rev. A.A. Schabehorn, Pastor of the German Presbyterian Church, of Nyack, was concluded to-day and the result of the proceedings will be presented at a special meeting of the Hudson Presbytery to be held in about two weeks.
ALBANY, May 17.--The Governor did today what it was expected he would do a fortnight ago. He sent to the Senate nominations for the Quarantine offices.
BOSTON, May 17.--The hearing in the contested will case of John Amory Codman, resumed to-day after an interval of two months, proved very interesting to the hangers-on about the Probate Court.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., May 17.--Messrs. Alken swift, of this city, received a dispatch to-day from Hapodadi, Japan stating that the officers and crew of the bark Europa, before reported wrecked, were all safe.
CHICAGO, May 17.--The "tip" was distributed around the pit at the opening of wheat this morning that 88 c. was the "peg" price for the day, and that June would touch 90c.

The sub-committee of the Royal Nova Scotia Yacht Squadron, in charge of the jubilee regatta to be held at Halifax, consists of viceCommodore A.C. Edwards. Rear-Commodore W.H. Throop, and F.C. Sumichrast.

Silence fell upon the crowd in the Brooklyn Court of Sessions yesterday when Mrs. Evadne Weeks, widow of the man who was murdered on March 15, was led to the witness stand. Mrs. Weeks was accompanied by her mother, Mrs. Ellingham.

PARIS, May 17.--The debate on the report of the Budget Committee, which demands a reduction in the estimates submitted by the Government, was begun in the Chamber of Deputies to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17.--General Master Workman Powderly arrived suddenly in the city today to the surprise even of members of the General Executive Board, who thought him out in Omaha. When asked how he enjoyed his Western trip Mr. Powderly was so chary of his words and shy of reporters that he declined to be interviewed. He seemed to be much improved in health, looking rather rugged in a beard of several days' growth.

The hunt for the jury in the Sharp case is a proceeding of no little interest. Sixty-two men were sworn yesterday, fifty-six were rejected, and six chosen.
The stockholders of the New-York and Harlem Railroad Company met yesterday, and re-elected the Board of Directors which served last year.

The Governors of the Stock Exchange discussed the Saturday, half-holiday law yesterday, and on the recommendation of its Committee on Constitution voted that for the present the Exchange should be closed every Saturday at noon.

To prepare for the first meeting of the new Republican County Committee, which was to assemble at 8 P.M., the Chairmen of the various Assembly district delegations met at the headquarters at Grand Opera House Hall at 4:30 P.M. yesterday afternoon.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 17.--The death of Mrs. Randall Lee Gibson, wife of Louisiana'a Senator, has caused a feeling of sorrow to pervade this community where she was born, and in which she was so highly esteemed for her social virtues and admired for her accomplishments.
UTICA, May 17.--A gloomy feeling pervades the hop districts of Central New-York. Two years ago the grower hardly realized enough from his hops to pay the cost of raising.

RED BANK, N.J., May 17.--Drs. Edwin Field and William Warner this morning went to Macedonia, the scene of the alleged child murder on Sunday. They made an examination of young Crummell's body, but were unable to find any marks of violence. Death was caused by inflammation of the base of the brain. Robert Crummell, the father, was taken to the county jail at Freehold. The evidence of the physicians will probably clear him.

ST. LOUIS, May 17.--The official order of the Governor and the Adjutant-General disbanding the Missouri militia arrived to-day. This action is the result of the refusal of the Legislature to appropriate funds for the support of the militia, and of a request of the organizations that it be disbanded. The First, Second, Third, Fifth and Seventh Regiments are now disbanded, and the only organization left in the city now is a light cavalry company.

CHICAGO, May 17. --Eugene C. Race, the restaurateur and successor of the well known firm of Race Brothers, confessed judgment to-day for $10,427 due Philip Ellsworth, a New-York oyster dealer.

The strained relations between the villagers at Park Ridge, N.J., and Evangelist Mason and Minister Switzer have not yet been relieved. Both sides seem to be in active preparation for a test of power to-morrow night.

BOSTON, May 17.--The employes of the Bay State Brick Company at Cambridge, 300 in number struck this morning for an advance in wages. Early in the season they received an increase of $2 per month.

LAWRENCE, Mass., May 17.--The old Washington Mill in this city was totally destroyed by fire to-night, and it is doubtful if the new Washington Mill, about 20 feet west of the old mill, can be saved, while the Pacific and Pemberton are in imminent danger.

The "professional matinee" is a curious thing that has come into vogue lately. Its origin was reasonable, and the spirit that prompted actors of high position to give extra performances of successful new plays for the edification of their fellow-actors whose work prevented them from attending the regular performances was highly commendable.

LONDON, May 17.--The debate on the Coercion bill was resumed this evening. Sir William Vernon Harcourt moved an amendment exempting from secret inquiry all proceedings relating to public meetings or agrarian movements, including combinations to obtain reductions of rent.

Alexander H. Reavey, a lawyer, was convicted in January, 1885, of having swindled a client by whom he had been retained to sue for a divorce. Judge Cowing sentenced him to imprisonment for two and a half years.
At the meeting of the Board of Pilot Commissioners yesterday a letter from William P. Clyde was read saying that he had only heard of his election as Commissioner on Monday.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 17.--The annual extempore debate by members of the Senior Class of Rutgers College for the Bussing prizes took place this afternoon in the college chapel.

J.M. Hirschom Co., wholesale dealers in clothing at 532 Broadway, made an assignment yesterday to Henry Hess, preferring B.M. Cohen Co. for $2,114. The firm began here in May, 1885, claiming $10,000 capital. Hirschom had failed in the West and went through bankruptcy in this city in 1878. The liabilities are about $14,000.

CHICAGO, May 17.--Chandler Shader, jewelers at 57 Washington-street, made an assignment to-day to James E. Moore. The assets are $20,000; liabilities, $25,000. The attorneys are Hynes, English, and Dunn.
A daring and successful burglary was committed early yesterday morning at the residence of John D. Cheever, on the south side of Long Island, near the Cedarhurst steeplechase course.
The Brush Illuminating Company, which is now furnishing this city with electric lights at 70 cents each per night, wants to perform a like service for a further period at 25 cents.
Some of the gentlemen who are interested in the new Western National Bank have a project in view that will attract a good deal of attention in the financial world.
There was such a crowd of spectators yesterday at the hearing of the Pacific Railway Commmission as that grave inquiry into the past had never attracted before.
HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., May 17.--The committee having in charge the erection of a monument to Tillie Smith, who was murdered here by Janitor Titus on April 8, 1886, met last night in Fireman's Hall.

The Senate yesterday by a vote of 18 to 7 agreed to make the bill taking a million dollars from the taxpayers of this State and distributing it among the life insurance companies a special order for to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17.--The Spring meeting at Belmont Park began to-day. Lady Thistle won the 3:00 class race in 2:32, 2:32, and 2:31, after Queen Dido took the first heat in 2:30.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., May. 17.--Two young boys this morning found the body of little Horace Downs in the Delaware, near here. He was drowned by the upsetting of a boat. A reward of $50 will be paid to the boys, who were led to the spot by seeing a fishing pole, which was still clutched by the drowned lad.
The attempt of the Rapid Transit Commissioners to convert another large part of Battery Park into a switch yard for the Manhattan Elevated Railway has raised a violent storm about their ears.

WASHINGTON, May 17.--League Championship --Washington, 14; Chicago, 6. Pitchers--Whitney and Baldwin. Earned runs--Washington, 12; Chicago, 6. Base hits--Washington, 17; Chicago, 11. First base on called balls--Washington, 2. Stolen basesWashington, 5: Chicago, 4. Errors--Five each.
A drawing room concert was given by Mrs. Harriet Clarke last evening, in which her pupils, assisted by prominent artists, rendered a particularly varied programme, with bright results.
At its last meeting the American Association for the Advancement of Science decided upon New-York as the place for its reunion this year.

Charles G. Francklyn spent most of yesterday morning at the office of the Horn Silver Mining Company, of which he is President, attending to the mail that had accumulated since he sailed from Europe on the Fulda. He had nothing to say in regard to the affairs of his company, about which some of the shareholders became exercised during his absence.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 17.--The legal fight over the possession of the Denmead property began to-day, after a long and ineffectual attempt to compromise the case.
A determined delegation from the Ladies' Health Protective Association devoted several hours yesterday to an inspection of gas houses on the east side.

The New-York Athletic Club held the first of its Summer series of club races on the Mott Haven Grounds yesterday afternoon. The event was the third contest for the fifty-dollar Bell medal for 100 yard handicap running.

The Brooklyn Jockey Club races came to an abrupt termination yesterday afternoon. Not over 2,000 people were on the track, because no betting was permitted there, and so the usual patrons staid in town and patronized the bookmakers here.
Mme. Selina Dolaro's play called "Fashion." as already announced here, will be performed for the author's benefit at the MadisonSquare Theatre to-morrow afternoon.

William Graley, of 227 Delancey-street, the father of two boys who were injured on the Harlem Bridge Sunday afternoon by a street car, will bring a suit for damages against the company.

BALTIMORE, May 17.--Richard McSherry, a lawyer, who was instrumental in breaking up the padrone evil in this city was decorated by the Queen of Italy for his services. For several years past Mr. McSherry has been the counsel for the Spanish Consulate here, and yesterday at a dinner given by the Spanish Minister in Washington he received from the Queen Regent the decoration of the Order of Carlos III.
The remains of Mgr. William Quinn, the late Vicar-General, were removed from the cathedral rectory at 10 o'clock yesterday morning to the cathedral, where they lay in state all day and evening.

Mayor Hewitt took hold of the electric light "combine" in the Board of Aldermen yesterday and shook out of some of the members a few silly and in part untruthful statements in excuse for the failure to cheapen the cost of lighting the streets of the city by electricity.
Miss Hattie Boggs, daughter of William Boggs, was married last evening at the Fifth-Avenue Presbyterian Church to Frank Seely.
ERIE, Penn., May 18.--Ex-Alderman Francis Peter Liebel, at one time one of the wealthiest citizens in Erie, is a prisoner to-night upon a serious charge.

PARIS, May 18.--President Grevy summoned MM. Clemenceau, Ferry, Deves, de Freycinet, Rouvier, and Raynal to his residence at the Palace of the Elysee to-day, and had interviews with each of those gentlemen in relation to the formation of a new Cabinet.

ROCHESTER, May 18.--Counsel for Manager Burke, of the Casino, today applied to Special County Judge Werner for an injunction restraining the Mayor from interfering with the exhibition by the Sullivan combination, which has been prevented by the police on the Mayor's order for the past two nights. The motion was denied. The Sullivan party went to Amsterdam to-day, but stated that they intended to return to-morrow and continue their effort to show.

LONDON, May 19.--The Chronicle's correspondent at Rome has received the proof sheets of the memoir prepared by the Irish college. The document begins by pointing out that in the Parnell or the Fenian movement interests far higher and holier than the material advantages sought for are at stake.

RONDOUT, N.Y., May 18.--The strike among the brickyard hands in this vicinity continues. To-night the manufacturers say they will not concede the demands of the strikers even if they are compelled to stop the manufacture of brick for the entire season.
ST. LOUIS, May 18.--The Southern Presbyterian General Assembly convenes in this city tomorrow, and at the same hour the Northern General Assembly convenes at Omaha.

The dedication of the monument which has been raised in Evergreens Cemetery by the Actors' Fund of America to the memory of those whose bodies repose in the Actors' Fund Plot in that cemetery will take place on June 6.
At 8:30 o'clock yesterday morning the funeral of the late John Johnston, the well known merchant, who died suddenly on Sunday, took place at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The managers of the New-York nine thought they had such an easy thing of it with the Indianapolis nine that they yesterday put a weak nine in the field and so lost a game. Welch, who pitched for New-York, was batted freely, and Boyle proved himself the superior of any pitcher seen here this season, with the possible exception of Madden, of the Boston team.

BELVIDERE, N.J., May 18.--The case of Thomas Walton, the half breed Cherokee Indian, who kidnapped Frank Santee, aged 8 years, at Phillipsburg, on the night of April 26, came up in the Court of Quarter Sessions to-day.

WARRENTON, Va., May 18.--Ex-Gov. William Smith, popularly known as "Extra Billy" Smith, died at his home near this place to-day in the ninetieth year of his age. The remains will be taken to Richmond for interment.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 18.--The Board of Finance decided to-night to report adversely upon the proposition of the New-England Railroad people to buy the city's interest in the New Haven and Derby Railroad for $175,000.

John Greenwall, on trial for the murder of Lyman S. Weeks, was a little lees cheerful in the Brooklyn Court of Sessions yesterday. He smiled less, and he listened more anxiously to the testimony.

ALBANY, May 18.--Gov. Hill has nominated Gen. Daniel E. Sickles as Emigration Commissioner at New-York. This is the third time an attempt has been made to fill this office since its creation by the Democratic Legislature of 1883. That Legislature abolished the old Board of Emigration Commissioners and in its stead substituted a single Commissioner, with two deputies.

The ship Robert L. Belknap sailed from San Francisco for Liverpool Nov. 18, 1886. Two of the sailors, H. Frederick and James Peterson, never got to Liverpool. Frederick was seen on board the night of the day the ship sailed and then disappeared.

ST. LOUIS, May 18.--Mr. James Wallace Paramore, an enterprising and widely known citizen, died suddenly of pneumonia at an early hour this morning. Mr. Paramore was born at Mansfield, Ohio, in 1830, and in his boyhood was a friend and companion of John Sherman. His father was a farmer, and early in life young Paramore was compelled to look out for himself.

Henry Van Hise, a truckman living at 78 Clermont-avenue, Brooklyn, was driving across the Brooklyn bridge about 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon when his horse became unmanageable and ran away. Near the Brooklyn entrance the animal ran into an ice wagon, throwing Van Hise to the pavement and breaking his jaw. The injured man was attended by an ambulance surgeon and taken home.

Reiff, who is the owner of 100 shares of Western Union, has applied to the Supreme Court for an injunction to restrain the Directors from issuing new bonds to be exchanged for the stocks and bonds of the leased lines which had been guaranteed by the Western Union. PORT MONMOUTH, N.J., May 18.--Nathan Brown caught a salmon weighing 24 pounds in Raritan Bay this morning. This is the first salmon caught here in over 20 years.

NEW-ALBANY, Ind., May 19.--The will of Washington C. De Pauw was probated to-day. It bequeaths $3,000,000 to his family, and the residue of his estate, estimated at $5,000,000, is devoted to benevolent and educational purposes, including a bequest of $1,025,000 to De Pauw University.

Albert Cardozo, a son of ex-Judge Cardozo, was severely hurt yesterday at his office, 96 Broadway, by a bookcase falling on his back. A physician attended to him at his office. He sustained a spinal concussion and fracture of the ribs. Friends removed him to his home, 803 Madison-avenue.

Ernest Emil Wilhelm Graber, the Government Director of National Mills at Stettin, Germany, who embezzled about $30,000 and fled to this country and was captured by Deputy United States Marshal Bernhardt upon his arrival late in April and was sent back to Germany in the Allen on May 3, hanged himself in his cabin just before the vessel reached port. The German Consul got a cablegram yesterday announcing the suicide.

Mr. Richard Mansfield begins his Summer season at the Madison-Square Theatre on the 30th inst. with a revival of "Prince Karl," which will be run for a week or so. It will be followed by a three-act farcical comedy entitled "Tom Anjerry," a rollicking play which will give Mr. Mansfield an opportunity to display his peculiar talents in the line of eccentric comedy.

The ante-mortem statement of Bartholomew Carnachi, who was shot and stabbed by Joseph Grifstie in front of 17 Baxter-street, was taken by Coroner Messemer last evening at Bellevue Hospital. Carnachi said that he was shot at six or seven times, and that it was done in front of a restaurant in James-street, near Chatham. He claimed that he gave no provocation, and did not know the name of his assailant. Carnachi will undoubtedly die.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 19.--An eastbound express train on the Pennsylvania Railroad ran into a gang of men at work this afternoon on the four-line track near Dean's Station. The body of the man struck another of the workmen, knocked him off the track, and badly injured him.

ELGIN, Ill, May 21.--Two hundred farmers who drive into Elgin each day with milk assert it to be the dryest season ever known in this section. The pastures are about exhausted and the meadows have not started well. Rye is being plowed in and replanted with corn. One hundred and fifty farmers who come into Dundee report a similar state of affairs. Unless rain falls within a week farmers will be obliged to fodder.

OMAHA, Neb., May 21.--The third day of the Presbyterian Assembly was opened this morning with prayer, Moderator Smith in the chair. The question of consolidated magazine was made the special order for Monday.

The proprietor of the cottage, with his wife and an elderly guest, had been sitting near the fireplace for some moments listening to the wailings of such portions of the blast as had been caught in the chimney.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 21.--One of the saddest accidents on record occurred in this city about noon to-day. A young man in the full vigor of manhood, the husband of a loving wife and the father of three children, sacrificed his own life to save from a horrible death a woman and her little baby boy.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 21.--The towboat Charley Bowen No. 2 struck a snag about 20 miles below here this forenoon, and sank in 16 feet of water. CITY OF MEXICO, May 21.--Reports from local officials in the regions of North Mexico recently visited by earthquake shocks reached here yesterday. The Chief of the Fiscal Guard at Babispe says the earthquake was so strong there that it did not leave a single habitable house standing.

Two weeks ago she shot herself in the head, and was taken to the New-York Hospital. The wound was slight.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 21.--The League of American Wheelmen's annual parade this morning had nearly 600 riders in line. The route was through the principal business and resident streets, which were lined with spectators. President Kirkpatrick, on his wheel, and a squad of mounted police, led the procession. To-night the meet concludes with a banquet at the Lindell Hotel.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 21.--The Board of Industry statistics just completed show that the value of petroleum products manufactured in Cleveland last year was nearly $12,200,000, five-sixths of which was turned out at the Standard Oil Works. Almost 3,000,000 barrels of illuminating oils were made. On the average 12,000 barrels of crude oil were refined daily.

The semi-annual meeting of the Society of the Sixth Regiment, New-York Veterans, otherwise known as the Wilson Zouaves, was held last evening at Congress Hall, 192 third-avenue, with about 70 out of the 125 members present. This is one of the oldest war veteran associations in the city, and meets twice a year to talk over old times and honor the memory of its deceased commander, Col. "Billy" Wilson.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21.--The Lehigh Navigation Company has ordered an entire suspension of mining operations among its collieries next week. Last Thursday was a church holiday in the region and there has been no work at the mines of the Company since that day. Monday, May 30, is a national holiday and work will be resumed on the 1st day of June.

QUANAH, Texas, May 21.--The general cattle round-up is operating in this vicinity at present and the cattle men report a more successful "gather" on cattle this Spring than for several years past. WILMINGTON, Del., May 21,--The "cat-o'nine-tails" was applied to eight culprits who were lashed to the whipping post at NewCastle Jail this morning, in the presence of a throng of idlers.

PARIS, May 21.--The strain to which the French people have been subjected in keeping calm during the crisis of the last five months is beginning to tell on their sensitive nerves. The resignation of the Ministry was taken very coolly at first, but signs of suppressed excitement are now beginning to appear.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 21.--At the Phi Beta Kappa election yesterday for Cornell Chapter the following were elected: From '87-E.D. Wright, H. M. Lovell, G.E. Fisher, R.E. Wilbur, J.E. Russell, P.J. PHILADELPHIA, May 21.--An order was made by the Court of Common Pleas to-day upon the Philadelphia Trust Company to pay to the Central Transportation Company all the funds now in hand according to the account filed in the Pullman Palace Car suit. The amount held by the Trust Company is $628,020,30.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 21.--The suit for divorce brought by Mrs. Ella C. Hurlbut, of New-York, against Henry A.Hurlbut, Jr., was again called in the Supreme Court to-day before Judge Durfee and Associate Justices Matteson and stiness. It was an adjourned hearing.
James Crooks, while cleaning his revolver at his home on Van Winkle-street, Jersey City Heights, last evening, accidently shot himself through the head. He died at once.

DOVER, N.H., May 21.--An attempt at jail delivery was made at the County Jail to-day. Jerome King of Great Falls, awaiting trial at the September term of the Supreme Court, made an effort to Overpower Jailer Meserve, while being allowed to empty a pail in the corridor.

Marks for damage for property alleged to have been stolen from his store in February, 1884. It is thought this will have an important bearing on the criminal action.
PARIS, May 21.--M. Rouvier has consented to form a Ministry. He hopes to induce the leading members of the Budget Committee of the Chamber of Deputies to accept positions in the new Cabinet.

ST. LOUIS, May 21.--Renhold Passler, one of the men struck by lightning during the electric storm last Sunday, has developed into a human battery. When he recovered his senses his legs were numb and one of his arms was partly paralyzed.
LONDON, May 21.--The Hamburg American Line steamship Lessing, Capt. Barends, from New-York May 12, for Hamburg, arr. at Plymouth to-day.

The thirteenth annual convention of the Young Men's Catholic National Union will be held in New-York this week. The exerises will begin with a solemn mass in the cathedral on Wednesday morning. Archbishop Corrigan will address the delegates, of whom there will be at least 200.

The Hebrew Free School Association celebrated its twenty-fifth anniversary with an exhibition yesterday at the Terrace Garden, in Fifty-ninth-street, near Lexington-avenue. LAMAR, Mo., May 22.--At Quantha, seven miles west of here, prospectors for natural gas have encountered at a depth of 200 feet what is considered to be a rich lead of zinc. Experts pronounce it zinc and the run is nine feet thick.

The funeral of William H. Macy was held in the Friends' Meeting House, in Rutherfurdplace, yesterday afternoon. There were no pall bearers, and the services were conducted according to the custom of the Society of Friends, addresses being made by Several ministers and elders.

MEXICO, Mo., May 23.--W.W. Dawson committed suicide to-day by shooting himself through the heart. He had just returned from Dodge City, Kan., where he had been fleeced of all his money by land sharks.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 23.--Another notice was served on the Denmead hermits to-day that brings a fourth party into the legal contest over their property. F.R. Boice, who leases the Jarrard mansion, has notified them to move out of the barn, which he claims to come under his lease.
