His favorite romance is "Parnellism and Crime."

SCRANTON, Penn., May 23.--A large and enthusiastic meeting was held here to-night to protest against the Tory policy of coercion for Ireland. Senator Watres presided, and addresses were delivered by the Rev. Dr. Price, Pastor of the Adams-Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church; Dr. Spencer, Pastor of the Penn-Avenue Baptist Church; District Attorney Edwards, and others. Dispatches were forwarded to Gladstone and Parnell protesting against coercion and applauding the policy of home rule for Ireland.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 23.--Bessie Miles, aged 8 years, a daughter of a blacksmith living near Harrod's Creek, was on Saturday night the victim of a cruel joke which caused the loss of her reason. On the night in question the little girl's mother took her to the residence...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 23.--General Counsel Williamson, of the Nickel Plate, and T.E. Stillman, of New-York, have gone to Chicago to secure the confirmation of the Nickel Plate foreclosure sales in the Illinois courts, and when that is accomplished they will go to Fort Wayne, Ind., on the same errand.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 23.--John Preston, the oldest citizen in the State of NewJersey, died yesterday.

Hugh J. Duffy, teacher of Class D in the fourth grade of Grammar School No. 82, presented his defense last night before the Nineteenth Ward Trustees in School No. 76, to the charges affecting his competency made by his Principal, George E. Hardy. He presented teachers' certificates that had been given him in 1858, 1860, and 1876.

The Legislature of New-Hampshire meets on Wednesday of next week and will have occasion to elect a United States Senator for the unexpired term of Mr. PIKE, Senator CHENEY'S appointment holding good only until a successor has been chosen.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 23.--A sensational fist fight occurred here this afternoon between two prominent Democrats, Charles S. Bronston, Commonwealth's Attorney, and J.C. Bryant, a well known druggist, in which Bryant was badly used up by Bronston. Both were arrested, and upon Bronston's person the police found a pistol. Mr. Bronston is a candidate for Congress against Col. W.C.P. Breckinridge, and had cursed Bryant in vigorous language.

The unveiling of the cathedral facade today has been a splendid success, favored by the finest possible weather and without a hitch in the arrangements, whether on the part of the committee or of the architect. Order has been perfectly maintained.

HAMILTON, Ontario, May 23.--The chief incident connected with Mr. O'Brien's visit to Hamilton occurred just after the meeting tonight, when the party were fired upon while returning in cabs to the hotel.

CHICAGO, May 23.--Vice-President Van Horn, of the Canadian Pacific, is in the city perfecting arrangements for establishing a new through line from Chicago and St. Louis to Montreal both for freight and passenger traffic, in direct competition with the Grand Trunk.

The Government has since 1859 taken three observations daily of the height of the water at the Milwaukee Lighthouse. At the present time the water in Milwaukee Bay is a foot lower than in May, 1885. Last September the water reached the highest level it has attained since 1859, a period of 27 years. In 1876, however, the water level was very high, but not...
Sherman S. Rogers, of Buffalo, is at the Windsor Hotel. Bishop J.F. Hurst, of Buffalo, is at the St. Denis Hotel.

NEW-HAVEN, May 23.--The Yale-Columbia championship game scheduled for to-morrow will be forfeited to Yale, notice to that effect having been received by the manager of the Yale nine to-day. The following telegram gives Columbia's reason's:

PORTLAND, Oregon, May 23.--Articles incorporating the Columbia Navigating Company were filed to-day with the Secretary of State. The purpose is to establish a line of steamboats between the Dalles and Portland, with portage through incompleted locks at the Cascades. The work of constructing the steamers is already begun. The incorporators are; Judge O.S. Savage, of the Dalles; Capt. Henry M. Coe, of Hood River, and Frank L. Dodge, of Portland.

John Greenwall, the convicted murderer of Lyman S. Weeks, was to have been sentenced yesterday, but at the request of his counsel sentence was postponed until Friday, when he will move for a new trial.

WASHINGTON, May 23.--The leave of absence granted Capt. Cass Durham, Eighteenth Infantry, has been extended until further orders. Capt. Frederick F. Whitehead, Commissary of Subsistence, now on sick leave, has been assigned to temporary duty as Purchasing and Depot Commissary of Subsistence in Washington, to relieve Capt. Wells Willard.

Dr. McGlynn lectured in the Cooper Union last evening to an immense audience, mainly composed of his old parishioners. The lecture was for the benefit of the treasury of the United Labor Party in the Eighteenth Assembly District. The Concordia Musical Club furnished the music.

Egmont von Tilly, a young and handsome Prussian, ended his somewhat romantic life yesterday morning by sending a pistol ball through his brain. The act was the result of morbid brooding over real and imaginary trouble, which unbalanced his mind.
WILMINGTON, Del., May 23.--Mrs. Rebecca Ruthvin, a guest of the Deer Park Hotel, at Newark, and mother of the proprietor, successfully adopted to-day a novel method of taking her life.

Such a crowd as assembled at the White Star pier yesterday morning had not been seen there since that bleak day in April, 1873, when the news came that the Atlantic, of the same line, had foundered on Golden Rule Rock, off Halifax, carrying down 300 passengers into a furious sea.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 23.--Charles Merck an artist, committed suicide to-day by taking poison. He was a native of Sutherland and had friends in the East. Letters left behind indicate that he killed himself because starvation faced him.

The litigation of the New-York City and Northern Railroad, which has hampered the Yonkers Rapid Transit Company ever since its organization, has now been settled and an agreement has been completed by which the latter company yesterday put 100 men to work commencing to build the road.

BOSTON, May 23.--The message of Gov. Ames vetoing the Beverly Farms Division bill, sent to the Senate to-day, ends the most sensational contest of the legislative session, for it is not believed that the measure can pass over the veto.

WASHINGTON, May 23.--Before the Inter-State Commerce Comission to-day Mr. William Brown, in behalf of the Chicago and Alton Railroad Company, filed charges against the Pennsylvania Railroad Company of violation of the third section of the Inter-State Commerce act.

ALBANY, May 23.--The members of the two branches of the Legislature, some of the State officers, and the public to the number of probably 300 ladies and gentlemen, listened to the oration upon Samuel J. Tilden delivered in the Assembly Chamber to-night by ex-Senator George Raines, of Rochester.

Mr. Chauncey M. Depew was seen last night at his residence in reference to the charge made yesterday at Washington before the InterState Commerce Commission that the NewYork Central Company was violating the third section of the inter-State commerce act.

WASHINGTON, May 23.--The President made the following appointments to-day: In the Revenue Service of the United States: Horace Hassell to be a Chief Engineer; Charles W. Munroe to be a First Assistant Engineer; William H. Warren to be a First Assistant Engineer; Orrick N. Turner to be a Second Assistant Engineer; Dennis F. Bowen to be a Second Assistant Engineer.

Judge Van Hoesen, in the Court of Common Pleas, and his jury, formed themselves into an art committee yesterday and critically examined a representation of a Mediterranean scene, which the owner, Jacob H. Studer, says is an oil painting by Salvator Rosa, and for injuries to which he asks the Manhattan Storage and Warehouse Company to pay him $25,000.

A crash of falling timbers and bricks from behind the old Tompkins Market startled everybody in the neighborhood just after 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and the rattle of trucks and fire engines a few moments after caused much excitement. The firemen found that ambulances and surgeons were needed instead of men to fight a fire.

In Saturday's sitting of the Reichsrath Herr Pernerstorfer called attention to the management of the Vienna Allgemeines Krankenhaus, the largest hospital in Austria, and one of the largest in Europe, with over 2,000 beds, in which 26,000 patients are treated yearly.

So many gentlemen responded to the invitations issued by the Commonwealth Club for its dinner last night that the resources of the Metropolitan Hotel mere seriously taxed and it was forced to crave the indulgence of the guests and serve a late dinner.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 23.--The Senior Class at Rutgers College have selected the following class day officers: President--A.B. Herman, ...
The Brooklyn Aldermen yesterday appointed 15 matrons to take charge of female prisoners locked up temporarily in the various police stations. Each matron is to get a salary of $600 a year.
Orville Oddie, Jr., Of Brooklyn, and L.A. Flanagan, of Philadelphia, started the amateur billiard tournament for the championship and a five-hundred-dollar silver cup at the Racquet Club last night.

Among the most appealing charities in aid of the sick is the picture mission. It goes hand in hand with the flower mission in bringing beauty and comfort to those who are shut out from the delights of the world by physical misfortunes.

It was 26 years ago yesterday that the Fourteenth Regiment of Brooklyn was mustered into the service for the period of the war, and the remaining members of the regiment went to the armory on Portland-avenue last night to celebrate that event.

Betting men who have placed their money on Tremont to win the suburban were much agitated yesterday by the report that it has been decided not to start the famous unbeaten colt for that race. His bad foot has not come around right yet, and he is being handled tenderly at the Brooklyn track, and given no hard or fast work.

Mayor Hewitt announced at yesterday's meeting of the Gas Commission that he would veto the electric light resolution recently passed by the Aldermen. The Mayor will send his veto in at to-day's meeting of the board.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 23.--The President and Mrs. Cleveland will be unable to attend the monument dedication services on June 17, for reasons given in the following letter, received to-day:

PHILADELPHIA, May 23.--William Stanton, a tall young man, built on fine lines, who lives at Twentieth and Federal streets, had his head repaired to-day. He at first thought he had run his head against a buzz saw, but it was only a meat saw in the hands of the irate father of his best girl.

A big drab-colored spider crawled on the hand of little Fritz Kiblitz, who lived at 650 Fifth-street, Saturday afternoon, and bit it. Fritz's mother killed the spider and noticed that the hand was beginning to swell. A doctor was called in and treated the injury, but the little follow suffered much pain and died yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 23.--There were no important developments in the wheat deal to-day. The clique operated to a moderate extent only early in the session, selling lines of July and September, and prices advanced cent to 7/8 cent in response chiefly to the covering of the...

Commissioner Donovan, of the State Board of Arbitration, and his colleagues met yesterday at the Metropolitan Hotel to effect, if possible, a settlement between the locked-out silver workers and their employers.

MONTREAL, May 23.--There has rarely been such a large and representative gathering of influential citizens as that which assembled this afternoon to pay the last tribute of respect to one who so lately occupied what is considered the foremost position in the banking institutions of the Dominion.

LONDON, May 23.--Mr. Balfour, Chief Secretary for Ireland, replying to Mr. Gladstone in the House of Commons to-night, promised to procure during the recess a return of Irish agrarian crime to the end of May.

The interior of James Seligman's house, at 14 East Fifty-seventh-street, was decorated last evening with palms, tropical plants, and flowers in profusion, on the occasion of the wedding of his daughter, Miss Fannie Seligman, to Robert F. Nathan, Jr. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Gottheil, of Temple Emanu-El. Miss Seligman wore a white satin gown trimmed with pearls and point lace.

CHICAGO, May 23.--Chairman Fairthorn has issued a call for a meeting of the Western and Northwestern Railway Freigh Bureau, to be held at his office next Tuesday, to consider the troubles between the Northwestern roads regarding the maintenance of freight rates. Grain and flour rates from all points in the Northwest are now being made on the basis of 72 cents per 100 pounds.

Here, too, are a few items regarding the royal yachts which may prove interesting to the British taxpayer. The original cost of the Victoria and Albert was about 136,000, and she has since had spent on her over 300,000.

Subway Commissioners Hess and Gibbens testified before United States Commissioner Shields, in the McMahon-Flynn subway suit yesterday, in regard to their work on the commission, and told how the contract was made with the Consolidated Telegraph and Electric Subway Company through Edward Lauterbach to do the work of putting wires under ground.

From Aldgate to the People's Palace the eye is feasted by a blaze of bunting and a forest of Venetian masts, which have been erected by the loyal eastenders in honor of her Majesty's visit to-day, and this portion of the route should make up for the less plentiful decorations in Paddington and other streets through which the State procession will pass.

Mayor Hewitt attended yesterday's meeting of the Committee on Railroads of the Board of Aldermen, which was held to discuss the violation of law by the street railroad companies in sanding their tracks. President Hart, of the Christopher and Tenth Streets Cross-town...

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 23.--In the Southern Presbyterian Assembly this morning the Committee on Organic Union, Co-operative Union, or other relations with the Presbyterian Church of the United States. Dr. Smoot, of Texas, Chairman, presented three reports.
Mix in a dish a little of everything to be found in a hotel kitchen and you have the ground work of a salad. Add to it a fancy name and it is ready for the table.
CINCINNATI, May 23.--The Summer meeting at Latonia to-day opened auspiciously, for there was a large crowd at the track, good racing, and money won by the bankers of the short horses.
The second week of the Sharp trial opened a little somnolently yesterday owing to the weather or a preternaturally quiet Sunday.

President Houston, of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, has sailed for Europe, and it is averred by his friends that under no circumstances will he accept a re-election as the executive head of the company. Edward Lanterbach, the lawyer, is talked of for President now. George Gould has intimated that he would not take the post, though this intimation is believed to be subject to revision.

The Kings County Grand Jury, which is supposed to be investigating the charges made against Fire Chief Nevins and District Attorney Ridgway, by the Bacon committee, had a lot of new witnesses on hand yesterday.

KEATING, N.Y., May 23.--The protracted dry spell has reduced the woods in this section of the country to the condition of tinder, and as a result there is a most disastrous forest fire raging. Last week a spark started a fire near Liberty Station, on the Buffalo, New-York and Philadelphia Railroad...

BALTIMORE, May 23.--To-day the State Veterinary Surgeon discovered a milk dairy of 18 cows in the northwestern section of the city, 14 of which were afflicted with pleuro-pneumonia. All of them were killed, and as soon as the stable can be appraised that will be burned. The four cows not afflicted by the disease were killed as a precaution to prevent the spread of the malady.

PORTLAND, Oregon, May 23.--At a meeting of the Directors of the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company, of this city, to-day, the President and Secretary of the company were authorized and instructed to accept a franchise granted by the last Oregon Legislature to build a railway bridge across the Willamette River at Portland, and file said acceptance with the Secretary of State. Work on the bridge will be commenced at once.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 23.--The health authorities of this city were informed recently of the appearance of what was thought to be a sporadic case of yellow fever at Key West. The information is confirmed, and it is reported that two more persons have been taken with the disease. The first case was that of a man named Baker, who died to-day, and the other two persons are his wife and sister.
"Fair Fame," a play by Clinton Stuart will be acted for the first time at the Madison Square Theatre this afternoon.
Lieut. John Wyckoff, of the revenue steamer Grant, which makes this port its headquarters, will be soon transferred to the steamer Dexter, now at Newport.

Herman Gruendler, musical director of the Patti-Rosa Company, was arrested in Wareing's Theatre, Hoboken, last night, charged by Louis Budenbender, a real estate agent of that city, with having obtained from him $900 under false pretenses.

CLAY CENTRE, Kan., May 23.--A tornado struck Idana, a small town eight miles west of here, last evening. The new schoolhouse was entirely demolished, two churches badly damaged, and half a dozen dwelling houses blown down. The people generally took refuge in cellars. Only one person was seriously hurt.

CLARKSVILLE, Mo., May 23.--The 100mile bicycle road race for the championship of the world, under the auspices of the League of American Wheelmen, was run here today. Besides the immense representation from the Pike County towns there were several hundred members of the League present.
The body of a man greatly decomposed, which had been apparently in the water six months or more, was picked up in the harbor yesterday morning at Glen Cove, Long Island.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., May 23.--The Erie Railway has closed a contract for two sixty-thousand-dollar iron steamers for Chautauqua Lake.
BROCKVILLE, Ontario, May 23.--While Mrs. Keefer and Mrs. Pocock were out driving to-day their horse ran away. Both ladies were thrown out of the carriage and Mrs. Pocock was killed.

The strange disappearance of the British screw steamship Lovaine, Capt. H.M. McCaulley, is the cause of much alarm in the shipping circles at this port. The steamer arrived here March 2 from the Mediterranean with a full cargo of iron ore and sailed for Coosau on the 8th of March, where she loaded 2,400 tons of phosphate rock for Newcastle, England.

The sale of the library of Richard M. Hoe, who died on June 18 last, was begun yesterday at 739 and 741 Broadway. In all 718 lots were sold, consisting of works on printing, engraving, and the allied arts.

READING, Penn., May 23.--A distressing and fatal casualty occurred at the locks of the Schuylkill Canal at Birdsborough last evening, the victim being William Maderia, aged 14, a driver on a canalboat. Desiring to take a bath, he leaped into the water near the feeder of the lock, and the current drew him down and through the gates. His body was...

The defense of Dr. Reynolds, accused of defrauding the London Assurance Company, was begun in the Yorkville Court yesterday. Dr. Reynolds said he would reserve his right to make a statement as to the line of defense until some later date.

Mr. WILLIAM O'BRIEN has been assailed by a mob in Toronto and again in Kingston. How many times is it necessary that he shall be hooted, or pelted, or knocked on the head, in order to vindicate his principle, whatever it may be? Apparently twice...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 23.--The John L. Sullivan combination is billed to give a performance at the New-Haven Opera House Wednesday evening, but Chief of Police Bollmann has refused to grant a license if any sparring is to be done.

BERLIN, May 23.--The Westphalian Manufacturing Company will close its works in Russia owing to the heavy duties imposed by the new tariff on material used by the company. Several failures of firms in the textile trade are announced.

SUPERIOR, Wis., May 23.--The village of Hawthorne, Wis., on the Omaha Road, about 18 miles south of that place, has been destroyed by fire. No lives were lost. The pecuniary loss cannot be estimated at present.

Frank I. Frayne, an actor, who, in his play of "Mardo," rescues an all-important document from the cage of a big lion, to the wonder and delight of the galleries, had a narrow escape a few days ago from furnishing a meal for the animal.

When the examination of Morris Spiegel, Receiver of the Maison Tortoni, was resumed yesterday before Referee W.H. Clark, Spiegel appeared with a new legal adviser, R.S. Newcombe, well known as counsel for the "boodle" Aldermen.

MILWAUKEE, May 23.--For the past few days rumors have been rife that Mrs. Alexander Mitchell would contest the will of her late husband, and it has even been said that she had already engaged legal talent to make the contest.

WASHINGTON, May 23.--The opening formalities of the national drill took place at noon to-day and were very brief and simple. Policemen cleared a space about the flag staff in front of the camp headquarters in the monument lot.

"Gillette de Narbonne" is an operetta, by Audran, which has on several occasions been talked of as on the verge of production in this city, but it was not until last night, at Terrace Garden, that it was made known. In the German tongue and in the hands of German performers it is probable that the operetta loses ...

WASHINGTON, May 23.--A most exciting and interesting game of baseball took place between the Washington and Detroit teams to-day. Ten innings were necessary to decide the contest, and when the last Detroit plan was thrown out at first base the spectators were almost frantic with delight. About one-half of the spectators were visiting military men.

Sir Charles Tupper, Canadian Minister of Finance in Canada, at present visiting this city, yesterday expressed his views on matters which interest the metropolitan public. His first remarks concerned the visit of Mr. O'Brien to Canada, and while he did not go in the subject very...
The schooner Magnolia, Capt. Kent, bound from Kingston for Boston, was run into at 5:30 yesterday afternoon in the East River, opposite the foot of Wall street, by the steamer City of NewYork.

The Grand Army posts of Sing Sing are making great preparations for the observance of Decoration Day. They will unveil a new soldiers' monument in Merchants'-square, which has been designed and made by the sculptor, Maurice J. Power, of Sing Sing.

BOSTON, May 23.--Mr. Daly's company produced "The Taming of the Shrew" in Boston to-night. It was the first time the induction and comedy had ever been offered here, and the literary interest of the city was fully aroused, and the audience, which packed the Museum from parquet to gallery, was gathered...

THEIR DECLARED PRINCIPLES. CHICAGO, May 23.--The Chicago builders who have locked out their men and are trying to establish a basis for their re-employment discovered to-day that they have "bitten off more than they can chew," and accordingly divided the morsel.

The Third-Avenue Railroad Company applied to Judge Bartlett, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, for a mandamus to compel Gen. John Newton, the Commissioner of Public Works, to permit them to excavate Thirdavenue from One Hundred and Thirtieth-street to the City Hall Park for the purpose of laying a cable with which to move its cars.

Widespread interest attaches to two decisions which were handed down by the United States Supreme Court at Washington yesterday. The cases are those involving the use of driven wells under the patents of Nelson W. Green. The brief memorandum furnished by the court is as follows:

WASHINGTON, May 23.--The United States Supreme Court briefly announced decisions to-day in about 20 cases and then adjoerned until Friday. Leading counsel in the telephone cases were present, but a decision in those cases was not rendered. Among the cases of general interest were the following:
After the close of business yesterday afternoon the members of the Cotton Exchange held a meeting to discuss the proposed amend ments to the by-laws to conform with the Saturday half-holiday law.
The New-Yorks and Pittsburgs play this afternoon on the Polo Ground and the Jersey Citys and Buffalos in Jersey City.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 23.--Chattanooga raised to-day $150,000 to subscribe to a mammoth mower and reaper works which will be moved from the North to this city. It will be capitalized at $400,000, and will employ 700 hands.

Every time dogs are put on the trail of a criminal the telegraph is sure to say they are bloodhounds. Now, there are not many bloodhounds in this country, and we venture to say that of the few there never was one of the breed used in trailing men.

CITY OF MEXICO, May 23, via Galveston.--The National Railway and its branches were sold to-day at public sale to the purchasing committee of the new National Company. No outside parties attended the sale, which will in a few days be made complete, according to the laws of Mexico.

PARIS, May 23.--President Grevy to-day sent MM. Floquet and Rouvier to endeavor to induce M. de Freycinet to make another attempt to form a Cabinet M. Grevy subsequently received M. Duclerc, and M. Floquet, believing that a combination was intended under Duclerc, did not visit M. de Freycinet, who, consequently, did not receive the message that had been sent to him by the President.

David Rice, a big Hungarian, was complainant in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday against Mrs. Ernestina Wertheim and her daughter, Teresa Blum, who is 17 years old. He charged them with stealing two gold watches and chains. The only result of his prosecution was that he was himself committed to jail in default of $600 ball on a charge of assault.
LONDON, May 23.--The steamship Caledonia, (Br.,) Capt. Garvie, sld. from Naples for New-York yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 23.--East-bound shipments of dead freight from this city through to seaboard points last week amounted to 28,589 tons, against 28,742 tons for the previous week. The following statement shows the percentages carried by each of the roads named during the last week:

We have never denied or doubted the necessity of party machinery or its capacity, when rightly organized, in the hands of really representative men to do excellent and indispensable work for the party.

WASHINGTON, May 23.--The recent executive order consolidating 22 collection districts of internal revenue out of official existence is to be put into effect on the 15th of June next, or as soon thereafter as practicable, the object being to have all the newly consolidated...

SELMA, Ala., May 23.--The Bar Association of Dallas County by a unanimous vote has recommended Gen. E.W. Pettus, of Selma, to the President for appointment to the vacant place on the Supreme Court Bench of the United States. A committee consisting of J.R. Butterfield, Sumpter Lea, and Judge Jonathan Haralson was appointed to lay the action of the bar before the President.

ALBANY, May 23.--Gov. Hill listened this afternoon to two very strong sermons against the Ives Pool bill, which were delivered by the Rev. Dr. Talmage, of Brooklyn, and the Rev. Dr. R.S. MacArthur, of New-York.

The examination for the degree of LL.B., which took place last week in the University Law School, came to a close yesterday. The following are the names of the successful candidates: Messrs. Albert, Alker, Beaty, Busby, Buttenweiser,...

John B.A. Mullaly, a stockholder of the National Consumers' Meat Company, asked Judge Bartlett, in the Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, for an injunction restraining the Marquis de Mores and the other Trustees of that company from "selling, or disposing of, or in any manner transferring, alienating, or incumbering its property, real or personal."
The New-Yorks yesterday won their third consecutive game from the Pittsburgs. It was a thoroughly interesting game, and showed that the NewYork nine can win even with their weakest pitcher ...
The value of a series of watertight compartments in an ocean steamship was never more clearly shown than on Thursday last, when the Britannic and the Celtic were in collision.
LOWELL, Mass., May 23.--Nine hundred operatives employed by the Lowell Manufacturing Company will be idle this week on account of the breaking down of the new engine this morning.

The residence of the Rev. John C. Eccleston, rector of St. John's Church, at Clifton, Staten Island, was entered by burglars early yesterday morning, who took a large amount of silver ware and $50 in money.

ALBANY, May 23.--The imperfections of the half holiday law, which has been so criticised by bankers and business men, will be removed by the terms of a bill which Mr, Sheehan, of Buffalo, passed in the Assembly this afternoon, and which was promptly progressed to the order of third reading in the Senate.

The Socialists met last evening in Unionsquare to hear what Lawrence Greenland, the Socialistic writer, who has just come from England, had to say. About 450 people stood in front of a truck near the cottage, and from the truck Greenland and other speakers addressed the meeting.

Mr. W. O'Brien, who is now on his way across the Atlantic, is to be elected member of Parliament in his absence. There is no limit to the restless energy of this remarkable man. His soul is too active for its case, and his ardent and indomitable spirit is wearing out a physical frame that was never exceptionally robust.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 23.--The speakers who will compete for the Townsend oration prize, at the Yale Law School graduation exercises, are: V.V. Barnes. Du Smet, Dakota, "Old Age of Gladstone;" Warner T. McGuinn, Baltimore, "Constitutional Limitations to Land Taxes," and E.I. Sanford, Jr., New-Haven, "Old Age of Gladstone." The Hon. John Randolph Tucker, of Lexington, Va., has accepted an invitation to deliver the oration to the graduating class.

In the matter of the contest between Nathaniel Hunter, of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, and Henry Leter, for the guardianship of Charles Leter, a brother of the latter and a minor, the following petition was filed in the Probate Court yesterday by the child:

Fifty boys employed in Nelson Klueber's torpedo factory, on Eldert-avenue, Brooklyn, demanded a half holiday on Saturday, and failing to get it struck and left the shop in a body. Several of them stood outside and threw stones, and a detective arrested six of them on a charge of conspiring to injure the firm's business. Justice Schellein held them for examination.
PARIS, May 23.--The sale of the crown jewels was completed to-day, the four unsold sub-lots of Lot 45 being first disposed of. These were bought by M. Mont for 4,300f.

Queen Kapiolani, attended by her daughter and various accompanying dignitaries, visited the navy yard yesterday and inspected the beauties of that picturesque locality. Mayor and Mrs. Hewitt and several other ladies and...

SAN FRANCISCO, May 24.--The estimated California hay crop this year will be 80,000 bales, an increase over last year of 23,000 bales. Reports from Oregon, Washington Territory, and British Columbia also show an increase.
The excursion which John H. Starin had offered the police force was fixed for June 2, but it has been indefinitely postponed by direction of Superintendent Murray.

A meeting was held in Chickering Hall last evening to help along the Saturday holiday movement. The clerks and salesgirls and day workers who are to be benefited by the new scheme did not come in the big crowds that might have been expected, but many business...

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 24.--The candidacy of Judge Samuel W. Williams for the Supreme Court bench is attracting general attention throughout the Southwest. THE TIMES'S correspondent interviewed many of the leading...

WASHINGTON, May 24.--Surgeon-General Hamilton, of the Marine Hospital Service, said to-day that he has received official notice of the existence of yellow fever at Key West, but that the situation is not sufficiently grave to call for action on the part of the Government.

The Rapid Transit Commissioners made their report to Mayor Hewitt yesterday, and the latter sent the document to the Board of Aldermen. The Mayor sent a short explanatory note with the report suggesting that the Aldermen have the report printed so that the recommendations could be examined at leisure.
A.T. Goshorn, of Cincinnati, is at the Everett House. James J. Beldan, of Syracuse, is at the Windsor Hotel.

LONDON, May 24.--Canon Fleming, one of the Chaplains in ordinary to her Majesty, has just published a volume of sermons. The Pall Mall Gazette alleges that one of the sermons is a gross plagiarism of a sermon delivered by Dr. Talmage, of the Brooklyn Tabernacle, six years ago.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., May 24.--R.W. Gilder, the poet and editor of the Century Magazine, was greeted with a brilliant audience this evening at his lecture before the students of...

CHICAGO, May 24.--The crowd made a bold charge at the clique to-day, and, as on one other occasion during the existence of the May deal, took the market away from them and plunged it into a semi-panic.

ROME, May 24.--The Pope, in an allocution yesterday, referred to the religious peace with Prussia, which the Pope said he had made every effort to attain. Continuing, the Pope said: "We felt more concerned at the evils of...

LONDON, May 24.--Sir Algernon Borthwick, (Conservative,) Member of Parliament for South Kensington, and proprietor of the London Morning Post, in an address to his constituents last evening said that after the Whitsun recess the Government proposed to force the passage of the Irish Crimes Act Amendment bill within a specified period whether or no all the amendments to the bill were disposed of.
BOSTON, May 24.--The House this afternoon refused to pass the bill for the division of Beverly over the Governor's veto.

"Sixty-seven men examined, one juror obtained," was the Clerk's summary in the Sharp trial yesterday. There is no expectation that the taking of testimony will begin before next week, and the hardship on the jury of being kept together over Saturday and Sunday will be avoided.

BERLIN, May 24.--The Tagblatt says that the physicians who operated on Crown Prince Frederick William's throat found an inflamed growth the size of a lentil on the vocal chord.

TORONTO, Ontario, May 24.--Lord Lansdowne, in his speech before the National Club to-night, referred to Mr. O'Brien's visit to Canada as follows: "The kindness and hospitality of your people have been as delightful as the weather which we have encountered.

BOSTON, Mass., May 24.--There was no formal observance of the Queen's birthday in this city. At Marlborough delegations from the various Irish societies, except the Clan-na-Gael, which refused to participate, held a parade and mock demonstration, with black flags, c. A mass meeting followed in the Town Hall. Addresses were made by the Rev. P.A. McKenna, J.J. Donovan, ex-Mayor of Lowell, and others.

BOSTON, Mass., May 24.--Ex-Gov. Robert E. Pattison, of Philadelphia, and Mr. David T. Littler, of Springfield, Ill., members of the United States Pacific Railway Commission, are now in Boston, and Mr. E. Ellery Anderson, of New-York, the other member, is expected to arrive to-night.

KEYPORT, N.J., May 24.--Great clouds of asparagus flies have made their appearance within the last few days and are carrying destruction into the fields of asparagus throughout the county. The fly eats away the tips of the asparagus, thus spoiling its sale in the city market. The insects have also attacked the young peach trees and are feeding upon the leaves.

NORWALK, Conn., May 24.--George B. Gilbert, aged 65 years, a wealthy and prosperous farmer of Wilton, jumped into a well this morning and was drowned. For the past two or three weeks Gilbert had been acting strangely, and it is thought that at times he was insane. He was one of the largest fruit growers in the State.

The new steel sloop building for Gen. Paine will probably be launched in about five weeks. She will then be towed to Boston and fitted the yard of Lawley Sons. Her sail plan will be much like the Mayflower's, with a trifle more hoist at the peak of the mainsail. Her forestay will be of steel and will lead to the gammon iron.

CINCINNATI, May 24.--With a track half mud and half dust the races were run here today, and they proved a bad lot for the backers of the favorites, as the summaries show.

Three sailors went to Commissioner Shields yesterday to testify against Albert M. Rich, mate of the Robert L. Belknap, accused of so brutally beating and starving James Peterson, one of the crew, as to cause his death. Rich is a big man, powerfully built, and seemingly all bone and muscle.

LONDON, May 24.--The Epsom Summer meeting opened to-day. The Woodcote Stakes for 2-yearolds was won by Baron Rothschild's filly by Robert the Devil, out of Peace, who was the favorite in the betting at seven to four on her. Simon Pure was second and Polydor third of the seven starters.

WASHINGTON, May 24.--The President's appointment to-day of Mr. Charles M. Stafford, of Brooklyn, to be United States Marshal of the Eastern District of New-York, will probably be the last appointment of importance made before his departure for Saranac Lake on Thursday next.

ST. LOUIS, May 24.--The bloody shirt was flaunted in all its ghastliness in the Southern Assembly to-day. The debate on organic union came up, and Dr. Smoot, of Texas, a signer of the minority report, talked for three hours against organic or any other kind of union.

WASHINGTON, May 24.--The cushion-carrom billiard match between Messrs. Daly and Sexton was continued in this city to-night. In the sixtyfourth inning Daly's score reached the limit for one night, 300, to 191 for Sexton, and playing was suspended until to-morrow evening. Daly's score for the two nights is thus 600 to 321 for Sexton. Daly's highest run to-night was 36, and Sexton's, 35.

There was no formal celebration of Queen Victoria's sixty-ninth birthday in this city yesterday. However, as usual, there were many evidences of patriotic pride and loyal affection in many quarters.

PARIS, May 24.--In view of the failure of all the combinations to effect a settlement of the Ministerial question, President Grevy has recalled M. Floquet and appealed to his patriotism to form a Cabinet. M. Floquet asked for 24 hours to consider the matter.

WASHINGTON, May 24.--In nearly all the departments there are already indications of a relaxation of business in view of the President's approaching departure. The Secretary of State, however, has been closely engaged to-day in disposing of some important matters which have to be passed upon before the President leaves the city.
James E. Welch, an examiner under Appraiser McMullen, has resigned his position. It was worth $2,500 a year. His successor is not yet appointed.
CAIRO, May 24.--It is believed that England and Turkey will propose a conference of the powers to settle the reforms of the Egyptian capitulation by a new convention.

TORONTO, Ontario, May 24.--The National Club this evening entertained the Marquis of Lansdowne. In reply to the toast in which the club honored him, the Governor-General made a long and able address, which was frequently applauded and interrupted with cheers by the assemblage of prominent citizens around the table.

TORONTO, May 24.--Exactly 21 years ago the United States constructed a barrier between it and the provinces of Canada. This barrier possessed all of the annoying and none of the advantageous qualities of a barbed-wire fence; it was invisible until it made itself felt.

ALBANY, May 24.--An excise bill upon which both Democrats and Republicans were united passed the Assembly this morning. It is known as the Erwin Five-Gallon bill. It is, in effect, an absolute prohibition of liquor selling in no-license towns in the country.

READING, Penn., May 24.--Katie German, a 17-year-old daughter of Franz German, a farmer living at Engelsville, in this county, while helping her father in digging a cistern this afternoon, was instantly killed by being crushed under a mass of rock and earth, which gave way and slid down about 15 feet from the top. Her head was crushed to a jelly. Joseph Boyer, a young man who was assisting, was seriously injured, but may recover.

All the right, title, and interest of the American Reporter Company, Limited, of 65 Duane-street, was sold out by the Sheriff yesterday.

BOSTON, May 24.--A fire occurred at the house 1,238 Tremont-street early this morning, starting in the bakeshop of Peter Zimmer, on the lower floor.

WASHINGTON, May 24.--The Superintendent of the Recruiting Service has been directed to forward 40 recruits to Fort Snelling, Minn., for assignment to the Fifteenth Infantry.

Gen. Abraham Duryee, the organizer of the famous regiment of zouaves which bore his name, had a slight attack of apoplexy yesterday afternoon in the office of Theodore N. Melvin, in the Bennett Building.

The second trial of Mrs. Chiara Cignarole for the murder of her husband, Antonio Cignarole, in October last, was begun in earnest yesterday in the Court of General Sessions, Part I. Mrs. Cignarole had been ill treated by her husband.
Two cases of smallpox were reported yesterday, one at 145 Sullivan-street, and the other at 210 Elm-street.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 24.--There promises to be an unusually large gathering in this city Sunday next, the occasion being the meeting of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers. Special trains will be run on all the railroads entering the city. There are 23,000 members of the organization, and delegates are expected from every State.

Had the New-Yorks played ball yesterday as they did the day before they might have gained a fourth victory over the Pittsburgs. As it was the visitors won the game on its merits. With Welch in the box the New-Yorks seemed properly impressed with the fact that they must play a strong fielding and batting game in order to win.

Lawson N. Fuller and Russell Sage conferred yesterday regarding the plans for the four-in-hand race they propose to make next month, against time, for $5,000. The details of this race are to be practically those suggested in THE TIMES a fortnight ago.

KINGSTON, N.Y., May 24.--Much indignation is expressed by anglers in the Hudson River tier of counties and in the inland counties adjoining over the trouble along the Neversink, in Denning, Ulster County.

Probst, representing their interests, bought the road at a public sale yesterday. The Decoration Day sail of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club promises to be a very lively one. The Galatea is expected to go over the course with the Priscilla, and in the second class sloops the Mischief and Arrow are pretty sure to start.

A case that would seem to demand a rigid investigation by the proper authorities came to light yesterday, when Abraham Brother, of 184 Ludlow street, called on Coroner Messemer and related the circumstances attending the death of his infant child, Annie.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 25.--The British Hosiery Company, at Thornton, has posted a notice of the probability of a reduction to half the present force, or a possible shut down.

The Rev. Mr. Geer, Rector of Christ Church, Oyster Bay, presented a resolution to the Episcopal Diocesan Convention at Garden City, Long Island, yesterday which will interest members of the church all over the country. It was well on in the afternoon when Mr. Geer, after the Rev. Dr. Middletown, of ...

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 25.--Prof. John M. Klein, the Kentucky astronomer, discovered the Star of Bethlehem last night at 7 o'clock. Its position is in the northwestern heavens, closely skirting the horizon. Its lustre is most intense.

The cattle in Westchester, New-York, Richmond, Kings, Queens, and Suffolk Counties have been quarantined by Norman J. Colman, Commissioner of Agriculture, on account of the prevalence of pleuro-pneumonia.
The second annual dinner of the NewYork Mercantile Exchange was held at the Hotel Brunswick last night About 135 members and guests sat down to an excellent menu.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 25.--E.J. Jennings, of Middlebury, Vt., has bought of A.A. Kitzmiller, of this city, the b.c. Tom Hendricks, 3 years old, by Red Wilkes, dam by Curtis Clay. The price paid was $2,100.

BOSTON, Mass., May 25.--The second session of the Pacific Railway Investigating Commission in the matter of the Union Pacific Railroad was held at the Directors' office of the Union Pacific Company this afternoon.

Theodore Hahr, a young Swede, by profession a butler, but in reality an ingenious, thief, is now resting in one of Inspector Byrnes's cells at Police Headquarters. His method was to find employment in the houses of well-to-do families, and thence gaining admission into the ladies' boudoirs, take out the stones from diamond jewelry and replace them with imitations.
On a first rate wicket, on the Staten Islland Cricket Club's ground, at Livingston yesterday, the St. George and Staten Island Clubs played their return game.

The Sharp trial continued as before throughout the two sessions of yesterday. Thirty-eight men were sworn and examined; two jurors were obtained, and one of these was parted with almost immediately on a peremptory challenge by the defense.

Minnie Butlers, a girl of 18, died at her home 116 Harrison-avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday, from the effects of a does of rat poison which she took the evening before by mistake. Several weeks ago her physician told her to take a teaspoonful of cream of tartar every night.

BOSTON, May 25.--The second day's racing of the Country Club at Clyde Park to-day developed great sport, in which New-York horses took a prominent part. The track was rendered exceedingly heavy by the morning rains, but the sport was good in spite of this fact.

Many new securities were listed in the Stock Exchange yesterday, including $1,795, 000 additional first mortgage 4 per cent. bonds of the Mexican Central Railway, making a total of $41,170,000 now listed; $606,000 additional ...

WASHINGTON, May 25.--The Bourbon element, which never learns and never forgets, forced itself to the front to-day in the review by the President of the militia organizations who are supposed to be participating in a "national drill" in the Nation's capital, aided by the gratuitous use of a national reservation and commanded by officers of the national army.

John R. Dos Passos, counsel of the NewYork Underground Telegraph Company, has written a letter to Gov. Hill, in which he asks for another hearing in opposition to the subway bill, and, if it be given, promises to demonstrate ...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 25.--The NewHaven schooner Carrie, Capt. Joshua W. Chappell, from this city to Rockaway Beach with a cargo of oysters, was run into when off Eaton's Neck, Long Island, at 9 o'clock last night by the United States Coast Survey schooner Eager.

Fire started from some unknown cause in the air shaft of the four-story brownstone flats at 165 and 167 East One Hundred and Eleventhstreet, early last evening, and the flames quickly extended up through the shaft, damaging the suites of rooms adjoining.
OTTAWA, May 25.--Two hundred Canadian veterans who participated in the late American civil war will hold a meeting here shortly for the purpose of organizing an association.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 25,--After President Gates had delivered his farewell address to the graduating class of Rutgers College this morning the class honors were announced as follows: Valedictorian, W.P. Merrill, New-Brunswick: Latin salutatorian, Asa Wynkoop, Catskill, N.Y.; philosophical ...

The feature of the annual Commencement of the Columbia Law School, which took place last evening in the Metropolitan Opera House, was the address of Prof. Theodore W. Dwight, the Warden of the school, to the graduating class. Prof. Dwight said that the duty of the lawyer in the future, as in the past, would be to defend life, liberty, and the sacred rights of property.

ALBANY, May 25.--The 74 Republicans of the Assembly were throttled by the 54 Democrats to-day and preventing from riding roughshod over them and outraging every principle of decency and fair play. As their leader on the floor, ex-Speaker Erwin undertook to jump the Vedder Whisky Tax bill to its passage.
PARIS, May 25.--The Opera Comique took fire this evening, and the whole building was soon wrapped in flames.

Frank Sims, 16 years old, of 1,607 Lexington-avenue, who is employed as, a news agent on the Manhattan Elevated Railway, fell from a train to the street below, at Fifty-ninthstreet and Third-avenue, last evening, fracturing his left arm and receiving a dangerous scalp wound. He was sitting on the chain on the rear platform of the train, and when the train started from the Fifty-ninth-street station he was thrown off.
All the canoe clubs of the Lower Hudson, about a dozen in number, will have their Spring meet this year at Croton Point, off Sing Sing, and the Shattemucs, of that village, will entertain them.
CHICAGO, May 25.--The Joliet, Aurora and Northern Railroad, now completed from Aurora to Joliet, has lately been purchased by a syndicate, at the head of which is Drexel, Morgan Co., of New-York.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 25.--For some time past a movement has been on foot in favor of the return to Canada of Gabriel Dumont, Riel's lieutenant in the Northwest rebellion, but his friends urged him not to leave the United States, as it was not known whether the amnesty of July, 1886, covered his case.
At the Custom House it is rumored that the scheme of reorganization devised by the special committee will be put into effect on July 1, when a new fiscal year begins.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 25.--A suit is to be brought against the Perry House proprietor for large damages by Mme. Janauschek, the actress. A week ago last night she fell down a flight of stairs in the hotel and broke her wrist and seriously injured herself otherwise.

The case of the transcontinental lines was taken up again yesterday morning when their representatives met those of the Iowa roads, the Central Traffic Association, and the trunk lines, in Commissioner Fink's office.
COLUMBIA, S.C., May 25.--Amy Avant, a colored woman on the plantation of Major James Reaves, in Marion County, died yesterday of measles at the advanced age of 122 years.

BALTIMORE, May 25.--The Twentyseventh Annual Convention of the United States Brewers' Association was opened this morning at the Concordia Opera House. William A. Miles, of New-York, President of the association, delivered the opening address, in which he congratulated the convention on the work accomplished ...

Waldo Sprague, a prominent member of the New-York Athletic Club, appeared before Justice Ford, at the Jefferson Market Police. Court yesterday, in obedience to a summons granted at the request of Frederick Comstock, ...

SAN FRANCISCO, May 25.--Christian Nauret has filed a complaint in the Superior Court to recover $50,000 from John W. Mackay. He avers that the American Opera Company, Limited, was incorporated in New-York for the purpose of establishing a national opera; , with ...

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 25.--The steamship Genrath, Capt. Storey, from Coosaw, S.O., for the United Kingdom, arrived at Sydney, Cape Breton, yesterday, received a supply of coal and sailed this morning. During a thick fog she grounded on Low Point. Tugs are at work trying to pull her off.

Artists, picture dealers, and connoisseurs testified yesterday that the picture for injuries to which Jacob H. Studer is seeking to recover $25,000 from the Manhattan Storage and Warehouse Company, is not a genuine Salvator Rosa, and is worth but a very small sum, if it is worth ...

CLEVELAND, May 25.--At Canton, Ohio, to-day Charles Danseizen, a bricklayer, went home drunk, and picking up a butcher knife six inches long, murdered his wife by stabbing her in the throat and breast. He says she drove him to the deed because she joined the Salvation Army.

THE TIMES lets its abundant information speak for itself, and leaves the sound-thinking, well digested information and scholarly literary treatment of its expression of opinion for the commendation of the judicious.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., May 25.--Mr. O'Brien was again obliged to remain in bed during the greater part of the forenoon. His back and ribs still continue to trouble him greatly. When he did arise, late in the afternoon, he looked pale, haggard, worn out, and unable to avail himself of the invitation of Frank ...

It was stated at the White Star office yesterday that the official list of those killed in the Celtic-Britannic collision contained only three names--Jane Robinson, James Timbury, and James Greenalch.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 25.--A curious trial ended at Hagerstown to-night in the conviction of Emanuel Cump of murder in the second degree. Mrs. Catharine Cump and her invalid son, Carlisle, lived on a small farm about five miles from Hagerstown.
The eleventh annual picnic and field day of the Pastime Athletic Club at the Empire City Colosseum yesterday was very successful from a sporting standpoint, but was attended by scarcely 200 people.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 25.--The Rate Committee of the Southern Railway and Steamship Association held another meeting at the Southern Hotel yesterday, and, after more or less wrangling, adjusted the drayage question.

The funeral of Grace Leslie, the actress, who was killed on the railroad at Salida, Col., last week, took place yesterday from the home of her husband, George T. Turton, at 434 Herkimer-street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, May 25.--The Inter-State Commerce Commission today adopted the following rules of practice in cases and proceedings before it: I. When at Washington the commission will hold its general sessions at 11 o'clock A.M. daily, except ...

The Washington-Pittsburg game scheduled for yesterday was postponed in consequence of rain. Kelly played second base for the Boston team yesterday and put out six men and assisted three times, taking every chance for a play offered.

Dr. Gallaudet, Pastor of St. Ann's Church for Deaf-Mutes, at Eighteenth-street and Fifthavenue, caused the arrest yesterday of Catharine Hall, a middle-aged woman, who has been a source of annoyance to him for many years.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 25.--Drafts on NewYork--Sight 17 cents; telegraphic 25 cents.

LONDON, May 25.--Mr. John Morley spoke to-day at an immense anti-coercion meeting at Norwich. In the course of his remarks he said that the time was not ripe for a conciliatory movement by the Liberals, because the Unionists were forcing a hateful coercion bill upon them, replying to appeals by defiantly and doggedly making the bill as drastic as possible. Lord Salisbury had referred to Irishmen as Hottentots, ...
LEXINGTON, Ky., May 25.--Forty-five head of Jersey Cattle were sold at public auction here today for $3,210; average, $71.55.
As already announced, Mr. Richard Mansfield will begin his Summer season at the Madison-Square Theatre next Monday with "Prince Karl," to be followed soon afterward by a new farcical comedy.

WATERVILLE, Me., May 25.--Miss Mand Mason, who mysteriously disappeared night before last, was found last evening in a piece of woods near the village. Blair, the man who was seen talking with her, was found on the street and arrested.

CHICAGO, May 25.--The Canadian Pacific has not only succeeded in getting the bulk of the sugar traffic from San Francisco to St. Paul and other Eastern points which it is able to reach, but has lately been taking large shipments to Omaha via the Manitoba and the St. Paul and the Omaha Roads.

MADISON, Ind., May 25.--It was reported tonight that in Trimble County, Ky., ten miles from here, a widow named Belle Kent, living with J.W. Maddox, last evening gave birth to a child, and in the absence of the family dashed its brains out on a rock and hid the body in the smokehouse, where it was found this morning. She was arrested.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 25.--Charles Fish, a resident of Hatborough, N.J., was arrested yesterday charged with having robbed his brother, Joseph B. Fish, a teamster residing near Twelfth and Market streets, of a box containing $2,000 in cash and promissory ...

The chancel of St. Francis Xavier's Roman Catholic Church, in West Sixteenth-street, was yesterday beautifully decorated for the celebration of the wedding of Col. George Bliss and Miss Anais Casey. The beautiful white altar and tabernacle were tastefully decorated and draped with festoons of smilax, interwoven with orchids, tuberoses, chrysanthemums, and white pinks, ...

Three more games were played yesterday in the amateur championship tournament at the Racquet Court Club. All of them were interesting and marked by many brilliant plays. In the afternoon C.F. Jones and L.A. Flanagan played a pretty game in which Mr. Jones was victorious. His two big runs were 54 and 58 while his opponents highest was 27.

OTTAWA, May 26.--The Gazette contains a dispatch fron the Commissioner of Navigation for the United States, in which he calls the attention of the Canadian Government to the fact that vessels bound from Canadian to American ports are often found unprovided with the manifests of cargo, and especially of sea stores, prescribed by law.

The Queens County Board of Supervisors has passed an ordinance prohibiting the burial of bodies in any cemetery within the borders of the county without a permit from the town authorities, the local Boards of Health having power to fix the fee for issuing such permit.

WASHINGTON, May 26.--Leave of absence for four months has been granted to First Lieut. John E. Myers, Third Artillery. Leave of absence for one month with permission to apply for an extension of one month has been granted to First Lieut. Charles H. Grierson, Tenth Cavalry. The Alliance arrived at Mauritius today. The Thetis sailed from Barbados to-day going southward.

Coudert Brothers, who have under their charge one of the wills of Jose Sevilla, the Peruvian millionaire, who died in December last, made no appearance yesterday before the Surrogate, though the citations in proof of the will were returnable at that time.

ALBANY, May 26.--The Legislature of 1887 adjourned at noon to-day. Speaker Husted held the Assembly well in check, and the closing hours of the session were unmarked by more confusion than attends an ordinary meeting of the lower house.

NORFOLK, Va., May 26.--On March 24 Mack NicholSon, foreman of the Virginian, of this city, and a prominent Knight of Labor, left the city under very mysterious circumstances, leaving word with his wife that when she received his letter he would be dead, thus leading suspicion toward suicide.
A few weeks hence the Interior Department will begin to enforce a law whose enactment marked the adoption of a new policy concerning the Indians and the reservations which they occupy.

A bill of complaint was filed with the Clerk of the United States Circuit Court yesterday by the Oregon Transcontinental Railway Company against the Northern Pacific Railway Company, charging that the Northern Pacific, intending to build a railway from Marshall, Washington Territory, south for 43 miles, induced T.F. Oakes ...
RICHMOND, Va., May 26.--An injunction was granted by Judge Bond, of the United States Circuit Court, in Chambers, in Baltimore, this morning, and filed in the office of the clerk of that court ...
Miss Lillian Russell, radiant in Spring attire and Summer smiles, sat in the office of Curtis R. Hathaway, in the Equitable Building, yesterday, and volubly answered a number of legal questions.

Ten pieces of property that have been in one family for the best part of a century were sold under the hammer at the Real Estate ExChange yesterday by Richard V. Harnett. The sale scattered the remnant of a once large estate.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 26.--The tug Ivy, owned by Walker, Fowler, McVittie, of Galveston, came here a few days ago with a cotton-laden barge and started on her return this evening with a coal-laden barge in tow. In rounding Algiers Point she collided with the British steamer Wydale and sank, carrying down with her the pilot and a son of Capt. Andrews. The damage to the Wydale, if any, has not been ascertained.

Judge Lawrence has been sitting extra hours in the trial of the Anderson will case in order to finish it this week if possible. He gave up the attempt yesterday, however, and announced that thereafter he should adjourn at 4 P.M. sharp.

The General Committee of the Electric Club having in charge the plan of constructing a building in this city which will be the general headquarters of that industry on the Atlantic coast met at the clubrooms in the Hotel Dam last evening for primary consultation. President Davis, of the club, occupied the chair, and there was a full attendance.

COLUMBUS, May 26.--A prominent Republican, formerly identified with the Blaine interests in this State, in speaking of the course pursued by indiscreet Congressmen who assume to speak for Senator Sherman, very pointedly observed: "There is no disposition of any kind ...

PROVIDENCE, May 26.--Edward F. Curtis was to-day appointed Chief of State Police, vice Charles R. Brayton, resigned. He enters upon his duties to fill the interim pending the action of the incoming General Assembly, which has power to remove him in favor of another man or abolish the office altogher.

The annual parade of the park police occurred on the Mall in Central Park yesterday. About 150 able-bodied men, resplendent in gray uniforms and light helmets, under the command of Capt. Beatty, stood in line.

PARIS, May 26.--The bodies of ballet dancers who lost their lives by the burning of the Opera Comique last night are lying in heaps in the ruins of the theatre. The firemen assert that many bodies are lying in the upper galleries.

The bill of exceptions in the case of "Honest" John O'Neill, the "boodle" Alderman, now in Sing Sing serving out a sentence for bribery in the Broadway Surface Railway affair, was argued in the General Term of the Supreme Court yesterday.
WESTCHESTER, Penn., May 26.--Great excitement prevails here over a tragedy enacted last night upon one of the principal thoroughfares of the place.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 26.--"Tract Work" was the subject under discussion at this morning's session of the Baptist Publication Society. After the usual devotional services Dr. Griffith, Secretary of the society, began the discussion.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, May 26.--THE TIMES's correspondent just received from the magistrate at Bonnebay the following particulars respecting the movements of the American schooner Thomas F. Bayard and the loss of two of her crew.

The cornerstone of the new Mount Morris Baptist Church, to be elected on the west side of Fifth-avenue, between One Hundred and Twenty-sixth and One Hundred and Twenty-seventh streets, was laid yesterday in the presence of nearly 500 people.
BOSTON, May 26.--Delegates of the various Unity Clubs and other organizations for social and intellectual purposes in connection with the Unitarian Church all over the country met here this morning.

The meeting of the Executive Committee of the Irving Hall organization at Irving Hall last? evening was well attended. Ex-President Robert B. Nooney presided. Resolutions comprising a platform of principles were submitted by J.S. Rogers, of the Seventeenth Assembly District.

PARIS, May 10.--Just as in 1870, when everything and anything were all sufficient pretexts for "manifestations" and public assemblages, so it is now. Somebody wants trouble; I do not pretend to say who, but certainly either Gen. Boulanger or Bismarck is interested in mixing the cards--the troubled-water principle, you know.
WASHINGTON, May 26.--The appointment of Corporation Counsel Lacombe to the additional United States Circuit Judgeship for the Seccond New-York Judicial Circuit was expected.

SIOUX FALLS, Dakota, May 26.--People who hold policies in the old Fargo Insurance Company held a meeting to-day to investigate the condition of the company. It is alleged that the company of assets of $5,000 to pay liabilities of $125,000. Local officers here claim that Secretary Lowell, of Chicago, has made way with $100,000 belonging to the company.
Mr. A.H. Hummel, of the law firm of Howe Hummel, has originated a scheme which he thinks will render bookmaking in this city a possible business even under the new law.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 26.--A special from Port Townsend, Washington. Territory, says! The United states revenue cutter Oliver Walcott has returned from a four days' cruise along the west coast of Vancouver Island in search of news concerning the ship St. Stephens, which sailed from here on March 29 loaded with 2,200 tons of coal from Seattle for San Francisco.

Another complainant appeared at Police Headquarters against Theodore Hahr, the thieving butler, who had done such a successful business in stealing diamonds from his employers and substituting imitation stones for the gems removed.
The Harlem Regatta Association will hold its regatta next Monday afternoon. The committee of Irish societies has engaged passage for William O'Brien on the Adriatic, which sails hence June 8.

Mrs. Hetty Green, who has been called the "Queen of Wall-street," appears in a new contest as opposed to the reorganization of the Houston and Texas Central Railroad Company. She owns $1,000,000 of the company's bonds.

LONDON, May, 26.--The Dubling Express (Conservative) accuses Mr. Parnell of cruelty to one of his Avondale tenants named Kennedy. The paper says that although Mr. Kennedy has been a tenant on the Irish leader's estate for nine years, Mr. Parnell has coerced him into exchanging the farm he had occupied and improved for a tract of inferior land. In adddition...
WASHINGTON, May 26.--The result of the billiard match to-night was, as it has been for three previous nights, a victory for Mr. Daly. There was no particularly brilliant playing.

LONDON, May 26.--The Epsom Grand Prize for 8-year-olds was won by "Mr. Manton's" Eiridspord, by tow lengths; Chippeway second, and Salisbury third. The last betting was nine to four against Eiridspord and two to one against Salisbury.

The clouds which have been threatening New-York for the past few days, got together yesterday, and poured down 35-100 of an inch of water. The shower, which began at 3:38 P.M., only lasted 49 minutes, but it was a lively one. Part of the time there was a fusillade of ...

CHICAGO, May 26.--An order was entered to-day by Judge Gresham in accordance with his decision 10 days ago authorizing Receiver McNulta, of the Wabash, to pay certain interest on the sectional division mortgages of those branches of the system which have earned enough to pay interest.

BERLIN, May 26.--The Reichs-Anzeiger gives the following account of the course of Crown Prince Frederick William's illness: "In January last his Imperial Highness was seized with an inflammatory affection of the throat, of which the outward indications were a slight cough and intense hoarseness.

ALBANY, May 26.--Bank Superintendent Willis S. Paine has given out an opinion relating to the recently enacted half holiday law and supplemental act passed May 25, in which he defines the effect which should be given to that portion of the law which relates to the maturity of commercial paper.

The members of Mount Olivet Baptist Church, 161 West Fifty-third-street, held a grand jubilee last evening, in celebration of the acquirement of the title to their handsome house of worship. Mount Olivet is the leading colored religious society of the city, and the wealth and fashion of the colored residents of New-York were thickly gathered there.
Commodore H.P. Pearson's new sloop Gertrude was launched at Poillon's yard in Brooklyn yesterday. Mr. Pearson is Commodore of the Jersey ...

TORONTO, May 26.--Is Canada in a frame of mind to accept commercial union with the United States were it offered to her? Upon this question there is a wide diversity of opinion.
ALBANY, May 26.--The following is the report of the special committee of the Assembly on Gov. Hill's veto of the bill providing for a Constitutional Convention:
The sun had long ceased to shine on Central Park's lake yesterday afternoon when the fifth annual anglers' tournament of the National Rod and Reel Association was declared finished.

NASHVILLE, May 26.--The Rev. Sam Jones, the Georgia revivalist, will speak at Nashville and other places next week in the interest of the proposed Constitutional amendment prohibiting the manufacture and sale of intoxicating liquors in the State.

CHICAGO, May 26.--This morning the members of the National Butchers' Association assembled at Central Music Hall and after a street parade, headed by a band of music, proceeded in a body to Cheltenham Beach, where a grand barbecue was held.
OZARK, Me., May 26.--Three of the nine supposed Bald Knobbers arrested last Friday, charged with whipping John Swearingen, were tried yesterday. The other six took change of venue.

CHICAGO, May 26.--Mrs. Kato Knodell, who is said to keep a fashionable boarding house in New-York City, began an action to-day in the Circuit Court against Frank Upman, proprietor of the Briggs House.

The Eastern Boulevard Club, the oldest club in Harlem, which has many well known New-Yorkers in its ranks, is making great preparations for a fitting celebration of the Fourth of July. At an enthusiastic meeting last night it was voted that $500 be spent on fireworks.

The examination of the accounts of Gen. William Cutting as Executor of the will of Francis B. Cutting, his father, proceeded yesterday before Hamilton Cole, the Referee. Although originally ordered to file his account in January, it was not until April 26 that Mr. M.S. Burrill, his counsel, produced the first installment of the account.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 26.--At a Democratic legislative caueus held in this city to-day Charles E. Gorman, of this city, was nominated for Speaker of the House: Elisha W. Bucklin for State Auditor, and D.P. Pond, of Woonsocket, for Sheriff of Providence County. Other county officers were nominated.
Alfred Sully was examined yesterday before Commissioner Shields in the McMahonFlynn subway suit. When his last answer had been made the testimony for the plaintiff was practically finished.
The trial of the suit of Jacob H. Studer against the Manhattan Storage and Warehouse Company came to an end yesterday afternoon by the jury finding a verdict for $800 in Mr. Studer's favor.

CHICAGO, May 26.--A sudden fright seized the shorts in June wheat to-day, and their efforts to cover ran the price of that future up nearly a cent in five minutes, to 90 cents, the highest price touched by wheat this year.

When the telegraph wires from Albany were bringing the news yesterday that the Legislature had adjourned Mr. Thomas C. Platt was writing a long letter to Gov. Hill. By the time it was certain that the statesmen could do nothing in his case Mr. Platt made his letter public.

ST. LOUIS, May 26.--The National Opera Company opened in "Nero" at the Music Hall to-night. There was a large audience, and if applause can be taken as a criterion the principals scored a great success.

The testimony in the trial of Mrs. Chiara Cignarale for the murder of her husband last October, was concluded yesterday in the Court of General Sessions, and to-day the case will be given to the jury.

Bella Formel, a pretty little maiden of 10, daughter of Julian Formel, the druggist, at Broadway and Fourth-street, has had considerable trouble with her stepmother at their home, 339 West Twenth-seventh-street.

Henry George intends to speak at the Ohio United Labor Party's Convention that will be held in Cincinnati. John McMackin, the Chairman of the United Labor Party in this city, is absent, preparing for the New-York State Convention of the United Labor Party that will meet at Syracuse on Aug. 17.
PITTSBURG, May 26.--A meeting of sheet iron manufacturers was held here to-day to consider the alarming increase in the importation of tinned sheets and shoot iron.
William S. Stewart, of Mount Vernon, N. Y., arrested several days ago on a charge of bigamy, was held in the Harlem Court yesterday by Justice Welde for trial.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 26.--A short time since the lasters in the employ of Buckley Co., boot and shoe manufacturers of Port Jervis, struck against a proposed reduction of wages. When the lasters went out Buckley Co. closed the shop and looked out their remaining hands.

When Frankie Bell was found in a supposed dying condition from the effects of an operation she accused Dr. Mary John, a midwife, of Atlantic-avenue, and Courtland Bliven, a well known society man, of being the cause of her trouble, they were arrested and taken before Justice Walsh for examination.

We give this morning a carefully prepared and full statement of the course of income and outgo in the Treasury for the present fiscal year up to May 20, for the corresponding portion of the last fiscal year, and estimates based on these for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1888.

OTTAWA, May 26.--Sir Charles Tupper, Minister of Finance, spoke to-day to a reporter in regard to the protest of British manufacturers against the new Canadian iron duties. "No further changes," said he, "will be made, despite the representations made to the Colonial Secretary.

Elihu Root, John L. Cadwalader, and Franklin Bartlett, representing Mrs. Lydia S. Cutting, went before Surrogate Rollins yesterday, and opposed the granting of an order to show cause why letters of administrations should not be granted to Robert L. Cutting on the estate of his aunt, Mrs. Gertrude Cutting, widow of Francis B. Cutting.

WELLSVILLE, Ohio, May 26.--The Ohio Valley Gas Company has been laying gas mains in the town of New-Cumberland, West Va. Tuesday night the work was finished and preparations made to test the large mains.

CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., May 26.--The boiler of a portable sawmill belonging to John Craft, near Leisenring exploded yesterday, instantly killing James Naylor and seriously injuring the proprietor and a man named Alexander Work. The cause of the explosion is not known.
