There has been much talk among the clergy and laymen of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island as to whether Henry Hilton, as Executor of the Stewart estate, will further endow the cathedral foundation at Garden City.

The Retail Jewelers' Protective Association held its annual meeting at the Cooper Union yesterday and elected the following officers: President--Edward Karsch; Vice-Presidents-- Charles Hartdegan and J.P. Philips; Secretary --M.D. Gallagher. A committee was appointed...

The icemen in the employ of the ice companies in this city will probably go out on strike to-day or to-morrow for an increase of wages. They have been organized under District Assembly No. 49, and complain that they are being underpaid and overworked.

During the recent contest for the control of the St. Louis and San Francisco Railway Company, which waged between the firm of E.L. Oppenheim Co. and the firm of J. W. Seligman Co., Gen. Edward F. Winslow, President of the railway company; Thomas W. Lillie, its ...

BALTIMORE, May 26.--The United States Brewers' Association resumed their labors this morning, and after listening to reports of the various committees adopted resolutions appropriating $5,000 for the assistance of the brewers of Michigan, $5,000 for the brewers of Texas ...

PHILADELPHIA, May 26.--A special dispatch to the Times from Wallingford, Delaware County, Penn., says: "Chief-Justice Mercur, of the Supreme Court of this State, was taken suddenly ill here at a dinner party at Lawyer Shapely's on Wednesday evening.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 26.--Four women have appeared here since Monday who claim to be wives of John Bute Holmes, who was buried on that day. How many more may appear seems not to be known.

The famous cow Electa, for which her owner, A.J. Cowan, of Venango County, Penn., once refused $10,000, was sold by him to an Oil City butcher the other day for $50, she having been ruined by overfeeding. Although this cow stood at the head of all milk producers in this country a few years ago her pedigree was never known. She came to Cowan's farm as an estray, She was a famous prize winner.

RONDOUT, N.Y., May 26.--A series of electric storms, accompanied by torrents of rain and in one or two localities a downpour of hailstones, prevailed along the Hudson River this afternoon and evening.

Never did grand opera attract a larger or more enthusiastic audience to the Metropolitan Opera House than that which gathered there last night to attend the Commencement exercises of the law department of the University of NewYork. Vice-Chancellor H.M. MacCracken presided ...

John Greenwall is to be sentenced to-day for the murder of Lyman S. Weeks. His lawyer obtained an adjournment last Monday on the ground that he had a witness who would swear that he was playing cards with Greenwall at the time Mr. Weeks was shot. The affidavit of this man had not been forwarded to District Attorney Ridgway yesterday, and Lawyer Kinsley was heard to say that the man had not been found.
Mr. William Birch, formerly of the San Francisco Minstrels, had a benefit at Harrigan's Park Theatre yesterday afternoon. There was a small audience.

RONDOUT, May 26.--Albert Munson, of Port Ewen, has caught an 18-pound salmon in the Hudson River near the mouth of the Rondout Creek. A dispatch from Coxsackie states that a 21-pound salmon was caught near there this afternoon. Munson's catch is on exhibition here.
City Works Commissioner Conner, of Brooklyn, who has been doing his best to prevent the contract for street cleaning being awarded to Heman Clark, of this city, tried another plan yesterday.

The Legislature that has just adjourned has gained the reputation of being corrupt and inefficient. The evidence of corrupt action appears rather in those things that were attempted than in those that were accomplished.
Dealings began yesterday on the Stock Exchange in the stock of the Kingston and Pembroke Mining Company. The opening price was $5.50 per share, from which it advanced to $6.
ELLSWORTH, Me., May 26.--Three men, father and two sons, by the name of Giles, at Falls Village, have for a considerable time shown signs of poisoning.
CINCINNATI, May 26.--Racing was continued at Latonia to-day, with the following results:
Vice-Chancellor Van Fleet yesterday dismissed the case of Mary A. Vreeland against the estate of the late George Vreeland, of Greenville. It was brought to secure alimony.

There were three games of billiards played at the Racquet Club yesterday in the amateur tournament, and the best one of the day, and, in fact, the most exciting one so far in the contest, was the last one played.

MONTREAL, May 26.--O'Brien and Kilbride arrived here at 10:45 to-night from Albany and were received at the station by about 200 people. They got into a hack, accompanied by Mr. Cloran, President of the National League, ...
Henry F. Downing, a colored man, employed as a clerk in Commodore Gherardi's office in the Brooklyn Navy Yard, was notified yesterday that he had been appointed United ...

PHILADELPHIA, May 26.--The second day's meeting of the eleventh General Council of the Reformed Episcopal Church of the United States and Canada was taken up in an animated discussion of a canon on divorce, to which two substitutes, with about a dozen amendments, were proposed.

DEVIL'S LAKE, Wis., May 26.--An open switch caused the wreck of a freight train 13 miles east of Minot to-day. The engine and nine cars were ditched and the engineer, Miller, and the brakeman, Brainard, were killed.

Not being a fool, Mr. THOMAS C. PLATT understood as well yesterday as he will understand to-day that the public will not regard his impudent letter to the Governor as in any sense a resignation of his valuable office.

Four new cases of smallpox were discovered in this city yesterday. One case was found in a small room in the rear of the grocery store of Bernard McKlernan, adjoining the four-story tenement house, 301 East One Hundred and First-street.

Joseph Levine, of 331 East Fifty-firststreet, told Judge Duffy at the Tombs Police Court that he had employed Counselor Suyden to collect $140 and that Suyden had compromised the matter by promising to pay $85, but had paid nothing.

Detroit's big ball players have, figuratively speaking, struck a snag. Up to yesterday it looked as if nothing could stop them in their headlong rush for the bit of bunting which represents the championship of the National League of Professional Baseball Players.
The Church of the Transfiguration was the scene of a very pretty wedding last evening. The bride was Miss Margaret Williams Mead, daughter of Henry B. Mead.
VIENNA, May 26.--The Empress of Austria will become patroness of the Home for British Governesses, which is to be founded in honor of the jubilee of Queen Victoria.
Mayor Hewitt and President Beekman, of the Board of Aldermen, went about the city on Wednesday night looking into the dives and questionable resorts generally.

BOSTON, May 26.--The new steel steam yacht built at the Atlantic Works in East Boston for Commodore John M. Forbes took her maiden plunge to-day soon after 2 o'clock. As she glided from the cradle she carried about 75 passengers, among them E. Burgess, the yacht's designer.

The greatest fire that has taken place in this city for many years broke out at 1:30 o'clock this morning in the car stables of the Belt Line Horse Railroad, on the west side of Tenthavenue, between Fifty-third and Fifty-fourth streets.

The Rockaway Steeplechase Association yesterday decided to hold a meeting at their Cedarhurst course Sept. 21, 22, 23, and 24. The usual variety of races on the flat, over the hurdles, and across country will be run.
The flower of the New-Jersey Bench and Bar were assembled at Delmonico's last night to do honor to Theodore Runyon, ex-Chancellor of New-Jersey.

SALT LAKE CITY, May 20.--The eastward current in the transcontinental migration has been for some time eddying about the Mormon "elephant," and that immense animal, notwithstanding the annoyance of the legal hornests, is on his best behavior to the visitors.

Fire Chief Nevins was a witness before the Kings County Grand Jury yesterday and was accompanied by Robert Payne and Horace E. Deming. Nevins looked worried when he left "Boss" McLaughlin just before going to the Grand Jury room.
OTTAWA, May 26.--Sir George Stephen informed a Cabinet Minister yesterday that the Canadian Pacific Railway steamers would likely be running between British Columbia and Japan within two weeks.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26.--Clergymen from Maine to Texas and from the Atlantic to the Pacific were in attendance this morning at the opening of the Twenty-ninth General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church of North America.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 26.--The Ohio Woman Suffrage Convention adjourned to-night, after being in session here three days. Anticipating a large attendance the Cleveland friends of the cause provided Music Hall, which seats 5,000. The handful of people who heard the ...

BOSTON, May 26.--The meeting of the Women's Board of Missions this morning was presided over by Mrs. Bowker. The report of the home Secretary, Miss Abbie B. Childs, stated that the work-during the year showed satisfactory results.

CHICAGO, May 26.--The Milwaukee and St. Paul is firmly determined to reduce rates between Chicago and Council Bluffs to proportionately the same figures as are made by the Burlington and Northern between Chicago and St. Paul and Minneapolis.

ASTORIA, Oregon, May 26.--The acts of violence of the fishermen at Ilwaco have resulted in bloodshed, and the end is not yet. At about 11 o'clock Tuesday night A.E. King, owner of a cannery at Ilwaco, and Albert Green ...
PESTH, May 26.--The Hungarian Diet was closed to-day. Emperor Francis Joseph, in his speech closing the session, expressed his appreciation of the measures passed by the Diet.

Adulteration of food is prevalent and is a just cause for complaint. Coffee, however, seems to be rightfully free from the charge. The mixture of chicory with the delicious beverage is generally condemned in this country, but abroad it is actually demanded.

One of the papers recently announced that the Queen had sent a message to a lady who was divorced from her husband a few years ago, but who was perfectly blameless, and whose position excited general sympathy, that her Majesty was prepared to receive her at Court.
Corporation Counsel Lacombe will to-day render his decision to the Police Commissioners as to whether excursions can take place on the water with music and dancing without a concert license.

The opening of the excursion season brings the steamboats from their Winter hiding places, and the Iron Steamboat Company will begin their trips to Coney Island to-morrow, the time table being hourly from West Twenty-third-street from 9 A.M. till 6 P.M., half an hour later from ...
WASHINGTON, May 26.--The President this afternoon appointed L.W. Reid, of Virginia, to be Assistant Register of the Treasury and Nathaniel H. Odell to be Postmaster at Tarrytown, N.Y., vice ...

BRUSSELS, May 26.--A committee of strikers has written to Premier Beernaert demanding universal suffrage and the abandonment of the Cattle bill, and hinting that if he fails to reply before Sunday the strikers will march upon Brussels. A general strike has occurred at Cockerill's works.

CHICAGO, May 26.--Jennie F. Purington and Katherine Ver Mooy, residents of Chicago and daughters of the late Judge Hiram Crandell, of Cortland County, N.Y., filed a bill of complaint today in the United States Circuit Court against Henry L. Roger, Executor of their father's estate. They ask for an accounting of the $100,000 or more which their father, they say, left them.

Racing will be continued at the Brooklyn Jockey Club's track this afternoon. There are six races on the card, and though the entries are not numerous they are of such a character as to indicate good contests.

The President, accompanied by Mrs. Cleveland and Col. and Mrs. Lamont, left Washington at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon for 10 days of "roughing it" at Saranac Lake, in the Adirondacks. A small crowd of people, including ...
BUCHAREST, May 26.--A plot to assassinate the Sultan of Turkey was discovered last Thursday. Extraordinary, efforts have been made to conceal the discovery from the public.

Shortly before the Commissioners of Emigration met yesterday afternoon Commissioner Stephenson received a dispatch signed by a friend, an official of the Senate Chamber in Albany, stating that the nomination of Gen. Sickles had been confirmed.

Two ladies, who said they were sisters, and that their name was Walterman, asked the Brooklyn police last night to find their brother Conrad, a young man of 29, who disappeared from his place of business in a hotel kept by a man named Kuster, in Lewis-street, New-York.

The hearing in the matter of Receiver Mortis Spiegel's accounts was continued yesterday before Referee William H. Clark at his office, in the Potter Building. David Leventritt, counsel for Mrs. Chaude, resumed his examination of Spiegel, who twisted about on his chair as though he were undergoing torture.
Mayor Hewitt sent the following communication to Gov. Hill yesterday: NEW-YORK, May 26, 1887.
SARATOGA, May 26.--To-day's sessions of the Right Worthy Grand Lodge of Good Templars and of the English, or seceding body, were almost entirely given up to the discussion of the question of reunion.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 26.--The attention of the General Assembly of the Southern Presbyterians was entirely occupied to-day by discourses on the advisability of organic union with the Northern church.

BOSTON, May 26.--At the third day's session of the Union Pacific Railroad Committee to-day F. Gordon Dexter, a Director of the company for 20 years past, corroborated Mr. Ames's version of the condition of the Union Pacific and Kansas Pacific Roads prior to the consolidation.

WASHINGTON, May 26.--The usual rainstorm came up again this evening to curtail the proceedings of the National drill, but there was a full attendance in the early part of the day, who enjoyed the drilling, and this evening the pyrotechnic exhibition was witnessed by an immense crowd.

BOSTON, May 26.--League Championship-- Chicago, 3; Boston, 1. Pitchers--Baldwin and Madden. Earned runs--Chicago, 2. Base hits--Chicago, 13; Boston, 9. First base on called balls--Chicago, 1; Boston, 4. Stolen bases--Chicago, 3; Boston, 4. Errors--Chicago, 3; Boston, 6.

CHICAGO, May 26.--An advertisement will be printed Saturday in all towns having 500 population and upward in Illinois, Indiana, Wisconsin, Michigan, Ohio, and Missouri, offering steady work to 1,000 bricklayers at 45 cents an hour, and protection guaranteed.

The grand fair at the Casino at St. George, Staten Island, in aid of the S.R. Smith Infirmary at Tompkinsville, was formally opened yesterday afternoon by George William Curtis, who made an earnest speech for the charity.

MONTREAL, May 26.--The appeals in the cases of Messrs. S. Carsley Co. and Mr. S. Carsley against the Bradstreet Mercantile Agency, for heavy damages, were decided this morning by the Court of Appeals.

The minority of the Seventeenth Assembly District Republican Association was out in force at the regular meeting of that organization, at 341. West Forty-seventh-street, last evening, and the object was evident when the resolution offered at a former meeting by Judge Flammer was taken from the table and put on its passage.

Capt. Williams sent a letter to the Board of Police, yesterday, in which he says he has just read a communication to the board made by the Mayor, referring to a complaint made to him by P. Murray, J. Chatelin, and Howard Crosby, charging the Captain with "inefficiency and neglect of duty" in allowing immoral resorts to exist in his precinct.

VINCENNES, Ind., May 26.--A dynamite bomb was thrown against the residence of Mrs. Frances A. Richey yesterday morning. It exploded with a terrible noise and tore a large hole in the side of the building.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., May 26.--The trial of Barclay Peak for the murder of Mary C. Anderson was resumed to-day. A witness testified that she was present at the injured girl's bedside when Peak entered the room. He kissed her and asked her how she got hurt.

Seventy members of the Veteran Volunteer Firemen's Association met at the Brooklyn City Hall yesterday at 1 o'clock, and falling into line behind the Thirteenth Regiment Band, marched over to this city to get their new machine, which was formerly known as the Friendship, of Philadelphia. Chief Engineer W.A. Furey led the firemen, and was followed by President F.A. Walsh.
Abstracts from the books of the Produce Exchange were issued yesterday. The income account for the year ending April 30, 1887, is $263,656 26, as against $269,991 20 for the preceding year.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 26.--The California Sugar Refinery to-day advanced the price of all grades of sugar one-eighth cent. and the American Sugar Refinery met the advance this evening.

NORWALK, Conn., May 26.--The following named gentlemen are bondsmen for the Hon. James W. Hyatt, Treasurer of the United States: F.St. John Lockwood, $20,000; Ira Cole, $20,000: Ebenezer Hill, $20,000; Winfield S. Moody, $20,000: Edward K. Lockwood, $20,000; George M. Holmes, $10,000; Christian Swarty, $20,000, and Elbirt A. Woodward, $20,000, all of Norwalk.

The number of victims to the fire by which the Opera Comique was destroyed is not yet precisely ascertained. There seems to be little doubt that more than a hundred persons were burned, suffocated, or crushed to death. Many, perhaps most, of these were employed in some capacity upon the stage.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 26.--Drafts on NewYork--Sight, 17 cents; telegraphic, 25 cents.

There must have been 8,000 people on the Brooklyn Jockey Club track yesterday afternoon in spite of the threatening weather. It was the first day's racing since betting on race tracks was made legal by statute of the State of New-York.
PARIS, May 26.--M. de Freycinet has informed President Grevy that he cannot form a Cabinet.

The Columbia College 'Varsity Crew yesterday raced against a picked professional crew Captained by Wallace Ross over a four-mile course for practice preliminary to leaving for New-London to row against Harvard. The crews that contested were:

PHILADELPHIA, May 27.--Upon petition Of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company, the Coal and Iron Company, and the Receivers, the United States Circuit Court to-day gave permission that arrangements be made to provide for the payment of reorganization plan assessments on such of the company's securities as are pledged to secure its floating debt.

JACKSON, Miss., May 27.--Prof. Edward Myers, of the State University at Oxford, Miss., has been appointed to the bench of the Supreme Court of the State by Gov. Lowry. He is a son-in-law of Secretary Lamar.

OTTAWA, May 27.--It is understood that Sir Adolphe Caron, Minister of War, and Major-Gen. Sir Frederick Middleton will start for British Columbia via the Canadian Pacific Railway about the end of next August.
The notice a few days ago of the death of John McCully, of Hubbard, Ohio, calls to mind a family of long livers. John McCully was, at the time of his death, in his ninety-fourth year.

LONDON, May 27.--The Dublin Freeman's Journal denies that Mr. Parnell has been guilty of crueity to Mr. Kennedy, one of the Irish leader's Avondale tenants, as charged yesterday by the Dublin Express.

ALBANY, May 27.--Boss Platt may be saddened to learn through the newspapers, the same medium through which he chose to communicate with the Governor, that his letter will receive no reply by post. But the Governor consented to make a statement to-day to the same public to which the boss has appealed for sympathy.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 27.--As Joseph Porter and his wife, of Grahamsville, Sullivan County, were driving down a hill near their home to-day, the harness broke, letting the wagon run against the horse, which took fright and ran the wagon against a stone wall. Mrs. Porter's skull was crushed and her neck broken. Mr. Porter escaped badly bruised.

NEWBURG, N.Y., May 27.--The clergymen and lay delegates of the Western Convocation of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Diocese of New-York, who have been in session in this city, returned home to-day.

DENVER, Col., May 27.--Considerable excitement was created here to-day over the death of the trotting stallion J.W. South, which, it is reported, died from the effects of poison given him yesterday to defeat him in the 2:30 race for which he was entered. He was owned by Mr. Nat Bruen, of Burlington, Iowa, and valued at $6.000.

BOSTON, Mass., May 27.--The Union Pacific Railway investigation was resumed to-day. The first witness was Mr. Elisha Atkins, a Director of the Union Pacific since 1869 and owner of 600 shares of Union Pacific stock.

The twenty-eighth annual reception and exhibition of the work of the art students was held at Cooper Union last night. The exhibition this year is unusually interesting. Studies in oil, black and white, and water colors aro hung on all sides. Engravings, charcoals, and decorative and fancy work are numerous. Last night, a large crowd enjoyed the exhibition, and to-night the prizes will be awarded.

MONTREAL, May 27.--At a meeting of the Directors of the Bank of Montreal to-day, Sir Donald A. Smith was elected President, George A. Drummond Vice-President, and W.C. McDonald to fill the vacancy in the Directorate.

FORT WAYNE, IND., May 27.--The suit in the Circuit Court against Civil Service Commissioner Edgerton brought by Joseph Ketchum was settled yesterday by Ketchum proving that he was the Administrator of the estate of Anna Ketchum, deceased.
PHILADELPHIA, May 27.--At this morning's session of the General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church of North America the following resolution was presented and referred to a special committee:

FARGO, Dakota, May 27.--While the entire Territory is to vote in November upon the question of division, as provided by the Legislature, that matter is almost lost sight of in the agitation over prohibition.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 27.--The property of the New-York and New-Haven Steamboat Company was attached to-day in a suit for $10,000 brought by Charles J. Anderson, a mechanic, of this city, who claims that he was assaulted and seriously hurt by Capt. Fred Peck and the deck hands of the steamer C.H. Northam on the night of May 20.
The smallpox patient who escaped from the County Physician Monday cleared the Police Headquarters in Jersey City in the twinkling of an eye Thursday night.

CHICAGO, Ill., May 27.--The master plasterers met again last night. The lock-out has not yet affected them to and degree and they declare that it will not for a good while. Contrary to the rule of the master builders they are willing to hire union men, but cannot pay their prices and live, because of the close competition in plastering contracts.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 27.--Nearly three weeks ago all the dock hands engaged by the NewYork, Pennsylvania and Ohio Railroad in loading cars with iron ore struck for an advance in their pay of 25 cents a day. Since then vessels have been...
On inquiry we learn that the following are about the facts connected with a matter which for some days has been "town talk" here in Raleigh.

PARIS, May 27.--The examination of the ruins of the Opera Comique for the bodies of victims continues vigorously. Twenty bodies have been found in the dining-room. These victims had all met their death by suffocation. The firemen saw other bodies, but were unable to reach them. It is believed that there are 150 more bodies in the ruins.

PHILADELPHIA, MAY 27.--Pretty Josephine Mallison-James, who left her home of elegance and ease with her wealthy parents at 419 North Thirty-fourth-street six weeks ago to become the wife of "Prof." James, an obscure phrenologist, Spiritualist, and general mystery man, has now caused another sensation by leaving her husband. Where she has gone no one seems to know.

It was after 11 o'clock yesterday morning when Recorder Smyth took his seat on the bench to listen to the summing up in the trial of Chlara Cignarale, who is charged with the murder on Oct. 20 last of her husband.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., May 27.--The evidenze produced in the trial of Barclay Peak today was quite important. Two witnesses, one of whom was Miss Hattle Joyce, of Vincentown, testified that on uhe night of the murder, between the hours of 6 and 7 o'clock, which is about the time the fatal shot was fired, they were driving along the road that leads past the house where Mary C. Anderson lived.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 27.--Drafts on NewYork--Sight, 17 cents; telegraphic, 25 cents

MADISON, Wis., May 27.--Gov. Rusk has pardoned Amelia Zimmerman, sentenced to prison for life in 1871 for the murder of her husband. She was convicted upon circumstantial evidence, and Gov. Rush satisfied himself she is innocent. She is now 68 years old.

TORONTO, May 28.--The day is coming when the proposition to give three cheers for commercial union will be heard quite as frequently as three cheers for the Queen. To the rampant loyalist who can never attempt the discussion of a public question without shouting...

WASHINGTON, May 27.--Daly was again victorious to-night in his contest with Sexton in the six days' cushion carom billiard match. Both men played a good game, and a number of brilliant plays were recorded.

ALTOONA, Penn., May 27.--To-night as the fast line train west was nearing Kittaning Point, the wheel of a car on a freight train coming east burst, and the car crashed into two passenger coaches with terrible effect, killing instantly four men and injuring many others.
Desiring to satisfy all tastes at their coming meeting the Coney Island Jockey Club have offered to owners of jumpers three hurdle stake races to be run on dates to be announced hereafter.

In the Presbyterian Church in Rye Mr. David S. Cowles and Miss Matilda Parsons, daughter of Mr. William H. Parsons, were married by the Rev. Dr. Henry M. Baird, of NewYork University, on Thursday evening.

George W. Dunn, of the Arbitration Committee of Assembly No. 49, yesterday succeeded in settling amicably the strike of James G. Shaw's book bindery on Duane-street. He also settled a strike of tin can makers at Towle's factory in Burling-slip.
CHICAGO, May 27.--Wheat ruled rather quiet throughout the morning to-day, and displayed a drooping tendency. A moderate selling movement in June at 89 c. was attributed to the clique.

So far as preliminary legislation can secure it the way is now open for the construction of a second bridge across the East River between Manhattan Island and Long Island. Congress almost at the very end of the last session passed an act giving...

CHICAGO, May 27.--Receiver McNulta, of the Wabash, is making a good record in his management of the company's affairs. The property has been much improved since he assumed charge, and its earning capacity is steadily increasing.

Corporation Counsel Lacombe yesterday sent to the Police Board two opinions of some interest. The first opinion thus disposes of the doubt as to whether there could be music, dancing, and selling of beer on the policemen's excursion:
ST. LOUIS, May 27.--The Wabash Railway was made defendant here to-day in a suit for $2,000,000 in the form of a claim by the New-York and Pacific Car Trust Association.
MONTREAL, May 27.--What was done here this evening in honor of William O'Brien was meant as the crowning demonstration. This was the first place he spoke after "invading" Canada.
During the height of Thursday's thunderstorm, Mrs. Theresa M. Fisher, the young wife of Eugene Fisher, of 109 Java-street, Brooklyn, dropped dead.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27.--Chief-Justice Mercur passed a reasonably comfortable night. His son, Dr. Mercur, remained with him and gave him nourishment at intervals of several hours, all of which he retained without discomfort.

WASHINGTON, May 27.--The first event at the National drill to-day was infantry competition and company firing, in which the following corps took part: Indianapolis Light Infantry, Alexandria (Va.) Light Infantry, Jackson Rifles, Jackson Mich., Molineux Rifles, Company D. Thirty-second New-York;...
PHILADELPHIA, May 27.--At to-day's session of the General Council of the Reformed Episcopal Church the following standing resolutions were reported from the Committee on Constitution and Canons:

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 27.--The oldest Baptist ssciety, the American Baptist Missionary Union, held its seventy-third annual meeting to-day. The President, Dr. Edward Judson, of New-York, delivered the annual address. Dr. Murdock, the Corresponding Secretary, submitted his annual report, showing a manifest increase in the cause of missions. The following missionaries have died during the past year:

BIDDEFORD, Me., May 27.--C.E. F.P. Brackett, leading dry goods dealers of Biddeford and Norway, Me., and Farmington, N.H., have failed. The liabilities are heavy, but the exact financial standing of the firm is not yet known. New-York, Boston, and Portland parties are the heaviest creditors. The firm today made an assignment for the benefit of their creditors.

A decision of interest to people who sell lager beer in unlicensed saloons was made by Justice Walsh in Brooklyn yesterday. Louis Carlson had been arrested for selling lager in an unlicensed saloon, at 307 Atlantic-avenue.
The opinion almost universally expressed of the Legislature of this State which has just adjourned is that it was the most corrupt and misguided legislative body that has sat at Albany in many years.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 27.--Special Pension Examiner Charles Hill to-day arrested T.A. Rayburn, a notorious pension swindler, at Lime Ridge, Columbia County. Rayburn made a desperate resistance.

The meeting of the Tammany Hall Committee on Organization last night was a sort of a congratulatory, jubilee affair. The Senators and Assemblymen who belong to the Tammany tribe were present and received congratulations at the end of their labors in Albany.

The foreman of the Kings County Grand Jury yesterday morning handed three indictments up to Judge Moore in connection with the case of Frankie Bell, the young woman who accuses Yacht Broker Blivens, Mrs. Mary John, and her assistant, Mary Wood, of being reponsible for an operation performed upon her.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 27.--The first meeting of the New-England Intercollegiate Athletic Association was held this afternoon at Charter Oak Park, representatives of seven colleges taking part in the events. Dartmouth took first place, with six firsts and two seconds: Amherst second, with four firsts and ten seconds, and Williams third, with three firsts and two seconds.

Commissioners of Accounts Shearman and Adamson yesterday continued their special examination into the methods of the Dock Department. Chief Engineer George S. Greens, Jr., was shown a pamphlet entitled "An Argument...

PHILADELPHIA, May 27.--The 2:45 class race was won in straight heats by Lady of Lyons in 2:30, 2:29 , and 2:31 . The only other race trotted was the 2:19 class, in which Orange Bud won the first heat in 2:27 and Libby S. the next three in 2:24 , 2:27, and 2:25. Billy Button was last in all three heats.
CHICAGO, May 27.--The order of Commissioner Colman quarantining Cook County on account of pleuro-pneumonia created great excitement among cattle dealers and others interested here.

It is a notorious and melancholy fact that a large fraction of this Legislature were open to purchase. Their unblushing shift of front in the face of the enemy--their change of votes, that is to say, when the act was well known to command a profit--made this clear.

Andrew F. Underhill has obtained an injunction from Judge Dugro, restraining J. Armoy Knox, editor of Texas Siftings, and Charles M. Snyder from convening or granting licenses for the production of a comic opera entitled "The False Prophet."

NORTH SYDNEY, Cape Breton, May 27.--The bark Katie Maguire, of Buenos Ayres, which arrived here this morning, reports that on the 24th inst. she picked up a dory containing two men belonging to the schooner Richard Lester, of Gloucester. The dory missed the Lester on Banquero in a fog. The men were six days in the boat without food, and when picked up were in a very exhausted condition.

WASHINGTON, May 27.--The leave of absence granted Lieut.-Col. Cyrus B. Comstock, Corps of Engineers, has been extended six months with permission to go abroad. The leave of absence granted First-Lieut. John C. Gresham, Seventh Cavalry, has been extened three months.
The annual Spring meet of the Hudson River canoeists began last evening at Croton Point, off Sing Sing, where they will remain in camp until Monday afternoon.
Thomas F. Gray, manufacturer of cigars at 121 Maiden-lane, made an assignment yesterday to Max Marx.

BOLTON, Lake George, May 27.--One of the fiercest forest fires ever Down in this region is now raging in the neighborhood of Buck Mountain. The centre of the conflagration is just opposite Bolton. Although the lake is a little over three miles wide at this point, guests of the Mohican House declare that they can at intervals distinctly hear the roar of the flames.
The Polytechnic Institute students held their annual Spring games on the Brooklyn Athletic Club's ground yesterday. The attendance was small and few of the contests exciting.

The Board of Aldermen met yesterday to consider the majority report of the Committee on Lamps and Gas, granting franchises to various companies who desired to compete with the older companies in lighting the streets with electric light.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 27.--Steps have been taken by Racine election officers to institute legal proceedings against the Rev. Olympia Brown Willis on the charged of attempting to stuff the ballot box, Mrs. Willis is the leader of the woman suffragists of Wisconsin.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 27.--"Jimmy" Hope, the cracksman, left for the East this morning in charge of the New-York officers and two men of the San Francisco force to serve his uncompleted term in Auburn Prison. The detail of San Francisco officers was given on account of fears that the wily burglar would attempt to escape on the journey.

MORRISVILLE, Vt., May 27.--An east-bound way freight train on the St. Johnsbury and Lake Champlain Railroad ran into a washout 10 miles east of here this afternoon. The fireman was killed and the conductor and engineer were badly injured. The engine and five cars are in the washout.

Thomas Murray, alias Henry Stewart, sentenced Nov. 29, 1886, to 10 years for robbery in the first degree by Judge Cowing, escaped from Sing Sing Prison yesterday morning about 8 o'clock by concealing himself in a case used for shipping shirts to Troy.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27.--The long lock-out of the clothing cutters by the Philadelphia Clothing Exchange was settled to-day to the satisfaction of all parties concerned. The lock-out now ended has lasted since Feb. 7, almost four months, and although at first affecting about 600 men, about onehalf that number can now enjoy the harmonious relations.

John Greenwall, the convicted murderer of Lyman S. Weeks, was sentenced yesterday to be hanged on Friday, July 15. He was taken from his cell in Raymond-Street Jail to the Sessions Court, and at 10 o'clock Judge Moore had him brought to the bar.

One of our esteemed evening contemporaries extracts from the story of the burning of the Belt line stables a moral in favor of cable roads. No doubt anything that tended to diminish the demand for horses would tend also to diminish the number and...

BATAVIA, Ohio, May 27.--Yesterday evening two negroes and a white man, of the convicts engaged in constructing a railroad on the Kentucky side of the Ohio River, opposite New-Richmond, Ohio, carrying out a conspiracy to escape, mortally wounded Overseer Marshall by a blow with a spade.

PROVIDENCE, R.L, May 27.--The four infantry battalions forming the brigade of Rhode Island militia were consolidated today, by order of the Governor, into two regiments of infantry and two separate companies additional, these latter being the former colored battalion.
CONSTANTINOPLE, May 27.--All the powers except Russia have replied to the Porte's recent circular consenting to a discussion of the Bulgarian question.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 27.--A local paper says it has just been learned that the Associated Wholesale Grocers of this city have entered a formal complaint of discrimination against the Missouri Pacific before the Inter-State Commerce Commission.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., May 27.--The northbound train due here at 5:20 A.M. left the rails four miles north, at Addison Junction, this morning. The express, baggage, and smoking cars and one coach went off.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 27.--Phosphatic circles in this State are agitated over well founded rumors that a wealthy and powerful syndicate, including several Northern millionaires, has been organized, in which all the phosphate miners and mining companies have joined, for the purpose of controlling and keeping up the price of crude rock.

"No, I haven't seen the star of Bethlehem," said Prof. Pickering, of the Harvard College observatory, last evening. "I looked for it Wednesday evening when I heard that some Professor in Kentucky, unknown to me, had discovered its presence in the heavens, but I could not see it.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 27.--In the House of Commons this morning the resolutions introduced by the opposition for the abolition of the monopoly clauses of the Canadian Pacific Railway charter in the province of Manitoba were defeated by a majority of 48. This is the largest...
RICHMOND, Va., May 27.--The significance of the result of yesterday's local elections in this state was the indifference to party lines manifested by the voters in the large colored counties.

At the meeting of the School Trustees of the Nineteenth Ward last night, at Grammar School No. 76, the Trustees went into executive session upon the charges brought by Principal George E. Hardy against Hugh Duffy, a teacher in the fourth grade of Grammar School No. 82.
The date of their departure for the seat of war in 1861 was commemorated last night by the veterans of the Ninth Regiment by a banquet at the Metropolitan Hotel.
The earnings of the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad Company for the month of April, as shown in an official statement issued yesterday, increased materially.

WASHINGTON, May 27.--The Secretary of War has experienced considerable trouble in the settlement of claims for property and clothing lost by army officers and men is the line of duty. The act of March 3, 1885, which authorizes the payment of indemnity for losses so incurred.

Late Thurday night the police of the Sixth Brooklyn. Precinct searched the house kept by Mrs. Kate Smith, at 1,235 Flushingavenue, and arrested Mrs. Smith and her daughter Annie, and in a room on the top floor found the special object of their search in the person of Katie Offerting, aged 15 years, who has been missing for a week from her home, at 148 Gwinnette-street.

A Parisian dentist, about 50 years old, has just committed suicide in very tragical circumstances. He had fallen desperately in love with a rather good-looking woman, who was a singer in a suburban cafe concert.

At the Health Office yesterday was given the one hundredth thousand death certificate since the inauguration of the present record system. It was issued for Cecelia Bee, an infant. The present method of recording deaths has existed nearly 12 years. The daily rate has been nearly 24.
Among the laws enacted at the recent session of the Connecticut Legislature is one for the prolonged confinement of incorrigible criminals.

Edward T. Martin, who has been staying at the New-York Hotel for the last three weeks, went to the theatre Thursday night with a friend. After the performance the two young men took a number of drinks and returned to the hotel about 1 o'clock yesterday morning.

BALTIMORE, May 27.--Information reached this city to-night from Bowie, Prince George County, a small village 12 miles from Washington, to the effect that P.H. Watts, a storekeeper of that place, had this afternoon, while crazed by drink, endeavored to burn the village.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba, May 27.--Another Indian outbreak now appears certain, this time between the Canadian Bloods and American Grosventres. Some time ago the Grosventres came across the line.
S.H. Morse, of Boston, is modeling a bust of the President. The American Exhibition in London is to have a grand cyclorama of New-York City and harbor prepared by Bartholdi.

Although the fields were small in all the six races run at the Brooklyn Club's track yesterday, the racing was excellent, and, like that of Thursday, brought out the running qualities of another Suburban candidate, in Guenn.

The card for the Brooklyn races to-day is an excellent one, and will furnish rattling sport. Speculatively inclined persons will have a good lot to pick from, and it will require a long head to select the winner from the lot in any of the events, except the Clarendon Stakes for 3-yearolds, which seems to be at the mercy of Hanover.

A proposed new by-law on the subject of margins, with the amendments to existing bylaws which its adoption would involve, was posted yesterday on the Produce Exchange.

ALBANY, May 27.--Speaker Husted has an idea that the committee to investigate the telephone companies will simplify its labors and make them more effective by dividing the State into districts and designating a member to conduct the inquiry in each district.

Detroit's big ball players had a bad effect upon the very clever little pitcher which NewYork has to relieve keefe. The reputation of the Michiganders for hard hitting, coupled, perhaps, with his belief in the exploded theory that a pitcher is expected to play the whole game, led to the result.

Two young Munich ladies, the Baronesses Anna and Louise Guttenberg, aged respectively 26 and 23, committed suicide yesterday by drowning themselves in the Starnberg Lake, on the identical spot where the King of Bavaria was found dead 11 months ago.
NEW-ORLEANS, May 27.--Advices received tonight from Little Rock state that requisition papers have been issued on the Governor of California for William Kissane.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 27.--Special reports to the Pioneer Press show that crops in Northern Minnesota and Dakota are in good condition. In Southern Minnesota and some of the older counties there are complaints of rain needed, as the recent showers are not sufficient.

The Cotton Exchange will go beyond the half holiday law to-day and be closed all day in accordance with the vote passed last week. The Liverpool markets will be closed to-day, too. The other downtown Exchanges will observe the half holiday law as they did last Saturday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27.--The committee appointed by the Methodist Episcopal ministers of this city to consider plans to keep newspaper reporters from their weekly meetings met in the fourth story of the Historical Society building this afternoon.

CHICAGO, May 27.--In the Superior Court this morning Judge Jamieson accepted the bid of $101,000 of W.W. Cudworth, Mary E. Handy, and W.B. Clapp for the stock and fixtures formerly owned by Clapp Davies, the jewelers who failed a few weeks ago.

SARATOGA, N.Y., May 27.--The Right Worthy Grand Lodge of Good Templars to-day elected the following-named officers: Right Worthy Good Templar--John B. Finch, Evanston, Ill., re-elected; R.W.G. Counselor--William...

PHILADELPHIA, May 27.--By stataments made before Special Master Dallas to-day it would appear that the suit of the Reading conductors, regarding their withheld wages, will not be pressed further at this time.
New-York's nine will play two games to-day, one against the Yale University nine this morning and another with the Detroits in the afternoon. Tiernan may be tried as a pitcher in the morning game.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 27.--Four weeks ago T.O. Brown, alias T.B. Otis, came to this city from Boston and registered at the Peabody Hotel. He became acquainted with the prominent real estate agents and attended all their sales.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 27.--Details of a remarkable case of murder in the Parish of Catahoula, in North Louisiana, have just been received. On Thursday last a colored man named Kilpatrick, formerly of Alexandria, residing upon the small farm of Ben Lee, colored, and married to Rosetta, one of his daughters, was murdered by his wife.
The usual notices that the Custom House world be closed on Decoration Day had not been posted yesterday and the minor officials were greatly troubled.
The first open tennis tournament of the Marine and Field Club, at Bath Beach, Long Island, was attended yesterday by representatives of the most prominent families in Brooklyn.
LONDON, May 27.--The steamship Caledonia, (Br.,) Capt. Garvie, from Mediterranean ports, for NewYork, passed Gibraltar to-day.
The pile driver in use on the ground which is to be covered by the new Consolidated Stock and Minning Exchange afforded the brokers any amount of amusement yesterday.

Several more persons were sick in Harlem yesterday from using milk which came from W.J. Robinson's farm at Stormville, Dutchess County, N.Y., the place from which the milk came that caused so much sicknees two weeks ago.
CHICAGO, May 27.--Nic Schneider, who served so long as a dummy contractor for the county boodlers and who is now informing on them, was again in the witness chair at the criminal court to-day.

PARIS, May 27.--President Grevy this morning summoned M. Rouvier and M. Deves for a conference and induced M. Rouvier to undertake the task of forming a Cabinet. M. Rouvier will endeavor to persuade M. Flourens...

CHICAGO, Ill., May 27.--An order has been entered by Judge Gresham authorizing the Receiver of the Wabash Road to pay certain interest on the sectional division mortgages of those branches of the system which have earned enough to pay interest.

Henry Hart threatens to take the Presidency of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company himself. He and Jay Gould are at odds, and George Gould, instead of following out the original programme and becoming President, may even retire from the Board of Directors, to which he has just been chosen.
St. John's Guild, that praiseworthy charity which takes the sick children of the city in its keeping, is about to begin its free daily steamer excursions for the benefit of its little charges.
The trial of Dr. Reynolds, accused of trying to defraud the London Assurance Company, was resumed at the Yorkville Court yesterday afternoon.

The little town of Ashfield, Mass., is about to have an excitement. A building for paintings, books, and objects of art is to be erected by his widow in memory of JOHN W. FIELD, of Philadelphia, a Quaker, who made his Winter home in Washington and spent part of his Summers in Ashfield.

City Works Commissioner Conner, who has stood in the way of clean streets in Brooklyn for some time in order to prevent Heman Clark, of this city, from getting the contract, backed down from his position yesterday, and Mr. Clark signed the contract, the work to begin on June 15.
Proceedings in the Anderson will case yesterday were confined to testimony showing that John Anderson was sane and did not talk with ghosts.
The intercollegiate games will take place today on the Manhattan Athletic Club's ground, and the O.N.T. Athletic Association will hold games in Roseville Park.

Maps and plans for a new railroad between New-York and Boston have been filed in the Register's office is this city. They call for a double-tracked line 193 miles in length, stone ballasted, equipped with iron bridges and 81pound steel rails, and without a grade crossing in its whole length.

UPPER SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., May 27.-- The Presidential party, including the President and Mrs. Cleveland, Col. and Mrs. Lamont, and Dr. and Mrs. Rosman, of Brooklyn, reached the Prospect House at 7 o'clock this evening.

LONDON, May 27.--The Duke of Beaufort's filly Reve d'Or, who was the favorite in the betting at five to four on, had no trouble in winning the Oaks at the Epsom meeting today, beating St. Helen in a common canter by three lengths. Freedom was a bad third. The Acorn Stakes, for 2-yearold fillies, was won by Mr. Brydges Willyam's Saucy Lass, with Mon Droit second and Aqueta third.

The recent fire in the Opera Comique in Paris which resulted disastrously to a great many people teaches a lesson, inasmuch as it proves that the risk to European travelers is not confined to steamship or railroad accidents.

The origin of the fire which destroyed the Belt Line Railroad car stables early yesterday morning is a mystery which will probably never be explained. Night Depot Master Byrne was standing out in front of the stables on Tenthavenue when he was startled by an outcry from some of the employes.

SYRACUSE, May 27.--Dr. George L. Curtiss, a dentist of this city, and one of the best known young men in Syracuse, was arrested today in a suit brought by his wife by a secret marriage for support and separation. Curtiss has lived in Syracuse 10 years, and has moved in the first circles of society.

CHICAGO, May 27.--The rules, by-laws, and regulations of the Chicago Board of Trade Stock Exchange are published to-day. The general rules for the government of the Exchange are similar to those enforced by the parent organization, but the regulations for the conduct of business are new.

The Street-Opening Board yesterday listened to discussion on the report of the subcommittee of that body in favor of the widening and extension of Elm-street. The Mayor's office was crowded with advocates of the project, including many property owners and other business men.

Grammar School No. 4, at 203 Rivington street, was the scene of much enthusiasm and gratitude yesterday. The enthusiasm was manifested by the pupils, teachers, a few graduates and Trustees, and members of the School Board, who had gathered to congratulate the Principal, James D. Domilt, upon the fiftieth anniversary of his first connection as a teacher with NewYork public schools.

The second scholastic year of the National Conservatory of Music closed yesterday, and the new year will not begin until Oct. 3. There will be at least 200 candidates, from all parts of the country, the Pacific coast included, for the entrance examinations, Sept. 27 and 28.

NATCHEZ, Miss., May 28.--About 6:30 o'clock this morning the boiler of the Natchez Cotton Factory exploded with terrific violence, entirely demolishing the engine room and the pickery, which was above it, and bursting in the walls of the main building, causing the roof to settle in the centre.

That big failure in Chicago a few weeks ago, when the wholesale jewelry house of Clapp Davies went under, brought up some interesting reminiscences of an affair that had a criminal ending less than five years ago.
Col. Louis Finkelmeier orders the Thirtysecond Regiment, Brooklyn, to assemble at 8 A. M. to-morrow for the parade. Capt. William Strining, Company B, has resigned.

CINCINNATI, May 28.--To-day's races at Latonia were run, with the following results: Seven Furlongs Selling Race. Handy Andy, (Watson,) 85 pounds, won, Alamo second, John Henry third. Time--1:30 . Eleven others ran. In the pools the field sold for $25, and Handy Andy and Rob Roy at $7 each, and Deboe, $6.

KINGSTON, N.Y., May 28.--The new Presiding Elder, Benjamin H. Burch, of the new Kingston District, created at the sessions of the New-York Methodist Episcopal Conference held here last month, together with the old and the new Stewards, met in St. James's Methodist Episcopal Church this week.

BERLIN, May 28.--The announcement from Paris that M. Rouvier had succeeded in forming a ministry, excluding Gen. Boulanger, and composed of Moderates who favor peace, was received here with satisfaction, qualified by fears that the existence of the new Cabinet would be stromy, soon ending in a more acute crisis.
ST. LOUIS, May 28.--Mrs. W.A. Latham, the wife of the chattering third baseman of the St. Louis Club, swore out a warrant against him to-day for assault and battery.

The fourth triennial tournament of the Bohemian Gymnastic Associations of the United States will be held at Brommer's Union Park to-morrow and Tuesday. The prizes will be contested for by delegates from many cities throughout the country.

Brother William W. Hall, of the Christian Brotherhood, whose place of meeting is in Twenty-fourth-street, between Seventh and Eighth avenues, took a small company a week ago to-day to the foot of West Seventy-sixthstreet to baptize young converts.

Judgment was rendered by the Court of Appeals on Monday on a new and most interesting point in the case of Cayotte dit Laciserole, the prisoner claimed that the sentence pronounced upon him was illegal, as the court had not first asked him if he had anything to say why sentence should not be pronounced.

In a line of tombs beyond the Ramesseum lived four sturdy Arabs named Abd-er-Rasoul. They supplied guides and donkeys to tourists who desired to visit the ruins of Thebes and sold them genuine and spurious antiquities.

BOSTON, May 28.--Mr. Daly's company closed their engagement here to-night, playing "The Taming of the Shrew" to the largest house ever seen in the Boston Museum.

The immense outdoor stage at St. George, Staten Island, to be used for the grand spectacle called the "Fall of Babylon," is being pushed rapidly to completion. It will be 450 by 250 feet, and illuminated by $20,000 worth of electric are, incandescent, and focusing lights.

ELMIRA, May 28.--The Cavalry Society of the Armies of the United States will hold its meeting this year on the 21st of June at Saratoga, one day in advance of the Army of the Potomac meeting at that place, which meeting President Cleveland, Gen. Sherman, and many other notable persons are expected to attend.

NEWBURG, N.Y., May 28.--The representatives of the Synod of the Reformed Presbyterian Church of America will convene in this city, in Westminster Church, on Wednesday, June 1. Many States will be represented by prominent clergymen. The sessions may last a week, and it is expected that it will be the most noteworthy meeting of an ecclesiastical body held along the Hudson River in many years.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 28.--The Rev. A.I. Hobbs, of the Central Christian Church, of Louisville, well known here, has accepted the Professorship in the theological department of the new Garfield College at Wichita, Kan. Dr. Everest, formerly President of Butler University here, is President of the new institution. The Rev. R.L. Powell, of Maysville, Ky., succeeds Dr. Hobbs at Louisville.

The Pioneer of India publishes an interesting account of the travels of Mr. Carey, of the Bengal Civil Service, who started about two years ago on a journey of exploration to the north of the Himalayas. He arrived at Lake Lob in April, 1886, and, having got together a caravan to carry supplies, continued his journey.

BOSTON, May 28.--The police to-day arrested L.M. Johnson, the head of the concern known as the American Detective Association, which has sent circulars out inviting application for membership upon a fee of $10. All such members were to receive liberal payment for detective work, but the police take the view that the entire scheme is fraudulent.

BOSTON, May 28.--The biggest kind of a row is among the prospects for the future over the bills which are coming in for the entertain ment of Queen Kapiolani. These foot up $18,000, and perhaps the queerest item in the whole lot is the bill presented by Galvin Brothers for flowers. This amounts to $4,500.
Joseph Byrnes, alias O'Brien, who stabbed Timothy Whalen at his liquor store on Greenwich-street, was captured Friday night, and is now at Police Headquarters.

BOSTON, May 28.--Gen. B.F. Butler gave the embryo lawyers of Boston University some very interesting advice to-day, deduced from the experience of 47 years in the practice of law. He talked to them nearly two hours, and his remarks were at once curious, practical, and instructive.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 28.--Mr. H.W. Clarke, of this city, father of Lieut. Arthur Clarke, who was shot on board the United States steamer iroquis at Panama on May 7, will request the Secretary of the Navy to investigate the matter, with a view to ascertaining if death was by suicide, as reported, or by murder, as Mr. Clarke believes.

The observance of Memorial Day will begin in Brooklyn to-day. The larger part of the decoration of graves will be completed and nothing will remain for to-morrow except the parade of Grand Army posts and National Guardsmen.
A letter received this week by R.C. Woods from his son, John Woods, gives the particulars of a desperate encounter the latter had with a mountain lion a few days since.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 28.--Newland T. De Pauw, Peter R. Stoy, C.W. De Pauw, and John W. Ray have qualified as Executors of the estate of the late W.C. De Pauw, giving bonds in the sum of $2,000,000, with John McCullough, Moses Irwin, Elijah J. Newland ...
"The Kindergarden" continues at Dockstader's. Miss Pixley and "The Deacon's Daughter" will remain at the Union-Square Theatre another week.

The Gas Commission yesterday awarded a contract to the Brush Electric Light Company for 324 lights at 25 cents per light, per night. All the other bids for public lighting were rejected and the Commissioner of Public Works was authorized to readvertise for proposals for lighting those portions of the city by electric light not already contracted for.

On the 5th of June, at Kiel, the inaugural ceremony of the commencement of the canal between the German Ocean and the Baltic will take place. According to the present arrangements the Emperor, accompanied by Prince Bismarck, will attend.

The telegraph has told of the liberal bequests made by the late Hon. W.C. De Pauw, of New-Albany, Ind., to the De Pauw University at Greencastle, Ind., and to his family. His will also gives to the Missionary Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church, $10,000; to the Church ...

There is no longer any material happiness worth speaking about on the face of the earth. M. Schnaebeles has been restored to his indignant countrymen, but without a letter of apology, and after, as before, the German sword hangs menacingly over France.

--Those who are accustomed to think of the history of the Crusades as merely that of a succession of marvelous fanatic raids will have their ideas modified when they hear of this civil constitution of the Frankish Kingdom.

LONDON, May 28.--The cotton spinners at Ashton-Under-Lyne have agreed to the proposition made at the meeting of spinners in Manchester yesterday that the mills should be run on half time for eight weeks in case two-thirds of the trade agree to the plan.

So far as business was concerned Wallstreet might just as well have taken a whole holiday yesterday. Less than 65,000 shares of stock were traded in during the hours that the Stock Exchange was open, and everybody had an easy time.
Gen. FAIRCHILD, Commander-in-Chief of the Grand Army of the Republic, has notified his command that there is no such day known to his order as Decoration Day.

Although the report that NORDENSKJOLD intended to spend eighteen months in antarctic exploration does not appear to have been well founded, it is probable that the southern polar region will soon be visited by an exploring party.

The Police Commissioners yesterday received from the Civil Service Examining Board an eligible list of candidates for promotion, in response to the notification sent recently that there existed vacancies in the department for 1 Inspector, 4 Captains, and 10 Sergeants.

WASHINGTON, May 28.--The so-called controversy with respect to the Alaskan seal fisheries and American rights to exclusive jurisdiction over the waters of Behring Sea has recently been made the subject of more misrepresentation to the square inch than almost any other pending topic of public discussion.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 28.--According to the Signal Service Bureau this has been the hottest day experienced in this city for 15 years, or since the establishment of the bureau here.

The members of the Veteran Corps of the Twenty-second Regiment, headed by Col. S. Ellis Briggs, celebrated last evening the twentyfifth anniversary of the departure of the regiment for the war by a banquet in Nilsson Hall.
Officer Charles A. Place, of the Eldridge-street station, went to the Essex Market Court yesterday and obtained a warrant which empowered him to raid the saloon at 15 Bowery.
Racing at the Brooklyn Jockey Club's tracks closed for the present yesterday. There were good fields of horses, good, sharp racing, generally popular victories, and lively betting.

There is a glaring want of tact about the court arrangements, both great and small. On the afternoon of the drawing room tens of thousands of people waited for hours in the Mall with the object of seeing the Queen drive out.

WASHINGTON, May 28.--The weekly abstract of sanitary reports, issued to-day by Supervising Surgeon General Hammond, of the Marine Service, affords no basis whatever to sustain the statement recently telegraphed from Philadelphia, on the alleged authority of the chief officer of the bark MacLeod, from Buenos Ayres, that people were dying like sheep from cholera in the Argentine Republic.

NEWPORT, May 28.--Newport will be a lively place next week. Monday will be observed as Memorial Day. The troops from Fort Adams and the naval apprentices and marines from the United States training squadron will be in line, together with Duryea's Zouaves, of ...
Adam Forepaugh's "New Olympia," at Erastina, Staten Island, will be in readiness by June 27.

WASHINGTON, May 28.--The heavens were overcast to-day and threatened rain. The air was cool--almost chilly. The infantry companies competing to-day were: Company B, First Virginia; Nealy Rifles, of Maine; National Rifles, of this city; ...

The Sing Sing Prison authorities have not succeeded in capturing Thomas Murray, the convict who got himself carted out of the prison on Friday in a packing case and then cut himself out when left alone in the car in which the box had been placed.

The Columbia College Baseball Association has resigned from the College League, after forfeiting two games to Yale. It is probable that if the association had not resigned efforts would have been made for its expulsion.
The Columbia College Class of '88 yesterday defeated the Class of '90 baseball by a score of 17 to 7.

The fight that has been going on for several months between Deacon Richardson and the Broadway Railroad for the possession of Central-avenue, Brooklyn, for railroad purposes was decided yesterday by Justice Bartlett, who finds that the Deacon has no right to lay his tracks, along the street in question.

HARWICH, May 28.--It was a dull, heavy morning when eight of us steamed from the west pier at Greenwich on the committee boat of the West Thames Yacht Club, bound for Southend. The wind was light, but gave promise of better things when we got clear of land. As we started down the river one jolly yachtsman remarked:
SAN FRANCISCO, May 28.--The first of the three Cunard steamers purchased for Pacific Ocean traffic, to ply between Hong-Kong and Vancouver, will sail from Yokohama to-morrow. The Pacific Coast...
The little bobtail car which crosses Twenty-third-street was becoming uncomfortably crowded as it wended its way eastward yesterday afternoon.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 25.--"Arkansaw is an empire, Sir, as well as a State," is the glowing bit of information presented to the man who pays his first visit to this capital, intent either on pleasure or business.

The Sixty-ninth Regiment of New-York City and the Fourteenth Regiment of Brooklyn, under command of Gen. James McLeer, have been ordered by the Governor to escort the Society of the Army of the Potomac at Saratoga on June 21.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., May 28.--Antone Joseph, a boy 15 years old, fell from Tober's Wharf to-day and sank. It was half an hour before his body was found. His father belongs to the steamer Verbena, in the service in the Lighthouse Board.
The unveiling of the facade of the Duomo of Florence marks the completion of one of the most interesting expressions of popular energy and persistence which the world contains.

In addition to the three stake hurdle races to be run at the meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club, already announced, there will be a hurdle race of a mile and a quarter on the opening day of the meeting. All the hurdle races run at the Sheepshead Bay track will be on the turf, and they promise to furnish good sport.

CHICAGO, May 28.--The wheat clique sent a number of new brokers into the pit to-day, who, by taking all the crowd would sell them and bidding for millions more, held the price of the June future at 88 cents. Their purchases...
Joseph Harris, an expressman, living at 167 Division-street, took to Police Headquarters last evening a wagonload of gravestones and the marble posts used in fencing burial plots.
The dinner was over. The servants had cleared away the ornamental pieces of confectionery and the automatic figures at which every one had laughed so hard.

Joan of Arc still lives in the memory of her fellow-countrymen, and the attempt made some time ago by an erratic writer to deprecate the fame of the Maid of Orleans was followed by such a storm of indignation that the profanation is not likely to be repeated for many a year.

Emanuel Baptist Church, in Suffolkstreet, near Grand, has been beautifully decorated for the memorial services, which will be held this evening under the auspices of the Adam Goss Post, No. 330, G.A.R. Pastor Samuel Alman, who is a member of the post, will conduct the exercises.
WASHINGTON, May 28.--First Lieut. Abiel L. Smith, Fourth Cavalry, has been ordered to report to the Superintendent of Recruiting Service for duty at the cavalry depot.

SARATOGA, N.Y., May 28.--After routine work in the session of the Right Worthy Grand Lodge of Good Templars this morning, the Committee on Political Action reported, stating the objects, aims, and position of the order, its policy of abstinence for the individual and of prohibition by the State.

LONDON, May 28.--Up to Friday Europe was still waiting for a Ministry in Paris. The delay added importance to Gen. Boulanger, who, during the week, has taken a bold step by sending to the papers a communication denying that he will abandon his project to mobilize one army corps, and adding that he will call up to their colors a class hitherto exempt. Gen. ...

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 28.--Before United States Commissioner Crail to-day, Daniel O'Rielly, who was the Republican Postmaster of Litchfield, Ky., and who is Inspector-General of the Grand Army of the Republic, had a preliminary trial on the charge of making false returns to the Post Office Department while Postmaster in order to increase his pay.

A new view of the Saturday half holiday was given yesterday by Chief-Justice McAdam, of the City Court. The Judge said that the Thirteen Club was the first to welcome this holiday, the practical feature of which was to make much-abused Friday the most important day of the week.

The place of Master of the Horse in the fourteenth century was a highly responsible and important one. The officer who held it was the head of the "cavalry department;" and as cavalry formed the main strength of a feudal army it was imperatively necessary that the breed of horses should be encouraged by every means at the disposal of the Government.

Quong Gee Lung deals in Chinese groceries and teas at 47 De Kalb-avenue, Brooklyn. He is no everyday specimen of his race, and never took in washing. Mr. Lung wears the pigtail of which the Quong Gee family has been justly proud for many centuries.
The Faculty of the Grand Conservatory of Music of the City of New-York last evening gave a banquet to Dr. Ernest Eberhard, the President of the Conservatory, at Martinelli's, in Fifth-avenue.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 28.--Graham Graham, dry goods merchants, made an assignment to-day. It is thought the liabilities will reach a very large amount. They surrendered all private property, including their homes.

If many were kept away by the weather from the intercollegiate athletic games yesterday, the spectators would have had a hard time on a clear day. As it was only early comers could get good seats on the grand stand, and when the games had fairly started, sightseers occupied all the space that could be spared them.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., May 28.--At Crary's Mills, St. Lawerence County, last evening, Ira Church and George Elwood started out to shoot a crane that had alighted near Mr. Church's residence. Elwood, who walked behind Mr. Church, carrying a shotgun, with his finger on the trigger, made a misstep, discharging his piece into the side of Mr. Church, killing him. Mr. Church was 68 years old, and leaves a widow and two children.
An insane man appeared at the Franklin-street entrance of the Tombs yesterday morning and said: "I've killed 11,000 men this morning and I want to kill all the men locked up here."

The thirtieth anniversary of the German Dispensary was celebrated last evening by a "commers" at Beethoven Hall. All the physicians of the German Dispensary and of the German Hospital were present, besides 25 invited guests.

May glides onward into June so quietly in the world of society that the transition will be scarcely perceptible. There has been no change in the conditions of the social atmosphere since last Sunday, no event of any importance, save the coaching parade, having taken place to vary the monotony of this transition period of the year, when the Spring season ...

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 28.--The official list of the persons killed and injured at the Pennsylvania Railroad accident at Horseshoe Bend last night, as given by officers of the company, gives six killed and eight injured, as follows:

MONTREAL, May 28.--A project is on foot to invite the Governor-General here for the Queen's jubilee celebration on June 21 as a set off to the O'Brien demonstration. Some of the more fiery of the Irish threaten to rotten egg Lord Lansdowne if he puts his foot in the city.

"Pfingsten," or Whitsuntide, is always looked forward to with great interest by all Germans throughout the world. However long a German may have resided in the United States, when "Pfingsten" comes around, nature gains the ascendancy and he yearns to go out into the green fields under the shade of trees with his family or friends.

The number of Scotch estates in the market increases daily. Mr. Watson Lyall, of Pall Mall, the well known Scotch agent and author of the "Sportsman's Guide," has several millions of pounds' worth on his hands for sale, and at his usual sales in June and July will expose a number of properties of the aggregate value of 500,000.

About 50 deaf-mutes met in Lyric Hall last evening to protest against the action of the Gallaudet Centennial Committee in awarding the contract for erecting a bronze statue to the Rev. Dr. Thomas Hopkins Gallaudet without giving notice to deaf-mute sculptors.

The young man who leaves the country to come to New-York and go into business has one trial in store that it is hard for him to avoid. He leaves friends behind him, of course, in the town he came from, and these friends are in the habit of paying periodical visits to the city.

Charles S. Schleier, a real estate dealer at 180 Atlantic-avenue, Brooklyn, was a prisoner in Justice Walsh's court yesterday on complaint of a widow. Henrietta Schoene, who charged him with selling her property to which he held no title.

--Agrippa d'Au bigne, Mme. de Maintenon's grandfather, was among the most distinguished Frenchmen of his day, a champion of the reformed cause with sword and pen, and a friend and comrade-in-arms of Henry IV.
A detail from the Seventh Regiment, under command of Lieut. John A. Tackaberry, Company H, will perform guard duty at the reviewing stand during the parade to-morrow.
The funeral of Judge Josiah Sutherland took place yesterday afternoon at his residence, 336 Lexington-avenue. It was very simple in all its arrangements.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 28.--Bishop Ryan has refused the use of St. Stephens' Hall for a lecture announced to be given here by Father McGlynn, on the ground that the latter is in open rebellion against the church. The report in a New-York paper that the refusal was by James Mooney, exPresident of the Irish National League, is denied. He had nothing to do with the matter.

Including yesterday's games, the record of the clubs of the National Baseball League is as follows: Detroit, 20 games won, 5 lost; Boston, 17 won, 7 lost; New-York, 15 won, 10 lost; Philadelphia, 13 won, 12 lost; Pittsburg, 9 won, 12 lost; Chicago, 9 won, 14 lost; Washington, 7 won, 14 lost; Indianapolis, 5 won, 20 lost.

--The Blind Brother. A Story of the Pennsylvania Coal Mines. By Homer Greene. New-York: Thomas Y. Crowell Co.--This is the prize story of the Youth's Companion, and is well deserving of the high award.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 28.--Richard Hardle, a 10-year-old colored boy, of Charlotte, is dying from the effects of a self-inflicted bullet wound, because he preferred death to a whipping at the hands of his mother.

BOSTON, May 28.--Gov. Ames has requested the War Department to return to Massachusetts the flags of Massachusetts regiments captured by Confederates during the rebellion. They were taken from the Nineteenth, Twenty-third, Fifty-sixth, and other regiments.

One impediment to the policy of commercial union between Canada and this country appears to be a feeling on the part of loyal Canadians that it might in some way promote a movement toward a political union between the two countries.
One dull day in November of last year an operation of a highly delicate nature was performed upon a negro at St. Thomas Hospital. The operator was Professor Pearce, the famous surgeon.

The "shoots" of the asparagus have a range of 15,000 yards, with a low trajectory and an explosive power which is to melinite as melinite is to gunpowder. The difficulty of transport is at once overcome by the size, docility, and swiftness of the rabbits and hares, which grow to magnificent proportions.

Assistant District Attorney Ambrose B. Purdy, who conducted the prosecution of Mrs. Chiara Cignarale and secured a verdict consigning the murderess to the gallows in the face of a hundred obstacles, said yesterday that, though fully convinced of the justice of the verdict, he felt like a murderer.
