BOSTON, May 28.--The Spring meeting of the Country Club ended to-day in mud and rain. These untoward elements, however, did not prevent some of the best races of the meeting, and only partially affected the attendance.
The death is announced from Leghorn of an old lady who was one of the few relatives of the late Lord Beaconsfield. This is Mme. Sara de Rossi, nee Israeli-Tedeschi.

The members of District Assembly No. 75 deny that a tie-up is to be ordered on the ParkAvenue (Brooklyn) Road because General Manager Johnson is a Director in a horse car line in Indianapolis, the employes of which are now on strike. They have passed resolutions of sympathy with the strikers, and will send them a little money if necessary.
WASHINGTON, May 29.--Major Ben: Perley Poore died at the Ebbett House in this city tonight at 12:30 o'clock, surrounded by his wife, nurse, and attending physicians, Drs. Baxter and Harrison.

Michael Gavin and Timothy Flaherty, the two New-Yorkers who were arrested on suspicion of having robbed the residence of John D. Cheever, at Cedarhurst, of silverware valued at $3,000, were discharged by Justice Hendrickson, of Hempstead, owing to Mr. Cheever failing to appear in court.
I read with amazement that Lord Wolseley was allowed the other day to make an ascent in a captive ballon, with which the Royal Engineers are experimenting at Chatham.

RONDOUT, N.Y., May 28.--Rain fell along the Hudson River Valley generally to-day, and farmers now say that the serious drought which prevailed in seven counties is at an end. The crops of hay and grain will not be materially affected.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., May 28.--The preliminary work on the projected new coffer dams here has been begun. Grants for land now under water in the Hudson River were obtained recently from the State, and the rich brickmaking clay therein contained will be taken out by manufacturers here.
Crumbs of comfort for the Cobden Club dinner this year are accumulating. The recent free trade victory in New South Wales has been followed up by one in Sweden.

In the counties of Surrey and Sussex when it was known that a man was in the habit of beating the partner of his joys and sorrows; some chaff from the threshing floor was sprinkled in front of his house at night.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 28.--The Clearing House exchanges for the past week were $15,339,822. Drafts on New-York--Sight, 17 cents; telegraphic, 25 cents.

CALCUTTA, May 28.--The cyclone which visited this section yesterday was very destructive. A local steamer, with 750 passengers aboard, was caught by the cyclone and is missing. It is feared she is lost with all abroad. The district of Orissa was completely devastated by the cyclone.

While engaged in cutting coupons off of bonds in the Union Safe Deposit Vaults, Thursday, Mr. Alpheus Hardy dropped the scissors which he was using. They struck his leg, but he did not think that he was cut and went to work again. After a short time he found that he was bleeding. The wound is not dangerous, but had to be sewed up.

Miss Jessie Cole, whose home is at Peekskill, was instantly killed at Yonkers yesterday afternoon. In company with Miss Laura Stockholm she started to go to the Erie Railroad station, and proceeded by way of a walk which led through the rear yard to a gate opening upon the tracks.

Mayor Hewitt yesterday granted Charles Pilkington a three months' license to have music and sell beer at his Oak Point gardens, upon the latter making an affidavit that "The" Allen was in no way interested in the place.

--The habit of wearing warm coverings on the head is not of recent date; the armies of Europe, for instance, no inconsiderable number of men, with heads close cropped, have worn for a long period warmer and heavier headgear than the modern dwellers in cities, without the same tendency to baldness.

The Rev. Henry Van Rensselaer, a scholastic of the Society of Jesus, will be ordained to the priesthood at the cathedral at 7 o'clock Tuesday morning by Archbishop Corrigan. Mr. Van Rensselaer is a member of the well known Albany family of that name, and a convert from the Protestant ministry.

Mr. Westland, Acting Secretary of the Financial Department, lately visited Gwalior to make arrangements for taking over three and a half crores of rupees which the Regency is lending to the Indian Government.

BOSTON, May 28.--In looking over the political field for the coming campaign in this State, or, for that matter, for the greater contest in national politics in 1888, they who leave Gen. Benjamin Franklin Butler out of their calculations are counting without their host.

Thursday last was the five-hundredth exhibition day of the Merrimac-Monitor Panorama, and yet the popularity of this place of amusement is as great as months ago. Tickets of admission have been sold during the past two months for the benefit of the Decoration Day funds of the Grand Army posts, and to-morrow the old soldiers, with their wives and children, will probably visit the exhibition in great numbers.

Mr. Chamberlain's trip to Scotland has been a dismal failure. It was made under the impression that the eyes of the entire world would be fixed upon the Birmingham traveler, and that his tour in the Hebrides would vie with that of Dr. Johnson.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 28.--The faculty of the Atlanta University at Atlanta, Ga., have tendered the presidency of that institution to the Rev. Erastus Blakeslie, Pastor of the Second Congrega tional Church of Fairhaven.
GLASGOW, May 28.--A terrible explosion has occurred in the Udston coal pit at Blantyre, a village in Lanarkshire, eight miles from this city. The shaft is blocked with debris caused by the explosion.

Lewis B. Lent, who was once well known as a showman, died suddenly Thursday evening at his house, 246 Lexington-avenue. Mr. Lent was born in 1814 at Somers, Westchester County, and entered the show business at the age of 19. His father bought him an interest in Brown Fogg's Circus, with which the young man remained for a couple of seasons.

At 4:44 o'clock yesterday afternoon an elegantly upholstered English groom, in a high hat, dark green double-breasted coat, belt, cream-colored pantaloons, top boots, and an iron rod in lieu of a spine, leaned in a graceful pose against the riding academy in Eighth-avenue across from the Fiftyninth-street entrance to the Park.

John Vanderveer, the wealthy Coney Island hotel keeper, was notified yesterday that his son Abe had been found in an unconscious condition in Carson, a little town in Indiana, and that he was in a critical condition.
F.A. Schneider, the man picked up in the East River at 7 o'clock Friday night by the tugboat F.H. Grove and taken to the ChambersStreet Hospital, left that institution yesterday afternoon.

"The Black Hussar" will call his shapely soldiers to arms for the last time at Wallack's to-morrow evening, and an extra matinee of the opera will be given to-morrow afternoon in commemoration of Decoration Day.

A few minutes before 11 o'clock last night a fire broke out in the storehouse belonging to the cooperage works of L.M. Palmer, in Brooklyn, Eastern District, which occupies an entire square, 400 feet deep by 200 feet wide.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 28.--There is a nice row in the Democratic Party, caused by the appointment of Joseph L. Carson, of Shelby County, as President of the Benevolent Board of the State, and Mr. Joseph Flack, of this county, as a member of the Insane Asylum Board.

John McMackin, Chairman of the County General Committee of the United Labor Party, has returned from a tour through the State. He has made 25 engagements for lectures by the Rev. Dr. McGlynn, and said yesterday that Catholics in all the places he visited supported the position taken by the deposed priest. Dr. McGlynn will be the principal speaker at the meeting of the Anti-Poverty Society this evening at the Academy of Music.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 28.--Probably the smallest specimen of humanity now living in Indiana was born to the wife of Ashley Cooper, of Mooresville, a few days ago. This little midget, now 6 days old, weighs less than three pounds.

BRUSSELS, May 28.--The strike in the Mons district is becoming general. The trial of de Fuisseaux for publishing a seditious manifesto has begun. Copies of it have been seized wherever found by the police throughout Belgium.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., May 28.--The bulk of the testimony presented in the Peak murder trial here to-day was for the purpose of showing what the mental condition of Katie Anderson was at the time she made the declaration that Barclay Peak shot her.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 28.--Charles Peakes, a dairyman on the outskirts of the city, heard burglars about his house yesterday morning and raised a window. As he did so the burglars opened fire upon him, and one of the balls lodged in his abdomen, causing a mortal wound. Detectives arrested Edward Brantingham and Orey and Raymond Judy, three young men who had been in Peakes's employ, and they confessed that they made the murderous assault.

ST. LOUIS, May 28.--The Court House was turned into something of a prize ring for about two hours this afternoon, State Legislator William P. Macklin and son and Alexander J.P. Garesche and two sons figuring as combatants.

H.K. Enos, who was the close personal friend and principal broker of William H. Vanderbilt, is one of the quiet men of the Stock Exchange. In the old days, when bent on executing some of the big deals of his mighty millionaire friend, he was, as he is now, unobtrusive and never posing.

BOSTON, May 28.--John K. Tarbox, Insurance Commissioner of Massachusetts, who died in Boston this morning, gained a reputation for stern integrity, painstaking labor, and rigid justice in the discharge of his duties rarely attained by a public official. He was by far the best Insurance Commissioner the State ever had.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 28.--A letter from Mr. Fred Romband to Mr. Alvin D. Brooke, ex-Director of the Credit Foncier, is printed here describing the condition of affairs at the American colony in Topolobampo, Mexico, which was founded under the direction of Mr. A.K. Owen, who held a special grant from the Mexican Government.

LEXINGTON, May 28.--William T. Withers, of Lexington, has sold to Judge Irvine and others, of Montgomery County, the b.s. Almont, 3 years old, by Almont, dam Jessie Pepper, by Mambrino Chief, for $1,500.

Queen Kapiolani spent some time while in the city in visiting our palatial dry goods houses, and expressed herself more than delighted with the magnificence of our goods and the artistic elegance of American costumes.
There were 1,652 arrests by the police last week. The next regular meeting of the Life Insurance Association will be held at the Hotel Brunswick, Tuesday, June 7, at 5 P.M.

The Ministry formed by M. ROUVIER yesterday has the advantage of being a logical outcome of the movement by which the Goblet Ministry was overthrown.
Two trots were to have taken place at the track of the Driving Club of New-York yesterday, but they were postponed until to-morrow because of the smallness of the attendance.

Disappointment must have been felt at the way the market acted the past week. It has not been satisfactory. Neither bull nor bear could have got anything out of it, and the commission brokers certainly did not.
The old gold and red pennant of the Rye Lawn Tennis Club will be hoisted from the handsome clubhouse at Rye to-morrow, and the season of 1887 will be opened.
The various clubhouses have been perfect paradises since the enforcement of the Sunday liquor laws, because the frequenters can obtain all the "supplies" they desire.

WASHINGTON, May 28.--The six days' cushion carrom billiard match of 1,800 points, for a purse of $1,000 and the championship of the world, which has been in progress in this city during the past week, terminated to-night, Daly coming out an easy winner.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28.--During the past week 12,000 copies of a secret circular and the revised constitution and laws governing the formation of national trades assemblies have been sent out to all the local assemblies of the Knights of Labor from the general headquarters of the order in this city for approval.

LONG BRANCH, May 28.--There is no time in the year when the Summer capital is so enjoyable to those who do not care for the crush of mid-Summer as during such days as these, when the houses have just been brightened up by the painters and cleaners, the lawns nicely mowed, and everything has an attractive air of newness.
Capt. R. Hobbs, of this city, after he met with the misfortune of losing his arm on the battlefield during the late war, was appointed purchasing agent in this territory for the Army of Virginia.

WHEELING, West Va., May 28.--A murder trial just now occupying a large share of public attention in the Upper Ohio Valley is in progress at New-Martinsville, the county seat of Wetzel County and a river town 35 miles south of this city.

The tobacco monopoly will be taken up by a syndicate of foreign and native bankers, assisted by the Bank of Spain, to form a company with a capital of several millions sterling to which, under the law voted by the Cortes, a lease of 10 years will be adjudicated on June 6.

MERIDEN, Conn., May 28.--The Rev. Dr. McGlynn, who lectured here last night, stopped at the Winthrop Hotel and there met a waitress named Maggie Malloy, recently from New-York and a former parishioner of his at St. Stephen's. She expressed regret that he should have to leave his old church, whereupon he said: "Never mind. I'll have it back again. I intend to go to Rome inside of 19 days."

Seeing that the average brain weight of women is about five ounces less than that of men, on merely anatomical grounds we should be prepared to expect a marked inferiority of intellectual power in the former.

Henry Hart did yesterday what his friends have been predicting, refused to be dictated to by Jay Gould and elected himself President of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company.
Prof. A.C. Merriam, Adjunct Professor of Greek in Columbia College, will start on June 15 for Europe. He is to take charge for the coming year of the American School of Classical Studies at Athens.

At the meeting of the Executive Committee of the Harlem Independence Day Association Friday evening the arrangements for the dinner July 4, at West End Hall, were reported complete.

A drizzling rain was falling when the pigeon-shooting match between Dr. Carver, the expert, and L. Davenport, the amateur, of the Coney Island Rod and Gun Club, was started yesterday at Dunler's Park, Long Island.
Frog catching in the marshes north of Whitehall is proving profitable business for the boys. Over half a ton has been shipped to NewYork, where they bring 40 cents a pound at wholesale.

An advertisement appeared yesterday asking those who saw the conductor of a Sixth-avenue car throw a gentleman from the platform Friday afternoon to communicate with him. The advertiser was Mr. Marc Levy, a broker, living at 100 West Fiftythird-street.
PARIS, May 28.--Political conjecture and Ministerial possibilities have passed into secondary consideration. The terrible disaster at the Opera Comique is absorbing all public interest.

Why should they be called currants indeed, thus giving people a notion that they are a richer, and more generous form of those red or white bunches that grow on our currant bushes at home. Precisians, indeed, of the last century may have refined upon the name.
The New-Yorks yesterday for the third consecutive time outplayed the Detroits, and thereby gained their second victory over the team popularly supposed to be well-high invincible.

LONDON, May 28.--Mr. Bayard, United States Secretary of State, has sent a circular to the different American Legations and Consulates in Europe requesting that efforts be made to ascertain the whereabouts of Mrs. Sarah Montgomery, who had been travelling in Europe for two years.

We are glad that Gov. Ames has signed the Crispus Attucks memorial resolve. There are too many iconoclasts nowadays bent upon overthrowing and trampling upon all "the traditions of the elders," which have become sacred to the popular heart.

PARIS, May 29.--At midnight to-night it is semi-officially stated that the Ministry is still incomplete. The War and Marine portfolios are still unallotted. Gen Saussier has declined the office of War Minister. It is probable that Gen. Ferron will accept the War portfolio.

CITY OF MEXICO, May 29.--The Secretary of Foreign Affairs, Mr. Mariscal, has addressed a reply to the request made by the United States Government that the death sentence pronounced against Col. Arvisza and his companions, on account of the part they took in a recent violation of American territory at Nogales, be commuted.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 29.--Justice C. F. Brown, of the Supreme Court, sitting in Chambers at Newburg, has just rendered an important decision in the cases in litigation commonly styled in railroad circles "time-buyers' suits." The "time buyers" are a class of speculators along the line of the Erie Railway who...

UTICA, N.Y. May 29.--Three young persons were drowned in the Mohawk River this afternoon while boating.
Nineteen years ago Gen. John A. Logan as Commander-in-Chief of the Grand Army of the Republic issued the following order setting apart May 30 as Memorial Day:
WASHINGTON, May 29.--A rumor was in circulation to-night that the Vicksburg Southrons had withdrawn from the dress parade this afternoon on account of the presence of a colored company.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29.--To-morrow the disastrous boycotts against the members of the Philadelphia Clothing Exchange, which have been kept in effective operation by the Knights of Labor for over three months, will be lifted, and circulars announcing that fact will be sent out from the general headquarters here to all the local assemblies of the order.

Liquidly, New-York City was yesterday divided against itself. Above Fourteenth-street --east and west of Broadway--the thirsty man could get whatever he wanted to drink in almost any place he chose to consume it.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29.--The steerage of tha Allen Line steamer Scandinavia, which this morning arrived at Pier 47, South Wharves, with 650 emigrants aboard, was to-night the scene of mixed humor and despair, such as none but Irish peasantry can present.

It was a cold day at Coney Island yesterday. Those who journeyed thither mostly returned with blue noses. Nature was cross, contrary to her accustomed mood at this season of the year, and smutched the sky all over with dirty-hued clouds, which put a damper upon the spirits of even the fat negro boy of whom the scales of Coney Island say that he weighs 617 pounds.
When Dr. De Groff, of Union Hill, went into his office yesterday morning he discovered that burglars had forced an entrance into his house and rifled his safe.

The New Testament, which was translated into Hebrew by the late Rev. Isaac Salkinson, missionary among the Jews of Vienna, of the British Jews' Society in London, has been reprinted here in a second edition of 120,000 copies.

Some importance is attached here to a scheme of the Russian Government according to which the entire management of a Western Russian railway is to be given into the hands of the military authorities.

TORONTO, May 29.--A number of protectionists who were discussing the strong and weak points of commercial union to-day, and who were anxious that their side of the case should be presented in its strongest light in THE TIMES, decided that Mr. Edward Gurney was the man for the work. Mr. Gurney was born here; his father was an American.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 20.--Last night while four union men were walking on the track near Natrona Salt works, where the men are now on a strike, they were attacked by three non-unionists and severely beaten.

BOSTON, Mass., May 29.--The train from Montreal bearing Editor William O'Brien reached the Boston and Lowell Station in this city at about 10:30 o'clock this morning. A large crowd was in waiting, and as Mr. O'Brien stepped from the train he was greeted with cheer upon cheer.

At the time of the death of George IV. in 1830 there were 328 hereditary peers. There are now 477. During this period 335 new baronetcies have been created, 278 by the Liberals and 96 by the Conservatives--a proportion which shows that Liberals are more greedy for this honor than Conservatives.

WASHINGTON, May 29.--Mr. George E. Lemon, General Treasurer of the Logan fund, has completed and transmitted to Mrs. Logan a detailed statement of the source and respective amounts to the subscriptions to the fund, as well as the disposition made of the money.

London, May 29.--Discount during the past week was weak at 1@ . The Stock Exchange loan rate to next account is 2@1 . Business on the Stock Exchange during the week was inactive, but there was an upward tendency promising well for strength in all departments after the holidays. The coming conversion of Indian stocks induces further purchases of consols.

The Committee on Contested Seats of the Republican County Committee will meet tomorrow evening at the headquarters of the Thirteenth Assembly District Republicans in the Grand Opera House. The troubles in the First, Sixth, and Thirteenth Assembly Districts will be investigated.

HARWICH, May 29.--This morning I went on board the Thistle and met Mr. Bell, the owner, and Mr. Watson, the designer of the winner of yesterday's race. Mr. Bell expressed thanks for the fairness displayed by THE TIMES in reporting the success of his vessel, and he hoped to be able to express his appreciation in New-York in person. Mr. Watson was writing in the ample saloon...

The Burns brothers, James and Thomas, of 123 Mott-street; Hugh McMahon, of 213 First-avenue; Robert Gildely, of 222 Firstavenue, and Thomas Hartington, of 192 Worthstreet, had a grudge against James O'Connell, of 93 Elm-street.
ROME, May 29.--The report that a President Cleveland had sent a jubilee present to the Pope is unfounded.
MONTREAL, May 29.--Billy Moloney's daughter and Mr. Reilly, her husband, who have been spending a few weeks in Montreal, left for New-York yesterday afternoon.

MONTREAL, May 29.--Half a dozen fishermen went over to Nuns' Island last night to fish, taking with them a plentiful supply of whisky. They all got drunk, and while returning this morning the boat was upset and four of them, named Charles Vezeau, Joseph Robidoux, Wilfrid Leroux, and Phileas Montreuil, were drowned.

Though yesterday was not the day formally set apart for decorating the graves of those to whom the Nation owes its preservation, many organizations and individuals took advantage of its leisure and paid that tribute to the dead with which the duties and cares of today would interfere.
There are few more handsome coins than the gold twenty-dollar piece, or eagle, of the United States, and a comparatively small number of these are in actual circulation.

In obedience to the pressing demand for additional public schools in the Eighteenth, Twenty-first, Twenty-third, and Twenty-fifth Wards of Brooklyn the Pastors of the various churches within their boundaries have been devoting some of their Sunday evening services to the consideration of educational subjects.
A sensation was created on the streets last night by a large and brilliant meteor, which shot from the southeast and seemed to burst over Richardson street, near Plain.

There was a tremendous row at the drawing room between a lady well known in society and one of the Lord Chamberlain's officials, the individual whose stern and uncompromising demeanor has earned him the name of Cerbeus.

The annual Spring regatta of the Yorkville Yacht Club was held yesterday. There were 13 entries, as follows: Under 16 feet, catrigged yachts--Mabel, Benzine, Harry C.; over 16 and under 19 feet, cat-rigged yachts--Lily L., Mollie McCarty, Sadie; jib and mainsail yachts, 16 to 19 feet--Imogene, White Wings, Little Dean, Hoodoo; cabin sloops, 20 to 25 feet-- Ethel, Minnie D., and Rappahanoc.

OMAHA, Neb., May 29.--A tragedy occurred last night at Loup City, a lively little town 100 miles west of Omaha, in which O.B. Willard, editor of the Sherman County Times, was shot and instantly killed by B.L. Richardson, editor of the Northwestern, a rival paper.

Baldwin, of Kingston, has renewed his periodical attempt to prove that Farragut was not "lashed in the rigging" of the Hartford at the Mobile Bay fight it may be well to call attention to the fact that the question is one which has Mr. Baldwin on one side and on the other side Admiral Farragut, Fleet Captain Drayton, Flag Lieutenant (now Captain) Crittenden ...
The relatives and friends of Ben: Perley Poore left Washington with the remains of the dead journalist at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon for New buryport, Mass., where the interment will take place.

It is announeed that the Indian Government is actively taking up the cause of the decaying silk industry.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29.--Bishop William Bacon Stevens, D.D., LL. D., of the Diocese of Pennsylvania, Protestant Episcopal Church, who has been seriously ill for some time, was reported to-night to be resting somewhat easier, but his death is looked for at any time.

BALTIMORE, May 29.--Edwin Blackburn, who has been Treasurer of the Lombard-street Friends for four years, has been displaced for shortage in his accounts. The amount involved is about $6,000. Mr. Blackburn came to Baltimore from Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, May 29.--The practice prevailing in Morocco of using the name and authority of the United States and the privileges conferred upon American citizens by our treaty arrangements with the Barbary powers for the purpose of extorting usury and inflicting cruel hardships upon debtors unable or unwilling to pay the exorbitant demands has been described in THE TIMES.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 29.--The management of the Indianapolis Club, in common with nearly all the other League clubs, is making strenuous efforts to secure pitchers. Indications point strongly to but a single year's life for the Indianapolis nine as a League club, and the...

CHICAGO, May 29.--Senator John Sherman arrived here this evening from Washington on his way to Springfield, where he has been invited to deliver an address on general political topics before the General Assembly, on June 1. Senator Sherman was accompanied only by his private secretary, L.P. Babcock.

The Legislature left Gov. Hill a legacy of 338 bills to consider after adjournment. Bills not receiving his signature by June 25, the constitutional limit of 30 days then expiring, will fail to become laws. A list of bills affecting New-York and Kings Counties and of special interest to this city and the sections immediately outlying is given herewith:
CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 29.--Smith's effective pitching, backed by brilliant and errorless fielding, broke the run of bad luck to-day and enabled Cincinnati to defeat the Baltimores easily.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29.--The March statement of the Reading Railroad and Coal and Iron Companies astonished the financial world on account of the enormous net increase of earnings, but the April statement exceeds it by $169,246.

MONTREAL May 29.--G.A. Burzon, the Belgian embezzler and fraudulent bankrupt who was sentenced at Brussels during his absence to five years' imprisonment, was committed yesterday for extradition. He had fled to Paris, and on hearing the result of the trial sailed to New York, and after staying a fortnight there came on to Montreal where he was arrested.

Boston, May 29.--A Science Observer code dispatch received to-day announces the discovery of an asteroid--No. 267--by Prof. Charlois, an assistant at the observatory of Nice. The following position was secured: May 27, 5 hours 57 minutes 5 seconds, Greenwich mean time, right ascension 17 hours 2 minutes 11 seconds, south declination 22 31' 43". The asteroid is of the thirteenth magnitude.

LONDON, May 29.--The American Indian Red Shirt visited the Savage Club on Saturday night in full war paint. There were also present Fly Above, Little Bull, Col. Cody, Mr. Burke, Broncho Bill, and Wilson Barrett. A pipe of peace was smoked.
Frank N. Robinson, a farmer from Greenville, N.J., met a couple of men on Hudson-street just before daybreak yesterday morning and asked them the way to Desbrosses-Street Ferry.
ATLANTA, Ga., May 29.--A peculiar suit for damages has been instituted under the Civil Rights bill against the Central Railroad.
The popularity of Jerome-avenue, as a driving road, increases with each week. Yesterday, according to the testimony of the Old Observer, more stranges crossed Macomb's Dam Bridge than ever before.
PARIS, May 29.--A noisome smell arises from the ruins of the Opera Comique, interfering with the work of searching for bodies, although deodorizing fluids are thrown upon the ruins from hydrants.

CHICAGO, May 29.--Modjeska finished her engagement of one month at the Chicago Opera House last evening and has gone to St. Paul and Minneapolis, where she will finish her season. Her business here was fairly good, but it was apparent a fortnight ago that the engagement would be too long.

William Vanderveer, the proprietor of Vanderveer's Hotel, said yesterday that the rumor about his son Abram having been drugged and thrown from a train near the village of Marshfield, Ind., was not true.

BALTIMORE, May 29.--For the First time in the history of Maryland a Grand Army post attended services in a Catholic chrurch to-day in uniform. It was Burnside Post, with its drum corps, and the Howard Zouaves, all in uniform, but without music. The veterans were escorted by the Knights of St. Aloysius. The services consisted of a mass and an address by the priest, Father Jordan.
The Russian Bankruptcy Court here continues to be blocked by the insolvency cases of a number of old-established and hitherto flourishing concerns.

The British Suez Canal Directors, in forwarding to Lord Salisbury their returns of shipping using the canal during the year 1886, observe that there was a considerable falling off, both in vessels and tonnage, for last year as compared with 1885, and, consequently, in the transit receipts.
At Arctic Park, Brooklyn, yesterday the Acmes proved altogether too strong for the Macans --score 27 to 11.

CHICAGO, May 29.--The thin end of the wedge which was inserted when the Rev. Arthur Ritchie first introduced the practice of singing the "Kyrie Eleison" in Greek at the Church of the Ascension was driven in further to-day.
Rain and sunshine in about equal portions seasoned sunday for the forty-odd canoeists at the meet of the Hudson River canoeists in camp at Croton Point, off Sing Sing.

CARCASSONNE, France, May 14.--So much has lately been spoken and written about Russia's vast warlike preparations by land and sea that it may be worth while to pause here for a moment in the present series of letters from France to state briefly the real facts, which are masked by these imposing demonstrations.

OZARK, Mo., May 29.--The Bald Knobbers who took a change of venue from Ozark to Porter Township on account of the alleged prejudice against the Regulators here, found none of the hoped-for mercy in Squire West's Court.
The latest "lions" of Paris are nine negro chiefs with unpronounceable names. They have been brought from the African coast by an enterprising contractor.
DUBLIN, May 29.--Father Keller, who was recently released from prison, was presented with an address at Youghal to-day by the local branch of the National League.

The relations of Mayor Hewitt with the members of the elecric light "combine" in the Board of Aldermen have become much strained. The Mayor has become certain that he has been deceived by the Tammany Hall and County Democracy leaders, who promised him that the Aldermen belonging to either faction would leave the "combine" and support the honest Aldermen, as led by President Beekman.

The eighteenth regatta of the Harlem Regatta Association to-day promises to be the most successful one ever held by the association. There have been more entries and more enthusiasm has been shown than in any previous year.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 29.--A secret convention of knights of Labor was held here this afternoon, at which a small majority voted in favor of organizing a separate political party, after the style of their brethren in Cincinnati.

ALTOONA, Penn., May 29.--The wounded persons of the fast line wreck are doing well, and several will resume their journey to-morrow. Miss Luckett, of Alexandria, Va., is the only one in a serious condition.

It has been determined to establish a fresh-water communication between the rivers Duna and Dnieper. Riga, on the Baltic, will thus be united with Krementschug, on the Dnieper, one of the principal military centres of the south. The distance between Riga and Krementschug will be about 700 English miles.

The Central Labor Union at its meeting yesterday adopted a resolution stating that, whereas the United states Consul at Ottawa had refused the use of the consulate to those people who were receiving Editor O'Brien, the Central Labor Union denounced the Consul's flunkyism, and resented the insuit offered to Mr. O'Brien.

A meeting of the Anti-Poverty Society was held last night in the Academy of Music. Every seat in the house, the stage, and nearly all the standing room were filled before 8 o'clock, and hundreds of people were turned away.

WASHINGTON, May 29.--The important service rendered by the reports required by law to be furnished to the Supervising Surgeon-General of the Marine Hospital, in regard to the health of foreign countries and the prevalence of infectious diseases there, has suggested the extension and concentration of sanitary statistics of the United States.
One of the Conservative papers in Paris has compiled some interesting tables showing the rate at which Ministries are used up in France.

The people of New-Hampshire know more about fire insurance than they did two years ago, when the enactment of a so-called "valued policy" law caused 58 powerful companies to withdraw from the State, but it is not probable that this law will be repealed by the legislators who are to meet this week in biennial session.

Detective-Sergeant Liston drove up to Police Headquarters last night in a coach with a man, woman, and baby who were immediately taken into the detective office. They had evidently arrived on a European steamer, and had considerable baggage. Who they were was not made known last night.

The Rev. Arthur J. Donnelly, Rector of St. Michael's Church, at Ninth-avenue and Thirty-first-street, has been appointed by Archbishop Corrigan Vicar-General to succeed the late Mgr. Quinn. Father Donnelly received the news late Saturday afternoon, not through letter but by a personal call from the Archbishop.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 29.--Lydia A. Williams, an unmarried woman, 75 years old, was last night burned to death in the attic of a house at Auburn. It is supposed that she started the fire by accidentally overturning a lighted lamp.

Yesterday afternoon the schooner was towed into NewYork Harbor by the steamer. The Richmond, bearing the flag of Rear-Admiral Luce,...

CONCORD, N.H., May 29.--The biennial session of the Legislature will begin on Wednesday. After organizing, both branches will meet in joint convention to ballot for Governor and to fill vacancies in Senatorial and Councilor districts in which no choice was made at the last election.
The town of Eperies has been on fire all day, a hundred houses, according to latest accounts, being reduced to ashes.

Prof. Francesco Fanciulli and his pupils will give a concert in Nilsson Hall this evening. St. Cecile Lodge, No. 568, F. and A. M., will confer the third degree to-morrow at 1:30 P.M., in Tuscan Room, Masonic Temple.

Flames were discovered soon after 1 o'clock yesterday morning in one corner of the bunk house, at Shaft No. 2, of the new Croton Aqueduct, in the town of New-Castle. Not long ago the attention of our readers was called to a series of volumes containing "The Ante-Nicene Fathers," published by the Christian Literature Company. The series was edited by Bishop A.C. Coxe, the theologian as well as poet, and was completed in eight large octavo volumes.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 29.--For the last week a rough wooden box about 60 feet long has been lying back of the Harvard boathouse, and the students have been wondering where it came from and what came in it.
Mr. James Grant's tales were of a class all but obsolete. He was a military novelist. We have ceased to be, as we were till 1815, a military, and we have become a manufacturing people.

GLASGOW, May 29.--Forty bodies have been recovered from the Udston coal pit at Blantyre. Many of the corpses are unrecognizable, limbs having been blown of and the bodies being horribly charred. Queen Victoria has sent a dispatch expressing sympathy with the families of the dead miners. Distressing scenes were witnessed at the pit as the bodies were brought up. There is no hope that the others in the mine can be saved.

It was announced last night on apparently good authority that Mayor Hewitt would appoint Henry R. Beekman, now President of the Board of Aldermen, to succeed E. Henry Lacombe as Corporation Counsel when the latter shall have taken his seat on the United States Circuit Court bench.

CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, May 29.-- The report published in American papers of a plot of the Church Party leaders to bring Don Carlos here to head a movement against the Government has attracted much attention among politicians here, although little has been heard of the matter.

CHICAGO, May 29.--The coming week is likely to be the critical period of the big lock-out and strike. Fully 17,000 men are idle, and it is believed that 1,000 first-class mechanics have left the city and found work elsewhere.
As I stood outside the Athenaeum the other day I saw a Bishop--a humble suffragan-- drive up in a hansom and bid the (unpaid) cabman wait while he went into the club.

PARIS, May 17.--Although the Chambers did give priority to the bill on sugar over the Military Reform bill which has been before the National Legislature in various shapes for 16 years, they did not hesitate to vote almost without debate the appropriation of 4,945,500f. asked for that experiment of mobilization which is to be the great feature of next Autumn's grand manoeuvres.

It was 2 o'clock yesterday morning when the Brooklyn firemen had the flames which were blazing in L.M. Palmer's cooperage warehouse, in the Eastern District, under control, yet at 6 o'clock last night many engines were at work in the same district.
Robert Owens, a young man who had been employed at the store of Bebus, the Broadway florist, went to visit his father, at 454 secondavenue, yesterday afternoon.

The Day of Pentecost, or Feast of Weeks, was celebrated yesterday in the Jewish synagogues of this city. It was called Pentecost, because it occurred 50 days after the Passover, or the Feast of Weeks, inasmuch as seven weeks marked its separation from that greatest of feasts, the Passover, seven being the sacred number among the Jews.

CITY OF MEXICO, Via Galveston, May 29. --A heavy earthquake shock was felt in this city and throughout the valley at 2:50 o'clock this morning. Saturday afternoon had been extremely warm; in fact, the weather for the last four days had been extraordinarily warm for this region, which generally enjoys a very mild degree of temperature even in Summer.

Some 200 journalists were present yesterday at the Folies Bergere, where a sort of general rehearsal was given of a seance of magnetism which took place in a cage containing two fine lionesses, Saida and Sarah, and an immense lion, Romulus. The cage was placed on the stage, and the lion tamer, Giacometti, having...
CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 29.--The Grant memorial meeting to-night in Music Hall was attended by about 4,000 people.

PROSPECT HOUSE, UPPER SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., May 29.--There was no luck for the President on his first fishing venture of the season, but it was easily accounted for. The wind was easterly and the President said on Saturday night, as he sat by a bright wood fire in his comfortable little cottage, that he was not out for fish, but just to sail about and get acquainted with the ground.
The Rev. Dr. Wilbur F. Watkins closed his connection as Pastor of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity yesterday.
CHICAGO, May 29.--The Following crop summary will appear in this week's issue of the Farmers' Review:

All preparations for to-day's exercises in this city have been completed and they are on a scale unusually worthy of the occasion. The great procession will form on the streets crossing Fifth-avenue above Forty-second-street, the right of each line resting on the avenue.

RONDOUT, N.Y., May 30.--The Grand View Mountain House at East Windham was burned to the ground this morning. Its situation in the northern extremity of the Catskill range made it a notable house in its day.
In years gone by the New-York ball players have bettered their condition in the race for championship honors by defeating the famous White Stocking Club of Chicago.
Many ladies were among the audience which gathered last night in Miner's Newark Theatre to hear Father McGlynn deliver his lecture, "The Cross of the New Crusade."

NEW-HAVEN, May 30.--Railroad circles in this city were very much excited to-day by a letter which President Clark, of the Consolidated Road, sent to Mayor York, in which he stated that it was necessary for his company to get control of the Derby Road, which is the only one now running into this city not controlled by the Consolidated.
Jerome Park never had a greater crowd in its inclosure than it did yesterday. The grand stand was packed with a mass of humanity who perspired, trod on one another's toes, fought ...
OTTAWA, Ontario, May 30.--The PostmasterGeneral will endeavor to make arrangements, after the House prorogues, for the establishment of a parcel post system with the United States.

UPPER SANDUSKY, Ohio, May 30.--A cyclone passed over this place between 5 and 6 o'clock this afternoon, doing great damage to trees, fences, The spire of the Catholic church, 200 feet high, was blown over and the front of the church wrecked.
LEXINGTON, Ky., May 30.--Eugene Fogle, who killed Police Captain L.V. O'Connor last September, was acquitted this afternoon by a jury in the Circuit Court.
The Athletic Association of Queens, Long Island, held its races and games yesterday. Most of the events were well contested by the amateurs.
I have just received an interesting statement concerning the construction of the Central Asian Railway.

ROME, May 30.--The Asservatore Romano interprets the Pope's utterance in his allocution as meaning that no reconciliation is possible between the Vatican and Quirinal without restitution of the Pope's temporal power.
The German American Schuetzen Society held its May Festival and celebrated Pfingst Monday in Louis Wendel's Lion Park yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, May 30.--The troubles of the National Opera Company were again brought to public attention this evening by a strike of the stage hands just as the curtain was to go up on "The Flying Dutchman."

There was a breeze and a quarrel at the last meeting of Assembly No. 49 Sunday evening and the delegates called each other unkind names. Complaints have been made from time to time by various local assemblies connected with No. 49 that the officers of the District Assembly had not made any report on the management of its finances for a very long time.

KEY WEST, Fla., May 30.--Three Spanish fishing smacks, the Maria Dolores, Enriqueta, and Habanero, arrived here to-day. Their Captains say they came in for provisions, but Collector Harris, believing that they were attempting to pass through the Northwest Channel to fish in the bay, and finding that they had no proper clearance papers, has detained them and will hold them under surveillance.
Coney Island was loaded--and so were hundreds of the people who returned from there last night--with about all the surplus of the New-York Decoration Day patriotism.

When Mr. CHAUNCEY M. DEPEW became the visible vicegerent of the Vanderbilt interest it was fondly hoped by those suburban residents and tourists whom that interest had so long fatigued and discouraged that a change would come over the administration of the Vanderbilt roads.

Thousands of people visited the scene of the Belt line stable fire yesterday. The crowd was especially large in the afternoon, when the large block which the building occupied, but which now could be converted into one of the proposed small parks without great difficulty, was almost encircled by spectators.

CINCINNATI, May 30.--The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway officers announce this evening that they have made freight rates from East St. Louis to the Atlantic seaboard the same as are now made by the trunk lines from Chicago to Boston, New-York, and Philadelphia. The Kanawha Dispatch Fast Freight line will carry this new arrangement into effect at once.
The decomposed remains of a man apparently about 45 years old, were found in the North River yesterday, opposite Pier 19.

RED BANK, N.J., May 30.--A canoe race took place on the river to-day between members of the North Shrewsbury Canoe Club. There were 25 entries, and 14 of the canoes finished the course, which was triangular, and started from a stake off of the Monmouth Boat Club House.

The cornerstone of a new hospital was laid in Long Island City yesterday afternoon by Frank R. Lawrence, Masonic Grand Master of this city, assisted by the grand officers and members of the several local Masonic lodges. There was a large attendance.

WASHINGTON, May 30.--The services at the tomb of Gen. Logan, in Rock Creek Cemetery, were picturesque and interesting. Such profusion of floral tributes as decorated the last resting place of the dead General has rarely been seen.
TRENTON, N.J., May 30.--A.W. Conklin, representing himself as general agent of the Equitable Life Insurance Company of New-York, was arrested here to-night on the charge of swindling.
The Knights of Temperance, a body of young men whose objects are to cultivate and practice the principles of sobriety, purity, and ...

HUNTINGTON, West Va., May 30.--This morning the boiler on the elevator at the foot of Twentieth-street exploded, killing T.H. Reece, aged 45 years, married; John Kelly, single, and W.K. Albertson, ...

PHILADELPHIA, May 30.--The General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church of North America continued its session to-day. Resolutions were submitted approving the work of the Board of Education for the year; recomending that $5,000 appropriated for the present year; and that the board be directed to continue ...
The mysterious prisoner locked up in Police Headquarters Sunday night turned out to be Charles P. Johnson, a contractor of Sanford, Fla.

In all its history the old Macomb's Dam Bride has never trembled under so many vehicles as invaded it yesterday between noon and 2 o'clock. The necessity of a better bridge to connect New-York's favorite driveways than the present narrow wooden structure was sharply demonstrated.

PANAMA, May 30.--The contractors for the sale of Peruvian guano in the United States have been ordered to pay into the Treasury of Peru $17,850 American gold, which the Treasury officers declare has not been received.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 30.--The whereabouts of William Kissane have been definitely learned. He is not secluded in Victoria, but remains at his ranch near Sonoma.
The steamship Elcano, which arrived yesterday at the Empire Stores, Brooklyn, from Porto Rico, brought nine of Japan's gorgeously attired inhabitants to these hospitable shores.

ST. LOUIS, May 30.--Gen. Powell Clayton, of Arkansas, who was recommended by the National Committee for Chairman of the Republican Convention of 1884, arrived in the city this evening, and, speaking of the national problem of next year, said: "Cleveland will be renominated to a certainty.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 30.--The steamer City of New-York arrived to-day with mail intelligence from Hong-Kong down to May 5 and from Yokohama to May 13.
In one of Boston's prominent dry goods establishments yesterday, while a lady was making some purchases, her attention was called to a colloquy between a prospective purchaser and a salesman.

As was stated in our dispatches yesterday morning, the Knights of Labor have succeeded in enforcing the demands to sustain which they have been carrying on an extensive "boycott" against the members of the Philadelphia Clothing Exchange.
PADUCAH, Ky., May 30.--While the funeral procession of the late Dr. W.W. Wilson, a well known New-Orleans plysician, who was buried here yesterday, was on the way to Mount Kenton ...

NEWPORT, R.I., May 30.--To-day's memorial exercises were of a very significant character. The army and navy were represented by the troops from Fort Adams and by the marines and naval apprentices from all the vessels of the naval training squadrons.

The Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club's fleet got under way from the anchorage at Staten Island at 11 o'clock yesterday morning, the smaller vessels starting first and the larger ones following. The Priscilla waited until the last.

The members of the Brooklyn Yacht Club enjoyed their annual Decoration Day sail yesterday. A few "luffing matches" were indulged in on Graves end Bay, and the day's sport ended with a collation at the clubhouse.
The annual three days' tournament of the Washington Rifles, an association of the German sharpshooter societies of New-Jersey, was opened yesterday at Schuetzen Park, Union Hill.
Although yesterday was so generally devoted to commemorating the men who died for the Union, there was at least one attempt to honor the memory of brave women.

John Hughes, the "Lepper," has a saloon at 1,724 Third-avenue. His bartender was arrested Sunday for violating the excise law, and Hughes, deciding that if he could not do business his neighbors should not, accused one named McMahon of ...

PHILADELPHIA, May 30.--The Irish emigrants who were detained on board the steamship Scandinavian yesterday were giving a hearing to-day. Nearly all of the adults told their story, which was to the effect that there is great destitution in Westport ...
It must be the universal testimony that no day was ever better suited to its purpose than yesterday. Every condition favored a fitting celebration of the day.

The German Minister of Education has distinguished himself. This great and generous man, in consideration of the services which female teachers at public schools have rendered the State after 30 or 50 years' labors, proposes that to each of these teachers on her retirement a special reward should be given, if she has pursued her career with honors.

HARWICH, May 30.--The old town of Harwich and its harbor looked gay this morning in honor of the hundreds of yachtsmen assembled to participate in the annual regatta and supplementary ocean race to Southend.

The Governor's judgment on the Vedder bill to tax the sale of liquors in this State is that it was "conceived in political expediency, born of political hypocrisy, and has had its growth in rank injustice and in the utter violation of every correct principle of taxation."

WASHINGTON, May 30.--The culmination of the national drill was reached and passed at 3 o'clock this afternoon. The troops--about 2,000 in number--were drawn up in five lines, their centre facing a stand erected in the middle of the broad drill inclosure, upon which Lieut.-Gen. Sheridan and a brilliantly uniformed staff had taken their places.
To-day's races at Brighton Beach were run with the following results:

Mrs. Cignarale, the Italian woman who was convicted last Friday of murdering her husband, has since been at the Tombs in an extremely excited condition. She has cried and raved in Italian the greater part of the time.

For some time goods have been stolen almost nightly from Pier 32 East River. Last night a policeman saw Arthur Champion and Edwin McSweeney leaving the pier with 18 pairs of women's shoes taken from a case standing there. He arrested them.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 30.--In two respects Memorial Day was different from any of its predecessors. All public buildings and many private establishments gave a half holiday, in order that their employes might attend the services at Chalmette. For the first time the Committee of Arrangements went outside the ranks of the Grand Army of the Republic to find an orator for the day.

NOGALES, Arizona, May 30.--Last evening a terrific dry cyclone visited this place. It came from the mountains on the east side of the town and demolished a great many Mexican huts and unroofed several other more substantial buildings. No one was injured.
The mysterious disappearance of Magdalena Zorn, daughter of Winand Zorn, who lives at 401 East One Hundred and Twenty-second-street, was reported to the police yesterday.

RONDOUT, N.Y., May 30.--The coal heavers and other dock employes of the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company in the territory known as the Rondout department, notified the company's Superintendent this afternoon that unless their wages were raised on Thursday they would strike.
CHICAGO, May 30.--Hooley's Theatre looked this evening as though Mr. Hooley were giving a reception in honor of some visiting friends and had issued more cards than he should have done.

About 5,000 persons witnessed the games of the Scottish-American Club in Jersey City yesterday. The games were poor. T.E. English won the 100 yards' run in 0:09 4-5. William Freeth won the one-mile run in 4:58. George Logan won the mile walk in 7:33; C. McCarthy the half-mile run in 2:09; E.W. Hepper the 440 yards' run in 0:55 1-5, and T.A. McAnally the three-mile run in 16:20.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30.--The June circular of the line and city prices of the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company is based upon the new regulation which makes a uniform rate of lateral tolls of 30 cents and compels the consignee to pay these from the mines, instead of from shipping points as heretofore.

A young girl, probably 16 years of age, entered the Twenty-first Precinct Police Station Sunday evening and asked to be provided with a place of shelter. She left almost immediately, however, without giving any information about herself except that her name was Annie O'Neil.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 30.--Five thousand people gathered on the bluff this evening to hear a number of gentlemen denounce the Irish Coercion bill.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 30.--At the Goshen meeting to-day Violin won the three-minute class race in straight heats in 2:38, 2:40, and 2:36 , Kentucky Blanche second, Frank H. third, Longford fourth.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30.--Dr. John G. Dorrence, of Nyack-on-the-Hudson, has been missing from this city since Wednesday. He is the patentee of a new style tricycle and came to Philadelphia on Saturday, May 21, to look after business relating to his invention.

The final oratorical contest of the year by the senior students of Manhattan College, for the Byrnes gold medal, was held yesterday afternoon at Manhattan High School, Fifty-ninthstreet, near Sixth-avenue.
A number of well known real estate lawyers have organized a title insurance company, with a capital stock of $500,000, and have opened an office in the new Equitable Building.

With a light breeze from the westward and the young flood tide, 85 yachts started from Port Morris yesterday morning, in the Spring Regatta of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club. A prettier marine spectacle has seldom been seen than this fleet of white-winged racers presented, ...

LONDON, May 30.--The Marquis of Lansdowne, replying to an address from 500 of his Wiltshire tenants, says he has no fear that the attacks made upon him will prejudice his position in Canada, and expresses the hope that the differences, which exist on only a small portion of his Irish estates, will not prove permanent.
A tournament of progressive tennis was held yesterday afternoon on the grounds of the Franklin Lawn Tennis Club at Nutby, N.J., it being the opening day of the club for the season.

The champions of the American Association made their first appearance of the season at Washington Park, in Brooklyn, yesterday and characterized the event by winning a ten-inning contest from the Brooklyn team.
The Bay never presented a more interesting scene than it did yesterday. Two of the crack yacht clubs formally opened the yachting season with their customary Decoration Day sails.
The members of the Gaelic Society and about 5,000 other citizens gathered around the statue of Tom Moore in the Central Park yesterday afternoon, and handsomely and profusely decorated it.

NOGALES, Arizona, May 30.--There was quite a severe shock of earthquake here at about 1 o'clock this afternoon, which created much excitement, although no damage was done. Ten minutes afterward there was another shock, but it was a very light one.
CINCINNATI, May 30.--A rain in the morning made the track very heavy to-day, and racing was almost dangerous. The seven races were run, however, with the following results:
Mrs. Robert Woodrow, wife of the overseer of the late William H. Vanderbilt's farm at New-Dorp, Staten Island, met death early yesterday morning in a horrible manner.
The sharp report of a pistol attracted the attention of John Pope, who keeps a grocery in the basement of 90 King-street, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, and he went up stairs to discover its cause.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 30.--California's popular bathing resort, Santa Cruz, 80 miles down the coast, met with a serious loss this afternoon in the destruction by fire of the Swanton and Santa Cruz Houses, two of the largest hotels in the place. Loss, $50,000; partly insured.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 30.--It is now 12 days since James P. McCabe, the condemned murderer of Michael Reilly, who was to have been hanged on the 26th inst., escaped from the ...

The boats running to Bowery Bay Beach were crowded yesterday. At least 15,000 persons enjoyed their holiday there. The great event of the day was the boat race between Wallace Ross and George Hosmer for $1,500.

The open lawn tennis tournament of the Marine and Field Club at Bath Beach yesterday was attended by large numbers of the best known people of Brooklyn. After the games a reception and ball was given in the clubrooms. The band of the Twenty-third Regiment was in attendance all day. The result of the tournament is as follows:

FORT WAYNE, Ind., May 30.--Miss Sarah Jane Gunther, of Warsaw, Ind., was arrested on Saturday for throwing into the St. Joseph River and drowning her 4-weeks-old child. She confessed the crime, and stated that the child was born at the county infirmary. She is now locked up.

Seven hundred wheelmen with their bicycles met at Orange, N.J., yesterday at the third semi-annual road race of the New York and New-Jersey Team Road Racing Association. Fifteen association clubs were represented, and there were visitors from Philadelphia, Baltimore, Albany, Troy, Paterson, and other cities.

NEWBURYPORT, May 30.--The remains of the late Major Ben: Perley Poore arrived this afternoon and were escorted by a delegation of Newburyport Commandery, Knights Templar, to Indian Hall Farm, where the funeral will occur Wednesday at 2:30 P.M.
Three hundred persons were present at the combination shoot of the Fountain and Coney Island Rod and Gun Clubs at Woodlawn yesterday.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 30.--The boiler in the Hitchcock Manufacturing Works at Cortland exploded this morning, demolishing the engine room and part of the blacksmith's shop. Clifford Fuller was taken out of the ruins dangerously injured, and Frank Scott was found with his head crushed and cannot live. A man named H.A. Webster was taken from the ruins dead. He was one of the firemen. Bricks and large pieces of iron were thrown 300 feet.

PLYMOUTH, N.H., May 30.--The annual meeting of the Boston, Concord and Montreal Railroad Company was held here to-day. The following were elected Directors, receiving all the votes cast: Edward H. Rollins, of Concord; Harry Bingham, of Littleton; Nathan H. Weeks, ...

The firing of cannon and beating of drums awakened the inhabitants of Sing Sing early yesterday morning, and Grand Army posts, fire companies, and drum and fife corps were marching through the streets all day.
The ground at St. George, Staten Island, was well patronized by the lovers of lacrosse yesterday, when the ex-champions of the United States, the New-York Club, and Harvard University crossed sticks.

The Hudson River canoeists brought their meet to a close yesterday afternoon at Croton Point, off Sing Sing, with a series of sailing and paddling races. The first race was for class A, one and a half miles, sailing.

The five children of Leopold Harris, a tailor, living at 185 Havemeyer-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, are suffering from the effects of poison, which it is supposed was taken in some cheese of which they ate freely on Saturday night.
Steamship Yoxford, (Br.,) Crosby, Elba, Sorrento, Palermoa, and Gilbraltar, with fruit, , to Lawrence, Giles Co.
PARIS, May 30.--The funeral services over the bodies of victims recovered from the ruins of the Opera Comique were held to-day in the Cathedral of Notre Dame.

Count Numa J. Lepkowski died on Sunday at the Presbyterian Hospital of Bright's disease. He was 82 years old, the last of a noble family, and the last known survivor of the Poles who sought refuge in the United States after the revolution of 1830.

PLYMOUTH, Mass., May 30.--The annual meeting of the Pilgrims' Society was held at Pilgrim Hall to-day, William H. Whitman in the chair. Resolutions of respect to the memory of Judge Thomas Russell, the late President of the society, were adopted.
The Harlem water was alive yesterday. Over its turgid depths floated every kind of craft in the world that is propelled by oars. There were whitehalls, canoes, kayaks, skiffs, and mud ...
PHILADELPHIA, May 30.--The sessions of the Reformed Episcopal Council were continued to-day. Considerable discussion ensued upon a report of the Committee on Aggressive Church Work.

Gov. Hill did not appear to be the least bit fatigued when he left the reviewing stand after the procession had passed yesterday. He went to his rooms in the Hoffman House and received such visitors as had thought it worth their while to call on him.
There were 15,175 people who paid to witness the afternoon game. As soon as the grounds were cleared after the morning contest crowds formed in front of the ticket offices and clamored for admission.

BUFFALO, May 30.--"Anarchy" was produced to-night in the Academy of Music before an audience that had a familiar appearance to a New-York "first nighter," with Judge Brady and Larry Jerome and Tom ...
LONDON, May 30.--Steamship De Ruyter, (Belg.,) Brarons, from New-York May 15 for Antwern, passed the Lizard to-day.
PARIS, May 30.--It is reported that President Grevy, in order to avoid the certain defeat of the new Ministry on any important issue, will close the session of the Chamber of Deputies on June 15.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 30.--While the persons having the arrangements for the visit of Senator John Sherman in charge do not expect an extraordinary crowd in the city on Wednesday, they are confident that it will be composed ...

BOSTON, May 30.--The dinner given this evening to Mr. William O'Brien, the distinguished Irish editor, was one of the most notable meetings in favor of the Irish Nationalist cause ever held in Boston.

SAVANNAH, Ga., May 30.--Fire broke out at 10 o'clock to-night in David Weilbin's retail dry goods house, on Broughton-street, the principal retail business street of the city. A lack of water put the firemen at a disadvantage, and in 15 minutes the fire was beyond control.

The appointment of Gilbert O.F. Nicoll as Deputy Surveyor was yesterday received by Surveyor Beattie from Secretary Fairchild. The new Custom House officer is 46 years old, a native of Newburg and a resident of this city for more than 25 years and a steadfast Democrat. He first entered the Government service as Secretary to the Surveyor in September, 1885, and has been appointed on Mr. Beattie's recommendation.
NEWPORT, R.I., May 30.--Calvin S. Brice, the railroad financier of New-York, has decided to spend the Summer here, and has rented Stone Villa, owned by James Gordon Bennett.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 30.--Memorial Day was more generally observed here to-day than in any previous year. The 900 soldiers' graves in the city cemeteries were decorated with flowers in the forenoon by Grand Army posts.
HAMILTON, May 30.--A lovelier bit of country than the fruit producing belt of Ontario at this season of the year is not to be found in the Dominion, nor perhaps elsewhere.
CORSICANA, Texas, May 30.--A.G. Hill, a book agent representing a Cincinnati firm, called at the home of Mr. Terri, about 15 miles east of this place, Saturday.

All preparations for the annual parade of the police force, which is to take place to-day, have been completed and the display promises to be the finest ever made by the department. There will be about 2,200 men in line, divided ...

LAWRENCE, Mass., May 30.--Pretty Tillie Coates, the young woman who eloped with Robert Brendle from the home of her stepfather at Valley Forge, Penn., was taken back to her mother this afternoon by John L. Hoy, the wealthy hotel keeper who stands in the place of Tillie's father.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 30.--The three mile race for $500 a side between James A. Ten Eyck, of Worcester, and Joseph Laing, of Montreal, was rowed over the old college ...

WASHINGTON, May 30.--The Commissioner of Internal Revenue will to-morrow issue notice to 21 Collectors, whose territorial limits have been changed by the pending order of consolidation, to file new bonds to meet their changed responsibilities.
LINCOLN, Neb., May 30.--Constable Jacoby was at Mrs. Glenan's house last night to notify her to appear in court to-day. A short time afterward Glenan came in and a row ensued.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, May 30.--John, Jacob, and Nicholas Johnston, three brothers, of Put-in-Bay Island, were all drowned near that place to-day. They were fishermen and were in a small boat in tow of the steamer Ferris. The rudder of the boat came out, the craft capsized, and the men were drowned. John Johnston leaves one child. The others were single.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington Territory, May 30.--The steamer Acon, which arrived yesterday from Alaska, reports that a miner had arrived from the Yukon country who stated that the Indians and miners had engaged in a fight in the interior in which one white man was killed and five wounded, and five Indians were killed and several wounded.

Gen. BENJAMIN F. BUTLER has said and done many things to outrage the public sentiment during his long and somewhat turbulent career as lawyer, soldier, and politician, but he has seldom, if ever, shown ...

Augustus and Townsend Johnson, two brothers, confessed yesterday that they were the men who set fire to Palmer's cooperage in Brooklyn, Eastern District, late on Saturday night, and caused a loss of $350,000 and probably the death of the watchman Deary.
Mr. Richard Mansfield came forward at the Madison-Square Theatre last evening in his popular impersonation of the chief role in A.C. Gunter's comedy, "Prince Karl."
Decoration Dap made busy times for the elevated railroad gatemen and guards and the policemen who preside in state at the entrance to the Brooklyn Bridge.
ELIZABETH, N.J., May 30.--The Alcyone Boat Club, of Elizabethport, held its Spring regatta this afternoon, there being five events over a mile course and a tub race.
SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., May 30.--Fortune favored the President to-day, for his fishing excursions were fruitful of fish as well as great incidental refreshment by the superb mountain air.
VIENNA, May 30.--A postal clerk named Zalevski has absconded with registered letters containing bank notes to the amount of $75,000.

CITY OF MEXICO, Via Galveston, May 30.--Up to 10 o'clock this morning no second shock of earthquake had been experienced, and this is fortunate, as some high and modern buildings constructed of light, porous stone, unfit for lofty buildings, are badly cracked, and might easily fall under additional strain.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30.--There was a sound like that of several cannon last evening a little before 6 o'clock, and simultaneously all the heavy iron coverings over the manholes of the sewer on Chestnut-street, from Seventh to Ninth, shot upward with tremendous force.

PANAMA, May 22.--A letter from Cucuta, Santander, Colombia, dated April 14, says: "On the 6th I sent you a telegraph message containing important information. I told you how successful inoculation is proving here for yellow fever. About 10 per cent. of the inoculated patients are attacked by the discase, but none of them dies. The heat is intense, and ranges between 34 and 38 centigrade."

LIMA, May 30, via Galveston.--Don Carlos de Bourbon, traveling incognito under the title of Count de Breu, has arrived here. After a sojourn of 15 days in Peru he will go to Bolivia, and thence to Chili, the Argentine Republic, and Brazil.
The British Government is again trying to unload upon the people of this country destitute and pauperized persons whom it is unwilling to support.
Confirmation exercises for pupils in the Hebrew free schools were held at the Temple Rudolph Scholom yesterday morning. There was a large attendance.

The second annual games of the Brooklyn Athletic Association yesterday were remarkable for the fact that Page, of the University of Pennsylvania, made the best high jump American record, and nearly tied Davin's, the Irish champion, who holds the world's record as 6 feet 2 inches. The results of the games were as follows:

ALBANY, May 30.--The Governor has done exactly what he was expected to do--he has killed the precious darling, the Vedder Whisky Tax bill, which was intended to be a platform on which Boss Platt could muster his forces.

CHICAGO, May 30.--The Board of Trade and the Produce Exchange were closed to-day in recognition of Decoration Day and the attendance on the curb was so light as to be the subject of comment by the few that were present. Trading was said to be limited to a sale of June Wheat at 88 cents and July was 85 5/8 to 85 cents.

The yacht race sailed yesterday under the auspices of the Regatta Committee of the Larchmont Yacht Club proved to be a success, although the competing craft were obliged to wait two hours beyond the appointed starting time for the necessary breeze.
The by-laws of the Middletown, Unionville and Water Gap Railroad Company provided that the annual meeting for the election of officers shall be held on the last Monday in May.
CHICAGO, May 30.--Mr. Edward Hanlan, oarsman, discovered to-day that when a man is training for a match with as good a sculler as Jacob Gaudaur Bass's ale and sherry had better be left alone.

The New-York Maennerchor and the Central Turnverein celebrated Pfingst Montag at Washington Park, Sixty-ninth-street and the Boulevard. This turner society has been rapidly gaining in membership and is now a formidable rival of the New-York Turners.

"Gillette de Narbonne" will be given by Mr. Amberg's company at Terrace Garden tonight. To-morrow evening and every evening during the rest of the week Mme. Adolfine Zimaier will appear in "The Mascot."

The winners at the races of the Newark Yacht Club yesterday were: First class, Alexander, 1:41:21. Second class, Falcon, 1:40:22. Third class, Frank S, 1:50:21. Fourth class, Unexcelled, 1:56:19. Fifth class, Triton, 1:57:56.

A new complexity has arisen in the Sharp trial. The jurors decline to remain captured. When it is remembered that up to yesterday afternoon 1,100 citizens had been summoned, and 12 good men and true were still represented by only 11 possible jurors, it will be understood...

Although the clouds hung over the city yesterday with a big suggestion of rain in them and the zephyrs carried a reminiscense of Winter in their course, there was a goodly gathering of the members of the Driving Club of New-York at their park.

WASHINGTON, May 31.--The Inter-State Commerce Commission has a sufficient number of difficult problems to solve in relation to the long and short haul clause of the law without being called upon to pass upon any fifteenth amendment questions as falling within the limit of unjust discrimination provided for by the act.

CINCINNATI, May 31.--It has been reported on Third-street for two days that the control of the Vandalia Road, the important line from Indianapolis to St. Louis, has been secured by the Staynor-Ives syndicate, who own the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton, and have been...
ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 31.--The Sheldon House in Ocean Grove was sold this afternoon at public sale by Walter J. Knight, acting as a special master of the New-Jersey Court of Chancery.
CINCINNATI, May 31.--Racing was continued at Latonia to-day with the following result:
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 31.--The AttorneyGeneral filed an important railroad case in the Supreme Court to-day against Theophilus Brown and others, of Toledo, and Judge Stevenson...

BUFFALO, N.Y., May, 31.--The eastward movement of flour and grain from the west through Buffalo for the month of May, 1887, shows a decrease of 10,144 barrels in the receipts of flour and an increase of 1,232,197 bushels in the receipts of grain, estimating flour as wheat, as compared with the same month last year.

All the members of the Committee on Contested Seats of the Republican County Committee were present in the rooms of the Thirteenth Assembly District Republican organization, in Eighth-avenue, near Twenty-third-street, last evening. Capt. Cregan attended, and so did representatives of the opposition faction, with Assemblymen Robert Ray Hamilton to back them up.

The beautiful ground of the Staten Island, Cricket Club at Livingston, Staten Island, was dotted yeaterday with the blue and black jackets of the Pittsburg Cricket Club men as they worked hard to get out the strong team of the islanders, who were then at the wickets.
Great game to-day at St. George, Staten Island, at 4. "Mets" vs. Cleveland, Admission, 25c. Boats from the Battery; fare, 10c.--Exchange.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., May 31.--A distinct earthquake shock was felt in this city at 10 o'clock this morning. The shock lasted only a moment and seemed like an underground explosion of great severity. In some portions of the city women ran out at their houses in alarm.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 31.--Col. R.S. Strader, of this city, has sold to Crisman Brothers, of Keene, Ky., the bay brood mare Cicely, by Mansfield, dam Camille, by Rysdyk's Hambletonian, and a bay mare 3 years old, by Kentucky Prince, dam Cassandra, by Messenger Duroc. Price for both $2,900. The sale was made for Charles Backman, Stoney Ford, N.Y.
The Bijou Opera House was last night draped in blue and white to welcome the Columbia students, Sophomores, who went there to celebrate the completion of their mathematical course.

These is no likelihood that the President will be in any haste about filling the vacancy on the Supreme Bench caused by the death of Justice WOODS during the recess of the court. Before the new term opens is October we have no doubt he will find a fit...
The question of a change in the motor power in use on the lines of the Brooklyn City Railroad Company from horses to a cable was discussed at some length by the Board of Trustees yesterday.

WEST POINT, May 31.--Once more the embryo warrior awakes to the fact that it is a long lane that has no turning. Nine long months he has toiled and toiled and figured his books, and the time has now arrived when the goal for which he has striven is within a good perspective.

The lawn tennis tournament for the championship of the Middle States, which is to be held to-morrow, Friday, and Saturday on the grounds of the St. George's Cricket Club, at Hoboken, has had a most satisfactory entry. The tourney is open to all, and is for singles only.
UTICA, N.Y., May 31.--A special to the Press from Oswego says the International League team of that city disbanded to-night.

Harvard had the best of the lacrosse game with the New-York University on the Brooklyn Athletic Club ground yesterday. They were particularly strong in the attack, and New-York had to act on the defensive nearly all the time.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 31.--The California Sugar Refinery to-day reduced the prices of all grades of sugar 1/8 cent.

PARIS, May 31.--M. Rouiver read a statement of his policy in the Chamber of Deputies this afternoon. He urged financial reform and retrenchment. The new budget, he said, would be prepared in accord with the recent vote of the Chamber.

Iselin, Neeser Co. imported in July, 1885, some velvets which were appraised for duty by Collector Hedden in advance of the invoice valuation. The firm claimed a reappraisement. To cover the fee of the merchant appraiser it left with Benjamin Russell, a Custom House clerk, $10.

The old and highly respected firm of Lothrop Scott, of 45 William-street, NewYork, has been dissolved. Mr. Lothrop, as is well known, is President of the American Steam Boiler Insurance Company, and...

The Lamps and Gas Committee of the Board of Aldermen, through Alderman Mooney, reported at yesterday's meeting of the Common Council in favor of granting franchises to the Waterhouse, the American, the Ball, the Mount Morris...

POTTSVILLE, Penn., May 31.--Negotiations were concluded to-day between a syndicate of Pottsville capitalists and the Phoneix Manufacturing Company of Paterson, N.J., for the establishment of a large silk mill here. The mill will employ from 600 to 1,000 hands, and the building and machinery will cost $300,000. The work of erection will be commenced at once.

PARIS, May 31.--President Grevy has made a personal donation of 10,000f. for the benefit of the sufferers by the Opera Comique fire. No search has as yet been made in the upper galleries of the opera house for the bodies of persons who are supposed to have lost their lives there.

"Falka" was given by the McCaull Opera Company at Wallack's Theatre last evening and attracted a large and fashionable audience. All the artists of the company were well received, the laughter and applause were unstinted, and recalls were frequent.

George R. Lemon, who forged his father's name to numerous small checks on the Essex County National Bank, was arrested in Newark last evening on complaint of Edward Johnson, Secretary of the Prudential Insurance Company. It is said that Lemon's forgeries amount to about $1,200.
