A grand demonstration in honor of the patriot will take place at the Academy of Music Thursday evening, June 2. Boxes for sale at the Academy, and admission tickets as well as reserved seats at the office of the Treasurer, John P. Lynch, 385 Broadway.

One of the most curious and interesting of the country houses in the vicinity of the metropolis is situated a few miles up the Hudson River, on the east shore. The mansion is Gothic in style and built of gray stone. It is surrounded by velvet swards, upon which the sunlight lies in...
Prof. Charles Siedhorf, 92 years old, a man of rare attainments, and his wife, Matilda, aged 93 years, committed suicide yesterday afternoon at their home in Liberty-street, Union Hill, N.J.

NYACK, N.Y., May 31.--Jacob Wolf came to Nyack from Berlin, via Castle Garden, just 10 days ago. Jacob's brother, a prosperous shoemaker, was called home to attend to some property matters, and summoned Jacob to attend to the Nyack business.
To-day at Washington Park, Brooklyn, the St. Louis Browns and Brooklyns will meet.

NYACK, May 31.--Dr. John G. Dorrance, of Nyack, whose mysterious disappearance from Philadelphia was announced in THE TIMES in a dispatch from that city this morning, has not yet been heard from by his relatives and friends in this place and they are very anxious as to his whereabouts.

The Larchmont Yacht Club's Spring pennant regatta will be sailed on Saturday, the start being set down for 10 A.M. The annual regatta will take place on July 4, when, in addition to other prizes, the Gould and Connor Cups Will be sailed for. Later in the season the club expects to have a race of big sloops for a big prize.

It is expected that over 250 New-York veterans will attend the opening parade of the National Veteran Militia Association, which takes place in Boston on June 17. The Seventh, Ninth, Twenty-second, Twenty-third, and Seventy-first Regiments will send delegations.

There is an astonishing amount of push among newspaper men in the Canadian Dominion. Take the Toronto Daily Globe, for example.

Rapid Transit Commissioners Thurber, Shultz, Worthen, and Stanton met yesterday afternoon and went over somewhat minutely the maps of the routes already adopted. The fina1 decision on plans and specifications will be made June 7.

CITY OF MEXICO, May 31, via Galveston.--The Government is having the theatres and other large public buildings carefully inspected to see if any serious damage, which might result in future catastrophes, occurred during the earthquake of Sunday morning.

LEBANON, Penn., May 31.--In the little borough of Annville, five miles west of this city, an atrocious double crime was committed two weeks ago, which has just been unearthed. The victims were two little boys, aged 3 and 5 years respectively, who were strangled to death by...

BALTIMORE, May 31.--The fourth annual meeting of the American Climatological Association was begun in the lecture room of the physical laboratory of the Johns Hopkins University this afternoon. ROME, May 31.--The central crater of Mount Etna was discovered to be in a state of eruption this morning. The flow continues and is increasing in volume. Heavy clouds of smoke and masses of stones and cinders are issuing from the crater.

There is a little friction between the Tammany Hall organization and Mayor Hewitt. The announcement of the trouble comes from such a distinctive Tammany source that there is very naturally a suspicion that the information is given out in order to bulldoze the Mayor into doing something for the wigwam. It was Sheriff Grant who publicly announced the discontent yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 31.--An important question to importers was decided this morning in the United States court by Judge Blodgett, in the case of Mandell Brothers, dry goods merchants, against Collector Spalding.

The annual parade of the Police Department was made yesterday afternoon under conditions favorable over head and under foot. It was the most imposing turnout that the bluecoats ever made, and as a popular demonstration was a huge success.

James H. Lester, the Southern spy and blockade runner, sued Gen. B.F. Butler in 1866 for damages for false imprisonment. He was beaten last February before Judge Coxe and a jury. Now he has begun a second action against the General to recover certain papers and personal property taken from him when he was arrested.
MONTREAL, May 31.--L.D. Parent, the young Cashier of the Hochelaga Bank, has absconded and is a defaulter to the extent of $12,000.

LONDON, May 31.--The third of the series of matches in which the Thistle took part was sailed to-day from Harwich to Southend. Eight yachts entered, the Foxhound and Sleuthhound retiring and Bonny Doon, a cutter, rated at 33 tons, being added to the list.
The entire stock of the Bates Manufacturing Company, consisting of 2,100 cases of quilts, valued at $500,000, was sold at auction yesterday morning by Wilmerding, Hoguet Co.

CONCORD, N. H. May 31.--The officers of the Sullivan County Mutual Fire Insurance Company of Newport, organized in the Fall of 1885, have issued notices to agents and policy holders that they will cease doing business on June 10. A cash dividend of 10 per cent. was declared in favor of renewed policies in January, and business was then prosperous. Recent heavy losses in the State necessitate the winding up of its affairs.

There were six starters for the Bell medal offered for an 880-yards' club handicap run at the New-York Athletic Club grounds, in Mott Haven, yesterday afternoon.
PARIS, May 31.--There was a brilliant assemblage at the military fete at the opera house this evening, Gen. Boulanger was absent.

WHEELING, West Va., May 31.--While Miss Edith Chipperfield, with a party of five other ladies, was crossing the Ohio River, near Parkersburg, yesterday evening, a sudden gust of wind capsized their boat and threw them all into the water. Five of the ladies were rescued in an exhausted condition, but Miss Chipperfield sank and her body has not yet been recovered.

Harry Irving Land wrote some time ago to Mayor Hewitt complaining that the Knights of Labor and trade unionists would not let him earn his living as a painter because he would not join one or the other of the organizations.

CHICAGO, May 31.--The Board of Trade will to-morrow morning open its Stock Exchange, and begin what is confidently expected to prove an era of solid and permanent growth in the stock and bond business of this city.

Among the indictments handed down by the Kings County Grand Jury yesterday was one charging Joseph R. Huntting, one of the Justices of the Peace of Westbury, Queens County, with the embezzlemment of $25,000 belonging to Frederick Willetts, a wealthy resident of the same village.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 31.--News has reached Merv from Herat that the Chilzais have defeated a thousand of the Ameer's regular troops and captured five guns and considerable baggage. Daharnell, the commander of the Ameer's forces, was captured and beheaded.

Tunis Covert, of Ontario, Canada, began an action in the United States District Court yesterday to get possession of a big slice of Harlem. The land Mr. Covert wants is bounded by Fourth-avenue for 49 blocks, by Eightyfourth-street for nine blocks, and by the Harlem River. Its valuation is put at many millions.

READING, Penn, May 31.--Lauer's Park was the scene of a double tragedy a little before midnight, which had its sequel in the death of a man and the serious wounding of a young woman, the former a jealous and maddened lover of the girl.

Maurice Spiegel, whose conduct while Receiver of the Maison Tortoni caused Mrs. Louise Chaude to turn to the law, sat quietly smoking a cigar yesterday when the reference in the case was resumed, and severely tried the temper of Lawyer David Leventritt when cross-examined by his inabilitty to remember the greater part of the transactions in which it is alleged he was engaged.
Friedrich Mitterwurzer is at the Belvedere House.

The single scull race between George Lee, of New-York, and John McKay, of Halifax, Nova Scotia, which was to have been rowed yesterday at 6 o'clock P.M., on Bowery Bay, for a purse of $l,000, did not take place.

CHICAGO, May 31.--Hanlan, the oarsman, announced to-night that on his return to Canada he would challenge Gaudaur to row yesterday's race over again on the same course, under exactly similar conditions.

Nearly every broker except those who deal only in stocks was interested yesterday in an Exchange meeting. The annual meetings of the Produce and Cotton Exchanges were held, and the Coffee Exchange voted upon certain amendments to the by-laws submitted by the Governing Committee 10 days ago.

William Pitt Shearman and Joseph B. Adamson, the Commissioners of Accounts, met yesterday in the board room of the Dock Department to continue their investigation into the board's accounts and methods. President L.J.N. Stark, of the Dock Board, was to have been examined, but he had gone to his farm on Lake Champlain, and Commissioner James Matthews said he preferred to be examined when President Stark was.

Candidates for admission to Columbia College presented themselves yesterday for examinations. There also appeared some of the students who will be Sophomores next Fall, and who wanted to do a little examining themselves in the line of testing the rushing abilities of their future antagonists.

A meeting of Catholic citizens who are friends of the Rev. Dr. McGlynn was held last evening at the Cooper Institute. They decided to hold a street parade and mass meeting on June 18 to give expression to their feelings about the Pope's recent letter.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., May 31.--When the President stepped from his carriage to the stoop of the Saranac Inn to-night, on his return from Ray Brook, he brought with him besides a handsome catch of trout, several added shades of tan,acquired by the exposure of the last four days to the sun and winds of the Adirondacks. He has had sport enough to-day, he admits, to...

SAN FRANCISCO, May 31.--Exchange--Sight traits on New-York, 17 ; telegraphic, 25.

CHICAGO, May 31.--The men who have charge of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe extension to Chicago have not yet announced how they intend to get into the heart of the city, possibly because they are not themselves altogether certain.

TORONTO, May 31.--Commercial unionists are anxiously awaiting the fate of a measure agreed upon at a meeting of people who are prominently identified with the movement held here a few days ago. Regarding the best plan of bringing the question before the country in...
ST. LOUIS, May 31.--Manager Charles A. Locks, of the National Opera Company, said to-night that some radical changes would be made in the organization.

The Municipal Council of the Irish National League met last evening at Fourth-avenue and Eighteenth-street. James A. O'Gorman, Chairman of the joint committee on the O'Brien reception, reported that arrangements for the mass meeting in the Academy of Music on Thursday evening had been nearly completed and that Judge Edward Browne would preside.

DETROIT, Mich., May 31.--The negotiations between a La Crosse and Milwaukee syndicate of capitalists, who have been interesting themselves in the water power at Sault Ste. Marie, has finally resulted in an agreement...

Gen. Francis Darr, who represents the Chemical National Bank in San Francisco, telegraphed yesterday that the suit in the United States court against William Kissane, alias William K. Rogers, to recover money fraudulently obtained, amounting, with interest, to about $26,000, had been begun.

The Harlem Railroad people do not think they were wholly at fault for the delay in getting people to and from Jerome Park promptly on Monday. In all, they carried from this city to the park and to Woodlawn Cemetery over 13,000 people by special trains, in addition to those taking the regular trains.

John Kelly, of 349 East Sixtieth-street, went home drunk, on Sunday, and beat and kicked his wife until she was insensible. Then he tried to hang her, but his potations had been too deep and he failed. Kelly spent the night in a carouse.

LONDON, May 31.--Mr. Gladstone writes that as the Unionist Liberals have assisted in passing the second reading of the permanent Coercion bill, the Irish question is virtually settled for the present.
The nineteenth annual Commencement of the Womans' Medical College of the New-York Infirmary took place last night in the concert hall of the Metropolitan Opera House.

The Rev. Henry Van Rensselaer, a scholastic of the Society of Jesus who is a convert from the Protestant ministry, was ordained to the priesthood yesterday morning in the cathedral by Archbishop Corrigan. This morning the new priest will say mass in St. Francis Xavier's. Some Paulist students were raised to inferior orders. There were a number of Jesuits and Paulists present, some of the cathedral priests and a few of Mr. Van Rensselaer's friends.

MONTREAL, May 31.--A mysterious poisoning case occurred at Pointe aux Trembles yesterday. Two laborers employed on Mr. Gauthier's farm want to the horse of Mr. Piton, the manager, and asked for a drink before going to work.

When the body of a man who registered as A. Allen was found in a South Norwalk hotel a year or so ago it was asserted that Allen was really John Tyler, a New-York broker, who had committed suicide to pay his debts.

George D. Lennon, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Union Labor Party, which was organized at Cincinnati last Washington's Birthday, stated to a TIMES reporter yesterday that the party will, beyond a doubt, place a State ticket in the field this Fall.

At the special meeting of the congregation of the Fourteenth-Street Presbyterian Church, held last night for the purpose of considering the resignation of the present Pastor, the Rev. F.H. Marling, which was presented last Sunday ...
PARIS, June 1.--There has been no repetition to-day of the disturbances made last night in front of the Opera House in favor of Gen. Boulanger. The excitement has generally subsided.

A meeting held yesterday of the American Tract Society was the occasion of an earnest and somewhat heated debate. This debate arose over the report of a committee which recommended extensive changes in the organization and methods of the society.
Mayor Hewitt spoke yesterday before the Railroad Committee of the Board of Aldermen on the sand-sprinkling nuisance, as perpetrated by the surface railroad companies.

KEY WEST, Fla., June 1.--Five new cases of yellow fever are reported to-day and the truth has now dawned upon us that we are in the first stages of an epidemic, the like of which we have not had for many years, but of which there is no hope of prevention till the disease has exhausted itself upon the thousands of unacclimated inhabitants of this unhappy island.

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Tenement House Building Company was held last night at 109 West Fifty-fourth-street. Besides electing Trustees for the ensuing year the stockholders were called together to act upon a proposition to reduce the capital stock of the company to $100,000.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 1.--For several days Dr. McCosh, Pesident of Princeton College, has been prostrated with a very seve be cold, which finally developed into bronchitis. To-night the doctor is a little better.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 1.--Although the negotiations between the Ives-Staynor syndicate and Mr. McKeen, owner of the Vandalia, are not yet completed, it is evident that they are expected to be concluded soon, and the important link in the Pennsylvania system will pass into the control of the Baltimore and Ohio.

With every prospect of rain and the certainty of a muddle track and with a not specially attractive card the races at Jerome Park yesterday failed to bring out a great crowd of people, though there must have been 3,000 or ...

BOSTON, Mass., June 1.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Franklin Telegraph Company was held to-day. The following Directors were elected: C.A. Tinker, Norvin Green, T.T. Eckert, John Van Horn, Jay Gould, Thomas Roche, and Joseph F. Greenough, R.H. Rochester was chosen Treasurer, and Thomas Roche clerk. The Directors will probably meet in New-York, where the President will be chosen.

The General Committee of the GermanAmerican Independent Citizens' Association met last evening at Beethoven Hall. The delegates resolved to ask the next Legislature to enact another excise law which would permit the sale of beer and wine accompanied by music after 2 o'clock on Sunday afternoon.
Theodore Stohler, a German silk weaver, 35 years old, living at 17 North Third-street, Paterson, N.J., shot his wife and then himself last evening.

OMAHA, Neb., June 4.--The thirty-third biennial convention of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in the United States opened this evening in Kountze Memorial Church. The General Synod represents 223 synods, consisting of 876 ministers and 134,840 members.

A meeting largely attended by women was held in Historical Hall, Brooklyn, last night to urge the appointment of some of the gentler sex upon the Board of Education when the terms of the present members expire.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 1.--Under a new liquor law passed by the last Legislature the saloons in this city were ordered to close up at 11 o'clock to-night. Some of the liquor dealers claim that the licenses which have been granted them and which specify 12 o'clock as the closing hour are contracts between themselves and the State which cannot be abrogated by any statute law, and some of them refused to close up.
Gov. J.R. Bodwell, of Maine, is at the Murray Hill Hotel. Col. H.M. Black, United States Army, is at the Rossmore Hotel.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, June 1.--Gabriel Dumont, Riel's Lieutenant, is now on the boundary line inciting the half breeds and Indians to another rebellion. An attempt was made by the Canadian mounted police yesterday to capture bearers of dispatches from Dumont to half breeds.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 1.--The death of the aged and distinguished Gov. Smith, of Virginia, the other day, has been telegraphed all over the country. Gov. Smith had a sister who for many years prior to his death was a resident of Georgia. Since the war she had lived in Atlanta.

The general boom in club affairs which has been evident about the city of late has affected the electricians, and the members of this vigorous and rapidly developing branch of commercial industry are shortly to have a handsome headquarters of their own.
The following contributions have been received by the St. John's Guild on behalf of the "Free Excursions" and Seaside Nursery:

Good, sharp, steady fielding marked the work of the New-Yorks in their game with the Bostons yesterday. They also batted in a lively way, and the result was that the visiting players were beaten 8 to 3.

CHICAGO, June 1.--There were some curious features to Senator Sherman's visit here. He arrived in Chicago Sunday night, and not even a newspaper reporter met him. On Monday Senator Farwell called upon him bright and early, ...
Wilmerding, Hoguet Co., of 64 and 66 White-street, yesterday conducted a peremptory trade package sale of flannels by order of Faulkner, Page Co.

The funeral of Julius Wadsworth, who died in Middletown, Conn., on Saturday, took place yesterday from the Church of the Holy Trinity, at Fortysecond-street and Madison-avenue. The services were conducted by the Rev. Dr. C.C. Tiffany, of Zion Church, assisted by the Rev. Kenneth MacKenzie. The pall bearers were George Irving, James O. Sheldon, James T. Woodward, Effingham Nichols, Adon Smith, A.F. Warburton, James Stillman, and Frederick de Billier.

Anthony Comstock appeared at the Special Sessions yesterday to prosecute John Roberts, Michael Kelly, Robert Jackson, Frank Cloud, and George Holland for keeping pool rooms on the second floor of 16 Beekman-street. Mr. Comstock testified, as did his agent, George E. Oram.
ALBANY, June 1.--A former inmate of the Utica Insane Asylum named E.C. Deiffenbocher walked into the lobby of the Executive Chamber today and demanded an investigation of his alleged insanity.
BUFFALO, June 1.--The receipts of flour at Buffalo by lake during the month of May, compared with the receipts for the corresponding month in 1886, show a decrease of 113,126 barrels.

Six races are to be run at Jerome Park to-day, these, including the Juvenile Stakes for 2-years-old and a steeplechase over the short course. The Juvenile is the race in which the most interest will centre, and with 14 named as probable starters the race should be a good one, for the track will be in good condition by the time for the race to be run.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y. June 1.--O.P. Barber, of Ellington, a leading citizen of this section, died last night from injuries received in a runaway. He leaves a family.

PITTSBURG, June 1.--A committee consisting of Gen. W.H. Powell, of Belleville, Ill.; J.D. Dubois, of the Belmont Mill, Wheeling; H. M. Priest, of the Junction Iron and Steel Company, Mingo, Ohio; Mr. Arms, of the Mahoning Valley; Gen. C.L. Fitzhugh, of Schoenberger Co., ...

The Democratic Aldermen of Jersey City are playing a sharp game to secure time to bring a bolting Democrat back into the ranks. The board has made four attempts to elect a President, and has taken about 180 ballots.

WASHINGTON, June 1.--Brig.-Gen. Thomas H. Ruger, Col. James F. Wade, Fifth Cavalry, and Major Edmund Butler, Second Infantry, have been ordered to assemble at Fort Leavenworth on June 10 to attend the examination of officers who have taken the two years' course of instruction at the ...

WASHINGTON, June 1.--In all the speculation as to the probable successor to Judge Woods as Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States scarcely a passing comment has been made upon the cause which undoubtedly hastened his death, namely, overwork.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 1.--Four men, while trying to cross the river in a skiff to-day, were thrown into the water and two of them, Henry Meyer and John Reider, were drowned.
Mr. JOHN SHERMAN'S journey to Illinois to make a bid for the Republican nomination for the Presidency involves a question of taste which it is not necessary to discuss.
PERNAMBUCO,June 1.--Several warehouses here and 25,000 bales of cotton have been destroyed by fire.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1.--Another long debate on the music question occupied the General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church today. The direct cause of the issue was the use of the organ by the Rev. J.T. Tates's church, at Keokuk, Iowa, to which objection had been made first to the local Presbytery and then to the Synod of Iowa.

DETROIT, June 1.--Business and political circles in Grand Rapids are in a fever of excitement to-day over the disappearance of Probate Judge Lyman D. Follett. It seems to be a clear case of another good man gone wrong through the fascinations of wheat speculation.

LONDON, June 1.--The yacht race to-day over the Royal Thames 50-mile course was won by the Thistle, which ran the course in 6 hours. The Irex covered the distance in 6 hours 23 minutes and the Genesta in 6 hours 25 minutes. The Thistle achieved a brilliant victory.
Tuesday was pay day at the Court House, but the clerks and officers did not wear the air of gayety which should adorn men on pay day.

BALTIMORE, June 1.--At the convention of the Episcopal Diocese of Easton held at Chestertown, Md., to-day the Rev. John S. Lindsay, of St. John's Church, Georgetown, D.C., was elected Bishop, to succeed the late Bishop Lay. He makes the sixth Bishop elected since the death of Bishop Lay in 1883. He was once Chaplain of the House of Representatives, and is 45 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., June 1.--Carroll Cook, a prominent attorney, is charged with crookedness in the management of the estate of Mrs. Cynthia Shillaber. He is accused of using moneys of the estate for purposes other than those prescribed by the court.

The brief dispatch announcing that "the Sultan of Turkey has ceded the island of Cyprus to England" will attract far less attention than the publication, nine years ago, of the terms of the secret treaty by which the administrative control of that little island passed into the hands of the power which has now acquired it absolutely.

LEXINGTON, Ky., June 1.--W.C. France, formerly of New-York, but now of this county, is sweet on the get of Red Wilkes. To-day he purchased in a lump of A. Smith McCann, of this city, three 2year-old fillies, one 2-year-old colt, six yearling fillies, and seven yearling colts, 17 head in all, all sired by Red Wilkes, and from well-bred dams. The price paid is private, but will reach nearly $20,000.
The New-York, Woodhaven and Rockaway Railroad is announced to be sold under foreclosure on June 28.
