One of the greatest commercial combinations of recent years was effected in this city yesterday. It involves the control of the entire rubber industry in America, an industry which has already assumed immense proportions and which will undoubtedly increase at an accelerated rate now that the scheme of consolidation has become an established fact.

CHICAGO, June 1.--Both sides in the great lock-out and strike are lond in their assertions that victory for them is a foregone conclusion. The force of non-union bricklayers was increased to-day by eight new arrivals, who reported at the Builders' Exchange.
On Mondays till Oct. 1 the Cotton Exchange is to be opened at 11 o'clock, and not at 10 as usual.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 1.--A number of old line Democrats appeared in Columbus a few days ago and called upon ex-Congressman Converse with a view of urging him to become a candidate for the Gubernatorial nomination.

Those party organs which are striving to make political capital out of the passage of the Vedder Liquor Tax bill by the Legislature and its veto by the Governor are resorting to the grossest misrepresentations.

The organization which was formed 15 years ago for the erection of a great Protestant Episcopal Cathedral in this city has come to life again with a better prospect of success than ever before. In a letter to the citizens of New-York, given below, Bishop Potter explains the enterprise as far as practicable at present.

The action of the General Executive Board of the Knights of Labor in revoking the charters of District Assembly No. 126 and of the local assemblies attached to it has been much commented upon in knightly circles.

The question of general retrenchment in expenses and business, including several radical changes in method of administration, which were recommended in a report by a special committee at the annual meeting, came before the American Tract Society yesterday at its adadjourned meeting held in the lecture room of the Madison-Square Presbyterian Church.

CINCINNATI, June 1.--There is a stringent law in Ohio against all forms of pool selling and bookmaking which the fraternity have sought to evade by opening offices just across the river in Kentucky and taking business from this side.
Michael Morrison, a man known to hundreds of anglers and employed by Abbey Imbrie, of Vesey-street, was found dead in bed yesterday morning of heart disease.

The General Theological Seminary of the Protestant Episcopal Church held its Commencement exercises yesterday morning at the seminary, in Chelsea-square. Over a hundred clergymen were in attendance, among them being Bishop Paddock, of Massachusetts; Bishop Whitehead, of Pittsburg, and Bishop Seymour, of Illinois.
BERLIN, June 1.--Negotiations are proceeding between Germany and Austria regarding the Russian ukase prohibiting aliens from holding land in Russia.

SARANAC INN, New-York, June 1.--Dave Cronk, the President's guide, remembered last night after the newspaper dispatches had been sent off from the Saranac Inn that one of the most interesting events of the day at Ray Brook had not been referred to by the President or himself.

WEST POINT, June 1.--With an amount of vigor and tenacity of purpose which was disheartening it rained all day up to 4 o'clock. Early this morning it looked for awhile as if the heavy clouds which hung overhead had spent the greater part of their spare time during all these dry weeks in storing up in their capacious folds that amount of water which they cast down upon a combatative multitude to-day.

Gen. William Cutting was under examination again before Referee Hamilton Cole yesterday upon his accounts as Executor of the estate of Francis B. Cutting, his father. He identified the schedules he filed with the Referee, under order of the Supreme Court, containing a statement of all the assets remaining of the estate on Jan. 13, 1886.

To-day will probaby end the hunt for the Sharp jury. When the court adjourned yesterday there was still a vacant seat, but both Mr. Martine and Mr. Parsons stated that unless something developed in the meantime, the 11 men in the box would content them.

There was no meeting of the Park Commissioners yesterday, but Mr. Crimmins was waited upon by the owners of property north of Central Park, among whom were A.E. Orr, Henry A. Cram, W.H. Lee, and E.J. King.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 1.--Senator Sherman's address before the Illinois Legislature today was an adroit appeal for the support of the Logan men, and to-night is discussed solely in that light.
George Disque, the Hoboken wife murderer, was hanged in the Hudson County Jail, on Jersey City Heights, yesterday morning. He preserved his equanimity to the last.

CHICAGO, June 1.--The Chicago Board of Trade Stock Exchange began its first session at precisely 9 o'clock this morning without any formalities whatever, and a brisk trade was at once inaugurated. At the close of the first half hour or business the sales amounted to over 3,000 shares.

The German version of "La Mascotte," Audran's best work, is now current at Mr. Amberg's Terrace Garden, in Fifty-ninth-street, near Third-avenue. The opera in its German dress is not a whit less attractive than in the original French.

LONDON, June 1.--The inaugural conference of the Radical Union was opened to-day at Birmingham, by Mr. Joseph Chamberlain. Lord Hartington, in a letter to the conference, said the doubt and confusion surrounding the home rule question were still unremoved.

The Board of Education held a meeting yesterday afternoon. The report of the Committee on Sites and New Schools, recommending the purchase of two lots adjoining Grammar School No. 76, in East Sixty-eighth-street, was adopted.
Adolph Reich was put on trial yesterday, before Recorder Smyth, for killing his wife on the 19th of last April at their home, 144 Norfolk-street.

MONTREAL, June 1.--It has been learnedthat Parent, the defaulting Cashier of the Hochelaga Bank, has fled to Chicago. The authorities of the bank have discovered that his first irregularity occurred on the 6th of May, when he took an accepted check for $6,800, signed by himself, to Dupuis Freres and asked them to change checks with him for a few days.

ALBANY, June 1.--The Governor to-day signed the supplemental Cantor bill giving the singing societies of New-York the right to rehearse without taking out theatrical licenses; the Murphy bill allowing salmon-trout, black bass, and wall-eyed pike that are caught without the State to be sold at any time within ...

The Hotel Association met in force yesterday at the Ashland House to discuss the question of selling intoxicating liquors on Sunday. E.L. Merrifield, of the Continental Hotel presided, and others present were A.L. Ashman, of the Sinclair; H.H. Brookway, of the Ashland; G. Wetherbee, of the Windsor; C.N. Vilas ...

Miss Maud Harrison has at last adorned her artistic career with a suit at law, and her case is of even more interest than the sensational litigation with which her sister-actresses, Lillian Russell, Lilian Olcott. Mrs. Langtry, and innumerable others, have been favored.

The full State Board of Arbitration, consisting of ex-Judge Robertson, William Purcell, and Mr. Donovan, of this city, met yesterday at the New-York Hotel, and had a first hearing in the matter of the locked-out silversmiths and chasers. Of the manufacturers that had been summoned there were present Messrs Cook ...
ALBANY, June 1.--This promises to be an unusually brisk year for the politicians. Both the old political organizations realize that the skirmish lines for 1888 will be thrown out this year.

The three-story tenements at 226 and 228 West Thirtieth-street are inhabited by colored people. Behind them is a three-story brick building, the ground floor of which is occupied by the Empire Iron Works and the upper floors by Johnson Sharp's suspender factory.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, June 1.--A romantic story is connected with the death of Joseph McLellan, an engine driver an the Intercolonial Road, who was accidentally killed in the railway yard here a short time ago. He was born in Belfast, Ireland, and lived for some years in Edinburgh, Scotland, and came to this country about 1852.

CONCORD, N.H., June 1.--The Legislature organized to-day with the choice of officers in harmony with the Senatorial candidacy of ex-Secretary Chandler. Alvin Burleigh was chosen Speaker of the House and Frank D. Currier President of the Senate.

The marriage of Miss Margaret, the only daughter of S. Otis Livingston, to Walter W., son of Charles Watrous, took place at her father's residence, 25 East Sixty-fourth-street, at 3:30 yesterday afternoon. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. William M. Taylor, Pastor ...

BALTIMORE, June 1.--An appointment that throws those of Appointment Clerk Eugene Higgins and Indian Inspector Morris A. Thomas completely in the shade has just been made in the office of the Collector of Internal Revenue.

HAMBURG, June 1.--A great fire broke out at 9 o'clock last night in the Strand. The Huebener Quays were speedily destroyed. Six large sheds were next gutted. The flames communicated to two British vessels, the City of Dortmund and the Gladiator, and destroyed them.

A new regulation of the Health Officer obliges all vessels from Havana to remain at Quarantine until five days have elapsed since their departure from that port. The City of Alexandria, of the Alexandre Line, has the distincion of being the first steamer detained by the rule.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., June 1.--The legal season for taking pickerel opened to-day, and immense numbers of pickerel and bass were taken in Chautauqua Lake. This proves the wisdom of the prohibition of spearing which has been enforced for three years. Fishing parties are numerous from neighboring cities.
At Scranton yesterday the Cuban Giants defeated the Scrantons 5 to 4.

BOSTON, June 1.--The little New-Hampshire town of Pittsfield is very much excited over the mysterious disappearance of the Rev. W.C. Stiles, Pastor of the Congregational church there, and at one time, it is said, settled in Brooklyn, N.Y., and St. Louis, Mo. Mr. Stiles left his home yesterday morning to visit a parishioner.

BOSTON, June 1.--The official investigation into Union Pacific Railway affairs was continued this morning. Gov. Ames resumed the stand to make a correction in his testimony. He desired to state that the rental of the Colorado and Pacific Road was not the interest on the bonds, as he previously stated, but $1,000 a mile.
President Von der Ahe, of the St. Louis Browns, and Joseph Doyle, one of the stockholders of the Brooklyn team, met in the corridor of the Grand Central Hotel last evening.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., June 1.--The report sent out by the Associated Press last night that Jamestown experienced an earthquake on Tuesday was false. Christian Gosselt exploded a quantity of dynamite in a driven well, which shook the earth in the vicinity, causing small alarm and doing no damage.

CHICAGO, June 1.--The total shipments of dead freight from Chicago through to seaboard points by all the lines, except the Chicago and Atlantic, last week amounted to 28,321 tons, against 28,579 tons for the week previous. The percentages carried by each road were:

CHICAGO, June 1.--About 3,000,000 bushels of wheat, it was estimated, went round on deliveries on June contracts this morning. Of this amount 2,500,000 was taken by the clique and paid for. The fact caused the market to open wildly excited, with June quoted anywhere from 90 1/8 cents to 90 cents.

BOSTON, June 1.--The bill of the West End Street Railway Company, whose plans have for some time agitated the press and public of the city and State pro and con, has passed the critical stage in the State Senate, and by a majority that would indicate the final success of the measure, as no one anticipates Executive disapproval.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 1.--Mr. T.H. Merrimee, a bookkeeper for J.F. White Co., was overcome last night while attending services at the cathedral by a strange affection which has thus far baffled medical skill. Mr. Merrimee, accompanied by his brother and sister, went to the May devotions at the cathedral at 8 o'clock.
LONDON, June 1.--The Anchor Line steamship City of Rome, Capt. Munro, from New-York May 25, for Liverpool, arr. at Queenstown to-day.
CHICAGO, June 1.--The Clapp Davis case was up before Judge Jamieson yesterday, and the Judge effected a settlement which was very favorable to the creditors.

The creditors of the Asbury Park Grand Opera House Company met the Directors of that company at the Astor House last evening. The meeting was a harmonious one. A majority of the creditors voted to extend the time for paying their claims in order to give the company an opportunity to meet its obligations.

Patrick Foster, the Blackwell's Island prison keeper who shot two men and assaulted another on a South Ferry boat on May 17 last, was before Justice Massey, at Brooklyn, yesterday, accompanied by Lawyer Ferguson and a number of friends.

ST. LOUIS, June 1.--The National Opera Company closed its season in St. Louis to-night, and Manager Locke acknowledges that it was a failure. "Opera has its season as well as the oyster, and both are out of season now." he said.

BOSTON, June 2.--George Fred Williams, as counsel for many of those injured at the Bussey Bridge disaster, has brought suits against the Boston and Providence Railroad for damages amounting in the aggregate to $401,500. These suits are returnable on Monday next, but will not be tried for several months. Individual damages claimed vary in amount from $500 to $10,000.
MONTREAL, June 2.--The Grand Jury to-day found 12 true bills against Parent, the absconding Cashier of the Hochelaga Bank. Parent has so far escaped arrest.

MARGARETVILLE, N.Y., June 2.--George C. Clausen, Howard Carroll, D.E. Seybel, E.H. Johnson, Sir Joseph Fuller, Henry W. Schmidt, Julius Simon, C.A. Benton, and Col. E.B. Parsons, of the New-York Riding Club, with three grooms, two supply wagons, and six extra horses, arrived in Margaretville this morning.

Jap Gould's health was the subject yesterday of a good deal of hysterical interest in Wall-street. The bears who used to kill William H. Vanderbilt every time they wanted to raid the stock market have gone to slaughtering Mr. Gould with the same free and easy facility. He was reported dead by a number of authorities before the stock market closed. Then his son was quoted as denying that he was even in bad health.

Ex-Gov. Cornell presided yesterday at an extra meeting of the Executive Committee of the Grant Monument Association, and others present were Sidney Dillon, ex-Mayor Grace, William Lummis, Cornelius O'Reilly, A.L. Sanger, George N. Williams, and Secretary R.T...

IS Mr. SHERMAN afraid of President CLEVELAND! If not, why can he not in a carefully prepared political speech treat him with a decent degree of fairness, such as it is the habit of gentlemen to show toward each other in public! If he is afraid of him,...

SCRANTON, Penn., June 2.--Benjamin Court right of this city, killed himself with a shotgun shortly after noon to-day. He was alone in the house at the time his wife and two children being absent visiting friends.

LONDON, June 2.--The race under the auspices of the New Thames Yacht Club took place to-day. The course was the same as in yesterday's race--from the Lower Hope to the Mouse Lightship and return, a distance of 50 miles.

The sum of $85,052 11 was yesterday appropriated from the excise fund to various charitable and reformatory institutions by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment. Excise Commissioner Andrews asked for an appropriation of $148,620 for the Excise Board for the ensuing fiscal year, and was ordered to furnish a detailed statement of the men to be employed and the salaries to be paid, with the amounts disbursed last year.

The County General Committee of the United Labor Party met last evening at Clarendon Hall, where Corresponding Secretary O'Meara read a letter from G.W. Spencer Littleton, secretary to Mr. Gladstone, acknowledging receipt of the resolutions passed by the United Labor Party, expressing sympathy with his Home Rule policy and expressing Mr. Gladstone's thanks.

The first match between the Riverside and Kings County Cricket Clubs took place yes terday in Central Park. The Riversides had a strong team and easily defeated the Kings County, as the following score will show, by nine wickets:

A writer in the Bowdoin College Orient calls attention to a danger ahead, which, in his opinion, threatens the well being of the college, and that is the great and increasing expense devolving upon the students from too much attention to athletics.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 2.--Drafts on New-York --Sight 17 cents; telegraphic, 25 cents.

WASHINGTON, June 2.--First Lieut. Eben Swift, Fifth Cavalry, has been ordered to the Military Academy as an aid-de-camp to Brig.-Gen. Wesley Merritt Col. Edward F. Townsend, Twelfth Infantry, has been ordered to attend the State Camp of Instruction at Peekskill, N.Y., June 18 to Aug. 6, to inspect the National Guard of the State of New-York.

CHICAGO, June 2.--The 1st of June having passed without the leaders in the supposed big wheat deal showing their hands, the discussion of whether or not there really is any corner in wheat comes to the surface again.

The Hon. John H. Starin has probably no warmer well wishers in this city to-day than the members of "the finest," together with their families and friends, who enjoyed the water excursion to Excelsior Grove, on the Hudson, yesterday, being the ninth complimentary excursion tendered by him to the New-York Municipal Police and their families.

President Norton's statement of the earnings of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad for April show that the gross earnings increased $210,580, to $1,178,320, and net earnings rose $71,233, to $385,158.

Wednesday evening Jules Chatelan, of the Owners' and Business Men's Association, and its counsel, Frank Moss, went to Police Headquarters and delivered to superintendent Murray affidavits which charge Capt. Alexander ...
Paymaster Henry T. Wright, United States Navy, is at the New-York Hotel.

The library of Columbia College was yesterday draped in blue and white bunting to welcome the 700 ladies, interspersed with a few of the sterner sex, who had come to greet'87 in her Class Day exercises.

WEST POINT, June 2.--With the sweet hope of a better day coming the fair young creature who has thus early come up to the Academy to indulge to the utmost her admiration for gold lace and brass buttons--to say nothing of the manly forms they adorn--closed her...

At a meeting of the Executive Board of the National Association of Amateur Athletes of America, last night, at the Gilsey House, it was decided that as Malcolm W. Ford, of the NewYork Athletic Club, states through his counsel,...
CHIHUAHUA, Mexico, June 2.--A terrible panic prevailed here yesterday afternoon in the Catholic cathedral, caused by the falling of a candle, setting fire to one of the altars.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 2.--Notwithstanding the murder of two Mormon Elders in Lewis County two years ago by enraged citizens, and the passage of a law by the Legislature making it a felony for any one to preach the doctrine of polygamy in this State. Mormon Elders are again at work. Several have made their appearance in Lincoln and adjacent counties, and are quietly expounding the faith to the more ignorant classes.

Chester W. Chapin's steel schooner Julia has been sold to T. Jefferson Coolidge, Jr., of Boston, and will start for that port on Saturday. She will hereafter sail under the flag of the Eastern Yacht Club. She will not start in any of next week's regattas, but will sail in the Eastern Yacht Club's race on June 23.
The New-Yorks will play in Washington again this afternoon.
Six races are to be run at Brighton Beach to-day, the entries being as follows:

The latest of the great commercial combinations known as Trusts is one designed to absorb and control the entire rubber industry of the United States--an industry that is represented by an investment of $50,000,000, that employs 25,000 workmen, and that uses every year millions of pounds of imported crude rubber.

Here is a paragraph from the will of the late Samuel H. Blake, who died at the Tremont House the other day. He was an old lawyer, and the President of a bank at Bangor for many years. Said the venerable Mr. Blake, in a document dated some 10 years before his death:

MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 2.--Thirty-five Mormon elders, accompanied by four women, passed through the city this afternoon. Then came direct from Salt Lake City via the Southern Pacific, and are en route to New-York, whence they sail for Europe. They expect to remain abroad about two years.

Capt. Wynn, who commanded the Sumter Light Guards, was killed at the battle of Gettysburg. One morning, the one after that battle, his wife, who lived in Americus, entered her parlor, where upon the wall had hung a handsome painting of her husband.

When handsome "Dave" Johnson left Jerome Park last evening he was $10,000 poorer than he was when he went there. He had plunged on all the "good things" for the day, Connemara, Queen of Elizabeth, Phil Leo, and Letritia, and had got badly left.

Josephine Ehrenrich, a pretty Polish girl of 17, who came to this country three years ago, applied for a situation recently at the intelligence office kept by Dorothea Horn and her husband at 168 Third-avenue.

CHICAGO, June 2.--Chauncey M. Depew, in an interview to-day, referring to the national political situation, said: "The elements which will determine the next Presidential canvass are the labor question and the Irish vote.
LONDON, June 2.--The steamship Tantallon, (Br.,) Capt. Partridge, from New-York May 13, for Newcastle, passed the Lizard to-day.
A black and white English bull terrier, owned by a theological student who is out of town, got astray yesterday morning and was caught by dog catchers at Twenty-third-street and Tenth-avenue.

Four men started out from Fort Lee yesterday for a sail on the sloop-rigged yacht Lillie Morris. Off Weehawken the boat was capsized, and Charlie Gregory, one of the party, was drowned. The others were picked up by a Pennsylvania Railroad barge. The Lillie Morris and her crew are said to hall from Port Richmond, Staten Island, but nobody there knew anything about the yacht last night.
A short time ago James McVicker was arrested by the United States Government and taken before United States Commissioner Shields. After an examination he was held and indicted.

To-morrow, should the weather be pleasant, there will be rare sport at Jerome Park, for both the Ladies' Stakes for 3-year-old fillies and the Westchester Handicap are to be run, in addition to three other flat races and a steeplechase over the full course. Weights for the Westchester Handicap were announced yesterday, and are as follows:

One of the strongest arguments against laws absolutely prohibiting the sale of intoxicating liquors, especially in large cities, is that it is impossible to enforce them, and the result is the lack of such a degree of restriction as might be maintained.

ALBANY, June 2,--Senator Hendricks kept back the report in favor of the passage of the Subway bill for a long time, and did not bring it in until United States Senator Hiscock saw him. It is reported that Jake Hess got Hiscock to work upon Hendricks.
VIENNA, June 2.--The breaking of the dykes of the Theiss River has resulted in the submerging of 50 miles of the Alfold Plain, near Szegedin. It is estimated that the damage will reach 1,000,000.
ALBANY, N.Y., June 2.--Gov. Hill to-day announced the following hearings to be given at the Executive Chamber:

DETROIT, June 2.--The resumption of work in the large stove manufactories in this city simultaneously with other cities is not being accomplished very satisfactorily. The men upon offering themselves yesterday for re-employment were uniformly told that they would be expected to employ "bucks."

Mrs. M.J. Hawley, of 1,814 Third-avenue, wrote to THE TIMES recently asking for information as to whether sickness could be urged as an excuse for non-payment of rent. Other particulars stated in her letter led to investigation, ...
CHICAGO, June 2.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Chicago and Northwestern Railway Company was held at its office in this city to-day.

The report was yesterday received that Vicar Warren, of Trinity Church, Lambeth, had sent a conditional acceptance to a call extended to him by the Church of the Holy Trinity, NewYork, from which the Rev. Dr. Watkins has lately resigned. It was, however, authoritatively denied last evening that any call had been given as yet.

ST. LOUIS, June 2.--The Republican to-day publishes a number of letters which it obtained from a prominent Irish Nationalist, and which purport to have been written by British agents in this country to the Legation in Washington and the authorities at Scotland Yard. The first, addressed "My dear Sir Charles," says:

Magdalena Zorn, the pretty little 10-year old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Winand Zorn, who wandered away from her associates during the picnic near One Hundred and Ninety-second street last Saturday, has not yet been found...
CHICAGO, June 2.--Senator John Sherman arrived here from Springfield this morning and spent most of the day quietly at the Grand Pacific Hotel.

At the annual meeting of the Holland Society of New-York at the Hotel Brunswick, Tuesday, the following officers were elected: President--Judge Hooper C. Van Vorst; VicePresidents--New-York, Robert B. Roosevelt;

It was suggested a few years ago that a Young Men's Christian Association tent should be erected at Peekskill, adjoining the State encampment. The innovation could not be effected, however, owing to the various obstacles.

LONDON, June 2.--Mr. Gladstone started for Wales to-day, where he will deliver a series of addresses in favor of home rule for Ireland. He arrived at Swansea this evening and was enthusiastically welcomed at all the places at...

A good start was made in the trial of Adolf Reich for the murder of his wife April 19 at 144 Norfolk-street, before Recorder Smyth, in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday. The two additional jurors were obtained without difficulty. Mrs. Julia Cook, the daughter of the janitress, and Cecilia Neumann, who lived next door to the Reichs, testified to the finding of Mrs. Reich's body.

WASHINGTON, June 2.--In recent Washington dispatches to THE TIMES reference was made to a communication from Mr. Henry W. Elliott, of the Smithsonian Institution, on the question of whether Behring Sea had been treated by Russia, prior to the sale of Alaska to the United States, as a closed sea, and whether the United States had acquiesced in such a claim.
The crowd of politicians who filled the Court of sessions in Brooklyn yesterday in anticipation of some startling piece of news from the Grand Jury had its expectations fully realized.
The Irish societies of the city gave a public reception in the Academy of Music last night to William O'Brien, editor of United Ireland, and Dennis Kilbride, the evicted tenant.

DAYTON, Ohio, June 2.--While the drill was at work in the well of the Citizens' Natural Gas and Oil Company, about 4 o'clock this morning, on the Mumma farm, near Trotwood Station six miles west of here, an enormous pocket of gas was liberated in shale rock at a depth of 550 feet.

Not Episcopalians alone, but members of all religious sects, and even men who confess allegiance to no church in particular, were favorably impressed yesterday upon reading the appeal of Bishop Potter for contributions with which to erect a great cathedral commensurate with the dignity of New-York City.
There was a disappointed bride and a highly indignant father on Wednesday night at the home of Thomas McCoy, l7 Columbus-place, Brooklyn.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., June 2.--Four years ago the 12-year-old son of Cass Berry, of Grand Valley, was kidnapped by a colored man and woman. The boy was at school. The man and woman called at the schoolhouse and called for Frankie Berry.

The fact came to light yesterday that attempts had been made to corrupt persons who stood a chance of serving on the Sharp jury. These efforts could not be traced to Jacob sharp himself, but they were traced toward friends of his. None of the persons approached have succeeded in getting a place on the jury.

John Hussey, better known as "Captain Jack" Hussey, gate keeper at Castle Garden, and widely known as a courageous and bemedaled life saver, was dangerously wounded last night by Policeman Edward Hahn, of the Twelfth Precinct.

ATHENS, Tenn., June 2.--The first sale of lots on the grounds of the Athens Mining and Manufacturing Company was held to-day, and the sales aggregated $100,000. A new town will be built, the company guaranteeing to build factories costing $500,000.
MALONE, N.Y., June 2.--Ex-vice-President William A. Wheeler is dying. He is unconscious, and, while he may live several days, his death at any moment would not be unexpected.
A meeting of the depositors of the Rahway Savings Institution has been called for Saturday night, when a final effort will be made to compel a settlement from the managers.

The members of the Committee on Contested Seats of the Republican County Committee met last evening in the headquarters of the Thirteenth Assembly District Republicans, on Eighth-avenue, just above Twenty-third-street, to consider the Thirteenth Assembly District troubles.

The State Board of Arbitration began yesterday the investigation into the causes of the look-out of the silverworkers by the manufacturers. John Fearn, who was employed as a chaser with the Whiting Manufacturing Company, said that the trouble began last Fall when the chasers asked for an increase of 25 per cent. ...

In the nine suits brought by John J. McComb to foreclose his mortgages upon the Navarro apartment houses he is opposed, not only by Jose F. de Navarro, the originator of the enterprise, but by many men who were led to purchase apartments in the four westerly buildings.

PITTSBURG, June 2.--The east-bound express train on the Pittsburg and Western Railroad ran into a car of lumber last evening, badly wrecking the engine, but not damaging the coaches. Engineer Al shook, of this city, was crushed to death was seriously but not fatally hurt. None of the passengers were injured. The accident was caused by the lumber car dropping from a siding to the main track.

The Middle States lawn tennis championship games for a handsome silver cup valued at $250, presented by the St. George Cricket Club, commenced yesterday on the grounds of the St. George Club at Hoboken. The threatening weather prevented a large attendance and little enthusiasm was shown.

The committee having in charge the arrangements for the centennial celebration of Franklin and Marshall Collage, of Lancaster, Penn., June 12-16, has issued an invitation and programme which has in one sense the charm of novelty and antiquity.

Acting under orders received from Superintendent Murray, the police of the Twentysecond Precinct, at 11:30 o'clock last night, made a raid on the gambling house at l,560 Broadway, of which William Davis is the reputed proprietor.
DETROIT, Mich., June 2.--The affairs of Judge Follett at Grand Rapids continue to grow worse as the investigation progresses, and it is doubtful if the shortages fall less than $30,000.

In the Reynolds case yesterday the crossexamination of Architect smith did not materially alter his direct testimony. James B. Sules, employed by the Domestic Sewing Machine Company testified that but little could be told from the remnants found in the ruins of the Flushing cottage as to the quality of the machine destroyed.

BOSTON, June 2.--The Butler Club was fully organized at the Revere House this afternoon, for purposes, as Col. Noah Plympton announced, "of no political significance whatever." The Butler men gathered from all over the state.
Gen. William Cutting's accounts as Executor of the estate of his father, and of the estate of his brother, Hayward Cutting, were yesterday the further subject of inquiry before Referee Cole.

TOMBSTONE, Arizona, June 2.--Senor Campa, who has just arrived from Nacosari, states that authentic news has reached Oposura that at the time of the first earthquake a volcano broke out on the Chihuahua side of the Sierra Madre Mountains, near Piedras Verdes, and...
INDIANAPOLIS, June 2.--The Vandalia sale is generally regarded as an accomplished fact, and the question is how such a strong Pennsylvania man as Mr. McKeen could ever consent to such a transfer.

The "Books that have Helped Me" article in the June number of the Forum is by Andrew Lang, who, so far as the great problems and trials of life are concerned, questions if books can really help any one save in the way of sympathy. Each man, he says, must face the world for himself.

NEW-HAVEN, June 2.--A.A. Stagg, the famous pitcher of the Yale ball nine, was badly hurt in the game with Torrington on the Yale field this afternoon. While batting, a ball delivered by the Torrington pitcher with great force struck him in the small of the back, and he had to be carried to a seat. A physician was called, but he cannot as yet tell how seriously the young man was hurt.
Mr. Joseph W. Harper, Jr., gave a breakfast yesterday at the University Club to about 20 gentlemen, invited to meet Mr. James R. Osgood, who is to sail for London on Saturday.

ALBANY, June 2.--Attorney-General O'Brien, at the request of Bank Superintendent Paine, made application to Justice Williams, at Syracuse, on the 1st inst., for the appointment of a Receiver of the property and effects of the Farmers' Bank of Fayetteville.

Miss. Lillian Russell took homeopathic pills from a dainty little glass bottle and ate them all the time that Eugene H. Lewie examined her yesterday in the supplementary proceedings arising from the judgment obtained against Miss. Russell by Mme. Pauline Godchaux for $802 28.

The Chamber of Commerce yesterday held its last regular meeting before October. As William P. Clyde has declined to become one of the Pilot Commissioners it was voted to hold a special meeting of the Chamber June 9 to elect his successor.
CONCORD, N.H., June 2.--The inauguration of Gov. Sawyer occupied the attention of the legislators and politicians to-day, but still there was plenty of work done, as opportunity offered.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., June 2.--When the sun rose this morning over the mountain tops to the east of Saranac Lake that sheet of water was as calm as the face of a mirror, and it reflected sky, the blue mountains, and the emerald shores with exquisite clearness and minuteness.

WHEELING, West Va., June 2.--A terrible tragedy, growing out of a quarrel between two lovers, occurred at the residence of Mr. Thomas Berg, a few miles from Parkersburg, this evening. Sherman Law, a wealthy young farmer, was the lover of Lizzie, the eldest daughter of Mr. Berg, and this evening he called to see her.

No organization will be earlier in the political field than the Prohibitionists this year. They think that late events have worked to their advantage and intend that no time shall be lost in making effective use of them.
Wall-street had something of a lively day yesterday. The bears were responsible for the liveliness, with Deacon S.V. White for then leader.

READING, Penn., June 2.--During last night a crowd of 50 determined men left Annville for Lebanon to lynch William Showers, the murderer of his two grandchildren, now in jail there. They were joined by 150 more from Lebanon, and marched through the streets for the purpose of storming the jail.

The appeal of Bishop POTTER, published in yesterday's TIMES, "To the citizens of New-York," takes the project of a Protestant cathedral in this city for the first time into the sphere of public discussion. Heretofore it has been regarded as a matter to...

Although the plan of the National India Rubber Trust has been adopted, with the capital stock and executive officers agreed upon, the general feeling in trade circles yesterday was that the great scheme would never be finally consummated.

The St. Louis Browns, champions of the American Association, won another game from the Brooklyns at Washington Park yesterday. Good, faithful work marked the play of the Brooklyn men, but they were overmatched, and the well trained players form the West won by 9 to 5.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 2.--It has just become known that the Standard Oil Company has bought all the property and franchises of the Middletown Gaslight Company. The price is said to be about $80,000.
The Charleston Herald records the death, near Westfield, Ill., of James C. Bennett, who was taken ill with tootache, which led to vomiting and finally resulted in paralysis of the brain.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 2.--The senate this afternoon pardoned Charles C. Brockway, a noted forger and one of the most clever in the country. He was sentenced in October, 1880, for five years, and in 1885 entered upon a further term of three years. This latter lacks, therefore, nearly a year and a half of expiration. Pardon is granted in view of his long imprisonment and good behavior.

"Jimmy" Hope, one of the Manhattan Bank burglars, arrived last evening from California in charge of two detectives. Hope had just completed a term of imprisonment in California when his extradition to this State was arranged for. He escaped from Auburn Prison three years before he had served out his time there, and it is possible that he will complete his unfluished term there before he is tried for the Manhattan Bank burglary.
Herrmann, the magician, will give his entertainment at the Bijou Opera House next week. The last performance of "Adonis," therefore, will be given on Saturday night.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., June 2.--The steamboat Queen City, owned by the New-Orleans and Bayou Teche Steamboat Company, was destroyed by fire this morning. The loss is $15,000; insurance, $10,000, in foreign companies.

Miss. Mari Imogene Eidlitz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leopold Eidlitz, was married to Walter Dannat Starr at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning, in St. Ann's Church, in East Twelfthstreet. Mr. Starr is the younger son of Mrs. Mary C.D. Starr, founder and manager of the House of the Holy Family, 136 second-avenue.

Two mysterious packages, one directed to Inspector Byrnes, the other to H.K. Book, 22 State-street, this city, were given to John McGuire, a driver for Haydick's Express, in Jersey City, last night. The driver's suspicious were aroused and he carried the packages to Police Headquarters.

WASHINGTON, June 2.--Superior batting and brilliant fielding enabled the Washington to secure a creditable victory over the New-York team to-day. Whitney was at his best, and had he been properly supported the visitors would have been shut out. Welch was batted hard at opportune stages of the game, allowing the home team to earn 4 runs.
AUSTIN, Texas, June 2.--John and Cheed Craft, Ike and Bill Ussery, and Charles Buckley, the alleged McNeill train robbers, had a hearing before the United States Commissioner yesterday.
ALBANY, June 2.--Since the repeal of the United States bankrupt law several attempts have been made to amend the insolvency laws of this State so as to prevent the giving of preferences.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 2.--Articles of association were filed at the office of the Secretary of State to-day for the Pekin and Danville Railway Company.

PITTSBURG, June 2.--The conference between the coke operators and striking coke workmen to-day was a failure and the fight will now be continued to the bitter end. The operators said that under no circumstances would they deviate from the decision made by Umpire Jackson.
Col. Robert G. Ingersoll, with several hotel men, called on Mayor Hewitt yesterday and asked him whether the hotels could not be allowed to dispense ale, wine, beer, or liquor to guests on Sunday.

ROME, June 2.--The French Government has telegraphed to the Vatican approving the appointment of Mgr. Rotelli as Papal Nuncio at Paris. Mgr. Rotelli has been instructed to endeavor to restore amity between France and the Vatiean.
The Lenox homestead, on the northeast corner of Twelfth-street and Fifth-avenue, has been sold to the Boards of Foreign and Home Missions of the Presbyterian Church.
A committee of the Mercantile Exchange yesterday asked Mayor Hewitt to prevent the sale of produce on sundays.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2.--The Rev. John Cox, an assistant priest connected with the Church of Our Lady of the Visitation, at Lehighavenue and Leamy-street, was drowned in the Delaware, off Chester Island, yesterday, by the upsetting of a small sailboat.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 2.--At the session of the Synod of the Reformed Presbyterian Church of America here to-day the following officers were elected: Moderator--Prof. D.B. Wilson, of the Allegheny Seminary, Pittsburg, Penn.; Clerks--the Rev. M. Sommerville...

We must once more ask the indulgence of our readers for not keeping up our quotations from the Republican press of tributes to the loyalty, manliness, sincerity, and sound Republicanism of the Hon. THOMAS C. PLATT.

Exchange politics occupied a good part of the time of members of the Produce Exchange yesterday. A lively canvass was held in the afternoon and a ticket was nominated for the annual election next week. Alexander E. Orr, representing the grain trade, was put up for President; C. C. Burke, petroleum, for Vice-President; Edward C. Rice, flour and grain, for Treasurer; for ...

OTTAWA, June 2.--An arctic village, sustained by a little trade in lumber and a Legislature. There has been a coolness between the capital of the Dominion and Prof. Goldwin Smith since he so described Ottawa; still the place manifests no special warmth for any one in Winter and Goldwin Smith probably visited it at that season of the year.

PITTSBURG, June 3.--The puddlers employed at the National Rolling Mill, McKeesport, Penn., struck to-day for a 10 per cent. advance in wages, and the puddlinq department has been closed down. Several hundred men are idle.
HARTFORD, Conn., June 3.--The management of the New-York, New-Havon and Hartford Railroad has to-day ordered the Sunday morning newspaper train discontinued.
The first open air ball of the season was held last evening in Battery Park. Raynes's Sixty-ninth Regiment band furnished the music, and everyone of any importance in down-town society was there.

A sale of horses and ponies at the Madison-Square Garden yesterday bY John H. Draper Co. attracted a large attendance, but the prices paid were not very large. The Percheron stallion Raspail, sire Pierrot, dam Couronne, age 11 year, 17 hands high, and weight 1,800 pounds, ...
The Independence Day Association of Harlem held another enthusiastic meeting last night. They are making extensive preparations to properly celebrate the Fourth of July.

The following letter from the Hon. R.B. Hubbard was received by the Rev. W.K. Marshall, and as it contains information concerning the evangelization of the Japanese Empire that may prove of interest to ministers and church members we publish it entire: ...
Thomas F. Nevins is no longer Chief of the Brooklyn Fire Department. He asked Commissioner Ennis yesterday to relieve him from duty pending his trial for grand larceny, and his request was granted.

J.W. Morris, a saloon passenger on the Inman steamship City of Chester, which arrived yesterday from Liverpool, disappeared about 5:30 o'clock in the morning, when the vessel was nearing Sandy Hook, and it supposed to have fallen overboard.

ROME, June 3.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day the Minister of War, in the course of a debate on the proposal to grant 7,000,000 lire for the expenses of the troops in Africa, stated that the Government was determined to retain ...

ALBANY, June 3.--The Court of Appeals will meet in Saratoga next Monday. The calendar for that day is as follows: Nos. 416, 417, 372, 368, 402, 403, 410, 411. Tuesdays, June 7 and 21, are motion days.

WASHINGTON, June 3.--First Lieut, Leonard Wood, Assistant Surgeon, has been relieved from temporary duty at Los Angeles, Cal., and ordered to temporary duty at Fort Huachuca, Arizona, Capt. Paul R. Brown, Assistant Surgeon, has been granted leave of absence for four months.

The New-York City and Northern Railroad Company was put into the hands of Arthur Leary as Receiver in 1882, and in 1885 into the hands of Joel B. Erhardt as Receiver, the latter proceeding being on foreclosure proceedings begun by the Central Trust Company, the Trustee of its mortgage bonds.

SALEM, N.J., June 3.--Sarah Bradshaw, a colored girl aged 18, was arrested in this city this morning charged with having killed her grandmother, Deborah Bradshaw, at Millington, Del., on April 16. Sheriff Hatcheson, of Kent County, Del., traced her to this city.

Capt. Jack Hussey, the life saver, of Castle Garden, who was shot Thursday night by Policeman Edward Hahn, passed a quiet night at Gouverneur Hospital. A great many people called yesterday to see him, but Dr. O'Hanlon would not permit them to do so. Only his wife and brother were admitted.

CHICAGO, June 3.--George Hankins, of this city, has bought the 2-year-old filly Huntress, by Springbok, out of Edith, at Latonia for $5,000. Last night he purchased the ch. c. Santalence, formerly St. Helena.

The great gift which it was rumored was to be made for the benefit of Winsted by the Hon. William L. Gilbert is now said to be about to take form in the endowment of an educational institution for girls, which will have an endowment of $400,000.

It will be news to most people that Chauncey M. Depew is entitled to rank as a veteran of the war. He earned that distinction, however, by having been ordered to Washington in 1861 with the Eighteenth Regiment, of which he was Adjutant. He obeyed orders, and so became entitled to say that he had been in service.
PEEKSKILL, May 31.--Gen. James W. Husted's memorable change of base from Rockland to Westchester County is about to he duplicate in an even more remarkable, if not more daring, flight.

The Police Commissioners yesterday received a letter from the Mayor asking about the presentment made by the Grand Jury in 1883 against Capts. Williams and Allaire, and what action, if any, was taken. The chief clerk was directed to furnish the information requested.
No tidings of James H. Campbell, the young mechanic who failed to turn up at the hour he was to have been married to Nellie McCoy, of 17 Columbus-place, Brooklyn had been received yesterday.
The Metropolitans played their first game since their return from the West at Staten Island yesterday in the presence of a large number of persons.

BELVIDERE, N.J., June 3.--Mrs. Rachel Teets, of Fairmount, who has just died, in her ninety-second year, left a remarkably large number of descendants. She was married at the age of 18 to Peter R. Teets, and in 25 years became the mother of 20 children-- 10 boys and 10 girls--17 of whom are still living. At the date of her demise she had 60 living grandchildren and a number of great-grandchildren.

Mr. George Kennan contributes to the June number of the Centruy what is probably its most note worthy article, an account of a personal visit to Toistoi, on his estate in Russia, about one night's ride south from Moscow.

Everybody who considers the question must, we think, agree that it is desirable, upon purely secular grounds, to reduce to a minimum the amount of labor done on Sunday. The man who loses his Sunday is supposed to have it made up to him on a secular day, but in many branches of business ...

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., June 3.--In the trial of Barclay Peak to-day the most important witness for the defense was Amanda Peak, aged 14 years the defendant's sister, who told a comparatively straight story in regard to the whereabouts of the defendant on the night of the shooting.

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 3.--Freight train No. 119 crashed into the caboose of a construction train at Esopus, eight miles south of this city, on the West Shore Railroad, this afternoon. The locomotive or the construction train was having its water tank replenished, when the freight train came around the bend, just north of the station at a lively rate of speed.
Col. Robert G. Ingersoll, counsel for the Hotel Keepers' Association, appeared before the Board of Police yesterday and presented the following document:

The terms of the eight Bridge Trustees credited to Brooklyn expire to-day, and yesterday Mayor Whitney, Controller Livingston, and Auditor Rutan appointed their successors. This action was only a formality, for seven of the eight Trustees mere reappointed.
Gen. Armstrong's annual report of the Hampton School, just made, has even more than the ordinary amount of interest which would naturally attach to it.

The General Executive Board and General Master Workman Powderly, having emptied their vials of wrath upon District Assembly No. 126 by expelling them from the Knighte of Labor, have now turned their attention to Mr. Higgins, who employs a large number of the members of No. 126.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3.--Robert G. Hall, an ex-variety actor, at 7 o'clock this morning shot twice and killed Lillian Rivers, wife of James Rivers, actor and playwright. While the woman was still gasping he cut her throat from ear to ear, nearly severing the head from the body. He then gashed his own throat, cutting deep into the guilet, and causing a ghastly wound, which may end in his death before morning.
VIENNA, June 3.--The Aligemeine Zeitung mentions a project which has been hinted at to make the Pope King of Palestine under a guarantee of protection on his throne by all the Catholic powers.
LONDON, June 3.--The steamship Argosy, (Br.,) Capt. Atchison, from New-York May 17, for London, passed Lizard Point to-day.

There was a much larger assemblage at the st. George's Ground, Hoboken, N.J., yesterterday to witness the tennis play in the second day of the Middle State lawn tennis championship. The grounds were in splendid condition, and all the players were satisfied.

ALBANY, June 3.--Gov. Hill signed to-day Senator Walker's bills authorizing a bank to change its name and any bank to change its location. Senator Plunkitt was pleased by obtaining the Governor's signature to his bill imposing an additional tax of $1,500 yearly on the city of New-York, in the shape of an officer to be known as Notaries' Clerk.

CATSKILI, N.Y., June 3.--To-day at the General Synod of the Reformed Church in America the Rev. Dr. T.W. Chambers and Judges Bookstaver and Danforth were appointed the committee to investigate the irregular transfer of the Reformed Church of Canastota, N.Y., to the Presbytery of Syracuse.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 3.--An earthquake swept over the greater portion of Northern California and Western Nevada between 2 and 3 o'clock this morning. Reports from different points seem to place the centre of the ware at some place an the boundary line between the two States.

The crowd flocks to the "Zoo" in the Central Park, the Museum of Art, and its neighbor, the obelisk, attracting attention next, while only a comparatively few find their way to the Museum of natural History, on Eighth-avenue and Seventy-ninth-street, where, by the way, is one of the most interesting exhibitions of the ...

HARRISBURG, Penn., June 3.--Leading members of the Legislature, Sonators and Representatives, irrespective of politics, unite in urging on Gov. Beaver the propriety and necessity of calling an extra session for the purpose of re-enacting the General Revenue bill, which, as discovered by the Governor this week, failed ...

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 3.--The Presbytery of Hudson met in adjourned session in this town to receive and take action on the report of a commission previously appointed to hear testimony in the case of the Rev. A.A. Schaberhorn, Pastor of the Clarkstown and Nyack German Presbyterian Churches, who was ...

There is in all New-York but one firm devoting itself exclusively to the trade in mourning goods. This lack of competition is explained when one makes an examination of the stock at Jackson's, 777 Broadway, between Ninth and Tenth streets.

BOSTON, June 3.--Franklin J. Moses, who, as Governor of South Carolina, at one time occupied a large share of public attention, but who is now an occupant of the Massachusetts state Prison, has been pardoned by Gov. Ames, ...

Henry Prouse Cooper, the tailor, who has figured in the courts on many occasions, was arrested yesterday on complaint of his brother, David Cooper, that he is ahabitual drunkard. At the Tombs Justice Duffy committed him to the Fort Hamilton Iebriate Asylum. No examination was had, and the case was disposed of very quietly.

TRENTON, N.J., June 3.--Caleb Swayze, of Hope, Warren County, who has been identified for years with the business interest of the neighborhood, has transferred his property and is virtually a bankrupt.

The carpenters who belong to the open trade unions and the Progressive Carpenters' Association, which is attached to District Assembly 49, are at loggerheads. The union men are the upper dog in this fight, as they are far more numerous than the Knights of No. 49. The unionists call the latter "scabs," and refuse to recognize their working cards or to work with them.

The question of Henry Ward Beecher's successor as Pastor of Plymouth Church was discussed at some length, last eveing at a business meeting of the church, held after the usual Friday night prayer meeting. Thomas J. Tilney presided and Prof. R.W. Raymond, on behalf of the Advisory Committee appointed some ...

OTTAWA, June 1.--The Premier of Canada, Sir John A. Macdonald, or as he is familiarly-- one might say lovingly--called, "The Old Man," stands in the same relation to the Dominion as Bismarck does to Germany and as Disraeli did to England.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 3.--Mr. Henry S. Ives was seen to-day in reference to the recent deal of the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Railroad, and asserted positively that the transaction was completed.

CHICAGO, June 3.--Assistant State Veternarian Williams, of Bloomington, is investigating a strange horse disease in De Witt County which is believed to have been contracted from imported Norman horses, and finds there is very grave cause for alarm unless the greatest care is taken in the matter of quarantine.

TROY, N.Y., June 3.--A gentleman named Nugent, said to be connected with the City Government of New-York, arrived in this city to-day in pursuit of his daughter, Mary, a girl of 18. He found her living with Leonard H. Wager, a well known man about town.
PROSPECT HOUSE, Upper Saranac Lake, N.Y., June 3.--This has been a very quiet and uneventful day for the President's party.

The frail little Italian woman, Chiara Cignarale, who last week was tried and convicted of killing her husband Oct. 20, 1886, by a pistol shot, was sentenced yesterday in the Court of General Sessions by Recorder Smyth to be handed Friday, July 22.

Mrs. M.J. Hawley, of whose troubles THE TIMES spoke yesterday, was much surprised and moved last evening when given the subscriptions that had been received, amounting to $23. She had not seen the paper and did not know that any effort was making to assist her.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 3.--At 1:45 o'clock to-day a colored man by the name of Martin, who lived on Gilmer-street, fell from the new Capitel to the around below, a distance of 75 feet, and was instantly killed. He went to work Monday as a mortar roller, and was rolling a wheelbarrow full of mortar upon the scaffolding when he lost his balance and fell to the ground.

The Faculty of Columbia College took action yesterday in the cases of a Senior, a Junior, a Sophomore, and five Freshmen who were charged with a disturbance in front of the college Tuesday morning, when the candidates for the next Freshman Class appeared for examination.

Constable Ayers late Thursday night arrested Henry Frank in Williamsburg on a warrant charging him with being implicated in the supposed murder of Capt. Thomas Carpenter on the schooner Long Island in November last.

WEST POINT, June 3.--Nothing could be more buautiful than the appearance which West Point presented this morning. Refreshed by days of heavy rain, after a long parching period of many weeks, during which budding life was slowly burned out by the scorching rays of a ...

There was a goodly attendance at last night's meeting of the Tammany Hall General Committee. Gen. John Cochrane presided. A report was submitted from the Committee on Organization, embracing the resolutions denouncing the attacks on William O'Brien while ...

The alleged efforts on the part of various parties to treat the Sharp jury with the same allopathic freedom with which the Aldermen were influenced created something of a sensation in Judge Barrett's court yesterday. Nc sooner had the court convened than Mr. Parsons rose with a prefaced statement relative to the reports of attempts at bribery mentioned in the ...
WATERTOWN, N.Y., June 3.--The latest reports of the condition of ex-Vice-President Wheeler sate taht he is yet alive, but unconscious and gradually sinking. His death is expected at any womens.

LONDON, June 3.--Nineteen 2-year-olds started in the race for the Whitsuntide Plate of 5,000 sovereigns, which was run at Manchester to-day. Douglas Baird's Briarroot, a bay filly by Springfield, out of Eglentyne, and a seventeen to one chance in ...

The entries for the hurdle stakes to be run at the Sheepehead Bay track during the Coney Island Jockey Club's June meeting have closed. The nominations give promise of some good sport, as all the good performers over the sticks are in the list, which is as follows:
CLEVELAND, June 3.--Prof. William H. Woolery, of Bdethany College, has been elected president of Hirma College, at Hiram, Ohio.

CONCORD, N.H., June 3.--The Senatorial canvass monopolizes the entire attention of the Legislature, and very little business will be done until that question is disposed of. This morning the Legislature adjourned until Monday, but few legislators left the city.

MONTREAL, Canada, June 3.--The results of O'Brien's visit are showing themselves more plainly every day in the bitter feeling that has been stirred up between the different sections of our population. The propriety of the agitation is being discussed more acrimoniously than ever.

The report sent to our State Department by the Commercial Agent of the United States at New-Caledonia would be almost incredible if it were merely the repetition of a rumor or a warning based upon the agent's opinion.

WASHINGTON, June 3.--The irrepressible Ottawa correspondent who persists in forwarding "specials," in which he depicts the Canadian dependency of the British Government as an independent and sovereign power, gravely considering treaties and negotiating modifications thereof, has become almost as much an institution as Joe Mulhatten's stories of skeletons ...

The Chicago Zouaves, Company E, Fourth Regiment, Illinois National Guard, winners of the first prize, $1,000, for zouave drill at the recent contests at Washington, gave an exhibition drill at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night.

It was reported at North Salem, Westchester County, that a female school teacher had been criminally assaulted yesterday near Jesse R. Grant's place. The house in which the crime was committed was the scene of a similar occurrence June 13, 1883.

Morris Marx, the man covicted of killing Mrs. Hrokowsky at 22 Attorney-street by throwing vitriol over her as she lay asleep, was sentenced yesterday to 20 years at hard labor in State prison by Recorder Smyth in the Court of General Sessions.
PITTSBURG, Penn., June 3.--A meeting of the stockholders of the Eads Ship Railway of Tehaunte. pec will be called on the arrival home of Col. James Andrews, of Allegheny City.

BOSTON, June 3.--After a week of fog andeast wind the off-shore breeze so impatiently desired by Commodore Hovey for a start upon his trip across the water, came this morning. The Commodore and Mr. Charles A. Longfellow, his only cabin companion on the voyage, were on board early, but were delayed by the nonarrival of Commodore Weld, of the Gitana, ...

There were probably more people yesterday in Pierrepont Park--a pleasant, shady spot at the foot of Pierrepont-street, Brooklyn--than had ever been there before. Each one paid $1 for the privilege of entering, and the money was turned over to the building fund of the Home for Consumptives.

Racing was resumed at Brighton Beach yesterday, and the chief feature was Barnum's winning the mile and a quarter race, as every one expected he would. Possibly the stable was short of oats. The results of the races were as follows:
The Prisciila has been invited to start in the annual regatta of the Atlantic Yacht Club on Monday and has accepted the invitation. Her competitors will be the Galatea and Atlantic.

CHICAGO, June 3.--It is alleged that the wholesale dressed beef handlers at the stock yards are very much interested in the continuance of the present quarantine against Cook County, and that five of them, in fact, are making from $10,000 to $30,000 a day each as an extra profit accruing indirectly from the quarantine restrictions.

Senator JOHN SHERMAN is perhaps the most maladroit statesman who ever set about the task of capturing a Presidential nomination. Shortly after the adjournment of Congress Mr. SHERMAN made an extended trip through the South-purely for his health and recreation, so he at first protested.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., June 3.--To-day's session of the wheat market was one of sharp excitement and the bears were thrown into a panic, Yesterday a demand was made upon those who had sold buyer the year contracts short for 10,000 tons of actual, and the option was given these sellers to settle for cash in case ...
NORWAY, Me., June 3.--The Rev. W.C. Stiles, the missing clergyman, of pittsfield, N.H., arrived here this afternoon, and is at his mother's house apparently demented.
A parts of 300 persons representing the Bohemian Turners of this city, who are going to attend the great annual games at Prague, will sail this morning on the North German Lloyd steamship Werra.

PARIS, June 3.--The Republic Franaise, commenting on the convention between England and Turkey in relation to Egypt, says: "France is not ambitions regarding Egypt. She will always contend that Egyptian territory is Inviolable as regards all nations."

The jury in the Anderson will case went out to deliberate upon their verdict at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon. At 6 o'clock they had not agreed, and Judge Lawrence ordered them to bring in a sealed verdict at 10:30 o'clock this forenoon.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, June 3.--It has just come to light that Charles M. Sterling, a tramp, who was hanged on April 21 for the murder of Miss Lizzie Grombacher, was judicially murdered. At his first trial the jury disagreed and was discharged, and in ignorance or violation of the Supreme Court decisions and the Ohio statute, the reasons for the jury's discharge were not journalized by the court Clerk.

The death of Frank Sullivan at the Newark City Hospital last Saturday will, it is believed, probably lead to an official investigation. Sullivan was admitted to the hospital on May 25, suffering, as his friends claim, from acute ...

The demonstration in honor of William O'Brien by the Central Labor Union and District Assembly No. 49, which will take place this evening, promises to be a great affair. The procession will be headed by the Sixty-ninth Regiment, Col. Cavanagh commanding, and Daniel S. Jacobs, an active labor organizer, has been ...

PHILADELPHIA, June 3.--The convention which will be held in this city to-morrow by the 10 expelled local assemblles belonging to District Assembly No. 126 promises to develop the most significant results bearing on the future history of the Knights of Labor.

LEXINGTON, Ky., June 3.--A Smith McCann, of this city, has sold to W.C. France, of Fayette County, the full sister to Phil Thompson for $3,000, and three yearlings sired by Red Wilkes for $1,000 each.

CHICAGO, June 3.--T.B. Geddes sent a gold watch by mail to M. Huffmann, a Quiney jeweler, to repair. Huffmann said he had not received it, and the Post Office Inspectors, after weeks of search, found the watch in another jewelry store at Quiney.

The case of Dorothea Horn, who keeps an intelligence office, at 168 Third-avenue, came up at the Tombs yesterday. Josephine Ehrenrich, aged 17, told how, on May 18, she went with Mrs. Hanbrandt, to a house in Jersey City, how she was tempted by the offer of money, how she was drugged, and how she finally escaped from the house and returned to the city.

Theresa McNabb, a domestic employed at 2 West Sixteenth-street, found in the area of the house, late last night, a basket in which was a male infant about 2 years old. It is a remarkably handsome child and wore a beautifully embroidered dress and a silk cap. The little stranger was intrusted to the care of Matron Webb, at Police Headquarters.
When Mrs. George W. Bland, who lives at 140 Prince-street, Brooklyn, went to her kitchen at 7:30 o'clock yesterday morning she discovered the servant, Mary Cox, sitting in a chair near the sink dead.

PITTSUBURG, Penn., June 3.--The exodus of Chinamen from the Pacific coast has assumed such proportions that it now exceeds that of any previous year. The through trains on the Fort Wayne Railroad bring in regularly every morning from 15 to 20 of them.

The St. Louis Browns won another game from the Brooklyn team at Washington Park yesterday. Terry was hit hard, and the St. Louis men ran the bases in their usual daring manner. At times the local players showed up to good advantage, but the superiority of their opponents manifested itself, and they were forced to succumb. Score:

The salute fired on Thursday by the French frigate Minerve was answered yesterday morning from the fort on Governor's Island. col. S.G. Tassin and Lient. S.E. Allen, on behalf of Gen. Schofield, visited the Minerve and invited Capt. Mervard to visit Governor's Island.

The case of the three Pinkerton detectives--Sheehey, Neff, and Moriarty--charged with having killed young Thomas Hogan during the recent strike troubles in Jersey City, was given to the jury yesterday morning. District Attorney Winfield had already declared that he would ask no verdict against Moriarty and Neff ...

The Seventeenth Assembly District Republican Club was formally organized last evening at Union Hall, 354 West Forty-fifth-street, by the adoption of a constitution and election of permanent officers. There were about 40 persons present.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 3.--Two carloads of Texas ponies that had been shipped from Texas to Eastern Pennsylvania and which had been wrongly transshipped to Bangor, Me., were unloaded here to day. It is understood that they had been 18 days on the cars without food. Several of the animals were dead when the cars werr opened, and those that were alive were in a terribly emaciated condition. No driver was with them.
People who happened to be in the NewYork Central waiting room yesterday, just before the 6 P.M. train left for the West, had a chance to see popular theatrical persons off the stage.

RICHMOND, Va., June 3.--The Secretary of the Beecher Memorial Association of Brooklyn, in a letter to Mrs. ex-President Tyler, of this city, says that a short time before the death of the great preacher he "in a sermon of rare excellence, delivered ...

It is reported that the Inter-State Commerce Commissioners are gradually coming to a disagreement as to the meaning of the fourth section of the act from which their authority is derived. The language which chiefly gives them trouble is found in the phrase "under substantially similar circumstances and conditions."

Twelve attractive Park View Villa sites, opposite and overlooking Jerome Park, at Fordham, in the Twenty-fourth Ward, will be sold to the highest bidder at the Real Estate Exchange, in Liberty-street, Wednesday, June 8, beginning at noon. The auctioneer on this occasion will be James L. Wells, of 59 Liberty-street, at whose office maps may be seen and full particulars obtained.

All the details of the plan agreed upon for the reorganization of the Jersey Central Railroad Company were perfected yesterday, officially approved by the company's Board of Directors, and made public. Months of diligent labor have been spent upon the scheme; as completed it represents harmony in every quarter.

CHICAGO, June 3.--Among other reforms which the new city administration proposes to inaugurate is the extermination of the Chicago policy and lottery shops. For some time the detective department has had these enterprises under strict surveillance in order to procure evidence sufficient to substantiate charges.

Police Commissioner John McClave, while on the way to his place of business yesterday morning saw a tramp mounting guard at a gate in the part of Twenty-third-street known as London Terrace, and heard another inside the inclosure abusing, in the vilest of tomato-can vernacular, a lady who had seen fit to give him only a few cents.

BERLIN, June 3.--The Kreuz Zeitung says: "In view of the recent events in France the immediate future is looked forward and to with full confidence. Assurance of the maintenance of peace is felt for the first time since last Summer.

TROY, N.Y., June 3.--H.G. Hull, Overseer of the Poor of the town of Berlin, brought to this city on the Fitchburg train to-day an insane woman, whose name could not be ascertained further than that she said it was "Christine." She is about 45 years of age, and had been tramping about Berlin and Stephentown for several days.

The two fixed events at the races at Jerome Park this afternoon are the Ladies' Stakes for 3-year-old fillies at a mile and a quarter and the Westchester Handicap at a mile and three-eighths. These, with three other races on the flat, and a steeplechase over the full course, will make up a very attractive programme and one that should draw a crowd.

BOSTON, June 3.--The United States, through Assistant District Attorney Reed, filed to-day its answer in the case of John S. Lee and others against charles A. Abbey, commander of of the revenue cutter Corwin.

OTTAWA, June 3.--A copy of the dispatch sent by Lord Lansdowne to the British Government on the 21st ult. regarding the seizure of the Canadian sealing schooners in Behring Sea last August by the American revenue cutters was laid before Parliament to-day.

DUBLIN, June 3.--The evictions at Bodyke continue. The tenants are offering all the opposition in their power to the Sheriff and his guard of police and troops, and find various means seriously to annoy the officers. In some of the houses from which the occupants were to be evicted cayenne pepper was burned, the fumes of which nearly choked the bailiffs.

"Jimmy" Hope, the chief of the Manhattan Bank burglars, slept well in his close quarters at Police Headquarters Thursday night, and was closely watched. During the day his wife and his son Harry called and spent two hours with the prisoner.

While driving on Bowery Bay beach yesterday afternoon Charles Grawford, a manufacturer of electrical indicators, of New-York, fell from his seat in the wagon to the ground, striking on his head and breaking his neck. He died a few minutes later.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 3.--The Reformed Presbytorian Synod of America, in session here today, elected the Rev. Dr. R.J. George, of Beaver Falls, to fill the vacancy in the Faculty of the Pittsburg Theological Seminary caused by the death of Prof. Sloans.

The State Board of Arbitration resumed its investigation of the silver workers' strike and lock-out at 9:30 o'clock yesterday morning. CLEVELAND, June 3.--The publication office of the Standard of the Cross, which has been the organ of the Episcopal Church in the Diocese of Ohio almost 20 years, is soon to be removed from this city to Philadelphia.

The Produce Exchange enjoyed the luxury of another caucus yesterday afternoon. Although the meeting indorsed most of the ticket nominated the day before, it was a very lively session, and the voting was energetic enough to take the root off a less substantially built structure.

A meeting of the gossamer rubber manufacturers has just been held at the Parker House, in Boston, the following companies being represented: Mystic, Gossamer, Standard, Sterling, Boston Gossamer, National, Taylor Bloodgood, and the Byers Epauletted Ventilation Company. A resolution was offered that the cheapest waterproof garment made shall not be sold wholesale for less than $1.--Boston Globe.

CHICAGO, June 3.--The New-York Directors of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Road arrived here this morning, and in company with P.D. Armour took a special train at once for Milwaukee. The annual meeting is to be held at the latter point to-morrow. There is much speculation as to who is to succeed Alexander Mitchell as President.

The two firebugs, Townsend and Augustus Johnson, who set fire to Palmer's cooperage, in Williamsburg, last Saturday night, and were arrested and indicted before the fire in the ruins had been quenched, were arraigned in the Sessions Court, Brooklyn, yesterday.

LONDON, June 4.--The first sign of a lack of courtesy which I have seen during the week of yachting just closed was exhibited by the Thames Yacht Club to-day.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 4.--Henry W. Clarke, of this city, has requested the Navy Department to investigate the reported suicide of his son, Lieut. Arthur H. Clarks, on board the Iroquois, at Panama, a few weeks ago.

HARPER, Kan., June 4.--This city was thrown into intense excitement this morning by two distressing incidents. About 6 o'clock this morning the Hon. George D. Thompson was found in an outhouse at his residence with a 44-calibre bull dog revolver in his hand and a bullet hole entirely through his head, the bullet entering at the right temple and passing out at the left.

KEY WEST, Fla., June 4.--Two new cases of yellow fever have occurred since yesterday, but no more deaths. The total number of cases to date is 15; convalescent, 3; now sick, 8; deaths, 4. A great number of strangers left in the steamer to-day for New-York, thus reducing the danger.

BOSTON, Mass., June 4.--The Herald says: "R. Parks, the well known young Boston actor, has been mysteriously missing since Tuesday evening last. E.Y. Backus, of the World company, now playing at the Boston Theatre, is supposed to be the one of Mr. Parks's acquaintances with whom he last talked. The impression has very generally gone abroad that Mr. Parks has committed suicide."

George H. Sutton, the juror in the Sharp trial who reported that he was approached on behalf of the defense, had a talk with District Attorney Martine yesterday. The latter refused to speak of the result of the conversation, but said that on Monday all those persons knowing about any attempt to fix the jury would make their statements in person to Juflge Barrett.

TYRONE, Penn., June 4.--A delayed explosion occurred at the Cambria Iron Company's stone quarries at Birmingham, three miles east of this place, at 2 o'clock this afternoon, resulting in the death of eight men and seriously injuring one other.

OTTAWA, Ill., June 4.--The outcome of the anuual delegate convention of Turners which opens here to-morrow is being awaited with interest by members of Turner societies throughout the country, as it may lead to a split in the National Union.

CEDARTOWN, Ga., June 4.--At Rock Run, Ala yesterday, Alf Woodley shot and killed William Stone and mortally wounded Bob Mills. Stone was a professional gambler and had of late been plying his vocation among the furnace operatives, winning all their money.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 4.--Gen James S. Speed, Who was Attorney-General under President Lincoln, is dangerously ill at his home in this county. The family and physicians state that he can live, but a few days longer. He is almost 80 years of age, and is gradually sinking from mere exhaustion.

LONDON, June, 4.--On Monday the Parlimentary clock will strike 12 again; there will be a rush from the village hustings; the Holyhead boats will be crammed with the returning Irish members, and Westminster will begin to hum with the old babble.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 4.--Fountain George, the murderer of Dr. Epps 12 years ago, died in the penitentiary yesterday. He was sentenced by a jury to be hanged, but appealed to the Supreme Court, which affirmed the verdict of the jury. The day fixed for the execution having passed, it devolved upon Gov. Sherman to fix a day, which he refused to do.

If any one were to ask how the market has acted the past week, the reply would have to be that its tone was bearish, because one or two spells of activity it had were in the direction of lower prices.

WASHINGTON, June 4.--The prettiest game of baseball played here this season was that between the Washington and New-York Clubs to-day, the former winning through good batting. The game was replete with brilliant fielding, no less than six double plays being made, of which the home team made four.

Many depositors of the defunet Rahway (N.J.) Savings Institution met in Rahway last night, with William A. Osborn, of Woodbridge, as Chairman. Dr. E.B. Silvers, of Rahway; J. Hampton, of Metuchen, and Franklin Moorse of Woodbridge, were appointed a committee to advise means to procure a speedy settlement.
Foulard is to be the favorite material for Summer use. There are a numbeer of foulard toilets in all the latest Parisian bridal trousseaux. One of these trousseaux includes six foulard dresses.

Wall-street has just lost one of her most noteworthy characters. News came down town yesterday that "Tom" Warner was dead. For 20 years he was the jolly man of the Stock Exchange district. Once he was rich--a millionaire he was rated; he died poor.

HAZLETON, Penn., June 4.--Frank Ferneler, bookkeeper for D. Yuengling Sons, of this city, has absconded, and his accounts are found to be over $1,000 short. Fernsler's mother was his security, and it is thought the firm will not lose anything.

CHICAGO, Ill., June 4.--Judge Gresham, in a decision concurred in by Justice Harlan, of the Supreme Court, has again overruled Judge Woods, of the Federal District Court at Indianapolis, in what is known as the stallion case, wherein animals valued at $20,000 were seized in Dekalb County for evasior of duty.

Mary Cox, the servant in Mrs. Bland's house at 140 Prince-street, Brooklyn, who was found dead on Friday morning, was buried yesterday afternoon from the house of her sister in Hicks-street. The post-mortem examination showed the presence of arsenic in the stomach, and a flask containing some of that poison was found in the girl's pocket.

There was a stiff wind and a choppy sea at Bowery Bay Beach yesterday, but in spite of, these drawbacks the double scull race between Wallace Ross and George Lee and George Hosmer and John McKay for $1,000 took place.

In nearly all the Sus sex villages not only boys, but grown up and even very aged men, play at marbles on Good Friday. It is considered as wrong to omit this solemn duty as to go without the Christmas pudding, and Queries.
