The Prison Association of this city asks attention to its labors, and will gladly receive donations to push its work onward. To meet the expenses of the year the treasury was emptied, and, while the association is not in debt, unless some gifts are received its work will have to be curtailed in many directions.

PARIS, June 4.--With the exception of the Lanterne, the Justice, and the Intransigeant, the latter filling new vials of wrath every morning, which continue their daily war against M. Rouvier, the Parisian press as a rule gives evidence of a desire to sustain and encourage the new Ministry, while at the same time it seems to be the general conviction that its existence cannot be of long duration.

Stewart and a construction of her will.

Gen. Annenkoff, who superintended the construction of the Central Asian Railway, will leave for Chardhui in a few days, and will arrive there toward the middle of June. The railway through Bokhara will be commenced immediately and pushed forward with the greatest activity. It is thought here that the present state of affairs in Bokhara will not cause any serious difficulty in the construction of the line.

Very few know of the extent of the work carried on among the deaf-mutes of the city which was started in Dr. Gallaudet's church, on West Eighteenth-street. The church mission to deaf-mutes procures situations for those out of work and holds sign services in 25 places.

Mrs. Isabella Keating, a young and attractive woman, came from Babylon, Long Island, last night in hot pursuit of her husband, Oscar, who, she said, eloped on Friday with Matilda Bruce, living at Amityville, Long Island. Mrs. Keating had given her husband $200 to come to New-York to buy out a grocery business.

The Merrimac and Monitor Panorama, on Madison-avenue, is one of the coolest amusement houses open during the Summer months. A huge fan revolves above the spectators' platform, sending refreshing currents of air in every direction. During the past week the exhibition has been well patronized. The panorama will be open as heretofore every day of the week.

LOUIS, Mo., June 4.--While Henry Gaulut, the owner of a large farm about three miles below the southern limit of the city, was working in his field about noon to-day with a hired man known by the name of John, a slight altercation occured and John struck Gaulut over the head with a heavy hoe and, it is thought, fractured his skull.

CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., June 4.--Five more of the Jimtown coke rioters were arrested this morning. NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 4.--Heavy batting and perfect fielding by Yale and weak batting and loose fielding by Princeton gave Yale a championship game this afternoon by a score of 15 to 0. Stagg pitched a remarkable game, keeping Princeton down to one scratch hit. Dann caught Stagg's puzzling delivery without an error, and the field also gave him perfect support.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 4.--The Board of Visitors to the Naval Academy was formally received this morning at 10 o'clock by the Academic Board and officers in charge of the various departments.

The Rutgers College lacrosse team was defeated by the Brooklyn Athletic Club yesterday at New-Brunswick after a hard tussle. In the first half of the game no goal was scored, but after that Brooklyn got 4 goals in succession, and just before time was called Rutgers got 2. Matthews and Roberts played a good game for the winners.

EL PASO, Texas, June 4.--Gen. Lorenzo Vega, the President of the Mexican Military court that sentenced the three Negales invaders to death, is in El Paso, and says that Col. Arvizu, Lieut. Guitterez, and the third prisoner, a civilian, are still in jail at Guaymas, pending an appeal for mercy to the President and Secretary of War in the city of Mexico.

All classes of the Vienna population are deeply moved by the dangerous illness of Dr. Billroth a surgeon of world-wide reputation. Hundreds of students and others stand before his house to hear the latest news. Dr. Billroth is suffering from fatty degeneration of the heart, together with inflammation of the lungs. I am happy to be able to state that the latest news to-night is somewhat better, but his life is still in danger.

LITTLE VALLEY, N.Y., June 4.--The jury in the case of Mrs. Mary Wileman, on trial here for the murder of her husband, retired at 10 o'clock last night. Mrs. Wileman was prostrated during the night, and it was with the greatest difficulty that she walked into the court room this morning.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., June 4.--William Clark and William MacClevartz, the two young married men who knocked down and robbed John Gray, an aged farmer, about a mile south of Medina, last evening, were captured at their homes in Medina at 9 o'clock last night. After the assault they swam the Oak Orchard Creek to escape the farmers who pursued them, and they were easily identified by their wet clothing. They obtained about $20 from Farmer Gray.
PARIS, May 24.--Nine days and the hammer of an auctioneer has broken up that priceless collection which France's sovereigns during three and a half centuries had stored by as national heirlooms.

Tanner, and others to notes amounting to $2,000, which were discounted by a broker here. American railroad securities were quiet, with a tendency to decline, until yesterday, when there were symptoms of an upward reaction.
KRY WEST, Fla., June 5.--T.C. Cragin died of yellow fever at the hospital last night, making five deaths in all. There were two new cases to-day.

LONDON, June 6.--The Thistle, Irex, Genesta, Sleuthhound, Neptune, and Foxhound will take part in the Dover contest to-day. The distance is 44 miles. The Thistle will compete in some of the leading contests at Liverpool before sailing for America. She will not take part in the Jubilee race.

Emil Larsen, aged 9 years, son of Otto Larsen, of 468 Clermont avenue, Brooklyn, was killed last evening while Crossing the track of the Steinway and Hunter's Point Horse Railroad, near Eighthstreet and Jackson-avenue. The boy was frightfully managed, the wheels cutting his head off. the driver of the car. William Buell, was arrested.

CHICAGO, June 5.--Mr. Daly's company carried off the palm in the way of good business at the Chicago playhouses the last week. "Love in Harness" proved a capital medium with which to establish the old-time friendly relations between Mr. Daly and Chicago theatregoers, and the houses were uniformly large.

A trial involving a rather mysterious drama has just come off before the Rhone Assizes. The accused was a young woman of prepossessing appearance named Marechal, who was charged with having caused the death of a Greek sea Captain.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 5.--At an early hour this morning Thomas McCarthy shot Harry Smith, with probably fatal result, in front of the residence of the former in West St. Paul. Smith had been out during the evening with McCarthy's wife, and McCarthy avers he has been showing her altogether too much attention, in spite of frequent warnings to desist. McCarthy was arrested.

MILWAUKEE, June 5.--Despite the efforts of the Milwaukee Merchants' Association to have John Plankinton chosen President of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railway, and to secure for John Mitchell the place made vacant in the directory by the death of Alexander Mitchell, neither of these things came to pass at the annual meeting held here to-day.

FORT WORTH, Texas, June 5.--Word reached here early last evening that the Texas and Pacific east-bound mail and express had been stopped by four masked men at Bon Brook, a siding 10 miles west of Fort Worth, and the express and mail robbed. A short time afterward the train came in and T. Marsh, the express messenger, gave his story of the robbery.

HAVERHILL, Mass., June 5.--At no time has the labor situation in this city presented a more forbidding aspect than now. The partial settlement of two weeks ago was only a temporary smoothing over of the difficulty.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., June 5.--The charter of the Atlanta, Asheville and Baltimore Railroad has been turned over to Col. T.J. Powell, of New-York, part of the contract being that the road is to be begun in six months and finished in five years.

A paper yesterday published the statement that Congressman Kelley contemplated leaving Philadelphia at the end of his present term and settling in Alabama, where one of his sons is interested in the iron and coal company.

BERLIN, June 6.--During a circus performance at Neschen last evening a storm arose and a portion of the roof of the circus structure was blown off. The pendent lamps hanging from the roof were broken and the blazing petroleum poured down upon the heads of the people below.

Owen Williams, a man 72 years old, cut his throat with a razor in his room at the Carleton House, on William-street, about 10 o'clock last night. His groans attracted the attention of the watchman, who knocked on his door. Williams, who was half undressed, opened the door and then walked back to the bed.
Thomas Devine, of 238 North Seventh-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, was found yesterday afternoon lying unconscious on Grand-street, near Bedford-avenue.
ATLANTA, Ga., June 5.--The announcement yesterday that S.H. Phelan had failed produced a sensation in business circles. The liabilities are about $300,000 and the assets are practically nothing.

William Brown, aged 65, of Dominick-street, New-York, visited his married sister, Mrs. Ford, at 36 Hudson-street, Jersey City, on Saturday evening, and asked to be permitted to stay all night, as he had quarreled with his wife. At 1 o'clock yesterday morning he was found by some longshoremen lying dead on the sidewalk. He had either fallen or leaped from the third story window of the house.

Little Magdalena Zorn has been found at cast-and found dead. On Saturday, May 27, with the children of St. John's Lutheran School, on One Hundred and Nineteenth-street, she went to Fort George for a May day picnic.

The "plan of campaign" is not a programme that it would be advisable to follow in any country in which the law was respected. It is true that a "rack rent" is simply a competitive rent, such as is obtained in this country without difficulty or disturbance.
BENNINGTON, Vt., June 5.--The Directors of the Bennington Battle Monument Association have voted to ask the Grand Lodge of Masons of Vermont to lay the cornerstone Aug. 16 next.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 5.--By a private telegram which has been received here from New Zealand it is learned that upon the defeat of the Government in the Colonial Parliament on the budget last week the Ministry at once resigned. Parliament was at once dissolved and an appeal to the country will be taken. The regular election has been set for September next.

PROSPECT HOUSE, N.Y., June 5.--This has been a quiet, uneventful day with the Presidential party. The weather has been cloudy, with a soft southeasterly breeze strong enough to ripple the lake, but not so boisterous as to make it necessary to put on outside wraps.

CHICAGO, June 5.--"The Arabian Nights; or, Aladdin's wonderful Lamp," the new burlesque which has been in preparation at the Chicago Opera House since December last, was produced at that house last evening and for the first time upon any stage.

Bishop Potter's letter impressing upon the people of the city the necessity of building a great cathedral worthy of America's metropolis has attracted widespread attention and seems likely to lead to an immediate undertaking of the work.

Cases to test the excise law in relation to Sunday liquor selling were furnished in some of the hotels yesterday. Wine, ale, beer, whisky, gin, and every kind of alcoholic mixture were sold during the day all over town generally, yet carefully. No one who knows how to pull the ropes had to go thirsty.

If Central Park be the lunge of the metroplis, it suffered yesterday from acute congestion, forrarely have its shady paths, its neat walks, and its well mown sward been more densely crowded with men, women, and children.

The Critic says Walt Whitman's receipts from all sources during the past year are reported to have amounted to $1,600.

Lewis Masquerier dedicated the monument yesterday afternoon which he has raised on the western slope of Cypress Hills Cemetery to carry down his name and his theories for the regeneration of society to coming ages.
DES MOINES, Iowa, June 5.--The Rev. Granville (also known as Colonel) Moody died at his residence, near Jefferson, Greene County, yesterday afternoon.
Minnie B. Farrell, a pretty girl 23 years old, who says that she lives at 343 East One Hundred and Eighteenth-street, was arraigned in the Harlem court yesterday.

PANAMA, May 28.--Cable messages have reached here that a combination has been formed in Europe by which the capital required to finish the canal is insured. All the wealthiest of the large contracting firms here have received cablegrams to this effect, and therefore are hurryingtonward with their work as increased speed.
The detachment from the New-York Riding Club which has been enjoying itself among the Catskill Mountains on a two-weeks ride arrived home yesterday morning.

The Rev. James A. Mitchell, of Centreville, Secretary of the Protestant Episcopal Convention of the Diocese of Easton, has received the following telegram from the Right Rev. W.F. Adams, who was on Thursday elected Bishop of Easton:

During a quarrel last evening in the hallway of the tenement house at 693 First-avenue John Ryan was shot, in the neck and dangerously wounded by Joseph Brady, of 697 First-avenue. The shooting was the outcome of an assault committed by Ryan on Brady's father, Patrick, during the afternoon.
LONDON, June 6.--The Cunard Line steamship Servia, capt McKay, sld. from Queenstown for New-York to-day.
The Central Labor Union, at its meeting yesterday, condemned the General Executive Board of the Knights of Labor for the boycott it has placed on the goods of Higgine Co., the carpet manufacturers.

W.J. Florence looked somewhat weary and sorrowful at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday. He had just returned from Europe by the Umbria, and no sooner was he installed in his cosy rooms, endeavoring to compose himself after the trip, than somebody came and read a play to him.

WEST POINT, June 5.--Possibly our old friend, the sun, did not read THE TIMES of yesterday until he retired last night, Then, undoubtedly, his ire was excited by the open manner in which his shameful flirtation with his venerable accompolice had been given away by the West Point correspondent, and he felt inclined to retaliate.

Cardinal Gibbons celebrated solemn pontifical mass at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning at the cathedral. The assistant priest was the Rev. Dr. Foley, of Baltimore. The Revs. Edward J. Slattery and Michael T. Mulhern, of the cathedral, were respectively deacon and subdeacon.

Since the Panama Canal Company replenished its coffers by selling at 45 cents on the dollar bonds whose par value was $91,760,400, thus raising a little more than $41,000,000, no successful attempt to procure additional funds has been made.

UTICA, N.Y., June 5.--It has been discovered that through the influences of a procuress a number of little girls at Little Falls, Herkimer County, have been betrayed to a life of shame, some of them at that village and some in NewYork City. The girls' ages range from 12 to 15 years.

The refusal of Editor William O'Brien to attend the demonstration of the United Labor Party, held in his honor as the representative of the Irish cause in and about Union-square on Saturday night, was the cause of excited comment all over the city yesterday. The explanatory statement which Mr. O'Brien gave out to ...

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, June 5.--Swan Brothers' failure assumed a new and peculiar phase yesterday, when it was learned that after 12 o'clock Friday night, instead of filing a schedule of their assets and liabilities, the suspended firm filed trust deeds of all their property to Erasmus Nagel, of this city.

Herman Springhorn blew out his gas Saturday night at the Summit hotel, Bowery and Canalstreet, and was found dead in the morning. A card in his pocket bore the address "16 State-street, Springfield, Mass." He had abort $26 and some Jewelry, and there was nothing to show that he had intended to commit suicide. He had been at the hotel two days.

The great crowd that filled the Academy of Music last evening to hear the Rev. Dr. Edward McGlynn talk under the auspices of the Anti-Poverty Society had nearly tired itself out in applauding and waving handkerchiefs at the distinguished priest, when a new turn was taken over the O'Brien episode of the previous night, and then the meeting went nearly mad.

TRENTON, N.J., June 5.--The Pennsylvania Railroad Company has decided to build a branch from Manumuskin station, on the West Jersey Railroad, to the oyster beds at the mouth of Maurice River. After considerable difficulty the right of way has been secured, and the contract for building the road will be given out in a few days. The road is to be finished in 60 days.

A canvass among prominent men who own property and pay taxes in this city in regard to the bill before Gov. Hill authorizing the use of Central Park as a parade ground has been made by reporters of THE TIMES. In every case, as will be seen below, opinion is strongly against the scheme. The following are some of the views gathered:

PHILADELPHIA, June 5.--Actor Hall, who murdered Lillian Rivers and then out his own, throat, made a desperate struggle to tear open his wound as he lay on a cot in the German Hospital this evening. The doctors say he wil recover, but Hall is determined to die.

BOSTON, Mass., June 6.--The cases against Richmond J. Lane for embezzlement, pending in the United States Circuit Court in this city, will not be tried, as they have been nol prossed by the Government.
Articles of incorporation of "The Metropolitan Ferry Company" were filed in the County Clerk's office yesterday.
John Illingworth, the head of the Newark Steel Works, has just patented and successfully tested a new steel armor plate for war vessels.

A delegation of about 40 old firemen waited upon Mayor Hewitt yesterday afternoon and asked him to appoint Michael Crane, President of the Volunteer Firemen's Association, to fill the vacancy as Fire Commissioner. "Does he know enough to pull down the wall of a dangerous building ?" asked the Mayor, and...
Scratching and pasting were the features of the annual election at the Produce Exchange yesterday. It was by far the liveliest election the Exchange ever had.
The General Term of the Court of Common Pleas yesterday denied a motion of Corporation Attorney Boyd to carry certain cases against the Marvin Safe Company into the Court of Appeals.

BOSTON, Mass., June 6.--A delegation from the Boston Commercial Club, comprising some of the leading merchants, bankers, and manufacturers of the city, left for Chicago this afternoon, where they go on an invitation of the Commercial Club of that city.

CHICAGO, June 6.--Just one ward in Chicago declared to-day in favor of boodle and anarchy. Except in Chicago's Sixth Ward the vote throughout the country averaged 3 to 1 against the twin evils. State Attorney Grinnell came out of the contest with flying colors, surpassing...

Three tickets were in the field at the annual election of the Cotton Exchange yesterday, all bearing the names of the same candidates for President, Vice-President, Treasurer, and Trustee of the Gratuity Fund.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 6.--Lord Lansdowne and suite will, as usual spend the Summer months at salmon fishing grounds in New-Brunswick. In the Autumn he will spend a month in the Citadel at Quebec, subsequently opening the Provincial Exhibition at Sherbrooke.

The simple granite shaft that rises in the northerly corner of Evergreens Cemetery to mark the resting place of actors buried by the Actors' Fund of America wa dedicated yesterday afternoon in the presence of about 3,000 persons.
KEY WEST, Fla., June 6.--There has been one death from yellow fever and one new case since yesterday. The record now stands: Deaths, 6; sick, 9; convalescent, 3; total number of cases, 18.

LONDON, June 6.--Herr Seidl and Mr. Stanton have gone to Bayreuth to conclude a contract for the production of Wagner's lyric dramas in America. Herr Seidl has acquired the American right to perform Wagner's symphony, which he will produce in the Autumn.
The funeral of Thomas F. Warner, the well known Wall-street man, took place yesterday at the Church of the Paulist Fathers, Fifty-ninth-street and Ninth-avenue.

While the steamship Normandie was lying at her dock in Havre 10 days ago two policemen marched a brace of Chinamen on board. United States Consul Dufais was with them, and he told the officers of the ship that the Chinamen, who were manacled, were prisoners.
PORT AU PRINCE, Hayti, May 10.--The duty on coffee has been raised $2.66 per 100 pounds.

CONSTANTINOPLE, June 6.--Count de Montebello and M. Nelidoff, the French and Russian Ambassadors, respectively, have lodged the objections of their Governments to the ratification by Turkey of the Anglo-Turkish Convention relative to Egypt. M. Nelidoff, in communicating his Government's objections, hinted...

The Prohibitionists of this State have determined to make an early start with their canvass this year and to pursue it with energy up to the election in November.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 6.--John Batterson, who was convicted of being an accessory to an assault upon a young woman, was this morning sentenced to five years' imprisoment in Auburn Prison. His wife made a scene in the court room by falling on her knees and imploring God to prevent the separation of man and wife, and beseeching Judge Morgan to recall the sentence.
Commencement Day at Bowdoin College, Brunswick, Me., this year is Thursday, June 23. On the Sunday preceding the baccalaureate sermon will be preached by President T. De Witt Hyde, of the college.

The rearrangement of dates for the racing meetings hereabout has necessitated a change in the Brooklyn Club's programme. Racing will begin at their course next Saturday, and will be continued daily until Friday, June 17, which will be the last day of the Spring meeting. The programme, as readjusted, is a follows:

BALTIMORE, Md., June 6.--Lieut.-Gen. D. H. Hill delivered an address on the "Old South" before the Confederate Society, at Ford's Opera House to-night. The house was crowded, and the applause was hearty and frequent. The concluding portion of the address was upon the effects of the war, and was as follows:

CHICAGO, June 6.--Mr. John Hamlin to-day leased the Grand Opera House for the Summer season to George O. Morris, now manager of the Standard Theatre on the west side and formerly of the firm of Morris and Little of "The World."
CHICAGO, June 6.--If there was a merrier crowd in Chicago this evening than that which filled Hooley's Theatre, something altogether out of the usual run of entertainments must have amused it.

READING, Penn., June 6.--A committee representing the 1,600 employes of the different mills of the Reading Iron Works called upon the management to-day and notified them that at a meeting of all the employes it had been agreed not to accept the 10 per cent. reduction announced to take effect June 13. If the reduction is enforced a strike is probable.

PRINCETON, N.Y., June 6.--The annual election of officers of the Princeton College Athletic Association to-day resulted as follows: President-F. S. Thompson, of New-York, Class '88; Junior Directors--James D. Donegre, M.D., Class '89, and H. J. Chapin, Jr., of New-York, Class '90. The Constitution was amended to provide for the election of a a field Captain for the Mott Haven team. T.B. Hamilton, Class '88, was elected to the new position.

In the club championship series of games of the West Side Athletic Club the event of yesterday was the throwing of the 56-pound weight. There were many entries, and competition was very close. T.F.J. Hannan took first place, C. Ward a good second, and R. Louder third. The next event will be the 440 yards' run, which promises to be very well contested.

An inquest was begun yesterday by Coroner Levy in the case of George Farrish, an insane patient who died at the Ward's Island Asylum on April 10. Counsel for the Commissioners of Charities and Correction and for the Farrish family appeared.

Three weeks ago Mrs. C.F. Martin, who keeps a boarding house at 93 Pineapple-street, Brooklyn, applied to the Home for Destitute Children, on Sterling-place, for a little girl to act as nurse to a Mrs. Donahue, a boarder.

DUBLIN, June 6.--The evictions at Bodyke were resumed to-day. The first three families evicted offered only a passive resistance. Mr. Cox, member of Parliament, had persuaded them to refrain from throwing boiling water upon the police.
ST. LOUIS, June 6.--A heavy rainfall just after noon to-day made the track heavy and slow and the attendance light. The races were run off with the following results:

MALONE, N.Y., June 6.--At a meeting of citizens on Saturday it was decided to hold a memorial service for ex-Vice-President William A. Wheeler on Tuesday evening, when prominent citizens of Malone and distinguished, friends from abroad will address the meeting. Committees were appointed to take charge of the details.

WEST POINT, June 6.--Something has certainly got to be done about it, for it this sort of weather keeps up much longer the graduation exercises next Saturday will differ from the great "O'Brien" meeting the other night in that "Hamlet" will be played with Hamlet attending to his melancholy duties all right, but there will be nobody to witness his performance.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 6.--Vassar College was brilliant to-night on the occasion of the annual soiree musicale under the supervision of Dr. Ritter, of the School of Music. Before the doors of the chapel were opened the main corridor was filled with elegantly attired pupils and...

Adolph Reich, who is on trial in the Court of General Sessions for killing his wife at his home, 144 Suffolk-street, on April 19, admitted yesterday, through his lawyer, C.F. Kinsley, that he killed the woman, but set up a plea of self-defense. The morning session was taken up with the testimony of Capt. Allaire and the police officers.
Creditors of the P. Scherer Company assembled at the Gilsey House yesterday to hear Receiver James H. Breslin's report and to express their wishes regarding the closing up of the estate.

All classes of people except the followers of Handry George, John McMackin, and Dr. McGlynn appear to be pleased with the action of Editor William O'Brien in refusing to take part in the United Labor demonstration in Unionsquare on Saturday night.
CHICAGO, June 6.--A gossiper in an evening paper says: "It is said by a very good authority that Jack Haverly has bought in a single bucket shop 1,000,000 bushels of June wheat.

WASHINGTON, June 6.--The accounting officers of the Treasury will, it is understood, ask the President to recommend to the next Congress to make no appropriations in lump sums for purposes which are capable of subdivision.
A Summer-night's festival will be held by the Order of Druids at Grauer's Ridgewood Park, on Long Island, next Sunday.
BOSTON, June 6.--The Merchants' Woolen Mill in Dedham, one of the largest of its kind in the State, employing nearly 500 hands, will in a few days shut down entirely.
About 200 colored people went from Brooklyn to Garden City on Sunday to witness the ordination of one of their colored brethren...

HARTFORD, Conn., June 6.--The Railroad Commissioners have reached a decision in the matter of Sunday newspaper trains on which a hearing was given this morning, it having been decided that such trains are to run; also the 3 o'clock limited over the New-England Road.
ALBANY, June 6.--The Executive Committee of the Prohibition State Committee, at a meeting held here to-day, decided to hold the Prohibition State Convention in the rink at Syracuse Aug. 25 and 26.

WASHINGTON, June 6.--An answer was received this morning by the Inter-State Commerce Commission from the Chicago and Grand Trunk Railroad Company to the complaint of the Michigan Central Railroad Company against it for selling tickets to commercial travelers at a lower rate than that given to the public generally.
The tent in which the revivalists, Mason and Switzer, have lately conducted meetings at Park Ridge, N.J., was torn down and made fuel for bonfires at a late hour Sunday night.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal Company was held in this city to-day and the following officers, to serve for the ensuing year, were elected: President--Joseph E. Gillingham; Directors...
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 6.--City Clerk Henry B. Cook has sued Howard Tindell, a reporter, for libel, and Tindell proposes to turn the tables on the official.

ST. LOUIS, June 6.--The Eagle Flour Mill at St. Louis, one of the largest in the city, was almost entirely destroyed by fire yesterday. The building caught fire in the rear on the fourth floor, and before an alarm was turned in the roof was in a blaze.
PANAMA, May 20.--Payta, Peru, port charges are now as follows: First--All vessels of over 200 tons will pay the anchorrge tax.
Thomas Devine, the young man who was found in the gutter in Grand-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, on Sunday, died early yesterday morning at his home, 238 North Seventhstreet.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 6.--In the Penseyres murder trial this morning Mr. Laughlin opened for the defense. He claimed that the prisoner, Mrs. Penseyres, was insane, and asserted that the prosecution had failed to prove that she murdered her husband. Medical testimony tending to show the prisoner's insanity was introduced.

A new plan is on foot to connect the new Battery and Thirty-ninth-Street (Brooklyn) Ferry with Coney Island by a steam railroad. The Trustees of the ferry company are heavily interested in the scheme. They propose to tunnel under private properly until they get beyond the city limits and then construct a surface road to the west end of the island. It will touch at Bath Beach and other points on Gravesend Bay.

The old fight between the Manhattan and Brighton Beach Hotel people over the moneymaking marine road which connects the two places has broke out again, and yesterday Manager Fritcheft, of the Brighton Beach, took the initiative by tearing up the plank walk leading to the station of the marine road.
The efforts of the State Board of Arbitration to settle the silverworkers' strike and lockout have proved futile, for matters remain about where they were at the beginning of the trouble.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 6.--Reports from along the line of the Cleveland and Columbus Railway indicate extensive damage by yesterday's excessive rainstorm, causing sudden floods.

The union regatta of the Hudson River Yacht Club, which took place yesterday, was more of a picnic than a yacht race. The big steamship Columbia had been hired by the club, and it carried a crowd of men and women who seemed to think they were out on an excursion pure and simple, and wotted very little of yachts and their technicalities.

LONDON, June 6.--The Standard this morning reads Canada a severe lesson for increasing her duties on iron and steel, which, it says, is a selfish policy, and can only tend to sunder the colonies from the mother country.

PROSPECT HOUSE, June 6.--The President had good luck to-day, but he worked hard for it, spending the entire day on the lake and one of its tributary streams, and coming back this evening with the largest lake trout that has been taken since his arrival at the Saranac Inn.

BALTIMORE, June 6.--The statement is made here to-day that the Baltimore and Ohio put up most of the cash that paid for the Vandalia Road.

Arthur E. Hornblower, the Teller of the Hoboken Saving's Bank, who disappeared last week, returned home yesterday. Hornblower's wife received a dispatch from Binghamton, N.Y., that he was there.

ALBANY, June 6.--That ancient visitor to the Legislature known as the Drafted Men's bill was signed by the Governor to-day. It was introduced by Assemblyman Longley, of Brooklyn, but was so amended that its own friends would hardly recognize it.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 6.--The physician of Gen. James Speed states to-day that his patient is much improved. Saturday Gen. Speed thought he was going to die, and he made a will after so stating.

ERIE, Penn., June 6.--The Erie City Council sold $250,000 in 4 per cent. 20-year bonds to-day at public auction. The bonds were issued to refund the city debt. Kean Co., of New-York and Chicago, were the highest bidders, taking the lot at one and fifty-six one-hundredths of a cent.

BOSTON, June 6.--East Boston narrowly escaped a scene of horror to-day. A large wooden building on Maverick-street, two stories high and 80 feet long, has long shown signs of weakness, but it was braced and shored up until it was supposed to be safe.

Before sending the youngsters down to the King's Bridge Reformed Church for the start in the first race at Jerome Park to-day it is to be hoped that the managers will have sufficient consideration for the public, whom they are supposed to cater to, to have a parade of the starters with the jockeys up and in their colors in front of the grand stand.

BOSTON, June 6.--The mysterious disappearance of George R. Parks, the actor, is just now the talk of the town. He left his apartments at the Tremont House last week, with no intimation of his intention to leave the city. At first it was supposed that he would turn up in a...

UTICA, N.Y., June 6.--The New-York State Association for the Protection of Fish and Game met here to-night.

This and the following two weeks will be very busy times for the lawn tennis players. Next Wednesday the postponed opening of the Prospect Park Lawn Tennis Association will take place. Upward of 80 clubs will be represented.
BERLIN, June 6.--Emperor William, on the advice of his physicians, has decided not to go to Liegnitz. The Post learns that the Emperor will go to Ems, probably on June 18, and afterward to Gastein.

VIENNA, June 6.--The efforts of thousands of workmen for three days, and the use of tons upon tons of stone and earth, have not proved sufficient to stop the gap in the Kistisza dyke in the submerged district of Hungary.

LEBANON, Penn., June 6.--The case of William Shewers, the murderer of his two grandchildren, was called for trial to-day, but in view of the present state of public excitement the trial was, by agreement of all parties interested postponded until Sept. 3.

Mr. Blaine will leave the Fifth-Avenue Hotel at an early hour this evening, and will go on board the North German Lloyd steamship Ems, at Hoboken, which starts for Europe at 4 o'clock to-morrow morning. Mrs. Blaine and her daughters are expected here this morning.
Coroner Rooney and a jury inquired last night into the facts surrounding the death of Mary Jane Cox, the servant who was found dead in Mrs. Blend's kitchen, at 140 Prince-street, Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, June 6.--The master masons are gradually recruiting their forces and resuming work. Several new jobs were begun to-day. Five union bricklayers applied for work, and upon agreeing to abide by the new rules were placed upon the most urgent jobs.

The champion St. Louis Browns came, saw, and were defeated yesterday by the tailenders of the American Association, the Metropolitans. The game was brilliantly played throughout. Latham's absence seemed to give inspiration to the "Indians" and they played in a manner almost faultless.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 6.--Frederick Hermann, aged 35 years, employed as a helper in an iron mill, this afternoon, in his own house, killed his little daughter, aged 19 months, beat his wife until he thought her dead, and then out his throat, severing the windpipe and jugular vein.

CHICAGO, June 6.--The Chicago Board of Trade and the open board were closed to-day, owing to the judicial election. The majority of the brokers' offices were open during the forenoon to receive and answer mail and telegraph correspondence.

ALBANY, June 6.--The Rev. Dr. McGlynn addressed a large audience at the Lark-Street Rink here this evening. He was enthusiastically received. Thomas J. Dowling, Master Workman of the Knights of Labor of the Albany district, declined to preside at the meeting, and declared that he would not attend it. The Rev. George Muller, of Schenectady, presided.

MONTREAL, June 6.--The annual meeting of the Bank of Montreal was held here to-day, Sir Donald Smith presiding. After passing resolutions of regret at the death of the late President, Mr. C.F. Smithers, Mr. W.J. Buchanan, the General Manager, submitted the annual report, a summary of which has already appeared in THE TIMES.
Trade dollars continue to come in at the Sub-Treasury for redemption at the rate of from 2,000 to 3,000 a day. Interior towns send in most of it.
WASHINGTON, June 6.--Mr. W.W. Corcoran, the aged millionaire philanthropist, was suddenly stricken with paralysis in the left arm and left leg this afternoon, while at the dining table.
Miss Ida Mouquin, daughter of Henri Mouquin, of Clifton, Staten Island, was married at her father's residence yesterday afternoon to Charles Jacqueas, of this city.

The Manhattan Athletic Club announces that the New-York Athletic Club has returned its entries for the Spring games that were to take place June 11. The entries of the Manhattan Club were made conditional that if the entry...
Overseer of the Poor Pearsall, of Jamaica, was notified by James Nevins, a colored man, that his wife had become insane and said that he wanted her committed to the county house.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., June 6.--The demand made on Saturday on short interest for round deliveries of wheat did not bring out the expected heavy purchasing on the call board this morning to meet outstanding engagements.

Charles Thirion in 1886 kept the Hotel Francaise, at 166 Washington-street. Jane Claudell, a French girl 19 years of age, who came in on a European steamer, went to the hotel. Thirion went to her room at night and attempted an assault.

OMAHA, Neb., June 6.--The School Board election took place today. Three tickets were in the field--Republican, Domocratic, and non-partisan. The Republican ticket was elected. Women were permitted to vote, and female school teachers were out in full force, had carriages to travel in, and worked like old-time politicians in gathering in votes.

The trial of "Butch" Miller, for complicity in the murder of Lyman S. Weeks, for which crime John Greenwall has been convicted, will begin today in the Sessions Court, Brooklyn. District Attorney Ridgway has several new witnesses and is confident of obtaining a conviction. It is understood that Greenwall will be put on the stand.

MADRID, June 6.--It is said that hidden treasure to the value of $475,000,000 has been discovered in the palace of a dead Vizier at Kabat, Morocco. The Sultan, it is said, has confiscated the treasure and is having it carried to the imperial coffers.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 6.--Drafts on New-York --Sight 17 cents; telegraphic, 25 cents.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6.--Ward saved New-York from defeat to-day by the most daring kind of base running in the ninth inning. He went to first on a hit and stole second, third, and home. He made the plate on the pass of the ball from Casey to McGuire.

MONTREAL, June 6.--A new freight line of steamers, to ply between the Clyde, the Mersey, and Bristol Channel and Montreal, has been organized in England, and the first steamer, the Cotherstone, of 2,234 tons, is now on her way over, having sailed from Cardiff May 31. The new service is called the McLean Line.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., June 6.--Gen. Miles, in speaking to-day of the latest Indian outbreak in Arizona, said: "It is the result of a drunken row, which led to a feud between two bands of Indians in the San Carlos Agency.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 6.--James Mark Baldwin, A.M., Ph. D., at present Assistant Professor of Modern Languages in the college here, has received and accepted a call to the chair of Metaphysics at the Lake Forest University. Prof. Baldwin has won some distinction by his translations of foreign metaphysical treatises and also by original work. He was graduated from Princeton in 1884.
BELVIDERE, N.J., June 6.--A cable dispatch received here announces the death in London on Saturday of Henry Whitall, Professor of Astronomy, at Belvidere Seminary, at the age of 75 years.
TRENTON, N.Y., June 6.--The last Congress made a large appropriation for the purpose of stamping out pleuro-pneumonia among cattle in the United States.
The funeral of little Lena Zorn took place yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents, 401 East One Hundred and Twenty-second-street.
A party of 30 residents of Hoboken went down the Bay Saturday evening on a fishing excursion in the schooner S.J. Lindsey, Capt. Baker.

QUEBEC, June 6.--News has just been received of an earthquake which recently appeared in the vicinity of Ste. Louise, in the county L'Islet, province of Quebec.

CHICAGO, June 6.--The total shipments of dead freight from Chicago through to seaboard points by the various Central Traffic Association roads during the last week amounted to 28,991 tons, against 28,321 tons for the week previous. The percentage carried by each road was:

Russell Sage and Cyrus W. Field did their utmost to convince Wall-street yesterday that finally the telegraph war was at an end. Western Union, they announced, was ready now to resume dividends, Jay Gould agreeing with them that that was a proper policy.

CINCINNATI, June 6.--There is no formidable Republican candidate for Governor of Ohio at the Fall election except Gov. Foraker, and it seems to be taken for granted that he will be nominated for re-election.

NORWICH, Conn., June 6.--In the city election today the Republicans elected 5 of their 12 nominees, and the Democrats elected 7. The Common Council is a tie between the parties. Mayor Carpenter is a Republican.

The quarrel in the ranks of the Knights of Labor which has led to the expulsion of District Assembly No. 126 (the carpet weavers) and to the boycotting of E.S. HIGGINS Co.'s carpets is an old one, and its history, like that of the contest with the...

Members of the National Guard who take a just pride in being not merely as good citizens as their neighbors, but better, must feel a great relief at the withdrawal of Gen. FITZGERALD and other officers of the First Brigade from the false position to which those officers had undertaken to commit the whole body.

It was rumored in Westchester County yesterday that some of the cattle which had been quarantined in the town of Bedford had been sold to New-York butchers. Jacob Loewel was said to have purchased two steers from Henry Voris, of Golden's Bridge.
It was a bad day for the favorites at Brighton Beach yesterday, and backers of short horses had a field day. The races resulted as follows:
The Circe, a small English cutter of about five tons measurement, arrived here yesterday on the deck of the Anchor steamship Ethiopia.

LONDON, June 6.--The Thistle has won another race, defeating the Genesta and Irex in a contest off Dover. A brisk breeze was blowing this morning when the yachts started over the 44-mile course. The Thistle promptly took the lead and turned the pier within her own length.

CHICAGO, June 6.--Mr. McVicker's beautiful theatre held a goodly portion of fashionable Chicago this evening, and the large audience was entertained with a remarkable presentation of "Jim, the Penman," by Mr. A.M. Palmer's excellent company.

"Hypocrite," a play that in its first performance at the Fourteenth-Street Theatre last evening had the advantages of the services of admired actors and a new and showy scenic dress, is a shallow, noisy, badly constructed, and excessively vulgar production.
MADISON, Ind., June 6.--William M. Amsden, (Rep.,) a graduate of Hanover College, was to-day elected County Superintendent over C.R. Cravens, (Dem.)

WASHINGTON, June 6.--First Lieut. M.F. Jamar, Thirteenth Infantry, has been detailed as Military Professor at St. John's College, Annapolis, to take effect Sept. 10, relieving First Lieut. Charles W. Foster, Third Artillery, who will join his battery.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 6.--Information has just been received of the execution near the Seminole Agency, Indian Territory, of two Seminoles convicted of having murdered a comrade some three weeks ago.
Judge Kirkpatrick, in the Essex County Orphans' Court yesterday, set down the case for the settlement of the estate of the late Jeremiah Counsellor for Monday next.

NORWALK, Conn., June 6.--United States Treasurer Hyatt, accompanied by his family, left for Washington to-day, and will reside there during the Summer. Mr. Hyatt's mansion on West-avenue is offered for sale.
Capt. Williams obtained from Justice O'Reilly, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday, warrants for the arrest of James H. Breslin, ....

Cardinal Gibbons made Major John D. Kelley's house, at 213 Clermont-avenue, Brooklyn, his home yesterday, and, upon his return from his visit to Archbishop Corrigan, took a drive through Prospect Park. At 5 o'clock he received the supreme officers of the Catholic Benevolent Legion and a few friends. The reception was quite informal. The Cardinal will leave for Baltimore this morning.
The steamship Bermuda arrived yesterday from St. Kitt's with the crew of the barkentine General Hereaux, which was wrecked near there on May 29.

The trial of William Kingsley for a criminal assault on Annie Cotter was concluded yesterday in the Sessions Court, Brooklyn, with a verdict of guilty of assault in the third degree. The punishment is imprisonment for one year and a fine of $500.

Call John H. Hudson." Judge Barrett's order was duly obeyed, Juror Jonn H. Hudson stepped to the witness stand in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday morning and the sensational embracery investigation began.
Gen. Louis Fitzgerald, commandant of the First Brigade, N.G.S.N.Y., and his officers, decided yesterday not to press their demand for the use of Central Park as a parade ground.
DETROIT, Mich., June 7.--The output for the Lake Superior copper mines for May was as follows: Calument and Hecla, 2,580 tons; Tamarack, 306 tons; Quincy, 280 tons; Franklin, 200 tons.

The resolution of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen fixing the City Hall Park as the site for the proposed soldiers and sailors' monument was signed yesterday by Mayor Whitney and a copy filed with the Park Commissioners.

SARATOGA, June 7.--The sixty-first anniversary of the Congregational Home Missionary Society is in session here. The Rev. Dr. F.A. Noble, Pastor of the Union Park Church, Chicago, preached the annual sermon, his subject being "The Obligations of the Rich to Christian Interests and Institutions in this Country."

Elevated railroad employes are much exasperated at a move made on Monday by the enterprising company they serve. Their discontent was considerably increased when it became known yesterday that Gov. Hill had signed the bill which prohibits the employment of surface...

CHICAGO, June 7.--It is reported upon reliable authority that the recent purchase of Rattlesnake Island, in San Pedro Bay, south of Los Angeles, Cal., is for the Union Pacific. This company, it is claimed, has purchased the island for terminal purposes.

Odbir M. Hartt, formerly foreman in Gardiner Estes's shoe Factory, who was driven out of employment by the Knights of Labor because he discharged a dishonest burnisher belonging to the order, says that the persecution of him continues.

Mayor Hewitt yesterday wrote to Recorder Smyth, saying that on a recent visit to the public institutions on Blackwell's Island he found many of the cells in the Penitentiary occupied by two prisoners, contrary to the regulations and "coutrary to law".

ROCHESTER, June 7.--The Stewards of the Grand Trotting Circuit met in this city to-day, and the application of Poughkeepsie for admission was left to the Hartford and Springfield associations to see if they could satisfactorily arrange dates, either...
Gen. T.N. Waul, of Texas, is at the Hoffman House. Ex-Gov. John P. St. John, of Kansas, is at the Grand Union Hotel.

Dr. Cyrus Edson, of the Health Department, is closely watching for the shipment to this city of the cattle suffering from pleuropneumonia, which have been slaughtered in Westchester County by the Government inspectors.
One of the finest yacht races ever sailed in these waters was the twenty-second annual regatta of the Atlantic Yacht Club, which took place yesterday.
The letter of Mayor Hewitt, published yesterday, to Gen. Louis Fitzerald in regard to military parades in Central Park has drawn forth the following reply:

Dr. J.R. Kingel, Sr., of 396 Sixth-avenue, was in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday, charged by Maggie Smith, a servant employed on West Fifty-second-street, with attempting on Monday night a criminal operation.
The Rev. Edward McGuffey, Assistant Rector of Holy Trinity Church, Clinton-street, Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Miss Florence Gibson Bussing, daughter of R.S. Bussing.

TORONTO, June 7.--In the seventh inning of the Newark-Toronto International ball match here to-day Hughes, pitcher for the Newarks, while at the bat, was struck a terrible blow with the ball from the hands of Crane, Toronto's pitcher.
CHICAGO, June 7.--There was put on record to-day the deed by which B.P. Moulton conveys to Mosier T. Green, the President of the Chicago Lumber Company, his home, 1,912 Prairie-avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7.--The bark Fluorine, from Ivigtut, reports continuous easterly winds and fog during the passage. From latitude 63 down to 47 ,in the lins of 52 , she passed icebergs and a large quantity of field ice. Some of the bergs were about 400 feet high.

CONCORD, N. H., June 7.--The Republican members of the Legislature held a conference this evening to consider the question of electing a United States Senator for the full term beginning March 4, 1889; but they ended just where they began and the question is still open.
The Metropolitan and St. Louis Clubs played again at Staten Island yesterday, and the home nine by brilliant fielding and timely batting defeated the Western champions for the second time.

At the meeting of the Rapid Transit Commission yesterday Julien T. Davies, counsel for the Manhattan Company, submitted construction plans of the West and South street annexes. In its general character the structure will be like the Sixth-avenue road, with the transverse girders.
A kerosene lamp exploded in the downtown station of the elevated railroad at Thirdavenue and Thirty-Fourth-street, just before 9 o'clock last evening.
SARANAC INN, N.Y., June 7.--An ambition was kindled in the breast of the President last night when he looked at the 23-pound "laker" caught by Mr. Wynants and presented to him.

After discussing for three hours the viands of the Hotel Brunswick last evening, about 40 members of the Life Insurance Association talked insurance to each other for quite as much longer.

CHICAGO, June 7.--The rumor that some of the bravest bears had thrown up the sponge and had made private settlements with the clique sold June wheat up to 94 cents on the curb this morning and opened the regular market greatly excited, with June 93 cents and July 87 cents.

LONDON, June 7.--In the House of Commons to-day the Hon. W.H. Smith said he hoped the papers in relation to the new Egyptian convention would be issued by the Government in a few days. Mr. Smith also stated that the negotiations with France concerning the NewHebrides question were still in progress. The delay, he said, was not the fault of England.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7.--The game to-day between Philadelphia and New-York was of the seesaw order. Dailey was in the box for the home team, but was knocked out of it in the third inning, after eight hits and nearly as many runs had been made off him.

DETROIT, Mich., June 7.--The troublesome fisheries question has broken out in a new spot. S.H. Davis Co., fish merchants of this city, wanted to buy whitefish from the Georgian Bay this season. Noble Clark, a Canadian firm, have for years controlled the Georgian Bay whitefish catch.

As the tug Three Brothers started yesterday morning to tow a garbage scow from the slip at the foot of Jackson-street, East River, the swiftly running tide careened her over so that she filled and sank.

WEST POINT, June 7.--Never let it be said again that the prayers of youth are disregarded. Last night hundreds of such were wafted up from the hearts of distressed young ladies, who prayed for fair weather to-day, and it has rained or lowered pretty much all the time since 8 o'clock last night.

M. Mercier, Premier of the province of Quebec, and M. Sheyn, the Provincial Treasurer, were given a dinner at Delmonico's last evening by a few of their friends and admirers.

WASHINGTON, June 7.--Numerous claimants, scattered all over the United States, who have interests in the French spoliation cases pending before the Court of Claims, feel disappointed that the court has adjourned till October next without passing upon the test questions affecting their claims.

The annual meeting of the Actors' Fund of America took place yesterday afternoon at the Madison-Square Theatre. A.M. Palmer presided. The meeting was very well attended, about 400 members being present. On the stage, with President Palmer, were Col. W.E. Sinn, T. Henry...

The proceedings against the three men charged with embracery in the Sharp case began yesterday morning with the affixing of the signatures of Messrs. Hudson, Sutton, and Raymond to their depositions taken the day before. The depositions were bright and cheerful in artistic covers of red leatherette with red ribbons.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 7.--State Railroad Commissioners John D. Kernan, William E. Rogers, and Isaac V. Baker, accompanied by Secretary William C. Hudson, met in the Common Council Chamber in this city to-day to consider the subject of railroad crossings at grade on city streets.

The case of Due Way and Ah Foo, the Chinese cook and steward shipped to this port from Havre on the Normandie by United States Consul Dufais, came up before the Custom House officials again yesterday.

LONDON, June 7.--The Ascot Heath race meeting opened to-day with a fine programme and some excellent racing. The race for the Jubilee Cup, with 500 sovereigns added, was won by R. Vyner's Minting by a length from the Duke of Westminster's St. Mirin.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 7.--Ex-Judge and Mrs. Thurman left to-day for Boston, where the former will take part in the telephone suit. Owing to the feeble condition of the "Old Roman", the journey will be made by easy stages. A stop will be taken at Buffalo to-night and at Albany to-morrow. On his return Mr. Thurman will go to Mount Clement, Mich., in the hope of finding a relief from rheumatic troubles.
NOGALES, Arizona, June 7.--A dispatch received here yesterday says that 17 Apache Indians have left the reservation and gone on the warpath. No reason has been given for their action.

The gentlemen who are interested in the affairs of the Republican Party are depending too much on the momentum of that old and respectable organization to carry it successfully through the next campaign.

At the meeting of the Board of Health of Newtown yesterday the committee appointed to investigate the accounts of the clerks issuing burial permits under Supervisor McGowan, who absconded to Canada, reported that ex-Clerk...
A jury in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, gave a verdict yesterday against the Brooklyn City Railroad for $12,500, for the loss of John McCollum's arm.
Rain prevented the Washington-Boston game at Washington yesterday. The Metropolitan and St. Louis Clubs will play again at St. George, Staton Island, to-day.

The canal and steam boat people, as well as others interested in transportation of freight on the Hudson River, are much exercised as to the probable action of Gov. Hill on the bill now in his hands which extends the charter of the Poughkeepsie Bridge Company until Jan. 1, 1889.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 7.--There were brilliant scenes at Vassar College this afternoon and evening, it being Class Day. The exercises in the chapel commenced with an address of welcome by Miss Skinner, President of the graduating class, who was followed by the class orator, Miss Ida June Butcher, of Utica.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 7.--Ex-Judge William Murray, who died in this city about midnight last night, was born in the town of Andes, Delaware County, Nov. 21, 1820, of Scotch parents. He studied law and was admitted to the Bar in 1848.

There were 1,500 little waifs at the Union-Square Theatre last night. It was the newsboys' benefit. From the footlights to the gallery ceiling row after row and tier after tier, with jackets and without, in clean faces and au naturel, the little, tattered, sturdy, shrill-voiced...
BRUSSELS, June 7.--The principal Government organ asserts that the Prime Minister of Belgium desires to abandon office.

The cases which James H. Breslin, of the Gilsey House, and Charles N. Vilas, of the Fifth-Avenue, have made in order to have the courts decide whether they may furnish liquor to their guests on Sundays were argued before Judge Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday afternoon.

Some of the Rev. Dr. McGlynn's friends who do not want to defy the Pope and the church are talking of appointing a committee to take a petition to Rome asking for Dr. McGlynn's reinstatement. It is said that Daniel O'Loughlin, editor of the Catholic Herald, will be one of the committee.

Another perverse day in the stock market came yesterday for Russell Sage and Cyrus W. Field and their little bull pool in Western Union Telegraph. A big crop of rumors and animated fairy tales was harvested, but the day's dealings came to an end, just as Monday's did, with none of that big advance that was promised.
Mr. Sherman's recent speech at Springfield, Ill., has been read with profound regret not only by those whose party ties are less stringent than his, but by great multitudes of Republicans.
Herrmann will give an afternoon entertainment at the Bijou Opera House to-day. Mr. R.C. Hilliard will be "leading man" in Miss Helen Dauvray's company next season.

CHICAGO, June 7.--The thirty-eighth annual convention of the American Medical Association assembled in this city to-day. The attendance of physicians and surgeons from all parts of the country is unexpectedly large. The session was opened by an address of welcome delivered by Mayor Roche.

BOSTON, June 7.--To-night the friends of George R. Parks, the actor, believe that he met a suicide's death, and this would seem to be settled beyond a reasonable doubt unless he is in hiding to escape his creditors. On the night that Parks disappeared he wrote letters to his wife and mother, then at New-York.

MONTREAL, June 7.--At a meeting of the Montreal Directors of the Bank of Montreal held to-day, Sir Donald A. Smith, member of Parliament, was elected President and George A. Drummond VicePresident.
Miss Elizabeth Hoagland, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. C.N. Hoagland, of 410 Clintonavenue, Brooklyn, was married last evening to Prof. Charles Otis Gates, of Adelphi Academy.

The officers of the New-York Athletic Club say their Spring games, advertised for Saturday, will take place, notwithstanding the fact that the Manhattan and some other clubs have refused to participate because the Athletics would not promise to bar Malcolm Ford from the contests. The club has 135 entries for the games, and expect more before the books close to-morrow night.

TRENTON, N.J., June 7.--Mrs. James Neilson, sister of Horace Greeley, is very sick with pneumonia at her home here. She is 79 years of age, and her family and friends fear that her illness will prove fatal.

The one hundred and sixth session of the Masonic Grand Lodge of this State opened at 2 P.M. yesterday in the Masonic Temple. When George W. NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 7.--The Spruce-Street Baptist Church, of this city, has called the Rev. M. W. Gilbert, of Hamilton, N.Y., a graduate of Madison University, to the pastorate of the church.

SYRACUSE, June 7.--The eighth annual convention of the New-York State Undertakers' Association assembled in Music Hall in this city at 10 A.M. to-day. About 150 undertakers were present, including delegates from the principal cities of the State. The hall was handsomely decorated with flowers and the gallery was filled with ladies.
INDIANAPOLIS, June 7.--"The Vandalia has not passed from the Pennsylvania's control," emphatically remarked a Pennsylvania official to-day.

Little Mamie Holland, who died at Mrs. Martin's home, 93 Pineapple-street, Brooklyn, on Monday, from supposed insufficient nourishment, was buried yesterday in Potter's Field. A physician who had been in attendance gave a certificate of death from rheumatism of the heart.

HENDERSON, Ky., June 7.--The city was shocked about 2 o'clock this afternoon to hear that Prof. E.F. Clark, Superintendent of the public schools, had been shot and killed by Prof. Thomas Posey, Principal of the high school.
TUCSON, Arizona, June 7.--A dispatch from Hermosilio says the explorers sent out by Gov. Torres to ascertain the existence of the volcano as reported near Bavispe, Sonora, have returned.

ALBANY, June 7.--Gov. Hill to-day devoted the afternoon to hearing arguments on senator Vedder's bill taxing "bucket shops" $350 in New-York, $150 in Brooklyn, and $75 in other places.

PITTSBURG, June 7.--The annual convention of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers was opened in Central Turner Hall, this city, this morning, by President William Weihe, with 180 delegates in their seats.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 7.--M. Kamper, representing wealthy German capitalists, is here trying to secure a monopoly of the iron industry of the Dominion.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 7.--At a meeting of the Republican State Central Committee here today Aug. 24 and Des Moines were selected as the time and place of holding the next Republican State Convention.

BALTIMORE, June 7.--Few recent events created more general notice than the arrival of Cardinal Gibbons to-day after an absence of four months. It was recognized that he was beloved by all Catholics, but to-day those of other faiths assembled to welcome him and to do him honor.

BOSTON, Mass., June 7.--The wedding of the season occurred to-day, when the daughter of the richest man in Massachusetts was married in what the North Easton people call the most beautiful church in the State.

MALONE, N.Y., June 7.--The obsequies over the remains of ex-Vice-President Wheeler were held to-day in the Congregational church, every available foot of space in the large edifice being occupied as a mark of esteem for the deceased and as a token of respect for his memory.

CONCORD, N.H., June 7.--In the House to-day a bill was read twice and referred, providing for the calling of a constitutional convention. The act stipulates that delegates be chosen at a special election to be held Nov. 8, and that the convention meet in Concord on the first Wednesday of next December.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., June 7.--The Saratoga express on the Fitchburg Road going west met with a serious accident at Pownal Station, Vt., at 8:30 o'clock to-night.

New-York's Prohibitionists had a busy day yesterday. In the afternoon they met at 3 East Fourteenth-street and discussed the outlook for the coming campaign, and in the evening the big hall of the Cooper Union was crowded with believers in cold water principles.

An event will occur on Sunday afternoon in the dedication of the Press Club monument at Cypress Hills, which will enlist the attention and sympathy of every newspaper writer in this city. The monument has been reared with little aid outside of the profession.
Racing will continue at Jerome Park this afternoon and a fine card is offered, with five fiat races, and a steeplechase over the full course.
Yesterday morning 160 men employed as tanners and finishers at B.G. Salemon's leather works on Sussex-avenue, Newark, struck for an advance in pay.

ST. LOUIS, June 7.--The races here to-day were run with the following results: One mile and one furlong, selling race. Gold Flea, 108 pounds, won by a length, Jim Nave second, War Sign third. Time--2:00. Hettie S., Osgood, Katie S., and Emma Manley also ran. In the pools War Sign was barred, and Gold Flea sold at $25 to $12 for Hettie S., $11 for Jim Nave, and $5 for the field.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., June 7.--The Secretary of the San Francisco Produce Exchange has collected reports of correspondents from all the counties of California as to the condition of wheat up to June 1, with reports as to damage by recent hot winds.

Michael Conway and David H. Link were drunk and disorderly at One Hundred and Twenty-second-street and Tenth-avenue last evening. Patrolman D.T. Connor, of the Thirtieth Precinct, ordered them to go home. They replied in abusive and threatening terms, and when the officer attempted to arrest them they assaulted him.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 7.--Drafts on New-York --Sight, 17 cents; telegraphic, 25 cents.

Mr. Blaine rose before 7 A.M. yesterday and received Mrs. Blaine and his two daughters, who had just arrived in town. Miss Abigail Dodge did not come on.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 7.--A heavy deal in unimproved city real estate is reported today. Samuel Scott, of Kansas City, who is representing a syndicate, purchased the Tyler tract, which adjoins Tower Grove Park and has a frontage of 4.705 feet with a mean width of 2,164 feet. The price paid was $1,000,000. Scott is one of the Kansas City and Wichita boomers and he proposes to try his hand here.

The Council of the University of NewYork held the closing meeting of the year last night. Seventeen members were present. The portrait of Richard H. Bull, Ph. D., Professor of Engineering from 1853 to 1885, by Frank Fowler, was presented and accepted.

Holders of Jersey Central securities who object to the reorganization plan are getting ready to make a fight to prevent the plan being put into effect. Breese Smith are leaders in the movement, and hold that the proposed arrangement will cause the bondholders to lose $230 interest on convertible bonds in 15 years and $180 on consols in 12 years.

LEXINGTON, Ky., June 7.--A terrific thunderstorm prevailed last night during which two Red Wilkes yearlings on the farm of Vincent Cromwell, near here, were struck dead by lightning. One was worth $1,500, the other $1,000. At McGrathiana a fine filly by Wanderer, dam Ouida, by Harry O'Fallon, was also killed in the same way. She was the property of Dudley Hughes.

We have been much edified and instructed by an article from the pen of the Hon. ELLIS H. ROBERTS in the New Princeton Review on "The Moral Aspects of the Tariff." Perhaps the edification and instruction obtained were not of precisely the kind the worthy writer intended, but they were real and they were considerable.

WASHINGTON, June 7.--The following changes in the stations and duties of officers of the Signal Corps have been ordered: Second Lieut. James A. Swift has been ordered to proceed from this city to San Francisco and Point Peyes, Cal., to examine the telegraph lines to be constructed between those points.
BOSTON, Mass., June 7.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Old Colony Steamboat Company was held at the Old Colony station this morning.
ALBANY, June 7.--The Executive Mansion will be ready for the Governor to occupy to-morrow night. The work of laying the carpets was completed to-night.

Yesterday's races at Jerome Park drew a large crowd of people in spite of the threatening weather. The track itself was in better condition than was to be expected after the rain. It was simply stiff, not muddy.

HAVANA, June 7.--Much discontent has been awakened here by the receipt of a telegram from Spain announcing the formation of a new division, which will have the effect of suppressing the provinces of Matanzas and Pinar del Rio. There is great excitement in both those provinces. Meetings and demonstrations have been held and telegrams sent to Spain protesting against the reform, which the people consider adverse to their interests.

Although Hanover has frightened all competitors but Oneko out of the Belmont Stakes, and so makes that event virtually a walkover this year, still there are five other good events on the card for the racing at Jerome Park to-day, and there will be plenty of sport.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8.--New-York won from Philadelphia to-day by better work at the bat and in the field. Buffinton was hit hard, particularly in the first and eighth innings, and his support was anything but brilliant.
PITTSBURG, Penn., June 8.--The Pittsburg and Western Railroad was sold to-day for $1,000,000. The first bid made was for $756,000, by Thomas H. Coster, of New-York, representing Drexel, Morgan Co.
People who went to Jerome Park yesterday and followed the advice of professional tipsters or newspaper prophets found themselves as badly "left" as those who follow the political tips in the Sun.

James B. Brewster, of the Brewster Carriage Manufacturing Company, was 70 years of age yesterday, and the employes of the establishment celebrated the event by presenting him with a gold-headed cane and umbrella as a testimonial of their regard and esteem.
SARANAC INN, N.Y., June 8.--President Cleveland was favored on the last day of his stay here with beautiful weather, if he was not blessed with good fortune as a fisherman.

BOSTON, June 8.--A mysterious shooting affair occurred on the road between Andover and Lawrence early this morning, and the unknown victim now lies at the Andover Almshouse unconscious, with an ugly bullet wound in the right temple.
The Coney Island Jockey Club have issued the programme for their June meeting, and an unusually attractive pamphlet it is. The cover is illuminated with a picture of King Fox, with Spellman on...

FINDLAY, Ohio, June 8.--The great natural gas celebration opened here this morning under the most favorable auspices. Thirty thousand gas jets will be in flame to-night, besides those heretofore in use. The 31 gas wells of Findlay have all been piped into the city to aid in the illumination.

The veterans of the Seventh Regiment have two excursions in view. One, which chiefly interests the uniformed battalion, will be a trip to Saratoga Springs to participate in the escort to the Society of the Army of the Potomac.

COLUMBIA, S.C., June 8.--In the southern part of Georgetown, S.C., is a large sheet of fresh water, known as Dawho Lake, widely celebrated for its great quantity of excellent fish of many varieties. About 10 days ago a terrific storm of several hours' duration passed over...

BALTIMORE, Md., June 8.--T.Wallis Blakiston and John E. Semmes, two prominent lawyers and society men, became involved in a quarrel in the Court of Common Pleas to-day, and the lie was passed. Blakiston struck Semmes a stinging blow on the side of the head. A general commotion followed. Judge Brown administered a severe rebuke to Blakiston, who at once apologized.

DETROIT, Mich., June 8.--The managers of the railroads reaching Grand Rapids have discovered a way to evade that section of the inter-State commerce law which provides a penalty for allowing rebates to heavy shippers.

Masonic veterans held their annual communication last evening in the Commandery room in the Temple and elected 13 members, after which they adjourned to the banquet room, where they indulged in their sixteenth annual feast. The laws of the veteran association declare that each of its members must have been a Master Mason for 21 years or longer. The oldest member present was 88 years of age, the youngest 43.

SCHULENBURG, Texas, June 8.--Col. Dan Rice, the veteran Cincinnati showman, was married here yesterday to Mrs. M.C. Robinson, a wealthy widow and owner of one of the finest cattle ranches in Lavaca County. Mrs. Robinson's daughter and the other members of her family were not favorable to the marriage. The bride is a lady of great benevolence. Her marriage to the aged showman is a matter of much comment.

Annie Nathan, a 13-year-old girl, living at 355 Grand-street, Williamsburg, called last evening as Joseph Fusca's shoe shop at 408 Keap-street, for a pair of shoes she had left there early in the day.

WEST POINT, June 8.--The first glorious 24 hours of his release has inspired the brassbuttoned, buoyant, love-making soldier with all the ardor of an older cavalier, and no shady nook, no sequestered bower, no lonely but lovely walk has escaped the soft love notes that have been made the voice of that tenderest passion.

The tenth annual meeting of the American Athletic Club will be held at the Manhattan Athletic Club grounds, Eighty-sixth-street and Eighth-avenue, Saturday June 25, at 4 P.M. The events include a 100 yards' handicap, 220 yards' handicap, 440 yards' handicap, 220 yards' hurdle, 880 yards' handicap, one-mile walk handicap a three-mile run, and two-mile bicycle race.

The Trustees of the American Cathedral Association held a meeting at the residence of the Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix, Rector of Trinity Church, last evening. They were in session several hours with closed doors. It was announced that the action taken would not be made public until the proceedings have been ratified by Bishop Potter, Chairman of the board, who was out of the city yesterday. He is expected back to-day.

A train on the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad struck a man near Summit on Tuesday evening and was delayed there. About the time it reached Montrose Policeman Charles Shields stepped on the roadbed. A train approached him from New-York and he stepped to the east bound track. An instant later the Summit train struck him and the cowcatcher tossed him to the roadside. He died in five minutes.

The arbitrary and despotic methods which characterize some of the present labor organizations suggest the necessity for a new union among workingmen or between workingmen and employers--a union for the protection of personal liberty.

LONDON, June 8.--The steamship Olbers, (Br.,) Capt. Clark, from New-York May 29, for Liverpool, passed Brow Head to-day.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 8.--The season at Shohola Glen was opened yesterday by an excursion given by the Erie Railway Company to the members of the press of the adjoining districts of New-York, New-Jersey, and Pennsylvania. The attractions of the Glen, including the Switchback Railroad and the hotel accommodations, were heartily approved.

DANBURY, Cenn., June 8.--Samuel A. Barnum resides on West-street. Last night he retired at the usual hour, after having secured his house, and at 4 o'clock this morning was awakened by hearing a noise. He opened his eyes and saw a man standing at his bedside.

WASHINGTON, June 8.--Officials of the Court of Claims are displeased at the passing reference made in THE TIMES'S dispatches to the careful way in which information as to the proceedings of that court is concealed from public knowledge.

Influential Roman Catholics friendly to Dr. McGlynn are moving to prevent his excommunication and secure his reinstatement in St. Stephen's. A meeting was held yesterday by a committee of those actively interested.

BOSTON, June 8.--Trotting at Mystic Park was continued to-day. There were eight starters in the 2:32 trotting class for a purse of $500, divided.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 8.--Richard Smith, a 10-year-old negro, murdered a colored baby that was left in his charge this morning at Bartlett, Tenn., nine miles from Memphis.

EUFAULA, Indian Territory, June 8.--The third day's session of the Indian Citizenship Council opened at 10 o'clock this morning. All the tribes in the Territory were fully represented, and the untutored savage of the Northwest was here in force.

MONTREAL, June 8.--The annual statement of the Merchants' Bank was issued to-day and compares most favorably with that of last year. The net profits, after deducting appropriations for bad and doubtful debts, amounted to $623,966 99, over 10 per cent. on the capital, and an increase of $99,212 96 over last year.
Assistant Chief Bonner is now engaged in making inspections of all the steam vessels owned by the city which are supplied with hose and other appliances for putting out fires.

BOSTON, June 8.--The Constitutional prohibitory amendment was defeated in the House to-day by a vote of 139 to 74, not the necessary two-thirds. There were three pairs. Of the 142 members recorded in favor of the measure 126 were Republicans, 13 were Democrats, 1 Independent Republican, one Independent Democrat, and 1 Independent. Of the 77 recorded against it 17 were Republicans, 58 Democrats, and 2 Independent Democrats.

The bear rumor committee is proving a very chestnutty concern. It doesn't seem to be able to rise above the killing of Jay Gould. Yesterday it overstrained its genius and dispatched him a couple of times.

MARSHALL, Mo., June 8.--A cyclone visited this county yesterday afternoon about 4 o'clock, doing much general damage, but very severe damage at Little Rock, about 15 miles from here on the eastern border of the county, and lying upon the river.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 7.--Scratch a member of Parliament from the maritime provinces, any of them, and you'll find a commercial unionist. The member may be a secessionist or even an annexationist; but if a Liberal he will...

KEY WEST, Fla., June 8.--During the past 24 hours 2 new cases of yellow fever have developed and 3 deaths occurred, making a total of 21 cases and 8 deaths. Two of those who died to-day were W.M. Jameson, of New-York, publisher of the Democrat, and Mrs. Mary McLean, of Georgia.

BENSON, Arizona, June 8.--Thirty Indians are now stated to be on the warpath, instead of 17 as at first reported. Their first victim was a Union veteran. It is feared that two white men who were at work at Table Mountain, on the Oak Grove Trail, have also fallen victims to the renegades.

SYRACUSE, June 8.--Senator Hiscock gave a dinner to-night to a number of newspaper men and personal friends, including the Hon. J.J. Belden and Senator Hendricks, M.H. Northrup, Carroll E. Smith, the Hon. Martin A. Knapp. Among those present from out of town were Postmaster Bailey, of the Utica Observer; S.N.D. North, of the Albany Express; Mr. Warren, editor of the Buffalo Commercial and Charles Francis, of the Troy Times.

DANVILLE, Va., June 8.--Capt. William T. Clarke, one of the oldest citizens of this city, and a retired merchant, dropped dead at his residence on Main-street Monday. He represented this city and county soon after the war in the Virginia State Senate, and for a number of years was a member of the Town Council. He was very valuable citizen, a devoted husband and parent, and a firm friend.

According to Lawyer S.G. Barnard, of 23 Park-row, William C. Tompkins, who was the financial backer of Myra Goodwin's "Sis" Comedy Company last Winter, is a person who does not pay his just debts, although having means.
