Gov. Lee, of Virginia, will accompany the R.E. Lee Corps of Confederate Veterans on their visit to Boston as the guests of the John A. Andrew Post. The Richmond ladies have made and presented to the corps a handsome flag, which they will carry to Boston with them. The portrait of Gen. Robert E. Lee is painted in the centre of the flag.

The veterans of the Ninth Regiment, 15 its number, held a reunion at the Rossmore Hotel last evening. A dinner was partaken of and a permanent organization was formed for the purpose of keeping up the acquaintance formed on the field of battle. J. F. Swords, who served as a drummer boy in the war, was elected President. Col. W.F. Heermance presided at last night's reunion.

The Rev. Charles H. Camp, of Lockport, one of the Grand Chaplains, opened yesterday's session of the Masonic Grand Lodge with prayer at 9 A.M. Lieut.-Gov. Jones was present and fraternized with the brethren on the floor.
After two successive defeats the St. Louis Browns beat the Metropolitan Club at Staten Island yesterday.

On the first day of this month the Teachers' Mutual Benefit Association of this city entered upon the third year of its existence and the first of its practical usefulness. It commences the year with a gift of $3,000 from a generous and philanthropic citizen, who desires to remain unknown.

The Fountain Gun Club's shoot at Woodawn, Long Island, yesterday, was exceptionally good. Out of 84 birds shot at only 17 escaped. The club badge was won by M. Donnelly, 29 yards, with 7 straight kills. A. Eddy, 30 yards, after being six other competitors, won second prize with 6 straight kills.

Patrick Henry, an old man living on Hudson-street, Newark, was shot and instantly killed by Daniel Murphy, a Newark police supernumary, at the home of the latter at 10 o'clock last night.
BERLIN, June 8.--The Strasburger Post denies semi-officially that Prince von Hohenlohe will resign the Governor-Generalship of AlsaceLorraine.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 8.--The Supreme Court handed down two decisions bearing upon the celebrated tally sheet forgery case. The first of these decisions overruled the motion for leave to file a petition in error to the Common Pleas Court.

MONTREAL, June 7.--The "boodle" Aldermen and Messrs. Moloney and Keenan are to all appearances thoroughly sick of their prolonged residence in Montreal and will be heartily glad when they can once more return to New-York.

The Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange yesterday placed "silver bullion certificates" upon the regular list, to be classed as "mining shares" when ready for issue. The proposition has been under consideration some weeks and has met with such general approval that the determination finally reached by the Governing Committee was universally expected.

The first elevens of the St. George's Club, of this city, and the Newark Cricket Club yesterday played a one-inning match on the grounds of the former at Hoboken with disastrous results to the visiting team.

MONTREAL, June 8.--The authorities of the Hochelaga Bank have taken steps to deprive Mr. Parent, their defaulting cashier, of his illgotten gains. Yesterday the Banque du Peuple received from Arthur Ray, broker, Randolphstreet, Chicago, a package of Canadian bank...
CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 8.--The Board of Industry, organized like bodies in some other places called Committees of One Hundred, has for its chief aim the fostering of the city's material interests.
LIMA, Peru, June 8, via Galveston.--Peruvian ports are opened to vessels bringing clean bills of health from Chili, subject to a quarantine of from five to seven days.

Adolph Reich, the self-confessed slayer of his wife, was yesterday convicted of murder in the first degree. The summing up of his lawyer and of Assistant District Attorney Purdy occupied fully four hours, and the charge of Recorder Smyth nearly two hours more.

RONDOUT, N.Y., June 8.--A young woman who says her name is May Ritherford and that her home it near Poughkeepsie, has created much excitement in Columbia, Greene, and Dutchess Counties by the story she relates in Hudson.
The Brooklyns found little difficulty in batting the delivery of Pechiney, of the Clevelands, at Washington Park yesterday afternoon.
Mrs. Thomas A. Hendricks, of Indianapolis, is at the Sturtevant House. Rear-Admiral John H. Upshur, United States Navy, is at the Clarendon Hotel.
ITHACA, N.Y., June 8.--Mrs. Mary Outwater White, daughter of the late Peter Outwater, of Syracuse, N.Y., and wife of ex-President Andrew D. White, of Cornell University...

UTICA, June 9.--In the fourth day of the twenty-ninth annual convention of the NewYork State Association for the protection of fish and game, in contest 5, 46 entries were made. B. Stackpole, of Wolcott, won first prize in class A by a score of 12 straight.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, June 9.--The steamer Acacia, with 2,000 tons of rails, bound for New-Orleans, ran ashore between Schooner Pond and Big Glace Bay this morning shortly after 6 o'clock.
LAWRENCE, Mass., June 9.--The body of the stranger who was shot at Andover yesterday has been identified as that of Cornelius McCluskey, of Centralville, near Lowell.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 9.--An explosion occurred at 4 o'clock this afternoon by which one fireman lost his life, one was fatally injured, and several were badly burned.

TORONTO, Ontario, June 9.--Mr. Doyle, manager of the Brooklyn Association ball team, was in Toronto to-day trying to secure the release of Slattery, left fielder in the Toronto International League ager, and the offer is being considered by Toronto. Slattery is one of the best all round men in the team and Toronto could ill afford to lose him.

MALONE, N.Y., June 9.--The President's vacation is at an end, and he is on his way back to Washington, somewhat sunburned and weatherbeaten, but generally refreshed by his fortnight's stay at the Saranac Inn.
The Mets will meet the Louisvilles again today. Association, the Mets advancing to seventh position yesterday.

At the meeting of the Trustees of the American Cathedral Association which was held at the house of the Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix on Wednesday evening the Executive Committee devoted themeselves to the consideration of a site for the proposed structure.
SARATOGA, N.Y., June 9.--The closing meetings of the anniversary of the American Home Missionary Society were held here to-day.

The delegation of ladies who were selected a few weeks ago to visit Mayor Whitney, of Brooklyn, and try to induce him to appoint women on the Board of Education, paid their visit yesterday, but met with a disappointing refusal.

The fishermen of Prince's Bay are up in arms against the menhaden fishermen who cruise in the bay and "scoop up" the weakfish by hundreds. The fishermen have several scouts on duty patrolling the beach. The first menhaden boat that appears on the grounds will be severely dealt with.

The Cincinnati players administrated a "whitewash" to the Brooklyn players yesterday. Harkins, who pitched, was hit hard and poorly supported. Smith of Cincinnati proved an enigma to the local batters, who got only six hits, five of which were bases on balls.

Interest in the Baltimore and Ohio deal having in good part subsided it was with mild surprise that the announcement was received down town yesterday that Mr. Garrett's visit to this city was for the purpose of bringing negotiations into shape to be closed before his departure for Europe, a fortnight hence.

GRAND FORKS, Dakota, June 9.--The Regents of the North Dakota University this morning unanimously elected ex-Gov. Gilbert Pierce President of the university.

CONCORD, N.H., June 9.--Chondler received the Republican nomination to-night for the Senatorial vacancy caused by the death of Senator Pike. He received 118 votes, against 38 for all others.

The beauties of the plan of trial by jury, as exemplified by the municipal machinery of New-York City, have become unbearable, and Judge Barrett, in Oyer and Terminer, has determined to better matters.

Commissioner Pierson's committee of Trunk Line General Passenger Agents met at Commissioner Fink's office yesterday and discusaed a number of cases in which excursion rates were petitioned for. No changes were made in any of the existing differentials.

The wholesale drug store of Charles H. Pleasants, 61 West Honston-street, was burned out yesterday. The building is an old-fashioned two story and attic brick structure, with a rear extension on Houston-street. Mr. Pleasants and his wife lived on the second floor of the premises.

MONTREAL, June 9.--"Billy" Moloney, with his wife and family, has left to spend the Summer months at the charming village of Lachine, situated on the banks of the St. Lawrence, about 10 miles from here. The "boodle" Aldermen have not yet made their arrangements for the Summer.

LEXINGTON, Ky., June 9.--At A. De Long's place, near here, a fine Shetland pony deliberately hanged itself with a rope swing in the yard.

The nomination of WILLIAM E. CHANDLER for United States Senator by the Republican legislative caucus at Concord last night puts the New-Hampshire Republicans handsomely "in line" with their party in this State under the leadership of TOM PLATT, and shows that their moral tone is in a condition which assures a hearty support of Mr. BLAINE next year.

There was many a warm tribute paid to the memory of Charles D. Keep yesterday when the "tape" unexpectedly announced his death. The rare good nature and genial soul of the man left an impress all over Wall-street.

The committee appointed by the managers of the Manhattan Club to investigate the conduct of Lawyer Ira Shafer in the billiard room several weeks ago took the matter in hand yesterday. They were busy for a long while. Their report, it is expected, will be presented next Thursday evening. The investigators are A. Wright Sanford, Frederic R. Condert, and Sergeant Cram.

Coroner Lindsay, of Brooklyn, Eastern District, was requested to take the ante-mortem statement of Joseph Heilman, who is dying at his home, 75 Varet-street, from injuries received at the hands of George Sellers, of 258 Hopkins-street. The men quarreled several days ago, when Sellers seized a cobble stone and dealt his victim a blow on the head with it. He is now under arrest.

PORT JEFFERSON, June 9.--The fast and stanch pleasure and freight steamer Nonowantuc, plying regularly between here and Bridgeport, Conn., went ashore at the mud flats early this morning, during an impenetrable fog.
SCRANTON, Penn., June 9.--There was a stormy scene at the Grassy Island colliery, near Peckville, a few miles north of Scranton, this morning.

Miss Susie Frances Lewis, daughter of Mr. Francis A. Palmer, of Stamford, Conn., and Mr. J. Miller Crampton, of New-York, were married at "Elmwood," the home of the bride's parents, yesterday by the Rev. Dr. William M. Taylor, of New-York, assisted by the Rev. F.H. Marling.
After holding the lead for eight innings the New-Yorks lost a game to the Washington Club on the Polo Grounds yesterday by the close score of 3 to 2.
The Commissioners of Emigration yesterday decided to send back all but one of the 17 Irish families who were sent here on the steamship Chester by an agent of the British Government.

LEXINGTON, Ky., June 9.--The Administrator of the estate of T.J. Nichols, a prominent turf man, who was killed two years ago by an accident on the Kentucky Central Railroad, sued the company for damages. This afternoon the suit was compromised at $8,000.
The roof of the Coliseum, at Jones's Wood, Sixty-eighth-street and Avenue A, was set on fire last evening by an electric light wire coming in contact with and igniting one of the beams.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 9.--A contract has been awarded for the construction and erection of the monument which the officers and crews of the Saratoga and other training ships will erect to the memory of the four shipmates of the Saratoga who were drowned off Trinidad on the last Winter's cruise.

The following notice was issued yesterday by the Grant Monument Association: The Grant Monument Association invite sketches or designs for a monument or memorial building to be erected at Riverside Park, in the city of NewYork, over the tomb of Gon. Grant.

CONCORD, N.H., June 9.--A joint convention was held to-day for the choosing of State officers. The following named gentlemen were elected: Secretary of State--A.B. Thompson of Concord; State Treasurer--Solon A. Carter, of Concord; State Printer--John B. Clark, of Manchester; Commissiary.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 9.--Drafts on New-York --Sight, 15 cents; telegraphic, 22 cents.

The suit of W.H.N. Sanger against Seymour, Baker Co., the stock brokers, which was on trial for three days in the Supreme Court before Judge Andrews and a jury, resulted yesterday in a verdict for the plaintiff for $8,500 and costs, all that he claimed, with interest.

TUCSON, Arizona, June 9.--A Pontsno special says: "The Indians crossed the railroad track one mile west of here this afternoon, and are hotly pursued by Johnson's and Lawton's commands. They are heading north, for the Santa Catalina Mountains."

AUGUSTA, Ga., June 9.--The Carpenters and Joiners' Union of this city has boycotted the larg dry goods house of C. Gray Co. Gray refused to join with the dry goods merchants of the city in a movement to close the stores at 6 o'clock during the Summer months.
OTTAWA, Ontario, June 9.--It bas been definitely decided that Mr. Laurier, member for Quebec, will be the new leader of the Liberal Party. The outlook for the Reformers is not very bright.

An unprepossessing person who landed in this city from a European steamer on Thursday is receiving constant attention from members of Chief Detective Byrnes's staff, He is under surveillance because of his criminal career and his ability as a cracksman.

Smith, the Government leader, gave notice that to-morrow he would move that the committee name the period at which they world report the Irish Crimes Act Amendment bill to the House. This announcement was received with great cheers and counter-cheers.

The Committee appointed by the Central Labor Union to make arrangements for the McGlynn demonstration met last evening and held a conference with the committee appointed by Dr. McGlynn's friends and parishioners.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 9.--The starters in the 25-mile bicycle road race this atternoon were William Harding, E.A. Deblois, and F.L. Damery, of the Hartford Wheel Club; Lewis A. Miller, of Meriden; Ludwig Forster, of Elmwood, and T.J. Mills, of Bristol.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 9.--The Wyoming Valley was visited by a terrfic rainstorm this afternoon. At Nanticoke there was a cloud burst, which did great damage to property and created consternation among the inhabitants.
At the annual meeting of the Princeton Review Publishing Company yesterday the capital stock was reduced from $15,000 to $14,450. The latter sum represents the actual stock issued.
After 22 years of existence without a home the Harvard Club last night celebrated the acquisition of one with appropriate ceremonies. The new clubhouse is at 11 West Twentysecond-street.

For the ninth time yesterday the members of the Grand Army of the Republic of NewYork and Brooklyn, together with their families, were the guests of the Hon. John H. Starin at an excursion up the Hudson to Excelsior Park.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 9.--At a meeting of the Kentucky Distillers' Association to day a resolution recommending a cessation of the production of whisky until Oct. 1, 1888, was adopted. At least 95 per cent. of the producing capacity of the state was represented.

The Metropolitans won a game yesterday from the Louisville team by a score of 7 to 4. Good sharp field work marked the game played by the victors.

OTTAWA, June 9.--Fred White, Controller of the Mounted Police, received a telegram to-day stating that over a hundred horses stolen from the Canadian Bloods in the Northwest by American Indians have been recovered by the American Agent stationed at Belknap, Montana. The Bloods express themselves satisfied, and no raids are anticipated. The Canadian authorities propose to return all horses stolen south of the line by British Indians.

The community that bustles about Wallstreet was stricken with a sense of personal loss when the tapes ticked out the announcement of Charles D. Keep's death yesterday. No better known or better liked man had ever more fully identified himself with that section of the city.

The anniversary parade of the children who belong to the Sunday-schools in the Eastern District of Brooklyn took place yesterday and, in spite of the intense heat none of the little ones suffered very much.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 9.--Secretary Lindsley, of the State Board of Health, has received an official report from Health Officer Blankenship, of Maryville, Blount County, concerning the epidemic of dysentery at that place. ERIE, Penn., June 10.--The use of natural gas for balloon ascensions was tested here this afternoon by Prof. Meyers, of Mohawak, N.Y. Scientists argued that natural gas was too heavy, having no lifting power. Mr. Meyers, contrary to expectations, made a successful ascent, and after gaining a height of nearly three miles landed safely to-night 20 miles south of Erie. The gas acted better than coal gas.

Judge Cullen, of the Supreme Court, yesterday rendered a decision to the effect that the Board of Health of Newtown had no right to levy a tax of $1 on every dead body of a nonresident buried within the borders of the town.
Worcester, Mass., is to lose the Pond Machine Tool Company's works, and Plainfield, N.J., is to gain them. The shops are among the largest in Worcester, and employ about 500 men.

BOSTON, June 10.--The West End Street Railway bill, over which there has been so much controversy, and which involves the control of the street railway lines of this city, came up in the House this morning.

ROME, June 10.--The Pope's gift to Queen Victoria on the occasion of her jubilee consists of a mosaic reproduction of Raphael's fresco representing an allegorical figure of Poetry. The work was executed in the Vatican. Mgr. Scilla will convey the gift to England, and he will be accompanied by Fathers Zalesca and Meri, two young priests of the Ecclesiastical Academy, whom the Pope will, in honor of the occasion, create Bishops.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 10.--When Doorman Moore at Police Headquarters went in to light up the cells in the lock-up this evening he discovered the body of Carl Teemer hanging by a strap from the iron bars at the top of his cell door. He had committed suicide. He had been on a long spree, and went to his home this morning and threatened to take his wife's life. Then she had him arrested.

The rocky pass at Spuyten Duyvil, near the spot where Senator Wagner was burned to death, was the scene of another accident yesterday morning, in which a number of passengers narrowly escaped and one was slightly injured. MADISON, Ind., June 10.--Two miles north of Brooksburg, this county, at midnight last night, six masked men took young farmer Stout Brinson and his wife and child from their beds, removed all the furniture, and then burned the horse and quietly disappeared. No cause for the deed is known, and there is no clue to incendiaries.

Good batting characterized the game played by the New-Yorks against the players from Washington yesterday, and the result was that the latter were defeated 9 to 2. Whitney, the tall and powerful pitcher of the visiting players, tried his utmost to deceive the batters of the local team, but without success, the latter batting the ball in all directions. For the NewYorks Keefe pitched a grand game, and he was handsomely supported.

COLUMBUS, June 10.--The Attorney-General filed a suit in the Common Pleas Court this afternoon, on behalf of the State, against Albert Netter, the Cincinnati banker, for $27,000. MADISON, Ind., June 10.--The Vevay Post Office was broken into last night and robbed of an unknown quantity of stamps and cash. The Cross Plains mail pouch was broken open and letters rifled.

ST. PETERSBURG, June 10.--Several shocks of earthquake have occurred at Vernome, in Turkestan. The town was almost entirely destroyed. One hundred and twenty persons were killed and 125 injured. Among the latter is Gen. Friede, the Governor of the province of Semiretchinsk. Shocks still continue to be felt at intervals. The inhabitants of the town are panicstricken, and have fled for safety to the open country.

CITY OF MEXICO, June 11, via Galveston.-- Louis Huller left to-day for Europe. He will be absent six months. Huller is the chief promoter of the International Company, owning and colonizing the upper section of the peninsula of Lower Cali fornia. He has made a large fortune in his Mexican enterprises, and has recently been granted other colonization and railway concessions.

LONDON, June 11.--A collision occurred to-day at Denbigh, Wales, between a mob and a body of police who were protecting an auctioneer engaged in selling property for tithes. The mob turned an excited bull loose on the police and assaulted them with rotten eggs.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11.--William Bacon Stevens, D.D., LL.D., Bishop of the Diocese of Pennsylvania of the Protestant Episcopal Church, died at 9:10 o'clock this morning. The cause of his death was dropsy. He had been lingering for several weeks.

BENSON, Arizona, June 11.--At dark Thursday night Lieut. Johnson was only a half hour behind the Indians who are on the warpath, but during the evening they threw him off the track. The renegades appear to have experienced leaders, probably some of Crock's scouts.

FINDLAY, Ohio, June 11.--The celebration of the application of natural gas to the mechanical arts that has been in progress here for four days closed to-night with an exhibition by Battery B, of Cincinnati.
The members of the Union Labor Party in this city have elected their delegates to their State Convention, which takes place in Elmira on June 15.

MEMPHIS, Tenn, June 11.--A hailstorm, accompanied with lightning, passed over Somerville, Tenn., to-day, at noon. Serious damage was done to crops, and W.H. Boyd, a prominent colored politician of Fayette County.

Mr. Herbert Spencer is of the opinion that the followers of Charles Darwin are more Darwinist than the founder of their school, and one object in writing the essays now reprinted was to call attention to the fact that they have retrograded toward a more restricted view than Darwin ever expressed.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, May 30.--Radiant in colors brilliant as the hues of the glowing disk just sunk below the billowy Western prairies, bubbling over with life and laughter, the night population of this curious city of double life and double history begins its labors.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 11.--By a collision between a passenger and an express train near Windsor, Victoria, on May 11, five persons were killed and 30 wounded.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 11.--An important step was taken by the Faculty of Princeton College last night. For the past few weeks they have been considering what should be done in regard to the numerous new branches which have been and are still being introduced into the curriculum of the college.

DUBLIN, June 11.--The evictions at Bodyke were further carried out to-day. The first house visited by the evicting force was that of Timothy Collins, but as it was announced that a daughter of Collins lay dying inside, the work of eviction was abandoned.
An Augusta liquor seller is freely selling the intoxicant at his shop and making no bones of it.
TORONTO, June 11.--Twelve hundred union and non-union carpenters went out on strike here at noon in accordance with the decision of a mass meeting of the carpenters held last night.

The ale and porter brewers say that they are not afraid of either the Beer Brewers' Union or of the central Labor Union, and will not consent to the proposed reinstatement of the 19 browers who were discharged from Lyman Co.'s brewery because they refused to join the ale and porter brewers' local assembly.

BOSTON, June 11.--After a two days' trial in the Circuit Court before Judge Nelson, a jury to-day awarded Seth A. Pierce, a Providence wool merchant, $2,000 damages against officers of the city of Springfield for false arrest on the occasion of the recent celebration.
BOSTON, June 11.--There was a large and fashinable gathering in King's Chapel at noon to-day to witness the marriage of Mr. Nathaniel Thayer, son of the late Nathaniel Thayer, and Miss Paul Revere.

EVERSON, Penn., June 12.--The District Board of the Knights of Labor met here to-day, and, after having a conference with Superintendent Lynch, effected an agreement under which they will order all their men to work at Frick Co.'s works to-morrow morning, at the advance of 12 per cent.

MONTREAL, June 11.--The fruitless search prosecuted with a lantern by Diogenes at a time when the virtue of newspaper advertising was among the undiscovered arts was a mere bagatelle compared to the quest of THE TIMES'S correspondent in Montreal for something original in the way of opinions on the question of commercial union between the undeveloped Canadian giant and the Titan across the border.

The wedding of Miss Frances Bishop, the actress, and Mr. John T. McKever was very quietly celebrated at St. Luke's Church, on Hudson-street, yesterday at 1 o'clock.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 12.--The Trades and Labor Assembly, which includes all building trades in the city except stonemasons, held a general meeting; this afternoon and decided that unless the demands of the striking carpenters are met by next Wednesday all the other workmen within its jurisdiction shall be called out. This would add about 900 men to the present number on strike.

The steamship Chandermagor, which arrived on Saturday from the Mediterranean, brought 1,193 steerage passengers. The last time she arrived here she was libeled for bringing over more passengers than she was allowed by the American law. Capt. Jacques said yesterday that he had brought over 200 more passengers than the limit fixed upon the last time he was in port, but he had brought no cargo, which left more space for passengers.

DANVILLE, West Va., June 12.--The body of Mr. R.W. White, a prominent citizen and business man of this city, was found this morning in the canal. He had been suffering for some time from vertigo and neuralgia, but left his home last night apparently in good spirits and somewhat improved in health.

LONDON, June 12.--The Queen, in order to invest the jubilee ceremony in Westminster Abbey with greater pomp, has consented to assume the state robes and to be surrounded with all the insignia of sovereignty after entering the Abbey. Eight thousand troops will line the route to the Abbey, besides a guard of honor of 600 persons.

Ten thousand persons are to take part in the jubilee service at Westminister Abbey. In order that all classes may be represented the Lord Chamberlain has announced his intention to give to Mr. George Potter 60 tickets to be distributed among the millions who toil and spin. It may perhaps surprise the Lord Chamberlain to learn that the workingmen of the metropolis do not regard Mr. Potter himself as in anyway representing them.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12.--Alfred Ham, trainer, and C.G. Pratt, manager of the crew of Cornell University, with the members of the crew, are in the city endeavoring to arrange a boat race with the crew of the University of Pennsylvania.

BERLIN, June 12.--Emperor William slept well last night and his condition is improved, the pains having abated.

MONTREAL, June 12.--"Billy" Moloney has chosen one of the prettiest and most romantic spots in the province for his Summer residence. He is staying at the principal hotel in Lachine, a pretty little town about ten miles above Montreal.

WASHINGTON, June 12.--The delay in proceeding with the examinations for promotions and dismissals at the War Department is explained by Civil Service Commissioner Oberly as being largely due to the difficulty of selecting a seventh member of the central board, which is to pass upon the questions to be submitted to the candidates.

Archbishop Corrigan yesterday laid the cornerstone of the Church of the Immaculate Conception at Amenia. SAN FRANCISCO, June 12.--The Captain of the steamer Alameda, which arrived here yesterday from Australia, bringing news of the death in Sydney, Australia, of William E. Sheridan, the tragedian, states that Mr. Sheridan was in poor health while in Australia.
HELENA, Montana, May 26.--In November, 1883, William A. Dewar, for many years a resident of Helena, and a man of considerable wealth, went East to spend the Winter.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 12.--The baccalaureate sermon to the graduating class at Brown University was preached in the First Baptist Meeting House to-day by President Robinson.
EVANSVILLE, Ind., June 12.--A report reached this city this evening that a meteoric stone had fallen near St. Joseph, in this county, this morning, The stone fell about eight miles from this city.

It is a remarkable fact that Florida, coast tropical State, is without a State Board of Health. Gov. Perry announces to the Louisiana board that a bill is pending before the Florida Legislature, now in session, for the creation of this safeguard to the public interests.

Commencement Week at Princeton College begins on Saturday. At 10 A.M. theses will be read by the graduating class of the John C. Green School of Science, in Chemical Hall, and in the afternoon the Princeton Athletic Association will have its annual Caledonian games.

The card presented by the Brooklyn Jockey Club for to-day's races, on the Gravesend track, is an excellent one and will furnish a fine afternoon's sport with some possible surprises.

The fair students of Packer Institute, Brooklyn, assembled in the chapel on Joralemon-street last night to listen to the Rev. Dr. Charles Henry Hall, Rector of Holy Trinity, preach the annual baccalaureate sermon. Many of their friends were present, and the cozy little chapel was comfortably filled. Good living in its moral sense was the subject of Dr. Hall's discourse.

BOSTON, June 12.--The mystery attaching to the disappearance of George R. Parks, the young actor, was solved to-day when the harbor police, in making their customary afternoon rounds, found his body floating in the harbor off the South Ferry, about midway between the city proper and East Boston.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 12.--Some time ago the Memphis Evening Scimiter sent out circular letters to the leading newspapers of Alabama, Arkansas, Mississippi, Louisiana, Tennessee, and Texas putting the following query: "In view of President Cleveland's pocket veto of the River and Harbor bill, do you favor his renomination by the Democratic Party in 1888" Thirty-five replies were received; of these, 27 were in the affirmative, 6 in the negative, and 2 non-committal.

Some curious experiments, which are likely to be productive of practical results of great interest to army surgeons and military men generally, have just been made here by M. Chauvel, of the Society of Surgery.
Five hundred thousand eels were recently sent from Altona by rail to Pesth for the purpose of stocking the Lower Danube, where this palatable fish was thus far unknown.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, June 12.--Of the seasons that have come and gone during the last 15 years none are regarded by Saratogians with such pleasurable emotions as those of 1879, 1880, and 1881.

A Methodist camp meeting and week of revival was begun at the Jane-Street Methodist Episcopal Church yesterday morning, under the direction of the Rev. Stephen Merritt, the Pastor, and the Rev. John Godson, his associate.
BOSTON, June 12.--The Hon. James N. Buffum, one of the last of the band of Abolitionists led by Garrison and Phillips, died at his home in Lynn this evening at 10 o'clock.

The Brooklyn Fire Department were again called to the Havemeyer's sugar refinery on Commercial-street, Greenpoint, early yesterday morning. Fire had broken out again in the smoldering ruins and threatened to commuicate with the surrounding tenements and warehouses.
Yesterday was the warmest day ever experienced in San Francisco since the Signal Service opened an office here.

F.J. Hepburn, for many years a compositor in THE TIMES office, died suddenly, Saturday evening, of heart disease, at his residence, 767 Lafayette-avenue, Brooklyn. He leaves a widow and three children. Funeral services will be held at the house to-morrow at 1 P.M. THE TIMES'S chapel will attend in a body, with his many friends in and out of Typographical Union No. 6.

The inquest in the case of George Farrish, who is said to have been maltreated by attendants at the City Asylum for the Insane, will be continued to-day at the Coroners' office. Cleary and McCue, the attendants at the asylum who are supposed to have inflicted the injuries which caused Farrish's death, were arrested yesterday on a warrant issued by Coroner Levy.

LONDON, June 12.--Discount was slightly harder during the past week at 1@ . The Stock Exchange loan rate to next account is 2@1 . On the Stock Exchange during the week there was a general reaction downward and dealings were limited.
Mayor Hewitt will return from Greenwood Lake to-day. He may bring with him a list of nominations for some of the offices where vacancies exist.

CHICAGO, June 12.--Mr. Daly's company had played "Nancy Co." to large houses during the last week, despite other powerful attractions, and the piece will be kept on the stage at Hooley's for another week.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12.--The funeral of Bishop Stevens will take place next Wednesday. In the morning the body will be removed to Holy Trinity Church, Nineteenth and Walnut streets, where it will rest upon a catafalque in the aisle.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 12.--Mrs. Mary Flynn was found in her room at the residence of Mrs. J. McCormack, in Waterbury, this morning with a terrible gash in the back of her head. She was employed in the McCormack family and retired last night at the usual hour.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 12.--A telegram from the city of Mexico yesterday, announced that a contract for draining the Valley of Mexico had just been awarded to a syndicate of Cleveland capitalists, known as the Bucyrus Construction Company.
Annie Miller, 28 years old, and a native of Germany, is filled with the belief that a horde of men are enamored of her and are pursuing her in hopes of being able to declare their affection.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 12.--John Felix, a native of Poland, aged 28 years, who recently arrived from New-York, was last night killed by a fall of coal and rock in W.G. Payne Co.'s mine at Luzerne. As he had no family or friends in this vicinity, the Poor Directors will bury him tomorrow.
A private dispatch received in this city yesterday announced the wedding of Harry Morris and May Howard, the well-known vaudeville artists. Both were divorced about a year ago.

KEY WEST, Fla., June 12.--One new case of yellow fever has appeared since yesterday and one patient has been discharged from the hospital. The British bark Brothers and Siters sent three sick men ashore.

A party of 16 Greeks from Syria arrived yesterday on the Netherlands American steamship Leerdam. They were poorly dressed, and had only a few dollars apiece. The immigration authorities detained the men, and they may be sent back to Rotterdam.

TUCSON, Arizona, June 13.--The Indians attacked the ranch of the Inter-Ocean Cattle Company on Sunday and burned all the buildings. William Penn Nixon, of Chicago, was the principal owner.
CHICAGO, June 13.--Since Saturday the crowd on 'Change has lost its faith in the clique's peg, which it had been generally supposed was firmly stuck in the July wheat market at 85 cents.

Little Willie Richardson, of 237 Washington-street, Newark, while playing on the dock at the foot of Clay-street, fell into the water early last evening and was drowned. The body was recovered later.

BUFFALO, N.Y. June 13.--Three motions were made before Judge Childs to-day for judgment of foreclosure and sale of mortgages against the Buffalo, New-York and Philadelphia Railroad. All were granted.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 13.--The three lower classes of Princeton College are now busily engaged with the final examinations of the year which will end on June 22. Most of the seniors are at home, writing their orations and theses or resting a little before the gayeties of next week.

CHICAGO, June 13.--The new working rules adopted by the Carpenters and Builders' Association, making nine hours a day's work, went into effect this morning.

CHICAGO, June 13.--Mr. Edward Harrigan and his company began an engagement at the Columbia Theatre this evening, playing "The Leather Patch." The house was crowded, and the piece was a success from the start. The types were recognized as so characteristic that they might have been taken from Chicago life as easily as from New-York, and were promptly and heartily appreciated. The engagement promises to be a very successful one.

Delegates from many Irish societies met last night at 64 East Fourth-street and decided to have a big celebration on Tuesday evening, June 21, to "commemorate the children of Ireland who have perished through famine, imprisonment, and the scaffold during Queen Victoria's half century reign."

Members of the Lamb Club, to the number of about 70, made a descent upon Mr. Leser Wallack, at his country home in Stamford, Conn., on Sunday, and were royally entertained by the veteran manager. It was what the Lambs call their "annual washing," and a hearty good time was enjoyed by host and guests. Among the guests of the club who participated in the day's enjoyment were Judge Brady and ex-Lieut.-Gov. Dorsheimer.

ST. LOUIS, June 13.--The most senseless strike that has ever occurred in St. Louis was inaugurated to-day by the shoemakers' union. Last week a non-union man was engaged by the St. Louis Shoe and Slipper Company at a salary of $6 a week.

A sub-committee of the Executive Committee appointed by the Trustees of the proposed new Cathedral of St. John Divine met in the office of S.D. Babcock, 32 Nassau-street, yesterday afternoon, to receive and consider propositions of property owners in regard to a site for the building. Nothing definite was determined upon, except that the advantages of each offer should be made the subject of a report to the Executive Committee.
The annual regatta of the East River Yacht Club was held yesterday. There were 21 entries, from little cat-rigged boats of 15 feet 4 inches up to cabin sloops of 36 feet in length.
There was an Anarchist picnic in Weehawken on Sunday, as our readers are already aware. There was the usual effusion of Anarchist oratory in various dialects of the German language.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 13.--The amendment to the factory law of last year, introduced by Senator McMillan, of Buffalo, and signed by Gov. Hill on May 25, has occasioned great excitement in labor circles in view of the fact that eight deputy inspectors are created by it.
The Rapid Transit Commissioners devoted two hours yesterday afternoon to the discussion whether the city shall demand a percentage of the gross receipts on the routes laid out by them.
BELVIDERE, N.J. June 13.--The town is somewhat excited over an affair that has an ugly look. Some one fired a pistol ball through a window of McCammon Perry's hardware store.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 13.--President I.F. Coe, of the Southern Female College, at La Grange, Ga., died suddenly last night of apoplexy. The city is full of visitors attending the Commencement exercises, which are necessarily interrupted by this sad and heavy stroke. The college he has built is his monument. He left it completely organized to be carried on by his family, who have for years labored with him in giving it such fame.

NEW-HAVEN, June 13.--A big crowd of lawn tennis experts assembled at the grounds of the New-Haven Lawn Tennis Club, on Whitney-avenue, this afternoon to witness the opening of the tournament for the championship of New-England in singles and doubles.

PLYMOUTH, Mass., June 13.--At a meeting of the Pilgrim Society, held in Pilgrim Hall to-day, the Hon. John D. Long, of Hingham was chosen President, in place of Mr. J. Henry Stickney, of Baltimore, resigned. Mr. Stickney was elected a VicePresident, and William Hodge of Plymouth, was added to the Board of Trustees.

ERIE, Penn., June 13.--Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Rosenzweig and their two sons, Edward and Whitney, were stricken down yesterday after eating, in addition to the meal, some strawberries. Edward lies at the point of death, the others will recover.
The piece in which Miss Marguerite St. John is to appear for Mr. Morton's benefit at the Harlem Theatre Comique is Minnie Palmer's farce called "My Sweetheart," not Mr. W.S. Gilbert's "Sweethearts."

Parker, Public Printer Benedict, and a score or more of other prominent men in various parts of the country have formed a club and purchased 600 acres of land at a cost of $1,200 at the base of Slide Mountain, one of the grandest localities in the Catskill Mountains.
MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., June 13.--Nearly two hours were occupied by Judge Parker today in his charge to the jury in the Peak murder trial.

The members of the Business Men's Association were the witnesses for the prosecution yesterday, in the trial of Joseph Murphy in the Court of General Sessions, for the keeping of a disorderly house at 101 West Twentyseventh-street.
Commander-in-Chief Fairchild, of the Grand Army of the Republic, paid a visit to Brooklyn yesterday, and received a big reception from the Grand Army men of that city.

The death of George Farrish at the insane asylum on Ward's Island has opened up a broad and deep line of investigation. Coroner Levy, appreciating his responsibility in the matter, has determined to prolong the inquiry, in the hope of definitely proving or disproving the charge made by the man's friends that he was practically murdered by the attendants.

MONTREAL, June 14.--The Grand Jury made the following presentment to the Court of Queen's Bench this afternoon, in the case of Mr. Shepperd, editor of the Toronto News, who has persistently refused to pay the fine of $200 imposed on him for libeling the Sixty-fifth Battalion during the Northwest rebellion.

Chairman Luther R. Marsh was not at the meeting of the New Parks Commission yesterday afternoon, but Commissioners Quintard and Page heard evidence in regard to the value of several pieces of property to be condemned for the Van Cortlandt Park.

The Pullman Car Company's latest acquisition is a train of vestibule cars for use on the New-York and Chicago limited express on the Pennsylvania Road. By means of a vestibule arrangement between the cars the whole train can be traversed without going outside.

At the meeting of the Municipal Council of the Irish National League in Justice Kelly's court room last evening President Delany gave notice that delegates to the council from the various branches must be elected some time this month. A special committee was appointed to reorganize St. Agnes's and other delinquent branches.

CONSTANTINOPLE, June 14.--Sir Henry Drummond Wolff, British High Commissioner in connection with Egyptian affairs, has informed the Porte that Queen Victoria has appended her signature to the Anglo-Turkish convention concerning Egypt, and that her Majesty awaits the issue of the Sultan's irade announcing the convention to be in force.

Of three large fires, each causing heavy loss, which have taken place within a month in Brooklyn and New-York, the origin of two is unknown. In each instance the property destroyed was owned by companies which have had recent troubles with employes.
The opinion of Corporation Counsel Lacombe that pool selling in this city is illegal, whether the bet is made through an agent or not, has stirred up the Police Captains.

The Brooklyn Board of Education wants $2,036,119 to carry on its work during the present year, and this demand was the subject of an hour's discussion in the Board of Estimate yesterday. It is an increase of more than $500,000 over the appropriation for last year...

TROY, June 14.--The will of the late William A. Wheeler has been opened at Malone. It gives $25,000 to home missions, $5,000 to foreign missions, $500 to his housekeeper, Betsey Chambers, and a few bequests to various friends. It is rumored that interested parties intend to contest the will.
LONDON, June 14.--The steamship Rhynland, (Belg.,) Capt Jamison, from New-York June 4, for Antwerp, passed the Lizard at 1 P.M. to-day.
TORONTO, Ontario, June 14.--The farm ers of nearly every county in Ontario have met, discussed, and declared in favor of commercial union.

Oliver Howard Blood, who was arrested on Monday at New-Orleans, charged by the proprietor of the St. Charles Hotel with obtaining money under false pretenses, has a wife living at 237 East Thirteenth-street, this city.
The sale of the Pene Du Bois library and art collection was continued yesterday. There were about 30 buyers, most of whom represented city book dealers.

Gerry, President of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, Justice O'Reilly, sitting at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday granted a summons for Thomas Maguire, whose company of Japanese acrobats is now performing at the Standard Theatre under the management of John R. Marshall.

WASHINGTON, June 14.--Chief Signal Officer Greely has been directed to go to New-York for the purpose of making arrangements regarding circuits and other telegraphic business connected with the Signal Service for the coming fiscal year.

The long and cautious preparations to discover whether Jacob Sharp really bribed the Aldermen or whether the Aldermen were struck by a lot of thousand-dollar bills which the wind blew in their unwilling faces continued as usual in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday.

When the Committee on Contested Seats of the Republican County Committee resumed the investigation last evening in the contest in the Sixteenth Assembly District neither Capt. Cregan, William H. Townley, his counsel, nor Secretary Edward E. Fisher were present. Chairman Russell declared that the case should be closed that night; if the other side was not present it was their own fault.

Four new Police Captains were given their shields at Police Headquarters yesterday. They are Edward Slevin, who was assigned to the Twelfth Precinct; Josiah A. Westervelt, assigned to the Grand Central Station; Thomas Reilly, sent to the City Hall command, and Philip Cassidy, who will have charge of the Morrisania district.

WASHINGTON, June 14.--The President made the following appointments to-day: Clarence H. Pitkin, of Vermont, to be United States Attorney for the District of Vermont; Henry S. Lubbock, of California, to be Supervising Inspector of Steam Vessels for the First District, San Francisco; Hyman Abraham, of Oregon, to be Collector of Customs for the District of Willamette, Oregon.

The indictment against George W. Gibbons, the lawyer, of 317 Broadway, has been dismissed, on motion of District Attorney Martine, who stated in Court that he was satisfied that Mr. Gibbons had no knowledge of the alleged swindles of the British American Claim Agency, for participation in which he was inindicted.

PITTSBURG, June 14.--At this forenoon's session of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers the annual scale was completed. It was given to the printer this afternoon, and printed copies of the scale will be furnished by Secretary Martin and Joseph D. Weeks to-morrow.

Alfred D. Griswold, Sergeant of the Old Guard, died suddenly last night in the armory at Fourteenth-street and Fifth-avenue. He dined at the Hotel Brunswick last evening with E.T. Moore, Secretary of the Old Guard. Together they started for the armory.

Fire broke out last night in the stable in the rear of Henry Vogel's bar fixtures factory, which runs from 311 Bowery to Extra-place, and is a four-story structure. While several men got out six of Vogel's horses an alarm was sent out.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 14.--Miss Helen Stanton, daughter of the late R.E. Stanton, was married this evening to Mr. Samuel Van Vanken Holmes, of Albany, N.Y. HARTFORD, June 14.--The Spring trotting meeting opened at Charter Oak Park to-day with a light attendance. The races were for the 2:37 and 2:19 classes.

Dr. H.D. Jennings and William Barnard played a game of billiards, 300 points up, in Daly's Assembly Rooms, Brooklyn, last night, for a prize valued at $50. Dr. Jennings was one of Brooklyn's representatives in the recent tournament of the Racquet Club, and Mr. Barnard is a popular amateur.

One of the most delightful customs among local yachtsmen is the annual ladies' day regatta of the Atlantic Yacht Club. Then all the wives and sisters and other fellows' sisters attached to the club assemble at the comfortable house overlooking the Bay, at Bay Ridge, and see a little regatta arranged especially for their benefit and sailed over a course that is visible from start to finish from the clubhouse veranda.

The Mets, by scoring two runs in the last inning, won a game from the Louisville men at Staten Island yesterday. Hecker pitched a poor game, but he met with poor encouragement in the shape of field work by his colleagues.

Those persons who imagine that Henry E. Abbey has exhausted the foreign market for theatrical attractions and that after Bernhardt and Patti there was nothing left for him to introduce to this country in the way of great novelties are woefully mistaken. The Court of Appeals handed down a decision yesterday which will prove of interest to every property owner in Brooklyn, as it upsets all the established ideas in regard to the sale of umimproved lots for arrears of water rates. The suit upon which the decision is founded was brought by Mrs. Margaret Remsen against George S. Wheeler and the city of Brooklyn, in 1882.
BUFFALO, N.Y., June 14.--The degree of LL. D. has been conferred on Judge Charles Daniels, of the Supreme Court, by Niagara University.

LEXINGTON, Ky., June 14.--The fine 2-year-old bay colt Decree, by Dictator, dam Kentucky Belle, by Harald, belonging to Spencer Brothers, Pine Grove, Ky., died of lockjaw to-day, the result of sticking a nail in his foot.

LONDON, June 14.--In consequence of the refusal of a section of the Parnellites last night to listen to the advice of Mr. Gladstone, who suggested that only the weightier points be discussed, little progress was made with the Coercion bill, the whole evening being consumed in discussing 12 lines of the fifth clause.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., June 14.--An easterly gale has prevailed here all day, during which the sloop-yacht Gracie dragged her anchor and was driven ashore on Riverhead Beach, where she lies in a dangerous position. The sloop yacht Fiona slipped her collar and drifted among a fleet of yachts off Bellows Wharf, but was boarded by Capt. Dennis before much damage was done.

TRENTON, N.J., June 14.--Gov. Green has issued an order calling the First Brigade into camp at Sea Girt on Monday, Aug. 22. The date is a week later than any one supposed it would be, and the guardsmen are said to be dissatisfied.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 14.--Col. James E. Morrison, of New-York, Chief Examiner of the State Civil Service Commission, arrived in Buffalo Monday evening to conduct the examination of candidates for the Collectorship of Canal Statiscs and clerkships in that office.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14.--This has been Commencement Week at the Ogontz School, which was established in 1850 as the ChestnutStreet Seminary, and which now occupies the palatial building erected by Jay Cooke near Jenkintown.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14.--Association Championship--Cleveland, 6; Athletic, 3. Pitchers--Crowell and Seward. Earned runs--Cleveland, 2; Athletic, 1. Base hits--Cleveland, 12, Athletic, 8. Bases on balls--Cleveland, 2; Athletic, 1. Stolen bases-- Cleveland, 2; Athletic, 1. Errors--Cleveland, 2; Athletic, 4.

COXSACKIE, N.Y., June 14.--Rumors have been current for several days that the National Bank, the only one here, was in trouble.
The new and luxurious Pullman Vestibuled Cars will be placed in service on the New-York and Chicago Limited of the Pennsylvania Railroad, commencing June 15.

CINCINNATI, June 14.--William Mahoney, a young man employed in a glove factory in this city, last night jumped from the Suspension Bridge, to satisfy himself and a few friends that the feat could be safely accomplished.

BERLIN, June 14.--It is officially announced that Emperor William is making remarkable progress toward recovery. He rose at noon to-day and passed the afternoon in his study, receiving several reports from Government officials.

Coroner Eidman, with his deputy, Dr. Scholer, and Dr. Justin Herold, went yesterday to St. Michael's Cemetery, Astoria, to again examine the exhumed body of Magdalena Zorn. A thorough autopsy was made. The decomposition of the remains was so advanced that the physicians had a difficult task, but they performed it with the greatest care.

Harvesters in the southern part of the Winter wheat region who were solicitous two or three days ago about the capacity of Chicago elevators, to which they desired to send their wheat, will now try to find a better market.
BINGHAMTON, June 14.--About 2,000 people attended the opening of the June races to-day. The 2:50 and 2:25 classes were trotted for purses of $300 each.

When Thomas B. McManus, the man who has been missing since Wednesday last, decided to quit New-York he made his preparations in a very methodical way. This is becoming more and more evident every day as the search for him continues.

Suburban candidates were thick at the Brooklyn Jockey Club races yesterday. The Bard and Hanover showed themselves to be ripe and fit for any demands made upon them next Saturday. CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 14.--The village of Kalida, in Putman County, is deeply exercised over a duel which took place yesterday between two young farmers scarcely of age-- John C. Grochus and Thomas Timberlake.

LONDON, June 14.--No handsomer sight was ever seen on the Thames than the start of the Jubilee yacht match, which took place shortly after noon to-day from Southend.

WASHINGTON, June 15.--Secretary Whitney has not yet approved the report of the board which selected the design of the armored battleship submitted by the Barrow Shipbuilding Company, but he will in all probability give his approval to that of the board, and thus make another step toward the reconstruction of the navy.

The White Star steamship Britannic, which was in collision with the Celtic, of the same line, on May 19, sailed yesterday afternoon. Her injuries had been thoroughly repaired, and she had received a new coat of paint.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 15.--The Democratic State Committee to-night called the State Convention to meet here on Thursday. Sept. 1. Fusion was only incidentally discussed, and an anti-monopoly campaign rather than anti-prohibition was foreshadowed by the discussion. Ex-Congressman Fredericks joint nomination seems now to be assured.

OTTAWA, June 15.--The social event of the season was a state ball given by Lord Lansdowne, Governor-General, at Rideau Hall to-night.
Thomas Gilligan, of 52 Warren-street, Brooklyn, was compelled to go to a police court yesterday to get his little 12-year-old daughter. Gilligan is a boatman, and some time ago employed Jacob Meyers.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 15.--Henry W. Slocum, of Brooklyn, to-day won the first prize and the championship in singles at lawn tennis at the tournament on the New-Haven Club grounds. He defeated Thacher, of Yale, in four sets by the score of 1-6, 6-2, 6-4, 6-1.

The trial of Daniel J. Bernstein and George Uppington for maintaining their Broadstreet "indicator stock exchange," thereby violating the gambling law, was yesterday concluded in the Court of General Sessions, Part III. The defendants claimed that they really dealt in stocks and did not gamble. The jury went out at 4 o'clock, and failing after several hours to agree, Judge Cowing discharged them and released the defendants.

CONCORD, N.H., June 15.--The Senate and House met in joint convention at noon for the purpose of electing a United States Senator for the unexpired term ending March 4, 1889. The Journals of both branches were read, showing that William E. Chandler had received a majority of the votes in each, and he was accordingly declared duly elected.

SARATOGA, N,Y., June 15.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. W.C. Ruger, C.J., and associates present, the following decision was handed down: No.420--William J. Gayner, respondent, vs. Leo Nelson etal, appellants.--Dismissed under Rule 21, without costs.

The Hon. Anson P. Morrill reached his eighty-fourth birthday last Friday. He is still remarkably smart and vigorous for a man of his age and is frequently seen on the street. His grounds and lawn are among the neatest and best kept in town, and he gives much attention to them.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 16.--The General Assembly has been in session all day to-day, wrestling with the big topics of politics and morals, the subject of a Constitutional Convention, and the matter of the new prohibitory law.

The Erasmus Hall Academy, the oldest institution of its grade in the State, was 100 years old yesterday, and last night celebrated its centenary in the Reformed Church of Flatbush.

READING, Penn., June 16.--Owing to recent legislation threatening the liquor interest a call has been issued to the brewers of this State to meet at Harrisburg on Sept. 8 for the purpose of forming the Brewers' Association of Pennsylvania.

KEY WEST, Fla., June 16.--The steamer Carondelet, which sailed to-night for New-York, took away a large number of refugees, unacolimated persons flying from the yellow fever. It has been raining and damp for the past two weeks, furnishing, with this high temperature, the proper conditions for the manufacture and spread of the disease. There were three new cases reported to-day, but no deaths. These make 30 cases in all to date.

WASHINGTON, June 16.--Major L.C. Overman, Corps of Engineers, has been ordered to inspect certain damaged camp and garrison equipage at the recruiting rendezvous.

CHICAGO, June 16.--The wheat market seems to have struck bottom. It bumped around gently to-day, but with few incidents and no excitement. The feverishness of the last two weeks was entirely absent, and the feeling prevailed that the panic was over, and that nothing serious need be apprehended for the future.

The New-York Children's Aid Society has once more begun its Summer work of health restoring and life saving at Bath and Coney Island. Last Monday began this year's activity at the Children's Home at Bath.

Starin's Glen Island, the popular day Summer resort for families, will be opened for the season on Thursday next. The pretty little collection of islands, connected by bridges, will be even more attractive this season than ever.

DETROIT, Mich., June 16.--The Legislature of this State has passed an addition to existing temperance legislation in the shape of a local option bill. The present statutes regulating the traffic in intoxicating liquors provide for a tax of $300 on every retail dealer and $500 on wholesalers, with a small tax on manufacturers of beer.

LONDON, June 16.--On the resumption of the debate on the Crimes bill this evening Mr. Dillon moved to adjourn in order to call the attention of the House to the Bodyke evictions. The Government, he said, had refused to appoint a committee' to inquire into the matter.

The Commissioners of Emigration and United States District Judge BROWN will find in our special cable dispatch from London this morning much interesting information concerning the legal status of assisted emigrants.

PARIS, June 16.--The Figaro says a sensation has been caused in French high life by the successful kidnapping of the Countess Campos, the recently divorced wife of the Duc de la Torre, a son of the late Marshal Serrano, of Spain.
READING, Penn., June 16.--Postmaster Goodman's money order clerk, Edward A. Schumacher, was to-day discovered to be short in his accounts to the extent of nearls $1,000.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 16.--The trial of P.J. Brumelkamp, Superintendent of the Onondaga Salt Springs, for conspiracy to defraud the State was brought to a close to-day, the jury rendering a verdict of "Not guilty."

The Brooklyn Jockey Club's meeting will be brought to a close this afternoon, and a half dozen races, all with a liberal lot of entries, are on the programme. Sinclair Tousey died yesterday at his home, 14 East Forty-sixth-street. He had been in poor health for several months, but as late as Saturday last was able to go out driving. Then he took to his bed, and, apoplexy supervening other complications, he had a painless death.

Drum, that all the recaptured Union flags, and all the captured rebel flags held at the War Department as the property of the Government, should be offered to the States to which they originally belonged.

BUFFALO, June 16.--After the National Opera Company had concluded its three nights' engagement here and had left for Toronto on the Grand Trunk, there was made public a recital of how narrow an escape the people had of not seeing American grand opera, and how narrow an escape the National Opera Company had of going entirely to pieces.

Cornelius E. Kene, of New-Rochelle, and Miss Emma Christine, daughter of Ferdinand Ehrhart, of this city, were married last evening at the residence of the Rev. Thomas S. Preston, Chancellor of the diocese.

Jennie Schneider, a native of Riga, who says she is 25, but who appears to be 40, and weighs at least 225 pounds, had an odd story to tell Deputy Register. Nagle at Sanitary Headquarters yesterday. She came to this country in 1880, and is a Jewess, speaking hardly any English and very poor German.
Dr. Owen Ward, of 272 East Broadway, one of the attending Surgeons at Gouverneur Hospital, recently discharged from his service an old Irishman named Patrick Donovan.

Agricultural societies of the State will receive a little over $2,000, to be used in premiums for improving the breed of horses and cattle, as their share of the gate receipts at the recent eight day's meeting at Jerome Park. This amount comes from the 5 per cent. tax on the total gate receipts imposed under the provisions of the Ives pool bill.

"Billy" Bennett and "Tommy" Devine, the sporting men who were arrested on Wednesday night on suspicion of having been engaged in the shooting affray at Twenty-eighth-street and Sixth-avenue on Wednesday morning, were yesterday taken before Justice O'Reilly at the Jefferson Market Police Court.
OTTAWA, June 16.--It is understood that the subsidy to be voted by Parliament to the Canadian Pacific Railroad's Atlantic and Pacific steamship schemes will be $200,000 per annum.

The sale of the Pene Du Bois collection of books and engravings was continued yesterday at the auction rooms of Leavitt Co., 787 Broadway. The attendance was larger and the bidding more spirited than at the previous sales.

Forty-eight wheelmen, who formerly composed the Ixion Bicycle Club, were elected members of the New-York Bicycle Club last evening, raising the total membership of the club to 91. PENSACOLA, Fla., June 16.--On the afternoon of June 13, 90 miles east of Sand Island Light, the American steamship Vidette, from New-York, with a cargo of merchandise for Mobile, sprang a leak. The men worked the pumps, but the latter became clogged with coal.

BALTIMORE, June 16.--In a conversation to-day Cardinal Gibbons, in speaking of the proposed Catholic University, said it is probable, but by no means absolutely certain, that it will be situated in Washington, nor will its location be definitely settled until the meeting in September next.

The fifty-fifth Commencement exercises of the University of the City of New-York were held last evening at the Academy of Music. In the absence of the Chancellor, Vice-Chancellor McCracken presided.

Several more silversmiths appeared yesterday for work at the various manufacturers shops. TUCSON, Arizona, June 16.--News has been received here that on Sunday afternoon Charabaus Vaques was killed in Cafion del Oro by Indians. There is no doubt that the Indians are still in the Catalina Mountains near Bachman's Station.

The second annual cricket match between the States of New-York and New-Jersey will be played to-day and to-morrow on the St. George's Ground, Hoboken. Neither team is as strong as it could be made, business preventing many from being present.

TROY, N.Y., June 16.--William Wilkinson, Jr., dry and fancy goods dealer, has made a general assignment to Frank E. Norton. His liabilities are estimated at $37,000, with nominal assets at about the same figure.

On May 27 the Hon. Alpheus Hardy dropped a shears which he was using and cut himself quite severely. Nothing was thought of this at the time, but soon after blood poisoning set in and the matter became very serious, and it appeared doubtful if Mr. Hardy would recover. One of Wall-street's latest suspicions about Jay Gould's withdrawal from Pacific Mail affairs is that an effort is to be made to list the stook upon the London Stock Exchange, a plan that would be interfered with were Gould known as an influential owner in the property.

PITTSBURG, June 20.--The session of the Amalgamated Association to-day was one of the most important yet held. The Committee on Constitution submitted its report, making several recommendations, which show that the association was determined to strengthen its ranks...
The fiftieth performance of "The Highest Bidder" will be given at the Lyceum Theatre tonight.
RANDOLPH, Mass., June 20.--Charles Alden, the inventor of milk-condensing, fruit-evaporating, and other processes, committed suicide at the Elms House this morning by shooting.

The condition of the public mind in the various provinces of Canada with regard to commercial union with the United States, and the facts by which opinion is controlled there, are described by our very thorough correspondent in a way that is instructive to our own people concerning their own problems.
Yesterday was Class Day at Princeton. The exercises began at 10:30 in the morning in the First Presbyterian Church with the address of welcome by the master of ceremonies, H.S. Savage, of Illinois.
There were two longshoremen, Irishmen, on Dover-street pier yesterday morning. They were square-jawed, grizzled, and brothers.
PEEKSKILL, June 20.--This day has been one of those which the poet has so feelingly alluded to as "corkers." Its heat has been concentrated and long drawn out.

Mrs. Grace Brotherton Deems, who is suing her husband, Dr. Frank M. Deems, for divorce, sat all day yesterday in the Court of Common Pleas, Equity Term, and submitted to a long examination with no further aid than that supplied by smelling salts.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 20.--The committee having in charge the erection of a monument to the late tragedian, John McCullough, consisting of Capt. William M. Conner, of the St. James Hotel, NewYork, and former manager for McCullough, and...

The course of the Diaz Administration in our neighboring Republic of Mexico in en-- . couraging the investment of "Yankee" capital in that country and granting valuable concessions to citizens of the United States...

LONDON, June 20.--In the House of Commons this evening Sir Henry Holland, Secretary of State for the Colonies, replying to Mr. Howorth, said that Sir Samuel Rowe, Governor of Sierra Leone, had informed the Government that a conference held between the French and the natives had resulted in the hoisting of the French flag at Bariboo, on the Gambia River.

WASHINGTON, June 20.--The talk about Secretary Lamar as the probable successor of the late Associate Justice Woods has developed naturally along with the efforts of the leading men from the South to find for the President a candidate who would be worthy of a seat on the Bench and at the same time reflect credit upon the section of the country he was chosen to represent.
ALBANY, June 20.--The most important bill signed by Gov. Hill to-day was the one regulating the heating of steam cars.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 20.--In the organization of the State Board of Equalization to-day Lieut.Gov. Robertson was recognized as a member over the protest of Gov. Gray, and he was also elected its President.
CHICAGO, June 20.--A large and fashionable audience gathered at Hooley's Theatre this evening to see as well as hear Mr. Daly's revival of "The Taming of the Shrew."

Georgo Cohen's store, at Baxter and Worth streets, has been closed by the Sheriff. Cohen is a son of Harris Cohen, who started him in the business, and in February, 1885, gave him the whole stock, worth about $6,000.
POUGHKEEPSIE, June 20.--Twelve years ago there came to Matteawan, Dutchess County, a stranger named Calvin Cole, who engaged board with the Widow Green, at her hotel on Main-street.
Without a pool or some similar device to limit production the distilleries of this country are in a bad way.

BOSTON, June 20.--The Irish question was uppermost in Boston this afternoon and evening. While the Board of Aldermen was holding a stormy session over the introduction of an order to rescind the permission granting the use of Faneuil Hall to-morrow night to the British societies in Boston, for the celebration...

WORCESTER, Mass., June 20.--The boot and shoe strike that has been in progress in Worcester, Spencer, and the Brookfields since Jan. 26, and which has affected between 7,000 and 8,000 men, has practically ended, so far as the Knights of Labor are concerned.

PARIS, June 20.--The Paris newspapers express indignation over the sentences decreed at Leipsic against the Alsacian members of the Patriotic League, just convicted of high treason for assisting in the agitation to keep alive the anti-annexation feeling in Alsace-Lorraine.

PITTSBURG, June 20.--The iron manufactures held a meeting this forenoon at the rooms of the Western Iron Association in the Renshaw building to consider the new scale of wages as presented by the Amalgamated Association.
SCHENECTADY, June 20.--A shadow has been thrown over the festivities of Commencement Week at Union College by the unexpected death this afternoon of Prof. Jonathan Pearson,...

LONDON, June 20.--The city is already showing signs of being crowded in anticipation of to-morrow. The throngs in the streets are more numerous than at any time within the recollection of the present generation.
Conterno's Ninth Regiment Band will furnish the music at Tompkins Square at 5 P.M. to-day.
Frank J. Dupignac, of counsel for Miss Mary Irene Hoyt, said yesterday that there was no truth whatever in the report that his client was a married woman.
The annals of England do not contain the record of a half century outwardly more prosperous and fortunate than that which is celebrated in the jubilee of Queen VICTORIA.
The open tournament of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, which commences to-morrow afternoon on the pretty grounds above Mountain Station, N.J., on the Delaware, Lackawanna...

NATRONA, Penn., June 20.--The work of evicting the strikers of the Pennsylvania Salt Works from the company's houses was begun to-day by Deputy Sheriff Carson and three assistants. The furniture of two families was carried out and set on the street. No more evictions were attempted. The strikers are inclined to be quiet, and so far have offered no resistance.

The trial of Chief Engineer Thomas F. Nevins, of the Brooklyn Fire Department, on an indictment for grand larceny in the first degree, was begun yesterday in the Court of Sessions, before Kings County Judge Moore and Associate Justices McMahon and Savage.

Lucien Marie, a young Frenchman, sailed from Havre June 11 on the steamer Bourgogne. The day before the police at Fleury, in France, found in a house where Marie had been the body of Francois Routaud, who apparently had been murdered.

The interview with General Master Workman Powderly in Philadelphia about the expulsion of District Assembly No. 126 from the Knights of Labor has created much indignation among the members of No. 126 and among other Knights who sympathize with them.

BELVIDERE, N.J., June 20.--Counsel for Dr. Comegys Paul on Saturday instituted suit against J.G. Shipman Son for $500 for services rendered as a medical expert in the Titus murder trial. The doctor was the principal witness for the defense, and his claim has not yet been settled.

Mayor Hewitt's letter to the State Board of Charities requesting it to investigate the insane asylum on Ward's Island on account of the abuses revealed by the inquest in the Farrish case, is likely to result in prompt action.
PHILADELPHIA, June 20.--H. Sloan Sons, the cotton brokers who have suspended payment, are arranging their affairs, and expect to present a statement to their creditors in a few days.
The Staten Island cow case came before the Board of Health, at Port Richmond, again yesterday, with Supervisor Doyle in the chair.

BOSTON, June 20.--The Overseers of Harvard College met to-day and confirmed a long list of appointments made by the President and Fellows. Most of the appointments were those of Instructors in Surgery and Medicine.

BOSTON, June 20.--It is understood that two appeals will be taken to the Supreme Court from the recent decision of the Board of Visitors of Andover Theological seminary, one by the Trustees and one by Prof. Smyth.

BERLIN, June 20.--The Emperor passed a good night and this afternoon received Count Perponcher, Chief Marshal of the Household; Count Herbert Bismarck, Secretary of the Imperial Foreign Office, and others. The strength of the Emperor gradually increases.
DENVER, Col., June 20.--Messrs. J.J. Thomas Co., of this city, have been prospecting some land which they own, 18 miles north of Denver, for coal.

The body of a man bearing ghastly evidences of murder was discovered by some aqueduct workmen on Sunday in the Pocantico River, a little stream near Whitson's, a station on the New-York City and Northern Railroad, about 28 miles from this city.

WATERBURY, Conn., June 20.--Mrs. Noah Judson, a widow, 71 years of age, was burned so severely by the upsetting of a kerosene lamp at her residence in the Weekeepeemee District, near Woodbury, last night, that she died.
NYACK, June 20.--During the severe thunderstorm which prevailed in Rockland last evening the lightning did considerable damage and performed some singular freaks.
The Tabernacle Baptist Church recently borrowed $65,000. Of this amount $30,000 was advanced by John D. Rockefeller, a like sum by Jabez A. Bostwick, and $5,000 by Caroline C. Bishop.

AMERICUS, Ga., June 20.--News comes from Terrell County of a shocking murder, caused by jealousy, in which Fulton Bradford, a negro living on Mrs. J.P. Sharp's plane, in this county, shot and killed Lee Frost, colored, living on the same place, in the employment of Bradford.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 20.--While workmen were employed under the funnel of a bin in Eakin Cheek's elevator this morning they discovered blood, which led to an investigation of the bin.
Coffee recovered yesterday, advancing at the start more than 1 cent a pound above the last prices of Saturday. The market was not notably active, and prices sagged a trifle in the afternoon.
LONDON, June 21.--Mr. Henry Matthews and other Catholic officials will attend the services in Westminster Abbey.

AURORA, N.Y., June 20.--The Aurora House, the only hotel here, is crowded to its utmost capacity, and accommodations are being sought at private residences for the large number of guests who are to attend the Commencement exercises of Wells College.

The announcement in an afternoon paper yesterday that the Rev. Charles E. Stowe, the nephew of Mr. Beecher, who preached in Plymouth church on sunday, was to be called to the pastorate was news to most of the members...

The Mets won another game from the Athletic Club at Staten Island yesterday. In spite of the rain there were 1,600 persons in attendance. The game was a repetition of Saturday's contest. In the first inning the local players, by a streak of batting, secured 6 runs.

Some of the Irish-American residents of New-York intend holding at the Cooper Union this evening what they call a "memorial demonstration in honor of the victims of Queen Victoria's 50 years of misrule."
John Engberg, a Dane, 22 years old, shot and probably killed his aged mother last night and then shot himself.
PITTSBURG, June 20.--The great cricket match between the East and West for the championship was begun at 11:30 o'clock this morning at the Brushton Grounds.

The advance of June wheat from 3 to 4 cents a bushel on the Produce Exchange, in spite of a drop of cent in Chicago yesterday, was due to a purely local struggle between long and short holders.

"A day or two ago," writes a correspondent, an elderly lady of high position, and enjoying an income of some 3,000 or 4,000 a year, sent to a neighboring Post Office to inquire the proper postage for a certain foreign letter.
Manager Locke, of the National Opera Company, notified the members that there would be a businees meeting at the Academy of Music yesterday afternoon.

APPALACHICOLA, Fla., June 20.--The sponge catch in Florida thus far this year is a failure, the vessels not having made enough to pay their provision bills. Dealers estimate that the catch will be about one-half as great as usual.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 20.--John Boyle, Jr., aged 8, was run over to-day by Ulmer's soda delivery wagon. He was playing in the street. The wagon wheels passed over his abdomen. Boyle jumped up, ran to the curbstone, sat down and expired. The driver was arrested.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 20.--Annie McDaniel, a servant girl, was arrested to-night charged with infanticide. She gave birth to a male child about 3 o'clock this morning, and locked it up in a trunk. She arose at the usual time and went about discharging her duties. Toward noon she became ill and confided the facts to her physician.

ST. LOUIS, June 20.--The Supreme Court has fixed Aug. 12 as the date for the execution of Hugh Mottram Brooks, alias Dr. W.H. Lenox Maxwell, the little criminal whose case has formed an international episode.
There is much uneasiness at the Custom House over the fear that the much-dreaded reorganization scheme will speedily be put in operation.
Miss Grace Howard, the oldest daughter of Joseph Howard, Jr., will leave this city tomorrow night as a missionary to the Crow Creek Agency. She expects to remain there for two years.
