F.A. Olsen, a Norwegian sailor, of 71 Regent-street, Brooklyn, died on Friday at the Emigrant Hospital on Ward's Island, and the staff of that institution have not been able to determine the nature of his disease.
Had several incidents not foreseen by the prosecution, and certainly unexpected by the defense, not occurred yesterday's session of the Sharp trial would have been utterly lifeless.
When the Brooklyn Board of Estimate met yesterday President Eaton, of the Park Department, presented an estimate for expenses smaller by $104,000 than the one originally submitted to the board.
Peter J. Gerven, who was indicted for killing Michael smith on New Year's night at Centre Market and Grand-street, was called to trial yesterday before Recorder Smyth.
STOCKHOLM, June 20.--Major-Gen. Ryding, Swedish Minister of War, has resigned because the Rigsdag has refused to grant his department an extra military credit.
REIMERSBURG, Penn., June 20.--Dr. J.H. Hepburn, of this village, has in his possession a table which was once the property of William Penn.
James Bogie, the Scotch painter arrested Sunday afternoon, charged with attempting to abduct little Willie Downes, was arraigned in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday.

Among the decisions handed down by the General Term of the Supreme Court Saturday were three, the result of which will be to save the city about $10,000,000, in the matter of compensation which it will have to pay for the taking of property by the Department of Docks in widening and extending West-street under the new plan of improvement.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20.--An innocent looking little eighteen-cent can of California salmon to-day poisoned four persons belonging to one family, threw them into convulsions, and may be the cause of four deaths. The family afficted is that of Alfred S. Stauts, who lives at 2,106 Hull-street, Richmond.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 20.--Drafts on NewYork, sight, 15 cents; telegraphic, 22 cents.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 20.--During the violent storm of last night large balls of fire danced about telephone instruments and over telegraph wires. A bolt entered the Western Union Office and partly melted the switchboard.
BIRMINGHAM, June 20.--An inquest was held to-day on the body of an unknown man found in the canal here with his throat cut.

A dispatch received yesterday by Mayor Daly, of Rahway, from Detective Keron, who went to Iuka, Ill., to examine Caspar Strombach, who confessed to have murdered the unknown girl, states that Strombach is not the man who committed the deed.

BOSTON, June 20.--For the first time this season the waters around Boston show signs of yachting activity. Marblehead Harbor is tonight filled with a great and growing fleet of small craft, while here and there, towering...

WASHINGTON, June 20.--The warm weather which has prevailed for the last few days in nearly every part of the country continues, and at the Signal Office it is said that immediate relief is to be expected only from local thunderstorms.

There is trouble at the shop of Lyell Brothers, machinists, in West Twenty-thirdstreet. The men said that they had been promised a Saturday half holiday, and accordingly quit work at noon on that day.

BELVIDERE, N.J., June 20.--The engagement of the Rev. J. De Hart Bruen, Pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, to Miss Lizzie Brookfield, youngest duaghter of John B. Brookfield, Cashier of the Belvidere National Bank, was announced to-day.
Frederick L. Cooper's suit against Weston Debillier, the stock brokers, was tried yesterday afternoon in the Special Term of the Supreme Court before Judge Donohue.
Berlin consumed during the year 1885-6 no less than 78,862 tons of slaughtered meat, namely 33,400 tons of beef, 31,462 tons of pork, 7,660 tons of veal, and 6,340 tons of mutton.

A panic occurred a few nights ago in the Court Theatre at Weimar. The commotion caused by the breaking down of a stall on which a visitor was seated alarmed a part of the audience, who were nervously impressed by accounts of the catastrophe in Paris, and a rush was made for the doors, notwithstanding the appeals of the Graud Duke himself. Calm was with some difficulty restored.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., June 20.--A remarkable series of marriages occurred in Clark County, Ill., a few days ago. Thomas and Josiah Black, brothers, who live just across the line in Vigo County, Ind., eloped with and married two young girls by the name of Smith.
WASHINGTON, June 20.--The President has appointed the following-named Postmasters: Edward A. Preuss at Los Angeles, Cal., vice J.W. Green,...

A pleasant company of electricians gathered around a long table at Martinelli's last evening and celebrated the Queen's jubilee in conjunction with the anniversary of the establishment of telegraphy in England.
The inquest in regard to the death of Magdalena Zorn in the marsh near Fort George was continued yesterday before Coroner Eidman.

The schooner yacht Sirene carried away her foremast head on Sunday off Hog Island. She was towed into Larchmont by the steam yacht Oneida, and will probably go to City Island to refit.
The Commencement festivities at Rutgers College began yesterday. The town was thronged with ladies and students.
The free baths were opened yesterday by the Department of Public Works amid much hilarity on the part of the small boy.

AUSTIN, Texas, June 20.--Gov. Ross received a telegram to-day informing him of the arrest of three desperate characters in Lavaca County, suspected of being implicated in the Southern Pacific train robbery of last Saturday morning.

The inquest in the case of Miss Caroline Kiesele, whose body was found in the water off South Beach, Staten Island, last Wednesday, was begun before Coroner Martin Hughes and a jury at Clifton last night.
Charles Toliner, a ship carpenter, calker, and joiner, owns the three-story brick house at 440 East One Hundred and Tenth-street and the two-story frame house adjoining.
There won't be such a pack of people at the handsome race track of the Coney Island Jockey Club this afternoon as there was no Saturday, but there will be racing of a more interesting character.
Howard Baker, aged 17 years, was with difficulty saved from being lynched at Mount Vernon on Saturday night. He resides with his parents on Third-street, between Third and Fourth avenues.

The sale of etchings and prints in the Du Bois collection went on yesterday at Leavitt's auction rooms with a large attendance. The collection is interesting and the bidding was often spirited, even on the poorer etchings.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., June 20.--The visit of Forepaugh's circus here to-day was signalized by the birth of a camel and an accident to Jessie Gorman, of Suguar Grove, Penn., who was injured by a flying plank from a rifle range that was knocked loose by a bucking horse.

CHICAGO, June 21.--The general Cattle market was without important change to-day. Some of the tidiest, best fatted little Cattle sold fairly well during the morning, but the general trade was slow and very dull.

CHICAGO, June 21.--The master masons have succeeded in obtaining nearly enough men to finish the work that was under way when the strike began. Forty contractors were at work to-day with from four to sixteen bricklayers each.

Judge Donohue has granted to Rosenbaum Brothers an attachment to the amount of $61,012,50 against the property in this State belonging to the Chicago grain firm of Maurice Rosenfeld Co., which went down in the recent panic.

WASHINGTON, June 21.--A cool wave was reported on its way east at the Signal Office this morning. The temperature has fallen 15 to 20 all through the West, and it is expected that the cool wave will reach the Atlantic coast bofore to-morrow night.

One hundred and fifty handsome veterans of the Seventh Regiment, dressed in their nobby uniforms and with their warlike swords knocking against their knees as they walked, were to be seen last night on the decks of the Albany steamer Dean Richmond.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 21.--George W. Nellis, of Herkimer, N.Y., en route on a bicycle to San Francisco is here to-night. His average progress has been 55 miles daily. His best day was from Camborough to St. Thomas, 77 miles. On Friday he covered the road between Davenport and Iowa City, 71 miles.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 21.--Drafts on NewYork, sight, 15 cents; telegraphic, 22 cents.

Miss Minnie Maddern has a place of her own on the stage. There is no other actress just like her. She has her own way of expressing the emotions, and seems to have learned the principles of dramatic art from no recognized model.

There will be great racing at Coney Island to-day, and Secretary Lawrence has so shrewdly handicapped the fields of starters in the different events that picking winners will be about as difficult as finding hen's teeth.

LONDON, June 21.--In the sense of hearty and enthusiastic manifestations the jubilee ceremony to-day was an unquestioned success.
They called it a jubilee service, the meeting at Cooper Union Hall last evening, but it was a strange jubilee. There were smiles, but few, and laughter not at all.

Robert Sewell, the prominent lawyer, who was Monday overcome by an attack of faintness, had yesterday so far recovered that he was driven to a steam yacht and taken up the Hudson to his Summer residence at Tarrytown. Early in the day he was visited by his brother, ex-United States Senator Sewell, of New-Jersey, who, with the wife and children of the invalid, accompanied him. Mr. Sewell's physicians expect a rapid recovery.
HARTFORD, Conn., June 21.--Connecticut's new restrictive law on Sunday traffic, while severe in its terms, is not likely to prove so in its practical operation.
LEXINGTON, Ky., June 21.--Two Iowa gentlemen, Miller and Huggins, bought the following fine young trotting stock here to-day: Of H.C. Mc Dowell...

A young man went to Police Headquarters late Monday night greatly excited and said that his father was missing.

It is altogether likely that the greatest assemblage of human beings that has ever been collected anywhere was that upon which Queen VICTORIA looked yesterday as she passed through six miles of "shouting streets" from Buckingham Palace to Westminster Abbey and back again.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 21.--Quite a strong and lively fight is in progrees against the Executive approval of the Pleuro-Pneumonia act passed by the General Assembly, which has not yet been signed by the Governor.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 21.--Dr. M.A. Vernado, aged 50, a prominent dentist and Justice of the Peace of the First Ward, Tangipahoa Parish, was yesterday shot and instantly killed by L.R. Draughn, aged 58, also a well known citizen.
CHICAGO, June 21.--The Patriotic Sons of America began a three days' convention at 208 La Salle-street this morning.
The service in honor of the Queen's jubilee, held at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday morning, was attended by an audience that crowded the building and was prolific in enthusiasm.
Gen. Isaac S. Catlin, who flopped over to the Kings County Democracy a short time ago, was formally repudiated by the Brooklyn First Ward Republican Association last evening.
The Pennsylvania Railroad Company has arranged for a grand excursion to the Alleghany Mountains and Cresson, to leave this city on Thursday, June 30.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., June 21.--This village was the scene of a terrible disaster about 6 o'clock this afternoon, and the Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore station and the track for several hundred yards present a horrible picture.

A rumor gained currency yesterday afternoon that the Manhattan Railroad Company had abandoned all attempts to acquire the valuable franchise which it has been for months past begging at the hands of the Rapid Transit Commission appointed by Mayor Hewitt.

Coroner Messemer held an inquest yesterday upon the body of Robert Anderson, the sailor who died at the Chambers-Street Hospital last Sunday morning from injuries sustained by a fall from one of the top floor windows of the lodging house at 110 Cherry-street.

Capt. Jack Hussey died yesterday afternoon at the Gouverneur Hospital from peritonitis, resulting from the wound inflicted by Policeman Hahn on June 2. Up to last Sunday Hussey had steadily improved and every one fully expected he would recover.
AURORA, N.Y., June 21.--Lights shone from every window at Wells College last night, while the parlors were brilliantly illuminated and decorated.

SARATOGA STRINGS, N.Y., June 21.--Three freight cars in train No. 47, south bound, on the Delaware and Hudson Railroad, Were wrecked about three miles south of this place at 5:30 o'clock this evening. The tracks were completely blockaded.

Hamilton's cartoon in the current number of Judge is as pat as it is telling. A yacht labeled "Republican Party, New-York State," is depicted hauled up out of the water.

The rivalry that has long existed between the baseball nines of the Brooklyn police force and of the Central Office reporters is to be settled at 2 o'clock this afternoon on the grounds of the Brooklyn Club at Washington Park.
DUBLIN, June 21.--A fight occurred in Cork to-day between the Loyalists and Nationalists during the military review held in honor of the Queen's jubilee.

LOWVILLE, N.Y., June 21.--The Rev. Dr. McGlynn and Henry George have been engaged to deliver addresses before the Lewis County Agricultural Fair Society, which will be held on the 13th, 14th, 15th, and 16th of September.

Nature's sweet restorer laid its gentle hand upon Jacob Sharp yesterday morning, and, forgetting that he was on trial for bribery, the street railroad financier dozed to the music of District Attorney Martine's voice.

The tin supply ran a little short yesterday, and a small squeeze resulted at the Metal Exchange. Under rapid manipulation the price advanced about 50 points. Nothing more serious happened than a little excitement and enough loss and profit to make the day exceptionally interesting. No one supposes the squeeze can last.

The last lot of the Pene Du Bois collection was sold yesterday afternoon. The sum total realized for the books, etchings, curios, and furniture is $17,599.70. Yesterday's sale was not as interesting as its predecessors.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 21.--The funeral of Dr. Hopkins at Williamstown this afternoon called together a greater number of people than Williamstown often sees, except at Commencements...
Announcement was made on the Stock Exchange yesterday of the death of two well known Wall-street brokers--Andrew L. Thompson and Charles Allardice.

HARRISBURG, June 21.--Mrs. Mary Gehrig, who died at Boyertown last week, aged 91, was the last of seven sisters, all but one of whom lived to be over 90. Hannah died at 97, Nancy at 96, Kate at 93, Betsey at 94, Susannah at 92, and Sarah at 88.
Mayor Hewitt vetoed yesterday the resolutions of the Board of Aldermen suspending on the Fourth of July the ordinance prohibiting the use of fireworks. In his message to the Aldermen the Mayor said:

PEEKSKILL, June 21.--The sun rose this morning, veiling his heated face behind a thin veil of gossamer haze. This relief from the torrid temperature of yesterday, made more welcome by the attendance of breeze-laden clouds...

Short holders of June wheat had their innings yesterday on announcements that the railroads had guaranteed to bring enough wheat here by the end of the month to effect settlements of all outstanding contracts.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 21.--The marriage of Miss Anna B. Mase to Mr. Edward Judson Millspaugh, of Staten Island, occurred last evening at Elm Grove, Matteawan, the residence of the bride's father, Assemblyman William H. Mase.
ALBUQUERQUE, New-Mexico, June 21.--Forty horses have been stolen from this city and county in the past five weeks.

Over 15,000 people flocked to the ground at Erastina, Staten Island, yesterday to witness the games that were given in honor of the Queen's jubilee. Nearly 250 entries were received for the different events, and most of those entered competed.

Weyhing, of the Athletics, pitched a strong game yesterday, and the result was that the mets suffered defeat in their contest at Staten Island with the Philadelphia Association representatives. Jack Lynch, who has been idle for some time...
CHICAGO, June 21.--C.J. Kershaw met a number of members of the Board of Trade in the arbitration room to-day and the signing down to various margins was discussed.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 21.--The Fidelity National Bank was closed this morning by order of the Government through its representative, Mr. Eugene Powell.
MARBLEHEAD, Mass., June 21.--Marblehead Harbor has been shrouded in mist all day, and for the first time in 14 years the Eastern Yacht Club was obliged to postpone a great race on account of the fog.
AUBURN, N.Y., June 21.--Charles F. Durston of this city, has been appointed Warden of Auburn State Prison, vice John Lonehart, removed.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 21.--At the Driving Park in this city this morning Congressman Flood's twoyear-old Nellie Mayo made a mile in 2:28, the fastest time ever made in the world by a two-year-old on a half-mile track.
Wall-street is still treasuring the idea that a settlement of the telegraph war is close at hand.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21.--In his report to the United States Circuit Court to-day Master Dallas recommended that the petition of the Reading Railroad Conductors for extra pay accrued prior to Dec. 1, 1883, be dismissed. The amount involved is $89,083 07. In explanation Mr. Dallas in his report says:

Twenty-four yachts, in seven classes, started in the eighth annual regatta of the Yonkers Yacht Club yesterday. The course for all classes except G was from Yonkers to the Tarrytown buoy and return. Class G sailed to Dobbs Ferry and return.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 21.--The Yale 'Varsity Crew and its substitutes started for New-London this evening. Their shells were sent up to the course on the steamer Ivernia this morning.

Many professionals on this side knew C. W. Cassidy, but they are not aware that he has been dead since June 6. He had been the architect of a number of circuses abroad, as well as the manager of some vaudeville theatres.
The Civil Service Examining Board sent to the Police Commissioners yesterday a list of the Roundsmen who succesfully passed the examination and are eligible for promotion to the grade of Sergeant.
Yesterday was Alumni Day at Rutgers College, New-Brunswick. The Rev. T. De Witt Talmage addressed the literary societies in the afternoon.
ALBANY, June 21.--The only bill of general interest among the seven signed by Gov. Hill to-day was the one making it unlawful to take trout less than six inches in length.
The anniversary of Koltes Post, No. 32, G.A.R., is always made a day of merrymaking by the comrades. In accordance with this custom they went up to the Empire City Colosseum...

No man who bet a dollar on Ben Ali to win the Suburban handicap can now be convinced but that he was cheated out of that money by the unfortunate start for that big event, which resulted in the big brown Californian being left at the post last Saturday.
LONDON, June 21.--The first day of the fifty-first year of the reign of Queen Victoria over Great Britain opened with perfect Summer weather in London.
HARRISBURG, June 21.--A heavy thunder storm came up while Charles Kinzleman was cutting grass for his cow on Col. J.H. Dick's farm, near Fredericksburg, on Saturday.
WASHINGTON, June 21.--The following is the President's letter presenting his jubilee congratulations to Queen Victoria:

The mystery surrounding the murder of the unknown man at Whitson's station, on the New-York City and Northern Railroad, in Westchester County, has not been cleared up. On the contrary, it seems to have deepened.
At a meeting of the New-York Free Trade Club at the Cooper Union last night "The Relation of the Tariff to Wages" was discussed.

BALTIMORE, June 21.--About 1,000 people saw the Brooklyn team defeated to-day by timely batting and loose fielding. Smith pitched in good form, holding the visitors down to six actual hits, but Fulmer was rather weak behind the bat, being responsible for 2 of the runs scored.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 21.--A large meteor fell last night upon the farm of Ollie Botelson, who lives not far from what is known as Pilot Mound. So rapid was its descent that the roar was almost deafening. A beautiful trail of light was seen in its wake, which illuminated the earth for many miles and lighted up the scene as would a bright moon light.
Why should Jay Gould's professed friends try so hard to conceal the truth? He is a very sick man.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 21.--The steam barge P.H. Walters, a 197-ton vessel, owned by John Homegardner, of Sandusky, was sunk in a storm off Black River, Ohio, about 7 o'clock last evening, and eight lives were lost.
CHARLESTON, S.C., June 21.--Last Winter H.F. Hoover, a white man, went through the upper part of this State organizing lodges of the "Co-operative Workers of America" among the negroes.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 22.--The Pacific coast branch of the American Shipping and Industrial League held a largely attended convention in this city to-day to consider remedies to prevent the decay of American shipping.

HARRISBURG, Penn., June 22.--The Board of Pardons to-day considered the case of William J. McMeen, the Juniata County wife murderer, under sentence of death, and decided to commute his sentence to life imprisonment.

ALBANY, June 22.--The New-York, Chicago and St. Louis Railroad Company was incorporated under the laws of this State to-day, with a capital of $4,500,000. Under the Vedder act the company had to pay a tax of $5,625 for the privilege.
News was received here yesterday of the very sad death of Mrs. William E. Barnes, of No. 50 East Twenty-first-street, at Manitou, Col., on Sunday last.

Dr. A. Jacobi denounces Ann Donnelly, a cook, who has been employed by Lieut. Reed at West Point, as "sowing death wherever she goes." She buried a child in May in West Forty thirdstreet. It died of diphtheria, and she carried the disease to her employer's house. His little girl died. Ann fled with her trunk when she learned what she had done, and Dr. Jacobi says she is "ready ...
Mary Murphy, wife of an Erie Railroad machinist, hanged herself at her home, 118 Pavonia-avenue, Jersey City, last night. The death of a daughter had crazed her.

Harry Bethune, the champion sprinter, was yesterday matched to run a dash of 100 yards against Alexander Davis for $1,500 a side. The race will be run at London, Canada, on June 27, and Bethune is to give Davis a start of two yards.

Mayor Hewitt, in a letter written yesterday to President Borden, of the Park Department, showed that he was in sympathy with the small parks idea as evolved by President Beekman, of the Board of Aldermen. In his letter the Mayor said:

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 22.--A horse disease is causing trouble in various localities in Ulster and adjoining counties. Several valuable horses have been ordered shot by the Boards of Health at NewPaltz and elsewhere.

LEWES, Del., June 22.--The bark Neptune, from Cienfuegos, reported having passed, about nine miles southeast half south from Cape Henlopen, a vessel bottom up. She was of about 300 tons and copper covered and is a dangerous obstruction to southern-bound vessels, being directly in the track.
CONSTANTINOPLE, June 22.--M. Nelidoff and the Count de Montebello, the Russian and French Ambassadors, respectively, have addressed a note to the Porte on the subject of the Egyption Convention.

PEEKSKILL, June 22.--Ominous, deeprolling peals of thunder shattered the State Camp's heavens all of last night, and by their growling intonations called from the misty depths that contained them tons upon tons of rain that was damp.

AURORA, N.Y., June 22.--During Mrs. Cleveland's present stay at Wells College no one who treasured a remembrance of her as an unpretentious school miss, has at all hesitated in chatting with her and renewing the old time acquaintance.

OTTAWA, June 22.--The Hon. G.E. Foster, Minister of Marine and Fisheries, starts for the lower provinces as soon after "Dominion Day" as possible. He proposes to first spend two weeks aboard the steam cruiser Acadia in the vicinity of Prince Edward Island in order to acquaint himself with the work of the fisheries protection fleet.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 22.--As George Chastin, a prominent citizen, and his wife, accompanied by another gentleman and his wife, were taking a walk last evening in Wichita, Kan., Mrs. Chastin was grossly insulted by a tramp. Mr. Chastin resented the outrage, and was about to chastise the offender, when the tramp plunged a large dirk knife into his breast near the heart, inflicting a mortal wound. The tramp escaped.
OTTAWA, June 22.--In the House of Commons to-day, on the third reading of the Customs Amendment act, Sir Richard Cartwright entered a final protest against the new iron duties.

South Amboy has about 5,000 inhabitants, and about all of them were interested in a wedding which took place yesterday noon in the Episcopal church there. The bride was Miss Emily Charlotte Potter Conover, daughter of Richard S. Conover, a well known and wealthy citizen.

PORT HURON, Mich., June 22.--Yesterday morning five men boarded the 1:15 o'clock A.M. Grand Trunk train at Fort Gratlot, Mich., going east, and "held up" the passengers.
SARATOGA, N.Y., June 22.--Saratoga is crowded with representatives of the several army corps that composed the Army of the Potomac. The various army corps had special reunions during the morning.

The Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club's book for 1887 is out, and is one of the neatest and most attractive ever issued.

The Coroner's jury in the inquest yesterday at Trenton, N.J., on the death of John Stewart, who was assaulted by John Britton, rendered a verdict that Stewart's death was caused by a fracture of the skull due to a blow from a cane in the hands of Britton.

Yesterday's races at the Coney Island Jockey Club's track were by all odds the best that have been had in this vicinity this year. There were large fields, sharp contests in every instance, and enough surprises from the success of outsiders to satisfy the backers of short horses and make the sport interesting to every one.

Prof. Vincenzo Botta, of this city, yesterday received from King Humbert, of Italy, a copy of the memorial edition of the "Divina Commedia," which was published last year to commemorate the eighteenth birthday of the Crown Prince, Victor Emmanuel.

Bourke Cockran wrote to Postmaster Pearson on Tuesday complaining that a large number of circulars which he had mailed to voters in the Twelfth Congressional District at the time of the last election had not been delivered. At 1 o'clock this morning fire broke out in Tritle's six-story building 179 to 183 Lewisstreet. The four lower floors were occupied by Simon Strauss, a maker of cigar boxes, who also ran a planing mill.

They "waked" Capt. Jack Hussey at 50 Jackson-street last night, and will "wake" him again to-night and to-morrow night in the most approved Hibernian style, with all the accessories common on those mournful occasions. His big body is packed in an ice chest, with seven candles at the head and a floral piece on top.

Blaine, and under the benevolent gaze of the Father of his Country, the members of the Republican Club, at its meeting last evening, denounced President Cleveland for what they called his attempt to return old battle flags to the Governors of States applying for them.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 22.--The steamer Providence, of the Old Colony Steamboat Company, went ashore on Dyer's Island, near Bristol Ferry, in a heavy fog this morning on her way from this city to Fall River. She is still on, but is lying on sandy bottom, and will probably come off all right. The passengers were landed at Coal Mines, and proceeded to Fall River and Boston.

The forty-second annual Commencement of St. John's College, at Fordham, was held yesterday afternoon on the college grounds. The rain threatened several times to necessitate an adjournment indoors, but it only threatened, and the exercises were carried out under the canopy spread between the lofty oaks and elms of the campus.
A meeting was held at 26 Broadway yesterday afternoon, which is of direct importance to all electric light interests. The causes which led to it have been developing for many months.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 22.--Roswell C. Coleman, the Surrogate of Orange County, has decided in the case of the contest over the will of Anna Horton, late of the town of Wallkill, that the will offered for probate is void because she made a subsequent will which she afterward destroyed. The destroying of the second will, the Surrogate decides did not revive the former will, as is the universal impression, and therefore she died intestate.

TORONTO, Ontario, June 22.--Detective Miller, of Philadelphia, arrived here to-day with papers to lay a charge against Wilson, ex-Treasurer of the Delaware and Chesapeake Canal Company, and proceedings for his extradition will be begun on Friday.
NEWBURG, N.Y., June 22.--The first shipment of Hudson River raspberries from points between Cornwall and Catskill are now being made to the New-York, Philadelphia, and Boston markets.

Jay Gould came down town yesterday and showed himself to some anxious Wall-street friends. This was bulletined all over the Stock Exchange district and relied upon to prove that he is not a sick man. Mr. Gould's sickness is not in his legs.
An open lawn tennis tournament will be given by the Elberon Club, of Elberon, N.J., on the Casino grounds on Thursday, Friday, and Saturday, July 21, 22, and 23.

WASHINGTON, June 22.--The exports of merchandise for the 12 months ending May 31. were $724,559,702, or $52,459,156 in excess of the exports for the 12 months preceding. During the last five months the exports were $282,859,251, as compared with $271,703,570 during the corresponding five months of 1886, or a gain of $11,155,681.

An immense impetus was given to the interest in the Sharp trial yesterday by the appearance as a witness of ex-Alderman William H. Miller, who is under indictment for having received a bribe for his vote for the Broadway Surface Railroad franchise, and has always posed as something of a martyr.

There was a commotion among the people at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday noon when a big black hull, with red water line and cream-colored smokestacks, moved slowly in from the East River and was made fast to the Cob Dock. It was the Chicago, the fourth and last of the fleet contracted for by the Government with John Roach Son, and built at Chester, Penn.
SUSPENSION BRIDGE, N.Y., June 22.--The Canadian Niagara Falls Park was opened to the public to-day without ceremony.
A renewal of the Bay Ridge Handicap, with $1,500 in added money has been decided upon by the Coney Island Jockey Club for the fifth race on the programme of Saturday.

BUFFALO, June 22.--Canadian defaulting bank Cashiers have no luck in Buffalo. A.D. Parant was arrested yesterday at the Genesee and is a close prisoner at headquarters.

The ale and porter journeyman brewers do not seem to be much concerned over the boycott that the Central Labor Union has placed on Lyman's brewery, and they say that inasmuch as Mr. Lyman pays union wages to his employes workingmen will not care to boycott his ale.
KEY WEST, Fla., June 22.--The Board of Health has taken up two new cases on its bulletin to-day, one of whom is a colored man who has been sick 12 days in a private house.

CANTON, Ohio, June 22.--A peculiar instance, which is virtually banishment from the United States, is attracting interest in this part of the State. Stanislaus Loichat is in jail charged with stabbing Dr. E.O. Portman with intent to kill.

LONDON, June 22.--Larry Donovan, who was arrested yesterday as he was about to jump from the Clifton Suspension Bridge at Bristol, was discharged to-day upon furnishing sureties that he would make no further effort to jump from the bridge.
LONDON, June 22.--The Queen rose early this morning and took a drive in the garden of Buckingham Palace. Subsequently her Majesty received guests, and then she visited the Duchess of Cambridge.

BOSTON, June 22.--Dense fog and light winds were the prevailing weather conditions off Marblehead to-day, and again was the Regatta Committee forced to postpone the race. To Eastern yacht club members these postponements are particularly annoying.
BALTIMORE, Md., June 22.--Prof. Crouch, the composer of "Kathleen Mavourneen." has been elected a Fellow in the London Society of Arts, Letters, and Sciences.

A collision occurred off Pier 18 North River at 12:30 P.M. yesterday between the Central Railroad ferryboat Communipaw and the sloop yacht Jewell, owned by George Wise, of 914 Third-avenue, South Brooklyn, and sailed by William Wise, of the same address.

The grassy knolls on the Long Meadow in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday were points of vantage for many spectators at the first open lawn tennis tournament of the Prospect Park Lawn Tennis Association.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, June 22.--A dispatch from St. John's, Newfoundland, says Sir Ambrose Shea has been appointed Governor of the Bahama Islands.

BOSTON, June 22.--When, a few years ago, the Bostonian Society proposed to replace on the old State House the lion and the unicorn upholding the British coat-of-arms, a relic of colonial government, a storm of protest was raised by Irish citizens. HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, June 22.--The celebration of Queen Victoria's jubilee has been in progress here for the past two days. The city is crowded with strangers.

Further reports of railway earnings for the second week of June show uniform increases. The highest gain reported in Wall-street Tuesday was by the Buffalo, Rochester and Pittsburg, whose earnings were more than double those returned for the same week last year, amounting to $49,675, a gain of $28,796.

When the dimensions of the Scotch cutter Thistle were sent to this country accompanying the formal challenge for the America's Cup, an article appeared in these columns asserting that yachtsmen who viewed the new vessel's figures with alarm had good cause for their fears.
It is very gratifying to learn that the Lick Observatory is not to suffer for lack of a "current expense" fund.

CHICAGO, June 22.--Though very large quantities of wheat were sent East from this city last week, the statement of east-bound shipments over the Central Traffic Association roads shows a decrease as compared with the preceding week.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 22.--Not since the fearful cyclone of 1878 has this section been visited by such a wildly furious and destructive storm as broke over the city early this morning. During the early evening the weather was oppressively sultry.
MILWAUKEE, June 22.--The opening session of the Supreme Lodge of the Ancient Order United Workmen was held yesterday, representatives being present from the Grand Lodges of 25 States and Territories.

BOSTON, June 22.--The Daily Advertiser and Evening and Sunday Record have been sold to a gentleman not now, although formerly, a resident of Boston. The Advertiser will remain a Republican and protectionist paper. It is not yet known who will be its new editor.

ST. LOUIS, June 22.--William Parker, alias Keller, an alleged ex-convict, wanted in Quincy, Ill., on a charge of burglary, was arrested this evening, and the capture brought a real romance to the surface.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., June 22.--Something of a sensation was occasioned to-day by the arrest by Federal officers of Reed Lewis, a member of an excellent family and a prominent Republican politician, having represented Jackson County in the last Republican Congressional Convention, on the charge of passing counterfeit money. Lewis had a big roll of "queer" five-dollar bills on a Charleston bank in his possession.

The brick manufacturers held their adjourned meeting yesterday, and showed themselves still firmly resolved to support the Verplanck's Point manufacturers in their present trouble.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 22.--Indications are growing plainer that the rivalry of American capitalists who desire to control the sugar trade of the Sandwich Islands is likely to plunge the kingdom of Kalakaua into civil war.

Capt. Townsend, of the schooner Anna M. Estell, which arrived yesterday from Abaco, reports the recent loss of the ship City of Boston among the Banamas.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 23.--The steel sternpost for the cruiser Charleston was successfully cast here yesterday. The post is 22 feet long on the keel, with an upright of 20 feet, and weighs upward of 15,000 pounds. It was claimed by the Eastern competitors for the building of the cruiser that a post of the size necessary could not be cast on the Pacific coast.

The citizens of Point Pleasant, N.J., have arranged to celabrate Fourth of July in the good old-fashioned way, and the committee appointed to prepare a programme has succeeded in filling the day with pleasant and patriotic exercises.

WASHINGTON, June 23.--The President today appointed James Sheakley, of Greenville, Penn., to be Commissioner for the District of Alaska, to reside at Wrangel, vice George P. Ihrie, declined. The Board of Finance of Jersey City last night appointed Assemblyman Robert S. Hudspeth Corporation Attorney. Hudspeth is a Democrat, and succeeds Roderick B. Seymour, Republican, who was removed for political reasons. Hudspeth was the Democratic caucus candidate for Speaker of the Assembly, but was defeated by a combination of five boiting Democrats, two Labor members, and the Republicans.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 23.--At Havre de Grace, Md., this morning, the Coroner's jury in the case of Alexander Gantrom, of Washington, who was killed in the railroad collision on Tuesday evening, rendered a verdict censuring "the railroad company and its employes for the reckless manner and the high rate of speed in running through our city, thereby endangering the lives of our citizens and the traveling public."

Hopkins, Assistant Cashier, were this afternoon surrendered by their bondsmen, and since 4 o'clock have been in the custody of the United States Marshal, while friends have looked in vain for new bondsmen.

WASHINGTON, June 25.--Dr. Robert N. Mills and John Laidlow, who are charged with having engaged in a conspiracy to defraud the Goverment of $13,000 through a bogus pension claim, left Washington this afternoon for Elmira, N.Y., in charge of Chief of Police Little. For the last week in June there is an unusual variety of theatrical entertainment. CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 25.--Crumb Baslington, bankers and brokers, failed to-day owing to the pressure of the Chicago wheat deal and the NewYork panic. They say their liabilities are $40,000, and hope their assets will meet them.

Four of us sat in the cafe around the corner, as usual after our night's work, drinking, smoking, and talking "shop." The conversation had varied somewhat from its customary vein that morning, and after drifting about in a desultory way had finally settled upon the subject of temperance, with one of our office companions figuring as the "horrible example."

The ante-Summer season calm continues; and the placid stream of society doings has flowed on with scarcely a ripple since last Sunday. Two days of pouring rain have not tended to enliven matters, and their effect has been to defer preparations for a speedy flitting to the seaside and the country.

--There is a story told of Perpignan, a literary Bohemian, having an encounter with Charles Maurice at five paces. The former fired and missed. The other, taking deliberate aim, said to his antagonist: "Well, now, before I send you into the other world, tell me what you are thinking." "I am thinking that if I were in your place I would not fire," said Perpignan, and to this cool rejoinder he owed his life.--Chambers's Journal.
Columbus, Ga., has the free mail delivery, and one of the carriers appointed by the Democratic Administration at Washington is a colored Republican.
Another gift to the city was announced yesterday from Stephen Salisbury, whose name was already associated with many such benefactions to the city or to institutious established here.

TROY, N.Y., June 25.--Two women were recently sent by the police magistrate of this city to the Woman's Reformatory at Hudson for five years under the statute that authorizes police magistrates and Justices of the Peace ...
An extraordinary amount of war material continues to be shipped hence for the East. The Nishni Novgorod leaves here on the 20th for Vladivostok.

The New-York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Sailors, whose articles of incorporation were filed in the County Clerk's office Friday, was organized to protect the sailor from boarding house runners, to enable him to collect his wages, and to prosecute any Captain or superior officer who maltreats him at sea.
There is a newspaper museum in Germany whose Directors are anxious to possess a copy of every rare journal.
Airily light are the published promises of new theatres in this city. Foremost among them has been the statement that Augustin Daly is to erect one in time for the season of 1888-9.

Wall-street made an ardent effort to be hopeful, yesterday, when the stock market opened; but the effort was not the most successful that ever was. Anxiety, very thinly disguised, was depressingly abundant; the Street was filled with speculators and brokers who either had been badly hurt Friday or now feared they were going to be.
Major R.H. Hall, Twenty-second Infantry, stationed at Omaha, has compiled and had printed for private distribution a register of the United States Army for Jan. 1, 1792.
KEY WEST, Fla., June 25.--No new cases of yellow fever have been reported since yesterday and none the day before, making two full days without new cases.

Mr. Frank Lincoln, who has been living in Chicago lately, is now at the Coleman House, Asbury Park. He proposes to visit the principal Summer resorts, giving his capital monologue of music and mimicry.
The American Athletic Club held its tenth annual Spring games yesterday at the Manhattan Athletic Club track.

The eighth annual regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club will be sailed off Larchmont July 4. Under the rules of the club the race must be sailed in eight hours, and in case any boat sails the course for her class in that time, it shall be a race for all classes.

PARIS, June 25.--It is the fashion now to be in the Bois at seven in the morning and the first dress is a riding habit of dark blue, or dark green; a white top hat with its becoming black band or a gray soft felt, which is a Rotten-row invention; pearl gray, black stitched, three button gloves, and an ordinary six-cent stick, which completes this amazone attire.

Early closing on Saturday has developed a movement among the employers of clerks to counteract an evil born of half holidays. It is feared that many of the clerks do not apply their leisure to the beneficent uses expected of them.
DETROIT, June 25.--Prof. Hogan, a well known professional aeronaut, made an ascension in a hot air balloon two or three miles below the city this afternoon.
--Old Selden says in his "Table Talk," "To preach long, loud, and damnation is the way to be cried up. Men love the man who damns them, and run after him to save them."
--Shang-le, or precious relies of Buddha, are so abundant that only a miracle could explain their number. Dr. Medhurst throws some light on their history.

The Kentucky Union Labor Convention in Lagrange yesterday nominated the Hon. A. H. Carden for Governor by acclamation. It is said that Mr. Carden will surely accept the nomination. He is a fairly prosperous farmer of Crittenden County, and has not voted for 12 years, having become dissatisfied with the old parties.
The Cleveland Leader gives currency to a report that the stockholders of the New-York Sun are exceedingly desirous of the retirement of Mr. Dana from the editorship of the paper.
LONDON, June 25.--The most obvious comment upon the jubilee celebration, now that it is practically over, is that the whole series of demonstrations were unexpectedly successful.

Brannon, of Nashville, Tenn., have had a serious falling out, and have gone to the courts to settle their quarrels. They own the horses Bootblack, Ovide, John J. Healey, Rio Grande, and Brilliant.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., June 25.--Fire broke out last night and destroyed the brick block, corner of Bay and Clay streets, occupied by Clark Loftus, furniture; Watson Co., drugs, and Sable Brothers, leather. The loss on the building and stock is $50,000; insurance about $30,000. It is supposed that three men who were in the building trying to save goods when the walls crashed in were killed. Their names are unknown.

NEWPORT, June 24.--Newport is going to have a very good season. The cottage-renting season is nearly over, and a survey of the field shows that the number of cottage residents for 1887 is unusually large. The movement of the Irish Home Rule Club to obtain subscriptions for a testimonial to the Sixty-ninth Regiment is meeting with success.

RACINE, Wis., June 25.--A sensation was caused here yesterday by the issuance by an exAldorman and prominent citizen of this city of 150 invitations for the celebration on Sunday next of the death of his wife. The lady died last Spring. It is reported that the man has bought $50 worth of fireworks to be used in the celebration. A commission has been appointed by the County Judge to examine into his mental condition.

Augustus St. Gaudens is about to send to the foundry the colossal statue of Lincoln for Lincoln Park, Chicago, on which he has worked for a longtime. It will stand on a square pedestal, which rises above the centre of an oblong, circular stone seat and balustrade, about 60 feet long by 30 wide.

The Metropolitan and Brooklyn Clubs played a close game at Staten Island yesterday in the presence of 10,000 persons. Good field work characterized the contest.

A lady recently arrived from London reports an interesting interview with Mrs. Potter, in which the latter expresses herself as much delighted with her recent provincial successes and full of confidence in the future. Certain newspapers, she said, had persistently misrepresented and maligned her.

Emeline Mengel died on Friday at the residence of her brother Benjamin at Shoemakersville, aged 27 years. She was by far the smallest adult in Berks County. Her height was but 36 inches and her weight 96 pounds. Miss Mengel was not deformed nor dull witted, but throughout her life retained the manners of a child and was favorite in the community.

BUFFALO, June 25.--Readers of THE TIMES have been told of the difficulty experienced by the National Opera Company two weeks ago in finding its way from Toledo to Buffalo. To accomplish that feat without money and without price it was necessary for the Buffalo Musical Association to pledge $880 to the Lake Shore to secure transportation.

LONG BRANCH, June 25.--Fogs, rains, and a depraved thermometer with distinctly low tastes have combined to keep the season back at the great Summer capital by the sea. "What is so rare as a day in June ?" quoth the poet; but the poet who quoth thus lives in Boston. June at Long Branch is a month of changes.

The main purpose of the proposed bridge across the East River at Blackwell's Island is to give the railroad system of Long Island an entrance into the city, and connection with the railroad lines running from it to the north. Its advantage to the city itself will be very slight.
CATSKILL, N.Y., June 25.--Sidney A. Dwight, the defaulting Cashier of the Coxsackie Bank, is locked up in the Greene County Jail here to await the action of the next grand jury.
The first heat for the Friek gold medal, to be presented to the best mile oarsman in the Gramercy Rowing Club, took place yesterday afternoon on the Harlem River.

Launt Thompson's equestrian statue of Gen. Burnside, for Providence, R.I. has been successfully cast at the Henry-Bonuard foundry, in West Sixteenth-street, and was removed yesterday to the steamer for its transfer to Providence before July 4.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 25.--Detective Curtin, who started a week ago for Salem, Oregon, to identfy a man arrested there on suspicion of being Bryant B. Crandall, supposed to have committed suicide at Niagara Falls, but reported to be alive in the West, telegraphs that the man in custody is not Crandall.

TAUNTON, Mass., June 25.--Quite a chapter of carriage accidents occurred last night. William Hart and a companion named Stone were thrown from a carriage in Weir-street and Stone was quite badly hurt.

LEXINGTON, Ky., June 25.--The indications for peace at Morehead are more favorable to-day. This morning J.A. McKenzie, Secretary of State, and D. B. Logan drafted resolutions to be adopted at a mass meeting next Wednesday. The resolutions pledge the Sheriff and officers of the law support in arresting and bringing to trial all persons indicted by the Grand Jury. They are of a pacific nature and further unpleasantness is improbable.

The Police Commissioners were notified yesterday that the General Term of the Supreme Court had rendered a decision directing the reinstatement of Patrolman Georgo W. Blonk, formerly of the Nineteenth Precinct.

The season of comic opera at Wallack's Theatre is proving one of the most successful, financially and artistically, ever given by Col. McCaull during the Summer. "Jacquette" has attracted good houses during the past week, and will be continued for another week, the last performance of this lively French opera being now announced for next Saturday night.
The thirteenth annual regatta of the Va-, lencia Boat Club was held yesterday afternoon at the club's boathouse, at the foot of Twelfthstreet, Hoboken.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 25.--The trouble with the ore shovelers is now thought to be definitely adjusted. Mr. John Tod, a Director of the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio Railway, has assumed the contract for handling and the strikers have agreed to go to work Monday.

Jackson-street presented a strange appearance yesterday afternoon, and many might have been excused for believing that the entire east side population was crowded into it. Capt. Jack Hussey's funeral attracted a bevy of friends such as few are blessed with, while the inevitable curiosity lovers were by no means absent.
Manager William A. Camp returned to his post at the Clearing House yesterday after a pleasant trip to Middletown, Conn., where he went to attend the wedding of his niece, Miss Charlotte Madge Elmer.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 25.--President Timothy Dwight will deliver the baccalaureate sermon to the graduating class of Yale College in Battell Chapel to-morrow at 10:30 A.M. On Monday at 11 A.M. will take place the presentation exercises, with class oration and poem.

The Church Temperance Society and the Society for the Prevention of Crime have not become disheartened by Gov. Hill's veto of the High License bill which they drafted and which passed both houses of the Legislature.

VIRGINIA, Nov., June 25.--In addition to the six men imprisoned by the fire in the Best and Belcher Mine, five men are shut off from escape in the 800-foot level and four men in the 400-foot level of the Gould and Curry Mine, making in all 15 miners imprisoned.
The cultivation of cotton in the Transcaspian seems to be attracting the attention of Russian capitalists.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 25.--The most destructive fire that has occurred here in years broke out in the tobacco quarter at 1:35 o'clock this morning. The entire square between Main and Market and Ninth and Tenth streets was the scene of the fire, and two acres of buildings with their contents were lost.

Racine College, Wisconsin, one of the leading educational institutions of the West, conferred the degree of LL.D., at its Commencement yesterday, upon Judge George C. Barrett, of this city, an honor most worthily bestowed.

A perfect day, a splendid track, fine racing, and a great crowd of people, all combined to make yesterday's racing at Sheepshead Bay all that could be desired. But it was a hard day for the speculative element to pick the winners of the various events, for in no instance except the cup race did the favorite win.
MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., June 25.--Counsel for Barclay Peak, who was convicted of the murder of his cousin, Mary Catherine Anderson, to-day made application before Judge Parker for a new trial.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 25.--The Executive Committee of the Ninety-fourth Regiment New-York Veteran Association met in this city yesterday and decided upon the erection of a memorial monument on the battlefield of Gettysburg. It will be of blue granite, 30 feet high, and will be placed on the field of the first day's fight. The dedication is expected to take place about the middle of October.

DETROIT, June 25.--The trouble which S.H. Davis Co., the Detroit fishing firm, had with the Canadian Government has been adjusted. Fred Lincoln, who went to Ottawa to represent the firm, has, returned.
CLTNTON, N.Y., June 25.--The seventy-fifth Commencement of Hamilton College began this evening with prize speaking by the Junior, Sophomore, and Freshmen Classes.

GLASGOW, June 25.--The yachts Thistle and Irex started from Rothesay to-day on a 50mile race. There was a brisk breeze at the time. The Thistle won the prize, covering the course in 4:06:45. The time of the Irex was 4:18:45. During the contest the Irex got to the windward of the Thistle and rounded the first flagboat two minutes ahead. The Thistle, however, quickly regained the lead and won.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 25.--The committee having charge of the erection of the McCullough monument at Philadelphia have changed their plans and have written to Mr. Noble, the sculptor, who executed the bust of the actor, to at once arrange to execute a full portrait statue to take the place of the bust. Mr. Noble will complete the statue by adding to the bust already accepted by the committee.

SARATOGA, N.Y., June 25.--J.W. Cook, fatherin-law of ex-Sheriff James O'Brien, of New-York City, was terribly injured in his saw mill at the Fish House, 20 miles from here, this afternoon. Both of his legs were broken and he was otherwise hurt.

LONDON, June 25.--The Genesta, which is leading in the jubilee yacht race, has passed Plymouth. She was making but slow progress. She was contending against a dead head wind and a strong tide. The yacht Sleuthhound, which is one of the contestants, passed the Lizard at 7:30 o'clock this evening.
The sixth annual race meeting of the Kings County Wheelmen was held on the Brooklyn Athletic Association's grounds yesterday before about 800 spectators.

NYACK, N.Y., June 25.--Dr. John G. Dorrance, of this place, who mysteriously disappeared from Philadelphia last month, has been heard from. He is in Minnesota and dangerously ill with brain fever.

The regular shoot of the Washington Gun Club for the championship badge took place yesterday at Dexter Park, Long Island. R. Mousees, 25 yards, won it for the third time this season, with a clean score of seven straight kills.

WASHINGTON, June 25.--Rear-Admiral Braine, commanding the South Atlantic squadron, reports to the Navy Deportment from Rio de Janeiro, under date of May 19, that the flagship Lancaster is awaiting there the relief officers and crew expected to arrive on the Trenton. The Tallapoosa was at Rio.

The play in the open tournament of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club at Montrose, N.J., yesterday afternoon, was of the highest standard. It was full of surprises, for in two instances were looked-for winners defeated.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 25.--There was less withdrawing of deposits from the banks today and the belief is that the worst of the trouble incident to the Fidelity Bank failure is over.

--A very interesting catalogue of the Oriel College library in the year 1375 has lately been published.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 25.--Yale was a winner again to-day, and again a University of Pennsylvania crew was defeated, but this time it was the Freshman lights of the two colleges who disturbed the tranquillity of the Thames. It was not a close race, for the winners led from the start, pulled in better form, and generally had things all their own way.

If that ancient prophet who declared "all men are liars" has any vanity left at this late day he must feel pretty proud as he looks down from the spirit world into Wall-street, just after any thing like a panic has traveled that way.

Miss Minnie Maddern, in "Caprice," enters upon her second week at the Bijou Opera House to-night. She has drawn large audiences since the opening of her engagement, and will remain at the Bijou during the Summer season.

The next meeting of the National Prison Association will be held in Toronto, Canada, Sept. 10 to 15. The presence there of such men as ex-President Hayes, the Hon. Francis Wayland, Charles Nordhoff, Charlton T. Lewis, Charles L. Brace, Frederick Wines, and Z.R. Brockway, all of whom will take part in the deliberations, insures an interesting and useful meeting.

The annual encampment of the National Guard at Peekskill is now in full progress, the Seventh Regiment having completed on Saturday the first week of the present season and the Twelfth having succeeded it there on the same day.

The club regatta of the Yorkville Yacht Club was held yesterday. The course was from off Oak Point to and around Stepping Stone Light and back. The smallest yachts turned at Schuler Buoy. There were 13 entries of small sloops and catboats.

The Paris gambling hells are rather busy just now, more particularly those in which women play. A police inspector and his men made two swoops yesterday evening. In one place in the Rue de la Terrasse 15 demimondaines...

NEW-LONDON, June 26.--If there could have been a race this afternoon it would have been a success it perfect weather conditions count for anything. There was hardly a breath of wind, but the clouds that hid the sun half the time saved the day from being sweltering.

CHICAGO, June 26.--The Land and Labor clubs of Chicago gave Dr. Edward McGlynn a reception this afternoon in the clubroom of the Grand Pacific Hotel. President Van Ornum, of Club No. 1, presided.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 26.--The Louisville Southern Railroad Company has made a mortgage for $2,500,000 to the Louisville Safety Vault and Trust Company. The mortgage is upon all the property, rails, roadbed, engines, cars, charrers, and all other privileges.

M. Yvan Zmertich, a Hungarian, has just walked from Buda-Pesth to Paris, a distance of 900 leagues, in 28 days. He has arrived in France to walk from Perpignan in the Pyrenees to Dunkerque, against a renowned Basque, who a short time ago walked from Pau to Paris. The stakes are 2,000f., and there are heavy bets on the result.

Margaret Breaton, of 511 East Eightyeighth-street, has been locked up in the Harlem Jail since Friday on suspicion of being a receiver of stolen goods. During all that period the keepers have been puzzled by the fact that the woman seemed to be constantly under the influence of liquor.

That District Assembly No. 49 of the Knights of Labor is capable of reform and that the great mass of its rank and file will not forever consent to be ruled and deluded by the Home Club was shown by a meeting it held yesterday--a meeting which lasted from 2 o'clook in the afternoon until near midnight.
KEY WEST, Fla., June 26.--There have been four new cases of fever since yesterday, but no deaths. The record now stands: Total cases to date, 42; total deaths, 18; sick now, 14; discharged cured, 10.

BARSON, Arizona, June 26.--The latest reports from the Apache Indians are to the effect that 11 of them have been driven back to the reservation by Lieut. Johnson and the troops. This leaves very few of them at large.

A large congregation attended the Fourteenth-Street Presbyterian Church yesterday morning to listen to the farewell sermon by the Rev. R.T. Marling, who has accepted a call to the Emanuel Congregational Church, in Montreal.
A. Bleecker Banks, of Albany, is at the Murray Hill Hotel. Ex-Gov. Thomas Carney, of Kansas, is at the Gilsey House.
PHILADELPHIA, June 26.--Two thousand people saw a wonderful achievement of engineering skill at Holmesburg Junction on the New-York division of the Pennsylvania Railroad to-day.
RONDOUT, N.Y., June 26.--The body of a strange man was found floating in the Rondout Creek this afternoon. Whether it was a case of accidental drowning or of foul play has not yet been determined.

Those who are familiar with official reports concerning the Panama Canal will not be surprised by the announcement that the chief executive officers of the canal company have left the isthmus in a hopeless frame of mind.

HANOVER, N.H., June 26.--Charles S. Cook, instructor in physics and astronomy at Dartmouth College, has been elected Professor of Physics in the Northwestern Universtiy, Evanston, Ill. Prof. Cook was graduated from the Chandler Scientific department in the Class of '79.

ST. LOUIS, June 26.--The effect of the repeal of the statute popularly known as the law of 1857 was demonstrated to a thirsty populace to-day. The repeal makes the sale of liquor and beer on Sunday illegal in the State.

Boats and cars took crowds of excursionists from this city to Coney Island yesterday, and the hotels did a lively business which made the managers feel as though the season had really begun in earnest at last.

James Larrabee, the old king of the forest, well known here, is dead. He was in the woods of North Conway with a big crew of men a week ago Friday, June 17, getting out spars for a Bath builder, when he took a sudden cold and died next morning.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., June 26.--A telegram was received late last night by City Marshal Agnew stating that C.R. Carter, Tom M. Killon, and three other prisoners Killed the Deputy Sheriff and escaped from the jail at Mount Vernon, 30 miles west of here, at 10 o'clock Saturday morning, and a reward of $400 has been offered for Carter's arrest.

Travel over the Sixth-avenue line of the elevated railroad was stopped for three-quarters of an hour last night in consequence of an accident to a car on a south-bound train, which ran off the track near South the Ferry station.

Frederick Nelson, employed by the Dry Dock and Avenue B Railroad Company, was cursed with a drunken wife eight years ago, and he was compelled to put his children, Marietta, now 14, and Frederick, now 12, under the care of Mrs. David Dunn, of 95 Greenwich-avenue. He ceased to pay their board, and disappeared in 1884.

The body of an unknown man was found in a cherry tree on Bath Gate-lane, near the entrance to Jerome Park, yesterday morning about 9 o'clock. The corpse hung head downward. It seemed as if the man had tied a rope around his neck and fastened it to the highest branch and thus hanged himself.
Mr. WILLIAM M. IVINS has done a real service to the cause of reform in his article on "Municipal Government" in the Political Science Quarterly for June.
QUEENSTOWN, June 26.--The Cunard Line steamship Umbria, Capt. McMickan, from Liverpool, sld. hence to-day for New-York.

LONDON, June 26.--Discount was firmer and more active during the past week at 1 to . On the Stock Exchange business was very limited, every department being dull and weak. On Monday the settlement begins, and after that more activity is expected.

The Hon. Dennis McMahon last night delivered a lecture on "The Illusions of Legislation" before a good sized audience which had assembles at the rooms of the New-York Labor Lyceum, at 16 Clinton-place.

The Academy of Music was again crowded last night, at the meeting of the Anti-Poverty Society. Abner C. Thomas the author of "Thomas on Mortgages," was Chairman. After a song by the Concordia Chorus, Mr. Thomas stepped forward and was greeted with loud applause.

Twenty-five of the immigrants who arrived yesterday on the French steamship La Gascogne were detained at Castle Garden on the ground that they had been brought here by contract. The party consisted of 19 men and 6 women.

Patrick McCoy, of 126 Leonard-street, was stabbed eight times in various parts of the body yesterday afternoon in front of his saloon, at 51 Elm-street. His assailant was Henry Rice, a machinist, of 92 Elm-street, who was intoxicated at the time of the assault.

Yesterday, in speaking of the pioneers, it was stated that "the early settlers of Oregon were of two distinct classes-frontiersmen and agriculturists from the Southern and Western States, and trades people from New-York and the New-England States."

There was a meeting last night at 54 Union-square of all or nearly all the employes of the various ice companies of this city. The meeting was called by the Knights of Labor organization of the icemen, but was open to all the men, no matter whether they were Knights of Labor or not.

St. Raphael's Chapel, in Fortieth-street, between Tenth and Eleventh avenues, was blessed at 11 o'clock yesterday morning by Archbishop Corrigan. The structure is only temporary, and has been in use since last September.

Archaeologists and antiquarians will rejoice to hear that an important discovery has been made near the town of Adamville. A few days ago a Paris architect, M. Mace, was superintending some alterations in the Park of St. Maur when his men suddenly dug up some moldering bones.

--Mr. Hill, the new editor of Boswell's Johnson, says in his preface that he is looking forward to three more Johnson enterprises. These are a "Selection of Wit and Wisdom," a collection of Johnson's letters not included by Boswell, and an edition of the "Lives of the Poets."

RAHWAY, N.J., June 26.--At a meeting last night of committees appointed by various societies, the militia, and City Government, on the proposal celebration of the Fourth of July the reports presented showed, an enthusiastic and liberal response from all classes of citizens and that the celebration will be an ambitious one.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., June 18.--Negotiations have been closed between ex-Mayor Bryant, of San Francisco, acting for Senator Stanford, and Mr. Mastick, representing the Irvine heirs, whereby Mr. Stanford becomes the owner of San Joaquin Rancho, in this county.

LONDON, June 26.--The time set for signing the Egyptian convention expires to-morrow. It is asserted that if the Sultan does not sign the document Sir Henry Drummond Wolff, the special British envoy, will depart from Constantinople instantly.

Mr. Daniel T. Worden, the stock broker, has been suddenly summoned home from Europe, his wife having become alarmingly ill of pneumonia. Mrs. Worden is one of the handsomest women in New-York, her charms of person and mind having made her prominent in social circles.

HANOVER, N.H., June 26.--Commencement Week at Dartmouth College dawned bright and fair this morning. The college town never looked lovelier, so far as rich foliage and verdant rolling uplands are concerned, and although the burned district still wears a desolate appearance, the town has put on its holiday attire for the college festivities.

The well known place of sepulture of the Thiers family was at the foot of a steep hill at Pere la Chaise, where in wet weather water used to collect. This rendered the visits of Mlle. Dosne to the tomb, whither she often went, dangerous to her health.

The Rev. William T. Carr, the new Pastor of the Shiloh Presbyterian Church, (colored,) at Seventh-avenue and Twenty-sixth-street, was installed last evening in the presence of a very large congregation.

There are 105 entries for the six races at Brighton Beach to-day, of which 36 are in the first race. In the third race, the "Renewal of the Suburban," Exide is entered, but will not be likely to start, as he is also entered in the renewal of the Bay Ridge...

"There is something wrong with this watch," said a gentleman to an avenue jeweler yesterday. "My wife wound it up all right last night; but it has stopped." The watchmaker opened the watch and found a live red ant fastened between the wheels, struggling for freedom. When it was released the watch resumed its ticking.

PEEKSKILL, June 26.--The Twelfth has settled down in camp, and evidently feels as much at home as if it had never known any other existence than being under the eye of an inspector to whom a blade of grass pointing the wrong way is a source of horror.
PARIS, June 26.--The bodies of nine more persons who lost their lives by the bursting of a waterspout at Toulouse have been recovered.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 26.--President Carter preached the baccalaureate sermon to the graduating class of Williams College to-day, taking for his text Ephesians ill., 9: "And to make all men see what is the fellowship of the mystery, which from the beginning of the world hath been hid in God, Who created all things by Jesus Christ."

CHICAGO, June 26.--By the burning of the main buildings of the Chicago Packing and Provision Company, in the town of Lake, early this morning, about $1,000,000 worth of property went up in smoke, and 9 firemen were injured.

A house in Ryerson's-alley, in Peterson, N.J., is occupied by several women well known to the police. One of them, Dolly Desmond, awoke yesterday morning and surprised a burglar in her room. She gave the alarm, and he jumped from a window and escaped, though chased by several persons. He disappeared in the woods north of the city.

Interest in all kinds of sport will be well kept up this week. The cricketers, particularly, will be busy. To-day the strong Manhattan Club will play a first eleven match in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, against the St. George's Club. The Kearney Rangers and the O.N.T. Clubs have...

PHILADELPHIA, June 26.--The storm that swept over Philadelphia this afternoon was particularly severe on the Delaware River and capsized a number of small sail heats. From one of the capsized a the Lydia L., salled by a party of three Philadelphians, and which capsized opposite Boyden-street, South Camden, Edward Fisher, aged 23 years, and John Schaffer, aged 20, were drowned. The third member of the party had a narrow escape.

CHICAGO, June 26.--The week has been one of fair business at the Chicago theatres when the competing attractions and the warm weather are considered. At Hooley'e "The Taming of the Shrew" has been played to good houses, and met with generally favorable criticism.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, June 24.--There is one characteristic of the business men of Nova Scotia's capital that fills an American with wonder. THE TIMES'S correspondent began a search for information at 8 o'clock one morning recently.

Coroner Cowin, of Newburg, went to the Central Office yesterday to report that on June 20 an intelligent German, 50 years old, tall and stout, arrived at Newburg on the night boat. He went to John Hanson's saloon and appeared to be very despondent.

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 26.--The Hudson River and West Shore Railroads and the various lines of steamers on the Hudson brought a great multitude of people to the city yesterday on route for points in the Catskill Mountains.
The revenue cutter Washingtan picked up yesterday a small skiff containing a pair of oars and several empty bottles in the Lower Bay.

There will be racing every day this week at "God's country," as the racing people call the picturesque Coney Island Club Course. Good racing there certainly will be if the programme for to-day is any criterion to judge by.

Gov. Ross has been Governor six months, and there have been five train robberies in that time. The chief strength of Gov. Ross in the campaign was the want of a strong, determined man for Governor, who would break up lawlessness in this State. That his beginning is not auspicious is the gentlest criticism that one can make.
The Thespian Club took possession of the Hudson River yesterday, and it will be some time before the Hudson recovers, to say nothing of the club.
The body of a boy about 10 years of age was found in the canal at Newark yesterday. It had been in the water for some time. There was nothing on the body by which it could be identified.

John McKenna, 27 years old, of 57 North Third-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, was removed to the Eastern District Hospital just before midnight last night suffering from several severe stab wounds about the body, limbs, and hands.

The closing exercises of the American Asylum for the Deaf and Dumb were held yesterday afternoon. When the other exercises were over little Albert Nolen went up to the stage. He is a very bright boy, who, like Laura Bridgman, is deaf, dumb, and blind.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 26.--By order of the bridge company, during the construction of the Poughkeepsie Bridge red lights only will be displayed on piles and cribs, and white lights only on barges. There will be a red light on each corner of each pier during construction, and the span blocked by scaffolding will be indicated by a line of red lights. This information is important to all navigators coming up or going down the Hudson.

The Tabernacle Baptist Church, at Clintonstreet and Third-place, Brooklyn, celebrated its twenty-fifth anniversary yesterday. In the morning the Rev. F.R. Morse, the Pastor, read a historical address and celebrated the communion. The church is an off-shoot of the Strong-Place Baptist Church and has a membership of 450.

"He hasn't enough money," said Warden Keating, of Ludlow-Street Jail. "Who hasn't enough money?" inquired a TIMES reporter who reached the Warden's office yesterday afternoon just in time to hear the remark.

A young man named George Hall made an attempt to board a moving train on the Pennsylvania Railroad at the Market-street station in Newark early yesterday afternoon. He fell and his left leg was cut off. He was removed to the hospital where it was said last night that the other would have to be amputated. It is doubtful if he will survive.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 26.--President Timothy Dwight, of Yale University, delivered his first baccalaureate sermon at Battell Chapel this morning, taking as his text a sentence from St. John xiv., 31: "Arise, let us go hence."

DETROIT, Mich., June 26.--The Legislature of this State closed its working session yesterday morning, the formal adjournment to take place next Wednesday, to give the Governor time to examine the work of the concluding days with a view to intelligent action.

St. Augustine's Church, on Gardner-street, near New-York avenue, at Union Hill, N.J., was dedicated yesterday by the Right Rev. Bishop Wigger, D.D. Pontifical mass was celebrated by Bishop Wigger, with Father Benedict, of the Monastery, as assistant priest, Father O'Connor as deacon, and Father Nevins as subdeacon.

Elmira physicians have regarded and watched with considerable interest the case of Mrs. Davidson, who resides on Harriet-street. About two months ago, while cutting wood, she chopped off the middle finger of her left hand and also cut through the bone of the first finger.
Cappa's Seventh Regiment Band was the centre of attraction in Central Park yesterday, and an audience most keenly critical applauded those particular pieces which appealed to their sympathies.

The first Sunday games of the Nassau Athletic Club at Washington Park, Brooklyn, were well attended. There were six contests and 53 entries. The first event was the 125 yards dash, in two preliminary heats and a final. E.S. Newhall, 1 yard, finished first, in 0:12 , with S.E. Corbett, scratch, second, only six inches behind him.

Edward Butler, boatswain of the Red Star steamer British Queen, was engaged in the hold of the vessel while she lay at her dock in Jersey City, yesterday, when John Murphy and John Hendrickson assaulted him. They were arrested.

BOSTON, June 26.--Mr. Henry Bryant, the owner and designer of the famous sloop Thetis, has sold her to Mr. Oscar C. Ferris, of New-York. From first to last the Thetis has cost her owner over $30,000, and he has disposed of her for less than half that sum. She will be enrolled in the Atlantic Yacht Club and will race in the same class as the Shamrock, Titania, Bedouin, Mischief, Oracle, and Fanny.
KEY WEST, Fla., June 27.--There has been one new case of fever since yesterday and one death. Mr. Harold, of Baltimore, died at the hospital.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 27.--on Saturday evening between 8 and 9 o'clock a freight train in charge of Conductor Seely, of this city, struck a black bear weighing 200 pounds a short distance west of Yost's Station, on the New-York Central Road. The bear had probably wandered down from the North Woods.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 27.--About 15 years ago a street car charter was granted by the City Council, the company being empowered to enter upon such streets as it chose; in short, having an exclusive right to all the streets.

NYACK, N.Y., June 27.--This afternoon John L. Brennan, a youth of 17 years, went in swimming in the pond along the Nyack turnpike, diving off the board walk, which runs out into the water some distance.

LONDON, June 27.--The Gaiety Theatre was crowded in all parts to-night when Mrs. James Brown Potter and her company presented, for the first time in London, "Civil War," an English version by Herman Merrivale of Alfred Delpit's "Mile. de Bressier."
The signing by the Governor of the Electrical Subway Commission bill created quite a breeze yesterday at the headquarters of the commission, in Wallack's Theatre building.

Police Justices Smith, Patterson, O'Reilly Welde, White, and Murray, a bare quorum of the Board of Police Justices, met last night in the Jefferson Market Police Court and reappointed all the present clerks, assistants, and officers of the various police courts for the term of two years.

LONGVIEW, Texas, June 27.--One of the most destructive storms ever known here occurred last night. The main portion of the storm did not strike this place, but 20 miles below here it carried death and destruction in its course.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 27.--A fight was reported yesterday from the Choctaw Nation, between a Sheriff's posse and a band of horse thieves, in which two of the latter were killed outright and three wounded. Three of the gang escaped.

TROY, N.Y., June 27.--William Bullis, of Glens Falls, claims to have discovered a mountain of coal in Warren County, in the vicinity of the North Creek. It is believed that the mountain contains millions of tons.

LONDON, June 28.--In the House of Commons to-night Mr. Maurice Healy moved as an amendment to the Crimes bill that prisoners be given the same right to challenge jurors as was granted the Government; that the Government be not allowed to challenge jurors on account of their religion, and that in the trials of foreigners one-half of the jury must understand the language of the accused.

George Weidler, who killed Dr. Edward H. Duggan in Brooklyn on Friday last, was arraigned in the Sessions Court before Judge Moors yesterday. District Attorney Ridgway appeared with the Grand Jury and C.F. Kinsley appeared for Weidler. After the indictment had been read to him Weidler responded, in a clear tone, "Not guilty." The trial was set down for July 18.
