Ex-President Henry Hart is a title that Wall-street will soon be using when it chooses to talk about Pacific Mail affairs. But George Gould is scarcely likely to go rattling around in the Presidential shoes. Henry Hart let go yesterday, as predicted in this column that he was getting ready to do.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 28.--James A. Bradley, the founder of Asbury Park, gave a dinner this evening to the members of the Board of Trade of the town, the town officers, and others. Over 100 covers were laid. Speeches were made by Mr. Bradley, ex-Postmaster Snedeker, Postmaster Toland, Mayor McEwen, Dr. Henry Mitchell, President of the Board of Health, and many others. It was the largest dinner party ever held here.

G.W. Blodgett, of Boston, electrician for the Boston and Albany Railroad, read a paper on "The Electric Lighting of Passenger Trains" at the dinner of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, at Martinelli's, last evening.

Mr. Jefferson Davis's last published letter contains the information that he did not expect nor covet the distinction of being President of the Confederate States. Many persons have long been aware of this. We once heard Henry A. Foote, the Tennessee Senator, say that it was designed as late as the date of the Provisional Congress at Montgomery to make Jefferson Davis Secretary of War of the Confederacy.
According to the view of those of his admiring constituents who believe in grabbing everything in sight, Mayor Patrick J. Gleason, of Long Island City, added a sprig to his laurels yesterday.

SAN CARLOS, Arizona, June 28.--All the renegade Apaches, who recently left the reservation on a raid, are in the guardhouse here, having given themselves up.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 28.--It is reported from Catlettsburg that the Tolliver faction of Rowan County are reorganizing, and the people in that section of the State are expecting another outbreak at Morehead.

The schooner Joseph Baymore, which sailed from Smithville, Pedee River, S.C., June 5, for New-York, was left in a sinking condition off Cape Henry on the 13th inst. Fair winds were met until June 10, when a storm from the northeast set in and increased in violence.

VIENNA, June 28.--The health of Dr. Dollinger, the eminent theologian, is fast failing and his friends are anxious regarding his condition.

ST. LOUIS, June 28.--The Washburn-Moen Barbed Wire Company sustained a serious reverse in the United States Circuit Court to-day. The company recently brought suit against the Freeman Wire Company on the ground of infringement...
LEXINGTON, Ky., June 28.--Ten Broeck, one of the greatest race horses ever foaled, died this morning of paralysis at the home of his owner, the Nantura Stock Farm, in Woodford County.

The hotel baseball game at the Polo Grounds yesterday was a success in every way. As an exemplification of how baseball and hotel keeping may be combined it was unique and rare. HANOVER, N.H., June 28.--The college town to-day was filled with visiting Alumni and friends of the graduating classes in the several departments of the university. The day began with the graduating exercises of the New-Hampshire College of Agriculture and Mechanic Arts in the college church.

It was reported yesterday afternoon, after the sudden stop in the trial, that Mr. Sharp was dying. At Ludlow-Street Jail Mr. Sharp himself was asked about the matter. His answer was: "Well, I'm pretty bad, but, thank God! I am not as bad off as that."

President Bayles, of the Health Department, yesterday wrote to Mayor Hewitt in reference to a letter from "An Indignant Taxpayer," printed in THE TIMES, and complaining that a servant in his family, suffering from scarlet fever, was not promptly removed to the hospital.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 28.--Some 500 hospital tents, belonging to the Government and stored here, have been shipped to Florida for use by refugees from Key West. A camp for the unacclimated, it is understood, is to be established at Edgewood Key, under charge of experienced yellow fever doctors of this city.

AUGUSTA, Ga., June 28.--Major J.W. Greene is General Manager of the Georgia Railroad. Col. James Barrett is a thriving farmer living here, lately a candidate for the State Legislature, and recently part owner of the Bath Paper Mills.

MILWAUKEE, June 28.--It is now estimated that the loss resulting from the destruction of the city of Marshfield will not be less than $3,000,000, and may be nearly $3,500,000. The heaviest loser is the Upham Manufacturing Company, whose loss is approximated at $800,000. Sanger, Rockwell Co., of Milwaukee, lose $450,000, representing a whole season's cut of lumber; Tremont Hotel Company, ...

The Court of Appeals of this State has just rendered a decision which is especially timely and important just now, as it passes upon the sufficiency of evidence in corroboration of the testimony of an accomplice.

A site was offered for letting on building lease by auction yesterday at the Mart, which illustrates the great value of land in good positions in the city of London.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 28.--Reports from Sunman, Ind., says a destructive fire occurred there today, destroying H. Nieman's warehouse and general store, besides nine other houses, mostly dwellings. There is no estimate given of the loss.

CHICAGO, June 28.--Contrary to general expectation the Directors of the Board of Trade to-day voted not to investigate the condition of wheat in Chicago, arguing that the charges that wheat is out of condition are insufficiently authenticated.

LONDON, June 28.--The race for the North Derby of 2,000 sovereigns was run at Newcastle today, and won by Mr. R. Botterill's b.c. Salisbury by a length from Mr. Hedworth's Puritan, who beat Mr. C. Perkins's Eglamore for the place by a head. The betting was 2 to 1 against Salisbury.
The free fresh-air excursions conducted by St. John's Guild will begin on Tuesday, July 5, and be repeated on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays during the hot weather.

Lawyer John Fleming, as Referee, yesterday sold the New-York, Woodhaven and Rockaway Railroad, including rolling stock and equipments, to satisfy a mortgage for $600,000 held by the Metropolitan Loan and Trust Company of New-York.

Among the more important arrivals from Europe by the steamship Arabic Monday was Miss Kitty O'Brien, the intended bride of Mr. Michael Crowley, the chimpanzee, now residing at Central Park. Miss O'Brien hails from the wild regions above the falls of the Congo River, and was secured by an agent of F.J. Thompson, of this city, from some natives who came down...

BOSTON, June 28.--The annual meeting of the Harvard Divinity Alumni Association was held to-day in the Divinity Hall Chapel in Cambridge. About 60 members were present, and these officers were elected: President--The Rev. Joseph Henry Allen, editor of the University Review; Vice President--The Rev. George Bacheler, of Wellesley Hills; Secretary-- ...

PEEKSKILL, June 28.--Dew lay on the grass this morning when the Twelfth was aroused for its day's work--about as heavy as dew is ever seen even in this mountainous part of the State. It was not mountain dew, but it made the soldiers feel much uglier than if it had been.

It speaks well for St. Helena brandy that we can ship it to the very heart of the wine-growing districts of France, and the shipment by Beringer Brothers of two carloads to Bordeaux and one to Glasgow recently will give some idea of the possibilities of the expanding market for the California production, and the bright future for the industry when once the limitless market is fully developed.

DETROIT, June 28.--Getzein was put into the box to-day and compelled the visitors to scatter their hits to such an extent that few runs resulted. The home nine did fair work with their sticks and won with comparative ease.

WASHINGTON, June 28.--The National Republican, a paper printed here every day in the week except Sunday, and respectfully, but with apologetic streaks, adhesive to the Republican Party, contains this morning the exclusive news that "certain" Ohio Democrats have opened a headquarters in this city for Democrats opposed to the renomination of Cleveland.

The King of Beasts, desiring to choose a Corporation Counsel, asked a prominent Wolf whether his Tribe had any Preference in the matter. The Wolf replied that he had no Candidate, and would be perfectly satisfied with any Selection His Honor might make.

Jay Gould and Russell Sage are triumphant; Cyrus W. Field's scalp has been taken. Wall-street has a new "victory" to celebrate, and aboriginal savagery is once more discounted by the Stock Exchange. Mr. Field made a brave fight, but he did not realize until the end came that he was to be struck down in the very house of his friends.

PARIS, June 28.--The Lafayette Theatre, at Rouen, has been destroyed by fire. The house was empty when the fire broke out, a performance having been concluded a short time before. There was no loss of life.

Forepaugh's New Olympia, the mammoth enterprise conceived by the veteran showman at Erastina, Staten Island, started on its career last evening. The immense space occupied by the enterprise makes quite a city of canvas. On the right of the entrance is the menagerie, with all those animals in cages which it is not safe to turn loose.

NORTHFIELD, Mass., June 28.--Arrangements are now perfected for the Summer school for college students at this place to open under the personal direction of Mr. D.L. Moody on Thursday, June 30, and to continue in session until Wednesday, July 13, Two sessions will be held each day.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 28.--The two Oriental steamship lines from this city have reduced the cabin fare from San Francisco to Hong-Kong and Yokohama to $200, a reduction of $100 and $50, respectively, and have made the round trip rate to the two cities $350. This is in consequence of Canadian competition.

R.D. Sears has been made Fleet Captain of the Eastern Yacht Club and has ordered the vessels of the fleet to assemble off Marblehead on the evening of July 6 for the annual cruise, which will begin the next morning.
Dr. Herman Plantiko, a distinguished lawyer of Berlin, 35 years of age, came to this country a year ago with letters to Oswald Ottendorfer and Carl Schurz.

MILWAUKEE, June 28.--Half the business part of Hurley, Wis., was destroyed by fire today. The town is one of the mushroom settlements in the mining region, and the buildings were not very valuable. The loss will not, exceed $80,000, and none of the individual losses are over $5,000.
Brooklyn batters hit Seward, the Athletic pitcher, in a lively manner at Washington Park yesterday, and beat the representatives of the Quaker City 11 to 3.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 28.--The attendance at the Hudson River Driving Park to-day was large, and the races were well contested. There were 12 starters in the 2:37 class. OMAHA, Neb., June 28.--The painters' strike which has been in progress at this place for the past four weeks has at last begun to assume serious aspects.

WASHINGTON, June 28.--Col. Elwell G. Otis, Twentieth Infantry, has been detailed to proceed to Harrisburg for the purpose of accompanying the Governor of Pennsylvania on his tour of inspection of the National Guard at the annual encampment at Mount Gretna, Lebanon County, from Aug. 6 to 13.

Mays was hit rather freely by the Baltimore players at Staten Island yesterday, and the result was that the Monumental City players placed another victory to their credit. They played with the vim and determination that characterizes the work of the St. Louis Browns, and had little trouble in winning.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 29.--With the exception of the heat, a more perfect day for Commencement at Harvard College could hardly have been desired. Early this morning the old boys and the undergraduates mingled in the college yard in fraternal enjoyment of the past, the present, and the future.

LONDON, June 29.--At the Newcastle and High Gosforth Park Summer Jubilee meeting to-day W. Blake's 4-year-old b.c. Exmoor won the Northumberland Plate of 1,000 sovereigns by four lengths, W. I'Anson's b.c. Castor, 4 years, second, and Lord Durham's Vagabond, 6 years, third. Ten others ran. The distance was two miles. Exmoor was the favorite in the betting at 3 to 1 against him.

When Jacob Sharp arrived in court, which he did a few moments before Judge Barrett, he walked with cool deliberation to his seat. But it was easy to see that the deliberation was assumed and that it cost Mr. Sharp a great effort. His face was flushed, his lips trembled, his hands grasped his cane, and, as if to hide his emotion, he talked with his grandson.

At a meeting of the clergy and laity of the Southern Diocese of New-York at Tarrytown, on Tuesday, Bishop Potter appointed the Rev. F.B. Van Kleeck, of Grace Church, White Plains, Archdeacon of the diocese, with jurisdiction over the counties of Putnam, Rockland, and Westchester.
NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 29.--This old town is waking up in earnest, and realizing the fact that the crowning event of the race week is only two days off.

The jury in the Sharp case was out thirteen minutes and found a verdict of "guilty as charged." This shows that after listening carefully to the evidence, to what was to be said on both sides, and to the fair and colorless charge of the Judge, not one of the twelve men had the least hesitation in regard to his duty.
The Commencement exercises of St. Peter's College were held at the Tabernacle in Jersey City last night. There was no regular graduating class.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 29.--Northern capitalists are rapidly acquiring all the pine lands in Southern Alabama that are still owned by the Government, and that can be had for $1.25 an acre. Elihu and William Jackson, of Maryland, have just purchased 40,000 acres of finely timbered land in one tract in Covington County, and 20,000 acres were bought by another party about a month ago.

BRUSSELS, June 29.--The Chamber of Representatives has reduced the duties on coffee. VIENNA, June 29.--King Milan, of Servia, has instructed Premier Ristics to take measures to prevent the return of Queen Natalie to Servia. A Cabinet crisis is expected if the Premier refuses to obey the King.

BURLINGTON, Vt., June 29.--At the exercises of the eighty-third Commencement of the University of Vermont at Howard Opera House to-day the following named gentlemen delivered orations: X.C. Wheeler, F.M. Button, H. N. Bosworth, G.L. Wheelock, J.N. Perrin, Jr., G.N. Roberts, W.V. Mitchell, Ernest Albee.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 29.--E.A. Ford, General Passenger Agent of the Pennsylvania lines west of Pittsburg, says business is largely ahead of last year's trade. He attributes it to the decrease in free riding.

A letter complaining of the overloading of foreign steam vessels sailing from this port was sent to Mr. Fairchild, the Secretary of the Treasury, by Mr. Nathaniel McKay, of this city, about ten days ago.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., June 29.--Drafts on NewYork--Sight, 22 cents; telegraphic, 30 cents.

The Mets won a game in fine style from the Baltimore men at St. George yesterday afternoon. They hit the curves of Knouff with apparent ease, and took advantage of the errors committed by the visiting players.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 29.--It is reported that the negroes intend to go to the beach board walks in full force on Saturday evening and attempt to remain in spite of James Bradley's remonstrance. An entire police force will be at the beach on Saturday.
HARTFORD, Conn., June 29.--Internal Revenue Collector Troup of the District of Connecticut assumes charge of the consolidated districts of Connecticut and Rhode Island on July 1.
Miss Jessie Petty, daughter of John Petty, of Petty Bostwick, was married yesterday morning to N.H. Lawton, of Cincinnati, at the residence of the bride's father, 33 West Twenty-fifthstreet.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 29.--To-day took place the one hundred and eighty-seventh anniversary of Yale College. The almost continuous rainfall since Sunday morning is one of the heaviest known in Savannah since the Signal Service was established.

C.C. Cusick, Twenty-second Infantry, from similar duty as a member of the court-martial convened at Columbus Barracks, Ohio.

There was a very pretty and quiet wedding in St. George's Church, on Stuyvesantsquare, yesterday noon. Mrs. Mabel Bayard Kane became the wife of Levi C. Bird.

AKRON, Ohio, June 29.--Lieut. G.J. Fiebeger, United States Corps of Engineers, Assistant Professor of Military and Civil Engineering at West Point, was married here this evening to Anna Perkins Upson, daughter of Circuit Judge William H. Upson.
The body of an unknown man was found early Tuesday morning near the Williams Clark Company fertilizing factory at Carteret, N.J., about four miles west of Rahway.

Sheer manipulation and a great big hurrah along with a carefully nursed mystery sufficed to boost all the Gould stock in Wall-street yesterday. Tempting bait was offered the dear public. All of the dog-eared Gould tricks were in full play.
PEEKSKILL, June 29.--If the State camp plateau was a sheet of tin spread out in the sun it could scarcely be any hotter than it has been to-day.

The graduating exercises of the Normal College Training Department, which took place yesterday morning at 10 o'clock, were attended by a large and interested audience. The exercises began with the chant, "Heavenly Father, Grant Thy Blessing," sung by the school, after the Rev. Dr. A.W. Cowles, President of the Emira Female College, had read a selection from the Scriptures and led in prayer.
Mayor Whitney, of Brooklyn, created his first genuine surprise yesterday when he named 15 members of the Board of Education, presumably on his own responsibility.

HANOVER, N.H., June 29.--Dartmouth College Commencement exercises had an extra feature this year in the centennial anniversary of the Dartmouth Chapter of the Phi Beta Kappa Society. A fatal shooting affair which had no apparent cause occurred in a disorderly house at 2 James-street yesterday morning. The assailant, Andrew Matson, is a steward on the yacht Mischief, and the victim is known as Hattie Devine. Matson became acquainted with Hattie about four days ago.
The Committee on Contested Seats of the Republican County Committee met yesterday, ex-Judge Horace Russell returning from Saratoga to attend the meeting.
WASHINGTON, June 29.--Two Republican Representatives in Congress were caught to-day by the interviewer and were allowed to express their opinions on diferent topics with unrestrained freedom.
PHILADELPHIA, June 29.--General Master Workman Powderly to-day detailed facts concerning child labor gleaned from his long residence in the coal regions.

ALBANY, June 29.--Bank Superintendent Willis S. Paine has issued a certificate authorizing the Union Savings Bank of Westchester County to open an office for the deposit of savings, subject to the provisions of the general savings bank law.

LEXINGTON, Ky., June 29.--Five hundred citizens of Rowan County met in Morehead in mass meeting this afternoon. They signed articles of agreement to protect with their lives the lives and property of the citizens of Rowan and the town of Morehead. Everything is quiet and no further trouble is expected. The rumored organizing of the Tollivers is without foundation.

CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, June 29.-- Very heavy rains continue and some of the outlying suburbs are badly inundated. The need of a system of drainage for the valley and city becomes more apparent each year, as the streets during the heavy afternoon rains are hardly passable.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 29.--The Northwestern Miller says: "The more sanguine feeling since the collapse of the Chicago wheat corner induced heavier running of the mills, the output last week showing a gain over several weeks previous, while the current week will doubtless go higher.

THE TIMES is requested by the Rev. HENRY M. FIELD, brother of Mr. CYRUS W. FIELD, to state that Mr. JAY GOULD took 50,000 shares of Manhattan from Mr. CYRUS W. FIELD, for which Mr. GOULD paid Mr. FIELD 120.

Messrs. Jacob Hess, Theodore Moss, and E.A. Gibbens, constituting the Electrical Subway Commission, met yesterday at Wallack's Theatre Building and formally closed out the affairs of the board and made provision for its reorganization under the new law.

CHICAGO, June 29.--A decision of Judge Garnett to-day will give the creditors of C.J. Kershaw Co. a chance to find out whether or not Eggleston is a special partner in the firm for $25,000, as he claims, or a general partner with obligations far exceeding that sum.

ST. LOUIS, June 29.--The dead body of A. Talmage, Vice-President and General Manager of the Wabash Railway, who died last night at Peru, Ind., arrived at the Union Station here this morning. Mr. Talmage was a man of commanding physique, and his first attack of illness, like that which resulted in the death of ...

PITTSBURG, June 29.--The families of 15 strikers at the Pennsylvania Salt Works, at Natrons, Penn., were evicted by the Sheriff and his Deputies to-day. The Sheriff was jeered by the strikers, but no resistance was offered.

CHICAGO, June 29.--The General Managers and General Freight Agents of the various roads in the Western and Northwestern Railway Freight Bureau met here to-day to consider what rules and regulations should be established to provide for uniform action relative to rates ...

A meeting of the brickmakers who are to aid the brickmakers of Verplanck's Point in their resistance of the demands made by the Knights of Labor was held yesterday at the Cosmopolitan Hotel, Mr. James A. Whitbeck presiding.

The market in No. 2 red wheat opened yesterday morning with the price advanced cent over the closing quotations of Tuesday. A large short interest soon developed, and under their efforts to cover, the price advanced rapidly from 92 cents to $1.05, at which price 30 loads were bought on orders by G.K. Clark, Jr.

The jury were conducted by Capt. Ricketts through the Clerk's office and Supreme Court Chambers into the hall and thence into the Special Term Court room. The door was closed and each juror knew that the time had come at last for his own action. Foreman Wiley J. Canfield prepared ballots immediately.

Almi De Schempfeleere, an ex-wholesale glovemaker of Sotteghem, Belgium, was arrested yesterday morning for forging drafts and bills of exchange to the amount of 90,000f. Coudert Brothers, as the attorneys in NewYork for the Belgian Government, were asked by a cablegram three months ago to secure the arrest and extradition of De Schempfeleere.

CONSTANTINOPLE, June 29.--The threats of France in connection with the Anglo-Turkish convention have had the effect of exasperating the Porte. It is believed that the Sultan will finally sign the convention.

Deputy Coroner Scholer yesterday held an autopsy on the remains of Samuel Roth, who died in the Ward's Island Insane Asylum on Saturday last under suspicious circumstances. Roth was a Hungarian, and by trade a shoemaker. He was 46 years old.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 29.--The suicide of Walter L. Terrell, who leaped from a ferryboat between New-York and Jersey City last night, ends the career of a young man who had caused his family much solicitude.

DELAWARE, Ohio, June 29.--The Prohibi-- tion State Convention was called to order at 2 o'clock this afternoon by B.S. Higby, of Youngstown, Chairman of the State Executive Committee. The Rev. C. Elwood Nash was chosen temporary Chairman.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 29.--Judge George F. Comstock, of Syracuse, was attacked with vertigo on Sunday last at the Windsor Hotel, and his condition caused the gravest apprehensions of his wife and son, who joined him here on Tuesday.

An attachment was issued in Judge Lawrence's court yesterday against a lady who, it was alleged, had failed to pay her board bill. This occurrence, nowise uncommon in itself, entered into the domain of the extraordinary when it became known that the plaintiff was Octavius...

AUGUSTA, Me., June 29.--Ex-Gov. Morrill seems to be slowly sinking, and his symptoms are not as favorable this morning. His pulse and breathing are irregular and more rapid. His mind is clear. The physician says he may survive 24 hours.

The second annual regatta of the NewRochelle Yacht Club will be sailed off NewRochelle on Saturday. The course for the larger classes will be from the starting point to and around the buoy on the west end of Execution Reef, thence around the Matinicock Point buoy, thence to and around a mark south of Captain's Island, thence around the Execution Reef buoy and home.

The jury in the Sharp case, after a deliberation of only 15 minutes, last evening found the defendant guilty of bribery. He will not be sentenced before July 13, for the court has been adjourned until that day.
Wall-street just now has ears for but one theme and an eye only for one spectacle--Cyrus W. Field, a lamb, led to the slaughter by Jay Gould and Russell Sage.
PHILADELPHIA, June 29.--Pinkerton's Detective Agency in Chicago think they have discovered James W. Taggart, the absconding Paying and Receiving Teller of the Union Trust Company.

Corporation Counsel LACOMBE makes one very surprising statement in the interview reported in another column. Being asked to give his opinion as to who was most worthy to be named as his successor, he said to the reporter: "You are the first person who has asked me this question."

LONDON, June 29.--Mr. Joseph Chamberlain writes a sarcastic letter in reply to Sir G. O. Trevelyan's letter of yesterday.

Unless Hanover falls down this afternoon he will win for the Dwyer Brothers the rich Emporium Stakes, which is to be run for on the Coney Island track this afternoon. Seven others are announced as probable starters for second honors, and of these Stockton seems the best of the lot, and the most likely to win the prize.

SARATOGA, N.Y., June 29.--The third day's session of the American Institute of Homeopathy was held to-day. This morning several new members were elected. Dr. Pemberton Dudley reported that there are 50 journals published devoted to this school of medicine.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 29.--The threemile single scull race between George Bubear, the English champion, and James A. Ten Eyck, of Worcester, for $500 a side, was rowed on Lake Quinsigamond this afternoon, and was won by Bubear easily.

Commissioner Oscar Craig, of Rochester, and John J. Milhau, of this city, members of the State Board of Charities, began yesterday morning in a committee room at the City Hall, by request of Mayor Hewitt, an investigation of the management and condition of the City Insane Asylum on Ward's Island.

PARIS, June 29.--The commission of the Chamber of Deputies appointed to examine and report upon the proposals relative to the army submitted by Gen. Ferron, the new Minister of War, rejected them to-day. The rejection of the proposals has caused a sensation.

If the counsel for the Barron estate really mean all they say it is not unlikely that the whole case as between the estate and the Dexter Savings Bank may come before the new Auditors--Messrs. Howard, of this city, and Morrill, of Lewiston--some time next month.

BOMBAY, June 29.--Natives state that Sirdar Novr Mohammed, a leader in the Ghilzai rebellion, recently captured Gardez without fighting and afterward marched upon Ghuzni. He gave battle to the Ameer's troops twice before Ghuzni, killing 180 of them, and is now besieging that town.
The journeymen tailors of Newark have two rival organizations, one belonging to the Knights of Labor and the other constituting the Tailors' Progressive Union, which is independent of the Knights.
PHILADELPHIA, June 29.--Senator John Sherman, of Ohio, reached this city late this afternoon and will leave for New-York to-morrow morning, where he is to attend a meeting ...

TRENTON, N.J., June 29.--Messrs. Bedle, Muirhead, and McGee, counsel for the Morris and Essex Railroad Company, and the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company, its lessee, have just filed the answer to the claim of the State of New-Jersey for alleged taxes in arrears amounting to something like $1,000,000.
BERLIN, June 29.--Emperor William is now able to go out daily, but his visit to Ems has been postponed some days.

SAUGATUCK, Conn., June 29.--Frederick Calvin, of Beacon Falls, was drowned at Milford Beach this morning. He was clamming and waded beyond his depth. He was 40 years old.
Henry E. Abbey, of the firm of Abbey, Schoeffel Grau, who is to be the sole manager of Wallack's Theatre next season, expects to reach New-York on Aug. 12.

The announcement that the General Executive Board of the Knights of Labor has declared that the amended constitution which it had drawn up and submitted to the various locals had been adopted and was therefore law ...

PITTSBURG, June 29.--This afternoon the iron manufacturers agreed to give the Amalgamated iron workers the 10 per cent. advance as asked in the principal points at issue, but not on what is known as the extras. The boiling scale is fixed at $5.50 per ton on a two-cent card.

CHICAGO, June 29.--The Lake Shore and Mississippi Valley Department of the American Shipping and Industrial League met in convention here this afternoon. Secretary C.S. Hill, of Washington, D.C., called the convention to order.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 29.--Joseph F. Larkin, President of the Cincinnati National Bank, today resigned, and Frank Alter was chosen in his place. Rumors having arisen that this action was demanded by Controller Trenholm, that officer stated that there was no foundation whatever for the story; that the bank had not been under suspicion, and that the change was a purely voluntary one.

A reporter of THE TIMES visited the Law Department yesterday and called Corporation Counsel Lacombe's attention to a paragraph in a morning paper about the selection of his successor.

WASHINGTON, June 30.--Capt F.W. Stone, Twenty-first Infantry, and First Lieut. F.B. Taylon Ninth Cavalry, have been granted two months extension of leave of absence. Leave of absence for four months has been granted Capt. G.T. Beall, Medical Director.

The American Society of Civil Engineers met informally at its headquarters, 127 East Twenty-third-street, last night, and attended to the final arrangements for the departure of the members this morning by the Albany day boat for the convention at the Hotel Kaaterskill beginning to-morrow.
LONDON, June 30.--Lady Muncaster won the Gold Cup race at the Newcastle and Gosforth Park Summer meeting to-day, easily beating her only competitor, Glorification, by a length.
The final meeting of the Brooklyn Board of Estimate was held yesterday, and the appropriations for the year drawn up for formal presentation to the Aldermen.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 30.--The Columbia Freshmen did to-day what the Columbia University eight failed to do, and defeated a Harvard crew in a race that was one sided enough to remind the spectators of the oldfashioned processions which took place here annually when Yale was enamored of the donkey engine stroke. The result was a surprise to everybody and to the betting men with crimson ...

In the number of soldiers sacrificed in the late war as compared with those sent by each State into the field Kansas sustained the greatest loss of life. One out of every five from Kansas died of disease or was killed in battle.
The glorious Fourth approacheth. The great firecracker, fat and ferocious, hangs in blood-red festoons upon the outer wall of the emporium of explosives.

Mr. Richard Mansfield is going to withdraw "Prince Karl" after one more week, and will produce on July 11 "Monsieur," a dramatic sketch in three acts, which he has been carefully preparing for some weeks. "Prince Karl" was not expected to run long when it was revived.

There is a good deal of anxiety on the Metal Exchange over copper. When the Calumet and Hecla Company, the largest producer in this country, made contracts with large consumers for deliveries, at 10 cents a pound, of 28,000,000 pounds up to November, a blow was struck at three interests.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 30.--After being restrained of his liberty for nearly three years by reason of the suits brought against him by the city and county of New-York, Nathaniel Sands was to-day released from jail.

three ambitious young men presented themselves at 9 A.M. of whom 45 were for Harvard, 34 for Yale, and 4 for the Sheffield Scientific School. They were examined in mathematics, Greek, Latin, and other branches. Most of them will pass. The indications are that the classes of '9l at Harvard and Yale will be unusually large. The examinations will be continued throughout the week.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 30.--The Clapp Memorial Library building, at Belchertown, the gift of the late John Francis Clapp. of Brooklyn, N.Y., was dedicated this afternoon. Bishop F.D. Huntington, of Syracuse, N.Y., offered prayer; Dwight P. Clapp, of Brooklyn, made the presentation address, ...
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., June 30.--Drafts on NewYork--Sight, 22 cents: telegraphic, 30 cents.
CHICAGO, June 30.--The Central Traffic Association's Road carried east from Chicago last week and points common thereto to the seaboard 28,835 tons of freight.

TORONTO, Ontario, June 30.--The Queen's jubilee celebration commenced here this morning with a parade of public school children numbering over 10,000. The route led to Queen's Park, where the children sang the national anthem and other appropriate songs.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30.--A peculiar fire and explosion happened at an early hour this morning at the residence of August J. Scholl, proprietor of Aurora Park, at Fifth and Tioga streets, by which Mrs. Scholl and a German employe, George Flemmer, were seriously burned.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 30.--Naturally, the Trustees of Wesleyan University at Middletown feel some delicacy in revealing their reasons for removing their venerable President, Mr. Beach, but it was admitted to-day that his unpopularity with the Alumni and students made it impolitic, if not impossible, to retain him longer. He is an able man, and of sterling integrity, but lacking the faculty of governing without making enemies.
Mayor Hewitt asked a TIMES reporter yesterday: "Did you interview Corporation Counsel Lacombe?"
The name of the New-York, Woodhaven and Rockaway Railroad is to be changed to the NewYork and Rockaway Railroad. Austin Corbin will be President of the road.
CONSTANTINOPLE, June 30.--The Turkish Commissioners have asked for a still further de lay in the matter of ratifying the Egyptian convention.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 30.--Editor Morrison, of the Evening News, was arrested to-day for the second time within a week on a charge of criminal libel, preferred by Postmaster Force, who is also one of the proprietors of the Daily Press.

There is no more delightful operetta in the German repertory than Suppe's "Boccaccio." The story possesses a factitious interest from its quasi-historical nature and a real interest from its intrinsic romance and comedy. It is a trifle risque here and there, but is on the plane of true comedy, and here is an abundance of bright things in the libretto.

Delegates from 56 Italian societies, representing a constituency of over 20,000 persons, met last night at 64 South Washingtonsquare to help along the movement to influence Gov. Hill to commute the death sentence of Mrs. Chiari Cignarale.

UTICA, N.Y., June 30.--Michael Roark, alias "Chael" Roark, alias "Mike McMillan," alias "Big Mike," the West Shore express robber, was sentenced to-day by Judge Kennedy to 20 years at hard labor in Auburn Prison. Roark was taken to Auburn this atternoon.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 30.--The Hon. John F. Smyth, ex-Superintendent of the Insurance Department, died shortly before midnight to-night at his residence, on Lancaster-street. He had long suffered from dropsy and had not left his house for several months. On Monday he was attacked with a congestive chill, as the result of a cold, and in his weak physical condition was unable to rally. He leaves a widow and one son.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 30.--The receipts of grain at the port of Buffalo for the month of June aggregate 15,155,000 bushels, which are in excess of those for any previous June on record with the single exception of June, 1880, when the receipts were 18,000,000 bushels.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 30.--Isaac J. Miller and Gustav Tafel, Trustees of the Purcell creditors, filed their report in the Probate Court late yesterday afternoon. It shows total receipts and disbursements since Jan. 4. 1886, namely, receipts, $90,000; paid creditors, $56,000; paid for expenses ...

The Alumni Association of St. Francis Xavier's College last evening tendered a reception to the graduates of '87 at Delmonico's. It was the largest meeting of the Alumni held since 1882, 75 members being present.

Mayor Hewitt yesterday appointed Peter B. Olney, Gen. Louis Fitzgerald, Stevenson Towle, Thomas C. Clark, and James B. Smith as Rapid Transit Commissioners to lay out new routes in accordance with a petition of 50 reputable householders in this city, which was filed in the Mayor's office May 30.

WASHINGTON, June 30.--Of the 57 clerks in the office of the Quartermaster-General who up to date have been examined, for promotion under the new civil service rules, 30 were men and 27 women. The examination of the papers shows that six men and two women failed to attain the minimum of 75 out of a possible 100. Commissioner Oberly to-day said that the women, as a rule, passed a much more satisfactory ...
LONDON, June 30.--In the House of Commons to-night Mr. W.H. Smith moved that if the report on the Crimes bill be not reached by Monday closure be applied.
The Emigration Commissioners decided at their meeting yesterday to make a change in the management of Castle Garden. Secretary Jackson has heretofore had entire control of Castle Garden.

CHICAGO, June 30.--Since the first few days of its existence the Stock Exchange, situated in the old Call Board room of the Board of Trade, has suffered a gradual decline in the volume of its transactions, until some members are beginning to fear it will droop and die, as did its predecessor several years ago.

Yesterday's settlements for June wheat on the Produce Exchange developed differences against the short interest of about $400,000. The settling price fixed by the Grain Committee was 107. Settlements covered 2,200,000 bushels, 1,200,000 for yesterday and 1,000,000 for Wednesday.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 30.--At a meeting of the Illinois Grain Merchants' Association yesterday Senator Cullom was called upon to speak on the inter-State commerce law. He thanked the convention for the opportunity offered him, and said he had remained silent in regard to the law until the commission appointed under it had got fairly started in the performance of its duties.

CONTOCOOK, N.H., June 30.--A shock of earthquake was felt in this vicinity at 5:10 P.M., jarring everything perceptibly. The shock lasted about five seconds and moved apparently from east to west.

Capt. William W. McLaughlin is now in command of the Old-slip station house, Capt. Nicholas Brooks of the Madison-street station, Capt. Edward Carpenter of the West Thirty-seventh-street station, and Capt. Alexander B. Warts, of the East Fifty-first-street station.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 30.--Among the horses that drew the canalboat W.H. Seward, of Chittenango, as it came into Schenectady to-day was one that has between its left ear and eye a horn about three inches long, ringed and ribbed, and resembling the horn of Durham cattle. The horse uses the horn handily in scratching its legs.

PEEKSKILL, June 30.--There were no flies on the Twelfth Regiment to-day, literally or figuratively. Literally, because they--the flies-- all died of sunstroke before the hour for battalion drill, and figuratively, because the regi ment has trained until it begins to resemble a regiment of veterans.

The New-Rochelle Yacht Club's annual regatta takes place to-morrow morning and promises to be an interesting affair. It will be followed on Monday by the annual regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club, which will this year be unusually interesting. AUGUSTA, Me., June 30.--Ex-Gov. Morrill, although apparently comfortable to-day, is slowly but surely sinking. Since 3 P.M. he has been unconscious.

The Commissioners of Charities and Correction yesterday employed Arthur H. Masten as counsel to represent them in the investigation into the management of the insane asylum on Ward's Island. Before doing so, however, they sought the advice of the Corporation Counsel. He saw no objection, providing it was agreeable to the members of the State Board of Charities, which is conducting the inquiry at the request of Mayor Hewitt.

A meeting of the local committee of the American Association for the Advancement of Science was held last night at Columbia College. Mayor Hewitt, who was to have presided, sent a telegram saying that he was not well enough to be present.

Secretary Lawrence has prepared a lot of puzzles in the five races to be run, for there are to be but five, the fourth race announced on the card having failed to fill. Flageoletta ought to win the opening scramble, with Patrocles in second place.

CHICAGO, June 30.--A State law making the operation of bucket shops illegal goes into effect to-morrow, and all the bucket shops in the city have ostensibly gone out of business as such. But the bucket shop men believe they have found a way to circumvent the law by operating through the Open Board of Trade.

A very pretty sight was the chapel of the Normal College yesterday morning, with the black-clothed dignitaries of the Board of Education on the platform, crowds of eager and expectant mothers, fathers, and friends, all packed into the back seats, around the walls and in the galleries, while massed in the centre of all sat the white-robed maidens of the graduating class, with flushed cheeks and sparkling eyes, speaking plainly of their happiness.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 30.--The Executive Committee of the Ohio Republican League last night issued a call for a convention of Republican clubs at Toledo oa July 28. New-York Republican clubs were invited to have representatives present with a view to organize a National Republican League.

OMAHA, June 30.--The Pacific railway investigating commission resumed its session here this morning. Thomas L. Kimball, General Traffic Manager of the Union Pacific, was examined with regard to the free pass system, rebates, and other particulars.

ROME, June 30.--The Chamber of Deputies to-day granted a military credit of 20,000,000 lire. The Minister of Foreign Affairs stated that a complete understanding existed between England and Italy.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 30.--The Standard Paper Company made an assignment late last evening to J.E. Friend, who gave bond for $130,000. This is supposed to represent the assets. The lia bilities are said to be nearly $200,000.

Eva Meyers, who keeps a lager beer saloon and lives in the basement of 182 Chrystie-street, is alone at night because her husband works in a sugar manufactory at Williamsburg, and they have no children. She retired at midnight in a room between the saloon and the kitchen.

RUTLAND, Vt., June 30.--A terrific gas explosion occurred here early this morning. Miss Sullivan went into her millinery stone on Merchants'-row and struck a match, when the gas which had filled, the room from a leak in the pipe ignited with a loud report.

The Executive Committee of the National Rifle Association yesterday considered the charges made by Lieuts. Pasco and Wilson against Gen. Charles F. Robbins, General Inspector of Rifle Practice.

ALBANY, June 30.--Gov. Hill has dismissed the charges preferred just before the last election by Anthony Comstock against District Attorney Ridgway, of Kings County, for his failure to prosecute persons charged with violation of the laws against pool selling.

Burnette G. Haskell, the Western Knight of Labor editor, who some time ago propounded a number of questions to General Master Workman Powderly, has written him another letter in which he expresses his opinion of Mr. Powderly in the most vigorous and unmistakable terms.

CHICAGO, June 30.--The reaction from the recent rush of wheat to this market is here at last. To-day's inspection sheet showed only four cars of wheat received for the 24 hours, and three of those were billed through.

PARIS, June 30.--The disputed Van Marcke picture exhibited by Knoedler Co. has been duly certified to be an original by the artist him self in the presence of Mr. Robert M. Hooper, the United States Vice-Consul-General. Van Marcke acknowledges having painted both pictures.

At about 11:30 o'clock last night a cash box, which had been forced open, was found in the hallway of 137 Thompson-street and taken to the Eighth Precinct Station. In it were a memorandum of property and three bank books, representing deposits to the amount of $12,000 in the name of Joseph Sweet. The police have been unable to learn who Joseph Sweet is.

OTTAWA, Ontario. June 30.--Grand Chief Engineer Arthur, of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, speaking at a public meeting of the order, held here to-day, said there should be no conflict between capital and labor.
BELVIDERE, N.J., June 30.--The trouble at the stacks of the Andover Iron Furnace, Phillipsburg, is much greater than was expected. Stack I has chilled, and will have to be dug, and possibly torn ...

BERLIN, June 30.--All of the leading papers here publish to-day articles, apparently inspired, advising the financial world to stop lending money to Russia, and follow the example of England and Holland, which have unloaded their Russian securities.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30.--The stockholders of the Central Transportation Company held a special meeting in Association Hall this morning to provide for the distribution of the surplus of $700,000 about which there has been so much litigation.

Yesterday was not the hottest day thus far this year, but it came within 1 of it. At Hudnut's the thermometer marked at 3:30 P. M. 95 , as compared with 78 at the same hour one year ago. On the 17th it marked 96 .
The following are the weights for the Knickerbocker handicap, at a mile and threeeights, to be run at Sheepshead Bay to-morrow:

A man known as John Smith was caught by Moses Meyer, of 55 Clinton-street, opening a wardrobe in Meyer's house the night of June 25. Smith was arrested and was yesterday to plead to the charge of burglary in the second degree.
Mr. Starin has provided a fine musical treat for the patrons of Glen Island to-morrow. Eben's Regimental Band will give two concerts, one from 2 to 4 P.M. and another from 5 to 7 P.M.
KEY WEST, Fla., June 30.--There have been three new cases of fever since yesterday, but no deaths.

NYACK, N.Y., June 30.--This has been the hottest day experienced in Rockland County in several years. At 11 o'clock this morning the mercury registered 95 in the shade, and it did not stop there. At 3 in the afternoon it went to 100 . Close along the river bank and up on the shaded hillsides the temperature was not so high, but in the centre of this village the heat was almost unbearable.
SAN ANTONIO, Texas, June 30.--It is rumored that the San Antonio and Aransas Pass Railway has been sold out to the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Company by Messrs. Lott Kennedy.

Thirteen innings were required to determine the Brooklyn-Athletic game yesterday, and the Athletics won the contest by the close score of 4 to 3. It was an unusually fine exhibition of ball playing, and the 2,000 persons who witnessed the work heartily applauded the efforts of the contestants.

The hospital ship Illinois, which was recently moored at the Lower Quarantine Station, was towed up to Staten Island yesterday. Health Officer Smith stated that the vessel was leaking so badly that he could not take the re sponsibility of leaving her in the Lower Bay.

The first half of the year 1887 has closed with a most encouraging outlook for the business interests of the country. The failures recorded during the last six months numbered but 4,912, against 5,156 for the same period last year, and 6,004 for the ...

The American Section of the Social Labor Party hold a secret meeting last evening at 16 Clinton-place. F. Arnheim was re-elected a delegate to the Central Committee of the German Section. It was resolved to hold a special meeting on July 17, when the members will discuss ...

CHICAGO, June 30.--Creditors representing about $450,000 of the indebtedness of C.J. Kershaw Co., signed an agreement circulated on the floor of 'Change to-day to bear their pro rata of the expense of prosecuting suits to be brought against the insolvent house.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 30.--United States Attorney, Burnett to-day requested Commissioner Hooper to increase the bond of E.L. Harper, late Vice-President of the Fidelity National Bank, to ...
Charles Tucker, a clerk in the New-York Post Office, residing at No. 251 Marion-street, Brooklyn, writes:

Jay Gould and Russell Sage are indignant. They have a grievance. They think that Cyrus W. Field is not treating them right. He isn't grateful, they say, and he is altogether disregardful of the gospel that one good turn deserves another. Russell Sage voices the indignation and submits the grievance to THE TIMES in this way:

HANOVER, N.H., June 30.--The train today was literally packed with people in attendance upon the Commencement exercises of Dartmouth College. The college church was too small to accommodate the people who wished to witness the exercises. Gov. Sawyer and Council and members of the Legislature came up on a special train. At 8:30 o'clock there was an adjourned meeting of ...
READING, Penn., July 1.--William Steinmetz, a deaf old man, was struck by an up passenger train on the Pennsylvania Road this morning and instantly killed. The engineer repeatedly blew the Whistle.

A summons to the Directors' room of the Maritime Exchange, where matters of serious moment sometimes happen, surprised Assistant Superintendent Gideon N. Young and Janitor Edward Lindig at noon yesterday.
GETTYSBURG, Penn., July 1.--The Thirteenth New-Jersey Regiment dedicated its monument, which is situated near Spangler's Spring, on the right of the Federal line, to-day.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 1.--Reports from a large number of counties in East Tennessee indicate that the wheat crop this season is the largest raised for 20 years. The grain is of a very fine quality.
The drought in Illinois, Iowa, and Wisconsin is becoming very serious, and if copious rains do not fall soon crops will be lighter than in many years.

The race meeting at the Coney Island track will be brought to a close to-day, and seven excellent races are to be run. They are puzzlers to the tipster and will be to the man why wishes to bet and win.
CONSTANTINOPLE, July 1.--Mr. Straus, the United States Minister, presented his credentials to the Sultan to-day and was warmly received.
Sadie Daily, a pretty 16-year-old girl, living with her widowed mother at 116 Berrystreet, Williamsburg, has been reported missing. The girl left the house at an early hour on ...
MADISON, Ind., July 1.--Mary, wife of Capt. Samuel Caplinger, Sr., fell dead of apoplexy to-night aged 62 years. Her husband is speechless from paralysis.

Three months ago, when it became known that Mr. E. Henry Lacombe was likely soon to relinquish the office of Counsel to the Corporation, Mayor Hewitt asked Mr. Morgan J. O'Brien if he would accept an appointment to the expected vacancy. Mr. O'Brien answered in the negative.
MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa, July 1.--In yesterday's races, Pathfinder, in starting, was badly driven, and it looked as if it was to keep Bob M. from the pole.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 1--W.D. Gatchel, proprietor of the photographers' supply business, at 328 West Jefferson-street, made an assignment for the benefit of his creditors this morning. Mr. Gatchel said that he was pulled down by the break of the Fidelity Bank, of Cincinnati.

The annual tournament of the Brooklyn Hill Lawn Tennis Club was Commenced on their ground at Ryerson-street, Brooklyn, yesterday. There was a good attendance of the Prospect Heights fashionables. The score was as follows:

CHICAGO, July 1.--Deliveries on the Board of Trade to-day were neither heavy nor light enough to make any perceptible effect on the market. There was no sign of a panic. The wheat deliveries ag gregated between 5,000,000 and 6,000,000 bushels, Corn deliveries were light and little was done in pork.
A car fitted up with a Julien electric motor, the power being furnished by Julien storage batteries, made several trips on the Fourth-avenue street railroad yesterday and the evening before.
POUGHKEEPSIE, July 1.--The racing at the Hudson River Driving Park closed to-day. The following are the results of the day's sport:
Ex-Corporation Counsel E. Henry Lacombe took the oath of office as United States Circuit Judge yesterday morning, in the Federal Building, in Room 40, where, July 8, he will begin to hear cases.

Sir Cyrus W. Field went calling yesterday, all in the early morn. He had read THE TIMES, (as, of course, being a good man, he always does,) and a few brief remarks of Deacon Russell Sage chronicled therein had toned his system up. And toward Deacon Sage's office he made a vigorous way.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 1.--The little village of Otisville, seven miles west of here, is greatly exercised over the appearance of malignant diphtheria in the town. Two children of Henry L. Craus died yesterday, and two others are not expected to live. There is so much excitement that the public school has been abruptly closed.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 1.--Three of the Ravenna gang, Who slew Detective Hulligan and left Police Captain Hoehr for dead while rescuing their prisoner, are safely lodged in jail here.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 1.--Today, being Dominion Day, was observed throughout Canada as a general holiday. Picnics, excursions, military reviews, processions, and outdoor sports were the order of the day. Business was entirely suspended.

Custom House Officer Hillbrandt, who represents Collector Magone at Castle Garden, detained three Cornish miners who arrived yesterday on the Inman steamship City of Chester on the ground that they came under the provisions of the contract labor law.
The Dwyer Brothers sold a number of their racers at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday, Col. Bruce acting as auctioneer. The animals sold, purchasers, and prices paid are as follows:

READINO, Penn., July 1.--The 2,000 employes of the Reading Iron Works this afternoon informed the management that they would not accept the reduction of 10 per cent. made recently, and the proprietors decided to close all the establishments, throwing all the men out of work.

The committee of the Common Council of Long Island City appointed to investigate the charges made by Mayor Gleason, to the effect that bribery was used in obtaining the contract for cleaning the streets of the First Ward, met last evening.

Mr. Adolf Neuendorf's operetta, the "Ratcatcher of Hamelin." was produced at Mr. Amberg's Terrace Garden last evening in the presence of an audience that was surprisingly large considering the extremely unfavorable condition of the weather.

The Cutting case yesterday provoked several incidents quite in keeping with the weather. After some humdrum testimony before Referee Cole in the morning Lawyer Zabriskie opened the dance by drawing from his pocket two little slips of paper, purporting to be ...

As a down train on the Third-avenue elevated railroad was passing Eleventh-street about 9:30 last night the cylinder head of the engine was blown out, and a large section of the cylinder fell into the street, accompanied by a shower of bolts and pieces of iron, which were scattered over the sidewalk and pavement.

BOSTON, July 1.--As some of the early risers in Newport noticed rather a peculiarity in the formation of the North Atlantic, squadron as it passed out of the harbor and commented thereupon, a word of explanation will put the matter in its proper light.
The closing exercises of the female department of the cathedral school, in East Fiftieth-street, were held yesterday, afternoon in the school hall.

WASHINGTON, July 1.--The President has appointed Julius T. Conrad, of Washington, son of Col. Conrad, of the army, and John M. Palmer, grandson of ex-Gov. Palmer, of Illinois, to be cadets at large at the West Point Military Academy.

CHICAGO, July 1.--A large meeting of the creditors of Rosenfeld Co. was held in the call board room this morning to hear the report of the committee appointed to obtain a proposition for settlement from the insolvent house.

The closing exercises of the primary department at the Vandewater-street school, which official lists call Grammar School No. 1, passed off yesterday with the success always to be expected of an event that appeals to a large constituency in the Fourth Ward.

Surrogate Rollins ended the protracted contest against the probate of the will of William Darling. Professor of Anatomy in the medical department of the University of the City of New-York, by rendering a decision yesterday admitting the instrument as a legally made and valid will. So Amelia Delacroix, of Yonkers.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 1.--The better element of the permanent colored residents of West Grove, the negro settlement west of Asbury Park, do not uphold the speakers at the indignation meeting of Monday night.

"Sunday laws or no Sunday laws," and "the price of beer by the pint" were warmly debated by about a dozen saloon keepers and liquor dealers of the Seventeenth Ward yesterday afternoon at Hertzog's Hall, on East Fifthstreet.

At the Colwell Iron Works, at the foot of West Twenty-seventh-Street, was standing yesterday the new diffusion battery which Mr. Colwell has had under construction for some time past for the United States Government.
Arnold Co., who failed for $763,000 during the coffee crash, have so far advanced in settlements with their creditors that they will apply for reinstatement in the Coffee Exchange next week.

On behalf of the Brooklyn--Elevated Railroad Company William J. Gaynor yesterday obtained an injunction from Judge Clement, in the City Court of Brooklyn, prohibiting the sale of the property of the defendant for unpaid taxes ...

A rather serious collision occurred about 4:15 o'clock yesterday afternoon between the New-Jersey Central ferryboat Elizabeth and the Castle Garden transfer boat George Starr.

There has again been trouble on the Forty-second-Street and Boulevard Railroad. On Monday last all the jigger cars that ran between the station in Forty-second-street near Fourth-avenue and Fort Lee Ferry were ...
