Considering the weather there was some suprise on Wall-street yesterday over notices that J.A. Kohn Co., stock brokers at 19 Broad-street, had dissolved partnership. Kohn Co. were commonly regarded as a more or less happy family Mr. Kohn, the senior member, ...

The business of the Inter-State Commerce Commission must be in a very backward and confused state, according to the following Washington dispatch to the Evening Post. Perhaps, however, it is only the Post that is confused:
A happy combination of circumstances makes the ever-glorious Fourth come on Monday this year. This places it immediately after Sunday, which is preceded by the Saturday half holiday.

The Commissioners of Public Charities and Correction yesterday made awards for supplies for the next two weeks. The evidence given at the investigation of the Ward's Island Asylum, it was thought, might possibly influence ...

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 1.--The new track of the Niagara Falls Racing Association will be opened to-morrow. There are 170 horses on the track and good sport is expected. Following are the probable starters in to-morrow's races:

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 1.--Albert Turner, colored, one of the murderers of Jennie Bowman, was hanged at 6:32 this morning. Only 50 people were admitted to the yard, but about 2,000 assembled in the vicinity of the place as early as 4:30 o'clock. During the prayer, which immediately preceded the fall of the trap, ...
Capt. J.H. Coster, Secretary of the Monmouth Park Association, to-day announces the weights for the Fourth of July Handicap, to be run at Monmouth Park next Monday afternoon.

CHICAGO, July 1.--A gang of non-union dock laborers engaged in loading the schooner St. Lawrence were set upon this afternoon by a number of members of the Seamon's Union, and a pitched battle between the two factions ensued.
With the opening of the new fiscal year yesterday, the annual appropriation made by Congress for army transportation becomes available for the transfer of troops.
The retirement from the House of Commons of the Irish Home Rulers and of all the English Home Rulers but two is an innovation in Parliamentary procedure.
In lovely weather and with a good attendance the second day's play in the cricket match, Canada against New-York, was commenced on the ground at Seabright, N.J., yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 1.--Adelaid D. Parent, the absconding Cashier of the Hochelaga Bank, of Montreal, Canada, was indicted by the Cook County Grand Jury to-day. He brought the proceeds of his thefts to Illinois, and is therefore ...
A large meeting of representatives of the Brush, Thompson-Houston, United States, Jenney, American, and other electric light systems was held at the Hotel Albemarle on Thursday to ...

Mrs. Adolph Walters was sitting on the steps of her home at 140 Johnson-avenue, Brooklyn, yeaterday afternoon, when a neatly dressed woman carrying a baby stepped up to her and asked her to hold the baby while the ...

Capt. Michael Cregan is no longer a member of the Republican County Committee, although he still has whatever consolation there may be in being an enrolled Republican in the Sixteenth Assembly District, in which for over 17 years he has been a leader. The Committee on Contested, Seats presented a report recognizing the anti-Cregan faction at last night's meeting of the County Committee, and it was adopted.
John Keenan, the oldest man in Newark, died yesterday, at the age 102 years and 2 months. He was born in Ireland and came to this country many years ago. He leaves two sons, both old men.

At last the Chinese are undertaking the construction of railways. But it does not appear that foreign syndicates are to profit by the changed attitude of the Government. In Map last there was issued a decree sanctioning the building of railroads north of the Pei-Ho River in the province which contains the great city of Pekin.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., July 1.--Fifteen or twenty young men at Yale University six months ago foreswore alcohol, tobacco, the delights of late hours, the blandishments of society, and the comfort of toothsome dishes, and gave themselves up to seeking strength in the gymnasium.
PORTLAND, Me., July 1.--The Hon. Bion Bradbury died this afternoon, aged 75. He leaves a widow, two sons, and three daughters.
The final games in the Prospect Park lawn tennis tourney were played yesterday. J. W. Raymond won the first class singles, C. Fransioli the second class singles, H. Fransioli the ...

The striking foundrymen and machinists on the Delamater Iron Works held another meeting yesterday at Caledonia Hall and received a communication from the men employed in the blacksmith's shop saying that they too would go out on strike.

MINDEN, La., July 1.--Information was received last night that three of the negroes engaged in the Morehouse riot had passed across the four parishes intervening and were near this point traveling on foot on their way to Texas.
BALTIMORE, July 1.--The weekly circular to be issued to-morrow by John A. Hambleton Co., bankers, who frequently have confidential business relations with the Garretts, will contain the following:

MASCOUTAH, Ill., July 1.--A steam thrashing machine exploded this morning on the farm of John Barth, three miles southeast of here, killing two men and wounding four. The dead are John Plab and James Dumond.

A special meeting of the Atlantic Yacht Club was held at the clubhouse, at Bay Ridge, on Thursday evening. The sum of $1,000 was appropriated, to be used for prizes to be sailed for while on the annual cruise under the direction of Commodore Swan.

Through the leniency of S. Gruner Co. ex-Mayor Edson, Chairman of the Grain Committee of the Produce Exchange, and his associates were relieved yesterday of the necessity of defending themselves in the appeal case which the dissatisfied firms who carried short interests on June wheat intended to take before the Governing Committee.

The course of Mr. HEWITT in the selection of the Corporation Counsel has been unworthy of a statesman of his pretensions and is calculated to seriously shake the confidence of the people of New-York in his sagacity, consistency, and good faith.
AUGUSTA, Me., July 1.--There is no preceptible change in ex-Gov. Morrill's condition to-night.

GARDEN CITY, Kan., July 1.--In February last an enumeration was taken to fix the temporary county seat of Merton County, Kan. The enumeration reported favorably to Richfield, and Gov. Martin designated that town as the county seat, appointing temporary officers.

The pool of wall paper manufacturers, formed seven years ago, came to an end yesterday in a failure to renew the agreement. There are about 35 wall paper manufactories in the United States, situated mainly in New-York, Philadelpdia, Brooklyn, and Buffalo.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1.--James A.L., Wilson, the defaulter, who helped Henry V. Lesley to steal $600,000 from the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal Company, is in Moyamensing Prison. After a year's absence in Canada Wilson came back to the city this morning in charge of Detective Peter Miller.

The temperature yesterday continued its aspirations for the lofty. At Hudnut's, where a thirsty crowd besieged the soda counter all day, the thermometer scored very much the same as on Thursday, reaching the highest, 95 , at 3:30 o'clock. This was the same as the day previous.

It is not surprising that we should receive the following note from Dr. Storrs in reply to our suggestion of last week. It is natural for him to feel as he does about occupying the high and responsible position for which his name was mentioned.
READING, Penn., July 1.--Peter Resch, a single man, who had been afflicted with fever and ague and could not sleep at night, procured a package of "Rough on Rats" last evening.

Although there were only five races on the card for the extra day at the Coney Island Jockey Club's meeting yesterday, there was a good crowd to see them run. Such as went to the track saw very fine races run, and the finish between Dry Monopole and Elkwood in the Ives Stakes was well worth the time and trouble taken to visit the track.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1.--The exports of wheat from Philadelphia for June amounted to 1,317,253 bushels, as compared with 207,292 bnshels in 1886. For the six months ended June 30, 1887, the total was 5,014,625 bushels, against 1,408,449 bushels during the same period last year.
DANVILLE, Ky., July 1.--A few weeks ago Ben Reeder, of this city, was awakened from sleep by a rat running across his body. The animal made a savage attack upon him, fastening its teeth in his nose.

OMAHA, Neb., July 1.--Before the Pacific Railway Investigating Commission to-day Edward Rosewater, editor of the Omaha Bee, testified that it has been for years the practice of the United States Marshal for Nebraska and his ...
SANDUSKY, Ohio, July 1.--George J. Anderson, Vice President of the Third National Bank of this city, committed suicide to-day by shooting himself.

VALPARAISO, Ind., July 1.--An interesting point of law has been decided in the Porter Circuit Court, viz., that a city cannot discharge an official employe without a trial C.W. Estelle made himself obnoxious to the gamblers and ...

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 1.--There are five sureties on the twenty-five-thousand-dollar bond which secured the release of Nathaniel Sands from jail yesterday, each of them qualifying in the sum of $5,000.
WASHINGTON, July 1.--The accounts of the Government were to-day balanced for the year. The showing is interesting as well as important.
SARATOGA, N.Y., July 1.--In the Court of Appeals to-day the following business was transacted:

BALTIMORE, July 1.--Mrs. Barbara Airey committed suicide last night by swallowing laudanum. There had been trouble between herself and husband, and she took the drug last night and retired. Her husband returned at midnight and went to bed ignorant that his wife was then dead.
The affairs of the American Cotton Oil Trust, as reported at the annual meeting yesterday, show a capitalization of $41,706,000, represented by mills, products, and securities.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 1.--The Board of Visitors of the University of Virginia adjourned today after accepting the resignations of Prof. Page, of the Agriculture Department, and Prof. Wheeler, of the chair of Greek. Ex-Lieut.-Gov. Marye was appointed Rector, vice the Hon. A.H.H. Stuart, resigned.
LONDON, July 1.--The steamship Etruria, (Br.,) Capt. Cook, from Nex-York June 25, for Liverpool, passed Brow Head at 8:O5 P.M. to-day.
Commodore Gherardi returned to the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday from Washington with power to spend $100,000 on improvements before election day.

CITY OF MEXICO, July 1, via Galveston, --A mangnificent banquet was given to-day by the Mercantile Confederation of the republic in honor of the success of the financial policy of Senor Manuel Dublan, Minister of the Treasury.
Assemblyman Ives, the father of the Pool bill, restoring pool selling on the race courses, is a regular attendant at the races, and especially at Sheepshead Bay.
KEY WEST, July 1.--Dr. Guieteras has arrived here from Savannah, sent here by Surgeon-General Hamilton to diagnose the existing fever.

Second Assistant Fire Chief McCabe returned to active duty yesterday without ceremony, a year lacking four days from the date when he ordered the memorable three sixes for the Harlem Fourth of July fire.
CHICAGO, July 1.--The American Cottonseed Oil Trust Company held its annual meeting here to-day and elected John Scott, John Bloodgood, J.V. Lewis, J.L. McAulay, and E. Urquhart as Trustees.
The final report of the commission appointed some time ago to lay out new rapid transit routes is wholly in the interest of the monopoly which now controls the elevated railroad system.

The pretty little town of Chatham, up in the hills of Morris County, N.J., on the line of the Morris and Essex branch of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, was startled, yesterday morning by the report that John Wilson, a laboring man, had killed his wife after attempting to shoot his daughter, Maggie Kane, and had then blown out his own brains.
ORDWAY, Dakota, July 1.--The June crop report of the Territorial Statistician is less favorable than that for May. Hot winds have injured the crops in places.

UTICA, N.Y., July 1.--William Lent, for 27 years engaged in the baggage and mail transfer business at the Central station in this city, dropped dead after dinner to-day from the bursting of a blood vessel in his head. His age was 64. Few men along the line of the road were more favorably known to the traveling public.
KINGSTON, Ontario, July 1.--During a fireworks display here this evening Joseph Thompson, a printer, was hit by a rocket and instantly killed.

LONDON, July 1.--The Athens Plate, for 2-yearolds, was run for at the Windsor meeting to-day, and won by Mr. E. Jones's br. c. Admiral Benbow, who defeated four others, including the favorite, Toscano, who finished last. Variety was second and Mon Droit third. The betting was 4 to 1 against Admiral Benbow, and 11 to 10 on Toscano.

Some people and papers profess to see signs of malice in the little passage between Drs. Evarts and Depew at Yale on Wednesday. It is all invention and a perverting of the mere overflow of good humor.

DANVILLE, Va., July 1.--The sales of leaf tobacco in this market for June were 3,702,716 pounds, at an average of $9.11 per hundred. The total sales to date since October are 21,070,416 pounds, at an average of $8.68. The sales for the same time last year were 30,052,886 pounds.

For years the building which was Gen. Meade's headquarters at the battle of Gettysburg has borne a sign inscribed "Mead's Headquarters." Many futile efforts have been made to induce the association to correct the spelling.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 1.--New-York won an easy victory to-day in a dull and spiritless game. Only eight innings were played, owing to a delay of 45 minutes on account of rain at the end of the third inning, which made ...
C.V.V. Ward, for 17 years the Eastern Division Passenger Agent in this city of the Erie Railway, resigned his position yesterday.

LONDON, July 1.--In the House of Lords this evening, in the report stage of the Irish Land bill, the Earl of Dunraven said that there were 300 amendments waiting, which might almost recast the bill, many of the provisions of which derogated from the main object of the measure.
CHICAGO, July 1.--The races were run here to-day with the following results:
The patriotic citizens of Harlem, in Independence Day Association assembled, last evening adopted an elaborate programme for the celebration of the coming Fourth.

Since Jacob Sharp was committed to Ludlow-Street Jail the buckwheat cake has taken rank among the consolations. Nothing else has any power to tempt the appetite of the fallen millionaire. Yesterday morning a quar tet of them, steaming, brown, and redolent of that odor of musty hay which is the buckwheat cake's greatest pride, came hot from the hands of the jail cook.

During the six months ending June 30, there were reported at the Bureau of Vital Statistics 19,312 deaths, 15,442 births, and 6,584 marriages, showing an inerease of 1,731 deaths, 439 births, and 814 marriages as compared with the figures of the first six months of 1886.

Room 13 City Hall was overcrowded yesterday morning when Commissioners Craig and Milhau, of the State Board of Charities, resumed their investigation of affairs at the City Insane Asylum on Ward's Island.

Everybody has heard of the Luray Caverns, and those who have not visited them have a treat in store. To be transferred from the stifling atmosphere of a hot July day to a region of grottoes, beyond the influence of the blazing sun and filled with subterranean marvels, is but one of the charms of a visit to this noted resort.

CHICAGO, July 1.--A sensation was caused this afternoon by the information that a dynamite bomb, with the fuse burned to within a quarter of an inch of the shell, was found by Judge Baker under his desk in the Criminal Court last Tuesday.

CHICAGO, July 1.--Mr. Holland, of the firm of Holland Johnson, was killed this afternoon while fixing an electric fan. Whether by accident or carelessness he laid hold of the wires and received the all force of the electric charge.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 1.--Drafts on NewYork--Sight, 22 cents; telegraphic, 30 cents.

It was learned yesterday from Rowland R. Hazard, who is interested in the New-York Underground Railway Company, that the new Rapid Transit Commission appointed by Mayor Hewitt on Thursday, about which some mystery seems to have been made, has been organized to change portions of the routes of that road.

WASHINGTON, July 1.--An examination which has been made of the accounts of the late Levi Bacon, financial clerk of the Interior Department, who died on June 22, reveals a deficiency of $28,000 in his accounts.

It is strange that the colored people of the North have not taken hold of this color question in a practical way. It cannot be pleasant to be treated as inferiors and submit to unreasoning prejudices. Of course, the color line will be obliterated in time, and even Asbury Park will...

A burglar raided the grocery store of Henry Lubbe at 3 o'clock yesterday morning. Merchant Policeman Kearney came up while the burglar was unlocking the door, but supposing it was one of the clerks made no effort to arrest him. The burglar talked to him and asked him to come in, and after he had gone finished his work. Only some small change was secured.
BISMARCK, Dakota, July 2.--The heaviest rains since June, 1885, have been falling almost without intermission since last midnight, doing untold good to crops, which now promise heavy yield.

Arthur W. Roudier, a slim, bronzed young Frenchman, formerly Venezuelan Consul at Boston, who a few days ago returned from Panama, where he sojourned for one year as official translator to the Societe des Travaux Publiques et Construction, and stationmaster to the Panama Railway, is very vigorous in his de termination never to return to that country.

One of the most successful racing meetings over held at the beautiful track of the Coney Island Jockey Club, at Sheepshead Bay, was brought to a close yesterday afternoon. Seven races were run, and, with the exception of the last one, all of them furnished exciting and close finishes.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, July 2.--The Con-, stitutional Convention of 75 delegates has been in session here since last Thursday. The Constitution adopted in 1882 is made the basis of the new Constitution.
CHARLESTON, S.C., July 2.--For some days the air has been filled with alarming rumors of race troubles in Fairview Township, Greenville County.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 2.--Halsey Gaines, aged 15 years, had his scalp partially torn off and one arm deeply lacerated this morning by a leopard in one of Barnum's cages. The lad climbed up on the leopard's cage and was peering in when the brute tried to drag him inside. He was only saved by the efforts of one of the trainers.

The Clerk of Dinwiddie County, Va., last week received from James Abbott. New-Jersey, for record, a deed of conveyance of two and three-quarter acres of land lying about a mile west of Petersburg, the consideration for which, as named in the deed, was $148,000.
As a general thing the colored ministers are a hard-working, zealous, and poorly sustained class.
The proverb "Strong as the Pont Neuf" will undoubtedly have to be erased without mercy from the French language and relegated to some museum of old-fashioned or obsolete phrases.
NEWPORT, R. I., July 2.--The steamer Providence, of the Old Colony Line, which has been ashore on Dyer's Island in Narragansett Bay for the past 10 days, was floated at high water this afternoon.

Charles Hamilton and William Butler, of 20 Adam-street, Newark, were engaged in put ting ice into Condit's beef refrigerator at East Orange, yesterday afternoon, when a wooden skid fell upon them. Hamilton's neck was broken. Butler's injuries are so severe that his recovery is not looked for.
There was a very large audience present at Terrace Garden last evening to witness the performance of Milloecker's "Der-Feldprediger" by Manager Amberg's company.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 2.--At a meeting of the Yale Crew to-day Frederic A. Stevenson, '88, of tis city, was elected Captain for the season of 1888. In his Freshman year Stevenson was on his class crew and class football team, and has played a number of games with the university eleven. He has been in the university boat race in the past two races and is a good oarsman.

EL PASO, Texas, July 2.--Heavy earthquakes continue at Bavispe, in the Mexican State of Sonora, 250 miles southwest of this place. J.J. Deaver, a miner, one of half a dozon Americans there, has just arrived here, and brings the first detailed and authentic report of the earthquakes.
Jacob Roberts, aged 60 years, was overcome by the heat in Newark yesterday and died last night at the city hospital.
Ignatius Donnelly was at the Merchants' yesterday, departing in the evening for his home at Nininger. He has just returned from attending the funeral of his gifted mother at Philadelphia.

Krebs is held at a station for a medical examination of his mental condition.

ALBANY, July 2.--Bank Superintendent Willis S. Paine has issued his official certificate authorizing the Farmers and Mechanics' Bank of Fort Plain to transact a general banking business under the State laws, with paid-up capital stock of $50,000. One hundred and three banks of deposit and discount are now engaged in active business under the State laws.

The schooner Hattie Ellen, of Fall River, went swordfishing Monday. Tan miles southeast of Brenton's Reef Lightship the crew struck a very, lively fish, which came near ending the fishing career of one of their number. LONDON, July 2.--Young Mr. Balfour, with his single eyeglass and Oxford drawl, lightheartedly steers the ship of state along. The sun is shining brightly, the water is calm and crystalline, and he is not impressed by the fact that he is in a hurricane latitude, or that a shark is following grimly in the vessel's wake.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 2.--The Americus, of Bridgeport, won the yacht race this afternoon over the Cruiser, of Larchmont. The Americus crossed the starting line at 10:45:11; and the Cruiser followed at 10:50:02.
A large number of city people left yesterday to escape the noise of the coming national explosion of firecrackers, and to enjoy for a few days or longer the liberty of rural life.

DENVER, Col., July 2.--The case of ex-Gov. Gilpin against his wife for a divorce on the ground of cruelty, which was on trial for two weeks, was concluded yesterday, the jury returning a verdict for the plaintiff.

BATH, Me., July 2.--Michael Donohue, 22 years old, an employe of Shaw's mill, left his boarding place last evening to bathe in the river. He took with him a 7-year-old son of George Brown. They were both drowned while bathing.

FORT SMITH, Ark., July 2.--A Deputy Marshal arrived yesterday from Children's Station, Cherokee Nation, having in custody a 14-year-old boy named George Smith, who is charged with the murder of a 10-year-old girl named Mareha Shaw on Sunday last. He does not deny the killing, but claims it was an accident. He shot her in the breast, killing her instantly.

There were two pretty trotting matches on the track of the Yonkers Driving Park yesterday afternoon. The first was for the 2:40 class, for a purse of $200, divided as folllows: $100 to first, $50 to second, $30 to third, and $20 to fourth. There were eight starters.

PARIS, June 17.--I have recently returned from the village of Domremy, and this is the anniversary of the birth 69 years ago of Charles Gounod. I mention these two circumstances together for reasons that will explain themselves as we proceed.

John Donovan, a laborer on the Erie Railroad docks, living at 171 Tenth-street, Jersey City, last night knocked his wife down and kicked her, rupturing an artery in her abdomen. The woman was taken to St. Francis's Hospital in a dying condition. Donovan was arrested.
The Rev. Maurice Wheldon Jones, M.A., of Wales, will preach at Calvary Chapel, in East Twenty-third-street, to-day.

The match race between Garult and Queen Wilkes for $10,000, which was to have been trotted at Charter Oak Park, Hartford, Conn., on Monday, has been postponed until Saturday next. Weather permitting, the two will meet then in a race that should be exciting and well contested.

Are the seasons in very fact changing or have our poets through successive generations beguiled us with pictures of a delusive and non-existent Spring? When Thomson wrote "The Seasons" (published in 1728) May 1 fell on May 12 as we now record it and his May 21 on June 1.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 2.--The Irish National League of this city tendered a reception to the Earl of Aberdeen, ex-Viceroy of Ireland, who arrived here yesterday from the Texas Pan Handle.

SHELBY, Ill., July 2.--The Rev. Howard Miller, Pastor of the Methodist Episcopal church at Camden, this county, has lost his mind and wandered away from home. He preached to his congregation last Sunday as usual. No special reason is known for the loss of his mind. He was transferred here from the Quincy District, Illinois Conference, last year.
DRAYTON, Ontario, July 2.--The commercial union gathering here to-day in Hambly's Grove was a magnificent success. It was largely composed of farmers, many of whom came from a great distance.

BOSTON, July 2.--The Hull Yacht Club sailed its sixty-second regatta this afternoon off the clubhouse, and the races, as usual, were very successful.

MONTREAL, July 2.--A fashionably dressed young fellow, resembling a university student, was arrestod to-day on a charge of forgery and fraud preferred by Mr. Iles, manager of the Windsor Hotel. He lived high, spent lots of money, and entertained like a lord.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 2.--A decision just handed down by the Court of Appeals, in the case of the people against Charles Kibler, of Buffalo, is regarded as of great importance. The defendant was indicted for selling milk adulterated with water.
LONDON, July 2.--The Queen to-day reviewed 50,000 London volunteers in front of Buckingham Palace. The weather was clear and warm.
CHICAGO, July 2.--The first annual regatta of the Chicago Navy will be held at Pullman Monday. All races will be one and onehalf miles except the canoe and barge.

BOSTON, July 2.--A large quantity of fireworks was taken out on the afternoon Cape Ann train from Boston to-day for cities and towns on the line. While unloading some at Beverly an explosion occurred, which net fire to the baggage car, partially burning it, together with a quantity of express goods and valuable baggage belonging to North Shore Summer residents. The loss was about $2,500.
The second annual regatta of the NewBochelle Yacht Club was sailed on the beautiful course of the organization yesterday, and was a thorough success in every respect.
The biggest missionary enterprise on record has been accomplished by the Rev. George Muller, founder of a preaching tour tol, who has just returned from a preaching tour round the world.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, June 29.--Lastnight, as Louis Klafter and Miss Julia Frankle were being married in the synagogue, the bride's long veil was set afire by an attendant holding a wax candle. Great excitement prevailed for a short time. For an instant flames enveloped the head of the bride. She was but slightly injured.

Thomas Reilly, a tinker, living at 382 First-street, Jersey City, became drunk and quarrelsome on Friday night. James McGarry had been his friend, but that fact did not prevent Reilly from offering to fight him. McGarry was not in a quarrelsome humor and he avoided the drunken man.
LONDON, July 2.--In the Parliamentary election to fill the vacancy in the Spalding division of Lincolnshire the Gladstonians have gained seat.
Collector Magone has amended an order in regard to bullion which has worked much inconvenience of late. The order was provoked by the petty smuggling of a few gold watches in packages of bullion.

He says he will strictly enforce the law prohibiting this.

NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario, June 30.--Col. C.S. Gzowski, Chairman of the Queen Victoria Niagara Falls Park Commission, accompanied by Commissioners J.W. Langmuir and J.G. McDonald, all of Toronto, arrived this afternoon.

The Canadian cricketers sailed for Great Britain yesterday on the Anchor steamship Furnessia. A large delegation of the cricket men of New-York and vicinity took leave of the Canadians on the deck of the steamer and wished them good luck during their tour. The team comprises 18 men, all of whom are hopeful of doing successful work abroad. Their first match will be at Dublin.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 2.--July opens well for Newport from a watering-place standpoint. Nearly all the Summer residents have arrived and are comfortably settled for the season, and are about ready to engage in the fashionable gayeties which are being arranged.
ST. JOHNSBURY, Vt., July 2.--The Hon. Luke P. Poland died at his residence in Waterville to-day of apoplexy.

CUMBERLAND, Md., July 2.--One of the stubbornest cases of litigation in the history of the state is nearing an end here. It is all on account of a lease on a farm worth $200, which has postponed the completion of a railroad for eight months. The farm has been constantly guarded by a force as many as 200 men, and the warfare has cost thousands of dollars to both sides.

LOCK HAVEN, Penn., July 2.--The country around the headwaters of Pine Creek, in Lycoming County, is wild and sparsely settled, being covered with deep pine forests. Here and there, scattered about in the region is an isolated farm or clearing, but the main dependence of the small population is lumbering. Wild animals are still numerous in the section, and life in the lumbar camps is varied frequently by exciting bear hunts.

COLUMBUS, Neb., July 2.--The Pacific Railway Investigating Commission heard a number of witnesees this morning. CHICAGO, July 3.--Dispatches to-night from many points in Northern and Central Illinois and Southern Wisconsin indicate the prevalence of a general heavy rain to-day, which broke the dry spell and had a very beneficial effect upon crops of all kinds. Mr. Wood soon began to make the acquaintance of the people and impressed all favorably. He was elected a member of the Grantland Club and was soon the leading society man of Griffin.

CHARLESTON, West Va., July 4.--Yesterday afternoon Lolly Robinson, colored, shot and killed Charles Williams, colored, at Caperton. The trouble grew out or Williams's intimacy with Robinson's wife. FITCHBURG, Mass., July 4.--Ninety passengers on a horse car became panic-stricken to-day because the driver lost control of the horses. Some jumped and some were pushed from the car to the rocks below. Marian O'Brien, aged 30, was almost instantly killed; Mary O'Hara struck on her head and was rendered unconscious; Ellen McCarty had her collar bone and an ankle broken, and several others were badly hurt. The car did not leave the track.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, July 4.--William Muldoon and the Jap, Matsada Sorakichi, wrestled three bouts, Graeco-Roman style, at the fair grounds here this afternoon for a purse of $500. MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 5.--"I am to-day as good a Catholic as the Pope," said Dr. Edward McGlynn to-day, as he read the newspaper dispatch announcing his excommunication. "I believe in all the teachings and sacraments of the church, but I do not believe that the Pope has the right to forbid me to express my convictions on social questions."

GARDINER, Me., July 5.--A mail train going east and a local passenger train going west on the Maine Central Railroad came into collision this forenoon at Farmingdale siding, owing to the failure of the air brakes on the mail train to hold. Both engines were badly smashed, and the tender of the mail train was telescoped into the postal car.

PORTLAND, Me., July 5.--Prof. Charles H. Grinely, accompanied by a newspaper reporter, made a balloon ascension from Lincoln Park yesterday. At the height of 3,000 feet the balloon struck a westerly current and was carried swiftly out to sea.

LONDON, July 5.--The race for the July Stakes at Newmarket to-day was won by three-quarters of a length by Sir F. Johnston's ch.c. Friar's Balsam, by Hermit, out of Flower of Dorset. Sea Breeze was second, Chillington third, and Lunan fourth. Friar's Balsam was the favorite in the betting at 9 to 4 on.

WASHINGTON, July 5.--The one hundred and forty-ninth call for $19,716,000 3 per cent. bonds matured on the 1st inst. Since then $15,512,600 of the bonds have been redeemed by the Treasury Department, leaving $4,204,900 of that call still outstanding. Of the bonds redeemed $11,000,000 had been deposited with the United States Treasurer to secure national bank circulation.

Christina Creig, the wife of Charles Creig, who keeps a saloon at 109 Greene-street, on Monday evening retired to her room over the saloon, removed her clothing, lay down on her bed, and shot herself in the breast with a pistol, causing death.

CHICAGO, Ill., July 5.--Roscoe Conkling arrived here to-day. In regard to the report that he was to make a speech at the Grant Club Thursday evening he said: "I shall not make a speech to the club. I was invited to visit the club as a guest and was distinctly told that no addresses would be made.

WHEELING, West Va., July 5.--At daybreak this morning about two dozen employes of the Crescent Iron Works of this city seized a fellow-workman named William Floding, and, attaching a rope to a traveling crane in the mill, swung him up to it as a punishment for whipping his wife yesterday.

BERLIN, July 5.--The Emperor of Germany has arrived at Ems, accompanied by Count Lesendorff. He was driven in an open carriage through Bahnhaus-strasse to the Kurhaus. The Bahnhaus-strasse was gayly decorated, and throughout the drive the Emperor was everywhere greeted with the most enthusiastic cheers.
Four children of Mrs. Nellie Sullivan, a widow, living in Fourth-street, near Grovestreet, Jersey City, were taken sick at the dinner table on Monday. They had eaten some corned beef and green peas.

The reorganization plan of the Custom House is likely to go into effect within a week. Delay has been due to the work necessary in order to prepare the lists for the various divisions. COTTAGE CITY, Mass., July 5.--A patient and persistent search has satisfied the Brooklyn pilgrims that clams no longer grow in this vicinity. Clam chowder grows here and all around here, but a reward of $50 offered for the first clam found in chowder is yet hung up.

The Board of Aldermen of Long Island City adopted last evening the minority report of the special committee which had been investigating the charges of bribery made by Mayor Gleason against James Stafford and several Aldermen in connection with the awarding of a contract for cleaning the streets.

A deliberate murder was committed early last evening on the corner of Second-avenue and Thirty-eighth-street and the murderer escaped. The victim of the murder was Joseph Quinn, a respectable young man, who for nine years past has been employed at the Cotton Exchange.

MOUNT WASHINGTON, N.H., July 5.--Theodore Leavitt, of Boston, fell 120 feet in the mountains to-day, and still lives to tell the tale, although terribly injured. With two companions he went on a trip to the "Gulf of Mexico" ravine, a wild gully 1,200 feet long, and even at this season of the year filled with snow.

SAUGATUCK, Conn., July 5.--John Marples, a planemaker, employed by Martin Doscher, was drowned to-day near Cockenoes Island while bathing. He was unable to swim and waded beyond his depth. His companions who were with him swam to his assistance, but he sank when they were some distance off.

NIAGARA FALLS, July 5.--There was a regular dump for the betting men here to-day in the opening race at six furlongs, when the old campaigner Barnum was beaten by Brait, a Canadian horse, who sold for $5 in the pools to $30 for Barnum and $6 for the field of five others.

LONDON, July 5.--In the House of Lords this afternoon Lord Salisbury announced that the Anglo-Turkish Convention in reference to Egypt had not been ratified by Turkey, and that Sir Henry Drummond Wolff, the special British Commissioner, had been instructed to leave Constantinople.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 5.--Dr. C.B. Cone, who has kept a "health movement" and gymnasium in the Union Block, was arrested this morning on a charge of incendiarism. At midnight last night fire was discovered in his office, but the firemen prevented ...

PHILADELPHIA, July 5.--William Turl, a bookkeeper for the firm of J.J. Seeds Co., who trade under the name of the Philadelphia Union Hat Company, with headquarters at Eighth and Vine streets, has disappeared with about $4,000 belonging to the company.

Gen. Alexander Shaler still claims that his removal from the office of President of the Board of Health was illegal, and his counsel, Messrs. Root Strong, yesterday obtained from Judge Potter, who is holding Supreme Court, Chambers, a writ of certiorari, commanding ...
The case of Dr. McGLYNN is very pitiable. Whatever faults or follies he may have committed are amply expiated by his excommunication from the Roman Catholic Church.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 5.--The State Convention of the Union Labor Party, this morning, nominated the following ticket by acclamation, except member of the Board of Public Works: Governor--John Seitz, of Tiffin; Lieutenant-Governor-- ...
SAN FRANCISCO, July 5.--Private Thomas N. Bateman, Troop A, Second United States Cavalry, shot and killed First Sergt. Samuel M. Sopher, of the same troop, at the Presideo Barracks, this morning.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 5.--The mystery attaching to the death of Patrick Joyce was cleared away by to-day's work of the police, and the affair is proved to have been a murder. Joyce's 16-year-old stepson, Michael H. Burke, is under arrest for the crime.

The members of the Board of Electrical Control, as successors of the Commissioners of Electrical Subways, met in the Mayor's office yesterday. In the absence of Mayor Hewitt Acting Mayor Beekman presided until Mr. Jacob Hess had been chosen President of the board.

The Legislature at Jefferson yesterday completed the passage of what is known as the Swamp Angel Railroad bill. Nobody knows or cares what the provisions of this measure are; but in general terms it may be described as something which will do the railroads no harm, ...

The assessed valuation of property in this city for the present year shows the extraordinary increase of $86,672,377 over that of last year, $50,550,784 of which is for real estate. Last year the increase was a little under $50,000,000, of which nearly $36,000,000 was for real estate.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5.--Magistrate List to-day held the preliminary examination into the killing of Alexander Rodney, colored, of 701 Minster-street. On Monday Augustus Emery, also colored, of 1,107 Bainbridge-street, was charged with the murder and George Owens as an accessory.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 5.--The race between the four-oared crews of Cornell University and Bowdoin College for the championship of the Inter-Collegiate Rowing Association, on Lake Quinsigamond this afternoon, was won by Cornell by about two feet.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 5.--John Garrish, Erie Railway locomotive engineer, disappeared from his home, in Port Jervis, at 11 o'clock Sunday evening last. Yesterday afternoon some children who had gone upon an uninhabited island in the Delaware River, near the three States boundary rock, to pick berries, came upon the body of the missing man.

Henriette Grimm, a widow, of 452 West Fortieth-street, who recently came from Northampton, Mass., with her son, lost Monday evening an envelope in which were a bank book on the Northampton Institution for Savings showing a balance of $175, and $20 in money.

The Board of Police recently certified to the Civil Service Examining Board that there existed three vacancies for police surgeons and asked for a list of candidates eligible for appointments to fill the vacancies. Yesterday a list containing the names and standing of candidates ...
Although there are no stake events to be decided at Monmouth Park to-day, still a half dozen good races, including one over hurdles, are to be run, and they should furnish good sport.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 5.--Primus Jones, who for 20 years has annually raised the first bale of cotton, marketed to Georgia, is first again this year. He brought in a bale of 452 pounds to-day, which he sold at 22 cents a pound. The bale was ginned yesterday. It was classed as low middling.

BALTIMORE, July 5.--The Baltimore Plow Company to-day made an assignment to Fielder C. Slingluff for the benefit of its creditors. The bond of the Trustee is $80,000. Frederick W. Whitman, agricultural implements, made an assignment to F. C. Slingluff for the benefit of creditors, bond $40,000, and Ezra B. Whitman, agricultural implements, to same Trustee, bond $40,000.

CHICAGO, July 5.--Chairman Blanchard's reply to the complaint made by the dressed beef shippers to the Inter-State Commerce Commission relative to alleged exorbitant rates will be quite elaborate, going over the whole field, showing the relative cost between dressed ...

BOSTON, July 5.--The Volunteer, the new steel sloop upon which the hopes of Boston yachtsmen now mainly rest, arrived in Boston Harbor about 2 o'clock this morning. Launched on Thursday last at the yard of Pusey Jones, Wilmington, Del., the Volunteer was towed to Boston by the tug Ocean King in about 58 hours, a remarkably quick trip.

Assistant Secretary Thompson, of the Treasury Department, says a false impression prevails in certain quarters with regard to that oft-agitated proposition as to whether or not two members of one family shall be allowed to hold office under the Government.
Booth Niblack, of Jefferson, Ga., discovered a few weeks since that some one had a key that would unlock his crib door and that corn had been stolen therefrom.

READING, Penn., July 5.--William Oldt, wife, and child were passengers on the Pennsylvania Schuylkill Valley Road on the 4 P.M. down train yesterday. While passing River-street, this city, a refrigerator car stood alongside on the Reading Road with the car door ajar.

ALBANY, July 5.--The University Convocation turned its first quarter century this year. At the opening session of the annual meeting today Chancellor Pierson, in his address of welcome, said: "Twenty-five years ago we had less than 20 colleges and universities, literary and ...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 5.--During the sham battle at Delta, Fulton County, yesterday, Postmaster W.R. Huntington was fatally shot. He lived but a short time after the shooting. How the bullet got in among the blank cartridges which the troops were supposed to use nobody can explain.
NASHVILLE, Mo., July 5.--Two brothers named Bass were killed by lightning yesterday. Two women and a child were also severely shocked--one perhaps fatally.

There were 520 deaths in Brooklyn during the past week, a higher rate than the city has known for years. The number was 237 in excess of the corresponding week last year. More than half the victims--352--were children. Cholera infantum killed 117 little ones, and 190 deaths were caused by diarrheal diseases.

The stockholders of the New-York Cable Railway Company held two short meetings yesterday afternoon, at the office of Charles P. Shaw, 96 Broadway. Owing to the absence of the President no report was submitted, and it was voted to adjourn to Aug. 2. No other business was transacted, although the stock was fully represented.

PORTLAND, Oregon, July 5.--It appears from the petition filed by the Receiver that the Oregon and California Road will be soon connected with the California and Oregon Road, when the two will form a through line between Portland and San Francisco.

A Parliamentary paper has been issued giving a return of the number of agrarian outrages which were reported to the Inspector-General of the Royal Irish Constabulary during each of the months of April and May, 1887.

Saloon Keeper John Flynn, of 157 Washington-street, was arraigned at the Tombs Police Court yesterday on the charge of shooting an 11-year-old boy named Eddie Weldon in the head with a revolver, because he was setting off ...

ST. LOUIS, July 5.--The Circuit Court today decided that Russell Sage was illegally elected a Director of the St. Louis and San Francisco Railroad at its last annual meeting, and that E.L. Oppenheim, of New-York, is entitled to the seat.

He is a very sick man," Dr. Loomis replied to inquiries regarding the physical condition of Jacob Sharp. Warden Keating said his prisoner had not slept a bit during Monday night and his appetite had completely disappeared.

CHICAGO, July 6.--The General Passenger Agents of the Alton, Wabash and Illinois Central Roads were in session here to-day conferring about the demoralization resulting from passenger rate cutting.

We can well imagine the feelings of the Queen on passing from her native village, Kensington, now an opulent borough, to Westminster yesterday, as she reflected upon the immense progress made by the metropolis in every respect since the day of her coronation.

The land occupied by the Union Ferry Company, at the foot of Fulton-street, Brooklyn, for ferry purposes is owned by the city of NewYork, but tue Brooklyn Board of Assessors assessed it at $128,000 for the purposes of taxation.

Providence has been kind to the Queen. Her jubilee day, June 21, has come and gone, and the most noteworthy fact about it is that it was not spoiled, either by failure, by accident, or by natural causes.
Anamosa, Iowa, has a case of twins that is exciting a good deal of interest. A man is confined in the penitentiary there for the crime of bigamy who claims that he is the victim of circumstances.
A Manchester grammar school miss recently defined "sinister" as a "female sinner." --Manchester (N.H.) Union.

Law is a very queer thing. Sometimes suggestion of a thing is enough, and other times even absolute proof is no good. Now when a man dies while a suit is pending, the attorney on his side can procure a postponement by saying he's dead.

The eclipse of memory which has suddenly fallen upon the once bright mind of a Chicago young lady awakens, indeed, widespread sympathy for the young beauty and her home circle but it also compels us to perceive that the different faculties occupy different parts of the brain ...

MONTREAL, July 6.--A man named Joseph Perrault was found dead in a field at Cote St. Louis yesterday. His head had been crushed in by a stone weighing 50 pounds. Two men named Dupre and Charlette have been arrested on suspicion of being the murderers of Perrault, as the deceased had been drinking with them, and Dupre had made threats to the effect that he would kill Perrault.

The colored people of Asbury Park are doing their utmost to bring the projector and patron of that resort into odium and contempt. Mr. BRADLEY has had so much to do with the growth of Asbury Park that it would not be inaccurate to describe it as a proprietary resort.
Louis J. Grant began legal proceedings yesterday to test the legality of the recent dismissal of the 70 police officers under what is known as the "60 years act."

At the exposition to be given on ex-Gov. Warmouth's plantation in Louisiana of the diffusion system of extracting sugar from the cane an exhibit will also be made of the new Yargan system of evaporation, which is as important, if not more so, in its effect upon the sugar industry of the future as the diffusion process.
Among the passengers by the San Pablo yesterday was a tall aristocratic lady, clad in black flowing robes, bound at the waist by a broad leather belt.
The Episcopal parsonage in Hempstead, Long Island, was struck by lightning yesterday and a portion of the building demolished. Several other buildings were damaged.
PIERRE, Dakota, July 6.--Trouble is feared at Forts Sully and Bennett with the Indians in case the Soldiers leavre for the East before the Twelfth Infantry arrives.
A well dressed gentleman at an Albany hotel yesterday, while conversing with a friend, took from his pocket a cigar and deliberately bit the end off and lit it without offering one to his companion.
John Hancock, a young man, who was married on Feb. 22 last to Miss Mary Burns, left his home at 32 Hopkins-place, Brooklyn, a week ago and all efforts to find him have proved fruitless.
PEEKSKILL, July 6.--The mountains and the river have come out into sight again, and now the State camp can see something besides itself.
