No part of the stately thanksgiving service was more impressive than the ceremony which followed the benediction, when the Queen, in the presence of her distinguished lieges, embraced the members of her family with obvious emotion.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 6.--At a special meeting of the Episcopal Synod to-day the Rev. Mr. Edghill was appointed Bishop of Nova Scotia, in place of Bishop Binney, deceased.

PADUCAH, Ky., July 6.--In 1873, while J. Hamp Swift was Sheriff of Callaway County, Ky., his accounts were $3,000 short. He thought a Deputy had robbed him. Making good the deficiency that bankrupted him, he has since supported his family as a day laborer.

BELVIDERE, N.J., July 6.--The rainstorm of Tuesday was unusually severe in Warren and Sussex Counties, and great damage was done to the corn crop and to the ripened grain. Field after field lies flattened to the earth and there is danger of mildew. The rain fell in torrents and the wind blew a perfect hurricane. Great washouts occurred in different sections.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 6.--The Southern Pacific Railroad Company to-day have notice that until further orders freight rates will be maintained as they are at present. The Union Pacific Railroad Company says that all its freight rates are printed to expire July 7, but the ...
The Empress of China desires to provide for herself a pleasant home when she retires from the Government. A vast army of laborers are still at work preparing the West Park.
Archbishop Corrigan has a few more visitations to make before he takes his vacation, on which he will start about July 15, and he is anxious to have the McGlynn case disposed of by that time.

A second survey held upon the Hartford has revealed the fact that the old vessel is in a much worse condition than at first reported, and that the cost of her repair will far exceed the 20 per cent. limit.
The managers of the propeller lines have found out that the crowded harbors of the lakes are not adapted to the monster steamships that they have begun building.

The General Term of the Supreme Court has ordered a new trial in the suit of Mrs. Delia Moller, in which she obtained a divorce from her husband, Dr. Frank Moller, who is a son of Christopher Moller, the retired sugar manufacturer.

WASHINGTON, July 6.--Lieut. Col. Amos Beckwith, Major Charles W. Foster, and Lieut. W.F. Wilder, Fourth Cavalry, have been ordered as a Board of Survey at St. Louis on certain property; Major H.S. Hawkins, Tenth Infantry, has been granted two months' leave of absence; First Lieut. ...

Ex-Consul-General von Lade, of Geisenheim, widely known along the Rhine as the owner of large vineyards and fine orchards, on recently celebrating his seventieth anniversary, received the following autograph from Prince Bismarck:

LEXINGTON, Ky., July--The west-bound fast express on the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad was ditched this forenoon at Leon Station, 90 miles east of Lexington, all the cars going off a slight embankment except the sleeper. Conductor Ragland, the engineer, and six passengers are reported injured, the two former quite seriously. A special train with physicians left for the scene of the wreck this afternoon.
As a romantic, precarious occupation diamond seeking is at an end. The whole business is reduced to a system, and is as prosaic and well organized as making calico or any other industry.

Superintendent John F. Noonan, of the Telephone Company in Paterson, N.J., and Daniel McDonald, one of the linemen, were arrested yesterday on charges of assault and battery preferred by George Addy, who asserted that they interfered with him when he was cutting ...

ST. LOUIS, July 6.--It cost Latham $100 to-day to get off some of his antics around third base and to joke with the Metropolitan players and the crowd. It pleased the crowd, who laughed at him until their sides ached, but it did not please President Von Der Ahe, as the Browns lost the game. Latham has been laid off temporarily and Hudson will play at third base.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 6.--Among those present at the University Convocation today were Regents Kernan, Beach, and Townsend Cobb. President Potter, of Hobart; G.W. Samson, of Rutgers; President Dodge, of Madison University; Brothers Fabrican and Thomas, of Manhattan College; Profs. ...

BOSTON, July 6.--For some time rumors have been current regarding the disposition of the Boston Daily Advertiser property, which has for several years been an elephant on the hands of its stockholders.

The Board of Walking Delegates met yesterday and discussed the advisability of aiding the strikers of the Delamater Iron Works by ordering strikes on all buildings where pumps manufactured at the Delamater Works are used.
FORT WORTH, Texas, July 6.--An attempt was made about 3:30 o'clock this morning to rob the through Kansas City express on the Santa Fe Railway between Pendleton and Temple.
KEY WEST, Fla., July 6.--There have been five new cases of yellow fever since yesterday, but no deaths.

LONDON, July 6.--In the House of Commons to-day, Mr. William Henry Smith, the Government leader, referring to the action of the House last night in the Cass case, said the House acted under the wrong impression that the Government was opposed to an inquiry in the matter.

LITCHFIELD, Ky., July 6.--At 1 o'clock this morning W.R. May, a distiller and whisky seller of this place, was called from his bed by some one unknown, who gave the name "Jack Williams" in response to the inquiry who he was, and who pretended to want a quart of whisky.

WHEELING, West Va., July 6.--An auriferous deposit, extending, as far as traced, over 1,100 acres, has been found in the southern part of this county, about 12 miles from the city limits. Samples of the rock show gold at the rate of 10 ounces to the ton. There is considerable excitement over the find.
The Aqueduct Commissioners had a tussle at yesterday's meeting with Gen. John Newton and three of his colleagues, and after a wordy war were defeated.

CHICAGO, July 6.--There was a great crowd at Washington Park to-day to witness some excellent racing between the crack horses of the West. The stake event was a race for 2-year-olds--the Hyde Park Stakes--which was won by Emperor of Norfolk. The races resulted as follows:
CONSTANTINOPLE, July 6.--Lord Salisbury has extended Sir Henry Drummond Wolff's stay here until Sunday next.

The seven young men who are charged with the killing of Robert W. Ostendorf in the Lafayette section of Jersey City late on Tuesday night were arraigned yesterday before Police Justice Wanser, who remanded them for further hearing.

SILVER CREEK, N.Y., July 6.--Last night about 6 o'clock James McCraig and his son, returning from Buffalo in a sail yacht, sighted, about 18 miles out, the yacht Mary B. Bucher, of Dunkirk, which capsized Monday night at 11 o'clock.
MOUNT STERLING, Ky., July 6.--Mr. Howard Williamson, a well known farmer of this county, is just now an object of much attention and the subject of no little sympathy.

William M. Disbrow, of 513 West Nineteenth-street, employed by William Whitehead, his uncle, a sand dealer at 517 West Fifteenthstreet, went to Police Headquarters yesterday with a lawyer and a friend and confronted Officer James Grier, of the Sixteenth Precinct, ...

The Board of Electrical Control received a prompt answer yesterday to its inquiry of the Western Union in regard to the poles and wires which have been removed by that company since permission was granted it to make use of the elevated railroad structures on Third and Ninth avenues for carrying its conductors.
For this great undertaking [the North Sea and Baltic Canal] the necessary money has already been voted by the Parliaments of the empire and of Prussia.
The cutting down of forests in the South by the owners of saw mills is opening up large tracts of cheap lands, which are gradually being turned into farms.

CHICAGO, July 6.--It is expected that on July 12 fully 10,000 teachers from all parts of the United States will be in Chicago to attend the first session of the National Educational Association. Preliminary to the general sessions there will be a series of meetings of the Educational Council, beginning to-morrow afternoon at 3 o'clock.

CHICAGO, Ill., July 6.--Rumors to-day that the jury in the County Commissioners' boodle cases had been fixed in the interest of the defendants brought the trial to a standstill. Court was adjourned for several hours to give the State's Attorney time to get at the bottom of the matter.
Tipsters, touts, "students of form," and the talent of the betting ring ran up against the liveliest kind of a Waterloo at Monmouth Park yesterday.
BALTIMORE, Md., July 6.--Six masked men appeared at the door of the jail at Towson, in Baltimore County, after midnight last night and demanded admission, declaring their intention to lynch ...

QUEBEC, July 7.--Between 11 and 12 o'clock last night fire broke out in the barracks at the Citadel and extended 300 yards, enveloping nearly all the buildings facing the entrance. There is great consternation among the residents in the neighborhood.
For several days past laborers have been digging up the ground at the foot of Laurelstreet to put in a new culvert. This ground is made land of slabs, sawdust,
Robert M. Budd, alias "Back Number Budd," was arraigned in the Yorkville Court yesterday on a charge of shooting Janitor Joseph Brown, of 257 West Forty-seventh-street, through the hand.
CHARLESTON, S.C., July 6.--If your skin is colored don't buy a first class ticket on the Georgia railroads. They are only food for seats in the "Jim Crow car."

GALVESTON, Texas, July 6.--Word reached here this morning from Santa Rosa, Mexico, of the killing of James A. Duvall, owner of the Cedral mines. His body was found hidden in some brush near the roadside leading from the mines into Santa Rosa with a bullet hole through the head.

Michael Donovan, a steerage passenger on the steamship Lord Clive, which arrived yesterday from Liverpool and Queenstown, was detected by Immigration Inspectors Rogers and Hess holding his hands behind his back and endeavoring to reach the wharf unnoticed.

Little Boyle T. Sullivan, 4 years old, of 317 East Eighty-fifth-street, was sent by his mother, June 28, on an errand. While passing the house of a neighbor Boyle accidentally stumbled against a little girl who was sitting on the front steps.

Straw hats are not so generally worn as in former years. The pearl-colored high hats and derbys are rapidly pushing them out of fashion. Last year the hatters, wholesale and retail, had an immense stock of straws, but they sold so slowly that no orders for the current season were given, and perhaps their sale will eventually stop altogether.

SCRANTON, Penn., July 6.--The question of immigration, which promises to become a vital subject with the Knights of Labor in the immediate future, is treated at length and with great boldness in an exhaustive letter published here last evening by General Master Workman Powderly, who replies ...
The Louisville and Nashville Railroad during June earned $1,237,700, an increase of $116,508 compared with the figures of the same month last year.

To-day the Bulgarian Sobranje begins, or rather resumes, its task of choosing a successor to Prince ALEXANDER. The candidates have been many in times past, but the objection that they are too Russian or not Russian enough has disposed of one after another until few are left.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 6.--Yan Phou Lee of the Class of '87 at Yale, and a native of Fragrant Hills, China, was married to-day to Miss Elizabeth Maud Jerome, daughter of Mrs. E. Gilbert Jerome, of this city.

A week ago Postmaster Summon, of Flatbush, resigned at the request of Congressman Felix Campbell, who had secured his appointment. It was given out then that Sammon's administration of the office did not exactly suit the Post Office Department in Washington.

TUCSON, Arizona, July 6.--Advices from Bavispe, Sonora, of the 24th of June are to the effect that Prof. F.S. Clark had been there nine day's under the auspices of the Hawaiian Government, engaged in the investigation of the traces left by the earthquake of May 31 and the succeeding shocks.

BURLINGTON, Vt., July 6.--This morning's session of the American Institute of Instruction opened with a large attendance. President J. M. Hall delivered the annual Presidential address. He said better times in the educational world have come, thanks to the American Institute of Instruction.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 6.--The weather to-day has been damp and sultry and early this afternoon there was a light rain.

When Patrick Murray was arraigned in Justice Massey's court, in Brooklyn, yesterday, on a charge of drunkenness, it leaked out that he and William O'Keefe had escaped from the prisoner's pen in the court room on Saturday. They were there with 25 others and tore up four planks in the floor.

Queer things happen in this pardon business. Historian L.B. Proctor, author of "Bench and Bar" and several other standard works, was telling me the other day of a peculiar pardon case under Gov. Seward.

Mrs. Betsy Fairfield, of Haydenville, will celebrate to-day her one hundred and second birthday. She belongs to a long-lived family, her mother having lived to be 98, a sister 92, a brother 88, and another is still living at 87.

In the dry goods trade yesterday the failure of John Blade Co., commission merchants at 57 Leonard-street, was freely discussed, and the opinion was expressed that, although the immediate cause was tight money, yet "dry rot" had most to do with the failure.

The trial of William Hanly, one of the Excise Commissioners of Richmond County, Staten Island, against whom the Grand Jury found an indictment charging him with having uttered a forged license, took place yesterday at the County Court House at Richmond before Judge Stephens and a jury.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, July 6.--The day in the Mormon Constitutional Convention was taken up in discussion of the clauses prohibiting polygamy and providing for a separation of Church and State. The discussion was animated, and some vigorous speeches were made against both clauses.
A young laborer who had taken arsenic was found dying at Fights-ninth-street and the Riverside Park at 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon by Park Officer Fitting.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 6.--The increase of life and fire insurance in Georgia during the last year has been remarkable. The increase this year over last in fire losses $8,835,116, in premiums $939,563, and in fire losses $240,846. The increase in assessment life risks is $860,500 and in total premiums $8,914. The increase in accident company risks is $3,398,578, in premiums $14,676, and in losses $2,664.

Jacob Sharp's seventieth birthday was passed in Ludlow-Street Jail with no festivities or congratulations to mark it. He was so much improved as to be able to put on a dressing gown and sit up in an easy chair.

A confectioner in Sixth-avenue, who has been in business for the past 15 years, and who is well known and trusted by the residents of the old Ninth Ward, filled, Monday, 122 orders for ice cream. Among his customers was Dr. McIntyre, of 221 West Fourth-street.
BINGHAMTON, July 6.--In the pension fraud case to-day Miller testified that he had been offered $100 apiece for affidavits made at different times relative to the cause of Patterson's blindness.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 6.--The famous Malinckrodt (German) Convent here was the scene of most impressive ceremonies this morning, consisting of the taking of the black veil by 20 lady candidates from various parts of the United States and Germany, and the taking of the white veil vows by 24 young novitiates from prominent cities in the United States and Europe.
DETROIT, July 6.--The Detroit baseball team left last night to play their Eastern series of games, and at the last moment sound themselves in a badly crippled condition.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 6.--Vice-President Reed, of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company, said to-day there was no truth in the recently published report that his company had completed arrangements for leasing the Housatonic Road.

Early in the war 100 army wagons were manufactured for the Government in NewHampshire, under a contract which provided for their delivery at Kingston, where they were inspected, accepted, and sent by railroad to Perryville on the Susquehanna River, opposite Havre de Grace.
BERNE, July 6.--A portion of the land bordering on the lake at Zug, the capital of the canton of that name, subsided to-day, and 27 houses were engulfed in the lake. Twenty persons are missing.

Men may come and men may go, but Lortzing's operetta, "Czar and Zimmermann," does on forever. For a score of years it has been a favorite work in Germany, and it appears to have as firm a hold on the affections of Germans in this city as on the affections of those in the Fatherland.
CHIHUAHUA, July 6.--Mr. A.R. Shepherd, exCommissioner of the District of Columbia, and wife, with Dr. Charles R. Lee as medical attendant, arrived here by stage from Batopilag Monday.

Albert Weinschenk, a young German Jew, employed as a folder in a shirt factory, made the acquaintance early last Summer of Grace Colbert, 20 years old, daughter of a wellto-do widow who lived at 235 East One Hundred and Fifth-street.

The controversy that has arisen over the circumstances attending the delivery of Abraham Lincoln's brief speech at the dedication of the Gettysburg Cemetery suggests the reflection that what is called "history" must be a very untrustworthy department of literature.

RONDOUT, N.Y., July 6.--The annual convention of the American Society of Civil Engineers, which began its sessions at Hotel Kaaterskill Friday of last week, will conclude its labors to-morrow evening with a banquet.

BOSTON, July 6.--Arguments in the Codman will case ware made to-day, and while Probate Judge McKim took the case under advisement, it seemed to be pretty well settled that there was little or no prospect of the will being set aside in the Probate Court.

LONDON, July 6.--Ormonde, the roarer, but still the greatest of English racers, won the Imperial Gold Cup race at the Newmarket July meeting to-day in a canter, and made the Duke of Westminster and his friends very happy.

PITTSBURG, July 6.--James Workman, carriage maker, of the West End, Pittsburg, died yesterday, the victim of a practical joke. The cause was elicited just before the taking of the autopsy of his remains this evening.

England is beginning to feel the burden of undesirable immigration in the great city where Parliament has repeatedly voted large sums of money to be used in shipping native paupers from the United Kingdom to our own shores.

Three teeth in the head of G. Onesti were operated upon recently by Dr. W.J. Younger, who sent in his bill for $336 50, alleged to be due him as an aggregate for 22 hours and 20 minutes' work at $15 an hour.

George R. Lyons, the youthful Brooklyn contractor, who eloped on June 18 with the young daughter of John E. Colyer, of Flatbush, has got himself into a peck of trouble. George is only 25 years old, but he will be older and wiser before he gets through with all the suits for damages which have been begun against him before Justice Cox, in Flatbush.

Dr. J. Huggins, of Hale County, Ala., has just discovered a skeleton of a mastodon, which may prove of interest and value to men of science. It was found in Prairie Creek, near the village of Newberne.
There is a convention in the Territory of Utah, made up entirely of Mormon delegates, which is engaged in framing a State Constitution with a view to asking for admission to the Union.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 6.--William Dennis, aged 17, while at work this afternoon on the culm bank of No. 2 Colliery of the Delaware and Hudson Company, at Plymouth, was struck by lightning and instantly killed. His limbs were torn and scorched and two black marks ran down his body from the neck to the groin.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 6.--Delegates from various portions of this State closed a three days' session here to-day in formulating a plan for the organization of an American Party.

BOSTON, July 6.--The Trustees of the Volunteer Soldiers' National Homes held sessions yesterday afternoon and this forenoon at the Hotel Brunswick. Gen. William B. Franklin presided and the following members were in attendance:
The temperature yesterday, according to the record at the Signal Service office, was very slightly warmer than on the preceding day. The mean temperature yesterday was 72.7 , and on Tuesday 72.3 .
ST. THOMAS, June 17.--Peter Barlow, who took part in the American Revolution under Gen. Washington, has died in Demerara, aged 130 years.
LEIPSIC, July 6.--In the treason trial today the Procurator demanded nine years at hard labor for Klein, five years for Grebert, and ac quittal for Erhart.

CHICAGO, July 6.--John Kelleher ran a rusty nail into his foot May 20. He washed the wound out with cold water, tied a piece of cotton over it, and in a day the foot was apparently well again, the nail having just punctured the skin.
CITY OF MEXICO, July 6, via Galveston.-- The London Economist of June 18, which reached this city to-day, contains an article sharply criticising the financial policy of the Mexican Government.
A gentleman named Davidson in Nashville drew a pistol while in an altercation, and was arrested and fined. He paid his fine, and then demanded his revolver of Chief of Police Kerrigan.

An advertisement in the morning papers calling for information regarding one William Stapleton was several times published within a recent period at the instance of Peckham Tyler, lawyers, in Broadway.

A farmer of Fayette County has been made prosperous and well-to-do by the products of a novel industry--the raising of calamus root. He has about a quarter of an acre of swamp land densely set in this plant, and has orders ahead for his whole crop, amounting to more than $5,000.

ST. LOUIS, July 6.--Up to the eighth inning King had the Mets at his mercy to-day, but they gauged his delivery in the eighth, and in that and the ninth pounded out four runs, sufficient to win the game. MacMullen, the young California pitcher, did fairly well, and had he been better supported would have made a better showing.

A meeting of the members of the grain trade was held in the Call Room of the Produce Exchange yesterday, and it was voted that "Wheat sold for future delivery at the public calls and on the floors of the Exchange, unless ...
LEAVENWORTH, July 6.--The Pacific Railroad Investigating Committee arrived here this morning, and held a public session in the Board of Trade rooms, at which they examined a number of witnesses.

Capt. Ryan, of the Twenty-first Precinet, in which the young athlete Joseph Quinn was murdered by the jailbird Daniel Lyons Tuesday night, is confident that the murderer will be caught ultimately and hanged. "If we don't get him," said the Captain yesterday, "Inspector Byrnes's men will get him wherever he goes. The Inspector's officers have worked up a great many more difficult cases than this."

Two men, equally interested, were present at the protracted meeting of the Police Commissioners yesterday. The first was mad clear through him, to express the fact colloquially, and the second was scared clear through.

Henry M. Whittelsey, a young man, who for six years had been employed as a clerk in the Corn Exchange National Bank, was held for trial in the Jefferson Market Policy Court, yesterday, charged with having, on March 28, passed a forged check for $9.53 on Jonathan A. McLean, a ticket agent at 7 Broadway.

O.M. Hartt, the foreman of the boot and shoe factory of Gardner Estes, who was prohibited by the Knights of Labor from working in that or any other factory, and who to secure his right to work for any manufacturer who would employ him began proceedings against Knights of Labor John Gill, McDonald Campbell, Foster, ...
By permission of Judge Lawrence, the American Female Guardian Society has added to its legal title the words "and Home for the Friendless."
Lightning yesterday afternoon killed Henry Johnson, employed on Preston Stevenson's farm, near Paterson, N.J. His brother was walking by his side and escaped unhurt.

NEWPORT, R. I., July 6.--Wind and rain interfered somewhat with the pleasure of the Brooklyn pilgrims to-day. They were to have made the journey from Martha's Vineyard to Newport by boat, but the sea was a trifle too heavy for a small and crowded boat, and so the pilgrims were landed at New-Bedford.

There are six races to be run at Monmouth Park to-day, including the Hopeful Stakes for 2-year-olds, the Long Branch Handicap, and the Lorillard Stakes for 3-year-olds. Two other races on the that and a steeplechase over the short course will furnish plenty of good and exciting sport.

Messrs. Craig, Milhan, and Foster, of the State Board of Charities, yesterday continued their investigation into the management of affairs at the city insane asylum on Ward's Island, two sessions being held in General Superintendent Macdonald's office.

WASHINGTON, July 6.--Pension Commissioner Black is inclined to think that the work of the Pension Bureau for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1887, is one that will relieve the Administration, so far as that office is concerned, from any charge of indifference to the interests of the soldiers of the United States.
WILMINGTON, Del., July 6.--A well dressed young Spaniard, giving his name as Arturio Machado and his residence Bridgeport, Conn., is held at the police station here at his own request.

Mr. Robert Louis Stevenson's brief memoir of the late Prof. Fleeming Jenkin has been delayed, because Mr. Stevenson is one of the few men of letters of to-day who send nothing to the press until they feel that they have done their best with it.
The Regatta Committee of the Larchmont Yacht Club decided yesterday that the prize contested for in Saturday's regatta by the Titania and Shamrock belonged to the latter vessel.

The Board of Education yesterday afternoon appointed 246 Principals and teachers for the 27 evening schools. The Trustees of Ward 22 were authorized to re-engage 252 West Fortysecond-street for Grammar School No. 80, at a rental of $2,400.

Most of our readers interested in the subject will remember the disclosures made before the Bacon investigation committee last Spring as to the complete perversion of the civil service reform system in Brooklyn.
Joseph McGrath, 6 years old, on Monday followed a procession that passed his home, 158 West Twenty-eighth-street, and was at night reported lost at Policy Headquarters.

The West Hoboken Town Council met last evening and opened bids for the building of the sewers which that towny in conjunction with the Hoboken Land and Improvement Company, has decided to have constructed.

PITTSBURG, July 6.--George Elphinstone, attorney, to-day filed a libel suit against Maria Miraglia, of Virgin-alley, Queen of the Italian Colony in Pittsburg. The plaintiff is Enrico Gennaro, a contractor for supplying laborers.

A policeman found a man, lying on a cart in Fourth-avenue, between One Hundred and Twenty-eighth and One Hundred and Twentyninth streets, last evening and was proceeding to run him in as a "drunk," when the prisoner ...
Jay Gould and Henry S. Ives are still having daily interviews with one another. Their yachts during the past few days have been side by side up in New-England waters.

FALL RIVER, Mass., July 6.--The mysterious disappearance of Edward Kershaw, an overseer in the Wampanoag Mill and a member of the Fire Department, on Monday last, causes a great deal of talk in the eastern part of the city.

The unpaid employes of the National Opera Company crowded the stage of the Academy of Music yesterday to listen to their committee, who had held a conference with the committee of the Board of Directors Tuesday.
The members of the United Labor Party are becoming annoyed over the ceaseless efforts of the Socialists to control them.

TRENTON, N.J., July 7.--The opponents of Assembly bill No. 47 before the last Legislature have had a hard time trying to kill the measure. It made any one a criminal who trespaseed on oyster beds, and provided severe penalties.

A permanent organization of a Jewelers' Exchange was formed at the Astor House last night. Its objects are to bring buyer and seller closer together, to facilitate busness, and to relieve the Astor House corridors of the throngs...
PARIS, July 7.--A dynamite explosion occurred in a shoemaker's shop in the Rue St. Martin to-day, doing much damage to neighboring shop fronts.

VIENNA, July 7.--A circular letter of June 16 from M. Rampolla, the Papal Secretary of State, to the Papal Nuncios abroad is published here. It embraces the leading passages of the allocution of the Pope delivered at the Consistory of May 23.

GALVESTON, Texas, July 7.--Gov. Ross will furnish the railroad companies with commissions for 390 train guards, to be paid by the companies. Five to ten men wiil be sent out on every through train liable to attack by robbers.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7.--General Master Workman Powderly, in the Journal of United Labor, published to-day, pays his respects to the grain and stock brokers in a vigorous manner. Referring to the recent corners in coffee and wheat Mr. Powderly says: "The lesson taught...
WASHINGTON, July 7.--Sixty recruits have been ordered to Fort Snelling, Minnesota, for assignment to the First Cavalry.

Howe Hummell, the counsel for Daniel Driscoll, the murderer of "Bezie" Garrity, whose conviction by the Court of General Sessions last September was affirmed by the General Term of the Supreme Court, three weeks...

President Cleveland's letter to the Mayor of St. Louis was discussed by men of all shades of politics in this city yesterday, and the opinion was universal that his decision not to visit St. Louis during the Grand Army encampment was wise, and his letter expressing that decision dignified and straightforward.

A small boat, rowed by three lusty mariners, toiled up to the Battery early yesterday morning with a whale in tow. The prize, which was from 30 to 40 feet in length and was several feet around the body, was what is called a black fin-back.
EVANSVILLE, Ind., July 7.--Perry County, Ind., is wildly excited over the defalcation and flight of Hinton Miller, County Treasurer. He owes the county $40,000 and private parties $10,000 more.

CINCINNATI, July 7.--The game to-day was a pitchers' battle after the fourth inning. Previous to that time the Cincinnatis hit Mays for six singles. After that inning but two more were secured, one being a scratch.

ALBANY, July 7.--Rumors are current that during the past week efforts have been made to purchase the Argus, for more than half a century the leading Democratic paper at the State capital, and at present the organ of ex-Secretary Daniel Manning.

Believers in civil service reform are not admirers of Surveyor Beattie's ways of carrying its rules into effect. They find that in one department at least he is laboring with a great deal of diligence and considerable success to avoid reform and to bring his subordinates more completely under his control as wires in a political...
In the busiest days of Spring there was hardly a time when more buyers went to the Real Estate Exchange than met there yesterday. They simply packed a large portion of the salesroom uncomfortably.
The Coney Island hotel people are getting up petitions praying the officers of the various railroads and steamboat companies to reduce their passenger rates.

BURLINGTON, Vt., July 7.--The meeting of the American Institute of Instruction was opened this morning by Head Master J.O. Norris, of the Charleston High School, with a paper on "The Extra Professional Duties and Privileges of the Teacher."
BELVIDERE, N.J., July 7.--Mrs. Oscar Boyer, of Bridgeville, was bitten to-day by a copperhead pilot snake. She is in a critical condition. The snake was in a barrel of potatoes in the cellar.
The town of Arlington, N.J., was shaken to its centre yesterday morning by a terrific explosion which occurred at the works of the Cellonite Manufacturing Company.

HUNTSVILLE, Ala., July 7.--About 8 o'clock this morning, when Tim Anderson, (colored,) assistant jailer, went in to the cell of Reed Townsend to carry him his breakfast. Townsend sprang to the door, seized the iron bar used as a fastening, and...

There was an agreeable surprise in store for the members of the New-York Club yesterday. They expected to meet a small crowd when they returned from Chicago, where they were forced to lower their colors three times in succession, but nearly 6,000 persons welcomed...

The people of Chicago begin to suspect that they have fallen into the hands of the Standard Oil Trust. The facts thus far brought to light concerning the establishment of a gas monopoly in that city are of considerable interest to the general public,
John Hoey, a young man of Jamaica, Long Island, has received a check for $200 from Mr. P.H. Cassidy, Auditor of the New-York, Woodhaven and Rockaway Railroad, under somewhat peculiar circumstances.

Jacob Sharp rose yesterday morning about 9:30 o'clock after a fair night's rest and ate a light breakfast. He lounged about his comfortable room, in Ludlow-Street Jail, all day, somewhat better than he was a day or two before.
Dr. Morell Mackenzie, of London, sent a cablegram to the Medical Record detailing the results of his third operation upon the throat of the Crown Prince of Germany.

UNIONTOWN, Penn., July 7.--This afternoon reports from the principal points throughout the region show that the strikers are all broken up and at several of the larger works are reporting for duty at several of the larger works are reporting for duty...

ST. LOUIS, July 7.--A private dispatch from New-York this evening announces the appointment by the Board of Directors of the Wabash of Mr. Charles M. Hays as General Manager to succeed the late A.A. Talmage, and of James I. Howe as Vice. President.

In strong contrast with the abuse which has been heaped upon the President by some members of the Grand Army of the Republic are the manly words penned by Gen. W.T. Sherman to comrades in St. Louis when he learned of the threats made against Mr. Cleveland. The following is the main part of that letter:

NEW-ORLEANS, July 7.--The substitution of a tragedy for a wedding took place last night. Dr. John A. Cullom, of Avoyelles Parish, 55 years old, a leading physician of that section, and possessing considerable wealth, came to this city to marry Miss Dart, a beautiful and accomplished lady, sister of a prominent lawyer...

HARTFORD, Conn., July 7.--Ex-State Treasurer V.B. Chamberlain, of New-Britain; Dr. George C. Jarvis, of this city; Representative Stephen Walkley, of Southington, and Gen. William H. Pierpont, of New-Haven, members...

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 7.--The National Rubber Works, at Bristol, on account of the large amount of manufactured goods on hand, have suspended operations for an indefinite period--it is rumored from two to three months. Twelve hundred operatives are thus thrown out of employment.

John Morrison, Master Workman of District Assembly No. 126, in speaking yesterday on the report about Powderly's impending resignation as General Master Workman, remarked that the rumor was a gray-bearded chestnut.
Fourteen roundsmen were yesterday made Sergeants by the Police Commissioners. Their names are as follows: Cornelius Reid, Henry Steinkamp, Francis Kelly, and Charles Tiernan,...
NELSONVILLE, Ohio, July 7.--Louis Andrews and Herman Fiddler, aged 13 and 14 years respectively, were found dead under the scales in a furnace at Buchtel at 6 o'clock this morning.
Henry Scharf, a genial old actor, who since the theatrical season closed has been boarding at 65 Irving-place, left that house on June 18, and has not been heard of since.

Judge Lawarnce has just made a decree annulling the marriage of David C. Pinckney to Ellen Maria Hisson. The wedding took place in November, 1876, the bride representing herself as a widow named Hisson.

ST. LOUIS, July 7.--President Cleveland's two letters declining the Grand Army and citizens' invitation to visit St. Louis during the encampment has caused a great sensation. The result is a monster mass meeting which will be held "on 'Change" to-morrow.

CHICAGO, July 7.--Every Chicago Democrat of any prominence, who was in the city to-day, waa deeply interested in the meeting for the reorganization of the party in Cook County, and scarcely found time to glance at President Cleveland's letter declining to visit St. Louis.

WASHINGTON, July 7.--A valuable collection numbering more than 10,000 objects illustrating the habits and accomplishments of pre-historic man in western Europe was opened to public exhibition at the Smithsonian Institution to-day.

The stockholders of the new MadisonSquare Garden Company, which is to rebuild that famous reception hall of the elephants and fancy horses; dogs, and cattle, that appeared at the various great "shows," held their first annual meeting at 10 Wall-street yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, July 7.--Gen. Landes Post, No. 5, of the Grand Army of the Republic of Lynn, Mass., which arrived here last night from Virginia, called on the President at 6 o'clock this evening, preceded by the post drum corps, and were received in the East Room.

SARATOGA, July 7.--A delightfully cool breeze, laden with the ozone of the Adirondacks, to-day tempers the otherwise distressing heat that has for five days made life in this resort more or less of a burden. People are arriving very fast.

The Board of Electrical Control met yesterday in the Mayor's office, President Hess presiding. Edward Lauterbach, for the Consolidated Telegraph and Electrical Subway Company, submitted the form of a bond, with a surety, as required by the board, and a committee will examine it.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 7.--Drafts on NewYork--Sight, 17 cents; telegraphic, 25 cents.
SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, July 7.--The matter of choice for Presidential nominee in 1888 has caused much discussion in this (Clark) county, one of the banner Republican counties of the State.

A new and strange peril is menacing Russia, which, by a curious irony of fortune, turns into a source of weakness what has hitherto been regarded as the mainspring of her strength, viz., the exclusively military character of her administration.
PORTLAND, Oregon, July 7.--Recent reports from Idaho Territory are to the effect that a number of Chinese mining camps, scattered along the Snake River, have been raided.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 7.--An important decision relating to the standing and rights of Directors of railroad companies and other corporations has just been rendered by Justice C. F. Brown, sitting in Supreme Court, Chambers, at Newburg.

BALTIMORE, July 7.--The fiftieth anniversary of the admission of Sister Mary Ann McAleer to the Sisterhood of Charity was celebrated to-day at St. Agnes Hospital. Cardinal Gibbons celebrated high mass, assisted by Mgrs. McColgan and McManus, and the Rev. Dr. John Foley preached.
Hanover, the great colt of the Dwyer Brothers' stable, put his fourteenth consecutive victory to his credit by winning the Lorillard Stakes at Monmouth Park yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, July 7.--The Democrats of Milwaukee are in accord in approving President Cleveland's stand declining to attend the St. Louis encampment. The following expressions gathered at random voice the general sentiment:

The Specialty Button Company at 349 Broadway has become financially embarrassed and the stock and fixtures are advertised to be sold out by the sheriff to-day. Judgments for $13,319 have been entered against the company, the largest being in favor of Charles Siedler, the President, for $12,041.

All the persons who were made sick July 4 by eating ice cream which came from the store of Ernest A.G. Intemann, 53 Sixth-avenue, have so far recovered as to be about and attending to their regular business and duties except Mrs. C.S. Wright, of 240 West Fourthstreet. She is still very sick and prostrated from the effects of the violent retching and vomiting...
LOUISVILLE, July 7.--The Louisville players outbatted their opponents to-day, but lost a close and exciting contest by costly errors in the last inning.

CHICAGO, July 7.--Gens. Chatelain and Bentley, the Commissioners of the Chicago International October Encampment, write Gov. Beveridge that on their arrival in England they called on Gen. Wolseley, Adjutant-General of her Majesty's forces, who cordially approved of...

About 2:30 o'clock yesterday morning, as Officer Sullivan, of the Fourth Police Precinct, was passing along Park-row near the corner of New Bowery, his attention was attracted to a man who was walking aimlessly about the sidewalk in a nude condition.
The long-talked-of match race between the sloops Shamrock and Titania was undertaken yesterday and was won by the Titania through her opponent's misfortune.
BOSTON, July 7.--The sloop yacht Shadow to-day won the second and final race for the cup offered by Commodore Meer for first class sloops of the Boston Yacht Club.

BURLINGTON, Vt., July 7.--At a meeting to-night of the Dartmonth Alumni attending the institute an association to be known as the Dartmouth Alumni Association of the American Institute was organized, with these officers:

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 7.--A letter, bearing date of July 4, has been received by Chief Marsh, from the Chief of Police of Bayonne, N.J., containing the copy of a piece of manuscript picked up in Bayonne Bay. The Bayonne officer says that the writing was in lead pencil. This is the note which was picked up:

LONDON, July 7.--In the House of Commons to-night, on a motion being made for the third reading of the Crimes bill, Mr. Gladstone, amid prolonged cheers, made a counter motion that the bill be read a third time this day three months. Mr. Gladstone said the bill was the Conservative alternative to home rule, and, there fore, bore a different aspect from any ordinary...

Of the hundreds of cases pending in the courts of New-York against the Manhattan Elevated Railroads for damages to property for obstruction of light and air, one that had been prosecuted with a little extra vigor has quite recently come to a conclusion quite favorable to the property owner.

JEFFERSON CITY, July 7.--The State Supreme Court in the case of Brooks, alias Maxwell, condemned for the murder of C. Arthur Preller, and sentenced to be hanged Aug. 12, to-day overruled the motion for a rehearing. A reprieve was granted to the defendant until Aug. 26. The defense will take an appeal to the United States Supreme Court.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 7.--The Eastern Yacht Club squadron sailed on their annual cruise east this morning. The flagship Gitana headed the procession, followed by the Mohican, Stranger, Wanderer, Ocean Gem, Ambassadress, and Galatea. Neither the Tioga, Latonia, nor Priscilla started.
BOSTON, July 7.--A pardon has been granted to Nathan P. Pratt, formerly Treasurer of the Reading Savings Bank, who was sentenced to State prison for four years in 1884 for embezzlement.

CHICAGO, July 7.--Some important facts have just come to the surface in regard to the great wheat deal, which were suppressed at the time of the collapse through the ingenuity of counsel for the Bank of Montreal.

Michael Yanger, aged 34 years, of 129 East Fourth-street, a cooper by trade, was examined at Essex Market Police Court yesterday on a charge made by Benjamin Freehling, a cigarmaker, of 511 East Thirteenth-street, that...

ST. ALBANS, Vt., July 7.--During a terrific thunderstorm yesterday afternoon. Francis Ryan's large barn in Fairfield was struck by lightning and burned, with a quantity of hay, grain, agricultural implements, c. The loss is $6,000; insurance $3,000. James Farr's corn barn in the same town was also struck by lightning and demolished.

One of the coming discoveries is that Jay Gould and Russell Sage have lately been heavy buyers of the stocks of the New-York and NewEngland Railroad, seeking to regain control of that property, not for any intrinsic value that it has, but to hold it as a lever in certain other stock speculations that they-have in view.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 7.--This was ladies' day at the races, and the women saw the races run with these results:

At the meeting of the County General Committee of the United Labor Party held last evening the Executive Committee requested that the Assembly district associations send in the names and addresses of their inspectors of elections by the first Monday in August.

A letter was received at the Coroners' office yesterday from F. Ratzel, of 8 Sullivanstreet, a brother of Mrs. Christina Kreig, who was found dead in her bed by her husband on the morning of July 5 at 109 Greenwich-street.
Capt. Samuel P. Griffin, formerly of the United States Navy, and more recently the Commodore of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, died yesterday of paralysis, at Aspinwall.
QUEBEC, July 7.--The fire in this city last night broke out in the stables attached to the barracks at the Citadel. The stable picket is said to have been asleep.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 7.--Edward O'Connor, of Davenport, late editor of the Weekly Transcript of that town, and a prominent lawyer and politician of Delaware County, has been placed under bonds to appear and answer any indictment that may be found against him...

The charges against Capt. Anthony J. Allaire, of the Eleventh Precinct, were no better substantiated yesterday before the full Board of Police Commissioners than those against Capt. Williams the day before.
TIRNOVA, July 7.--Prince Ferdinand of Saze-Coburg-Gotha was to-day elected Prince of Bulgaria by the Sobranje. The announcement was received with great enthusiasm.

Rain was copiously falling at about 9 o'clock yesterday morning when the early section of the first grand annual excursion of the Sheridan Shook Association left the foot of West Thirty-fifth-street on board the gayly bedecked barge Sumner.
NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., July 7.--John M. Forbes has sold his Herreshoff steam yacht Permelia to Capt. Winchester, of South-street, New-York City.

The Driving Club of New-York opened its Summer meeting yesterday with two excellent races. The day was a perfect one, although somewhat hot, but the 2,000 and more people who assembled on the grand stand and in and about the clubhouse were refreshed by a cooling breeze.

WASHINGTON, July 7.--The following letters, comprising the invitation of the business men, veterans, and citizens of St. Louis to President Cleveland to visit St. Louis during the Grand Army encampment in that city, and the two letters of the President withdrawing his acceptance of that invitation and giving his reasons therefor, were made public to-day:

The Board of Street Opening and Improvement met in the mayor's office yesterday, and heard arguments for and against the project of the New-York and Long Island Bridge Company to build a bridge across the East River, the approach on the New-York side connecting with the tracks of the Harlem Railroad Company under Fourth-avenue.

NEW-HAVEN, July 7.--A dozen or more prominent politicians of this city were asked their opinion to-night of President Cleveland's letter declining the invitation to visit St. Louis during the national encampment of the Grand Army. All were emphatic in their approval of the sentiments expressed and of the motives actuating the writer.

The Coney Island Jockey Club announces that entries for three of the handicaps to be run at the Autumn meeting will close on Friday, the l5th inst.

BOSTON, July 7.--It is rumored that Mr. Robert P. Porter, who was a member of the Tariff Commission, and since then has traveled abroad as correspondent of the New-York Tribune and has also been connected with the Philadelphia Press, is the coming editor of the Boston Daily Advertiser.

CHICAGO, Ill., July 7.--A goodly number of Chicago speculators, who have been backing Chicago and Northwestern common stock in the hope that some $10,000,000 of the company's large surplus would soon be divided among stockholders, were very much disgusted to-day...
Harry Lang, alias Henry Irving Lang, was remanded at the Tombs yesterday morning on a charge of grand larceny. For six weeks past Lang has been the janitor of the flat 341 East Forty-first-street.

The Astoria police telephoned to Police Headquarters in this city last night that they had in custody a young man supposed to be Daniel Lyons, the ex-convict who Tuesday evening shot and killed Joseph Quinn at Secondavenue and Thirty-eighth-street.
During the Presidential campaign of 1884 Robert Graham, of Tarrytown, was an ardent Blaine man. He made a large number of bets that Blaine would be elected, one of them being with Louis Rosenberg.

PARIS, July 7.--Commander Charles Le Strange, of the British dispatch boat Surprise, who mysteriously disappeared after being seen in the suburbs of Marseilles, has been seen. He is believed to be safe in Brussels.
MONTREAL, July 7.--The barkentine Aeronaut, which was reported to have passed up to this port with smallpox and yellow fever on board, arrived here to-night.

BOSTON, July 7.--The intensely hot weather in Boston may account for the apathy with which the President's declination to visit St. Louis is received, even by the Grand Army men. The newspapers are left to discuss it, and all have done so according to their political proclivities. The Morning Post says:
The Delamater Iron Works has already got nearly its full complement of machinists in the places of those who had gone out on strike. The boilermakers, however, have not returned,

PHILADELPHIA, July 7.--President Cleveland's letter to Mayor Francis, of St. Louis, declining to be present at the Grand Army reunion at that place was received by the Democrats here with favorable comments.
From their last and longest pilgrimage Dr. Talmage and his fellow-wanderers returned yesterday morning. The Trustees of the Brooklyn Tabernacle inaugurated these pilgrimages in 1885.

Collecting testimony in an insane asylum is necessarily a difficult and risky business. Especially is this the case when the testimony is given in an issue in which the patients of the asylum are on one side and the keepers on the other.

WASHINGTON, July 7.--The President does not appear to be likely to get fair treatment at the hands of the St. Louis people, whether politically friendly or hostile, and it may be just as well that he should decline to visit them for general reasons.

The action taken by the Directors of the National Rifle Association upon the charges preferred against Gen. CHALES S. ROBBINS forms an interesting contribution to the literature of military etiquette.
BERNE, July 7.--The disaster at Zug recalls in many respects the phenomena of South American earthquakes. For several days crevices had been observed in a new quay at Zug which cost $40,000.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., July 7.--Gen. Philip H. Sheridan, who is living this Summer at Nonquitt, was received to-day by the New-Bedford Board of Trade, and was entertained, with the Reception Committee, at the Hon. W.W. Crapo's residence. He says this is the first vacation he has had for over 25 years.
HARTFORD, Conn., July 7.--Department Commander Henry E. Taintor, of the Grand Army in this State, said this afternoon, relative to the President's letter declining to be present...
LONDON, July 8.--The Wen-Chow River, in China, has overflowed its banks, submerging miles of territory. Thousands of persons are believed to have been drowned.
ST. LOUIS, July 7.--The Health Department made a startling discovery this afternoon in Henry Wessel's South St. Louis dairy. He keeps 50 cows and supplies alarge section of the city with milk.
KEY WEST, Fla., July 7.--There have been three new cases of yellow fever since yesterday, and one death.

HOTEL KAATERSKILL, New-York, July 7.-- The 350 members of the American Society of Civil Engineers who have been doing the Catskills for a week late last night and early this morning witnessed a mountain storm in all its fury and grandeur.
LEIPSIC, July 7.--Erhardt, one of the men who has been on trial here for treason during the past few days, was yesterday liberated by the court, the charge against him not being sustained.

Mrs. James Brown Potter has been so vividly impressed by the manly beauty and fine acting of Kyrle Bellew in his support of her in "Civil War" that she has come to the conclusion that she cannot undertake her projected tour of the English provinces and this country without having that popular actor attached to her professional train.

DETROIT, July 7.--Congressman Tarsney, Democratic Representative from the Saginaw District, in this State, was in town to-day, and in an interview expressed his confident belief that Cleveland would be renominated next year.
Judge Wallace rendered a decision in the United States Circuit Court yesterday, reversing the judgment given in the District Court, before Judge Brown, against the Government in its suit...
There was a jovial gathering at Riccadonnas's, in Union-square, last night, and one which was of cumulative interest, being decidedly more lively at the end than it was at the beginning.
