Garnett, Division Freight Agent of the Missouri Pacific and the Central Branch of the Union Pacific, testified to the arrangements about rates between his road and others, stating that in...
Alfred Uhl, whose wife is a member of the old Howard family of Brooklyn, has begun suit in the Supreme Court against the Brooklyn Elevated Railroad and the Standard Oil Company...
NEWPORT, R.I., July 7.--An almost impenetrable fog has prevailed here nearly all the afternoon, and the place was visited by a severe wind and rainstorm last night.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba, July 7.--Canadian Indians are on the war path again. They were being paid "trety" at the reserve near Winnipeg to-day, when they donned the war paint and showed fight.

The-two turf courts laid out in the centre of the Staten Island Cricket and Baseball Club Grounds were in excellent condition yesterday, and were satisfactory to the lawn tennis experts who played in the club's invitation tournament.

The dignified and patriotic letter of the President withdrawing his acceptance of the invitation to visit St. Louis during the encampment there of the Grand Army of the Republic is calculated to make that organization ashamed of the conduct of some of its conspicuous members.
"Get me an axe and I'll split your head open!" "I am the American flag and I want to kill you because you are an Englishman!"

PEEKSKILL, July 7.--It was a surprise to the State camp when it awoke this morning and found it was really to have a chance to get dry. The sun was shining as brightly as before its two days' battle with the clouds, and the only reminders left of the storm were a few mud puddies...

WASHINGTON, July 8.--The President will go to Clinton, N.Y., on Monday, with Col. Lamont, to attend the celebration on the 13th. He expects to be absent from the capital a week, and will spend part of the time at Forest Port as the guest of his brother, the Rev. William Cleveland.

The probabilities are that no match race between the Shamrock and Titania will be sailed until late in the season. J. Rogers Maxwell, owner of the Shamrock, expressed himself yesterday as well pleased with his vessel's performance in the sail Thursday.
LONDON, July 8.--Gen. Owen Williams's colt Senanus had a walk-over for the Prince of Wales's Private Post Stakes at the Newmarket entries today.

MONTREAL, July 8.--An extensive lottery swindle has just been unearthed here. The Chief of Police has received a number of inquiries from persons in the United States asking for information about a financial firm named H. Reade Co., of Montreal.
ALLENFORD, Ontario, July 8.--A widow named McDougald was found dead here this afternoon, with two bullet holes in her heart. Samuel Hughes has been arrested on suspicion of being her murderer.
The records of the Sick Children's Mission of the Children's Aid Society show a rapid daily increase in the number of applications for medical aid for sick poor children.

BOMBAY, July 8.--The Ameer of Afghanistan has nailed to the Kandahar Gate, underneath the Koran, a proclamation offering a free pardon and the remission or two years' taxes to all rebels who surrender.
PORTLAND, Oregon, July 8.--Ben Halliday, of pony express and overland stage fame, died at St. Vincent's Hospital this evening after lingering painlessly for 48 hours.

EVERSON, Penn., July 8.--The Miners and Laborers' Amalgamated Association has showed a weakness to-day by offerihg to return to work at the old wages provided the operators would agree to form a sliding scale. The rank and file are loud in their condemnation of the action of the convention.

BALTIMORE, July 8.--Two weeks ago a child of William Albaugh, of Middletown, Frederick County, Md., disappeared. Searching parties were organized and the mountains for miles around were searched, but no trace of the little one could be found.

Kohe, Kuma, and Yeddo, the famous family of Japanese pugs belonging to Mrs. Eugene Clarke, of 148 East Forty-sixth-street, have all died since the hot season began, Kobe, the eldest, dying two days ago.
Trow's City Directory for 1887 appeared yesterday, and is the one hundred and first Directory issued by the Trow Company.
Gerald A. Seymour, a former employe of Swan Finch, oil dealers, of this city, has begun suit against them in the Brooklyn City Court for $10,000 damages for false imprisonment.
BUFFALO, July 8.--This city is to have greatly increased elevator capacity in another year. Land has been bought and a two-millionfive-hundred-thousand-bushel elevator will be...

The Catholic authorities have served the notice of his excommunication upon Dr. McGlynn. Archbishop Corrigan sent this notice through a registered letter, which the priest must have found in his mail when he arrived in the city last evening from Milwaukee. A registered letter was used in order that an acknowledgement of the receipt of the message might be secured.

ST. LOUIS, July 8.--The citizens of St. Louis, in mass meeting assembled, declared today that there is no embargo on St. Louis hospitality. The response to the call issued by the Citizen's Committee last night resulted in one of largest and most representative gatherings of citizens ever held on the floor of the Merchants' Exchange.

PEEKSKILL, July 8.--This was the last full day the Ninth had to stay in camp at Peekskill, and it was also the hottest. The mercury climbed way up to 100 in the shade and looked down on the other side. The boys did not have to consult the thermometer, however, to find out that it was hot.

If the Republican Party of the country hopes to retain the strength which it still has, much more if it hopes to recover the strength which it has unquestionably lost, it must face to the front and vindicate its claim to be a party of progress.
Such people as can solve the mystery of Brighton Beach racing had a chance to pick up a small fortune at Brighton yesterday, where six races were run.
ROCKLAND, Mass., July 8.--A sad drowning accident occurred on Tispaquin pond, this village, to-day, the victims being Jennie, the 19-year-old daughter of William Dunham and his grandson, aged 11.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 8.--Deputy United States Marshals Spurrier and Young returned to-day from an extended trip through several counties along the upper Cumberland and report the arrest of 40 persons for...

BUTLER, Penn., July 8.--The news of the death of James Wigton, who died at Salina, Venango County, a few days ago, aged 76, recalls one of the most dreadful chapters in the criminal history of Pennsylvania, Wigton's entire family, consisting of his wife and five children, having been murdered in Slippery Rock Township, Butler County, in 1843.

Rabbi E.B.M. Browne, of the Jewish Congregation Gates of Hope, will not trouble the congregation with his ministrations much longer. Thursday evening the Trustees of the congregation decided to suspend him, charges of conduct unbecoming a minister having been made against him and sustained, after an investigation by a committee of three of the members.
Capt. McLaughlin, of the First Precinct, had two prisoners in the Tombs Court yesterday charged with practicing a novel swindling scheme.

At a special meeting of the Board of Emigration yesterday Commissioner Stephenson intimated that he had a startling exposure to make. He gave as the title of his exposure "The Hidden Mysteries of Castle Garden and its Workings."
The much-discussed new constitution of the Knights of Labor which the General Executive Board is trying to force upon the order has almost caused an open rebellion in this city and vicinity.

The Summer meeting of the Driving Club of New-York will close to-day. Harry Wilkes, who made a record of 2:13 at San Francisco on April 2, last, will start to beat that record for a purse of $1,500. There will also be a race for horses in the 2:35 class, and the 2:23 class from yesterday will be fluished.

BURLINGTON, Vt., July 8.--This is the last day of the meeting of the American Institute of Instruction. The morning exercises were opened with a paper by Thomas Emerson, Superintendent of Schools of Newton, Mass., on "Free Text Books." There are 20 States that have not yet made any provision for free text books even for indigent children.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 8.--The Pacific Railway investigating commission to-day examined at great length Judge J.P. Usher, the Attorney of the Kansas Pacific Railway, now one of the attorneys of the Union Pacific, who drew up the mortgage consolidating the Union Pacific and the Kansas Pacific.

Frederick C. Knee and Miss Julia E.Miller, of Jersey City, have been secretly married. The young woman is the one whom Knee shot in a fit of jealousy on May 15 last. Knee had been paying attentions to Miss Miller, and on the evening of the shooting called upon her at her house in Grand-street.

LONDON, July 8.--Lord Hartington in the House of Commons this afternoon, continuing the debate on the Irish Crimes bill, said he recognized that every portion of the majority supporting the measure must bear its full onus of responsibility for what had been done.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 8.--There was another good crowd at the new track to-day to see the four races run with the following results:

The work of the Standard Gaslight Company, which began early in the Spring is now being rapidly pushed, especially in the neighborhood of Third-avenue and One Hundred and Twentieth-street. Many miles of pipe have been laid in Ninth, Second, Third, Fifth, and Madison avenues, and many of the up-town cross streets, ...

There is a convalescent patient, an Alsacian with a perpetual-motion hobby, in the office of the insane asylum on Ward's Island, who unwittingly almost caused a sanguinary encounter yesterday afternoon between the big, black-haired, swarthy-complexioned General-Superintendent of the institution and a giant-formed newspaper reporter of foreign birth and Herr Most tendencies.
When Diedrich Kohnken, a young and unemployed laborer, was last seen enjoying life it was at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, when in an intoxicated condition he was sitting...

Coroner Hall, of Oyster Bay, Long Island, will reopen the inquest on the body of John Malone, the Centre Island brickmaker who was supposed to have been drowned in Oyster Bay Harbor Tuesday by the upsetting of a boat.

HOTEL KAATERSKILL, New-York, July 8.-- A handsome, many looking boy of about 7 Summers threw his arms convulsively around a lady's neck on the front piazza here this morning, and, after pressing kiss after kiss upon her pale lips, the little fellow said: "Don't cry any more, mamma, dear; I'll never fall in the water again."

BOSTON, July 8.--Insurance Commissioner Merrill begins his administration by attacking the methods of the New-York Life Insurance Company, and insurance circles are somewhat excited over the arrest of two of that company's agents. The parties arrested are Frederick Webber, of 115 to 119 Broadway, New-York, and Charles M. Moore, of that city.

LEIPSIC, July 8.--Klein and Grobert, two of the men who have been on trial here on a charge of treason, were to-day convicted. Klein was sentenced to six years in the penitentiary and Grobert to five years.

Justice Cullen, of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, has just rendered a decision denying a motion for a new trial in the somewhat courtworn case of Louis Abrams against the Van Brunt-Street and Erie Basin Railway Company.
PHILADELPHIA, July 8.--Assistant District Attorney Kinsey sent into the Grand Jury to-day an indictment in the following words:

The New-Yorks lost a game to the Detroits on the Polo Grounds yesterday. Judging from the closeness of the scores one would suppose that the game was an interesting one, but such was not the case. The New-Yorks played lifelessly, and while their opponents did not make a much better showing they managed to score the larger number of runs. George, the left-handed pitcher, was put in against the visiting batsmen.
About 500 or 600 English children and their parents were taken out this morning for a splendid treat to Acheres, in the St. Germain Forest, under the care of the Jubilee Committee.
United States Circuit Court Judge Lacombe sat on the bench for the first time yesterday, and heard motion after motion like a veteran.

The first annual grand afternoon and evening missionary picnic, under the auspices of the African Methodist Episcopal Bethel Church in Sullivan-street, took place at Sulzer's Park, Harlem, yesterday. Judging from appearances it will never occur again.

CHICAGO, July 8.--The Executors and Trustees under the will of Phoebe L. Smith, who died on Dec. 24, 1885, are in a deep quandary. Mrs. Smith willed property to the Chicago Foundlings' Home, the Woman's Union Mission,...

CHICAGO, July 8.--Mr. Cleveland's Chicago friends have had a chance to read his letter declining to visit St. Louis, and they were more willing to-day to talk about it. THE TIMES'S correspondent met and conversed with a large number of these gentlemen during the day, and was unable to find one who did not think that the letter was a strong and able document, dignified, patriotic, and to the point.

CHICAGO, July 8.--The big strike and lock-out of the bricklayers and stone masons of Chicago will probably come to an end to-morrow and the result will be a capital illustration of the value of arbitration in settling such difficulties.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, July 8.--The Constitution of the proposed State of Utah was completed and adopted yesterday by the Mormon Convention. The provisions for the entire separation of Church and State, for non-sectarian education, forbidding the employment or...

MONTREAL, July 8.--A painful scene was witnessed this morning during the preliminary investigation in the case of Herbert Taylor, charged with forging the name of Mr. Blaine. While one of the witnesses was being examined...

PUTNAM, Conn., July 8.--The mother of "Doc" Wilson, of the famous Wilson-Moen mystery, has died at East Thompson, the causes given being "old age, apoplexy, and worriment." She made no confession concerning "Doc" Wilson's birth.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 8.--Edward Brunks's cistern manufactory, on North Water-street, was destroyed by fire this morning. Henry Bettman, aged 45 years, endeavored to secure his tools and was burned to death. He leaves a widow and several children. Loss, $1,250.

CHICAGO, July 8.--Receiver John McNulta of the Wabash Eastern Railway has decided to ignore section 4 of the inter-State commerce law (the long and short haul clause) in so far as it applies to traffic over his lines from Peoria and Chicago to the East.

Lizzie Strol, aged 10, of 237 West Fortysixth-street, and Louis Westphal, aged 9, of 310 West Thirty-eighth-street, were sitting on a stoop in West Forty-sixth-street, near Sixth-avenue, yesterday afternoon, when a high mettled horse,...

At Terrace Garden last evening Supe's popular operetta, "Boccaccio," was given before a large audience, which received the work with every demonstration of delight. It is hardly necessary to enter into any extended comment on the performance of this operetta as given at Terrace Garden, because it has hitherto been considered.

DETROIT, July 8.--The June output of the Lake Superior copper mines was as follows: Calumet and Hecla, 2,839 tons, the largest month's product in the history of this wonderful mine; Quincy, 210 tons; Atlantic, 202 tons.
AYER, Mass., July 8.-"Shang" Campbell, a noted pickpocket of New-York City, was arrested at Clinton this morning by State Officer Hayter.
WASHINGTON, July 8.--The President's letter declining to visit St. Louis in September has set all the friends of the Grand Army to explaining.

The little town of Arlington, N.J., which was shaken Wednesday morning by an explosion in the works of the Cellonite Manufacturing Company, looks as if it had been visited by an earthquake, and all day yesterday streams of visitors flowed in to view the scene of destruction.

Staten Island business men are up in arms against the management of the ferries upon which they have to depend for freight and passenger service to this city. Most business houses on the island were established when landings were made at various points on the north, east, and south shores, as had been customary for more than 50 years.

BOSTON, July 8.--Counsel for the Andover Professors have served notice upon the Board of Visitors of an appeal to the Supreme Court from the recent decision condemning Prof. Albert Smyth. The court will meet in November. The exact form of the appeal is not stated.

BOSTON, July 8.--The papers in the transfer of the Advertiser and Record were to have passed yesterday, but at the last moment Mr. C. E. Whitin decided against making the investment, and declined to consummate the trade.

All danger of a tie-up on the Brooklyn Cable Road has been obviated by an agreement which President Johnson and a committee of the men reached yesterday. It is similar to the one existing between the Brooklyn City and Atlantic-Avenue Companies and their employes.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 8.--Dr. E.N. North, of Peru, who was shot on Wednesday morning by James Christianson, died this morning at 4 o'clock. Christianson was taken from jail on Wednesday night by a mob and hanged from a bridge over the Wabash River.

EDINBURGH, July 8.--Mr. Blaine and Senators Hale and Frye, of Maine, arrived here last evening. The freedom of the city was conferred upon Mr. Andrew Carnegie to-day in recognition of his gift to the city of $250,000, with which to provide a public library. The ceremony took plane in the Council Chamber.

The extraordinary success of Miss Ramsay in the classical tripos at Cambridge; the more natural but still remarkable feat of Miss Hervey in the mediaeval and modern languages tripos, and the less brilliant, if even more solid, achievement of two ladies from Newnham at the same time, which has not been so much noticed as it deserves, are the real academical events of the past week.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 8.--Remittiturs from the Court of Appeals in the cases of the Buffalo Lubricating Oil Company (Limited) against the Standard Oil Company, and the Buffalo Lubricating Oil Company against Hiram B. Everest and others were filed this morning.

KEY WEST, Fla., July 8.--The steward of the United States Marine Hospital was taken down with the fever this evening. Dr. Guiteras deems it very unwise to remove him to the yellow fever hospital, and has telegraphed for permission for him to remain in the marine building, where he can have every care.

HUDSON, N.Y., July 8.--About 1 o'clock this morning a south-bound cattle train on the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad collided with an engine and caboose running the same way at Hallenbeck's Switch, three miles south of this city.
BOSTON, Mass., July 8.--The steamer Lewiston, of the Boston and Bangor Line, which arrived here yesterday, reports having been in collision early in the morning off Monhegan with an unknown schooner.

The Mormons' Constitutional Convention has completed its work and the Constitution prepared by it will be submitted to the legal voters of the Territory on Aug. 1. The confidence expressed by the Mormons with regard to the acceptance of this Constitution by Congress has been as remarkable as their recent outburst of patriotism.

The new Corporation Counsel, Morgan J. O'Brien, yesterday rendered his first official opinion. It was called for by the Park Commissioners as to the intent of the bicycle and tricycle law recently passed by the Legislature.

TIRNOVA, July 8.--Prince Ferdinand of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha, replying to the Sobranje's dispatch informing him of his election as Prince of Bulgaria, said he was proud of the honor conferred upon him and grateful for it. "I hope," he added, "to prove myself worthy of the confidence of the Bulgarian people.
George Addy, the enemy of the telephone company in Paterson, N.J., was yesterday made defendant in three criminal suits instituted against him.

The news columns of THE TIMES to-day show that finally Mr. Russell Sage and Mr. Jay Gould have extracted from Mr. Cyrus W. Field that "statement" which they have been so emphatically demanding as their due. What benefits it may confer they have.
ST. LOUIS, July 8.--The Sunday law was pulverized in one round by Judge Noonan in the Court of Criminal Correction this morning, and everything will be running wide open next Sunday.
CINCINNATI, July 8.--The Republican State Convention will be held in Toledo on the 27th and 28th of this month. Arrangements will be made to-morrow for the election of delegates from this county.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 8.--From inquiries among prominent merchants and warehousemen of the State whose business brings them into contact with the farming community, it is ascertained that the cotton crop is fuller of fruit than ever known before at this season of the year, that the yield will be much larger, and that it has been worked at 25 per cent. less expense than last year.

MADISON, Ind., July 8.--A violent wind and rain storm struck this locality at 5 o'clock this afternoon, uprooting trees, prostrating wires, flooding streets, and forcing river craft ashore. No lives were lost.

ST. LOUIS, July 8.--Maxwell's attorneys have abandoned his case and say there is no hope for him. Mr. Fauntleroy said to-day that he had determined not to attempt to carry the case to the United States Supreme Court, because...

LANSING, Mich., July 8.--The Secretary of State to-day furnishes the following statement of acreage and yield of wheat at the time the supervisors took the assessment last Spring: Area in wheat in the southern counties, 1,414,820...

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 8.--Before the title of the Old Senate House, Kingston, can pass to the State, the Trustees of Public Buildings of the State, consisting of the Governor, Lieutenant-Governor, and Speaker of the Assembly, must receive a statement that the cost of putting the building in repair, beautifying the grounds, , will not exceed the sum appropriated.

Mr. POWDERLY may not be a very wise man, and he has certainly undertaken a task much beyond his powers in attempting to regulate the relations of labor and capital throughout the United States. Nevertheless, his position entitles him to speak for the great majority of men who do manual labor for wages.
The funeral of Edward Lamb, the well known actor, took place at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon from his residence, 379 Sixth-street, Brooklyn.

Philip Daly, proprietor of the Pennsylvania Club, and L.A. Bullard, proprietor of the Ocean Club, at Long Branch, were arrested Thursday evening on compiant of Robert S. Durham and Joseph Hopper, proprietors of the Long Branch Turf Club.
Nicholas Muller, Jr., a son of ex-Congressman Muller, has been appointed General Eastern Passenger Agent of the Delaware, Lackawanna and West ern Railroad Company.

Special coupon tickets for admission to the Lyceum Theatre have been missed during several weeks past from the office of Daniel P. Finn, the advertising agent of the theatre. Howard J. Patterson, who is 25 years of age, of 56 East Thirteenthstreet, who was employed as a clerk in the office, was suspected.

The Pennsylvania, the Erie, and the Baltimore and Ohio, and possibly the New-York Central are the railroads which are understood to have objected to the decision of the Freight Classification Committee of the trunk lines not to change the existing classification of cotton piece goods.

Jacob Sharp's condition yesterday was worse than on any other day since he has been confined in Ludlow-Street Jail. He slept very little Thursday night, and felt so weak that he did not get up until about 11 o'clock. During the day he was able to take very little food, his stomach refusing even the weak clam broth on which he almost entirely subsists.
CHEBOYGAN, Mich., July 8.--Capt. Hallock, of the fishing tug Messenger, which arrived here yesterday, reports that a terrible scourge is raging on Cockburn Island, Lake Huron.
BOSTON, July 8.--The check of E.D. Morgan, in payment for the sloop Mayflower, was received in Boston to-day and the yacht was turned over to Capt. Harry Craver, of NewYork.

William Burns, who keeps a saloon at 48 Hudson-avenue, Brooklyn, and is regarded as a power among the Democratic politicians in the Eleventh Ward, is missing, and his creditors are after him with all the speed they can command.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 8.--From time to time during the past two years judgments aggregating $12,424 have been confessed by the Whitehill Sewing Machine Company, and as there appeared to be no likelihood of their being paid, ...

A grand campfire and reception was given last night at Elizabeth, N.J., by the Veteran Zouaves in honor of Gen. John C. Black, United States Commissioner of Pensions. The General arrived from Washington about 8 o'clock, attended by Major Frank A. Butts, Chief of the Division of Army and Navy Survivors.
Long Island, sportsmen flocked from all parts to Dexter Park, Long Island, yesterday to witness the pigeon shooting match between the Glenmore and the Coney Island Rod and Gun Club.
Twenty years ago Maurice B. Flynn and Guy C. Hotchkiss, Jr., were rivals for the goodwill of Guy C. Hotchkiss, the senior member of the firm of Guy C. Hotchkiss, Field Co., ...

NEWPORT, July 8.--A general inquiry among Democrats and fair-minded Republicans reveals a general sentiment of approval of the President's course in refusing to go to St. Louis at the time of the National Encampment there.

CERRO GORDO, Ill., July 8.--Mrs. Margaret Green, an old resident of this place, died at Swallow Branch Township to-day, aged 83 years. When Abraham Lincoln was afflicted with smallpox at Beardstown, Ill., many years ago, Mrs. Green was his nurse.
MIDDLETOWN, July 8.--The most wonderful escape from death by lightning stroke ever known in this section occurred about 4 o'clock Thursday afternoon near Searsville, in this county.

Two weeks ago William Stewart, who lives at Crosby's Beach, found a seal pup about 3 months old on the beach near his place. Mr. Stewart carried the little orphan to his house, about 100 yards away, where it appeared perfectly contented and happy in company with the...

SAN FRANCISCO, July 8.--The Chronicle devotes two pages to letters and affidavits found among the effects of the late Abner L. Blake, formerly Deputy United States Collector at Port Townsend, Washington Territory, who died under what were considered mysterious circumstances, at Chicago, last May, while on his way to Washington.
The clerk of the weather, placidly seated at five minutes after midnight in his tall tower of the Equitable Building, enunciated these prognostications for to-day.
A distinguished stranger arrived at the Cotton Exchange yesterday and attracted a great deal of attention before it was auctioned off by J.H. Draper in the afternoon.
William Kelly, who had been suffering from lockjaw for over a week, died in the Long Island College Hospital at an early hour yesterday morning.
Mrs. Lily Langtry, the English actress, has established her abode at 1,220 Twenty-firststreet, where, according to current rumor, she will live for some months to come.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 8.--Some time ago a dispute arose between Wearon J. Carman, a resident of Harper County, and two neighbors named Woodruff. The latter contested Carman's claim to land near Meade Centre, on the ground...

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 8.--Some 200 Irish-American and other citizens of St. Paul last night sat down to a banquet tendered the Earl of Aberdeen, late Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, now on his way East from the Pacific coast.

Will the Grand Army of the Republic, as an organization, have the grace to apologize to the President and people of the United States for the insult it has put upon both? Our Washington dispatch says that the President's letter "has set the Grand Army men to explaining."

Seven races are to be run at Monmouth Park to-day, including the run for the Monmouth Oaks and a steeplechase over the full course. There should be good races, for Capt. Coster's handicapping has made them very much of a puzzle. It ought to be a pretty good day for outsiders under the circumstances.

House property shows no sign of falling off in value in Paris, judging from a sale that took place last week. One of the most beautiful and commodious of the houses in the Avenue du Bois de Boulogne was sold by its late owner for nearly 40,000 more than it cost him shortly after the Franco-German war.
DALTON, Ga., July 8.--Gov. Gordon late last night commuted the death sentence of William Hollman, accused of the murder of his mistress, Matild Gudger, to imprisonment for life.

The trial of Dorothea Horn, the keeper of the intelligence office at 168 Third-avenue, who was indicted for sending respectable girls to immoral houses, was yesterday ended in the Court of General Sessions.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 8.--The convention of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union of New-Jersey, now being held here, continued its sessions to-day, Mrs. A.C. White con ducting the opening exercises.

Ever since Thomas B. Kerr, who was jointly indicted with Jacob Sharp, James A. Richmond, and James W. Foshay in connection with the bribing of the 1884 Board of Aldermen to pass the Broadway Railroad franchise, was thrown from his carriage while driving on Seventh-avenue and seriously injured, reporters have called daily at his house, 44 West Fiftysixth street, to ascertain his condition.

WASHINGTON, July 8.--The story of "Jim, the Penman," that has so interested and excited thousands of playgoers in New-York and other cities for many months, is matched by the story of Oscar J. Harvey, a clerk of the Treasury Department, who was arrested yesterday at Wilkesbarre, Penn., and to-night reflects upon his crime in the District Jail, whither he wassent in default of $12,000 bail demanded as the condition of his release pending trial.

Henry George was received with great enthusiasm at Garnett Hall, in West Twenty-thirdstreet, last night. The place was filled with a generous number of his supporters in the Eleventh Assembly District, both white and colored. Frank Farrell, the colored politican and orator, acted as Chairman, and introduced the speakers.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 8.--The National Association of Vapor Stove Manufacturers to-day chose these officers: President--George M. Clark, of Chicago; Vice-President--W.M. Lattridge, of Cleveland;

LONDON, July 8.--At to-day's meeting of the Board of Directors of the Panama Canal Company at Paris it was decided unanimously to issue 500,000 new shares at 440f., bearing 30f. interest and reimbursable at 1,000f. in 48 years, by bi-monthly drawings.

Speaker Husted was in town yesterday, and announced that he had accepted the Presi dency of the Hartford, Connecticut and Western Railroad Company, the new company into which has been merged the New-England and Southwestern Railroad Company, whose road is designed to connect the Poughkeepsie Bridge with the New-York Central and Hudson River, the Boston and Albany, the Harlem, the Pennsyl vania, the Lehigh Valley, and other roads.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 8.--John D. Van Gorden, 69 years of age, of Dingman's Ferry, Pike County, Penn., was killed by a bee sting on the wrist on Wednesday morning.
MONTREAL, July 8.--James Hoffman, aged 23 years, a native of New-Jersey, was brought to this city yesterday and taken to the hospital, where he died shortly afterward.

WASHINGTON, July 8.--An evening paper says: "As soon as Minister Lawton is received officially at Vienna Mr. J. Fenner Lee, Secretary of the Legation, and, during the absence of a regular Minister, Charge d'Affaires, will resign. His successor has been agreed upon, and will be announced as soon as Gen. Lawton informs the department of his reception by the Austrian Government."

GLOUCESTER, Mass., June 8.--The open city regatta, which was declared off July 4, was sailed this afternoon in Gloucester Harbor. The course was eight miles, and the start was made at 2:30 before a fine southeast breeze.

Frederic R. Coudert, speaking of the President's letter yesterday, said: "It is one of the most powerful papers the President ever wrote. It is very forcible and very proper. The President cannot afford to have mud thrown upon him by any one or any organization.

MONTREAL, July 8.--McDougall, Logie Co., paint, oil, and varnish manufacturers, assigned today on the demand of A. Ferguson Co., of Glasgow, Scotland, who are interested to the extent of $80,000. The total liabilities will probably amount to $200,000, and the assets are nominally about the same amount.

WASHINGTON, July 8.--The following changes have been made in the duties and stations of officers of the Medical Department of the army: Lieut.-Col. Anthony Homer, Surgeon, now awaiting orders in New-York, has been ordered to duty as Post Surgeon at Fort Columbus, New-York Harbor; Major John H. Janaway, Surgeon, relieved from duty at Fort Columbus, New-York, and ordered to duty at Benicia Barracks; Capt. Henry P. Birmingham, Assistant...

It is evident that the Sobranje, warned by its experience with Prince WALDEMAR, took precautions before its recent election to choose as ruler of Bulgaria one who would accept the trust. Prince FERDINAND MAXIMILLIAN CHARLES LEOPOLD MARIE of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha has responded with remarkable promptness to the official...

John Forrester, a packer, living at 464 Greenwich-street, was taken to the ChambersStreet Hospital about 1:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon suffering from a stab wound in the abdomen. Forrester fainted from weakness and loss of blood just as he was crossing the threshold, and it was some time before he recovered consciousness.

OSKALOOSA, Iowa, July 8.--Engineer John Short and Fireman James Huckiski were fatally in jured by the explosion of a boiler in the Excelsior mine this afternoon. The cause of the explosion is unknown.

LONDON, July 9.--An anonymous letter published in to-day's Times calls the attention of that paper to what the writer declares to be the fact that its articles on "Parnellism and Crime" have seriously perturbed the Parnellites and their allies in America, particularly the Irish World. BOSTON, July 9.--The retail coal dealers met to-day and advanced the prices of coal an average of 25 cents per ton over the previous lowest prices. In all outlying districts the prices will be 25 cents higher per ton.

JANESVILLE, Wis., July 9.--The sensational divorce case of Emma J. Arthur against the Rev. C. M. Arthur, of Dakota Territory, ended this morning, and a decree was granted. NEWTOWN, Penn., July 10.--The Holland Post Office and the store of Joseph Finney, on the Newtown Railroad, was broken into last night. The safe was blown open and about $300 was taken, besides a quantity of stamps and merchandise. The noise awakened the family, but the robbers prevented them from entering the store by firing a pistol repeatedly.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10.--Everybody up in Manayunk was talking to-day of the sad death of little Eddie McDade. Eddie, a lighthaired, blue-eyed lad of 15 years, was the crack catcher of the Mount Vernon Baseball Club, and was playing behind the home plate yesterday afternoon when a swift foul tip from the bat of young Mickey Curley of the Liberty Club, struck him in the neck and broke his windpipe. He died four hours later.

Yesterday morning as he was preparing to leave he placed in his valise, among other things, a loaded revolver and his gold watch. He set the valise on a table in his room, and while moving some things that were near it he knocked it off on the floor.
A portrait of Mme. de Pompadour, by Boucher, brought $50,000 in a recent London sale.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 10.--The debut of McMullen, the "California Wonder," was made here to-day in the presence of nearly 7,000 people, who went into hysterics from laughing at the awful exhibition given by the Wonder and his support.
--Truth, of London, hears that Cardinal Newman contemplates publishing this Autumn a volume of autobiographical reminiscences.

Mr. Mansfield's new play called "Monsieur" will have its first public performance at the Madison-Square Theatre to-night. A dress rehearsal of the piece was watched with interest by a few friends of Mr. Mansfield last evening. The new scenery is very pretty, and all the actors were as carefully dressed and "made-up" as if the representation had been public. The rehearsal was smooth and satisfactory.

Three thousand people willingly, enthusiastically, gleefully, with an abandon wonderful to witness, permitted their individuality to be utterly and completely absorbed last night in the personality of Dr. Edward McGlynn. These people attended the eleventh meeting of the Anti-Poverty Society.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10.--A party of 10, including Parry Seivle and his wife, of Twenty-eighth and Porter streets, went sailing on the Delaware to-day. During the trip, when off Gloucester, Robert Hartley, one of the party, fell overboard, and in endeavoring to rescue him the beat was capsized and Hartley and Mrs. Seivle were drowned. Mrs. Seivle was only 18 years of age.

Archbishop Corrigan's pastoral, giving notice of Dr. McGlynn's excommunication, which was published in yesterday's Catholic and secular journals, will not be read in the Catholic churches of the archdiocese either next Sunday or at any later time. The authorities seem resolved to make the pastoral their last word in the case and not to publish any more facts connected with it unless compelled by necessity.

UNITED STATES SHIP CONSTELLATION, NEW-LONDON, Conn., July 10.--At West Point the young soldiers spend the Summer in camp and learn from experience the requirements of a soldier; our young sailors spend their Summer in Chesapeake Bay and on the Atlantic, and they not only learn what a sailor's life must be, but they actually perform the work of blue jackets, and in fact compose half of the working crew of the old Constellation.

HALIFAX, July 10.--The steamer Merrimack, one of the packet line steamers between Boston, Halifax, and Charlottetown, left here for Boston Saturday at 4 o'clock, and is reported ashore at Little Hope, a small island on this coast. She Will be a total loss.

OSAKA, Japan, June 1.--That the Japanese Government, and to the extent of their knowledge the Japanese people, are trying earnestly to take a stand among the most civilized nations becomes pleasingly apparent so soon as one has an opportunity to observe them at all closely.

DAYTON, Ohio, July 11.--Katie Duffy, an inmate of the Southern Ohio Insane Asylumm, died at that institution to-day from an overdose of morphine, administered by mistake by a nurse. The patient was an incurable, and in a weak condition.

COLUSA, Cal., July 11.--At about 12:30 o'clock yesterday morning Hong Di, the Chinese domestic who murdered Mrs. Billiou at St. John some time ago, taken from jail and hanged by a mob. NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 11.--Albert Inslee, a well-to-do young man, who lives at Woodbridge, a short distance from this city, cut his throat yesterday with a razor with suicidal intent. Inslee is temporarily insane. The attending physician has slight hopes of his recovery. Woodbridge has had four suicides in as many weeks, and also four accidental deaths.

PUTNAM, Conn., July 11.--One hundred and fifty weavers of the Quinnebaug Mill, at Danielsonville, have struck, in consequence of which the entire mill will shut down until satisfactory arrangements are made. This throws between 500 and 600 hands out of employment. The cause is an outgrowth of the ten-hour and weekly payment law. The corporation will make no concession.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 11.--Commissioner O. R. Fyler, of the State Insurance Department here, will order a special examination concerning the value of the Standard Cement Company's stock, which is held to the amount of $200,000 by the Continental Life Insurance Company, of this city. LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 11.--A 16-year-old boy named Potter left Portia last evening to ride home in company with a man named Lester. When they got on the outskirts of the town Potter drew a pistol, demanding Lester's money. The latter handed over $150. At the same time he drew a revolver and shot Potter, who also fired, seriously injuring Lester.

United States Deputy Marshal Biggart went from Brooklyn to Astoria yesterday and arrested Frank Sweeney, an employe in the Post Office there. He was taken to the United States Court and held for examination.
OPELIKA, Ala., July 12.--A heavy cloud, followed by a brilliant electrical display, passed over this place yesterday.

The trial of Giuseppe Crifasi for the murder of Bartholomew Caresi was begun in the Court of General Sessions before Recorder Smyth yesterday. Only nine jurors had been obtained when the panel was exhausted, and the case was adjourned until 11 A.M. to-day.
PHILADELPHIA, July 12.--Two railroads controlled by the same company were chartered at the State Department at Harrisburg to-day, with a capital stock of $25,000,000.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 12.--It was expected that the monthly meeting of the Central Traffic Association at the Clifton House, Niagara Falls, to-day would be one of the most important and largely attended in the history of that body.

The fourteenth day of July is to Frenchmen much the same as the fourth day of July to Americans. On that day occurred the famous storming of the Bastile. As usual patriotic Frenchmen will observe the occasion to-morrow as is befitting. The Union of the French Societies of New-York, composed of five delegates from each of the 16 societies here, have arranged for an elaborate celebration of the national holiday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12.--Five boys went in swimming at Felty's Island in the Delaware near Kensington this afternoon. Three were drowned and two barely escaped with their lives.

BOSTON, July 12.--Mrs. Sarah Jane Robinson, now awaiting trial on six indictments for murder by poison, was subjected to a rigid examination to-day by a medical expert, the object being to ascertain her mental condition. The visit occupied over two hours, the time being taken up by conversation, of which the woman monopolized a considerable share.

BOSTON, July 12.--The Bell Telephone Company will hold an important meeting tomorrow, when it will undergo partial change in management. President W.H. Forbes will resign, and will be succeeded by Howard Stockton.

The branch of the United Labor Party which George D. Lennon leads met at Clarendon Hall last night in the room occupied the night before by the rival faction. NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 12.--Coroner Newton, of Woodbridge, was called to-day to take the ante-mortem statement of his sister-inlaw, Miss Louise Tucker. Miss Tucker, who is 20 years of age, shot herself in the head with a small pistol with suicidal intent. She cannot live, Some months ago her lover assaulted her, and since then she has been nervous and in delicate health.

The New Parks Commission met at their headquarters in the London and Liverpool and Globe Insurance Building yesterday and decided to hereafter hear the cases of property owners next Friday, and on Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and Thursdays of succeeding weeks until the commission may decide to take a vacation.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 12.--Special dispatches from Addison tell of great devastation by fire just over the Pennsylvania line. Many thousands of cords of tan bark, a million feet of logs, and large quantities of manufactured lumber have been destroyed, and a big trestle on the Addison and North Pennsylvania Railroad met the same fate. PITTSBURG, July 12.--In connection with the fourteenth annual council of the Hebrew congregations of America, held in Concordia Hall, Allegheny City, to-day, a question of international interest is presented.

CHICAGO, July 12.--Judge Tuthill this morning made an important ruling in the case of Berkowitz against John T. Lester Co., a suit to recover from the defendants a balance claimed to be due on the purchase and sale of some railroad stocks.

BOSTON, July 12.--The impression is gradually gaining among local insurance people that Insurance Commissioner Merrill made a serious mistake in arresting the agents of the New-York Life Insurance Company a few days ago.

Yesterday saw the first political fight in the Brooklyn Board of Education. Observers of the course of Mayor Whitney in his appointments of a year ago and in those of the present month were not surprised at the outcome of yesterday's election.

The Rev. Dr. McGlynn said yesterday, will reference to his excommunication, that he had not received any notice of his excommunication by name, and the only information he had about it was through the daily papers.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 12.--Drafts on NewYork--Sight, 20 cents; telegraphic, 30 cents.

LYNCHBURG, Va., July 12.--Grape rot is reported all through the Piedmont section, and the crop is virtually destroyed, Grape culture has become an important industry there, and the loss will be heavy.

The Rev. Tabor Knox was installed last evening as Pastor of the Second Reformed Church of Tarrytown to succeed the Rev. John Todd, who was for 33 years the faithful Pastor of that church, and why resigned a little over a year ago.

ROCKINGHAM, N.C., July 12.--Archie Martin, (colored,) who murdered Henry McNeill, (colored,) last May, was hanged here to-day. The execution was private, and was witnessed by only about 75 people, although 2,000 or more were attracted to the town by the event Martin acknowledged his guilt and said he was prepared to die.

BOSTON, July 12.--Mr. Joseph B. Lincoln, of the wholesale boot and shoe firm of Batchelder Lincoln, 96 Federal-street, was robbed of nearly $400 in money and a gold watch and chain last night by a burglar who effected an entrance to his Commonwealth-avenue residence.

EL PASO, Texas, July 12.--A package of circulars, evidently intended to stir up feeling against the Mexicans, was received here yesterday. The circular opens with "Official Bulletin No. 1: Headquarters American and Northern Mexico, ...
The strike on the Brooklyn Elevated Road is an exception to the recent rule. The men know what they are striking for, and there is a very good prospect that they will get it.

ST. LOUIS, July 12.--The St. Louis Club lost their second game this season to Brooklyn to-day, Harkins being the stumubling block in both games. The home team started out as if determined to annihilate Harkins, but after the first inning he changed their course.
Capt. Thomas Morley, one of the oldest Sandy Hook pilots, died suddenly yesterday at his home, 195 Willoughby-street, Brooklyn.

CHARLESTOWN, N.H., July 12.--Mr. Charles H. Hoyt, known to the public as the author of "A Hole in the Ground," "A Tin Soldier," and other successful farces, and Miss Flora Walsh, a young actress, were married here this evening at the country home of the bridegroom.

A Chinaman was arraigned at the Tombs Police Court yesterday charged with drunkenness. A policeman found him in Mott-street Monday night annoying his fellow-countrymen. He is the only known Chinese tramp in the country, and has acquired all the attributes and habits of the genus. When he was sentenced to six months in the workhouse he placidly remarked. "Me no care."
The report of Gen. Newton, Commissioner of Public Works, giving the transactions of his department for the quarter ending June 30, shows that the expenditures for that period were $933,515 86.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 12.--The people of the northern part of Sussex County, N.J., and of Unionville and Pine Island, this county, are undergoing another torment from the mosquito plague.
The Appraisers who have been summoned here to improve the classification of the tariff schedules expect a fortnight of tedious work.
With only two exceptions, the railroads reporting earnings in Wall-street yesterday for the first week of July show increases as compared with the figures for the same week of last year.
ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, July 12.--W. R. Wallace, ship builders and ship owners, have made an assignment for the benefit of their creditors.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 12.--A dispatch from Alexandria Rapide Parish announces the destruction by fire of an old landmark in that section.

George H. Meyer, a well known lawyer of Brooklyn, has disappeared and left a large number of creditors. He was to have been married soon and was fitting up a home at 350 Bedfordavenue for his bride.

TIRNOVA, July 12.--A new Cabinet for Bulgaria has been formed as follows: M. Stolloff, President of the Council and ad interim Minister of Finance; M. Natchevics, Minister of Foreign Affairs; M. Tchomekoff, Minister of Public Instruction; M. Stranskey, Minister of the Interior; Majet Petroff, Minister of War. M. Stolloff has telegraphed to the prefects of departments ordering them to release all political prisoners.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 12.--Just before the game to-day "Pete" Browning, who has been on a howling drunk, was fined $110 by Manager Kelly, of the Louisvilles.
Chewing gum is a means of salvation to a certain extent to the man who bets on a horse race. It's a salvation only in preventing him from "giving himself away."

Thomas Dilverd, or "Japanese Tommy," as he was known to the amusement world, died of asthma at the Colored Home and Hospital on East Sisty-fifth-street last Saturday, and was buried yesterday in Mrs. Margaret Loy's lot in Evergreens Cemetery.

CHICAGO, July 12.--The surprise of the day's racing at Washington Park to-day was the easy fashion in which Bonita, who sold in the field, won the Great Western Handicap, defeating all the "sure things." Details of the races are as follows:

Efforts are continued by corporations desiring to obtain the privilege of laying electric wires under ground to obstruct the work of the Board of Control which has charge of constructing a system of subways in behalf of the public.

The yacht Mystery, whose overturning in Canarsie Channel on Sunday caused the death of so many persons, floated peacefully in the calm waters of Canarsie Bay yesterday and was an object of interest to many visitors. It was a matter of wonder to many how Capt. Hendrickson bad loaded so many women and children in the small craft.

About 2,000 persons saw the New-Yorks lose another game to the Pittsburgs yesterday. Sworback, of the Reserves, pitched, and was hit rather freely by the visiting batsmen, but he was poorly supported and errors, especially two ...

TRENTON, N.J., July 12.--Justices Bradley and Nixon sat in the Federal court to-day to hear the arguments on the motion to dissolve the injunction granted recently by Chancellor McGill to restrain the Baltimore and New-York ...
Philip Tillinghast, a well known stock broker, of the late firm of Atterbury Tillinghast, has been placed in the hands of a Receiver.
John Schwarz, a tailor, of 77 Prince-street, Newark, was arraigned before Justice Roder yesterday morning on the charge of luring young girls into his store and leading them into crime.
LONGON, July 12.--The steamship British Queen, (Br.,) Capt. Wills, from New-York July 2, for Liverpool, passed Kinsale to-day.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 12.--Mrs. Nicholas Mechersheimer was grossly insulted this forenoon on one of the Naugatuck trains by John Conners. When she arrived in Birmingham she informed her husband.
PORTLAND, Oregon, July 12.--A disastrous flood has occurred at Thompson Falls, Idaho, from the breaking of a big dam on Blossom Lake.

WIMINGTON, Del., July 12.--The sudden and rather mysterious death of Richard T. Crossland, Matilda Crossland, his wife, and Harriet, an 11-months-old daughter, which have occurred within the past few days at their home near ...

CHARLESTON, S.C., July 12.--The committee appointed by the clerical and lay delegates who withdrew from the Diocesan Episcopal Convention in Charleston last May have completed their statement of the cause which led to the withdrawal.

The fight over the will of the late John Masterton was ended yesterday by the admission of the document by Surrogate Lott in Brooklyn. Masterton was a wealthy builder who came from Albany to New-York and became a politician.

The negotiations which have been pending for a long time between E.H. Sothern, of the Lyceum Theatre, and Miss Helen Dauvray for the release of the gentleman from his contract to play with Miss Dauvray's company next season were finally terminated yesterday.
Two well known thieves, James Martin, alias "London Harry," alias "Squid," and Daniel Cassidy, alias "Smarty," were hold in $1,500 bail for examination at the Tombs Police Court ...
Ex-Gov. F.W.M. Holliday, of Virginia, is at the Astor House. Judge George M. Beebe, of Monticello, N. Y., is at the Hoffman House.

Queen Kapiolani has turned her face toward the setting sun and started with anxious look and troubled heart for her home, the little seagirt kingdom of Hawaii Nei. She went in a special car, and her party with her, by the 6:30 train last evening over the New-York Central.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 12.--Among the important bills introduced in the House is one from Mr. Glenn, of Whitfield, intended to protect the rights of white and colored people alike by making it an indictable offense for teachers or, ...

The partial tie-up on the Brooklyn Elevated Road is still in force, and only eight trains were sent over the tracks yesterday. These were drawn by engines in charge of men taken from the machine shops.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., July 12.--P.H. Cummins, ex-Master Workman District No. 65, Knights of Labor, was expelled last night from Amsterdam Lodge, No. 134, I.O.O.F., for having been instrumental in placing and keeping up a boycott on...
The New-York and Pittsburg Clubs will play again to-day. Tiernan has been doing great work with the bat for New-York.

LOGANSPORT, Ind., July 12.--At 2 o'clock this morning Mr. W.A. Garner, a resident of Royal Centre, in the northern part of the county, was awakened by some one groping around the rooms. Seeing a form at a window he thought it was a burglar, and he fired at it. The body fell. When he got a light he found he has shot his wife, and she was dead.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 12.--This forenoon the generator of the soda fountain in Hair's drug store exploded with terrible force and broke both legs below the knees of James Martin, the clerk.

The anniversary of the battle of the Boyne was celebrated in Paterson in Belfast style. The local lodge of Orangemen had, as guests, lodges from Newark and Jersey City, and there was a parade and picnic.

The body of W.W. Bunce, of Saratoga, was picked up off the new iron pier at West Brighton yesterday morning. Bunce was missed from Tilyou's bathing pavilion on Friday evening. He was a watchman employed by the NewYork Central Railroad, and was 28 years old. He was to have been married soon.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 12.--It is now well known that the friends of Senator Sherman have given out the word that a resolution will be introduced in the State Convention two weeks hence, pledging the Republican Party of Ohio to the support of Mr. Sherman, as the choice of the State for the Presidential nomination.

ATHENS, Ga., July 12.--One of the bloodiest tragedies ever enacted in Georgia took place here to-day just before dark.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jul. 12.--Locked up in the Central Station this morning is a St. Louis murderer, John D. Shea, and the story of his crime, fight, and capture would make an interesting narrative.

LONDON, July 12.--The Baron had no trouble to-day in defeating Livingstone by two lengths in the race for the St. George Stakes at the Liverpool July meeting. The two named were the only two that ran, and the betting was 12 to 1 on The Baron.
The hay crop promises to be large this year. One of the largest dealers in this city said yesterday that the acreage in grass is fully 10 per cent. more than last year.

LONDON, July 12.--Mr. Dillon resumed the debate on the Land bill in the House of Commons to-night. He said he rejected the measure with contempt as utterly inadequate to meet the needs of the Irish tenantry.
BELFAST, July 12.--The 12th of July is being celebrated by the Orangemen throughout Ulster with unusual fervor. The Rev. Dr. Kane presided over a monster gathering in this city.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 13.--All the political signs point to the nomination of Allen G. Thurman for Governor by acclamation at the Ohio Democratic Convention to be held in this city next week. Gen. Thomas E. Powell, of the city of Delaware, would probably be the nominee if Thurman ...
The brickmakers who are standing by the manufacturers boycotted by the Knights of Labor at Verplanck's Point held another meeting yesterday at the Cosmopolitan Hotel.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 13.--About six weeks ago four acres of factories and dwellings were burned in the northern part of this city. The fire burned out for lack of water supply, and the loss was $100,000.

Overcome by remorse for some mysterious crime of the past, Alexander Gossmonn, a young Alsacian baker, committed suicide yesterday morning by shooting himself through the head. He arrived here from San Francisco Tuesday night, and about 10 o'clock went to the Hotel Muller, 22 South Fifth-avenue, where he had boarded for several years off and on prior to 1885.

Coroner Eidman began yesterday an inquest in the cases of Albert Eiles and August Hassler, who received fatal injuries during the fire on July 2 at P.J. Keary Brother's fire work and toy establishment, 343 Broadway.

The body of the 8-year-old child Anna Fargo, one of the victims of the yacht Mystery disaster, was recovered late last night within 200 feet of the scene of the accident. The body was badly disfigured, the face and hands having been nearly eaten away by fishes. It was taken to the house of her parents, 736 Park-avenue, Brooklyn, Eastern District.

"Z.V.H."--Any person dumping garbage within the limits of the city is liable to arrest. A number of the strikers in the Delamater Iron Works have applied for work. They were told that their services were not wanted.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, July 13.--The remarkable increase of the anti-Mormon vote astonishes, if it does not alarm, the Mormons. The first election since the new registration under the EdmundsTucker law, being an election for School Trustees, ...

NEW-HAVEN, July 13.--Major York signed to-day the order of the Common Council authorizing the sale of the city's interest in the Derby Railroad to W.H. Starbuck. The matter will now be carried to the courts.

WASHINGTON, July 13.--The most sensational murder that has occurred in Washington since the assassination of President Garfield was committed about 5 o'clock this evening on the corner of Fifteenth-street and Pennsylvania-avenue, opposite the northeastern end of the Treasury Department Building.

TRENTON, N.J., July 13.--The argument on the motion to dissolve the injunction restraining the Baltimore and New-York and Staten Island Rapid Transit Companies from erecting the Arthur Kill Bridge was finished in the Federal court to-day, and Justice Bradley announced that the decision would be rendered soon.
LEXINGTON, Miss., July 13.--J.S. Hoskins, Jr., one of the editors of the Lexington Bulletin, was killed in Lexington this afternoon at about 4 o'clock by R.B. Chatham.

MONTREAL, July 13.--Napoleon Labranche and a youth named Tremblay, while riding in an express wagon to-day, were instantly killed through being run into at the Cote St. Paul Railroad crossing by an express trian.

PARIS, July 13.--The German residents of this city have been ordered to remain indoors to-morrow, as it is feared that they would be attacked if they appeared on the streets during the celebration of the anniversary of the fall of the Bastile.

George Jackson, a wealthy retired manufacturer of Little Falls, N.J., was drowned last evening in his mill pond. He was an Englishman, and had been engaged in the manufacture of carpets. Some months ago he was sentenced to a year in State prison for attempted murder by shooting at a man, and a decision was expected in the Court of Errors and Appeals at the next term of court.

WASHINGTON, July 13.--The Board on Army Regulations has recommended the discontinuance of Sunday dress parades and the retention of the daily inspection. The report of the board, which is now under consideration by the Secretary of War, also recommends the condensation of the regulations into about one-half of their present volume.

CHICAGO, July 13.--The Appellate Court to-day decided the case of the Illinois Central Railroad against the Baltimore and Ohio and Chicago Railroad. This was a forcible detainer suit to recover possession of the freight grounds on the lake shore occupied by the Baltimore and Ohio.

CLINTON, N.Y., July 13.--Clinton differs from the usual country village of 1,500 residents in that it is pretty. Instead of a single main street, on which everybody lives and transacts business, it has half a dozen streets which meet at the village green, as wheel spokes meet at the hub.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 13.--Mr. and Mrs. P. T. Barnum boarded the train at Bridgeport this morning for the Adirondacks. Mr. Barnum was crowded into the doorway of the cars and his pocket picked of $200. Officer Arnold tried to capture the thief, but in the confusion he escaped. Mr. Barnum continued his journey without funds.
It strikes the ordinary observer as a rather curious circumstance that the City Paymaster should have selected a liquor saloon in which to pay the city's laborers.

There is a very good prospect that the tieup on the Brooklyn Elevated Road will be settled in some way to-day. This statement was made yesterday by Arbitration Commissioner Donovan in view of the fact that the full State Board of Arbitration will arrive to-day, and will call upon Superintendent Martin and the Executive Committee of the road at 10 o'clock.

The feature of the six races to be run at Monmouth Park to-day is the race for the Monmouth Cup, at a mile and three-quarters, for which The Bard and Troubadour are announced as the only starters. It will unquestionably be a very hot race, and as the distance suits The ...
George and Willie Brown, aged 5 and 8 years, respectively, the sons of William Brown, a truckman, who lives at 2,088 Third-avenue, were reported to the police yesterday as missing.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 13.--The jewelry store of Harvey B. Johnson, on Main-street, was entered last night by burglars who had learned in some way that Mr. Johnson received a number of diamonds valued at $7,000 yesterday. Entrance was effected through a skylight. The burglars carried off a number of gold pens and plated chains. They were frightened away before forcing open the safe, which contained the diamonds and a lot of watches.
LONDON, July 13.--The steamship Bassano, (Br.,) Capt. Rea, from New York June 29, for Gottenburg, passed the Isle of Wight to-day.

DENVER, July 13.--Among the witnesses examined to-day by the Pacific Railway investigating committee were J.K. Choate, Superintendent of the Colorado Division of the Union Pacific; J.B. Felker, formerly State Railroad Commissioner for Colorado; Willard Teller, one of the local attorneys of the Union Pacific; Edmund H. Smith, editor of the Denver Evening Telegram, and a number of local merchants.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 13.--Everybody complained of the heat here to-day. The mercury ran up to 92 in the shade at 3 o'clock. In the sun at the same hour it registered 122 . It was by all odds one of the warmest days ever experienced here.

The jury in the case of Giuseppe Crifasi, who is on trial in the Court of General Sessions before Recorder Smyth for the murder of Bartholomeo Caresi, was completed at noon yesterday, and Assistant District Attorney Purdy opened for the people. He said the prisoner and Caresi had been acquainted for some time.

BOSTON, July 13.--The American Bell Telephone Company at its meeting to-day declared an extra dividend of 4 per cent., payable Aug. 15, to stockholders of record July 30. No definite action was taken upon the election of a President, but an understanding was reached that Howard Stockton is to succeed Mr. Forbes in that office as soon as the change can be effected.

After losing four successive games the New-Yorks finally won from the Pittsburgs yes terday by figures of 7 to 3. Keefe resumed his work, and although he was a trifle wild at first he settled down to good, steady, effective work, and made matters very unpleasant for the Pitts burg batsmen who are seeking big records.

A large number of perspiring gentlemen walked on the pier at the foot of West Twentysecond-street yesterday afternoon and boarded the big steamboat New-York, of the Hudson River Line, which, gayly decked in flags and bunting, was about to give them an idea of what she can do, or, in other words, to make a trial trip.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 13.--The Chief of Police of this city, with a detachment of officers, raided 30 liquor saloons to-day, seizing beer, ale, and stronger liquors in each. The Chief of the State Police had nothing to do with the raid.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 13.--Fifty priests took part to-day in the services at the funeral of the Rev. John Rogers, the oldest priest in the Diocese of Trenton, who died on Sunday. Among them were Vicar-General Smith, who acted as celebrant; Bishop O'Farrell, Mgr. Doane, Mgr. Seton, and Dean John Kelly. Three thousand persons were in the funeral procession and the same number in the church, 1,500 to 2,000 being unable to obtain entrance.

The Commissioners of Emigration held a protracted executive session yesterday afternoon at which they reconsidered their order affecting the transportation business of emigrant boarding house keepers.

LONG BRANCH, July 13.--The fastest steam yacht now afloat in American waters arrived in the Shrewsbury River this afternoon. This vessel rejoices in the unique name of Now Then, and the suggestion of the title is at once apparent. She is the property of Norman L. Munro, whose lightning steam launch Henrietta was a year ago the wonder of these waters.

The menhaden fishing, upon which large numbers of persons in several of the eastern villages of Long Island depend for their living, is said to be a failure this season, the catches by the steamers being unusually small. The factories at Long Beach and Promised Land, where the fish is converted into oil and fertilizer, are running on short time. The loss will amount to over $100,000.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13.--Five men were burned and otherwise injured by an explosion which took place about 2 o'clock this afternoon at the crude oil still works of the Atlantic Refining Company at Point Breeze. There were two explosions at the works, the first being at still No. 58, which is nearly in the centre of the works.

BOSTON, Mass., July 13.--Gen. Sheridan was in this city yesterday and to-day, and is the guest of Commodore Bateman, of the yacht Meteor. He is on his way to St. Lawrence, where he intends to take a steamer and join his family by way of Lake Champlain. On the Meteor are Gen. Robert McFeely and Col. Sheridan, brother of Gen. Sheridan.
Ewing handled the team in good style yesterday. Buffalo was beaten by Rochester, 21 to 10 yesterday at Buffalo.

There has been a good deal of talk in Wall-street lately about an expected "Gould market." Just that sort of a market arrived yesterday. Suspicions and raids, slanders and onslaughts, mysteries and tatters--the whole Gould outfit was on review. The sand bag was busy; Gould sluggers were having a high old time.

Roads showing increases are: St. Paul and Duluth, $3,332; Lake Erie and Western, $3,441, and East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia, $22,514.

Four persons alighted from a carriage at the Hotel Brunswick about 10:30 o'clock last night, and walked slowly across the broad walk. By the time they reached the door they had seen all that was easily in view up and down Fifthavenue.

Landladies on the west side are on the lookout for an old sneak thief who is got up in a manner to deceive the very elect. He is tall and corpulent and gray. His hair, which is thick and wiry, stands up and back from his high, square forehead.

District Assembly No. 75, the car drivers, held its monthly meeting all day yesterday at 207 Bowery. Like all meetings of the Knights of Labor, this was strictly a secret one, and the troubles on the various car lines in this city and Brooklyn were thoroughly discussed.
WASHINGTON, July 14.--Major Edward B. Williston, Third Artillery, has been ordered to duty at Troy, N.Y. First Lieut. F.V. Walker, Assistant Surgeon, has been granted four months' leave of absence.

Ellen Carey, the wife of a cripple, Timothy Carey, living at Tenth-avenue and One Hundred and Fortieth-street, committed suicide yesterday morning by taking a dose of rat poison.

DETROIT, Mich., July 14.--An oil war is steadily developing in this city. Last December the Standard Oil Company, through its local agents, inaugurated the tank system of delivery in Detroit. Schurmer, Scofield Co., through their Detroit house, followed suit.

The golden-rod is in copious bloom along the railroad tracks, and the blue succory by every roadside. And yet the cyclopoedias say of these flowers that they "bloom in August and September." If they are precursors of the Autumn, must we expect snow in September? The fact is that the wild flowers and berries are all in advance of the season this year.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 14.--A very slim crowd saw the Metropolitans drub the Louisvilles unmercifully to-day. Hecker officiated in the box for the locals, and was supported behind the bat in superb style by Amos Cross, who has been ill for a greater portion of the season.

SHELBYVILLE, Ill., July 15.--James Tolly, an eccentric farmer, had $1,500 stolen from his house by burglars recently. The burglars overlooked $20,000 in coin. HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 15.--The steam yacht Meteor arrived here this morning, having on board Gen. Sherman and party. The General came ashore about 10 o'clock, and after sending off some telegrams drove about the city with Consul General Phelan. The yacht left this evening for Bay Chaleur.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 15.--The weather continues favorable, but the arrivals at the hotels are few.

CHICAGO, July 15.--A great gathering of boating men from all sections of the country was at Pullman to-day to witness the opening of the Mississippi Valley Rowing Association's annual regatta.

KEY WEST, Fla., July 15.--There have been seven new cases of fever since yesterday and no deaths. Nearly all the 27 new cases reported during the last three days have been children who are passing through au acclimating sickness without fatal results, and should not fairly be reported in a record of the epidemic without explanation.
The Earl of Aberdeen waS visited at the Hotel Brunswick last night by delegations from various Scotch and Irish organizations, who presented addresses, to which the Earl responded pleasantly.

MONTREAL, July 15.--The St. Lawrence Sugar Refinery was burned to the ground this morning. The night shift of 150 men was just preparing to leave work about 6:30 A.M., when the alarm was raised, and before the men could realize their position the flames swept through the place like a resistless stream.

An inquest in the case of Samuel Roth, who died at the Ward's Island Insane Asylum under suspicious circumstances on June 25, began yesterday morning before Coroner Eidmann and a jury. The first witness was Dr. Alexander Trautman, Medical Superintendent of the asylum.

For more years than she cares to think about the Goddess of Justice has rested in graceful pose on the dome of the City Hall. Her position in semi-celestial society has been an assured one, if somewhat lonely, and the only troubles she has had to contend against were the English sparrows and the ravages of time.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15.--J.C. Poulterer Co., iron commission merchants, at 214 South Fourthstreet, have failed, with liabilities amounting to about $15,000. It is said that the failure was caused by the embarrassment of several iron manufacturing companies in this State, one of which owes the firm a large amount for raw material.

STERLING, Col., July 15.--The drought report is doing Eastern Colorado considerable damage. Two heavy rainstorms have visited the locality during the past week. The crops and vegetation of all kinds are looking remarkably well owing to the late heavy rains. Farmers all over the country report flattering prospects.

LARAMIE CITY, Wyoming, July 15.--Mr. Augustin Daly's company was detained over 18 hours on their trip between Denver and San Francisco by the cloudburst which occurred on Thursday afternoon near Cheyenne, on the Union Pacific Railroad. The company played "Taming the Shrew" at Denver to an immense audience at opera prices, and will open at San Francisco on Monday in "Love in Harness".

WASHINGTON, July 15.--It is a singular fact that while the two houses of Congress, in providing the annual appropriations, diligently search through the departments to cut down expenditures, they never exercise their pruning knives upon those about the Capitol.

There are vacancies for 10 boys at the Burnham Industrial Farm, and these are to be filled from this city and Kings County. The pressure of applications for places on the farm is very great, and only 10 most promising boys will be taken to fill these vacancies.

LONDON, July 15.--Mr. Abington's colt Juggler, by Touchet, out of Enchantress, won the Kempton Park Grand Two-year-old Stakes today, beating Simon Pure, Pull Together, and four others. The race was at five furlongs, and Juggler was the favorite in the betting at 2 to 1 against him.

WHITE EARTH, Minn., July 11.--About 20 years ago the Chippewas were removed from Red Wing to this reservation under a treaty, the full provisions of which I have forgotten. At Red Wing the Indians had become thoroughly demoralized.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 15.--A man who gave the name of Harry Harris, Harry Fell, and Harry Luster, was sent to the county jail to-day, to await trial on a charge of robbery.

ST. LOUIS, MO., July 15.--The Sunday baseball test case was tried to-day before Judge Noonan, and Von Der Ahe won the case. The defense admitted all the State's evidence.

The Eighth Regiment will disport itself at Company H's picnic at Sulzer's Harlem River Park Thursday night.

Alfred Sully is planning a trip down South for the latter part of this month, accompanied by a few genial friends. The excursion primarily is for pleasure and recreation, Mr. Sully having tied himself down like a slave to work for months and months past; but, as usual, when he rests there will be a pretty big percentage of genuine labor in the trip ahead.
BOSTON, July 16.--H.S. Briggs, General Appraiser at the Custom House, has been requested to resign. It is stated that H.T. Kitfield, a Democrat, will take his place.

NYACK, N.Y., July 16.--Nyack is greatly excited to-day at the probably successful result of a carefully formed plan to throw light upon a long series of burglaries which have occurred, not only in this place but also in nearly every village along the Hudson River. For some time past it has been the opinion of many prominent hotel men in this State that an organized association for the protection and furtherance of their interests would be a desirable thing. This feeling seems about to be realized in a convention of hotel men from all over the State, to be held at Saratoga Springs next Thursday.

CINCINNATI, July 16.--The Commercial Gazette is in receipt of letters from nearly all the counties of the State, relative to the preferences of active members of the Democratic Party as to a candidate for Governor at the coming election and a candidate for President next year.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, July 16.--Sitting on piazzas, lying in the shade of the rocks, or plunged in the cooling waters of old ocean the guests of Narragansett Pier have been able to laugh at the sun for the past few days as it worked itself into a perspiration trying to get the mercury higher and higher each succeeding day.
